lead_paragraph: See which states have challenges seeking to bar Donald J. Trump from the presidential primary ballot.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Jenny Odell, Deepti Kapoor, Leila Philip and more.
lead_paragraph: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Jenny Odell, Deepti Kapoor, Leila Philip and more.

headline: Hamas Used Gaza Hospital as a Command Center, U.S. Intelligence Says
abstract: Israeli forces stormed the site in November, drawing intense international scrutiny and criticism.
lead_paragraph: U.S. spy agencies believe that Hamas and another Palestinian group fighting Israel used Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza to command forces and hold some hostages, according to new American intelligence declassified on Tuesday.

headline: Epstein Documents Naming Prominent Figures Expected to Be Released Soon
abstract: The documents, related to a lawsuit involving Ghislaine Maxwell, an associate of the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, are anticipated to include names previously redacted.
lead_paragraph: Court documents related to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein are expected to be released soon with many names that were previously redacted, and prominent figures on the right are holding up the impending disclosures as evidence of wrongdoing by Democrats despite a lack of concrete information about what they will show.

headline: Day 3: How to Eat for Better Energy
abstract: Today you’ll tune in to how food makes you feel.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 3 of the 6-Day Energy Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.

headline: How a Proxy Fight Over Campus Politics Brought Down Harvard’s President
abstract: Amid plagiarism allegations and a backlash to campus antisemitism, Claudine Gay became an avatar for broader criticisms of academia.
lead_paragraph: The resignation of Harvard’s president, Claudine Gay, on Tuesday followed a lengthening catalog of plagiarism allegations that appeared to steadily sap her support among the university’s faculty, students and alumni. But for many of Dr. Gay’s critics, her departure was also a proxy victory in the escalating ideological battle over American higher education.

headline: Tours de Force
abstract: Jared Goudsmit finds a shortcut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Court Rules Texas Can Ban Emergency Abortions Despite Federal Guidance
abstract: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed a ruling that sided with the state on whether emergency rooms are required to perform emergency abortions.
lead_paragraph: Emergency room doctors in Texas are not required to perform emergency abortions despite federal guidance that requires hospitals to offer stabilizing care, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Big Bet on a Pyramid Brings Signs of a Revival to San Francisco
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Downtown has often felt stuffy and stiff, the place where people stuck in offices go. This is 2023’s version of what makes San Francisco cool and interesting.”

headline: ‘Fargo’ Season 5, Episode 8 Recap: Rude Awakenings
abstract: Dot learns some harsh truths about her past and present. Danish takes an ill-advised trip to North Dakota.
lead_paragraph: When Dot was kidnapped early in the season and then she simply returned home as if nothing had happened, it was absurd on its face. No one, other than Wayne, could believe that she had stepped out for a while and come back in time to whisk up some Bisquick for their daughter. And even though she knew that her abductors would lay siege to the house again, she was determined to enjoy Halloween with her family, even as she laid out booby traps like Dustin Hoffman in “Straw Dogs.” She’s the sort of determined fantasist who believes she can bend reality to her will.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 3, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 29 about the Republican presidential candidate Nikki Haley not mentioning slavery as a cause of the Civil War omitted the given name of a billionaire co-founder of LinkedIn and a major Democratic donor who gave $250,000 to a super PAC supporting Ms. Haley. He is Reid Hoffman.

headline: Trump Makes Another Pitch to Appeals Court on Immunity in Election Case
abstract: The filing was the last step before an appeals court in Washington will hold a hearing on the crucial issue next week.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday made their final written request to a federal appeals court to grant Mr. Trump immunity to charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election, arguing the indictment should be tossed out because it arose from actions he took while in the White House.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: The killing of a Hamas leader.
lead_paragraph: The deputy head of Hamas, Saleh al-Arouri, and two leaders of its armed wing were killed in an explosion in Lebanon that the group attributed to Israel. Israel has refused to discuss the matter, but two senior U.S. officials said that Israel was responsible for the strike.

headline: Military ‘Practice Bomb’ Washes Ashore in California
abstract: The munition, which was carried to shore by the rough surf that battered the state last week, was found on New Year’s Eve.
lead_paragraph: The massive waves that pounded California’s coast last week washed ashore trash, driftwood and something unexpected: a very old bomb, rusted over and covered with debris.

headline: Abrupt Dismissals Point to Xi Jinping’s Quiet Shake-Up of China’s Military
abstract: The purge of several commanders from China’s legislature was the latest sign of widening investigations focused on the sensitive arms sector, experts say.
lead_paragraph: The expelled officials included some of the brightest rising stars in President Xi Jinping’s military: two generals who oversaw satellite launches and manned space missions; an admiral who helped entrench Beijing’s presence in the disputed South China Sea; and a missile commander who had honed China’s ability to respond to a possible nuclear war.

headline: Hamas blames Israel for the death of a senior official in Lebanon.
abstract: Israel and the surrounding region were on edge Wednesday, a day after the assassination of a top Hamas leader in Lebanon heightened worries that the war in Gaza could spill over into a broader conflict.
lead_paragraph: Israel and the surrounding region were on edge Wednesday, a day after the assassination of a top Hamas leader in Lebanon heightened worries that the war in Gaza could spill over into a broader conflict.

headline: Word of the Day: dhow
abstract: This word has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word dhow has appeared in three articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 5 in “U.S. Sent Munitions Seized From Iran to Ukraine” by Eric Schmitt:

headline: A Doctors’ Strike Sets Back England’s Crisis-Ridden National Health Service
abstract: The young doctors’ walkout could result in numerous canceled medical visits and surgical procedures, undoing recent progress in cutting wait times.
lead_paragraph: For Queen’s Hospital, a beleaguered big-city hospital east of London, the past year has been a slow, but steady, campaign to cut back waiting times in its crowded emergency room. Then, on Wednesday, junior doctors walked off the job in England, triggering a cascade of canceled appointments and surgeries — a fresh obstacle for Queen’s, and for Britain’s crisis-ridden National Health Service.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: From the Pilates Studio to a Cadaver Dissection Lab
abstract: Small talk at an exercise class led one reporter to explore why fitness professionals are seeking out cadaver workshops.
lead_paragraph: Six months ago, I was limbering up at my local Pilates studio when a conversation with my instructor stopped me midstretch.

headline: Healthy Habits
abstract: What small things do you do to take care of your body and mind?
lead_paragraph: It’s the start of the new year, a time when many recommit to healthy habits. But instead of asking you what you’d like to start doing, we’re asking what you already do to make yourself feel better.

headline: When Will New York Solve Its Housing Crisis? Probably Not This Year.
abstract: As the state’s legislative session gets underway, the politicians who could fix the problem face big hurdles.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like 2023 would be the year New York did something big to help solve its housing crisis.

headline: How to Declutter Your Dating Life
abstract: Overwhelmed by apps, profiles and not-quite-matches? Here’s how to start the new year fresh.
lead_paragraph: If you are on the dating scene in 2024, you have likely accumulated a certain amount of clutter. Maybe it’s an outdated online profile that you can’t bring yourself to overhaul, or a match you keep messaging despite not seeing a future together. Perhaps you’re still haunted by someone who ghosted you.

headline: Read Your Way Through Utah
abstract: Utah is a place of paradoxes, full of terrible beauty and complicated history. The writer Terry Tempest Williams recommends books to help you explore the state’s many facets.
lead_paragraph: Be forewarned: Utah is a state of mind, and the state of mind you adopt will determine the books you will want to read. As Brigham Young, the Mormon colonizer, said, “This is the place.” That invites the follow-up question: The place for what?

headline: Tales of the Black Underworld Fuel Hip-Hop. His Feed Recounts Them.
abstract: ValTown, an account on X and other social media platforms, spotlights gangs and drug kingpins of the 1980s and 1990s — and how crime and celebrity often intersect.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in the late 2010s, Brian Valmond started shining a light on stories that are often shaded by secrecy, exaggeration, self-protection and self-aggrandizing.

headline: It’s Time for America to Go Back to Afghanistan
abstract: Since the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan, Washington has isolated the Taliban, a tactic that backfired the last time the group was in power.
lead_paragraph: It’s striking how much Afghanistan, which has the unfortunate legacy of being the site of America’s longest war, has all but disappeared from public discussion in the United States. But perhaps it’s understandable. After all, there always seems to be another conflict, another war — which, as it happens, is also Afghanistan’s history.

headline: Would You Pay $1,800 for a Facial?
abstract: Lifting and sculpting facials, once a secret of the rich or famous, are trickling into the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Candice Miller is 42 and clinging to the millimeter of volume that held up her smile lines and cheekbones in her 30s. Once a week, unless she’s traveling, she goes to Aida Bicaj, a spa on the Upper East Side where the well-heeled get their faces lifted, tightened, de-puffed and brightened.

headline: How Charles Darwin Found Inspiration on the Cape Verde Islands
abstract: Most travelers following in Darwin’s footsteps go to the Galápagos. But it was here, on a rocky island off the coast of West Africa, that the young naturalist was said to have found his calling.
lead_paragraph: Charles Darwin was 22 years old when he first peeled a banana. “Maukish & sweet with little flavor,” he noted in his journal from Santiago, the main island in the Cape Verde archipelago off the coast of West Africa. He preferred oranges and tamarinds, feasting at every opportunity on tropical fruit after three awful weeks at sea.

headline: ‘The Color Purple’ Tips Its Hat to Classic Black Musicals
abstract: The new movie has so many references to Hollywood gems like “Stormy Weather” and early jazz shorts, it can be viewed as a Black film syllabus.
lead_paragraph: Even when Hollywood saw little use for Black performers other than as mammies and butlers, the musical genre, a storytelling mode composed of magical realist fantasy and hoofing artistry, provided space for Cab Calloway, Lena Horne and Dorothy Dandridge to manifest their glamorous glow. Through rapturous songs, sung in resplendent gowns and tailored tuxedos, the promise of Black liberation was heard.

headline: Should Patients Be Allowed to Die From Anorexia?
abstract: Treatment wasn’t helping her anorexia, so doctors allowed her to stop — no matter the consequences. But is a “palliative” approach to mental illness really ethical?
lead_paragraph: The doctors told Naomi that she could not leave the hospital. She was lying in a narrow bed at Denver Health Medical Center. Someone said something about a judge and a court order. Someone used the phrase “gravely disabled.” Naomi did not think she was gravely disabled. Still, she decided not to fight it. She could deny that she was mentally incompetent — but this would probably just be taken as proof of her mental incompetence. Of her lack of insight. She would, instead, “succumb to it.”

headline: Want a New You in the New Year? Try Committing to the Bit.
abstract: Personalities are cool. Personas are cooler.
lead_paragraph: You know those wellness drinks that advertise active cultures for gut health, adaptogens, ashwagandha, L-theanine with 25mg of full-spectrum CBD, with added charcoal? I admire them. Not because of how they taste (fine) or what they do (nothing), but because of the ridiculous ingredients on the labels. They’re thrilling, the way a stranger looking you dead in the eye and handing you a multivitamin at a rave is thrilling, and they’re just sitting there at your corner store, right next to the eggs and butter. It’s a little odd, and embarrassing, and — this is important — funny how compelled I am to spend $6.99 to drink a cold brew with added collagen and something called Brain Octane Oil.

headline: I Left My Faith. God Didn’t Flinch.
abstract: Even though I am no longer observant, my religious upbringing is still essential to me. I love ancient Jewish texts and Orthodox deep cuts.
lead_paragraph: The first time I intentionally broke a Jewish law, I was in college. It was a Saturday. I glanced around furtively, though I was alone in my dorm room. Then I flicked off the light, an act forbidden on the Sabbath. I flicked it on again. Around me, in the bright quiet, I exhaled.

headline: Waiting for Snow in the Netherlands
abstract: The Elfstedentocht, the Dutch skating race through the 11 historic cities of Friesland, hasn’t been held in 26 years. But nobody can admit that it’s gone.
lead_paragraph: Long before I knew his name, I knew Hendrick Avercamp’s paintings. They show a merry Christmassy world of funnily dressed people disporting themselves on frozen canals: paintings I knew from jigsaw puzzles and holiday cards. Here was a young couple gliding over the ice, love in their eyes; there were people exercising picturesque professions — a skate sharpener, a bird catcher, a chestnut seller.

headline: ‘It’s State Propaganda’: Ukrainians Shun TV News as War Drags on
abstract: A government-approved news program intended to counter Russian disinformation and boost morale is coming under criticism for painting a rosy picture of the war.
lead_paragraph: Since the early days of Russia’s full-scale invasion in 2022, the people of Ukraine have had access to a single source of television news — an all-day broadcast packed with footage of Ukrainian tanks blasting Russian positions, medics operating near the frontline and political leaders rallying support abroad.

headline: They Can’t All Be Nominated for Best Picture, Can They?
abstract: It’s a very competitive year for the top Oscar. With precursor awards like the Golden Globes coming soon, here’s what may make the cut.
lead_paragraph: The good news is that it’s been a great year for movies.

headline: Love for a Librarian Who Helps Immigrants
abstract: Fred Gitner, who runs programs for migrants at the Queens Public Library, is one of 10 librarians to receive an American Library Association award.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll meet a librarian who has been recognized for work with migrants in Queens. And we’ll look at the legal issues as the National Rifle Association goes on trial in Manhattan.

headline: Do You Ever Feel Envious of Others?
abstract: What role does envy play in your life? Can the oft-shamed emotion be beneficial?
lead_paragraph: Do you ever compare yourself with others — peers, friends, family, celebrities, people on social media? Do you ever wish you had something someone else has, such as their status, success or talent?

headline: How a Maui Local Makes Sashimi Extra Special
abstract: Hamachi gets a surprising lift from sweet onions in a ponzu sauce.
lead_paragraph: The first blaze was reported in the early hours of Aug. 8, rasping through the brush on the slopes of Haleakala on Maui. Then flames appeared along a road in Lahaina, on the island’s western shore. By afternoon, the government had called a state of emergency. By nightfall, fires were raging across thousands of acres, and Lahaina, once the capital of the Hawaiian kingdom, was lost.

headline: $825,000 Homes in South Carolina, Oregon and Pennsylvania
abstract: An island retreat in Charleston County, a midcentury-modern home in Portland and an early 19th-century rowhouse in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: This house is on James Island, about a 20-minute drive from the dining and nightlife in downtown Charleston. It is about a five-minute drive from a Publix supermarket, a brewery, a gym, a public library and James Island Elementary School. James Island Charter High School is 10 minutes away.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Strata-East Records
abstract: This label founded in 1971 gave Afrocentric and psychedelic jazz a home, and found a breakout hit with Gil Scott-Heron and Brian Jackson. Take a guided tour through its deep catalog.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been asking writers, musicians and scholars to tell us what songs they’d play to get people into jazz. This month, we decided to highlight a record label: Strata-East Records, founded in 1971 by the trumpeter Charles Tolliver and the pianist Stanley Cowell.

headline: Ramaswamy Is Still Sprinting Across Iowa, While His Polling Barely Moves
abstract: The 38-year-old entrepreneur has maintained a grueling schedule, but questions about the goals of his candidacy are mounting with less than two weeks before the caucuses.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy tore across eastern Iowa on Tuesday at the breakneck pace that has come to define his long-shot presidential campaign.

headline: Watch the First Meteor Shower of 2024 Reach Its Peak
abstract: The Quadrantids are forecast to be one of the year’s strongest showers, but they can be difficult to actually spot.
lead_paragraph: Our universe might be chock-full of cosmic wonder, but you can only observe a fraction of astronomical phenomena with your naked eye. Meteor showers, natural fireworks that streak brightly across the night sky, are one of them.

headline: If You’re Under 30, How Does Politics Affect Your Dating Life?
abstract: Young women say they’re more liberal, young men say they’re more conservative. How much does it matter?
lead_paragraph: There’s been a good deal of worry over the last year about the future of marriage in the United States. For those who see marriage as pivotal to a thriving society, there’s reason for concern: According to a report last year from Pew Research, as of 2021, a quarter of 40-year-olds had never been married, a “record-high share,” up from 20 percent in 2010.

headline: Could Nikki Haley Actually Do It?
abstract: Iowa and New Hampshire may soon make Donald Trump the unofficial G.O.P. presidential nominee. But could Nikki Haley pull off a surprise?
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy: Katherine, the Iowa caucuses are 12 days away — the first chance some Americans will have to vote again for Donald Trump or decide if they want to go in a different direction. Trump has a lead of roughly 30 percentage points in several Iowa polls over Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley. What do you see driving the race in Iowa right now? Can anything stop Trump?

headline: Biden Plans 2 Campaign Speeches to Underscore Contrasts With Trump
abstract: The president will speak at Valley Forge on the anniversary of the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, and later at a South Carolina church where a white supremacist killed nine people.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is intensifying his campaign efforts as he looks toward November, planning a series of speeches that aides said on Wednesday would cast the stakes of the coming election as the endurance of American democracy itself.

headline: Johnson Visits Border, Turning Up Heat on Biden for an Immigration Deal
abstract: The visit by the speaker and scores of House Republicans came as the G.O.P. seeks to increase pressure on President Biden and Democrats to agree to severe new border policies.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans threatened on Wednesday to starve the entire federal government of funding if President Biden and Democrats fail to institute a crackdown at the U.S.-Mexico border to choke off the flow of migrants streaming into the country.

headline: Vital Crossing Between Mexico and Arizona Set to Reopen This Week
abstract: The border crossing in a remote Arizona community was a passage for thousands of workers, families and businesses in the region who relied on it every day.
lead_paragraph: A remote Arizona border crossing that was shuttered last month to help strained immigration authorities cope with a surge in migrants in the nearby desert will reopen this week, U.S. Customs and Border Protection said on Tuesday evening.

headline: Ohio Woman Who Miscarried Faces Charge That She Abused Corpse
abstract: In a case that has drawn international attention, a grand jury in Ohio is considering whether to indict a woman who miscarried at home and disposed of the nonviable fetus.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury in Ohio is considering whether to indict a woman who miscarried a nonviable fetus at home and has been charged with abuse of a corpse in what experts say is an extremely rare interpretation of a state law.

headline: ‘World’s Oldest Pyramid’ in Indonesia? A Study Draws Skepticism
abstract: The study, under investigation by its publisher, has fueled a dispute over the age of a partially excavated site and prompted warnings about the dangers of nationalist mythmaking.
lead_paragraph: In a mountainous corner of Indonesia lies a hill, dotted with stone terraces, where people come from around the country to hold Islamic and Hindu rituals. Some say the site has a mystical air, or even that it might hold buried treasure.

headline: Knife Attack on Opposition Leader Raises Alarms in Polarized South Korea
abstract: The attack on Lee Jae-myung, who narrowly lost the 2022 presidential vote, came amid a deepening political divide and increasingly extreme discourse in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of stabbing Lee Jae-myung, the leader of South Korea’s main opposition party, in the neck had been stalking him in recent weeks, including attending a political event where Mr. Lee was present on Dec. 13, apparently captured on video there wearing a blue paper crown, the police say.

headline: Will America’s Good News on Inflation Last?
abstract: One of the biggest economic surprises of 2023 was how quickly inflation faded. A dig into the details offers hints at whether it will last into 2024.
lead_paragraph: Prices climbed rapidly in 2021 and 2022, straining American household budgets and chipping away at President Biden’s approval rating. But inflation cooled in late 2023, a spurt of progress that happened more quickly than economists had expected and that stoked hopes of a gentle economic landing.

headline: Resolution Refresh:
abstract: Three strategies for making your New Year’s resolutions less punishing and more nourishing
lead_paragraph: The Times deputy editor of Culture and Lifestyle, Melissa Kirsch, has spent many years thinking about innovative ways to approach the New Year’s resolution. Here she shares three of her favorite strategies for making your resolutions more achievable and more fun.

headline: Biden’s 2024 Playbook
abstract: The achievements of President Biden’s first term seem so far to be providing little help to his re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, we went inside Donald Trump’s campaign for president, to understand how he’s trying to turn a mountain of legal trouble into a political advantage. Today, we turn to the re-election campaign of President Biden.

headline: Top Hamas Official Is Killed, and Harvard President Resigns
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The New Campus Politics
abstract: The resignation of Harvard’s president shows how the Hamas attacks have scrambled campus politics.
lead_paragraph: For the third time in less than a year, the president of a top U.S. university has resigned under pressure. The details differ, but all three cases highlight the ways that the country’s political polarization is roiling elite campuses. These campuses are overwhelmingly liberal, among both professors and students, and have increasingly become targets of criticism from conservatives and some moderates.

headline: Al-Arouri’s killing is a blow to Hamas, though likely not a debilitating one, analysts say.
abstract: The killing of Saleh al-Arouri deprives Hamas of one of its most skilled tacticians, who helped route money and weapons to its operatives in Gaza and elsewhere in the Middle East and integrated the group more tightly into Iran’s network of forces committed to fighting Israel, according to analysts.
lead_paragraph: The killing of Saleh al-Arouri deprives Hamas of one of its most skilled tacticians, who helped route money and weapons to its operatives in Gaza and elsewhere in the Middle East and integrated the group more tightly into Iran’s network of forces committed to fighting Israel, according to analysts.

headline: As Flames Surged, Order Prevailed Inside a Japan Airlines Jet
abstract: In addition to a well-trained crew and an advanced plane, the safe evacuation of 367 passengers came down to a relative absence of panic.
lead_paragraph: As smoke filled the cabin of Japan Airlines Flight 516 after its fiery landing in Tokyo on Tuesday, the sound of a child’s voice rose above the din of confusion onboard. “Please, let us off quickly!” the child pleaded, using a polite form of Japanese despite the fear washing over the passengers as flight attendants began shouting instructions.

headline: Harvard’s Governance Dilemma
abstract: The resignation of Claudine Gay as Harvard’s president reopens the debate over who should run America’s elite universities.
lead_paragraph: The resignation yesterday of Claudine Gay, Harvard’s first Black president and the second woman to lead the university, was tied to a mounting crisis over plagiarism allegations. But she had also been under fire for months over what critics said was an insufficient response to the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks on Israel.

headline: Bombing in Iran Kills Over 100, Sowing Confusion and Speculation
abstract: No one claimed responsibility for the bombing at a memorial for Qassim Suleimani, the top commander killed by a U.S. drone strike four years ago.
lead_paragraph: A pair of explosions on Wednesday at a memorial for Iran’s former top general, Qassim Suleimani, killed at least 103 people and wounded an additional 211, according to Iranian officials, sowing fear in a country where domestic unrest and the prospect of a spiraling regional war have left many on edge.

headline: My Friend Offered to Dogsit, Then Backed Out When Her Mother Died. Now What?
abstract: A reader is left wondering how to patch things up with irked neighbors after an understandably preoccupied friend left the reader’s dog alone to bark all night.
lead_paragraph: I visited my family overseas for three weeks. It was our first Christmas together in 10 years. A close friend offered to take my dog while I was away. During the first week, my friend’s mother died. I offered to make other arrangements for my dog, but she said it wasn’t necessary. By the second week, she was struggling. She asked if she could return the dog to my house and visit twice a day. I asked another person to help her so my dog would get more visits and my friend could deal with her loss. Then, my neighbors complained that my dog was barking all night. I asked my close friend to spend one night at my house. She declined and insinuated that I was to blame for the situation. Her inability to commit has caused a rift with my neighbors. How can I remedy the problem with the neighbors? (I’m OK just moving on with my friend and not accepting offers of help from her again.)

headline: California’s Snowpack Is Far Below Normal Levels for Early January
abstract: Warmer weather is dumping more precipitation as rain instead of snow.
lead_paragraph: California’s wet season is off to a relatively slow start, despite El Niño conditions that often mean a rainy winter.

headline: Frick Leader to Step Down After a 14-Year Run
abstract: Having seen the museum’s controversial renovation through to completion, Ian Wardropper plans to retire in 2025.
lead_paragraph: After 14 years running the Frick Collection, during which this art museum finally realized a controversial expansion of its Gilded Age mansion on Fifth Avenue — and temporarily took up residence in the modernist Breuer building on Madison Avenue — its director, Ian Wardropper, said he would retire next year.

headline: It’s 2024, and the Candidates Are Campaigning at a Furious Pace
abstract: The Iowa caucuses are less than two weeks away. The candidates challenging Donald J. Trump hope a strong showing will lead to consolidated support.
lead_paragraph: Twelve days. Not that we’re counting.

headline: 3 Tips for More Energy
abstract: Do you want to have more energy as you go about your day? The answer is probably yes.
lead_paragraph: Do you want to have more energy as you go about your day? The answer is probably yes.

headline: Study Aims to Bring a Tinier Tyrannosaur Back From Oblivion
abstract: New research is trying to remake the case that fossils known as Nanotyrannus were their own species, rather than a teenage Tyrannosaurus rex.
lead_paragraph: It is only 23 inches long, but one tyrannosaur skull has been a bone of serious contention among paleontologists for decades.

headline: In Detroit, an Opera Leader Finishes With One Last Triumph
abstract: Wayne Brown, who recently retired, started his career in Detroit before returning there to run a transformed Detroit Opera.
lead_paragraph: After Yuval Sharon became the artistic director of Michigan Opera Theater in 2020, the company renamed itself the Detroit Opera — perhaps the most visible among moves that have led to a remarkable streak of successes based on a new, ambitious approach.

headline: The Word That Undid Claudine Gay
abstract: The fate of Harvard’s president is the latest evidence of a deep crisis in American academia.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect, Claudine Gay’s fate was sealed by a single word. (She resigned the presidency of Harvard on Tuesday, just six months into her tenure.) It wasn’t “plagiarism” or “genocide” — the fearsome fighting words most publicly associated with her case — but rather a careful, neutral piece of language that struck some listeners as outrageous for precisely that reason: an attempt at anti-inflammatory rhetoric that had the opposite effect. The word was “context.”

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Local News Outlets
abstract: What is the current state of local journalism?
lead_paragraph: This graph was previously published in a New York Times Opinion article about the decline in the number of local news outlets (newspapers, local digital sites, public radio newsrooms or ethnic publications) in the United States. As of 2023, of the 3,143 counties in the United States, there are 204 counties with no news outlets and 1,562 counties with only one outlet. Areas with insufficient news coverage are called “news deserts.”

headline: These Books Will Help Heal Your Relationship With Food
abstract: We asked experts in psychology, nutrition and body image for their top picks.
lead_paragraph: How is your relationship with food these days? For many of us, the honest answer is “it’s complicated.” Perhaps you stress-eat more than you’d care to admit or are always on the latest diet. Maybe you just spend too much mental energy on food and have a nagging sense that it’s supposed to be, well, easier.

headline: Four Children Die in Connecticut House Fire
abstract: The young children, who were all in the same family, lived in Somers, Conn. The family next door escaped physically unhurt.
lead_paragraph: Four children in one family died in a fast-moving fire that swept through their Connecticut home on Tuesday night. An older sibling, who is an adult, survived after jumping out of a second-floor window, fire officials said.

headline: Imam Is Fatally Shot Outside New Jersey Mosque
abstract: The shooting took place around the time of predawn prayers in Newark. The gunman remained at large.
lead_paragraph: An imam was shot and killed outside a New Jersey mosque early Wednesday, the authorities said.

headline: An Easy, Quick, One-Pot Meatless Pasta, Because January
abstract: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s creamy one-pot mushroom and leek pasta comes with a reader warning: “You can’t stop eating this!”
lead_paragraph: Now that the holidays are winding down and our regular workweek is revving back up again, the stakes for dinners at our house have risen even higher. Dinner is one thing we can reliably look forward to every day, so it ought to be delicious. But that’s not always easy. We’re talking about January after all, when we’re tired, busy and maybe struggling to keep our resolutions, culinary and otherwise.

headline: Britain’s Newest Sports Sensation Is a 16-Year-Old Darts Player
abstract: When Luke Littler isn’t playing Xbox, he’s winning thousands of pounds against the world’s best players. On Wednesday, he played in the world championship final.
lead_paragraph: The classic image of a darts game is a friendly contest in a smoky pub filled with middle-aged men holding pint glasses.

headline: Boy, 13, Is Believed to Be the First to ‘Beat’ Tetris
abstract: Willis Gibson, a competitive Tetris player prodigy from Oklahoma, advanced so far in the original Nintendo version of the game that it froze. “I can’t feel my fingers,” he said afterward.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 21, Willis Gibson, 13, put his hands to his head and rocked back and forth in an office chair in his bedroom in Stillwater, Okla., unable to believe what he had just accomplished.

headline: Leader’s Killing Is a Blow, but Not a Knockout, for Hamas
abstract: The killing of Saleh al-Arouri, a key Hamas strategist, in Lebanon sets the organization back at a vulnerable time. The group has rebuilt after the assassination of other leaders, though.
lead_paragraph: The killing of Saleh al-Arouri, a top Hamas leader, on Tuesday deprives the group of one of its most skilled tacticians, who helped route money and weapons to its operatives in the Gaza Strip and elsewhere in the Middle East and integrated Hamas more tightly into Iran’s network of forces committed to fighting Israel, according to analysts.

headline: As Literacy Lags, Hochul Proposes Changing How Schools Teach Reading
abstract: New York has lost ground in reading performance. The governor is proposing changes to literacy education to address that.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul proposed on Wednesday a major shift in education policy that could transform the way many schools teach reading across New York, following the lead of other states that have jettisoned methods experts say have left millions of children behind.

headline: Maurice Hines, Tap-Dancing Star With His Brother, Dies at 80
abstract: He rose to stardom in an act with Gregory Hines and also performed on and off Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Maurice Hines, a high-wattage song-and-dance man who rose to stardom as a child in a tap-dancing act with his brother, Gregory, then performed on and off Broadway, including in shows he directed and choreographed, died on Friday in Englewood, N.J. He was 80.

headline: Auto Sales Are Expected to Slow After a Strong 2023
abstract: Automakers sold more cars in 2023 than a year ago as supply chain chaos ended, but sales are now under pressure from higher interest rates.
lead_paragraph: After enjoying a strong rebound in sales in 2023, the auto industry appears headed for slower growth this year as consumers struggle with elevated interest rates and high prices for new cars and light trucks.

headline: I Just Learned My Son Is a Webcam Model. Should I Be Troubled?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on a sensational side gig — and the shame associated with sex work.
lead_paragraph: My son, who is in his early 20s, is a college student. He lives on his own, on a modest but ample budget. I have just found out that my son is a “model” on a pornographic streaming service. My initial reaction was shock, revulsion and shame. But the longer I think about it, the more I wonder, is there really anything immoral or otherwise wrong about what he is doing? He does it from the privacy of his home, alone, and seems to earn a substantial amount of money. If he likes what he does, is there any reason on my part to feel alarmed, ashamed, guilty or worried?  — R.P.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in January
abstract: Sofia Vergara’s narco queenpin miniseries and a crypto documentary highlight this month’s slate.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of January’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: At a Revamped Under the Radar, New York Greets a ‘Global Downtown’
abstract: No longer at the Public, the annual celebration of experimental theater disperses 17 productions across the city. About half are international works that are getting harder to import.
lead_paragraph: The writer and performer Inua Ellams was born in Nigeria, is based in England and performs internationally. “As an immigrant, I’m most comfortable when I’m not at home,” he said during a recent conversation. “To go to another country and see if my concepts still stand the test of artistry, that’s what I love doing.”

headline: A Hapless Robber, Exposed by a Cloud of Dye, Gets His Day in Court
abstract: Nobody disputed that the defendant had handed over a note demanding money — please — from a Newark bank. The only remaining question: How dangerous had he been, really?
lead_paragraph: The man left the bank like a satisfied customer who hadn’t just robbed it. With an envelope of cash smoldering in his right pocket, he began walking down a Newark street with studied nonchalance.

headline: Eddie Bernice Johnson, Trailblazer in Congress and Beyond, Dies at 89
abstract: A Texas Democrat, she broke barriers in nursing and her state’s legislature before serving 15 terms in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Bernice Johnson, who blazed a trail as a Black woman in health care and government, first as a nurse in Dallas, then as the first Black state senator from the city since Reconstruction and then in 15 terms in the U.S. House of Representatives, died on Sunday. She was 89.

headline: Mixtapes, T-Shirts and Even a Typeface Measure the Rise of Hip-Hop
abstract: New books collecting objects central to rap’s physical history demonstrate the importance of celebrating these relics before they vanish.
lead_paragraph: For the last year, celebrations of hip-hop’s first five decades have attempted to capture the genre in full, but some early stars and scenes all but disappeared long before anyone came looking to fete them. Three excellent books published in recent months take up the task of cataloging hip-hop’s relics, the objects that embody its history, before they slip away.

headline: First Case of Lethal Bird Flu in Polar Bears Reported in Alaska
abstract: Tissue samples from a polar bear that was found dead have tested positive for the virus.
lead_paragraph: A highly lethal form of bird flu that has been spreading across the world has now been detected in a dead polar bear in Alaska. It is the first known case in the Arctic animals, which are listed as threatened under the Endangered Species Act.

headline: Will New York City Finally Have a Snow Day? Maybe Sunday.
abstract: A major winter storm could deliver some major cities in the Northeast their first large snow in almost two years — or it could bring just a rainy mess.
lead_paragraph: A major winter storm will undoubtedly drop snow in the Northeast from Saturday into Sunday. Although things are starting to become a little clearer Thursday morning, exactly where the division between snow and rain would occur was still not exactly known.

headline: Who Was the Iranian General Qassim Suleimani?
abstract: General Suleimani, the powerful commander heading Iran’s Quds Force, was considered a hero by some in the country. The anniversary of his death has attracted horrific violence.
lead_paragraph: The explosions that killed more than 100 people in Iran on Wednesday took place at an anniversary commemoration for Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani, the top Iranian commander who was killed by a U.S. drone strike four years ago.

headline: A Swedish Teenager Was on Japan Airlines Flight 516. Here’s His Story.
abstract: Anton Deibe, 17, and his family were flying into Tokyo when their plane collided with a Coast Guard aircraft.
lead_paragraph: Anton Deibe, 17, a high school student from Stockholm, was on a trip with his family to Japan to celebrate his father’s 50th birthday. They were among the passengers on Japan Airlines Flight 516 when it collided with a Coast Guard plane on Tuesday.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Apple TV+, Disney+, Max and More in January
abstract: We’ve rounded up of the titles most worth checking out in the coming month, including an adaptation of “The Expatriates” and the return of “True Detective.”
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of January’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Russia and Ukraine Exchange Record Number of P.O.W.s
abstract: The exchange of prisoners was the first in months and came as both sides were engaged in an escalating cycle of air assaults.
lead_paragraph: Russia and Ukraine on Wednesday announced a mutual release of hundreds of prisoners of war, the biggest exchange between the two countries since the start of the conflict nearly two years ago and the first one in months.

headline: Woman Sues Dentist After Getting 4 Root Canals, 8 Crowns and 20 Fillings in 1 Visit
abstract: The Minnesota woman said the dental work, performed in one day in July 2020, caused her “pain and suffering, embarrassment, emotional distress and disfigurement.”
lead_paragraph: A Minnesota woman who said that she received four root canals, eight dental crowns and 20 fillings in a single visit to a dentist’s office has sued him for negligence, claiming that he caused her disfigurement.

headline: T.I. and Tiny Are Accused of Rape in Lawsuit
abstract: The Atlanta rapper and his wife, who have denied the allegations, are accused of drugging and assaulting a military veteran around 2005 in a lawsuit filed in Los Angeles on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Atlanta rapper T.I., born Clifford Harris, was sued on Tuesday, along with his wife, Tameka Harris, known as Tiny, by a woman who accused the couple of drugging and raping her after she met them at a Los Angeles nightclub around 2005.

headline: Did You Remarry Your Former Spouse? Tell Us About It.
abstract: We want to know what caused the breakup in the first place and why you decided to get back together again.
lead_paragraph: Did you remarry the person you divorced? The Times would like to hear the hows, whens, and whys of your story.

headline: Disney Gains Support From a Prominent Activist Investor
abstract: ValueAct Capital, known for working constructively with boards, said it would support the media giant’s director nominees amid a challenge by Nelson Peltz.
lead_paragraph: The Walt Disney Company said on Wednesday that it had gained the backing of ValueAct Capital, a prominent activist hedge fund, as it faces a board challenge from the billionaire financier Nelson Peltz.

headline: The Fallout From a Resignation at Harvard
abstract: Readers weigh in on Claudine Gay’s resignation as Harvard’s president. Also: Migrants in New York City; how to respond when attacked by Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Blasts Kill Dozens in Iran
abstract: Two bombs exploded along the road near the burial site of Qassim Suleimani, Iran’s former top general, during a commemoration on the fourth anniversary of his assassination by the United States.
lead_paragraph: Two bombs exploded along the road near the burial site of Qassim Suleimani, Iran’s former top general, during a commemoration on the fourth anniversary of his assassination by the United States.

headline: Mexico Authorities Rescue 31 Migrants Abducted Near Border With U.S.
abstract: Cartels are preying on asylum seekers and migrants from around the world as they crowd northern Mexico, creating a kidnap-for-ransom revenue stream.
lead_paragraph: Mexican authorities said on Wednesday that all 31 migrants seized over the weekend in a mass kidnapping near the border with the United States had been rescued.

headline: Fed Minutes Showed Officials Feeling Better About Inflation
abstract: Central bankers wanted to signal that interest rates were likely at or near their peak while keeping their options open, December minutes showed.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials wanted to use their final policy statement of 2023 to signal that interest rates might be at their peak even as they left the door open to future rate increases, minutes from their December meeting showed.

headline: Sidney M. Wolfe, Scourge of the Pharmaceutical Industry, Dies at 86
abstract: For over 40 years, he and his organization, the Health Research Group, held government and manufacturers to account for unsafe medication.
lead_paragraph: Sidney M. Wolfe, a physician and consumer advocate who for more than 40 years hounded the pharmaceutical industry and the Food and Drug Administration over high prices, dangerous side effects and overlooked health hazards, bringing a new level of transparency and accountability to the world of medical care, died on Monday at his home in Washington. He was 86.

headline: Harvard Couldn’t Save Both Claudine Gay and Itself
abstract: How the left, not just the right, helped bring Gay down.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the weeks that Harvard spent resisting, unsuccessfully, the calls for Claudine Gay’s resignation, a common line of defense of the embattled Ivy League president was that it’s essential not to hand any kind of victory, under any circumstances, to conservative critics of higher education.

headline: Pat McAfee Apologizes Over Role in Aaron Rodgers-Jimmy Kimmel Feud
abstract: Rodgers, the Jets quarterback, suggested during an appearance on “The Pat McAfee Show” that Kimmel had a connection to Jeffrey Epstein, leading Kimmel to threaten legal action.
lead_paragraph: Pat McAfee on Wednesday apologized for airing comments that Jets quarterback Aaron Rodgers made toward Jimmy Kimmel on McAfee’s ESPN television show a day earlier suggesting the late-night talk show host had a connection to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein.

headline: SpaceX Illegally Fired Workers Critical of Musk, Federal Agency Says
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board said the rocket company had wrongly dismissed eight people for a letter raising concerns about the chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Federal labor officials accused the rocket company SpaceX on Wednesday of illegally firing eight employees for circulating a letter critical of the company’s founder and chief executive, Elon Musk.

headline: What to Know About the Science of Reading
abstract: An effort to overhaul how children learn to read, known as the science of reading movement, is sweeping the country. Here’s where it stands.
lead_paragraph: During an era of intense politicization of education, there has been rare bipartisan consensus on one issue: the need to overhaul how children learn to read.

headline: DeSantis Keeps Getting Asked: Why Won’t He Directly Criticize Trump?
abstract: It’s a question the Florida governor seems to be growing tired of hearing.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida takes questions from voters at every campaign stop, so he often faces variations of the same question — sometimes several times in a single day at different events scattered hundreds of miles apart.

headline: Why I Welcome New York City’s Congestion Pricing Plan
abstract: We pay more for most things when demand is higher, and there are great reasons to do the same for roads.
lead_paragraph: I’m glad New York City is about to start charging vehicles for crowding the streets of Manhattan, and I say that as a New Jersey resident — a member of the bridge and tunnel crowd — who will be paying a fat toll whenever I drive into the congestion zone in Manhattan.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘High and Low’ and More
abstract: I’m a New York Times correspondent based in Ottawa. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a New York Times correspondent based in Ottawa. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: An Easy, Thrilling Tofu Recipe for Just About Any Resolution
abstract: This grain bowl, finished in with a sweet chile sauce, is perfect for the vegetarian curious or anyone wanting lighter fare.
lead_paragraph: If there’s one thing I’ve learned from years of New Year’s resolutions, it’s that it’s a whole lot easier to do something than to avoid something.

headline: Kennedy Announces He Is on the Ballot in Utah
abstract: It is the first state to give Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a noted vaccine skeptic who is running for president as an independent, a spot on its 2024 ballot.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who is running for president as an independent, will be on the ballot in Utah, his campaign announced on Wednesday at an event in Salt Lake City, capping a weekslong signature-gathering effort.

headline: Israel says it dismantled a Hamas-built tunnel under a Gaza hospital.
abstract: The Israeli military says the tearing down was done in November and that hospital wasn’t damaged in the process.
lead_paragraph: Israel said on Wednesday that in November it had dismantled a tunnel below Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City, the medical facility that Israel and allies have said Hamas used as a shield for a vast underground militia complex.

headline: Millions Die of Malaria With Miracle Drugs at Hand
abstract: Vaccines are available and could be widely distributed if governments paid for them.
lead_paragraph: On the end-of-year lists, Ozempic keeps taking top honors for achievements in science. But in our new golden age of medicine, one of the most eye-opening breakthroughs has been in the less glamorous corners of public health.

headline: Israel Supreme Court Delivers Setback to Campaign to Remove Checks on Netanyahu
abstract: The country’s Supreme Court ruled to postpone the adoption of a new law making it harder to designate a sitting prime minister unfit for office, a direct blow to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Supreme Court on Wednesday delayed the enactment of a new law that makes it harder to remove a prime minister from office — the court’s second ruling in three days that impeded attempts by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government to gain more power.

headline: Former Guard Official Says Army Retaliated for His Account of Jan. 6 Delay
abstract: Col. Earl Matthews, the top lawyer for the D.C. National Guard during the assault on the Capitol, said in a whistle-blower complaint that he was punished for contradicting the testimony of two top generals.
lead_paragraph: A former top lawyer for the D.C. National Guard has accused Army officials of retaliating against him for asserting to Congress that two top Army officers lied about why deployment of the Guard was delayed during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, according to a complaint filed with the Defense Department and obtained by The New York Times.

headline: What’s ‘In’ for 2024? In-and-Out Lists, Apparently.
abstract: In the final days of 2023, social media was overrun with tongue-in-cheek predictions for the year ahead from regular people moonlighting as professional prognosticators.
lead_paragraph: Extra-large bags, silver jewelry and gardening are in. Quiet luxury, podcasts and late bedtimes are out. That’s at least according to Instagram and TikTok, where lists confidently declaring which trends will thrive and which will die in the new year abounded as the clock struck midnight on Sunday.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Blasts in Iran Kill Dozens
abstract: Plus, China shakes up its military.
lead_paragraph: A pair of explosions yesterday at a commemoration for Iran’s former top military general, Qassim Suleimani, killed at least 95 people and wounded another 211, according to Iranian officials. The blasts heightened tensions in the broader region a day after an explosion killed several Hamas officials in a suburb of Beirut, Lebanon.

headline: Menendez Case Focuses on How Qatar Trades Its Riches for Clout
abstract: The tiny Gulf state has cultivated relationships with powerful people and institutions to raise its global profile, and to protect its interests.
lead_paragraph: When Senator Robert Menendez arrived in Qatar in 2022 to attend the country’s lavish production of the men’s soccer World Cup, he gave an unusual interview to the authoritarian government’s news agency praising the progress that Qatar had made on labor rights.

headline: Xerox to Cut 15% of Its Work Force in the First Quarter of 2024
abstract: The move is the printer maker’s latest as it tries to shift more toward its business services offerings.
lead_paragraph: Xerox said on Wednesday that it was cutting 15 percent of its work force as part of a restructuring, the company’s latest effort to shift focus to its business-services offerings and away from its iconic photocopiers.

headline: Hezbollah’s Leader Pledges Revenge for Killing of a Hamas Leader in Beirut
abstract: “Yesterday’s crime will not go unpunished,” Hassan Nasrallah warned ominously, but he gave no specifics, saying he would speak again on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Just 24 hours before he took to the podium on Wednesday, Hassan Nasrallah, the head of Lebanon’s powerful armed group Hezbollah, was preparing to deliver a speech commemorating another of Israel’s former arch foes, Qassem Soleimani, the Iranian commander killed in a U.S. drone strike four years ago to the day.

headline: Covid Has Resurged, but Scientists See a Diminished Threat
abstract: Hospitalizations have ticked upward, and there are at least 1,200 Covid-related deaths each week. Americans should mask more often, and vaccination rates remain too low, experts say.
lead_paragraph: The holidays have come and gone, and once again Americans are riding a tide of respiratory ailments, including Covid. But so far, this winter’s Covid uptick seems less deadly than last year’s, and much less so than in 2022, when the Omicron surge ground the nation to a halt.

headline: Claudine Gay: What Just Happened at Harvard Is Bigger Than Me
abstract: The demagogues won’t stop with Harvard.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, I made the wrenching but necessary decision to resign as Harvard’s president. For weeks, both I and the institution to which I’ve devoted my professional life have been under attack. My character and intelligence have been impugned. My commitment to fighting antisemitism has been questioned. My inbox has been flooded with invective, including death threats. I’ve been called the N-word more times than I care to count.

headline: Trump Asks Supreme Court to Keep Him on Colorado Ballot
abstract: The petition came in response to a Colorado Supreme Court ruling that the former president had engaged in insurrection and was ineligible to hold office under the 14th Amendment.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump asked the U.S. Supreme Court on Wednesday to keep him on the primary ballot in Colorado, appealing an explosive ruling from the state Supreme Court declaring him ineligible based on his efforts to overturn the 2020 election that culminated in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

headline: Read Trump’s Appeal to the Supreme Court Over Colorado’s Ballot Ruling
abstract: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump said rulings in Colorado and Maine deeming him ineligible for the ballot required the U.S. Supreme Court to act.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump said rulings in Colorado and Maine deeming him ineligible for the ballot required the U.S. Supreme Court to act.

headline: Trump’s January: Court Dates and Election Nights
abstract: While Iowa’s caucuses and New Hampshire’s primary could start to propel the former president to the G.O.P. nomination, he is facing two trials this month.
lead_paragraph: In the political world, Donald J. Trump is on the cusp of something that eluded him in 2016: a clear victory in the Iowa caucuses this month. His advisers hope it will be the first in a series of early state victories that propel him to collect enough delegates to be the presumptive Republican presidential nominee by late March.

headline: A Bombing Killed at Least 100 People in Iran
abstract: Also, Donald Trump asked the Supreme Court to rule on his eligibility. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A pair of bombs exploded into a crowd of people today at a commemoration for Iran’s former top general in the city of Kerman, Iranian officials said. At least 103 people were reported dead and another 211 wounded.

headline: Museum World Hit by Cyberattack on Widely Used Software
abstract: Hackers targeted software that many museums use to show their collections online and to manage sensitive information.
lead_paragraph: Several prominent museums have been unable to display their collections online since a cyberattack hit a prominent technological service provider that helps hundreds of cultural organizations show their works digitally and manage internal documents.

headline: Attacks Heighten Fears of a Wider War for the Middle East and U.S.
abstract: The killing of a top Hamas leader in Lebanon and mysterious twin explosions in Iran heighten fears of a regional war that could draw in the United States.
lead_paragraph: American, Israeli and Lebanese officials insist that few parties want Israel’s war in Gaza to become a wider conflict that engulfs the Middle East.

headline: More Than 100 People in Iran Killed in Blasts at Suleimani Memorial
abstract: More than 200 people were also injured after two roadside bombs exploded during a memorial for Qassim Suleimani, Iran’s former top general who was killed by a U.S. drone strike four years ago.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 people were also injured after two roadside bombs exploded during a memorial for Qassim Suleimani, Iran’s former top general who was killed by a U.S. drone strike four years ago.

headline: Donald Wildmon, Early Crusader in Conservative Culture Wars, Dies at 85
abstract: The American Family Association, which he founded, became a juggernaut in the Christian right’s campaign against sex and gay themes in art, television and pop culture.
lead_paragraph: Donald E. Wildmon, a conservative activist whose alarm over indecency on television spawned a national organization, the American Family Association, a once powerful cog of the Christian right, and who led boycotts over sexuality and gay themes in some of America’s most popular TV shows and in the arts, died on Dec. 28 in Tupelo, Miss. He was 85.

headline: What We Know About the Menendez Bribery Case
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat, was charged with accepting bribes, including cash, gold bars and a Mercedes-Benz, in exchange for political favors.
lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, a Democrat, was charged in September with accepting bribes, including cash, gold bars and a luxury Mercedes-Benz, in exchange for lucrative political favors and what prosecutors described as efforts to derail criminal investigations.

headline: The Persecution of Harvard’s Claudine Gay
abstract: As Black women have raised their profiles, they’ve also raised some right-wing hackles.
lead_paragraph: Claudine Gay, the president of Harvard who announced her resignation on Tuesday after her problematic congressional testimony about antisemitism and mounting questions about missing citations and quotation marks in her published work, was, in part, pushed out by political forces beyond academia and hostile to it.

headline: Unsealed Documents Shed Light on Epstein’s Misdeeds, and Little Else
abstract: The court documents include unredacted names of the disgraced financier and sex-offender’s associates, most of which had been widely publicized already.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of pages of previously sealed court documents related to Jeffrey Epstein, the disgraced financier and registered sex offender, were made public Wednesday — but as most legal experts familiar with the sordid affair had surmised, there was no smoking gun list of famous men who had sought to have sex with young women and teen girls.

headline: G.O.P. Senate Group Files Brief in Support of Trump’s Colorado Ballot Appeal
abstract: The National Republican Senatorial Committee argued in an amicus brief that the Colorado Supreme Court overstepped in disqualifying former President Donald J. Trump from the primary ballot.
lead_paragraph: The top Republican Senate campaign group filed a brief on Wednesday with the United States Supreme Court in support of Donald J. Trump’s appeal of a Colorado ruling blocking him from the state’s presidential ballot. It is the latest sign of the rallying effect that the former president’s legal woes are having on his party.

headline: Israelis Worry a Blow Against Hamas May Bring Blowback
abstract: Israelis welcomed news that a top Palestinian militant had been killed, but feared that it might impede the release of hostages and kindle a broader war.
lead_paragraph: A day after a blast killed a senior Hamas leader outside Beirut, Lebanon, many Israelis welcomed the assassination as an important step in the campaign to destroy the militant group, but worried it might carry costs.

headline: A Skeptic of the G.O.P.’s Hard Immigration Line Becomes Its Champion
abstract: Representative Tony Gonzales, who represents a Texas border district, drew a censure and primary opponents for defying his fellow Republicans on immigration. Now he has swung into line.
lead_paragraph: When Speaker Mike Johnson and scores of House Republicans converged in Eagle Pass, Texas, on Wednesday to call for a crackdown on migrants at the border, they had a somewhat unlikely host.

headline: Homicides and Shootings Fell in New York City as Felony Assaults Rose
abstract: Car thefts also increased amid a slight drop in crime overall in 2023, police officials said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Overall crime fell slightly in New York City last year compared with 2022, though the number of felony assaults and car thefts remained stubbornly high, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: The Jan. 6 Riot Inquiry So Far: Three Years, Hundreds of Prison Sentences
abstract: More than 1,200 people have now been arrested in connection with the attack on the Capitol, and more than 450 sentenced to periods of incarceration. The investigation is far from over.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,200 people have now been arrested in connection with the attack on the Capitol, and more than 450 sentenced to periods of incarceration. The investigation is far from over.

headline: Oprah Winfrey and Gayle King’s Iconic Friendship
abstract: Stories and insights from their enduring connection.
lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey and Gayle King talk with Jancee Dunn, a Well columnist at The New York Times, about what’s kept their friendship strong for close to 50 years.

headline: Listen to Oprah Winfrey and Gayle King Discuss Their Friendship
abstract: Best friends, Winfrey and King talk about their enduring, enlivening relationship.
lead_paragraph: When I picture the perfect friendship, I think of what Oprah Winfrey and Gayle King have. For around 47 years, through life and career changes, they have publicly cheered each other on with enthusiasm and love. What’s their secret to maintaining a friendship so strong for so long? I wanted to know, so I called them to chat about their near half-century together.

headline: Assessing Republicans’ Claims About Immigration During Border Visit
abstract: The visit to Texas reflects the extent to which immigration has become one of President Biden’s biggest political vulnerabilities, particularly as the 2024 election nears.
lead_paragraph: More than 60 House Republicans traveled to the southern border in Texas on Wednesday, seeking to pressure the Biden administration to enact stricter immigration policies as a record number of migrants enter the United States. They gathered near the Rio Grande in Eagle Pass, a town of fewer than 30,000 that has become a popular crossing point.

headline: Day 4: Identify Your ‘Energy Vampires’ and ‘Chaotic Friends’
abstract: Today you’ll explore whether your relationships are uplifting or depleting.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 4 of the 6-Day Energy Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.

headline: Judge in Las Vegas Attacked By Man Who Was Denied Probation
abstract: In a scene captured on video, Deobra Redden, 30, jumped over a courtroom bench onto Judge Mary Kay Holthus as he was about to be sentenced, court officials said.
lead_paragraph: A man who had been denied probation attacked a judge during his sentencing in a Nevada courtroom on Wednesday in a violent episode that was captured on video.

headline: Nevada Man Attacks His Judge
abstract: Court video from Clark County, Nev., shows Deobra Redden throwing himself at Judge Mary Kay Holthus during his sentencing on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Court video from Clark County, Nev., shows Deobra Redden throwing himself at Judge Mary Kay Holthus during his sentencing on Wednesday.

headline: Connected to the Spine
abstract: Chase Dittrich and Christina Iverson spell things out for us.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Citing Misinformation, Florida Health Official Calls for Halt to Covid Vaccines
abstract: Federal health officials and other experts have repeatedly sought to counter erroneous comments about the vaccines by Dr. Joseph Ladapo, Florida’s surgeon general.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s surgeon general on Wednesday called for a halt to the use of Covid vaccines, citing widely debunked concerns that contaminants in the vaccine can permanently integrate into human DNA.

headline: Quotation of the Day: What if Farmers Were Taxed on Water? In California, Some Are.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 4, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The pricing was really difficult, when the water used to be, you know, free.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 4, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the collision of two aircraft as they landed in Tokyo misstated the type of Japan Coast Guard plane that was involved in the collision. It was a de Havilland Canada DHC-8, not an MA722, which was the aircraft’s identification number.

headline: Denmark’s Next Queen Is a Progressive, Common-Born Former Australian
abstract: “I don’t recall wishing that one day I would be a princess,” Princess Mary told reporters. “I wanted to be a veterinarian.”
lead_paragraph: It was a classic Australian love story, set in a Sydney pub: Girl meets boy. Girl marries boy. Girl lives happily ever after.

headline: Israelis Question Army’s Rules of Engagement After Hostages Slain
abstract: Israel’s military said that soldiers who shot hostages, while they waved a white flag, violated its rules of engagement. Human rights activists say the rules are good, but enforcement is lax.
lead_paragraph: The news that three Israeli hostages were mistakenly shot and killed last month in Gaza by soldiers meant to save them outraged many in Israel, who have since demanded answers about how the army conducts itself on the battlefield and safeguards civilians.

headline: Canada’s Logging Industry Devours Forests Crucial to Fighting Climate Change
abstract: A study finds that logging has inflicted severe damage to the vast boreal forests in Ontario and Quebec, two of the country’s main commercial logging regions.
lead_paragraph: Canada has long promoted itself globally as a model for protecting one of the country’s most vital natural resources: the world’s largest swath of boreal forest, which is crucial to fighting climate change.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: A deadly blast in Iran.
lead_paragraph: Two explosions at a memorial for Iran’s former top general, Qassim Suleimani, killed at least 103 people and wounded an additional 211, according to Iranian officials, sowing fear in a country where domestic unrest and the prospect of a spiraling regional war have left many on edge. The attack came at a time of heightened anxiety in Iran and across the region.

headline: Word of the Day: nix
abstract: This word has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word nix has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 29 in “A Cozy One-Pot Chicken for a Fuss-Free Holiday” by Melissa Clark:

headline: Rage Against the Machine Says (Again) That It Will Stop Touring
abstract: A staple of 1990s rock music, Rage has disbanded before, including when its frontman quit in 2000. His recent leg injury forced the band to cancel its latest tour.
lead_paragraph: The rock band Rage Against the Machine is done touring and playing live shows, its drummer said in a social media post on Wednesday.

headline: Tetris Loses to 13-Year-Old Boy
abstract: Willis Gibson became the first person to advance so far in the original Nintendo version of Tetris that the game froze.
lead_paragraph: Willis Gibson became the first person to advance so far in the original Nintendo version of Tetris that the game froze.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: For Six Months, Bringing Dark Stories to Light
abstract: Debra Kamin spoke with current and former agents at eXp Realty, a real estate brokerage, where several women said they had been victims of drugging and sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, Debra Kamin, who covers real estate for The New York Times, was reading an online trade publication when an article caught her attention.

headline: A Good Coat Is Hard to Find
abstract: Paynter Jacket Co., a small label in London, has built a loyal following thanks to its limited-edition chore coats.
lead_paragraph: Fi Cotter Craig, a television producer in Britain, was scrolling through Instagram one day when she was struck by a photo. “I saw my friend wearing a jacket that I actually thought I would kill her for,” Ms. Cotter Craig said. “Rather than kill her, I rang her up and said, ‘Where did you get that jacket?’”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Reflections
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: The N.Y.P.D. Dance Team Walks the Beat and Feels It Too
abstract: This squad is finding its niche in a department where most clubs are dedicated to traditionally macho pastimes.
lead_paragraph: Officer Lauren Pagán looked at the line of dancers in the overheated cafeteria at a Queens high school on a recent Monday night and frowned.

headline: The Man Who Destroys $3,000 Handbags on the Internet
abstract: Under the handle Tanner Leatherstein, Volkan Yilmaz rips, burns and slices apart luxury goods to show how much he thinks they are really worth.
lead_paragraph: One video opens with a large white leather handbag covered in the signature LV logo of Louis Vuitton. Within milliseconds, a hand with a switchblade swoops in and slashes a huge gash in the side of the bag before tearing it apart at its seams. In another, the distinctive red sole of Christian Louboutin is loudly ripped from a black stiletto using a wrench; in still another, scissors snip through a $2,200 Prada clutch before a man sets fire to a piece of the leather and turns it to ash.

headline: 36 Hours in Zurich
abstract: Ride a fondue tram, explore art galleries in a converted brewery and toboggan down a mountain in Switzerland’s largest city.
lead_paragraph: Ride a fondue tram, explore art galleries in a converted brewery and toboggan down a mountain in Switzerland’s largest city.

headline: The 7 Keys to Longevity
abstract: Ignore the hyperbaric chambers and infrared light: These are the evidence-backed secrets to aging well.
lead_paragraph: Humans have searched for the secret to immortality for thousands of years. For some people today, that quest includes things like sleeping in a hyperbaric chamber, experimenting with cryotherapy or blasting oneself with infrared light.

headline: Jill McCorkle Is Getting Over Her ‘Henry James Phobia’
abstract: Finishing “The Portrait of a Lady” leaves the author of “Old Crimes,” a new story collection, “a little more confident.” Meanwhile, Rod Serling has a place on her shelves.
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: The Grim Heartbeat Propelling ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’
abstract: In a short but fast-moving sequence built around a children’s primer, Martin Scorsese lays out all the themes of this terrible true-crime tale.
lead_paragraph: Early in Martin Scorsese’s “Killers of the Flower Moon,” an Osage woman named Mollie gives her gravely unsuitable white suitor, Ernest, a Stetson. It’s a large off-white hat with a bound-edge brim and a wide ribbon around the band. It’s a gift but it feels more like a benediction, and anyone who’s ever watched an old western film (or “Star Wars”) will recognize the symbolism of her largess. Mollie is telling Ernest that she sees him as a good guy, even if the movie has already violently upended the familiar dualism of the white hat vs. black.

headline: 10 Great Ways to Pop the Question
abstract: Here are some of the sweetest, funniest and most heartwarming ways that couples who wed in 2023 asked, “Will you marry me?”
lead_paragraph: In 2023, the weddings industry made a comeback.

headline: The Thin Blue Line That Divides America
abstract: The stark symbol wielded in the Capitol riot was always more complicated than it seemed.
lead_paragraph: Among the banners that Donald Trump’s supporters carried as they stormed the Capitol three years ago — 2016’s Make America Great Again flags and 2020’s Keep America Great flags, Confederate battle flags, Gadsden flags, Pine Tree flags, the Stars and Stripes — appeared a now-familiar variant of the American flag: white stars on a black field, with alternating black and white stripes, except for the stripe immediately beneath the union, which is blue.

headline: ‘Good Grief’ Review: Somehow, Life Goes On
abstract: In his feature directorial debut, Daniel Levy applies a light but wise hand to a man navigating life after loss.
lead_paragraph: Romantic comedies are powered by farcical set pieces like missed connections, mistaken identities and mix-ups that lead to happy-ending fantasies. (They’re all modeled on Shakespeare, in the end.) Those sorts of moments do abound in “Good Grief,” which features pretty urbanites in pretty places learning lessons about friendship, life and love, just like a rom-com would. But to the immense credit of the movie’s writer, director and star Daniel Levy (of “Schitt’s Creek”), this is a very different kind of movie — and a much better one.

headline: One Indelible Scene: A Lovingly Prepared Meal in ‘The Taste of Things’
abstract: In a kitchen pas de deux, two cooks turn a feast into a meditation on time, longing and the seasons.
lead_paragraph: How a movie announces itself to you is everything, and “The Taste of Things” begins in a kitchen.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Galentine’s Day
abstract: How early is too early to send out save-the-dates for a get together for the gals?
lead_paragraph: Louis writes: My partner, Robin, enjoys hosting themed get-togethers with friends and goes all out with invitations, menus and décor. Galentine’s Day (the Valentine’s Day celebration for gal pals only) is her annual highlight, and she looks forward to it for months. This year, she wanted to send out save-the-dates in October. I said this was too early for most people. Who’s right?
