headline: In Europe, Trains Are Full, and More Are on the Way
abstract: Amid concerns about climate change, demand for rail service is strong, and both governments and private investors are trying to keep up. Even Eurostar may see competition on its London-Paris route.
lead_paragraph: Paris to Venice. Barcelona to Amsterdam. Brussels to Bratislava, Slovakia. European cities could see a flurry of new rail connections in the next few years, as governments and private investors respond to climate concerns and strive to keep up with strong demand for cross-border passenger rail traffic.

headline: ‘Memory’ Review: A Trauma Plot
abstract: In this contrived movie, Peter Sarsgaard stars as a man with dementia, and Jessica Chastain plays a caretaker with buried family secrets.
lead_paragraph: In “Memory,” a woman haunted by her past meets a man who’s scarcely holding onto his. That’s the setup in the writer-director Michel Franco’s contrived drama with Jessica Chastain and Peter Sarsgaard, whose work in this artsified slab of exploitation cinema is strong enough that you wish their characters would run off to an entirely different movie.

headline: Look What We Made Taylor Swift Do
abstract: Whether she is conscious of it or not, Ms. Swift signals to queer people — in our language — that she has some affinity for queer identity.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, the year Taylor Swift released her first single, a closeted country singer named Chely Wright, then 35, held a 9-millimeter pistol to her mouth. Queer identity was still taboo enough in mainstream America that speaking about her love for another woman would have spelled the end of a country music career. But in suppressing her identity, Ms. Wright had risked her life.

headline: The Newest ‘Godzilla’ Film Is Stranger Than Fiction
abstract: Effects artists annihilate cities in movies all the time. Tokyo really was destroyed, a reality the best Godzilla stories have always taken seriously.

headline: Call That an Earthquake? By L.A. Standards, It Was a Nothing.
abstract: New York City felt a little early morning quake on Tuesday with a magnitude of 1.7.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll find out more about the earthquake that shook New York just a little bit. We’ll also unpack statistics showing that overall crime fell slightly in New York City last year.

headline: Holly Jackson’s Maximization of Google Maps
abstract: In her “A Good Girl’s Guide to Murder” series and “Five Survive,” this British author makes herself at home on the East Coast.
lead_paragraph: How does a London-based novelist concoct a convincing story set in the United States? Some might splurge for a temporary relocation in the name of research, but Holly Jackson opts for a virtual visit via Google Maps. Navigating from street views to real estate listings — and even, eventually, to electoral records — she’ll piece together a universe for her characters.

headline: Willa Cather and Yehudi Menuhin: An Unlikely, Unwavering Friendship
abstract: These two titans of 20th-century literature and music formed a profound, yearslong relationship across generations and backgrounds.
lead_paragraph: Early in 1935, a blizzard blew through New York City. The storm was so fierce, it virtually emptied Central Park. But Willa Cather spent her morning there, sledding with the violin prodigy Yehudi Menuhin and his sisters.

headline: Flowers Are Evolving to Have Less Sex
abstract: As the number of bees and other pollinators falls, field pansies are adapting by fertilizing their own seeds, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Every spring, trillions of flowers mate with the help of bees and other animals. They lure the pollinators to their flowers with flashy colors and nectar. As the animals travel from flower to flower, they take pollen with them, which can fertilize the seeds of other plants.

headline: Are You Optimistic About the State of the World?
abstract: A New York Times columnist argues that despite many tragic events, 2023 may have been the best year in the history of humanity. Do you agree?
lead_paragraph: Overall, do you think the world is becoming a better place to live? Or do dire events like wars in Ukraine and Gaza or the growing climate crisis make you worried about the fate of humanity?

headline: Is the 2024 Election Already Heading to the Supreme Court?
abstract: Before Republican primary voters head to the polls, a thorny legal question has emerged over whether Donald Trump is eligible to be on the ballot.
lead_paragraph: It’s the start of the actual election year — and a new chapter in the campaign.

headline: Told Ya So: The Prescient Posters of the Environmental Movement
abstract: Graphic artists have been helping call attention to climate change for decades, and a new exhibition charts the evolution of their pleas.
lead_paragraph: Last year was the warmest in recorded history. The graphic artists of the environmental movement tried to warn us. Their posters aimed to scare people straight with pictures of ecological ruin, or glorified nature, clean air and water, sunshine and verdure. Some offered earworm-y slogans and haunting visuals. Whatever their approach — bright, witty, somber, blunt, even sexy — they sought an image, a phrase, that could change enough minds to literally save the world.

headline: Democrats Must Not Repeat the Mistakes of Globalization
abstract: The advent of A.I. doesn’t have to mean the death of labor.
lead_paragraph: Last September, tech’s biggest names trekked to Capitol Hill for a forum on artificial intelligence. In a meeting closed to journalists, executives briefed nearly two-thirds of the Senate on the future of A.I. A few respected labor and civic leaders were present, but the tech titans dominated the headlines.

headline: A Single Dad Wanted a Manhattan Pad Fit for Two. Would His Budget Be Enough?
abstract: After selling the family home in Westchester, an environmental engineer looked to ‘start over’ in the city — with his 23-year-old son in tow. Here’s what he found.
lead_paragraph: After selling the family home in Westchester, an environmental engineer looked to ‘start over’ in the city — with his 23-year-old son in tow. Here’s what he found.

headline: Week 18 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: Mapping the Paths That Remain for Each Team
abstract: Detailed tables and scenarios explain the remaining paths to the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: Detailed tables and scenarios explain the remaining paths to the playoffs.

headline: Want to Understand 2024? Look at 1948.
abstract: Americans were angry with Truman because of high prices in the aftermath of World War II, even as other economic signals looked promising.
lead_paragraph: In the era of modern consumer confidence data, there has never been an economy quite like this recent one — with prices rising so high and unemployment staying so low.

headline: For Harvard’s First Black President, Race Became the Unavoidable Issue
abstract: Claudine Gay celebrated her history making appointment. But after she resigned, she spoke very differently about her experience.
lead_paragraph: In her late September inauguration, Claudine Gay looked out at a packed audience and spoke of her pride in making history as the first Black president of Harvard in its 387 years.

headline: Who Will Investigate One of Georgia’s Most Ambitious Politicians in the Trump Case?
abstract: The investigation of Lt. Gov. Burt Jones was delayed after a judge blocked the Fulton County district attorney from conducting it. Nobody has been tapped to take over.
lead_paragraph: Since the indictment of former President Donald J. Trump and 18 of his allies last summer on election interference charges in Georgia, a delicate question has gone unanswered: Would criminal charges also be coming for Lt. Gov. Burt Jones, a longtime Trump supporter and one of the most ambitious politicians in the Southern swing state?

headline: U.S. Awards Chip Supplier $162 Million to Bolster Critical Industries
abstract: The Biden administration said its second grant under a new program would help Microchip Technology expand its facilities in Oregon and Colorado.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Thursday announced plans to provide $162 million in federal grants to Microchip Technology, an Arizona-based semiconductor company that supplies the automotive, defense and other industries.

headline: In Tense Election Year, Public Officials Face Climate of Intimidation
abstract: Colorado and Maine, which blocked former President Donald J. Trump from the ballot, have grappled with the harassment of officials.
lead_paragraph: The caller had tipped off the authorities in Maine on Friday night: He told them that he had broken into the home of Shenna Bellows, the state’s top election official, a Democrat who one night earlier had disqualified former President Donald J. Trump from the primary ballot because of his actions during the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.

headline: The Case for Disqualifying Trump Is Strong
abstract: Worrying about “consequences” is not a legal argument.
lead_paragraph: It’s been just over two weeks since the Colorado Supreme Court ruled that Section 3 of the 14th Amendment disqualifies Donald Trump from holding the office of president of the United States, and I spent way too much of my holiday vacation reading the legal and political commentary around the decision, and as I did so, I found myself experiencing déjà vu. Since the rise of Trump, he and his movement have transgressed constitutional, legal and moral boundaries at will and then, when Americans attempt to impose consequences for those transgressions, Trump’s defenders and critics alike caution that the consequences will be dangerous or destabilizing.

headline: Putin’s Drive to Rewrite History Snares a Retired Lithuanian Judge
abstract: A few years ago, Kornelija Maceviciene ruled against Soviet officers for a brutal crackdown on pro-independence protesters in her country in 1991. That has made her a target for a Russian court.
lead_paragraph: When the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant last year for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, a Moscow court launched a surprise counterattack: It ordered the arrest of a 70-year-old retired judge in Lithuania.

headline: Crisis in the Red Sea, and Epstein Files Unsealed
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Why Are So Many More Pedestrians Dying in the U.S.?
abstract: Other rich nations have surpassed America in protecting pedestrians, cyclists and motorists.
lead_paragraph: A puzzling new pattern has taken hold on American roads: pedestrian traffic deaths, which had been on the decline for years, have skyrocketed.

headline: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Deadly Bombings in Iran
abstract: The group, which has struck before in Iran, has a long history of division with the country.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State claimed responsibility on Thursday for the bombing attack that killed 84 people in Kerman, Iran, a day before, during a memorial procession for Maj. Gen. Qassim Suleimani, according to a post on the extremist group’s official Telegram account.

headline: A.I. Questions, Answered
abstract: We ask Times technology reporters to make artificial intelligence more comprehensible.
lead_paragraph: I want to make a confession: I don’t understand a lot of the hype around artificial intelligence.

headline: ‘Society of the Snow’ Review: The Stranded and the Faithful
abstract: Another movie tackles the story of the Uruguayan rugby players who survived a plane crash and turned to cannibalism.
lead_paragraph: Filmmakers love survival stories, but there are aspects of the so-called “miracle in the Andes” that pose special difficulties for any movie, not least because, a half-century on, the most notorious turn that events took will be well known to most viewers going in.

headline: ‘Artie Shaw: Time Is All You’ve Got’ Review: A Lens on a Jazz Luminary
abstract: Brigitte Berman’s dazzling 1985 look at the self-taught virtuoso clarinetist and bandleader is showing after a restoration.
lead_paragraph: The documentarian Brigitte Berman has made two spectacular pictures about American jazz pioneers. The first, “Bix: ‘Ain’t None of Them Play Like Him Yet’” (1981), chronicled the life of the brilliant and tragically short-lived cornetist and composer Bix Beiderbecke. It screened in a restoration at Film Forum a couple of years back. Now, her follow-up to that movie, “Artie Shaw: Time Is All You’ve Got” (1985), is similarly restored and booked at Film Forum.

headline: ‘He Went That Way’ Review: On the Road With a Serial Killer
abstract: In this thriller, the Australian actor Jacob Elordi tries on the tics of noteworthy American performers, from James Dean to Matt Dillon.
lead_paragraph: Apparently, some time in 1964, a professional ice skater and animal trainer named Dave Pitts, on the road with his chimp Spanky, picked up a young hitchhiker who was in the middle of a killing spree. The story of Pitts’s encounter with Larry Lee Ranes, whose brother also became a serial killer, was fictionalized in Conrad Hilberry’s book “Luke Karamazov.” That book is the source of “He Went That Way,” the picturesque feature directing debut of the cinematographer Jeff Darling, who died in a surfing accident in 2022.

headline: ‘Mayhem!’ Review: Just When You Think You’re Out
abstract: A former convict struggles to go straight in this ultraviolent revenge thriller.
lead_paragraph: No one in the mood for subtlety or nuance is likely to be beckoned by “Mayhem!,” a slugfest that cleaves to its title with punishing fidelity. A mood board of mashing, slashing, snapping and splintering, this feature, directed by Xavier Gens, is revenge-movie cliché ground down to the studs.

headline: Jeff Zucker’s Latest Bet: Prestige TV
abstract: The former CNN president will return to Hollywood by investing in the studio behind streaming hits like “The Morning Show” on Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Zucker is returning to the world of morning television. Sort of.

headline: 2023: The Year You Didn’t Buy a House
abstract: Just 16 percent of homes listed in 2023 were affordable for the typical American household.
lead_paragraph: The year ended disappointingly for many American home buyers — fewer than 16 percent of homes for sale in 2023 were affordable to local median earners, according to a study by Redfin. That’s the lowest rate since at least 2013, the year Redfin began tracking prices, when 50 percent of homes were affordable to local median earners. In 2019, before the pandemic, 40 percent of listed homes were affordable. In 2022, only 21 percent were.

headline: The Fight Over D.E.I. in the C-suite
abstract: Claudine Gay’s resignation as Harvard president is adding to the wider debate in boardrooms over diversity, equity and inclusion policies.
lead_paragraph: Even though Claudine Gay’s resignation as president of Harvard was tied to plagiarism allegations, debate on a broader culture war’s role in the move is grabbing lots of attention.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 8, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Luna Luna: A Fantasy That Comes With a Price Tag
abstract: A blockbuster restaging of an “art amusement park” from 1987 aims to recover a lost element in art — fun. But in our age of hype and commerce, was it doomed to fall short?
lead_paragraph: What happened to fun? In the clinical white of the gallery, art can be forbidding, aggrieved, elite, academic. Shouldn’t it also, sometimes, be joyous?

headline: A Trophy in Ruins: Evidence Grows That Russia Controls Marinka
abstract: Ukraine said it was defending territory behind the eastern frontline town. Its capture would be Russia’s most significant territorial advance in Ukraine in more than six months.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian military said on Thursday that its troops were fighting “in the vicinities” of a village behind the eastern frontline town of Marinka, a strong indication that Kyiv’s forces have lost control of the town, more than a week after Moscow claimed to have seized it.

headline: Experts See a Message in Chinese Balloons Flying Over Taiwan
abstract: Some analysts see the objects as a calculatedly ambiguous reminder to voters that Beijing is watching.
lead_paragraph: A surge in sightings of balloons from China flying over Taiwan has drawn the attention of the island’s military and struck some experts as a calculatedly ambiguous warning to voters weeks before its presidential election.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut.
abstract: This week’s properties are three-bedroom homes in Merrick, N.Y., and Redding Conn.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, two-bath house built around 1938, with wood flooring, an open layout with dining and living areas, a kitchen with an island and a pantry, a family room with a wood-burning fireplace, a partially finished basement, a rear deck and a detached one-car garage, on a 52-by-102-foot lot. Seth Pitlake, Douglas Elliman Real Estate, 516-521-7976; elliman.com

headline: A Train Trip Through Malaysia, With Stops for Snorkeling and Wildlife Safaris
abstract: Plus: celestial jewelry, a new restaurant in the Himalayas and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: When I wake up, I wash my face with Relevant Complete Cleansing Serum, which is part of the skin-care line I founded in 2022. I love it because it’s hydrating and doesn’t strip your skin. Three times a week I exfoliate with The Things We Do Gly Glow Scrub. I follow up with the Relevant Beam + Glow Eye Serum, which I use all around my eyes but also on the fine lines around my mouth. I use the Sunburst C+ Superfruit Serum, and then I finish with Relevant’s One & Done Everyday Cream With SPF 40. It doesn’t leave a cast on the skin, and you can reapply it over makeup. In the shower, I use Saltair’s Exotic Pulp body wash and República’s Sugar Body Polish. I was not into bar soaps for a while, but the beauty retailer I co-founded, Thirteen Lune, now carries Gently. I love Karité’s Hydrating Body Cream and Goop’s Afterglow Body Oil — my skin just drinks those up. I’ve been using Kiehl’s Creme de Corps since college.

headline: These New Laws Just Took Effect in California
abstract: Toy stores must have gender-neutral sections, employers must provide more sick days and more.
lead_paragraph: New year, new rules.

headline: 30 Shows to Watch This Winter
abstract: This season promises a deluge of big stars (Nicole Kidman, Kate Winslet), intriguing adaptations (“Avatar: The Last Airbender”), long-awaited returns (“True Detective”) and final goodbyes (“Curb Your Enthusiasm”).
lead_paragraph: Is it a delayed effect of the writers’ and actors’ strikes? The Year of the Dragon? Climate change? Whatever the reason, a paper-thin fall season on television screens (definitely a result of the strikes) is being followed by a deluge of attention-grabbing shows this winter. A-list stars (Jodie Foster, Nicole Kidman, Kate Winslet), intriguing adaptations and reboots (“3 Body Problem,” “Avatar: The Last Airbender”), long-awaited returns (welcome back, “True Detective”) and final goodbyes (so long, “Curb Your Enthusiasm”) abound. Throw in all the delayed broadcast-network premieres — your various “Chicago,” “FBI,” “NCIS” and “Law and Order” series, among others — and it promises to be exhausting.

headline: Kim Jong-un’s Daughter Is His Likely Successor, South Korea Says
abstract: Kim Ju-ae has long accompanied her dictator father to important state events, like long-range missile tests and military parades.
lead_paragraph: The young daughter of North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, who has frequently accompanied her father at public events, including long-range missile tests, is Mr. Kim’s most likely successor should he die, the South Korean intelligence agency told lawmakers on Thursday.

headline: Iraq Condemns U.S. After Drone Strike in Baghdad
abstract: The attack, acknowledged by the Pentagon, killed a senior militant leader of an Iran-allied group with ties to the Iraqi government’s security apparatus.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. Special Operations drone strike in Baghdad on Thursday killed a senior figure in an Iran-linked militant group that is part of Iraq’s security apparatus, drawing sharp criticism from the Iraqi government, as well as allied groups.

headline: In Overnight Sweep, Police in Berkeley Clear Protesters From People’s Park
abstract: The University of California, Berkeley, has been trying for years, against determined opposition, to build new student housing on part of the iconic property.
lead_paragraph: A fraught battle to build long-sought student housing at the storied People’s Park in Berkeley, Calif., took an extraordinary turn early on Thursday when hundreds of law enforcement officers surrounded the site and removed several dozen activists and homeless campers in preparation for the construction of a wall of shipping containers around the perimeter of the park.

headline: DeSantis and Haley Will Appear in Back-to-Back Town Halls Tonight
abstract: The events, on CNN, will give the two candidates a prominent chance to make their case to Iowa Republicans ahead of the caucuses on Jan. 15.
lead_paragraph: It’s another busy day on the presidential campaign trail in Iowa.

headline: Haley Jokes That New Hampshire Primary Will ‘Correct’ Iowa’s Result
abstract: Ms. Haley, campaigning in New Hampshire, quipped that “Iowa starts it. You know that you correct it.” Allies of Gov. Ron DeSantis pounced.
lead_paragraph: Campaigning in New Hampshire on Wednesday, former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina said that voters there would “correct” the result of the Iowa caucuses — the night before she was scheduled to appear for events in Iowa.

headline: Trump Received Millions From Foreign Governments as President, Report Finds
abstract: House Democrats released evidence that he took in at least $7.8 million from foreign entities while in office, engaging in the kind of conduct the G.O.P. is grasping to pin on President Biden.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s businesses received at least $7.8 million from 20 foreign governments during his presidency, according to new documents released by House Democrats on Thursday that show how much he received from overseas transactions while he was in the White House, most of it from China.

headline: Sixth Grader Killed and 5 Others Injured in Iowa School Shooting
abstract: Four other students and an administrator were injured in the shooting at an Iowa school. The gunman, identified as a 17-year-old student, died from a self-inflicted gunshot, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A gunman killed a sixth-grade student and injured five other people at a high school in Perry, Iowa, early Thursday morning just as students were arriving back to school after their winter break.

headline: Happy Puppies and Silly Geese: Pushing the Limits of A.I. Absurdity
abstract: A recent update to ChatGPT made it easier to create images. It wasn’t long before some began pushing the chatbot to its limits.
lead_paragraph: What is the happiest dog you can imagine? Is it beaming with joy on a celestial plane or frolicking in a field of psychedelic flora?

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in East Harlem, the West Village and Mott Haven.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 600-square-foot apartment with an open floor plan, built-ins in the bedroom, frosted-glass barn doors, central air-conditioning and a balcony, on the ninth floor of a 12-story doorman building with a garden, gym, roof deck, residents’ lounge, children’s play area, bike room, shared laundry and a live-in super. Jenny Delaney, Bond New York, 917-208-9185; bondnewyork.com

headline: New Images of Jupiter’s Moon Io Capture Infernal Volcanic Landscape
abstract: Juno, a NASA mission designed to study Jupiter’s origins, sent back new views of the most eruptive world in the solar system.
lead_paragraph: A NASA spacecraft swooped past Io, one of Jupiter’s largest moons and the most volcanically active world in our solar system. The spacecraft, the Juno orbiter, made its closest flyby yet of Io’s turbulent landscape, and sent back snapshots speckled with sharp cliffs, edgy mountain peaks, lakes of pooled lava and even a volcanic plume.

headline: What High School Is Like in 2023: The Winners of Our Multimedia Challenge
abstract: Via essays, poems, videos, photos, a graph, a GIF and a diorama, 25 students and teachers across the globe reflect on their lives in school.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, as The Learning Network celebrated 25 years of helping people teach and learn with the news, it seemed to us that education issues were making more headlines than ever.

headline: How Do You Feel About High School?
abstract: Scroll through some work by the winning students and educators who participated in our “What High School Is Like in 2023” multimedia challenge. Then tell us how well the collection captures your experiences.
lead_paragraph: Please note: We invite teenagers and adults to reflect on the winning student and teacher work from our “What High School Is Like in 2023” challenge by posting comments here.

headline: 8 Fitness Myths That Drive Experts Crazy
abstract: Running is bad for your knees. The heavier the weight the better. Ice baths. And more.
lead_paragraph: When done right, exercise can be a veritable miracle drug. But follow the wrong advice and you can easily set yourself up for injury. Take the sit-up: Once considered the gold standard of core exercises, we now know that it can make low-back pain worse.

headline: Fresh Spring Rolls, Pan-Seared Chicken With Harissa, and Salt and Vinegar Kale Chips
abstract: Fast and fun recipes for any resolution.
lead_paragraph: Tanya Sichynsky — a senior staff editor you might know from The Veggie — has written a friendly “start here” guide for common cooking resolutions. It’s worth a read, especially for this encouraging suggestion: “Try to become just a little bit better at something, rather than change your habits wholesale.” If one of your resolutions is to eat less red meat, we have plenty of inspiring recipes for you, including this new one by Ali Slagle for fresh spring rolls. They’re light yet filling, especially if eaten with a limey, chile-spiked peanut sauce.

headline: Christie Says in a New Ad That He Was Wrong to Support Trump in 2016
abstract: “Now, we’re confronted with the very same choice again,” former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said in the ad, rejecting calls to end his campaign in order to narrow the anti-Trump field.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said in a new ad released Thursday that he had been wrong to endorse Donald J. Trump in 2016.

headline: Major French Retailer Drops PepsiCo Products Over High Prices
abstract: Carrefour, a supermarket chain, said the maker of Pepsi, Lay’s and 7-Up was keeping its food “unacceptably” expensive despite falling inflation.
lead_paragraph: The economic headlines in Europe have been glowing recently: Inflation, according to official statistics, is finally coming down. But tell that to consumers still facing runaway prices when they head to the supermarket.

headline: He Ran the Uffizi. Can He Run Florence?
abstract: The museum’s former director, Eike Schmidt, is toying — somewhat mischievously — with entering the race to become Florence’s mayor.
lead_paragraph: Will he? Or won’t he?

headline: How a Drag Queen Event That Never Happened Forced a Library to Shut Down
abstract: In April, Drag Queen Story Hour was announced. Protests erupted, and by September, the library was forced to close. It still hasn’t reopened.
lead_paragraph: Lake Luzerne, in upstate New York, is a small mountain town of weathered clapboard houses, with a spired church on Main Street and a public library that offered internet access, a food pantry and twice-weekly story hours for children.

headline: Paxlovid Cuts Covid Death Risk. But Those Who Need It Are Not Taking It.
abstract: With Covid deaths rising to about 1,500 per week, researchers question why Paxlovid use has remained low among high-risk patients.
lead_paragraph: As Covid rises again, killing about 1,500 Americans each week, medical researchers are trying to understand why so few people are taking Paxlovid, a medicine that is stunningly effective in preventing severe illness and death from the disease.

headline: Why London’s Tube Is Shutting Down Next Week
abstract: Large strikes by workers on the London Underground are expected to cripple the capital’s transportation network for several days.
lead_paragraph: Update: The mayor of London on Sunday announced that the planned Tube strike had been suspended.

headline: How Trump Has Used Fear and Favor to Win Republican Endorsements
abstract: The former president keeps careful watch over his endorsements from elected Republicans, aided by a disciplined and methodical behind-the-scenes operation.
lead_paragraph: On his last day as president on Jan. 20, 2021, Donald J. Trump stood in a snapping wind and waved goodbye to relatives and supporters before he took his final flight on Air Force One back to Mar-a-Lago. No elected Republican of any stature showed up at Joint Base Andrews for the bleak farewell.

headline: Trump Wants Prosecutors Held in Contempt in Federal Election Case
abstract: The former president’s lawyers sought to have Jack Smith and two deputies explain why they should not be held in contempt of court for taking new steps in the case after it was put on hold.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump said on Thursday that they want the special counsel, Jack Smith, and two of his top deputies to be held in contempt of court and sanctioned for violating a judge’s order that effectively froze the criminal case accusing Mr. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I have an ambivalent reaction to writers’ biographies — in the balancing act between artists and their art, I’ll take the art on its own in almost every instance. But I do appreciate learning about the people who made it, especially if they led interesting or unusual lives, and all the more so if those lives can illuminate aspects of the work. So it’s a safe bet that, having started last year by reading Willa Cather’s “My Ántonia,” I’ll spend some time at the beginning of this year with Benjamin Taylor’s new Cather biography, “Chasing Bright Medusas,” which Andrea Barrett’s review calls “a brief, clear introduction to Cather’s life and work.” That’s on our reading list this week; why not add it to yours?

headline: New York Could Become First State to Offer Paid Leave for Prenatal Care
abstract: The plan is among several the governor is proposing to address what leaders have called a maternal health crisis in New York.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Thursday proposed a series of initiatives to address maternal and infant death in New York, including one that would make the state the first to provide paid leave for prenatal care.

headline: Where Did the Snow Go?
abstract: “A visceral feeling of what climate change looks and feels like.”
lead_paragraph: Almost no one in the United States experienced a white Christmas. Ski areas in the West are closed. The Great Lakes began the year with the lowest amount of ice in at least 50 years. Midwesterners are jogging in T-shirts in the dead of winter.

headline: Winter Storm Traps Hundreds of Motorists Overnight in Sweden
abstract: Truck drivers and other motorists were locked in blankets of snow on a major roadway overnight after nearly 10 inches of snow fell within 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: Thick blankets of snow and strong winds trapped hundreds of motorists in their vehicles overnight on Wednesday on a major roadway in southern Sweden, forcing emergency workers to call for help from the Swedish military.

headline: Year of the Vegetable
abstract: In for 2024: meatless meals, project cooking, luxurious breakfasts and energizing snacks.
lead_paragraph: Optimism abounds this time of year, the temporal fresh start a necessary reminder of our own potential for improvement, for clarity, for fulfillment. Last week, I encouraged readers to share their resolutions for the new year. I was moved by their buoyancy, particularly this note, from Suzanne:

headline: Mike Sadler, Intrepid Desert Navigator in World War II, Dies at 103
abstract: Like a human GPS, he guided Britain’s first special forces across the vast Sahara for hit-and-run raids on enemy bases in the battle against Rommel’s forces.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Mike Sadler, a World War II navigator on the trackless Sahara of North Africa, who guided Britain’s first special forces across sand seas on daring behind-the-lines night raids that blew up enemy aircraft on the ground and troops in their billets, died on Thursday in Cambridge, England. He was 103.

headline: As the Art World Watches, an Oligarch Takes an Auction House to Court
abstract: At trial next week, Dmitry Rybolovlev is set to accuse Sotheby’s of helping an art dealer trick him into wildly overspending for works, a claim the company disputes.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, when Dmitry Rybolovlev, a Russian oligarch, was in the midst of buying $2 billion worth of art, one of the many works he purchased was “Tête,” a sculpture by Modigliani, for $83 million. That, he says, was the price Yves Bouvier, a man helping to handle the transaction, told him the seller would need to part with such a masterpiece.

headline: Martha Diamond, Painter Who Captured New York Vistas, Dies at 79
abstract: Her work, at the border of representation and abstraction, influenced younger painters. But she did not gain broad public recognition until late in life.
lead_paragraph: Martha Diamond, a painter’s painter who captured the endlessly changing face of New York’s buildings, streets and light-filled vistas with deceptively simple expanses of color, died on Saturday. She was 79.

headline: What to Watch This Weekend: Catch Up on ‘The Curse’
abstract: The second-to-last episode of this cringe dramedy starring Emma Stone, Nathan Fielder and Benny Safdie arrives this weekend. There’s still time to watch before the season finale.
lead_paragraph: “The Curse,” a nightmare-tinted drama about aspiring HGTV hosts, starring Nathan Fielder, Emma Stone and Benny Safdie, is approaching its finale; the show’s ninth of 10 episodes arrives this weekend: Friday on Paramount+ and Sunday at 9 p.m., on Showtime. The show’s discomfort is so intense it becomes mythical, its white awkwardness so potent that those in its blast zone question reality.

headline: Vatican Defends Gay Blessings, but Offers Critics Some Leeway
abstract: The clarification on a declaration issued in December seemed designed to soothe critics while also showing that this is the way forward.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since Pope Francis approved a rule allowing the blessing of same-sex couples, some bishops in conservative corners of the church, such as Africa, have said they wouldn’t allow priests to perform the practice, which they believe contradicts church doctrine.

headline: Kentucky Clerk Who Denied Same-Sex Marriage Licenses Must Pay $260,000 in Legal Fees
abstract: Kim Davis, the former county clerk who refused to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples, must pay a couple’s legal fees and expenses, a judge ruled. A jury previously ordered her to pay the couple $100,000 in damages.
lead_paragraph: Kim Davis, the former county clerk in Kentucky who said she refused to issue same-sex marriage licenses in 2015 because of her religious beliefs, must pay more than $260,000 in expenses and attorney fees to a couple whom she denied a license, a judge has ruled.

headline: June Jackson Christmas, Pioneering Psychiatrist, Dies at 99
abstract: Dr. Christmas overcame race and gender barriers to run New York’s mental health agency under three mayors in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: June Jackson Christmas, a psychiatrist who broke barriers as a Black woman by heading New York City’s Department of Mental Health and Retardation Services under three mayors, died on Sunday in the Bronx. She was 99.

headline: Massachusetts Switches On Its First Large Offshore Wind Farm
abstract: Vineyard Wind is the country’s second large-scale offshore project to start producing electricity and comes at a turbulent time for the industry.
lead_paragraph: The first large offshore wind farm in New England has started producing electricity, a milestone for an industry that has struggled to get off the ground over the past year.

headline: Trump Meets With Teamsters President as Union Weighs 2024 Endorsement
abstract: The Teamsters union has yet to endorse a presidential candidate, even as President Biden has called himself the most pro-union president in history.
lead_paragraph: Sean M. O’Brien, the general president of the Teamsters union, sat down with former President Donald J. Trump on Wednesday at Mr. Trump’s seaside mansion, Mar-a-Lago, in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: ‘Night Swim’ Review: Hold Your Breath, Forever
abstract: The backyard pool is a symbol of love and of terror in this uneven but scary horror film.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood horror often attempts to work out collective anxiety about the suburbs, that place full of pleasant-looking houses creaking with ghosts and terrors. Suburban life is, admittedly, fundamentally strange, with neighborhoods full of atomized worlds and natural features turned into individual, highly-controlled assets. A forest becomes manicured bushes. A lake becomes a pool.

headline: Should Trump Be Removed From the Ballot?
abstract: Readers react to recent articles about the 14th Amendment. Also: Reflections on Claudine Gay’s resignation as the president of Harvard.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Problems Only Start With Plagiarism
abstract: Academics have to do a much better job of keeping it out of the ivory tower.
lead_paragraph: Plagiarism is perhaps the mildest academic sin, as well as the easiest to detect. There are innumerable cases of more serious forms of misconduct — such as the falsification and fabrication of data — that have stained the reputations of universities all over the world. If academia really wants to tackle the problem, it’s got to rethink the way it judges and rewards research — and tell good from bad.

headline: The Claudine Gay Debacle Was Never About Merit
abstract: Merit, itself, cannot be defined. That is why the concept is so useful for slippery slopes.
lead_paragraph: Claudine Gay’s resignation this week as Harvard University’s president marks the end of a shameful chapter for the institution. The debacle’s architects promise to make America’s elite institutions great again. They say they pushed out Dr. Gay and, nearly a month ago, the University of Pennsylvania’s president as a warning to the nation’s cultural institutions. How they will continue to wield their influence and if they will succeed depends on how willing we all are to keep buying age-old ideas about merit from power-hungry peddlers.

headline: Get Ready for a Bumpy Ride
abstract: 2024 will be a year like no other
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our first Trump on Trial newsletter of 2024, a year that’s almost certain to put American democracy to the test.

headline: ‘Reacher’: Women Want What He’s Got, and Not Just the Beefcake
abstract: The hit Amazon series about a bone-crushing crime fighter isn’t only Dad TV. Women dream of having the character’s freedom and abilities, too.
lead_paragraph: You may have felt the tremor: A jacked-up beast of a guy has wandered into TV Land, and his name is Reacher. Season 1 of the Amazon series that bears his name was a monster hit when it dropped in early 2022, and Season 2, which concludes on Jan. 19, appears to be even bigger, becoming Prime Video’s No. 1 title globally on its debut weekend. And the series is crushing it critically the way Reacher crushes a villain’s skull. As of early January, the new season had a 100 percent rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with an 84 percent audience score — when do critics ever rate a brawny action show higher than the audience?

headline: New York City Sues Bus Companies That Brought 30,000 Migrants From Texas
abstract: The lawsuit accuses 17 companies of carrying out a plan by the governor of Texas to send tens of thousands of migrants to New York.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York on Thursday ratcheted up his feud with Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas, filing suit against 17 transportation companies that he said had carried out a plan by Mr. Abbott to send more than 30,000 migrants to New York City and make the city pay for their care.

headline: White House Says North Korea Providing Russia With Ballistic Missiles
abstract: Russia has rebuilt its own domestic supply of cruise missiles, but to keep up with the intensity of the barrage against Ukraine, it has been turning to North Korea and Iran.
lead_paragraph: The White House accused North Korea on Thursday of providing Russia with ballistic missiles that Moscow has begun to fire on targets in Ukraine, and said that in return the North was seeking a range of Russian military technologies.

headline: Education Dept. Official Resigns Over Biden’s Policies on Israel and Gaza
abstract: Tariq Habash, who is Palestinian American, said the Biden administration “does not value all human life equally.”
lead_paragraph: A top adviser at the Education Department has resigned over President Biden’s handling of the Israel-Hamas war, the second official to do so as the administration faces divisions over U.S. support for Israel’s bombardment in Gaza.

headline: Friday Briefing: Islamic State Claims the Iran Bombing
abstract: Plus the seven keys to longevity.
lead_paragraph: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for a bombing attack that killed at least 84 people in Kerman, Iran, on Wednesday, according to a post on the extremist group’s official Telegram account.

headline: New Year, Very Old Restaurants
abstract: Start 2024 with the classics: prime rib hash at Keens, a grilled Muenster on black bread with sautéed mushrooms at the Old Town and more.
lead_paragraph: Happy new year. January is usually a month of fresh starts and new chapters. But to tell you the truth, I’m not ready to face the future yet. I don’t know if it’s the short afternoons, the feeble sunshine, the chafing wind or just a creeping dread of what might be down the road. But after New Year’s Day, when other people are ordering mocktails and grinding away on the Peloton, I often find myself in some old restaurant or other, holding a beer and dwelling on the past.

headline: Trump Ballot Challenges Advance, Varying Widely in Strategy and Sophistication
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s eligibility for the presidential ballot has been challenged in more than 30 states, but only a handful of those cases have gained traction so far.
lead_paragraph: John Anthony Castro, a 40-year-old Texan, long-shot Republican presidential candidate and the most prolific challenger of Donald J. Trump’s eligibility to be president, has gone to court in at least 27 states trying to remove the former president from the ballot.

headline: Subway Trains Collide in Manhattan, Causing Derailment, M.T.A. Says
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said that 24 people were injured in the collision near 96th Street. Their injuries were not serious, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Service on three subway lines remained disrupted on the West Side of Manhattan on Friday after a train carrying about 300 people collided with an out-of-service train near West 96th Street a day earlier, causing the trains to derail, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said.

headline: Glynis Johns, Tony Winner for ‘A Little Night Music,’ Dies at 100
abstract: In a trans-Atlantic career that endured for more than 60 years, she was also known for her role in the hit Disney movie “Mary Poppins.”
lead_paragraph: Glynis Johns, the British actress who in a trans-Atlantic career that endured for more than 60 years won a Tony Award for her role in “A Little Night Music,” giving husky, emotion-rich voice to the show’s most memorable number, “Send In the Clowns,” and played an exuberant Edwardian suffragist in the Disney movie classic “Mary Poppins,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 100.

headline: Anthony Dias Blue, Whose Writing Elevated California Wines, Dies at 82
abstract: A longtime editor at Bon Appétit and a radio personality, he helped millions gain a new appreciation for the American wineries he loved.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Dias Blue, a longtime wine writer and radio personality whose love for California whites and reds helped elevate the reputation of American vintners, died on Dec. 25 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 82.

headline: Judge Refuses to Send Defendant in Drug Case to Troubled Brooklyn Jail
abstract: A federal judge ordered that a man remain free to await sentencing rather than be sent to the Metropolitan Detention Center, citing terrible conditions there.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge, citing complaints of dreadful conditions, near perpetual lockdowns and grave staffing shortages in a long-troubled federal jail in Brooklyn, refused Wednesday to order a man convicted in a drug case to be sent there while awaiting sentencing in March.

headline: Ambulance Workers in Texas Are Reeling Under the Border Surge
abstract: Washington politicians are traveling to Eagle Pass, Texas, to highlight the politics of the border crisis. For local officials, the real cost is measured in lives and money.
lead_paragraph: Through the long, busy months of autumn, the calls kept coming in: Mothers losing grip of their children while trying to cross the treacherous waters of the Rio Grande. Pregnant women getting caught in barbed wire. Bodies washing up on shore.

headline: The Messenger, Which Aimed to Transform Media, Faces Dire Financial Straits
abstract: The company, which debuted last year with big plans to disrupt journalism, generated only $3 million in revenue by the end of December.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before the media start-up The Messenger launched last year, its president said the company planned to generate more than $100 million of revenue in 2024. It will need a major turn in fortune to get there.

headline: How to Claim a Share of Verizon’s $100 Million Proposed Settlement
abstract: Verizon customers that were charged administrative fees are eligible to apply, though payments are likely to be small and rise to $100 at most.
lead_paragraph: Some Verizon customers may be entitled to claim part of a $100 million proposed settlement that the wireless carrier agreed to pay to resolve a class-action lawsuit, according to a claims website set up by a settlement administrator.

headline: Biden Faces Pressure on Immigration, and Not Just From Republicans
abstract: Mayors and governors from President Biden’s own party are looking for help with overflowing migrant encampments, packed shelters and busted budgets.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is under growing pressure to curb record numbers of migrants crossing into the United States — not just from the usual Republican critics, but also from Democratic mayors and governors in cities thousands of miles from the border.

headline: And the 2023 Oscar Nominees Should Be …
abstract: Academy voters will do what they want, but if our chief critics had their way, these are the films and performers that would be up for Oscars this year.
lead_paragraph: Academy voters will do what they want, but if our chief critics had their way, these are the films and performers that would be up for Oscars this year.

headline: A U.S. Strike Killed an Iran-allied Militant Leader
abstract: Also, Biden faces immigration pressure from Democrats. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. drone strike in Baghdad today killed the leader of a militant group linked to Iran that is part of Iraq’s security apparatus.

headline: Tech Executive Sold Banned Chinese Products to State Agencies, U.S. Says
abstract: The owner of a technology company persuaded New Jersey public safety officials to spend at least $35 million on security equipment, a federal complaint says.
lead_paragraph: The owner of a technology company duped public safety and law enforcement agencies in New Jersey into spending at least $35 million, including $15 million in Covid-19 relief and other federal funding, on banned Chinese surveillance and security equipment, according to a complaint unveiled this week.

headline: DeSantis PAC Makes Donations to Iowa Lawmakers Who Endorsed Him
abstract: Ron DeSantis has aggressively sought the endorsements of influential Iowans.
lead_paragraph: A political action committee controlled by Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida donated tens of thousands of dollars to Iowa legislators who have endorsed his candidacy for president, according to state campaign finance records.

headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in January
abstract: This week, Jillian Steinhauer covers Dara Birnbaum’s video art, an intergenerational group show of Atlanta-based artists and Nickola Pottinger’s painted pulp sculptures.
lead_paragraph: This week, Jillian Steinhauer covers Dara Birnbaum’s video art, an intergenerational group show of Atlanta-based artists and Nickola Pottinger’s painted pulp sculptures.

headline: Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley and Politically Obtuse Plutocrats
abstract: The big money still doesn’t understand today’s G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: All Wall Street wants is a good hypocrite — someone who can convince the Republican base that he or she shares its extremism, but whose real priority is to enrich the 1 percent. Is that too much to ask?

headline: What Biden Needs to Tell Us
abstract: A presidential vision for a positive-sum world of innovation and peace.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes social revolutions emerge from ordinary ideas. In the 17th and 18th centuries, thinkers like William Petty, David Hume and Adam Smith popularized a concept called “division of labor.” It’s a simple notion. If I specialize in doing what I’m good at, and you specialize in what you’re good at, and we exchange what we’ve each made, then we’ll both be more productive and better off than if we tried to be self-sufficient.

headline: Uranus and Neptune Reveal Their True Colors
abstract: Neptune is not as blue as you’ve been led to believe, and Uranus’s shifting colors are better explained, in new research.
lead_paragraph: Think of Uranus and Neptune, the solar system’s outermost planets, and you may picture two distinct hues: pale turquoise and cobalt blue. But astronomers say that the true colors of these distant ice giants are more similar than their popular depictions.

headline: Vinie Burrows, Acclaimed Actress Who Became an Activist, Dies at 99
abstract: Her Broadway career blossomed in the 1950s. But after finding a dearth of roles for Black women, she turned to one-woman shows that addressed racism and sexism.
lead_paragraph: Vinie Burrows, a Harlem-born stage actress who made her mark on Broadway in the 1950s, but who grew frustrated by how few choice roles were available for Black women and turned her focus to one-woman shows exploring the legacies of racism and sexism, died on Dec. 25 in Queens. She was 99.

headline: Towns Empty and Farms Languish as War Stalks Israeli-Lebanese Border
abstract: More than 150,000 people have been driven from their homes on both sides of the frontier as Israeli forces clash with Hezbollah militants.
lead_paragraph: The border between Israel and Lebanon has become a landscape of abandoned towns and neglected farms as escalating tensions and tit-for-tat strikes between Israeli forces and Hezbollah militants have displaced more than 150,000 people in both countries.

headline: Trains Collide in Indonesia, Leaving 4 Dead
abstract: Hundreds of passengers were evacuated from the crash near the city of Bandung. The cause of the accident was not immediately clear, and the authorities have opened an investigation.
lead_paragraph: Five hundred passengers were evacuated on Friday morning after a train collision near the Indonesian city of Bandung killed four crew members and injured 37 people, officials said.

headline: Day 5: The Magic of Losing Yourself in a Task
abstract: Today, we’ll explore how low-stakes hobbies can energize us.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 5 of the 6-Day Energy Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.

headline: Safdie Brothers Are Done Making Movies Together
abstract: Josh and Benny Safdie are officially splitting up.
lead_paragraph: The Safdie brothers, the filmmaking duo behind “Uncut Gems” (2019) and “Good Time” (2017), are splitting up.

headline: Dark Side of the Moon
abstract: David P. Williams reveals a third stanza in his mash-up of crossword and poetry.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Going Too Far
abstract: Alex Eaton-Salners’s puzzle goes off the rails.
lead_paragraph: GOING TOO FAR — It’s been too long, nearly two years, since we’ve “gone too far” and solved one of these fan favorites in the Variety puzzle genre. Fortunately, Alex Eaton-Salners (another fan favorite) still has them in his construction rotation, among his blizzard of offerings that include Diagramless and Puns and Anagrams Variety puzzles, as well as frequent daily grids.

headline: U.S. Mint Releases Harriet Tubman Coins
abstract: Three commemorative coins featuring Ms. Tubman were released for purchase on Thursday. They were expected to ship out next month, the U.S. Mint said.
lead_paragraph: As the yearslong process to put Harriet Tubman on the $20 bill continues, Americans can now buy coins bearing her portrait.

headline: Two Trains Collide in Indonesia
abstract: Passengers were being evacuated after the crash on the island of Java.
lead_paragraph: Passengers were being evacuated after the crash on the island of Java.

headline: Florida Proud Boy Sentenced to 10 Years in Capitol Attack
abstract: Christopher Worrell had gone on the run after his conviction last August, and was captured six weeks later.
lead_paragraph: A Proud Boy from Florida who went on the lam after being convicted of using pepper spray on police officers during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced on Thursday to 10 years in prison.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Teenage Boy ‘Beats’ Tetris, Joining A.I. at the Top
abstract: Quotation of the Day for January 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t feel my fingers.”

headline: My Bad-Times-Only Boyfriend
abstract: Why is my long-ago fling suddenly acting as if he’s my husband?
lead_paragraph: I untangled my IV from the machine and hobbled backward into my crunchy hospital bed, directing my gaze at the Empire State Building to avoid making eye contact with the man on the couch.

headline: Circling Each Other For Years Before Their Paths Intersected
abstract: Garrison Rufa and Theodore Lavoie grew up in New England and were both avid snowboarders, but they didn’t meet until they matched on Tinder.
lead_paragraph: How Garrison Anne Rufa and Theodore Joseph Lavoie didn’t meet before they did is a mystery to them both. The two were avid snowboarders growing up in New England, which has a tight-knit snowboarding community.

headline: A Love Match That Crossed Continents and Cultures
abstract: Shoshana Heerter, who is Jewish, and Rahul Boga, who is Hindu and from India, met online and bonded over their differences. But they had to get creative about convincing their traditional families.
lead_paragraph: In June 2021, Shoshana Beth Heerter was swiping so perfunctorily on Tinder that she inadvertently swiped left on Rahul Kishore Boga’s profile. Immediately, it was as if somehow she sensed she made a mistake.

headline: A High School Romance Goes the Distance
abstract: Julia Gerard and Adam Romund began dating their senior year of high school. And after each had both earned an undergraduate degree, it was clear that an engagement was imminent.
lead_paragraph: Although they attended the same high school in Rochester Hills, Mich., Julia Marie Gerard and Adam Edward Romund never crossed paths until their senior year. They were placed in the same personal finance class and became fast friends. The two began spending more time together outside of class, attempting to prepare for their A.P. calculus exam.

headline: Red Sea Attacks Leave Tankers With Choice: Accept the Risks or Lose Money
abstract: Some oil tanker traffic continues to go through the Suez Canal, while plentiful global reserves keep crude prices steady.
lead_paragraph: Attacks on commercial vessels in the Red Sea by the Houthi rebels in Yemen have left oil tanker operators facing an unwelcome calculation: accept the risks of steaming through the danger zone, or lose business.

headline: Oscar Pistorius, Olympic Athlete Convicted of Murder, Is Released
abstract: The South African sprinter, whose trial for the 2013 killing of his girlfriend drew intense global interest, served more than seven years in prison.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Pistorius, the South African athlete hailed as an inspirational figure until he was convicted of killing his girlfriend, was released on parole on Friday after more than seven years in prison.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: The threat of a regional war.
lead_paragraph: The Middle East is coming closer to the brink of a regional war, which the Biden administration has tried to stave off since Hamas’s deadly attacks against Israel on Oct. 7. Growing attacks have forced thousands from their homes at the border between Lebanon and Israel, while Israeli forces continue to pummel the city of Khan Younis in southern Gaza. See the latest updates.

headline: North Korea Fires Artillery Near Border With South Korea
abstract: The South asked nearby islanders to seek shelter before it launched a military exercise in the disputed waters and chided the North for “threatening peace.”
lead_paragraph: North Korea fired 200 rounds of artillery into waters near its disputed western sea border with South Korea on Friday, a move that prompted the South’s military to ask residents on two nearby islands to take shelter.

headline: Word of the Day: aquaculture
abstract: This word has appeared in 14 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word aquaculture has appeared in 14 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 18 in “Sea Creatures From the Deep, Captured in Glass, Rise at Mystic Seaport” by Meredith Mendelsohn:

headline: The U.S. secretary of state begins a Mideast trip amid worries of broader conflict.
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was set on Friday to begin a diplomatic tour through the Middle East, as the Biden administration seeks to defuse tensions in the region, where fears are growing that the war in Gaza could spiral into a broader conflict.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was set on Friday to begin a diplomatic tour through the Middle East, as the Biden administration seeks to defuse tensions in the region, where fears are growing that the war in Gaza could spiral into a broader conflict.

headline: Unauthorized Settlement Surges in Occupied West Bank, Advocacy Group Says
abstract: Peace Now, which monitors settler activity in the West Bank, said it had recorded nine new outposts and several roads not authorized by Israel, fueling tensions in the area.
lead_paragraph: Under the cover of the war in Gaza, Jewish settlers in the occupied West Bank have carried out a “surge” of unauthorized moves to expand their footprint in the territory, according to a report by Peace Now, an Israeli advocacy group that opposes settlements and tracks their progress.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Raking
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating? Does it have a message for you?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Do you think it could offer a message of some kind for you? If so, what is your opinion of that message?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Heavy Rains Hit Parts of the U.K.
abstract: Torrential rainfall partially submerged some homes as residents waded through flooded streets.
lead_paragraph: Torrential rainfall partially submerged some homes as residents waded through flooded streets.

headline: Residents Near Israel-Lebanon Border Live With Uncertainty
abstract: As the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah escalates, some Israeli residents are making trips back to their homes along the border with Lebanon despite orders to stay away, while others wait with uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: As the conflict between Israel and Hezbollah escalates, some Israeli residents are making trips back to their homes along the border with Lebanon despite orders to stay away, while others wait with uncertainty.

headline: U.S. Added 216,000 Jobs in December, Outpacing Forecasts
abstract: Hiring has throttled back from 2021 and 2022, but last year’s growth was still impressive by longer-term standards.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. labor market ended 2023 with a bang, gaining more jobs than experts had expected and buoying hopes that the economy can settle into a solid, sustainable level of growth rather than fall into a recession.

headline: Brisk Wage Gains in December Could Keep the Fed Watchful
abstract: Average hourly earnings climbed 0.4 percent from the previous month, and 4.1 percent compared to a year earlier. That was faster than economists expected.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s jobs data suggested that wages are still climbing briskly as hiring remains strong — facts that could keep the Federal Reserve wary as it contemplates its next move on interest rates.

headline: If Trump Is Not an Insurrectionist, What Is He?
abstract: The former president is just the man the 14th Amendment envisioned barring from office.
lead_paragraph: Last month the states of Colorado and Maine moved to disqualify Donald Trump as a candidate in the 2024 presidential election, citing Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. In response, Trump has asked the Supreme Court to intervene on his behalf in the Colorado case, and he has appealed Maine’s decision.

headline: ‘Richard Scarry’s Cars and Trucks and Things That Go’ Turns 50
abstract: For my family, reading Scarry together was itself like a car trip — the rare sort where no one gets cranky and the world, as seen from the back seat, is fresh and startling.
lead_paragraph: My wife was editing our teenager’s bedroom, hunting things to pass on to his younger cousins, or donate to Goodwill. He is a high school senior aiming for college next fall, and we have lived in this Maine house since his birth, so his room is jammed with artifacts. Baseball gloves and defunct device-chargers; mounds of clothes; an Xbox. Shoes the size of pond boats. Sports trophies. It could be an archaeological site — 17 years of boyhood in uncurated layers.

headline: A Palestinian Man Vanished Oct. 7. His Family Wants to Know Who Killed Him.
abstract: Soheib Abu Amar, who lived in East Jerusalem, was captured by Hamas during its attack on Israel. His brothers spent weeks investigating what happened next.
lead_paragraph: On a clear December morning, two Palestinian brothers stood on a mound in southern Israel that overlooked Gaza, watching smoke rise after Israeli airstrikes.

headline: For Dizzy Gillespie, Queens Was the Place to Be and to Bop
abstract: Rebellious jazz took flight in Harlem at Minton’s Playhouse, but it was nurtured on the tree-lined streets that gave pioneering Black musicians a home.
lead_paragraph: Dizzy Gillespie helped make Minton’s Playhouse famous.

headline: A Factory in Maine Proves ‘Made in America’ Is Still Possible
abstract: What happened to manufacturing in America is a story we think we know but do not.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, my parents drove my brothers and me around in lumbering Fords and ungainly Oldsmobiles until one fateful day in the summer of 1980, when my dad showed up in a brand-new, all-beige VW Rabbit. It was a completely foreign thing, something from the future, a compact — perish the thought — German automobile. Buying a European car was now OK, my dad made a point of telling us, because this one was made in the U.S.A.

headline: A Reinvented ‘True Detective’ Plays It Cool
abstract: Starring Jodie Foster and Kali Reis, the new season travels to Alaska and takes on a decidedly more female perspective, starting with a new showrunner.
lead_paragraph: There were times, a year ago, in Iceland, on a glacier, in the dark, in temperatures well below freezing, when Issa López thought to herself: “Who wrote this? What is wrong with this person?” López, the showrunner and director of Season 4 of the HBO anthology series “True Detective,” had only herself to blame.

headline: How to Start Working Out Again
abstract: We asked experts for advice on creating an exercise plan you can actually stick with — and enjoy.
lead_paragraph: Resolving to get back into exercise or take up a new fitness routine is one of the best things you can do for your health.

headline: Taraji P. Henson Is Tired of Fighting
abstract: The “Color Purple” star talks candidly about her battles to get cast and paid her worth. Even as an Oscar-nominated veteran, she had to audition for her new film.
lead_paragraph: Before things started to click for Taraji P. Henson, she sought career counseling from the man upstairs.

headline: African Migration to the U.S. Soars as Europe Cracks Down
abstract: Thousands of people from African nations are flying to Central America and then traveling over land to Mexico and on to the southern border.
lead_paragraph: The young men from Guinea had decided it was time to leave their impoverished homeland in West Africa. But instead of seeking a new life in Europe, where so many African migrants have settled, they set out for what has become a far safer bet of late: the United States.

headline: Should Trump Be on the Ballot? And Other 2024 Sticky Wickets
abstract: New year, new problems. The hosts try to make sense of it.
lead_paragraph: Is Donald Trump an insurrectionist who should be barred from the ballot? On this episode of “Matter of Opinion,” the hosts discuss who should get to decide if the former president can try to return to the White House. Plus, the hosts lay out what other stories are on their 2024 political bingo cards.

headline: Winter Clothes, Hold the Snow
abstract: Capes, knit caps and woolly coats were plentiful on the streets of New York in December, even though flakes were not.
lead_paragraph: A bright red cape and headband. Creamy cable knit pants. Overcoats of all sorts: Single-breasted and double-breasted, in shades of camel and pink, some skimming knees and others falling closer to the floor.

headline: Starbucks Faces New Pressure Over Union Campaign
abstract: Amid a dissident bid for board seats and boycotts by activists, the company has sent mixed signals about its willingness to engage with labor groups.
lead_paragraph: More than two years into a campaign that has unionized more than 350 Starbucks stores, the company is facing mounting pressure from union officials and activists who say it has illegally retaliated against workers and resisted contract negotiations.

headline: Tired? Distracted? Burned Out? Listen to This.
abstract: A scholar of attention outlines how you can get your focus back.
lead_paragraph: I’m convinced that attention is the most important human faculty. Your life, after all, is just the sum total of the things you’ve paid attention to. And we lament our attention issues all the time: how distracted we are, how drained we feel, how hard it is to stay focused or present. And yet, while there’s no shortage of advice on how to improve our sleep hygiene, or spending, or physical fitness, there’s hardly any good information about how to build and replenish our capacity for paying attention.

headline: Come Home With Memories, Not a Shocking Phone Bill
abstract: Smartphones have become an indispensable part of any trip abroad. How you can use maps, social media and more without racking up international roaming fees.
lead_paragraph: The horror story goes something like this: A family returns from a trip abroad, and the glow from the vacation has barely begun to fade when a cellphone bill with hundreds — or even thousands — of dollars in international charges arrives. The phenomenon even has a name: bill shock.

headline: It Won an Oscar in 1987. It’s Finally Opening in New York.
abstract: “Artie Shaw: Time Is All You’ve Got,” a documentary, was embroiled in lawsuits for years. Now it has a weeklong run at the Film Forum.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll find out about a film that is being shown in New York for the first time. We’ll also see why a judge refused to send a defendant in a drug case to a Brooklyn jail while the man awaits his sentencing in March.

headline: 5 Songs That Will Make You Say ‘Yeah!’
abstract: A tribute to one of pop music’s favorite words.

headline: How to Watch the Golden Globes 2024: Date, Time and Streaming
abstract: Hollywood usually looks to the annual awards as a party, but this year they also have an unlikely mission: A bid for relevance.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the 2024 Golden Globes.

headline: The Families of Hostages Are Calling on Israel to Do Something Radical
abstract: In Israel, they are putting pressure on the government, pushing for a political path to release the remaining hostages.
lead_paragraph: Ido Shamriz turned his eulogy for his brother, Alon, into a protest.

headline: There’s No Place Like Sin City for the Holidays
abstract: After a pandemic hiatus, my family was finally back in Las Vegas for Christmas, and we were up $1.25. The world was ours.
lead_paragraph: It was almost the night before Christmas, and the house was winning.

headline: Like His Illustrations, Leo Lionni Contained Multitudes
abstract: The illustrator of classic children’s books like “Frederick” and “Swimmy” was also a painter, sculptor, graphic designer and more.
lead_paragraph: Before side hustles went mainstream, Leo Lionni was a multitasker — and a compartmentalizer. Best known as the writer and illustrator behind “Frederick,” “Swimmy” and more than 30 other children’s books, Lionni also had a distinguished career as a graphic designer and art director, helping Eric Carle and Andy Warhol get their starts. But, according to his granddaughter, Annie Lionni, the artist kept his own paintings, sculptures, mosaics and lithographs — what he called “art with a capital A” — separate from the rest of his work.

headline: Ozempic and Wegovy Users Had Less Risk of Suicidal Thoughts in Large Study
abstract: The research, supported by the National Institutes of Health, may reassure some patients after a European drug safety agency raised concerns last year.
lead_paragraph: People taking the wildly popular drugs Ozempic, to treat diabetes, and Wegovy, to combat obesity, are slightly less likely to have suicidal thoughts than people who are not taking them, researchers reported on Friday.

headline: DeSantis Lobs Most Forceful Attacks Yet Against Trump, Days Before Iowa Caucuses
abstract: In dueling town halls hosted by CNN, Nikki Haley struggled to find her footing at times, while Ron DeSantis delivered a confident performance.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is finally taking the fight to the front-runner, former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Biden Plans Speech Casting Election as a Fight for Democracy
abstract: The president’s speech on Friday in the battleground state of Pennsylvania represents a bet that many Americans remain shaken by the Jan. 6 attack.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is returning to the battleground state of Pennsylvania on Friday to try to define the 2024 presidential election as an urgent and intensifying fight for American democracy.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Jan. 5, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Daniel Levy's film “Good Grief” on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Daniel Levy's film “Good Grief” on Netflix.

headline: Where Downtown Poets Go to Church to Greet the New Year
abstract: On the first day of the year, over a thousand devotees passed through the old church where the Poetry Project has held its annual 12-hour marathon for the last half-century.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of New Year’s Day, along the sleepy streets of the East Village in Manhattan, scarf-bundled crowds trickled into St. Mark’s Church in-the-Bowery to attend a 12-hour poetry reading that has been a spiritually cleansing downtown tradition since the 1970s. To its devotees, the gathering’s hypnotically lengthy programming of readings and avant-garde performances provides a dependably radical initiation into the new year.

headline: ‘The Curse’ Season 1, Episode 9 Recap: ‘All in’
abstract: “Green Queen” gets an awkward early screening as Whitney tries to broach her feelings with Asher.
lead_paragraph: It’s amazing what a reality television edit can do. Throughout “The Curse,” we’ve been exposed to what Asher and Whitney look like acting for the cameras, but we have rarely seen what they are like when they are actually on camera, once they’ve gotten the glossy treatment that the Property Brothers and other hosts have before them.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's selection includes titles by Kyle Chayka, Matthew Delmont, Laura Zigman and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's selection includes titles by Kyle Chayka, Matthew Delmont, Laura Zigman and more.

headline: America Must Face Up to Israel’s Extremism
abstract: Government ministers’ calls to depopulate Gaza implicate the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Two far-right members of Israel’s cabinet — the national security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, and the finance minister, Bezalel Smotrich — caused an international uproar this week with their calls to depopulate Gaza. “If in Gaza there will be 100,000 or 200,000 Arabs and not two million the entire conversation on ‘the day after’ will look different,” said Smotrich, who called for most Gazan civilians to be resettled in other countries. The war, said Ben-Gvir, presents an “opportunity to concentrate on encouraging the migration of the residents of Gaza,” facilitating Israeli settlement in the region.

headline: The Times Sues OpenAI, a Debate Over iMessage and Our New Year’s Tech Resolutions
abstract: “This is sort of the big kahuna.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft last week for copyright infringement. Kevin Roose and Casey Newton walk through the lawsuit and discuss the stakes for news publishers. Then, they talk about Apple’s “walled garden,” which is facing threats from both regulators and 16-year-olds. Finally, we set our tech resolutions for the new year.

headline: The Jan. 6 Inquiry Three Years On, and a PepsiCo Boycott in France
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: A Confusing New World for College Applicants
abstract: How high-school seniors have navigated the Supreme Court’s landmark ruling against affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: In a landmark ruling last summer, the U.S. Supreme Court overturned nearly 50 years of precedent and banned the use of affirmative action in college admissions.

headline: Officer Who Defended Capitol on Jan. 6 Runs for Congress in Maryland
abstract: Harry Dunn, who endured racist slurs as he fought off a pro-Trump mob and gained fame with his emotional testimony before the Jan. 6 committee, is joining a crowded Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: Harry Dunn, a former U.S. Capitol Police officer who rose to prominence for his defense of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, and for his emotional public testimony describing the attack, announced on Friday that he was running for Congress in Maryland’s third district.

headline: A One-Sided Affair as Bangladesh’s Ailing Democracy Goes to the Polls
abstract: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina is expected to roll to a fourth consecutive term as the gutted opposition boycotts what it calls an unfair election.
lead_paragraph: There is little doubt that Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina will seize a fourth consecutive term when Bangladesh goes to the polls on Sunday. The bigger question is what will remain of the country’s democracy.

headline: Heavy Rain in U.K. Causes Hundreds of Flood Warnings and Travel Disruptions
abstract: In London, around 50 people were evacuated from rising waters. Heavy rain brought similar scenes to parts of France and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Torrential rains that swept across parts of England overnight prompted a wave of weather alerts and travel disruptions early Friday, forecasters and officials said, warning that some rivers could see flooding continue for days.

headline: Beyond the Front Lines
abstract: The war in Ukraine has entered a new phase.
lead_paragraph: The war in Ukraine has again entered a new phase. With neither side believing that it can make significant territorial gains, the action has expanded beyond the front lines.

headline: Eurozone Price Pressures Edged Higher to End the Year
abstract: Inflation in the countries that use the euro rose to 2.9 percent in December, but the underlying rate continued a downward trend.
lead_paragraph: Inflation across the countries using the common European currency rose at the end of 2023, after falling steadily over the past months, as government subsidies to help consumers manage energy costs ran out.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 5, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 5, 2024.
