lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about a colonel who said the Army punished him for claiming generals lied about Jan. 6 misstated Gen. Charles Flynn’s role in the Army at the time of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol. He was a deputy chief of staff, not the commander of the Pacific.

headline: Our Five-Star Kale Salad to Zhuzh Up However You Please
abstract: With its simple olive oil, lemon and garlic dressing, Julia Moskin’s kale classic is a launchpad for any and all improvisations.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I took a few days off and went down to Florida to visit family. We ate like royals. There was bo ssam for Christmas Eve and ham for dinner the next day. One night led to barbecue shrimp straight from the boat, another to grouper fish tacos from a similar vessel.

headline: F.D.A. Issues First Approval for Mass Drug Imports to States From Canada
abstract: The agency authorized Florida to purchase medicines directly from wholesalers in Canada, where prices are far cheaper. Pharmaceutical companies oppose the plan.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has allowed Florida to import millions of dollars worth of medications from Canada at far lower prices than in the United States, overriding fierce decades-long objections from the pharmaceutical industry.

headline: What Investors and the Fed Will Look For in the Jobs Report
abstract: All eyes will be on the latest nonfarm payrolls data scheduled for release on Friday. Here’s what to look out for.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street, the White House and the Fed will all be watching Friday’s jobs report for signs of how the labor market is holding up. The numbers may also deliver clues on the central bank’s next move on interest rates.

headline: Audiobook of the Week: Safiya Sinclair’s Rhythmic Incantations
abstract: Reading her audiobook memoir, “How to Say Babylon,” the poet gives voice to her Jamaican roots, her early ambition and the Rastafari father who would have quashed it.
lead_paragraph: After her strict Rastafari father threatens to kick her out of the family home for refusing to cower to his verbal abuse, a teenage Safiya Sinclair looks out into the darkness of the Jamaican mountains, “the thick countryside where our first slave rebellion was born,” and sees the specter of a woman dressed in white, her dreadlocked head bowed “under the gaze of a Rastaman.” The woman, she realizes, is herself, a harbinger of “the future that awaited me at my father’s hands.”

headline: Fire Engulfs 5 Buildings at Storied Singer Sewing Industrial Site
abstract: A predawn blaze raged for most of Friday near New York harbor, leading to the collapse of three buildings. Plumes of dark smoke were visible miles away.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 firefighters from New York City and northern New Jersey battled a large warehouse fire on Friday, pumping water from New York Harbor onto a blaze that eventually engulfed five industrial buildings in Elizabeth, N.J.

headline: He Went Out for Cigarettes. A Decade Later, His Car Was Found in a Pond.
abstract: Donald Erwin, a 59-year-old disabled veteran, disappeared in 2013 after leaving his home in the Ozarks. Last month, a YouTube diver found his car submerged at a nearby property.
lead_paragraph: One morning in late December 2013, Donald L. Erwin, a 59-year-old disabled veteran, told his wife he was going to buy cigarettes.

headline: With ‘Good Grief,’ Daniel Levy Goes From Laughs to Tears
abstract: A talk with the co-creator of “Schitt’s Creek” on making the transition to drama with his feature directorial debut.
lead_paragraph: “Good Grief” might have made an alternate name for “Schitt’s Creek,” the multi-Emmy-winning comedy Daniel Levy created and starred in with his father, Eugene. But unlike that series, which mined comedy from the dynamics of a family in financial crisis, Levy’s latest project, a drama, explores how loss affects a close-knit group of friends who are in their late 30s.

headline: Who Are All the Candidates Running for L.A. County District Attorney?
abstract: The incumbent George Gascón, who was first elected in 2020, faces 11 challengers, many of them from within his own office.
lead_paragraph: After the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis ignited protests across the country against police brutality, voters in Los Angeles County chose to take their criminal justice system in a new direction by electing George Gascón as district attorney.

headline: I.R.S. to Begin Trial of Its Own Free Tax-Filing System
abstract: Residents of 12 states are eligible to participate if they meet certain criteria. But the agency’s plans have already met resistance from tax preparation companies.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service is rolling out a free option for filing federal tax returns this year to some residents of a dozen states.

headline: To Bolster Russia’s Army, Putin Eases Citizenship Path for Foreign Fighters
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin is seeking to strengthen his military to fight in Ukraine while avoiding a potentially unpopular mobilization of Russians.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has approved a measure that makes it easier for foreigners to acquire Russian citizenship if they enlist in the army amid the war in Ukraine, part of an effort to increase the military’s ranks while also sparing Russians from being deployed to the battlefield.

headline: Richard Gaddes, Opera Impresario Who Spotted Young Talent, Dies at 81
abstract: As leader of opera companies in Santa Fe and St. Louis, he welcomed new works as well as new artists.
lead_paragraph: Richard Gaddes, a British-born opera impresario who nurtured young talent as director of companies in Santa Fe, N.M., and St Louis, died on Dec. 12 in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: Human Error Likely Caused Subway Crash and Derailings, Officials Say
abstract: The collision of two trains, which injured 26 people, appears to have been caused by confusion over which vehicle had the right of way.
lead_paragraph: A collision between two subway trains in Manhattan on Thursday occurred when a train carrying about 300 passengers was driven into the path of an out-of-service train because of confusion over which vehicle had the right of way, according to three transit officials with knowledge of the investigation into the crash.

headline: Three years later, Jan. 6 hangs over the presidential contest.
abstract: President Biden is using the weekend anniversary of the Capitol attack for a speech on democracy, seeking to set himself apart from Donald J. Trump, who is heading to Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Saturday is the third anniversary of the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol. The consequences of that fateful day still reverberate through American politics, and its fallout looms intensely over the 2024 presidential race.

headline: Blinken Returns to Middle East as Tensions Grow With Israel
abstract: Details of a clash between the U.S. secretary of state and Israel’s prime minister point to the challenges ahead.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken is returning to the Middle East this week with the goals of getting Israel to curtail attacks that are killing thousands of Palestinian civilians and preventing the war from spreading across the region.

headline: Wall Street Sobers Up After December’s Rally
abstract: The S&P 500 logged its first weekly decline since October, ending Wall Street’s longest winning streak in nearly 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s longest weekly winning streak in almost 20 years came to an end on Friday, as stock investors’ celebrations over slowing inflation and the potential for cuts to interest rates were replaced with caution over the lingering risks to the economy.

headline: In a Land of Primary Colors, Home Is Where the Bounce House Is
abstract: As part of Under the Radar, Nile Harris resurrects his play that weaves together text, sound, minstrelsy and dance to explore the American experience.
lead_paragraph: What makes a house a home? And what constitutes an American home? Planted dead center on the stage in “This House Is Not a Home,” a slippery, ever-shifting work by Nile Harris, is a house — a bounce house. But it’s more than an inflatable plaything.

headline: Brooklyn Museum, Courting Pop-Culture Icons, Readies for Alicia Keys and Swizz Beatz
abstract: Next month, over 100 works by Black art stars from the couple’s collection will travel to the Great Hall for “Giants.”
lead_paragraph: Call it an embarrassment of riches: The musician Alicia Keys and her husband Kasseem Dean, the producer and D.J. known professionally as Swizz Beatz, have purchased such massive artworks that only a few could squeeze inside their homes in California, New York and New Jersey. Some colossal paintings by artists like Kehinde Wiley, Derrick Adams and Titus Kaphar eventually got through the door and became staples of the couple’s daily routine — backdrops to movie nights and family parties.

headline: ‘Bring Them Home’: Families of American Hostages in Gaza Release TV Ad
abstract: The 30-second spot is set to air on cable channels and during Sunday network news programs in the United States for the next several weeks.
lead_paragraph: The families of Americans held hostage in Gaza since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks in southern Israel have released a television ad to press for urgent action to rescue their loved ones.

headline: An Ecology Minister With an Oil Pedigree Will Lead Global Climate Talks
abstract: Mukhtar Babayev has been appointed to preside over this year’s global climate talks in Azerbaijan.
lead_paragraph: Azerbaijan’s minister of ecology and natural resources, who occupies a relatively obscure position in the country’s authoritarian government, was appointed president of the annual United Nations-sponsored climate summit that will be held in the country in November. The announcement thrusts him into a role defined by the intense pressure of brokering negotiations on one of the most complex crises to ever face humanity.

headline: Review: The Philharmonic’s Maestro Revels in the Classics
abstract: Jaap van Zweden returned to the orchestra for the first time since October with a conservative lineup of works by Wagner, Beethoven and Brahms.
lead_paragraph: With the new year, it’s the homestretch for Jaap van Zweden’s six-year tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic, which ends this spring.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks riff on disorientation, with an unknowable ex, an unnatural house and an uncanny dad.
lead_paragraph: Steph (Steph Holmbo) starts a new life after leaving her awful boyfriend by getting a new apartment and a new group of friends. But she’s having bizarre dreams of traipsing through the woods, and what’s worse, her furniture sometimes moves on its own. Then, in this strange film’s strangest scene, Steph digs out the flesh of a giant watermelon, turning the floor where she’s sitting into what looks like a brutal crime scene — a taste of the spectral, time-collapsing horrors to come.

headline: Out of Sight, Out of Mind No More
abstract: The Africa Cup of Nations and the Asian Cup, once seen as poorly timed intrusions by European soccer, may finally be getting the respect they deserve.
lead_paragraph: At last, we appear to be getting somewhere. Late on New Year’s Day, Mohamed Salah’s beaming face appeared on British television screens. Salah always has the slightly ruffled appearance of a man who has not slept desperately well, but he was in distinctly good cheer.

headline: Young Voters Worry About a Biden-Trump Rematch
abstract: Anjali Huynh, a politics reporter for The New York Times, spoke to young voters about the 2024 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Anjali Huynh, a politics reporter for The New York Times, spoke to young voters about the 2024 presidential election.

headline: Young Voters Are Voicing Discontent: ‘I Don’t Want a Biden-Trump Rematch’
abstract: The dissatisfaction with the presidential front-runners among a key coalition of voters — who may vote third party or not at all — poses a serious threat to the president’s re-election effort.
lead_paragraph: The first time Lucy VanDyke voted for president, she reluctantly supported Joseph R. Biden Jr. But she says she won’t be doing that again.

headline: Neo-Nazi Podcasters Who Called for Prince Harry’s Death Receive Prison Sentences
abstract: The men, who were described by the police as “homophobic, racist, antisemitic, Islamophobic and misogynistic,” received eight- and seven-year sentences.
lead_paragraph: Two neo-Nazi podcasters who called for the execution of Prince Harry were sentenced to prison in London on Thursday.

headline: Winter Storm Moves Into the Northeast and New York City Could Get a Dose
abstract: Heavy, wet snow from the storm could cause power failures in some areas, especially in parts of New England, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: A strong winter storm will drop the first significant snow of the season across parts of the Northeast this weekend, bringing up to a foot of snow in some places across the northern Mid-Atlantic and New England.

headline: Tesla Recalls 1.6 Million Cars in China to Fix Self-Driving Systems
abstract: The recall follows a similar move by the company in the United States to upgrade the cars’ Autopilot feature.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese government announced on Friday that Tesla would recall practically all of the cars it has sold in the country to adjust their assisted-driving systems, less than a month after a similar recall in the United States.

headline: M.I.T.’s President Has Weathered the Storm, for Now
abstract: Despite calls from politicians for her resignation, Sally Kornbluth has avoided a concerted effort to bring down her presidency.
lead_paragraph: As the presidents of Harvard and the University of Pennsylvania were pushed out of their jobs in recent weeks, it was an open question whether the president of another prestigious institution, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, would suffer the same fate.

headline: ‘Kimberly Akimbo’ Will End Its Broadway Run in April
abstract: The Tony winner for best musical, about a high school girl with a rare genetic disorder and a criminally dysfunctional family, will begin a national tour in September.
lead_paragraph: “Kimberly Akimbo,” a quirky show that combined pathos and comedy to win last year’s Tony Award for best musical, will end its Broadway run in April, nearly 19 months after it began performances.

headline: Trump Turns His Attention to Iowa as Caucuses Grow Near
abstract: The former president has visited the state infrequently, at least compared with his rivals in the Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump will return to Iowa on Friday for the first time this year, and will hold four campaign rallies in two days there as he looks to cement his dominant lead in the polls as the Iowa caucuses draw nearer.

headline: Playing for Time, U.K. Leader Sets Up Chance of U.S. Election Overlap
abstract: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak signaled that voters will go to the polls in the fall, around the time that the United States will be in the midst of its own pivotal vote.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said this week that he was not likely to call a general election in Britain before the second half of the year, he was trying to douse fevered speculation that he might go to the voters as early as May. But in doing so, he set up another tantalizing prospect: that Britain and the United States could hold elections within days or weeks of each other this fall.

headline: Smoke Billows From Fire at New Jersey Industrial Building
abstract: A large warehouse fire in Elizabeth, N.J, led to the collapse of three buildings. Officials said one firefighter suffered minor injuries.
lead_paragraph: A large warehouse fire in Elizabeth, N.J, led to the collapse of three buildings. Officials said one firefighter suffered minor injuries.

headline: The Big Number: 0%
abstract: From low alcohol to no-alcohol, Dry January is in full swing, and never have there been more choices for those who want to abstain.
lead_paragraph: From low alcohol to no-alcohol, Dry January is in full swing, and never have there been more choices for those who want to abstain.

headline: After the Iowa Shooting, Demands That Politicians Act
abstract: Readers urge the public to push for stricter laws to reduce gun violence. Also: Young voters; Israeli-Arab hope; immigration judges; inmates and cats.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Oasis and Stone Roses Musicians Team Up, and 7 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by A.G. Cook, Mary Timony, Bela Fleck and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes), and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: A Homeless Man Sleeps in the Lobby of My Apartment Building. What Should I Do?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to be empathetic while also respecting one’s own boundaries.
lead_paragraph: I’m a college student living off campus in a lovely old apartment in a relatively upper-class suburb of a major U.S. city. Recently, a homeless man has been sleeping in the unlocked vestibule of my building. We’ve had one or two incidents in the past of people sleeping there, and smoking or urinating in the corners, but nothing of the sort has happened with this person.

headline: A ‘Golden Bachelor’ Wedding With an ‘Honest-to-Gosh’ Love Story
abstract: Gerry Turner and Theresa Nist married before 150 guests (and even more TV viewers), then enjoyed a more intimate, off-air reception with family and friends.
lead_paragraph: During his wedding ceremony at a picturesque resort in the Southern California desert, Gerry Turner made his way down an aisle lined with roses.

headline: Hezbollah’s Leader Says It Would Not Negotiate Peace With Israel Until War in Gaza Ends
abstract: In a televised speech, Hassan Nasrallah addressed Israeli citizens directly, warning that they “will be the first to pay the price” unless the military action stops.
lead_paragraph: Hassan Nasrallah, the head of the powerful armed group Hezbollah, pledged on Friday that it would not negotiate peace with Israel until the war in Gaza ends — a statement that came as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken began a diplomatic tour around the Middle East to defuse regional tensions amid deepening fears of a wider conflict.Israel’s top officials have repeatedly threatened that if U.S.-led efforts to secure a diplomatic settlement fall through, they will have little choice but to increase military action against Hezbollah inside Lebanon. U.S. officials have expressed concern that, should the fighting expand on more fronts, it could potentially drag the United States into a regional war.

headline: The Habanero Rules Yucatán. Let It Rule Your Kitchen, Too.
abstract: The tiny but mighty chile lends its unmistakable fruity heat to marinades, dressings and, of course, salsas.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t matter if you are at a hotel, restaurant, market, street-food stand or the home of a local in Yucatán, Mexico — if salsa de mesa, or table salsa, is not there when you sit down, you can count the minutes until someone quickly mashes some together or opens the refrigerator to pour some into a bowl.

headline: What Was ‘The Crown’ All About, Anyway?
abstract: The series’s end was less intriguing than the real future of monarchy.
lead_paragraph: Over the Christmas season, my household completed watching the sixth and final season of Netflix’s “The Crown,” finishing up a multiyear relationship with Peter Morgan’s lightly fictionalized version of the House of Windsor.

headline: David Soul, a Star of the Hit Cop Show ‘Starsky & Hutch,’ Dies at 80
abstract: An actor and singer, he rose to fame in the 1970s as one half of the popular television crime-fighting duo. He also notched a No. 1 hit single in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: David Soul, the doleful-eyed blond actor and singer who rose to fame portraying half of a cagey crime-fighting duo on the hit 1970s television show “Starsky & Hutch,” and who also scored a No. 1 hit single in 1977 with “Don’t Give Up on Us,” died on Thursday. He was 80.

headline: New York A.G. Seeks $370 Million From Trump After Civil Fraud Trial
abstract: The penalty was well over the $250 million that the attorney general, Letitia James, had estimated in the fall of 2022, when she sued the former president.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general on Friday asked the judge who had overseen the civil fraud trial of Donald J. Trump to penalize the former president about $370 million, saying the trial had demonstrated that he had gained that amount through unlawful conduct.

headline: If You Wanna Mail My Letter, You Gotta Get Some Spice Girls Stamps
abstract: Royal Mail said on Friday that it was issuing a set of 15 stamps to celebrate the girl group’s 30th anniversary. The stamps will go on sale on Jan. 11.
lead_paragraph: Postal customers in Britain will soon have the opportunity to spice up their mail: Royal Mail is issuing a set of 15 stamps to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the Spice Girls.

headline: Listen: Oprah Winfrey, Harvard, Resolutions
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Happy New Year, audiophiles!

headline: The Best Songs Our Readers Discovered in 2023
abstract: Songs by Labi Siffre, Bessie Banks, the Brat and more that became invested with fresh meaning.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, I asked readers to share the best older song they discovered — or rediscovered — in 2023. As usual, the Amplifier community did not disappoint.

headline: Anthony J. Alvarado, Former New York City Schools Chancellor, Dies at 81
abstract: He also turned two Manhattan districts into national models. But his tangled personal finances forced him to resign as the city’s first Hispanic schools chief.
lead_paragraph: Anthony J. Alvarado, a successful educator who served as New York City’s first Hispanic schools chancellor, but whose tenure was cut short when he resigned over personal financial improprieties, died on Monday at his home in Coronado, Calif. He was 81.

headline: U.S. Moves Closer to Filing Sweeping Antitrust Case Against Apple
abstract: Justice Department officials are in the late stages of investigating the iPhone maker, focusing on how Apple has used its other products and services to defend against threats to its core business.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is in the late stages of an investigation into Apple and could file a sweeping antitrust case taking aim at the company’s strategies to protect the dominance of the iPhone as soon as the first half of this year, said three people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Wayne LaPierre Resigns From N.R.A. With Trial Set to Open
abstract: The resignation of Mr. LaPierre, the National Rifle Association’s longtime leader, came as he faced a corruption trial in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of a legal battle in New York, Wayne LaPierre told board members on Friday that he would step down as the longtime chief of the National Rifle Association.

headline: Loan Servicers Penalized for Snarls in Resumption of Student Loan Repayments
abstract: The Education Department reduced payments to its loan servicers as the consumer bureau spotlighted mistakes.
lead_paragraph: The restart of government student loan repayments was plagued by late bills, incorrect billing statements and long waits for customer service, according to a government watchdog report released on Friday.

headline: Map: 4.2-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Southern California
abstract: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

headline: Former Mr. Bungle Saxophonist Charged With Murder in Girlfriend’s Death
abstract: Theobald Lengyel, a saxophonist, helped form the experimental rock band in Northern California in the mid-1980s. His girlfriend had been missing since early December.
lead_paragraph: A founding member of the experimental 1990s rock band Mr. Bungle, Theobald Lengyel, was arrested on Tuesday and charged with murder, after the police in Capitola, Calif., found human remains that they believed were his girlfriend’s in a wooded area of a regional park.

headline: Ramaswamy Repeats Call for Ballots to Be English Only
abstract: The tech entrepreneur has been frequently pushing for English-only ballots. The Voting Rights Act prohibits such ballots in many cases.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy, the Republican tech entrepreneur running a long-shot campaign for president, doubled down Friday on his pledge to tighten voting laws if he is elected.

headline: Suspect in Davis Stabbings Can Now Stand Trial, Judge Rules
abstract: A California judge who initially found the suspect incompetent to stand trial ruled on Friday that after treatment at a state psychiatric hospital, he now met the legal standard.
lead_paragraph: A former college student accused of stabbing two people to death and injuring a third near the campus of the University of California, Davis, is now competent to stand trial after being treated in a psychiatric hospital, a judge in Northern California ruled on Friday.

headline: Many of You Have Strong Feelings on Congestion Pricing. Here Are Some of Them.
abstract: I like New York City’s plan. Some readers do, too, but many do not.
lead_paragraph: A lot of readers had strong feelings about my newsletter on Wednesday, “Why I Welcome New York City’s Congestion Pricing Plan.” So I’m devoting today’s newsletter to excerpts from emails some of you sent in response, with a few comments from me interspersed. Thanks to all of you for the education. As usual, I’m including only people who gave their approval to be quoted.

headline: 5 Cheap(ish) Things for Home Fitness
abstract: How to work up a sweat without leaving the house.
lead_paragraph: How to work up a sweat without leaving the house.

headline: Terrorism in Iran Exposes a Vulnerability It Doesn’t Want to Admit
abstract: Even after the Islamic State took responsibility for deadly bombings, Iran’s government, facing public anger, blamed Israel.
lead_paragraph: For years Iran justified its military presence in Iraq and Syria, to its own people and the world, as a strategy for keeping terrorist groups at bay. Iranian officials frequently boasted that fighting terrorists directly or through proxy militias in the region meant they didn’t have to fight them at home.

headline: Three Years After Jan. 6, Trump’s Immunity Claims to Take Center Stage
abstract: An appeals court will hear arguments on Tuesday over the former president’s attempt to shut down the federal election case. Much is riding on how — and how quickly — the issue is decided.
lead_paragraph: Three years after a mob of his supporters stormed the Capitol, former President Donald J. Trump will make his latest and potentially most consequential argument in the coming week for why he should not be held responsible for seeking to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Christian Oliver, ‘Speed Racer’ Actor, Dies in Plane Crash
abstract: Mr. Oliver’s two young daughters and a pilot were also killed in the crash, the police in the Caribbean nation of St. Vincent and the Grenadines said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The film and television actor Christian Oliver, his two children and a pilot were killed on Thursday when the small plane they were traveling in crashed during a flight to the Caribbean island of St. Lucia, the police said.

headline: Why People Are Camping Out at Target for the Valentine’s Stanley Tumbler
abstract: A limited-edition tumbler has caused physical confrontations, parking-lot camp-outs and other mayhem at Target stores around the United States.
lead_paragraph: The next time you go to Target, you might need to wear a helmet. The store sells them, come to think of it.

headline: These 11 Tips Will Make You a Better Cook
abstract: In her new monthly YouTube series, the chef and cookbook author Sohla El-Waylly wants to teach you to improve your kitchen game, wherever you are in your culinary journey.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of practical reasons for learning how to cook: saving money, controlling what you eat, knowing precisely what’s in your food. I’m in it for the impractical. I love making a 27-ingredient mole negro when a craving strikes, hosting half a dozen friends on the fly on a weeknight, transforming peanut butter into a four-course meal in under an hour just for kicks.

headline: The Early Universe Was Bananas
abstract: Images from the Webb telescope suggest that newborn galaxies look weirder than expected. Exactly how screwy was physics at the dawn of time?
lead_paragraph: What does a newborn galaxy look like?

headline: Sign Up for Well’s Mediterranean Diet Week
abstract: Each day, we’ll send guidance and recipes to help make 2024 your most nourishing year yet.
lead_paragraph: When we published an article on the merits of the Mediterranean diet last year, the reader response was overwhelming — and for good reason.

headline: At This Museum, You Can Ask A.I. van Gogh Anything
abstract: Can doppelgängers of Vincent van Gogh help museums generate new interest and income? An A.I. of the Dutch painter fields our questions (and makes some mistakes).
lead_paragraph: Can doppelgängers of Vincent van Gogh help museums generate new interest and income? An A.I. of the Dutch painter fields our questions (and makes some mistakes).

headline: A Day Later, the Iowa School Shooting Strikes an Intimate, Painful Chord
abstract: An armed 17-year-old student left one dead and five wounded at Perry High School.
lead_paragraph: In downtown Perry, Iowa, on Friday, residents wore blue to support each other, reflecting the school district’s mascot, the blue jay.

headline: Biden Condemns Trump as Dire Threat to Democracy in a Blistering Speech
abstract: The president framed the election as a choice between a candidate devoted to upholding American ideals and a chaos agent willing to discard them for his personal benefit.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Friday delivered a ferocious condemnation of Donald J. Trump, his likely 2024 opponent, warning in searing language that the former president had directed an insurrection and would aim to undo the nation’s bedrock democracy if he returned to power.

headline: Barbara Lynch Has Closed Most of Her Boston Restaurants
abstract: The prolific chef, who was accused of mistreating employees, has shuttered her most prestigious kitchen, Menton, and four others.
lead_paragraph: The Boston chef Barbara Lynch, who more than 20 employees accused of multiple forms of workplace abuse in a New York Times report last year, announced Friday that most of her restaurants had closed at the end of 2023.

headline: As Eli Lilly Wades Into Telehealth for Weight Loss, Doctors Are Wary
abstract: The maker of Zepbound and Mounjaro launched a new platform to connect patients and prescribers.
lead_paragraph: The pharmaceutical giant Eli Lilly wants to make it easier for patients to get its buzzy new weight loss drug, Zepbound, delivered to their door.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The cats of Chile’s largest prison. Also: The plan to make Travis Kelce a star and predictions for life in 2024.

headline: The Last Love Letter
abstract: The Love Letter newsletter is coming to an end, but you will still receive Modern Love and wedding stories in your inbox.
lead_paragraph: We want to take a moment to thank you, Love Letter readers, for coming with us on this journey of love and relationships.

headline: How to Host a Proper English Pub Lunch
abstract: The chef Margot Henderson on gathering friends for a meal at the Three Horseshoes inn in Somerset and the perfect winter dessert.
lead_paragraph: The chef Margot Henderson was 10 when she catered her first party, a birthday celebration for her younger brother Robin, then 5, in their hometown, Wellington, New Zealand. “Our mother was a complete health nut who would feed us apple cider vinegar and honey,” recalls Henderson. “I wasn’t going to let my brother suffer like I had! I made a whole spread of oranges and jellies and cooked snails from the garden with garlic, parsley and breadcrumbs.”

headline: On the Border in Eagle Pass, Texas
abstract: Reporting from the banks of the Rio Grande

headline: Supreme Court to Decide Whether Trump Is Eligible for Colorado Ballot
abstract: The Colorado Supreme Court ruled last month that the former president could not appear on the state’s Republican primary ballot because he had engaged in insurrection.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to decide whether former President Donald J. Trump is eligible for Colorado’s Republican primary ballot, thrusting the justices into a pivotal role that could alter the course of this year’s presidential election.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Idaho’s Strict Abortion Ban
abstract: The court also temporarily reinstated the state law, which the Biden administration said conflicts with a federal statute on emergency-room care.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to hear a challenge to Idaho’s near-total ban on abortions, which the Biden administration said conflicted with a federal statute that allowed for some exceptions.

headline: What the Supreme Court Should Not Do in Trump’s Disqualification Case
abstract: If anyone is going to do so, elected representatives must be the ones to forgive Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans are convinced that the disqualification of Donald Trump from Colorado’s primary ballot is a terrible idea and want the Supreme Court — which agreed on Friday to take up this question — to find a way to let the former president run. Mr. Trump’s supporters are eager to vote for him and argue that his exclusion from the election would be anti-democratic. Some of Mr. Trump’s opponents are just as eager to see him thrown in prison but believe that throwing him off the ballot would set a more dangerous precedent.

headline: The U.S. Issued Its First Approval of Mass Drug Imports
abstract: Also, the longtime N.R.A. leader, Wayne LaPierre, resigned. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The F.D.A. announced today that it would allow Florida to import millions of dollars’ worth of prescription medications from Canada, where they are available at far lower prices than in the U.S.

headline: Colorado Police Officer Sentenced to Jail in Elijah McClain Death
abstract: Randy Roedema, the only police officer convicted in the death of Mr. McClain, was sentenced to 14 months in a county jail.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado police officer involved in the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a young unarmed Black man whose case helped galvanize the police reform movement, was sentenced on Friday to 14 months in a county jail.

headline: House Republicans to Broaden Higher Education Inquiry Beyond Antisemitism
abstract: Emboldened by the resignations of two prominent university presidents, House Republicans are planning an aggressive inquiry into academia, long one of their favorite targets of attack.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Virginia Foxx, Republican of North Carolina and the chairwoman of the Education and Workforce Committee, arranged a hearing about antisemitism on college campuses, she said, her goal was not to force the nation’s top university presidents out of their jobs.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, January 7, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Upper West Side Church Championed by Celebrities Won’t Be Razed for Now
abstract: The West Park Presbyterian Church has put on hold plans to tear down the landmark building after Mark Ruffalo and Matt Damon rallied to save it.
lead_paragraph: An Upper West Side congregation that sought to tear down its church building, a Manhattan landmark, and sell the property to a developer — to the consternation of some neighbors, including a growing list of celebrities — has put the plans on hold.

headline: ‘So You Think You Can Dance’ Judge Exits After Paula Abdul Lawsuit
abstract: Ms. Abdul accused Nigel Lythgoe, a longtime producer and judge on the reality show, of sexually assaulting her when they worked on “American Idol” together. He denied the accusation.
lead_paragraph: Nigel Lythgoe has stepped down as a judge of “So You Think You Can Dance,” the show said on Friday, after he was sued by Paula Abdul and accused of sexual assault.

headline: One Killed in Bus Crash in Upstate New York, Police Say
abstract: About a dozen passengers were injured, one seriously, when a bus traveling from Montreal rolled over near Lake George, officials said.
lead_paragraph: One passenger was killed and about a dozen other people were injured, at least one seriously, when a bus traveling from Montreal to Midtown Manhattan rolled over on an upstate New York highway near Lake George on Friday, officials said.

headline: Trump Accuses Biden of “Fearmongering” After Speech About Democracy
abstract: Mr. Trump, campaigning in Iowa, suggested that Mr. Biden was trying to divert focus away from issues such as the economy.
lead_paragraph: Hours after President Biden attacked former President Donald J. Trump as an anti-democratic threat to America’s founding ideals, Mr. Trump responded by accusing Mr. Biden of “pathetic fearmongering.”

headline: Joseph Lelyveld, Former Top Editor of The New York Times, Dies at 86
abstract: As executive editor from 1994 to 2001, he oversaw a period of growth, expanding national and international readerships, creating new sections and ushering in the digital age with a Times website.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Lelyveld, a former executive editor and foreign correspondent for The New York Times, who won the 1986 Pulitzer Prize for nonfiction for his book “Move Your Shadow: South Africa, Black and White,” died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Defense Secretary Hospitalized After Complications From Elective Procedure
abstract: Lloyd J. Austin III has been at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center since Monday, but is “recovering well and is expecting to resume his full duties,” the Pentagon said in a statement.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has been in the hospital since Monday, after complications from a recent elective medical procedure, the Pentagon said on Friday.

headline: Book-Signing for Marjorie Taylor Greene on Jan. 6 Stirs a Backlash
abstract: The Georgia congresswoman has repeatedly downplayed, and at times defended, the attack on the Capitol three years ago.
lead_paragraph: A Florida venue canceled an event on Saturday featuring Marjorie Taylor Greene, the far-right Georgia congresswoman and acolyte of Donald J. Trump, after materials promoting the event advertised it, in part, as an occasion marking the third anniversary of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

headline: Ohio Governor Orders Restrictions on Transgender Care After Vetoing Ban
abstract: Gov. Mike DeWine, who had vetoed a ban on gender transition care for minors just a week ago, issued an executive order that prohibits transition surgeries for all residents.
lead_paragraph: Just a week after vetoing a ban on gender-affirming care for minors, Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio issued an executive order on Friday banning gender-transition surgeries for anyone under 18 at state hospitals or ambulatory clinics.

headline: As Pressure Mounts, Israeli Minister Proposes Plan for Postwar Gaza
abstract: The plan exposed divisions in Israel’s war cabinet as Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken returned to the Middle East on Friday in an effort to ease escalating tensions.
lead_paragraph: As Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken returned to the Middle East on Friday in an effort to ease escalating tensions, Israel’s defense minister floated a postwar plan for the Gaza Strip that exposed divisions in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s wartime government.

headline: Trump Targets Nikki Haley in Sharpest Attacks Yet
abstract: At a campaign event in Iowa, former President Donald J. Trump denounced Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, as the choice of corporate and political elites.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Friday opened one of his most targeted lines of attack yet against Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina who has emerged as one of his top competitors for the Republican nomination, accusing her of being “in the pocket” of “establishment donors.”

headline: Questlove Made You an Energy Playlist
abstract: These 17 tracks will get you moving.
lead_paragraph: Ahmir K. Thompson, also known as Questlove, seems to have boundless energy. Just look at his résumé: He’s a producer, podcast host, Academy Award-winning director, author, D.J. and drummer for the hip-hop band the Roots.

headline: Day 6: How to Stay Energized All Year Long
abstract: Today, we’ll share a few final tips to keep you motivated in 2024.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 6 of the 6-Day Energy Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Gloria Mark
abstract: Ezra Klein interviews Gloria Mark.
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Gloria Mark. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Wife of Investor Who Pushed for Harvard President’s Exit Is Accused of Plagiarism
abstract: Neri Oxman, a former M.I.T. professor, is accused of copying from Wikipedia. Her husband, William Ackman, vowed to check the work of the entire M.I.T. faculty.
lead_paragraph: Accusations of plagiarism appear to be the newest weapon in the raging battle over the leadership and direction of elite universities.

headline: Prosecutors Push Back on Trump’s Contempt Claims in Election Case
abstract: The filing by Jack Smith was the latest volley in a battle over the timing of the case accusing the former president of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors pushed back on Friday night against former President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to hold them in contempt of court for continuing to file motions while the case accusing him of plotting to overturn the 2020 election is paused.

headline: Twists of a Screwdriver?
abstract: Ben Tolkin and Julian Xiao shake us up with a fast-paced Saturday themeless.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Ben Tolkin and Julian Xiao are fairly new to the crossword game —this is Mr. Xiao’s debut, and Mr. Tolkin had one grid published last summer. They make a winning combination. I think you can feel their enthusiasm in the clue set, which is stuffed with so many witty moments that it seems to be bantering with you throughout the solve. Two great idiomatic marquee entries, both debuts, also cross in the center of the puzzle.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Stroke Stole Manuel’s Ability to Communicate
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I couldn’t curse.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 6, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the colonial roots of poverty in the Philippines referred incorrectly to the background of Luis F. Lorenzo Sr., founder of Lapanday Foods and a former senior executive of Del Monte. He was not a former governor of the province Davao del Sur.

headline: F.A.A. Orders Airlines to Ground Some Boeing 737 Max 9 Jets After Midair ‘Incident’
abstract: An Alaska Airlines plane made an emergency landing at the Portland, Ore., international airport on Friday after losing a chunk of its body, terrifying passengers.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration on Saturday ordered U.S. airlines to stop using some Boeing 737 Max 9 planes until they are inspected, less than a day after one of those planes lost a chunk of its body in midair “with an extremely loud pop,” terrifying passengers before the jet safely returned to ground.

headline: A President’s Son Is in Indonesia’s Election Picture. Is It Democracy or Dynasty?
abstract: Critics say that hard-won progress toward democracy in Indonesia has been backsliding under Joko Widodo, a two-term president who was once a political outsider.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, the eldest son of President Joko Widodo of Indonesia was running a catering business and a chain of dessert shops. Now he is the symbol of a budding political dynasty and the beneficiary of family maneuvering.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Voice of the Subway Speaks for Herself, at Last
abstract: The bearer of one of New York City’s most ubiquitous voices revealed a secret: She was a woman.
lead_paragraph: It’s a voice that is unmistakable to millions of harried New York City subway riders, telling them to “please stand away from the platform edge” or that the next train is “approaching the station.”

headline: How a Nigerian Cuisine Chef Spends His Sundays
abstract: Ayo Balogun, the owner of the Dept of Culture restaurant in Brooklyn, devotes Sundays to pancake hunting with his 13 year-old son and art with his partner.
lead_paragraph: Since moving to New York in 1997, Ayo Balogun has cooked his way through Italian deli classics, Indian recipes and nouveau British dishes, all the while dreaming of showcasing the cuisine of his native Nigeria.

headline: Floating East River Pool May Open to Public Next Year Under Hochul Plan
abstract: The state and city will provide financing for the project, known as + POOL, as part of a broader initiative meant to encourage New Yorkers to swim.
lead_paragraph: A plan for a floating, self-filtering pool in the East River may soon become a reality, New York officials said on Friday.

headline: A Judge’s Oath, a Journalist’s Promise
abstract: A very old way of saying “impartially” lives on in Times history.
lead_paragraph: “Without fear or favor” seems to be in favor.

headline: What Happens When a Woman Wronged Resorts to Violence?
abstract: In “The Furies,” the journalist Elizabeth Flock reports the stories of three women who fought back — to defend themselves, other women or their people.
lead_paragraph: When Elizabeth Flock was 20, she took a trip to Rome with friends, and the group signed up for a guided tour. At night, they traipsed from one bar to the next with their male guide before heading to the Trevi Fountain, where they tossed pennies over their shoulders into the water, a local ritual ensuring their return to the city someday. That is Flock’s last memory of the evening. She woke in a dimly lit room to find herself being raped by the tour guide. She froze. “I let it happen,” she writes.

headline: Saving for Retirement on Part-Time Pay: The Challenges for Women
abstract: Most part-time workers in America are women — leaving them with less access to retirement plans and less money to sock away.
lead_paragraph: When Robin Giles asks women why they aren’t saving for retirement, they often say the same thing: They don’t make enough money.

headline: As Gaza Losses Mount Under Strikes, Dignified Burials Are Another Casualty
abstract: “The lucky are those who have someone to bury them when they die,” Dr. Mohammad Abu Moussa, a radiologist at one Gaza hospital, said of those killed by Israeli airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: For four days, Kareem Sabawi’s body lay wrapped in a blanket in a cold, empty apartment as his family sheltered nearby. He was killed during intense Israeli bombardment near his family home, his father and mother said, and in the days that followed, it was too dangerous to step outside and lay their 10-year-old child to rest.

headline: U.S. News Makes Money From Some of Its Biggest Critics: Colleges
abstract: U.S. News sells “badges” to colleges, so they can promote their rankings — whether they are 1st, 10th or much, much lower.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Henry, a vice president at the University of Maine at Augusta, is hoping that an email will arrive this month. He is also sort of dreading it.

headline: A Fresh Look at Grief, Featuring an Ever-Present Sidekick
abstract: In “Poor Deer,” Claire Oshetsky explores the long shadow of a tragedy with devastating consequences.
lead_paragraph: Midway through Claire Oshetsky’s beautiful, terrifying sophomore novel, a mother asks her daughter: “Did you leave Agnes Bickford in that cooler to die, Bunny?”

headline: I Was Addicted to My Smartphone, So I Switched to a Flip Phone for a Month
abstract: Was it inconvenient? Yes. Did T9 texting drive me crazy? Definitely. Was it worth doing? Absolutely.
lead_paragraph: This time of year, everyone asks what you like least about your life, but they phrase it as, “What’s your New Year’s resolution?”

headline: How to Make the Most of a Home Inspection
abstract: If you’re trying to buy a home, the inspection should examine major systems in the home. The key is to take an active role in the process.
lead_paragraph: Q: Home inspections can give buyers some peace of mind — or some leverage — when it comes to the biggest investment they may ever make. But the process can feel overwhelming, especially for inexperienced buyers: How do you find the right inspector, and what should you look for when hiring one? What questions should you ask an inspector, and what should you pay attention to during the inspection? We spoke with some experts to get clarity on how to make the most of an inspection.

headline: Fact-Checking Candidates’ Sparring Over Social Security and Medicare
abstract: The top presidential candidates are vowing to protect the entitlement programs for current seniors, though some have floated changes for younger generations. But they’ve muddied each other’s current positions.
lead_paragraph: Top contenders for the 2024 presidential election in recent weeks have accused each other of jeopardizing Social Security and Medicare, key entitlement programs for seniors.

headline: Can $500 Million Save This Glacier?
abstract: A bold engineering project might show a way to slow sea-level rise — and bring new imagination to the fight against climate change.
lead_paragraph: One day in 2016, a British glaciologist named John Moore attended a meeting in Cambridge, England, that included a presentation about a glacier on Greenland’s west coast. Typically referred to by its Danish name, Jakobshavn, but also known by its Greenlandic moniker, Sermeq Kujalleq, the glacier functions as a kind of drain, situated on the edge of Greenland’s massive ice sheet, that moves 30 billion to 50 billion tons of icebergs off the island every year. These icebergs, some of them skyscraper-size, calve regularly from the glacier front, crash into a deep fiord and float west into Disko Bay. Then they drift out into the North Atlantic, break apart and melt. The intense activity here, as well its breathtaking location, have earned the area a designation as a UNESCO World Heritage site and made it a powerful attraction for Greenland’s small but vibrant tourist trade.

headline: Quebec Still Longs for Its Lost Hockey Team, a Nationalist Symbol
abstract: Ever since the Quebec Nordiques decamped in 1995, leaving a hole in the Francophone city, vote-seeking officials have vowed to bring them back. But younger voters may be starting to forget the team.
lead_paragraph: When the Nordiques left Quebec nearly 30 years ago, the hockey team’s departure fueled the kind of mythologizing and nostalgia familiar to fans of the Brooklyn Dodgers.

headline: Ukraine’s Patriot Defenses at Work: Shuddering Booms and Bursts of Light
abstract: The American-provided air-defense systems have helped Ukraine defend itself against Russian assaults, but Washington has warned that it will not be able to keep them supplied for much longer.
lead_paragraph: The first warning was a blip, a small anomaly picked up by radar scanning the skies over Ukraine. Within seconds, it became clear that the blip was a Russian ballistic missile streaking in Kyiv’s direction at several times the speed of sound.

headline: Lily Gladstone Won’t Let Hollywood Put Her in a Box
abstract: The “Killers of the Flower Moon” star says awards attention feels like “being shot out of a cannon.” For a long time, she’d kept her distance from the industry.
lead_paragraph: In college, Lily Gladstone studied the history of Native American actors in Hollywood. Now, she’s making it.

headline: Ani DiFranco Learned (and Cried) a Lot During Her First Year in N.Y.C.
abstract: “The lessons that New York has for you around every corner — it was a big part of my young adulthood, this city,” said the singer-songwriter, who will make her Broadway debut in “Hadestown.”
lead_paragraph: Ani DiFranco calls herself the fairy godmother of “Hadestown,” the 2019 Tony winner for best musical. Anaïs Mitchell, its composer and librettist, calls her this too, as DiFranco discovered during a recent publicity event.

headline: How Harvard’s Board Broke Up With Claudine Gay
abstract: Facing intense pressure, it went from standing behind her as the university’s president to pushing her out within weeks.
lead_paragraph: ​Claudine Gay was in Rome on a family vacation on Dec. 27 when Penny Pritzker, the leader of Harvard University’s governing board, called to ask: Did she think there was a path forward with her as the school’s president?

headline: Not This Kind of Sweat Equity
abstract: When a colleague appears to be midworkout midmeeting, something should be said. But maybe not to the boss.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: These Wedding Cakes Are Going to Great Lengths
abstract: Why are receptions (and Instagram) increasingly filled with table-long confections?
lead_paragraph: After months of brainstorming how to have the most delicious wedding cake possible, Rachel Karten and Roxanne Rosensteel, a pastry chef based in Santa Barbara, Calif., concluded that only one kind of wedding cake could fit the bill: a big sheet cake.

headline: College Bowl Games in Trouble? Send in the Memes.
abstract: A playoff system upended old traditions, but a few minor games still manage to stand out. A vat of mayonnaise was spilled and one giant Pop-Tart was harmed along the way.
lead_paragraph: After winning the Pop-Tarts Bowl on Dec. 28 in Orlando, Fla., Kansas State’s football team gathered on the field around a garage-size toaster that was protected by a pair of mall cops wearing “Snack Security” shirts.

headline: Colorado River States Are Racing to Agree on Cuts Before Inauguration Day
abstract: California, Arizona and others, fearing a political shake-up of negotiating teams after the November election, are aiming to wrap up work this year.
lead_paragraph: The states that rely on the Colorado River, which is shrinking because of climate change and overuse, are rushing to agree on a long-term deal to share the dwindling resource by the end of the year. They worry that a change in administrations after the election could set back talks.

headline: Trump Signals an Election Year Full of Falsehoods on Jan. 6 and Democracy
abstract: In dueling sets of speeches, Donald Trump and President Biden are framing the election as a battle for the future of democracy — with Mr. Trump brazenly casting Mr. Biden as the true menace.
lead_paragraph: Rarely in American politics has a leading presidential candidate made such grave accusations about a rival: warning that he is willing to violate the Constitution. Claiming that he is eager to persecute political rivals. Calling him a dire threat to democracy.

headline: Red Sea Attacks Leave Shipping Companies With Difficult Choices
abstract: Attacks on two dozen ships since November are forcing shipping lines to figure out whether and when to skip the Suez Canal and send vessels on longer voyages around Africa.
lead_paragraph: The shipping companies that move goods on one of the world’s busiest trade routes for factories, stores, car dealerships and other businesses face an excruciating decision.

headline: In Frothy Awards Season, What Role Will Israel-Hamas War Play?
abstract: Stars are increasingly vocal about political issues, but the Mideast conflict has divided Hollywood, magnifying the choice of whether to discuss the topic or remain silent.
lead_paragraph: As Hollywood heads into the heart of its awards season — a three-month orgy of frothy self-celebration and pop culture glamour — celebrities and their handlers find themselves with a serious decision to make: what, if anything, to say about the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Canada’s Foreign Student Surge Prompts Changes, and Anxiety
abstract: As international students flock to Canada, the country is looking closer at ways to protect them against labor and financial exploitation.
lead_paragraph: The education consultant in India didn’t reveal to Maninderjit Kaur, a Canada-bound student, where exactly, relative to Toronto, the college she had enrolled in was.

headline: Resolving New Year’s Resolutions
abstract: What does it take to finally make a resolution stick?
lead_paragraph: How far into the New Year do you progress before you stop greeting people with “Happy New Year”? Is it two weeks? The end of January? Valentine’s Day?

headline: Hezbollah Fires Rockets at Israel in Response to Killing in Beirut
abstract: Israel said it had fired back at militants involved in the rocket launches, but the exchange stopped short of a major escalation.
lead_paragraph: The Lebanese militia Hezbollah fired a volley of rockets toward a small military base in northern Israel on Saturday, in what the group said was an initial response to the assassination of a senior Hamas commander in Lebanon five days ago that has raised fears of a wider conflict.

headline: Plan B
abstract: There’s the thing you plan to do, and then there’s the thing you end up doing.
lead_paragraph: There’s the thing you plan to do, and then there’s the thing you end up doing.

headline: Danger Ahead: Pedestrians and Cars at Night
abstract: Readers discuss the reasons for the rise in pedestrian deaths, in response to an Upshot article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Is Trump an Agent or an Accident of History?
abstract: Is Trump just an American expression of the trends that have revived nationalism all over the world?
lead_paragraph: In Isaac Asimov’s Foundation novels, a “psychohistorian” in a far-flung galactic empire figures out a way to predict the future so exactly that he can anticipate both the empire’s fall and the way that civilization can be painstakingly rebuilt. This enables him to plan a project — the “foundation” of the title — that will long outlast his death, complete with periodic messages to his heirs that always show foreknowledge of their challenges and crises.

headline: The Hand Gesture Heard Round the World
abstract: Tommy DeVito, the Giants’ improbable quarterback, brought new popularity to an age-old hand gesture. Here’s why you should raise your pinched fingers high.
lead_paragraph: Personalized celebrations have become an indelible part of football, so when Tommy DeVito, the third-string quarterback for the New York Giants, threw one of his first touchdowns in November, he raised a right hand and pinched his finger and thumb together in an Italian gesture that means, roughly, “Whaddya want?”

headline: How to Fix America’s Addiction Crisis
abstract: Effective treatments for addiction exist. We just need to use them.
lead_paragraph: In America, 48 million people struggle with addiction. Very few get the help they need. But Jeneen Interlandi, a member of the editorial board, believes we have effective tools to address this public health crisis. In this audio essay, she argues that Americans need to view addiction as a chronic health condition, and treat it as such.

headline: A Warning About Donald Trump and 2024
abstract: Americans cannot afford to tune out Trump’s campaign to regain power.
lead_paragraph: At the outset of this election year, with Donald Trump leading the race to be the Republican presidential nominee, Americans should pause to consider what a second Trump term would mean for our country and the world and to weigh the serious responsibility this election places on their shoulders.

headline: Is Trump Hell?
abstract: Trump portrays himself as Christlike, even as he bedevils America.
lead_paragraph: These are the men that try The Times’s soul.

headline: After Niger Coup, U.S. Scrambles to Keep a Vital Air Base
abstract: After the generals took charge, the United States was forced to suspend operations at its most strategic military asset in sub-Saharan Africa. Restarting them won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: On a barren swath of land in the Sahara, U.S. Air Base 201 stands far from public sight, on the outskirts of a remote city in one of the world’s poorest countries, its role more elusive than ever since its completion nearly six years ago.

headline: Molly Recommends 2 Unjustly Forgotten Crime Novels
abstract: Murder mysteries by the men who brought you Winnie-the-Pooh and Daniel Day-Lewis.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: After the Capitol Attack, Companies Pledged to Rethink Political Giving. Did They?
abstract: A new analysis of corporate PAC donations shines light on an opaque political giving landscape.
lead_paragraph: After a violent mob stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, many businesses and trade groups condemned the attack and pledged to review and shift their approach to political giving, including by halting donations to candidates who voted against certifying the 2020 presidential election.

headline: What to Know About Boeing’s 737 Max 9 and the Alaska Airlines Grounding
abstract: Boeing faced new safety questions after an Alaska Airlines jet made an emergency landing when a hole opened in its fuselage in midair.
lead_paragraph: An emergency landing on Friday of an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 jet in Portland, Ore., led the Federal Aviation Administration to order some U.S. airlines to stop using some Max 9 planes until they are inspected. The order affects about 171 planes owned by Alaska, United and other airlines. The episode also raised troubling new questions about the safety of a workhorse aircraft design dogged by years of problems and multiple deadly crashes.

headline: The Income Gap Jeopardizing Retirement for Millions
abstract: Americans in the lower middle class are losing ground financially, researchers have found.
lead_paragraph: Monique Louvigny, an event coordinator in the San Francisco Bay Area, economizes where she can. She drives a 10-year-old Prius, brings a thermos of coffee to work instead of patronizing a place with baristas, and takes advantage of a drive-through food pantry once a month.

headline: Transgender Candidate in Ohio Is Disqualified for Not Disclosing Birth Name
abstract: Vanessa Joy, who wanted to run for a state House seat, said she was unaware of a statute that said candidates must disclose previous names on nominating petitions.
lead_paragraph: A transgender woman was disqualified from a race for the Ohio House of Representatives after she did not include her previous name in election materials, raising the prospect that transgender candidates would face similar barriers elsewhere.

headline: Back to (Better) Basics
abstract: You can never go wrong with crispy-skin roasted salmon, baked chicken thighs and bircher muesli.
lead_paragraph: January is a great time for basics. After the excess and glamour of the holiday season (read: prime rib roast and rainbow rave cookies), the simplest no-fuss recipes can feel downright refreshing. Which is why we’re particularly excited to share Sohla El-Waylly’s recipe for roasted salmon, the sort of basic recipe you can turn to again and again. The genius trick here — it is Sohla, after all — is a quick dry brine, which firms up the flesh and helps prevent overcooking. The recipe is part of our new Cooking 101 video series; Sohla also makes a simple butter pilaf and roasted broccoli because, again, basic is not always a bad word.

headline: Trump Doesn’t Actually Speak for the Silent Majority
abstract: 2016 is not the only election that matters.
lead_paragraph: I can’t fit everything that I think into a single piece, especially when I’m writing on deadline. My column this week, for example, was on the effort to disqualify Trump from the 2024 ballot using Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. Although the piece is not exactly brief, it’s by no means exhaustive of my thoughts on the matter.

headline: Overlooked No More: Cordell Jackson, Elder Stateswoman of Rock ’n’ Roll
abstract: A pioneering record-label owner and engineer, she played guitar in a raw and unapologetically abrasive way. “Whatever song it was,” she said, “I always creamed it.”
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Our Friend Is Getting Married — But Her Father Says She Has Been Brainwashed.
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to navigate another family’s disagreements.
lead_paragraph: My friends and I are planning to attend the wedding of a close friend. As far as we know, the engaged couple have always seemed happy together and a good fit for each other.

headline: Plane Makes Emergency Landing After a Portion Blows Out Midair
abstract: An Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 jet lost a chunk of its fuselage shortly after takeoff. The crew cited a midair pressure problem.
lead_paragraph: An Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 jet lost a chunk of its fuselage shortly after takeoff. The crew cited a midair pressure problem.

headline: Joseph Hendrie, 98, Dies; Key Figure in the Three Mile Island Crisis
abstract: He was chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in 1979, when America faced its worst nuclear power mishap in history.
lead_paragraph: Joseph M. Hendrie, a physicist who led the Nuclear Regulatory Commission during the country’s worst nuclear power accident, at Three Mile Island — a mishap that chilled Americans’ trust in nuclear energy for decades — died on Dec. 26 at his home in Bellport, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 98.

headline: House Dysfunction by the Numbers
abstract: As Congress comes back into session this month, Annie Karni, a New York Times politics reporter, reflects on its lack of productivity in 2023, and what that could mean for the 2024 session.
lead_paragraph: As Congress comes back into session this month, Annie Karni, a New York Times politics reporter, reflects on its lack of productivity in 2023, and what that could mean for the 2024 session.

headline: Russian Attacks Kill 11 Civilians Near Eastern Front, Ukraine Says
abstract: Ukrainian officials said missile assaults had struck private houses, trapping residents under the rubble, and that the dead included five children.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian officials said on Saturday that Russian missile strikes on a city and a village close to the eastern frontline had killed at least 11 people, including five children, and injured 10.

headline: Arno J. Mayer, Unorthodox Historian of Europe’s Crises, Dies at 97
abstract: A Jewish refugee from the Nazis, he argued that World War I, World War II and the Holocaust were all part of a “second Thirty Years’ War.”
lead_paragraph: Arno J. Mayer, a historian whose unorthodox reading of the first half of the 20th century challenged conventional understandings of World War I, World War II and the Holocaust, died on Dec. 17 in a senior care facility in Princeton, N.J. He was 97.

headline: Biden to Deliver State of the Union Address on March 7
abstract: Speaker Mike Johnson invited the president to address a joint session of Congress on an unusually late date.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will deliver his third State of the Union address on March 7, an opportunity to detail his vision of the nation amid a presidential campaign that the White House has described as a test of democracy.

headline: Gimme a Second!
abstract: Allow Michael Schlossberg’s puzzle to repeat itself.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Defense Secretary Kept White House in the Dark About His Hospitalization
abstract: Lloyd J. Austin III issued a statement Saturday night saying, “I take full responsibility for my decision about disclosure.”
lead_paragraph: It took the Pentagon three and a half days to inform the White House that Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had been hospitalized on New Year’s Day following complications from an elective procedure, two U.S. officials said Saturday.

headline: On Jan. 6 Anniversary, Trump Repeats Lie That 2020 Election Was Stolen
abstract: In a two-hour speech in Newton, Iowa, the former president said those who attacked the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, had acted “peacefully and patriotically.”
lead_paragraph: Three years to the day that supporters of Donald J. Trump stormed the Capitol in an attempt to stop Congress from certifying Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s electoral victory, Mr. Trump said yet again that the mob had been acting “peacefully and patriotically.” He called for the release of people imprisoned for their actions that day, and he criticized the congressional committee that investigated the attack as “fake.”

headline: What Passengers Need to Know After the Boeing 737 Max 9 Incident
abstract: An Alaska Airlines plane made an emergency landing when a section of it ripped off in flight. Here’s what passengers should know about the aircraft, how airlines are responding and more.
lead_paragraph: After a portion of an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 jetliner’s fuselage blew out in midair last Friday and caused an emergency landing in Portland, Ore., the Federal Aviation Administration ordered the temporary grounding of 171 Max 9 planes until they are thoroughly inspected.

headline: F.A.A. Orders Airlines to Ground Some Boeing 737 Max 9 Jets After Midair Emergency
abstract: An Alaska Airlines plane made an emergency landing at the Portland, Ore., airport on Friday after a hole opened up in the plane while it was in flight.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration on Saturday ordered U.S. airlines to stop using some Boeing 737 Max 9 planes until they were inspected, after one of those planes lost a piece of its body in midair, terrifying passengers until the plane landed safely.

headline: Michigan Republicans Hold Disputed Vote to Remove Party Leader
abstract: The effort to oust the state’s controversial G.O.P. chair after infighting and financial troubles faces challenges from her allies and is likely headed to the courts.
lead_paragraph: Simmering tensions within the Michigan Republican Party boiled over on Saturday, with some party officials voting to remove their embattled chairwoman, Kristina Karamo, in a contentious proceeding that she and other state Republicans argued was illegitimate.

headline: A Small-Town Stabbing Takes On a Larger Significance for France
abstract: The death might have been just a local tragedy. But some of the suspects were from an immigrant community, turning the case into a cause célèbre for the far right.
lead_paragraph: The traditional village ball 18 minutes outside the city ended in the traditional way: young men fighting outside.

headline: Woman Rescued From Rubble in Japan Five Days After Deadly Quake
abstract: The survivor, who was in her 90s, was dug out from under a collapsed house, injured but responsive.
lead_paragraph: The police and other rescue workers pulled a woman in her 90s out from under a collapsed house on Saturday in western Japan, five days after a powerful earthquake struck the region, killing more than 126 people.

headline: Winter Storm Hits the Northeast, Bringing a Foot of Snow to Some Areas
abstract: Forecasters warned of low visibility and dangerous driving conditions during the heaviest snowfall, which could reach one to two inches per hour.
lead_paragraph: The first major storm of the winter season dropped more than a foot of snow in parts of the Northeast on Saturday, creating treacherous travel conditions in some areas while also bringing an end to a mostly snowless winter so far.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 7, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about “Car­men” at the Metropolitan Opera misstated the performance history of the Russian mezzo-­soprano Aigul Akhmetshina. She has performed at the Met before; “Carmen” is not her Met debut.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Prospect of a Rematch of Biden-Trump Causes Young Voters to Retreat
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “The biggest thing that my generation is begging for is for someone to be honest, and that is something we’re lacking from both sides.”

headline: Blinken, in Jordan and Qatar, continues his Mideast tour in hopes of reducing tensions.
abstract: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met separately in Amman with King Abdullah II and Ayman Safadi, Jordan’s foreign minister.
lead_paragraph: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, held meetings on Sunday with leaders in Jordan and Qatar as part of a weeklong eastern Mediterranean and Middle East tour aimed at reducing the risk that the war in Gaza could spread in the region.

headline: Dignified burials have become another casualty in Gaza.
abstract: For four days, Kareem Sabawi’s body lay wrapped in a blanket in a cold, empty apartment as his family sheltered nearby. He was killed during intense Israeli bombardment near his family home, his father and mother said, and in the days that followed, it was too dangerous to step outside and lay their 10-year-old child to rest.
lead_paragraph: For four days, Kareem Sabawi’s body lay wrapped in a blanket in a cold, empty apartment as his family sheltered nearby. He was killed during intense Israeli bombardment near his family home, his father and mother said, and in the days that followed, it was too dangerous to step outside and lay their 10-year-old child to rest.

headline: The Secret Weapon of Celebrity Stylists? Comfortable Shoes.
abstract: What do Queen Camilla, Julia Roberts and Gayle King have in common? Sole Bliss. The brand has become a go to for women who don’t want to suffer foot pain.
lead_paragraph: Helen Mirren declared herself to be “in love with them,” and Gabrielle Union said that “they might be the most comfortable shoes I have ever worn in my life.” Julia Roberts, Viola Davis and Drew Barrymore have worn them to Hollywood premieres. Queen Camilla owns 13 pairs and wears them at almost all of her public engagements.

headline: Why New York Has Faltered in Making Childbirth Safer for Black Mothers
abstract: Proposals to reverse stark racial disparities in who dies during childbirth face deep-rooted obstacles, including hospital quality and the pandemic’s uneven aftereffects.
lead_paragraph: Late last year, a 30-year-old woman, Christine Fields, died after giving birth at a public hospital in Brooklyn. Within a few weeks, inspectors from the New York State Department of Health arrived and began pulling medical files and interviewing doctors and nurses, the agency said.

headline: How a Millennial Estée Lauder Built a Widely Popular Beauty Brand
abstract: Karissa Bodnar played on her customers’ desire to belong to something bigger than … well, beauty.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Monday, Karissa Bodnar, the 34-year-old founder and chief executive of Thrive, a cosmetics company, arrived at a launch party for her latest product line. The setting: a fluorescent-lit, fifth-floor office in midtown Manhattan. The bells and whistles: cheese, crudités, basic beer and wine. The entertainment: a Bluetooth speaker playing early aughts hip-hop (Flo Rida, Lil Jon).

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘We Joked That Maybe We Could See Each Other Out Our Windows’
abstract: College roommates get a surprise, dropped mango slices and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Who Was the Mysterious Woman Buried Alone at the Pet Cemetery?
abstract: At Hartsdale Pet Cemetery, Ed Martin III had become accustomed to unusual requests. Then came Patricia Chaarte.
lead_paragraph: Ed Martin III was 14 years old when he began working at his father’s pet cemetery, and in the decades since he has tended to the graves of innumerable dogs, many cats, flocks of birds, a few monkeys, a lion cub, a Bengal tiger and countless other creatures from every corner of the animal kingdom.

headline: A Day in the Kitchen at The New York Times Cooking Studio
abstract: The sunlit space buzzes with activity, as photographers and photo editors, food stylists and their assistants prep and cook, frame and reframe, in pursuit of the most mouthwatering shot.
lead_paragraph: Like so many things in the world of food, it starts, often, with a smell.

headline: Bangladesh Leader Headed to 4th Straight Term in Vote Marred by Crackdown
abstract: With the opposition in jail or off the ballots in a boycott, the prime minister for the past 15 years was expected to maintain her grip on power in what appeared to be a low-turnout vote.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh was headed toward a fourth consecutive term in office as voting ended on Sunday in a low-turnout election that had been marred by a widespread crackdown on the opposition.

headline: Paul Giamatti Has Done the Reading
abstract: For his role in “The Holdovers,” set at a prep school not unlike the one he attended, the hyper-literate actor mined his own dormant memories.
