lead_paragraph: Paul Giamatti would just like to put it out there that maybe he doesn’t always have to play such a motormouth.

headline: Channeling the Pain of Chinese Immigrants, in Music and Verse
abstract: “Angel Island,” an oratorio by Huang Ruo, brings to life the stark poetry of the people who were detained on the California island in the early 1900s.
lead_paragraph: In “Angel Island,” a staged oratorio about the anguish and isolation of Chinese detainees at Angel Island Immigration Station in California, a choir recites a poem about tyranny and misfortune.

headline: In ‘Beautyland,’ an Awkward Alien Reports From Earth by Fax Machine
abstract: In Marie-Helene Bertino’s remarkable funny-sad novel, the young visitor and her mother find the means to persevere in the aisles of a cosmetics store.
lead_paragraph: “He was too good for this earth,” Abraham Lincoln said of a son who died young.

headline: American Unions Long Backed Israel. Now, Some Are Protesting It.
abstract: The shift reflects a broader generational change, and has exposed philosophical rifts in the labor movement about what the purpose of a union ought to be.
lead_paragraph: “Why are we here?” said Brandon Mancilla, a leader with the United Automobile Workers. Mr. Mancilla faced a crowd of hundreds of union members gathered on the steps of the New York Public Library’s Fifth Avenue branch, huddling against the cold as they rallied for a cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: Marijuana Buyers From Texas Fuel a ‘Little Amsterdam’ in New Mexico
abstract: Sunland Park, along the Rio Grande, has joined the ranks of U.S. cities transformed by state cannabis laws. But the good times may not last forever.
lead_paragraph: In a desert valley along the Rio Grande in New Mexico, the city of Sunland Park has generally offered few amenities for its roughly 17,000 residents. No large grocery store. Few shops. Little to offer those uninterested in the racetrack casino or a hike to the gigantic cross of Cristo Del Rey that looms from a nearby mountaintop.

headline: War Brings Tensions, and Assault Rifles, Into an Israeli College
abstract: At the University of Haifa, more than 40 percent of students are Arab, some with family in Gaza, and many others have now been called up as soldiers.
lead_paragraph: In a classroom at the University of Haifa in late December, Yitzhak Cohen, a fourth-year law student, began the shoulder-shrugging, arm-contorting choreography familiar to any student trying to remove a backpack.

headline: Blessing of Same-Sex Couples Rankles Africa’s Catholics
abstract: It is out of step with the continent’s values, many bishops say, and threatens to derail expansion in the church’s fastest growing region in the world.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican’s recent declaration allowing the blessing of same-sex couples caused a stir around the globe, but perhaps most of all in Africa, a rising center of the Roman Catholic Church’s future. In one statement after the next, bishops in several countries spoke of the fear and confusion the declaration has caused among their flocks, and said it was out of step with the continent’s culture and values.

headline: ‘Two Men Down’: For Ukrainian Medics, It Was Time to Move
abstract: They are the first line of treatment for soldiers wounded on the battlefield, racing against time to try to save lives.
lead_paragraph: To save lives, Ukrainian combat medics must stay alive.

headline: Eddie Izzard Doesn’t Trust This Whole Falling in Love Business
abstract: “I don’t have a relationship, and I’m very happy and have got all this work to do,” says the comedian turned politician.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t have a relationship, and I’m very happy and have got all this work to do,” says the comedian turned politician.

headline: The Mystery of the Coin That Shouldn’t Exist
abstract: Scientists recently analyzed a Peruvian 10-cent piece with an unexplained origin.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, a funny money mystery fell into the hands of scientists and students at the Pontifical Catholic University of Peru in Lima.

headline: Writing Checks Can Be Risky. Here’s How to Protect Yourself.
abstract: Should you keep a separate checking account for writing checks? Is there a specific pen you should use? We answer some reader questions.
lead_paragraph: Typewriters vanished, and then cassette tapes and encyclopedias did, too. But paper checks are one piece of our analog past that persists.

headline: Japanese Company’s Bid for U.S. Steel Tests Biden’s Industrial Policy
abstract: The president is under pressure from Democrats and Republicans to block the sale to Japan’s Nippon Steel, which could upset a key foreign ally.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Steel is an iconic example of the lost manufacturing muscle that President Biden says his economic policies will bring back to the United States.

headline: Trump Takes Aim at Haley as Primary Enters Final Phase in Iowa
abstract: Nearly a week before the state’s caucuses, a frenzy of campaigning belies a seemingly static G.O.P. race, with former President Donald J. Trump the prohibitive front-runner.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s escalating attacks on Nikki Haley both on the airwaves and at his rallies — criticisms she likened Saturday to “a temper tantrum” — captured the turbulent dynamics in the final week before the first votes of the 2024 Republican presidential primary are cast.

headline: The Misguided War on the SAT
abstract: Colleges have fled standardized tests, on the theory that they hurt diversity. That’s not what the research shows.
lead_paragraph: After the Covid pandemic made it difficult for high school students to take the SAT and ACT, dozens of selective colleges dropped their requirement that applicants do so. Colleges described the move as temporary, but nearly all have since stuck to a test-optional policy. It reflects a backlash against standardized tests that began long before the pandemic, and many people have hailed the change as a victory for equity in higher education.

headline: Boeing Again Under Scrutiny After Latest 737 Max Problem
abstract: A sudden hole appearing in the side of an Alaska Airlines plane midflight follows years of problems with the manufacturer’s aircraft.
lead_paragraph: A harrowing flight over the weekend is again forcing Boeing to confront concerns over its planes, particularly the 737 Max, already one of the most scrutinized jets in history.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Ghosts on the Glacier’
abstract: Decades after the unexplained deaths of two American climbers in Argentina, a camera belonging to one of them was found in the snow.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, eight Americans set off for South America to climb Aconcagua, one of the world’s mightiest mountains. Things quickly went wrong. Two climbers died. Their bodies were left behind.

headline: The Road to the Oscars
abstract: A good year for movies means a competitive awards season.
lead_paragraph: A great year for movies, as 2023 was, means a lot to look forward to as awards season begins. Things get started tonight with the Golden Globes ceremony, and later this week it’s on to nominations for the Screen Actors Guild and Producers Guild of America Awards. The big one — the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences — will announce its nominations for the 96th Oscars on Jan. 23.

headline: What Will Happen to Gaza’s People?
abstract: Officials are increasingly suggesting that Palestinians should leave the region. The government denies that’s its policy.
lead_paragraph: Conventional wisdom has generally held that Israel’s government lacks a strategy for the Gaza Strip beyond toppling Hamas.

headline: A Terrible Phone Call and What Came Next
abstract: A cancer diagnosis, a Swedish proverb and the blessing of human connection.
lead_paragraph: Early on the morning of Friday, Nov. 10, my phone rang with terrible news: My wife, Nancy, has a highly aggressive form of breast cancer.

headline: Things Have Gotten Pretty Weird With New York’s Mayor
abstract: A conversation about Mayor Adams’s weak leadership at a time when New York City is at an inflection point.
lead_paragraph: David Firestone: Hi, Mara, and welcome to a year that’s going to be full of news about Mayor Eric Adams and the long-term health of New York City.

headline: Baudelaire Would Be Run Over in New York City Today
abstract: A city that no longer accommodates wandering no longer accommodates wondering. A flâneur without freedom falls into a zombified routine.
lead_paragraph: In his 1863 essay “The Painter of Modern Life,” Charles Baudelaire described the passionate city dweller as “a kaleidoscope gifted with consciousness.” In the French poet’s eyes, the city dweller had a unique opportunity to absorb and mirror the poetry of freely moving multitudes. For the committed flâneur, Baudelaire wrote, “the crowd is his element, as the air is that of birds and water of fishes.”

headline: Manet and Degas and Robert and Me
abstract: A monumental art exhibit at the Met explored the kind of rivalry that can complicate, and fortify, a friendship. I recognized it all too well.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of the “Manet/Degas” exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, there is a small drawing by Edgar Degas of a bearish man with a beard. At first glance, you might think the man in the drawing is Edouard Manet, but in fact he’s an author and critic named Edmond Duranty. Nine years before this drawing was created, Duranty wrote something critical of Manet, in response to which Manet, encountering Duranty in a cafe, slapped him. Duranty demanded that Manet apologize. Manet refused. Duranty challenged Manet to a duel. The duel, by sword, took place three days later. Manet was unscathed; I guess you could say he won. Duranty, the man in the Degas drawing, “received a wound in his upper chest,” as the museum text accompanying the drawing states matter-of-factly. I stared incredulously at the text’s last line: “Surprisingly, the two men remained friends after the incident.”

headline: I Finally Figured Out Who ChatGPT Reminds Me Of
abstract: Generative A.I. is often described as being in its infancy. The truth is a little more of a handful.
lead_paragraph: As the mother of an 8-year-old, and as someone who’s spent the past year experimenting with generative A.I., I’ve thought a lot about the connection between interacting with one and with the other. I’m not alone in this. A paper published in August in the journal Nature Human Behaviour explained how, during its early stages, an artificial intelligence model will try lots of things randomly, narrowing its focus and getting more conservative in its choices as it gets more sophisticated. Kind of like what a child does. “A.I. programs do best if they start out like weird kids,” writes Alison Gopnik, a developmental psychologist.

headline: Two More Journalists Killed in Gaza, Including Son of Al Jazeera Reporter
abstract: Hamza al-Dahdouh, the son of Al Jazeera’s Gaza bureau chief, and a second reporter were killed in what officials in the territory said was an Israeli airstrike. Two others were wounded.
lead_paragraph: Wael al-Dahdouh, a well-known Palestinian correspondent for Al Jazeera TV who has spent his career covering Gaza, had already lost his wife, a son, a daughter and an infant grandson in an Israeli airstrike in October.

headline: A Spatchcocked Roast Chicken is a Better Roast Chicken
abstract: A de-backboned, flattened bird roasts more quickly and evenly, with juicy meat under crisp, burnished skin. Sohla El-Waylly shows us how.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’m just spitballing here, but I bet the use of the word “spatchcocking” — which describes the business of cutting the backbone out of a bird and flattening the remaining body into a pan so that it roasts more quickly and evenly — peaks around Thanksgiving, at least in America. A spatchcocked turkey is a marvelous thing.

headline: Parenting: A ‘Wonderful and Challenging Adventure’
abstract: Readers discuss the negativity that pervades discussions about parenthood. Also: Aligning election calendars; natural gas exports; semicolons.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mário Zagallo, Longtime Fixture of Brazilian Soccer, Dies at 92
abstract: The first person to win the World Cup as a player and a coach, he was a link to decades of Brazil’s success and failure on the sport’s biggest stage.
lead_paragraph: Mário Zagallo, who as both a player and coach helped lead Brazil to four World Cup soccer championships, becoming a national hero and one of only three people to lift the tournament’s trophy in both roles, died on Friday in Rio de Janeiro. He was 92.

headline: Vulcan Rocket’s Inaugural Launch Carries Moon Lander to Space
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about United Launch Alliance and the robotic lunar spacecraft it is sending to orbit.
lead_paragraph: A brand-new American rocket lifted off from a launchpad at Cape Canaveral, Fla., on Monday, and for the first time in more than 50 years, an American spacecraft will be headed toward the surface of the moon. The rocket is called Vulcan, and it was built by the company United Launch Alliance. Here’s what you need to know about its first flight.

headline: Subway Service Is Fully Restored After Derailment in Manhattan
abstract: The 1, 2 and 3 lines were back in service after tracks were repaired, and an investigation was continuing into the cause of a collision last week.
lead_paragraph: Subway service on the 1, 2 and 3 train lines in Manhattan was fully restored on Sunday, more than 60 hours after a collision between two trains left 26 people injured, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said in a social media post.

headline: London Tube Strike Is Called Off
abstract: London’s mayor announced late Sunday afternoon that a strike that would have crippled the city’s transit system this week had been suspended.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of London on Sunday announced that a planned strike that would have ground the city’s underground Tube system to a halt this week had been suspended.

headline: Klee Benally, Navajo Activist and Artist, Dies at 48
abstract: He helped found a punk-rock band when he was 14. That led to a long career as an advocate for Native American and environmental causes.
lead_paragraph: Klee Benally, a dynamic Navajo activist, artist and punk-rock musician who championed Native American and environmental causes, died on Dec. 30 in Phoenix. He was 48.

headline: ‘Color Purple’ Struggles at Box Office After Big Christmas Opening
abstract: The musical adaptation of the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel seemed an instant hit, but it sold less than $5 million in tickets in its second weekend.
lead_paragraph: “The Color Purple,” a new musical take on Alice Walker’s landmark novel, seemed to arrive as an instant hit.

headline: She Helped the Lillys Blossom. Now She’ll Champion Her Own Work.
abstract: After years of fighting to win parity and recognition for women in theater, Julia Jordan said: “Everybody gets produced now. There’s much more competition. In a good way.”
lead_paragraph: Ask the playwright Julia Jordan what the need was for the Lilly Awards, which she co-founded in 2010 to honor women in theater, and the answer is a mix of anecdote and statistic.

headline: Norby Walters, 91, Dies; Music and Sports Agent Who Ran Afoul of the Law
abstract: He ran a highly successful booking agency, but his secret contacts with college athletes led to convictions (later reversed) for racketeering and fraud.
lead_paragraph: Norby Walters, a booking agent for some of the country’s top disco, R&B, funk and hip-hop artists whose aggressive leap in the 1980s into signing college athletes to secret contracts before they turned pro led to legal problems, died on Dec. 10 in Burbank, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Monday Briefing: Bangladesh’s Troubled Election
abstract: Plus why the first galaxies were banana-shaped.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina of Bangladesh was nearly guaranteed a fourth consecutive term in office as voting ended in a low-turnout election yesterday.

headline: With Shutdown Looming, House and Senate Leaders Agree on Spending Levels
abstract: Despite the deal, time is short to assemble and pass legislation putting the agreement in force before a Jan. 19 deadline.
lead_paragraph: Senate and House leaders announced on Sunday that they had struck an overarching agreement on 2024 government funding, but it was not clear whether they would be able to cement the deal and pass it into law in time to avert a partial government shutdown in less than two weeks.

headline: From Lebanon to the Red Sea, a Broader Conflict With Iran Looms
abstract: With its proxies attacking from many vantage points and its nuclear program suddenly revived, Iran is posing a new challenge to the West — this time with Russia and China on its side.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his top national security aides believed last summer that the chances of conflict with Iran and its proxies were well contained.

headline: With Time Running Short, Liz Cheney Implores Republicans to Reject Trump
abstract: She endorsed efforts to remove him from the ballot and said, “Tell the world who we are with your vote. Tell them that we are a good and a great nation.”
lead_paragraph: In a flurry of appearances and commentary, former Representative Liz Cheney has stepped up her denunciations of former President Donald J. Trump in a last-ditch effort to persuade Republicans not to nominate him again.

headline: No Corrections: Jan. 8, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: As West Bank Violence Rises, Israel Vows to Pursue Military Goals in Gaza
abstract: Diplomats toured the Mideast Sunday on a mission to stop the war from widening, but tensions in the Gaza Strip spread across the region.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As the war in the Gaza Strip ended its third month on Sunday, with top diplomats touring the region to try to stop the conflict from spreading, Israel said it had broken up Hamas’s command structure in northern Gaza and signaled that it would not change its objective of dismantling the group’s capabilities across the ravaged territory.

headline: Swelled Heads
abstract: Nate Cardin ropes us in.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Taylor Swift Shows Up but Leaves Empty-Handed.
abstract: Swift has five nominations but no wins after “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour” lost to “Barbie” in the new blockbuster film category.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift is back in her Golden Globes era.

headline: Joan Acocella, Dance Critic for The New Yorker, Dies at 78
abstract: She wrote about the leading figures in ballet and modern dance for more than 40 years. One of her books was about the brash choreographer Mark Morris.
lead_paragraph: Joan Acocella, a cultural critic whose elegant, erudite essays about dance and literature appeared in The New Yorker and The New York Review of Books for more than four decades, died on Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78.

headline: Golden Globes Winners 2024: The Complete List
abstract: The winning films, TV shows, actors and production teams at the 2024 Golden Globe Awards.
lead_paragraph: Tuning into the Golden Globes this year meant more than catching a glimpse of the stars or getting an idea of what the Oscars might have in store.

headline: Pressure Builds on Pentagon to Explain Timeline of Austin’s Hospitalization
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin has yet to disclose why he has been at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center for the past week.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon came under increased pressure Sunday to explain why senior Biden administration officials, congressional representatives and the president himself were not notified of the hospitalization of Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III until days later.

headline: 2024 Golden Globes: Photos From the Red Carpet
abstract: All the best looks from the first major award show of the year.
lead_paragraph: Celebrities streamed onto the lush red carpet to pose in front of the floral backdrop for the Golden Globes on Sunday night as the awards ceremony made a return to television (it wasn’t broadcast in 2022, and was moved to a Tuesday evening last year).

headline: Boeing Max 9 Jets Remain Grounded as Airlines Await Inspection Instructions
abstract: Two days after a chunk of the fuselage blew out of one of the planes, the F.A.A. and the aircraft maker are still negotiating what to tell the airlines to do.
lead_paragraph: A Boeing passenger jet model, the 737 Max 9, remained grounded in the United States on Sunday as airlines awaited instructions from the plane maker and the Federal Aviation Administration on how to inspect the planes and resume service, two days after a harrowing flight raised concerns about the jet.

headline: California’s Ban on Guns in Most Public Places Is Blocked Again
abstract: Just a week after the law was allowed to take effect, a federal appeals court reinstated a lower court’s block on the ban.
lead_paragraph: California is barred again from enforcing its ban on guns in most public places after a federal appeals court ruled on Saturday that a lower court’s block on the ban should stand.

headline: The Frightful Minutes Aboard Flight 1282
abstract: After a section of the Alaska Airlines flight blew out of the plane, passengers described a mix of horror, confusion and eerie calm.
lead_paragraph: It felt like an explosion. Then the plane rattled, the oxygen masks dropped, and the lights flickered. A white vapor whipped through the cabin. Some people yelled. Others were disoriented.

headline: Ali Wong Makes History as a Best Actress Winner
abstract: The “Beef” star took home a Golden Globe, as did Steven Yeun, who starred alongside her.
lead_paragraph: Ali Wong’s character in the Netflix comedy “Beef” faced plenty of challenges and frustrations, but the actress herself was nothing less than triumphant on Sunday night. Wong made history by becoming the first actress of Asian descent to win a Golden Globe for best actress in the limited series or TV movie category.

headline: Jo Koy Sticks With Standard Celebrity Teasing in Opening Monologue
abstract: The comic’s monologue struck a far less provocative tone than last year’s host, Jerrod Carmichael.
lead_paragraph: In his opening monologue, Jo Koy made a return to the Hollywood tradition of mild celebrity teasing from the awards show stage, staying away from any mention of the Golden Globes’ recent troubled history involving race and ethics.

headline: Emma Stone Wins Her Second Golden Globe, for ‘Poor Things’
abstract: The actress won for her performance as Bella, a Victorian-era woman who was brought back to life with the brain of a fetus.
lead_paragraph: Emma Stone won her second Golden Globe, for her performance in “Poor Things,” a comedy-drama riff on the Frankenstein legend. In the film, she plays Bella, a Victorian-era woman who was brought back to life with the brain of a fetus; her performance was widely praised by critics.

headline: Heavy Snow Falls in Northeast
abstract: In parts of New England and New York, residents and road crews removed snow as the first major snowstorm of the winter season hit the region.
lead_paragraph: In parts of New England and New York, residents and road crews removed snow as the first major snowstorm of the winter season hit the region.

headline: ‘The Bear’ Wins Best Comedy at the Golden Globes
abstract: Its stars, Jeremy White and Ayo Edebiri, also won for their acting roles.
lead_paragraph: Globe voters said “Yes, chef,” to “The Bear,” which beat out “Ted Lasso” and “Abbott Elementary” to win best comedy.

headline: Lily Gladstone Becomes First Indigenous Person to Win a Golden Globe for Best Actress
abstract: The star of “Killers of the Flower Moon” plays an Osage woman whose husband is part of a murderous conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: In a history-making triumph, Lily Gladstone has become the first Indigenous person to win a Golden Globe for best actress, said a spokesman for the organization that hands out the awards.

headline: ‘Oppenheimer’ Wins 5 Golden Globes and ‘Succession’ Wins 4
abstract: “The Holdovers,” “Poor Things” and “Barbie” all won multiple awards in the film categories, while the TV shows “Beef” and “The Bear” each won three.
lead_paragraph: The 81st Golden Globes kicked off Hollywood’s awards season on Sunday in a chaotic and sloppy manner, with the host, Jo Koy, delivering a train wreck of a monologue, winners alternately seeming to take the ceremony seriously and not at all, and prizes going to a wide array of films and television shows.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: A newly aggressive Iran.
lead_paragraph: Hamas’s Oct. 7 attacks in Israel and Israel’s bombardment of the Gaza Strip have emboldened a newly aggressive Iran. After launching scores of attacks across the region, Iranian proxy groups have come into direct conflict with U.S. forces twice in the past week, and Washington is openly threatening airstrikes if the violence does not abate.

headline: 20 Looks That Did the Most at the Golden Globes
abstract: On a night full of fashion, these outfits stood out.
lead_paragraph: This year’s revamped Golden Globe Awards brought several changes to the program. But it was business as usual on the red carpet, with hundreds of celebrities seemingly relishing the chance to give us something to ogle after last year’s strikes stopped many from posing for cameras at award shows and events.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Curse’ and the Critics’ Choice Awards
abstract: The season ends for this Showtime series with Nathan Fielder and Emma Stone, while awards season begins.
lead_paragraph: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 8-14. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Spain Is Doing Something Brave
abstract: A new amnesty law could be a remedy for democratic coexistence.
lead_paragraph: Spain’s new amnesty law, on its way to the statute books after passing Congress in December, has ignited quite a ruckus. Tens of thousands of people have taken to the streets to protest the law — which provides a blanket pardon to hundreds of politicians, civil servants and ordinary citizens caught up in the illegal referendum on Catalan independence in October 2017 — and a majority of Spaniards oppose it. Many commentators and politicians, mainly on the right, have argued that the amnesty weakens the rule of law in Spain and even imperils the country’s democracy.

headline: Word of the Day: nondenominational
abstract: This word has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word nondenominational has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 21 in “At U.N., Narendra Modi Celebrates Yoga, and Joins In on a Pose” by Sarah Maslin Nir:

headline: Quotation of the Day: Town Turned Marijuana Oasis Near Texas Rakes In the Green
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 8, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I’d like to see a nice store, a pharmacy, a gas station that’s close to my home. Instead, all we see is cannabis.”

headline: Boeing Max 9 Plane Had Been Barred From Long Flights Over Water
abstract: Alaska Airlines restricted the use of the plane, which lost part of its fuselage on Friday, because of a warning light that went off on previous flights, an official said.
lead_paragraph: The Alaska Airlines plane that lost a piece of its fuselage in midair on Friday was not being used in long flights over water because a pressurization warning light had gone off during three recent flights, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Sunday.

headline: Vulcan Rocket Lifts Off for the Moon
abstract: The rocket launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., early Monday morning, sending a robotic spacecraft toward the surface of the moon.
lead_paragraph: The rocket launched from Cape Canaveral, Fla., early Monday morning, sending a robotic spacecraft toward the surface of the moon.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Dark Corners of the Web Offer a Glimpse at A.I.’s Nefarious Future
abstract: In the hands of anonymous internet users, A.I. tools can create waves of harassing and racist material. It’s already happening on the anonymous message board 4chan.
lead_paragraph: When the Louisiana parole board met in October to discuss the potential release of a convicted murderer, it called on a doctor with years of experience in mental health to talk about the inmate.

headline: N.R.A. Leader Accused of Unchecked Spending as Corruption Trial Begins
abstract: The New York attorney general is seeking penalties against several current and former leaders of the embattled gun-rights group.
lead_paragraph: Just days after the resignation of its longtime leader, the National Rifle Association faced off in a Manhattan court on Monday in a long-awaited civil showdown with the New York attorney general’s office.

headline: Wealthy Donors Pull Back From New York City’s Escalating Problems
abstract: Philanthropists worry that the city’s complex tangle of crises — migrants, homelessness, housing, the cost of living — cannot be easily fixed.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, this might seem like just the right moment for New York City’s deep-pocketed philanthropists to flex some muscle.

headline: Vulcan Rocket Aces Its First Launch
abstract: Despite problems with one of its payloads, the new launcher’s flight was flawless, showing the potential of several vehicles that could chip away at SpaceX’s dominance.
lead_paragraph: A brand-new rocket lifted off early Monday morning from Cape Canaveral, Fla., sending multiple payloads on journeys into space.

headline: Russia Pounds Several Ukrainian Regions With Missiles
abstract: The attack killed at least four people, wounded many others and caused heavy damage. It came as Moscow has intensified air assaults in recent days.
lead_paragraph: Russia launched a large-scale air attack against Ukraine on Monday, Ukrainian and Russian officials said, pounding several regions with missiles that killed at least four people, wounded more than 30 others and heavily damaged residential buildings and industrial sites.

headline: Just How Healthy Is Salmon?
abstract: Experts explain why it’s such a nutritional powerhouse and if all varieties are created equal.
lead_paragraph: Salmon is good for you — that part we know.

headline: An Innovative Vocalist Lost Her Speech, but She’s Still Performing
abstract: Linda Sharrock, an avant-garde jazz musician who became aphasic after a 2009 stroke, has returned to the stage and inspired new generations.
lead_paragraph: Last April, the Vienna-based avant-garde jazz vocalist Linda Sharrock gave her first New York performance in over 40 years: a sold-out concert at BAM’s Howard Gilman Opera House, as part of a series curated by Solange. Appearing between the poet Claudia Rankine and the saxophonist Archie Shepp, Sharrock guided eight musicians through a fully improvised set while she howled powerfully over the cacophonous squall of free jazz in a declamatory style that evoked the evening’s program title, “The Cry of My People.”

headline: My Sister Was Murdered 30 Years Ago. True Crime Repackages Our Pain as Entertainment.
abstract: I grew up watching the brief beauty of my sister’s life weaponized to usher in an era of mass incarceration and true crime obsession.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s you would have been hard-pressed to find someone who didn’t know the name of my sister Polly Klaas. I was 6 years old when a stranger abducted 12-year-old Polly from our bedroom on the evening of Oct. 1, 1993. Her face quickly became a fixture on nightly news, her name featured prominently in headlines alongside fearmongering about crime rates. News crews broadcast from our living room and remained camped in front of our house during the two-month search before her body was found.

headline: Two Friends Reunite. One Has a Secret.
abstract: In “Goldenseal,” Maria Hummel takes readers into a hotel room, then unfurls her characters’ complicated history.
lead_paragraph: Maria Hummel’s new novel, “Goldenseal,” begins in 1990, when Edith Morgan returns to Los Angeles for the first time in 44 years with a secret for an old friend. Lacey Weber Crane, the pampered only child of German-speaking parents from Prague, is now a recluse in the glamorous hotel her parents once owned. She’s so nervous at the thought of Edith’s arrival that she feels “her body betraying her, dampening her armpits, breathing out sour breath.”

headline: ​This Year, DeSantis Won’t Loom as Large Over Florida Legislative Session
abstract: With Gov. Ron DeSantis focused on the presidential primaries, the session that starts next week could be unusually low key.
lead_paragraph: When the Florida Legislature begins its annual session on Tuesday, Gov. Ron DeSantis will be on hand — fleetingly. After giving his State of the State address, he will leave for Iowa, where he has a packed campaign schedule ahead of the Republican presidential caucuses on Jan. 15. Few in Tallahassee expect to see much of him in the months that follow.

headline: The Seeds Joe Biden Has Planted
abstract: President Biden has reinvigorated the government’s role as the nation’s most important investor.
lead_paragraph: There is a famous story by the French writer Jean Giono about a man who plants trees in a barren valley. “For three years he had been planting trees in this wilderness. He had planted 100,000. Of the 100,000, 20,000 had sprouted. Of the 20,000 he still expected to lose about half, to rodents or to the unpredictable designs of Providence. There remained 10,000 oak trees to grow where nothing had grown before.”

headline: Trump Is Connecting With a Different Type of Evangelical Voter
abstract: They are not just the churchgoing, conservative activists who once dominated the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: Karen Johnson went to her Lutheran church so regularly as a child that she won a perfect attendance award. As an adult, she taught Sunday school. But these days, Ms. Johnson, a 67-year-old counter attendant at a slot-machine parlor, no longer goes to church.

headline: Can a Big Village Full of Tiny Homes Ease Homelessness in Austin?
abstract: One of the nation’s largest experiments in affordable housing to address chronic homelessness is taking shape outside the city limits.
lead_paragraph: On the outskirts of Austin, Texas, what began as a fringe experiment has quickly become central to the city’s efforts to reduce homelessness. To Justin Tyler Jr., it is home.

headline: Help! An Employee of Budget Kept My Phone and I Can Prove It.
abstract: After misplacing his iPhone while returning a rental car, a traveler tracked down the device and presented strong evidence to the agency that a worker took it — to no avail.
lead_paragraph: One day last July, I was dropping off a rental car at Budget’s location at Boston Logan International Airport when I misplaced my iPhone. As best as I can recall, I left it in the car while I went to throw away some trash, but neither my wife nor I nor the employee who was helping us could find it. After my flight home, I began tracking the phone using Apple’s Find My application, and after a trip through western Massachusetts and New Hampshire, the phone began traveling back and forth from an apartment building in Lynn, Mass., to the Budget office at Logan. I reported this to both Budget and the airport police, but the police told me that they could take action only if Budget gave them the name of any employees who lived at that address, and Budget would not help. I want Budget to return my phone or pay for a replacement. Can you help? John, Jacksonville, Fla.

headline: How the Met’s Prop-Shop Magic Makes Trucks Move Onstage
abstract: In the Metropolitan Opera’s production of “Carmen,” three pickup trucks and a tractor-trailer are crucial props.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll find out what drives the trucks on the stage in “Carmen” at the Metropolitan Opera. We’ll also get details on subway service on the 1, 2 and 3 lines after the derailment last week on the Upper West Side.

headline: Which TV Show or Movie Would You Want to Live?
abstract: Live interactive experiences inspired by popular shows like “Squid Game” and “Friends” are trending. Do they appeal to you?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever loved a TV show or movie so much that you wanted to walk through — or even exist within — its fictional world?

headline: A Novel of the Spanish Conquest, Magic Mushrooms Included
abstract: Álvaro Enrigue’s “You Dreamed of Empires” is a hallucinatory tale of the conquistadors’ arrival at Moctezuma’s gates.
lead_paragraph: The Mexican writer Álvaro Enrigue’s new novel has a soft, nebulous title: “You Dreamed of Empires.” Its cover is forgettable, too. Like nearly every book on the New Fiction table, it is all wavy patterns and beach-towel colors. This generic look has come to promise a) bright settings and b) young characters out to conquer racial and sexual threats as they perceive them. This would be excellent were it not for, as often as not, c) writing in which one is instructed how to feel at almost every moment.

headline: For a Brooklyn Family, the Infestation of Rodents Seems Endless
abstract: In Williamsburg, city housing authorities, the courts and, to a degree, even the landlord, are trying to help. But the mice and roaches keep coming.
lead_paragraph: Jackelyn Silva misses the days when she could store food in her cabinets without giving it a second thought. Or step away from the kitchen table for a moment without a worry.  “You can’t cook breakfast and leave it there,” she said, “because once you turn, you’ve got a roach on your food.”

headline: Robots Learn, Chatbots Visualize: How 2024 Will Be A.I.’s ‘Leap Forward’
abstract: A.I. is set to advance at a rapid rate, becoming more powerful and spreading into the physical world.
lead_paragraph: At an event in San Francisco in November, Sam Altman, the chief executive of the artificial intelligence company OpenAI, was asked what surprises the field would bring in 2024.

headline: Why Is My Dessert on a Pedestal? 7 New Styles at the Restaurant Table.
abstract: The art of arranging food, known as plating, has entered a freewheeling new phase. Here are the latest fashions, fads and follies.
lead_paragraph: At the restaurant ILIS in Brooklyn, your smoked tomato and clam dashi arrives in a giant clamshell, sealed with beeswax and roped shut. At Naks in the East Village, bites of beef tartare on crisped beef fat are ferried to your table on a cow horn.

headline: $3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Victorian rowhouse in San Francisco, a 1966 ranch house in Malibu and a three-bedroom home in Menlo Park.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Potrero Hill, about a 10-minute walk from Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center. It is also within walking distance of a public library, public elementary and high schools, and Potrero Hill Recreation Center, which sits in a park with a baseball diamond, tennis courts and a playground.

headline: Is It Ever OK to Wear Matching Sweats?
abstract: A reader wonders whether the Y2K-era staple is cringey — or due for a comeback.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld, the Chanel designer whose talent for dramatic pronouncements was equaled only by his talent for dreaming up extraordinary clothes, once declared sweatpants “a sign of defeat.”

headline: Claudine Gay Was Not Driven Out Because She Is Black
abstract: Opposing D.E.I. is not the same as racism.
lead_paragraph: Since Claudine Gay’s resignation as president of Harvard University on Tuesday, it has become an article of faith among some of her supporters and other observers that she was targeted, criticized and essentially driven from the job largely because of her race. The idea is that the people who questioned her abilities and academic integrity — be they Harvard donors who found fault with her leadership after Oct. 7 or conservative activists who led an inquiry into plagiarism in her scholarly work — were marked and even motivated by animus toward a Black woman attaining such a degree of power and influence.

headline: As the College Sports Model Teeters, Champion Michigan Works to Balance
abstract: The Wolverines beat the Washington Huskies 34-13 Monday night to win the College Football Playoff National Championship.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in Hawaii, Roman Wilson didn’t realize how much money was in college football until his senior year in high school when he took a weeklong recruiting visit to the mainland. His first stops were Cal-Berkeley and U.C.L.A. “Very nice facilities,” he thought.

headline: How a Conservative Christian College Got Mixed Up in the 2020 Election Plot
abstract: Hillsdale College has become quietly involved in many political fights — including Trump’s attempt to overturn his defeat.
lead_paragraph: A few days before Thanksgiving 2020, a half-dozen or so people gathered at the home of a Michigan lawyer named Robert E. Norton II.

headline: Which Trump Toady Would the MAGA King Pick as His No. 2?
abstract: The woman option is the one that most intrigues me.
lead_paragraph: With presidential primaries, it ain’t over till it’s over. Still, given the Republicans’ enduring devotion to their MAGA king, it’s best to mentally prepare oneself for the likelihood that the guy who has long been the prohibitive front-runner will, in fact, win the nomination. And a particularly juicy part of that preparation is obsessing over who Donald Trump will pick as his new pain sponge — erm, running mate — and what that choice could tell us about his strategy and state of mind this time around.

headline: Taking a Cue From the Squirrels in My Birdhouse
abstract: To make it through the gathering disquiet, I will need embodied connection.
lead_paragraph: Just before 2023 gave way to 2024, my husband and I drove down a mountain, talking about how to manage election-year anxiety. Specifically, my election-year anxiety. We had just spent a few days in a cottage in the woods, and we were jazzed on silence and stillness and the obligation to do nothing but walk together among the trees. To listen to the wind in the trees.

headline: Biden Tries to Rally Disaffected Black Voters in Fiery Condemnation of Trump
abstract: The president visited Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., the site of one of the most horrific hate crimes in recent years, to denounce racism and extremism.
lead_paragraph: President Biden sought to rally disaffected Black supporters on Monday with a fiery condemnation of former President Donald J. Trump, linking his predecessor’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election to the nation’s history of white supremacy in what he called “the old ghost in new garments.”

headline: Best and Worst Moments From the 2024 Golden Globes
abstract: Lily Gladstone made history, Jo Koy did not. And dressing on a theme proved a hit. These were just some of the highs and lows.
lead_paragraph: The Golden Globes had a lot to prove Sunday night. It was the award show’s return to a primo broadcast time slot after a series of scandals over finances and lack of diversity upended what used to be known as the biggest party of the year in Hollywood. Now privately owned with a greatly expanded pool of voters, the Globes were making a bid for relevance. Did that bid succeed? Well, it helped that this was the first major televised ceremony since the writers’ and actors’ strikes brought Hollywood to a halt, and stars and studios looking to goose their Oscar chances turned out after some skipped last year’s event. Then again, this wasn’t the liveliest show. Here are the highs and lows as we saw them.

headline: The Election No One Seems to Want Is Coming Right at Us
abstract: It’s 2024. Sorry.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Hey, Bret, it really is 2024 now. Happy new year. And the race is on! Next week, the Iowa caucuses. After Iowa …

headline: China Says It Detained a Foreign Consultant for Spying for Britain
abstract: The Ministry of State Security says the consultant collected intelligence and found people on behalf of MI6, Britain’s spy agency.
lead_paragraph: China’s top intelligence agency said Monday that it had detained the head of an overseas consulting agency for working as a spy for the British government to collect Chinese state secrets.

headline: U.S. Faces Week of Extreme Weather, Including Blizzards and Flooding
abstract: A series of powerful weather systems moving across the country will bring heavy snow to the Plains and up to four inches of rain to the Northeast, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: A series of powerful major weather systems are moving across the United States this week, bringing “extremely dangerous” blizzard conditions to the center of the country, widespread damaging winds across the East, tornadic storms to the South and “significant” flooding to the Northeast, forecasters warn.

headline: The Wild World of Money in College Football
abstract: How rich donors and loose rules are transforming college sports.
lead_paragraph: Tonight, millions of Americans are expected to tune in to watch one of the biggest sports events of the year, college football’s national championship game. On the field, the game will be determined by the skill of the players and coaches, but behind the scenes, secretive groups of donors are wielding enormous influence over what fans will see.

headline: How an Obscure Song Became an a Cappella Sensation
abstract: Few people were aware of the 1994 single “Insomniac” by the rock duo Billy Pilgrim, and it quickly sank into obscurity. But a cappella groups can’t stop singing it. We set out to find an explanation.
lead_paragraph: In high school, I joined Rebel Yell, an a cappella group named after the Billy Idol song. I mostly beatboxed or sang background vocals. But one year, my chorus teacher gave me a lead vocal.

headline: Final Campaign Week in Iowa, and a Rare Moon Mission
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Misleading SAT Debate
abstract: Higher education has a standardized-test problem.
lead_paragraph: Higher education has a standardized-test problem, and it’s not the problem that many people think.

headline: An Antique Dress Held a Secret: A Coded Message From 1888
abstract: For nearly a decade, sleuths had tried to decode a cryptic note discovered in the silk bustle dress. An analyst finally cracked the case.
lead_paragraph: Sara Rivers Cofield was on her usual search for interesting period clothing about a decade ago when she noticed what appeared to be a “textbook” silk bustle dress from the 1800s at an antique mall in Maine.

headline: World War II-era Munitions Found Dumped Off Los Angeles Coast
abstract: Using a high-tech underwater camera, researchers identified anti-submarine explosives, smoke devices and boxes of munitions on the ocean floor.
lead_paragraph: When marine scientists sent an underwater camera down to the seafloor off the Southern California coast, they expected to find the remnants of barrels used to dump chemical waste decades ago.

headline: Blinken Says Saudi Arabia Remains Interested in Diplomatic Ties With Israel
abstract: The U.S. secretary of state, on a trip to the Middle East that included a meeting with the Saudi crown prince, said such a move would require an end to fighting in Gaza and steps toward a Palestinian state.
lead_paragraph: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said on Monday that the leader of Saudi Arabia told him that establishing diplomatic recognition between the kingdom and Israel was still possible, but it required an end to the war in Gaza and practical steps toward a Palestinian state.

headline: India’s Top Court Reverses Early Release of 11 Men Convicted of Gang Rape
abstract: The case of Bilkis Bano, who was three months pregnant when she was attacked, became a powerful symbol of communal bloodshed and of the widespread violence against women in the country.
lead_paragraph: India’s top court on Monday restored life sentences for 11 Hindu men convicted of the gang rape of a Muslim woman in a case that became a powerful symbol of the widespread violence against Indian women and of communal tensions often exacerbated by Indian politicians.

headline: Exhausted, on the Defensive and at ‘Hell’s Gate’ in Ukraine
abstract: The country’s forces along a broad stretch of the front say that, with Russia pushing forward, the war has never been so dangerous.
lead_paragraph: ZAPORIZHZHIA REGION, Ukraine — Under the cover of darkness, leaning forward under the weight of packs and rifles, a squad of soldiers walked along a muddy lane and slipped into a village house.

headline: Investors Bail on Boeing Following Max 9 Grounding
abstract: The jet maker’s share price fell sharply in premarket trading on Monday after hundreds of flights were canceled and safety inspections resumed.
lead_paragraph: Investors are bailing on Boeing and one of its biggest suppliers this morning after a harrowing malfunction at 16,000 feet this weekend in which a door panel sheared off a new 737 Max 9 airliner in midflight.

headline: Jonathan Majors Says He Was ‘Shocked’ by Assault Conviction
abstract: Mr. Majors spoke on ABC’s “Good Morning America,” his first interview since being convicted of misdemeanor assault and harassment for attacking his girlfriend in a car.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Majors, an ascending Hollywood star whose career was upended when he was found guilty last month of assault and harassment for attacking his girlfriend, said in an interview broadcast on Monday that he was “absolutely shocked” by the verdict.

headline: Two Capitol Riots. Two Very Different Results.
abstract: Why has Brazil united in rejecting last year’s insurrection, while the United States remains deeply divided over Jan. 6?
lead_paragraph: Monday marks one year since thousands of right-wing protesters draped in the colors of the Brazilian flag stormed into Brazil’s Congress, Supreme Court and presidential offices with a violent fury and the goal of overturning an election.

headline: Prince’s ‘Purple Rain’ Is Being Developed as a Stage Musical
abstract: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins is lined up to write the book, and Lileana Blain-Cruz will direct.
lead_paragraph: “Purple Rain,” Prince’s breakout rise-of-a-rock-star film, is being adapted into a stage musical featuring some of the pop musician’s best-loved songs.

headline: Some California Farmers Pay for Groundwater. Is That Workable?
abstract: A conversation with Coral Davenport, a climate reporter, about a novel water payment system in the Pajaro Valley.
lead_paragraph: It’s Monday. Behind a program that charges farmers in the Pajaro Valley for groundwater. Plus, California and other states that rely on the dwindling Colorado River are racing to agree on consumption cuts.

headline: Francis Urges Ban on Surrogacy, Calling It ‘Despicable’
abstract: The pope said that an unborn child must not be “turned into an object of trafficking,” expanding his condemnation of a practice already illegal in Italy and some other European countries.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis on Monday called surrogate motherhood a “despicable” practice that should be universally banned for its “commercialization” of pregnancy, including the practice among wars, terrorism and other threats to peace and humanity in an annual speech to ambassadors.

headline: What Winning a Golden Globe Looks Like
abstract: Lily Gladstone, Paul Giamatti, Billie Eilish and stars from “Succession,” “Beef” and “The Bear” are captured in their moments of glory.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles-based photographer Erik Carter was backstage at the Beverly Hilton Hotel on Sunday, where he photographed Golden Globes winners for The Times.

headline: Mitch Landrieu, Biden’s Infrastructure Czar, Moves to Presidential Campaign
abstract: Mr. Landrieu championed public works projects across the country. He will now aim to rejuvenate Mr. Biden’s campaign in the face of voter frustration about the economy.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — Mitch Landrieu, the coordinator of President Biden’s ambitious infrastructure program, is stepping down from his post to help lead the president’s re-election campaign, the White House said in a statement on Monday.

headline: Many Have Preached Politics From This Pulpit, but Biden Is the First President
abstract: Mr. Biden visited Emanuel A.M.E. Church after a racist massacre in 2015 to mourn with a shaken congregation. He returned Monday to warn of the political threats of hate-filled violence.
lead_paragraph: Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., the oldest A.M.E. church in the South, will forever be associated with former President Barack Obama because of his memorable — and melodic — eulogy for the nine victims of a racist massacre in its fellowship hall in June 2015.

headline: Boeing’s Stock Drops as Investors Assess Fallout From 737 Max Incident
abstract: The aircraft maker and a key supplier of parts were punished in the markets after a chunk of a plane’s fuselage blew out on an Alaska Airlines flight.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s share price fell sharply on Monday, in the first trading session after part of the fuselage of one of its 737 Max 9 jets blew out on an Alaska Airlines flight on Friday night.

headline: Writing in an Endangered Language to Honor, and Challenge, Traditions
abstract: In “How to Be a Good Savage,” Mikeas Sánchez’ poems help preserve her language, Zoque, and allow it to commingle with English and Spanish, in an effort that is both global and deeply local.
lead_paragraph: Mikeas Sánchez writes poetry in Zoque, a language spoken by around 100,000 people. The variant she grew up with, called Copainalá, is considered endangered; some 15,000 people use it.

headline: Africa’s Birds of Prey Are in Decline, a New Study Finds
abstract: Numbers have dropped, in some cases sharply, for nearly all of the 42 raptor species surveyed in sub-Saharan regions.
lead_paragraph: Silhouettes of patrolling raptors filled skies throughout Africa as recently as a few decades ago, but it’s much less common to spot those birds of prey today. Now, new research gives an indication of just how sharp the birds’ decline has been.

headline: Pro-Palestinian Demonstrators Block N.Y. Bridge and Tunnel Traffic
abstract: Hundreds of demonstrators protesting Israel’s bombardment of Gaza blocked the Manhattan entrance to the Holland Tunnel and disrupted traffic on three major bridges.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators on Monday blocked off entrances to the Holland Tunnel and the Brooklyn, Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges, disrupting rush-hour traffic in Manhattan as they protested Israel’s bombardment of the Gaza Strip and called for a cease-fire.

headline: Video Captures Mouse Organizing Shed
abstract: Rodney Holbrook, a wildlife photographer in Wales, caught a mouse on camera decluttering his backyard shed.
lead_paragraph: Rodney Holbrook, a wildlife photographer in Wales, caught a mouse on camera decluttering his backyard shed.

headline: How to Fall in Love With Tofu
abstract: The tangy, spicy notes in this sweet chile grain bowl will delight both the tofu faithful and the merely tofu curious.
lead_paragraph: In my column this week I wrote about my quest to eat more plant-based meals, with the goal to become as fluent in tofu as I am in chicken thighs. Turns out, those proteins have a lot in common, including an affinity for pungent marinades and a tendency to become their tastiest selves when laid out on a sheet pan and blasted with high heat.

headline: How Well Do You Know Paris and Its Literary Landmarks?
abstract: This quick quiz tests your general knowledge of the great European city — and suggests five Paris-based novels for your reading list.
lead_paragraph: This quick quiz tests your general knowledge of the great European city — and suggests five Paris-based novels for your reading list.

headline: To Cut Back on Drinking, Try Damp January
abstract: Experts say that making an effort to drink less can benefit your health and help you build good habits around alcohol.
lead_paragraph: Raise a mock margarita or a phony Negroni — Dry January is once again in full swing.

headline: Hochul to Propose A.I. Research Center Using $275 Million in State Funds
abstract: The “Empire A.I.” project would be a public-private partnership aimed at making New York a key player in artificial intelligence research.
lead_paragraph: In her third State of the State address, Gov. Kathy Hochul will propose a first-of-its-kind statewide consortium that would bring together public and private resources to put New York at the forefront of the artificial intelligence landscape.

headline: Israel Says Its Military Is Starting to Shift to a More Targeted Gaza Campaign
abstract: Israeli officials privately say that they hope to complete the transition by the end of January, but that the timeline could change.
lead_paragraph: Israel said its military is starting to shift from a large-scale ground and air campaign in the Gaza Strip to a more targeted phase in its war against Hamas, and Israeli officials have privately told their American counterparts that they hoped the transition would be completed by the end of January, U.S. officials said.

headline: TikTok Quietly Curtails Data Tool Used by Critics
abstract: People and groups had harnessed the tool to scrutinize content on the site related to the Israel-Hamas war and other topics.
lead_paragraph: TikTok has quietly restricted one of its few tools to help measure the popularity of trends on the video app, after the tool’s results were used by researchers and lawmakers to scrutinize content on the site related to geopolitics and the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: India and Maldives Trade Barbs After Modi’s Beach Visit
abstract: Some in the Maldives were critical of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s trip to nearby Indian islands to promote tourism, seeing it as an attempt to draw visitors away from their nation.
lead_paragraph: It started with a postcard-perfect snapshot. An image of India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, lounging in a chair on a secluded white-sand beach, provoked heated words from officials in the Maldives, a tiny archipelago nation in the Indian Ocean.

headline: ‘Welsh Tidy Mouse’ Tidies Tiny Welsh House
abstract: For months, a mysterious helper was cleaning up the work bench in Rodney Holbrook’s shed every night. He caught the visitor, tail and all, on video.
lead_paragraph: There was something strange going on in Rodney Holbrook’s backyard shed.

headline: An Enforcer for a Strongman President Goes on Trial in Milestone Swiss Case
abstract: Ousman Sonko served the authoritarian president of Gambia for years, seeking asylum in Switzerland after losing his job. Now he faces charges of crimes against humanity.
lead_paragraph: For roughly 16 years Ousman Sonko wielded sweeping power in Gambia’s security apparatus, crushing opposition to the West African country’s authoritarian president.

headline: Trump’s Lawyers Say He Should Be Immune From Prosecution in Georgia Case
abstract: The motion echoes an argument that former President Donald J. Trump is making in a separate federal criminal case against him.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump in the election interference case in Georgia asked on Monday to have the criminal charges against him there dismissed based in part on an argument that Mr. Trump is also making in the federal criminal case against him: that presidents should enjoy sweeping immunity from criminal prosecution for “official acts” taken while in office.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘1989 (Taylor’s Version)’ Tops Chart Again
abstract: Swift holds at No. 1 as Christmas favorites vanish from Billboard’s top 10 albums. Morgan Wallen’s “One Thing at a Time” is at No. 2.
lead_paragraph: A week ago, holiday titles dominated Billboard’s album chart, occupying half the top 10. But now that streaming playlists are no longer overindexing on roasting chestnuts, things have gone back to normal. Which means, of course, that Taylor Swift is (still) on top.

headline: Far Right Balks as Congress Begins Push to Enact Spending Deal
abstract: With little time to spare before a shutdown deadline, Speaker Mike Johnson will have to navigate the same political currents that did in his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Congress on Monday began an uphill push to pass a new bipartisan spending agreement into law in time to avoid a partial government shutdown next week, with Speaker Mike Johnson encountering stiff resistance from his far-right flank to the deal he struck with Democrats.

headline: A snowstorm in Iowa is hindering Republicans’ campaign plans.
abstract: In the last week before the Republican caucuses, the threat of heavy snow has forced Nikki Haley, Vivek Ramaswamy and Donald J. Trump to alter their schedules.
lead_paragraph: A storm that is forecast to dump close to a foot of snow in parts of Iowa on Monday and Tuesday is upending the campaigning plans of some candidates as they try to make the most of the last week before the Republican caucuses.

headline: Israel Picks Holocaust Survivor Judge for Genocide Case, Surprising Some
abstract: Aharon Barak, a retired Israeli Supreme Court president, fought the government’s judicial overhaul plan. But it chose him for the panel hearing a case against it in a United Nations court.
lead_paragraph: As Israel prepares this week to face accusations at the International Court of Justice that it has committed genocide in the Gaza war, it has appointed one of the country’s most prominent jurists as the ad hoc judge to sit on the bench on its behalf.

headline: How to Define a Good Wine? It’s Complicated.
abstract: Yes, a wine ought to taste good. But there’s much more to consider, including farming, winemaking and intent.
lead_paragraph: What makes a wine “good”?

headline: Biden’s Harsh Attack on Trump in a Campaign Speech
abstract: Readers agree with the president that democracy is imperiled if his predecessor is elected. Also: The Japan plane crash; how the movie “Munich” resonates.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Protesters Calling for Gaza Cease-Fire Interrupt Biden Speech
abstract: A group of protesters chanted “Cease-fire now.” Biden supporters countered with “Four more years.”
lead_paragraph: Protesters interrupted President Biden’s speech at a church in Charleston, S.C., on Monday, urging him to call for a cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: What if Joe Biden Is Actually Right About 2024?
abstract: The president performed a public service by forthrightly stating what could happen to the country and its democracy if Trump wins again.
lead_paragraph: “What a sick … My God.”

headline: Man Who Attacked Las Vegas Judge Gets Up to 4 Years in Prison
abstract: The attack, which was caught on video, cut short a sentencing hearing for Deobra Redden on an earlier battery conviction. He now faces additional charges in the assault on the judge.
lead_paragraph: A judge who was attacked by a defendant in a Las Vegas courtroom last week sentenced the man on Monday to 19 to 48 months in prison on a previous battery charge, emphasizing that his actions last week did not affect her sentencing decision.

headline: Pakistani Justices Reject Ban for Politicians With Past Convictions
abstract: The decision by the Supreme Court paves the way for a former prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, to run in parliamentary elections in February.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan’s Supreme Court on Monday overturned a law that barred politicians with past convictions from seeking political office, in a move that paves the way for former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif to run in parliamentary elections in February.

headline: France’s Prime Minister Resigns Ahead of Cabinet Reshuffle
abstract: Élisabeth Borne, only the second woman to occupy the position, stepped down as President Emmanuel Macron tries to inject fresh energy into his second term.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Élisabeth Borne of France resigned on Monday ahead of a widely expected cabinet reshuffle by President Emmanuel Macron, as he attempts to inject new energy into his presidency at the start of a year of major events in France, including European Parliamentary elections and the Summer Olympics in Paris.

headline: Franz Beckenbauer, ‘Der Kaiser’ of World Soccer, Dies at 78
abstract: In West Germany, he revolutionized his central defense position and was one of only three people to win the World Cup as a player and a coach.
lead_paragraph: Franz Beckenbauer, a World Cup winner as a player and a coach who became the defining figure in German soccer for more than half a century, died on Sunday. He was 78.

headline: Panel on Boeing Plane May Not Have Been Properly Attached, Agency Says
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board’s statement about the Max 9 jet that had a midair blowout came hours after two airlines reported finding loose parts on some Max 9s.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators said late Monday that it was possible that the bolts that were supposed to keep a fuselage panel in place were never installed before the panel blew off an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 in a near-disastrous accident on Friday night.

headline: Tenmile Distillery’s Single Malt Whisky Conjures the Hudson Valley and Scotland
abstract: Deluxe hot chocolate on the Upper East Side, a talk on national dishes and more food news.
lead_paragraph: American distillers have been turning their attention to single malts, defined in Scotland as whisky produced in one distillery from 100 percent malted barley. In the United States these rules are usually followed, but have yet to be mandated by government regulators; it should happen soon. In Wassaic, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley, John Dyson is betting on the appeal of American single malts at his Tenmile Distillery. A former state Commissioner of Agriculture and Tourism who owns Millbrook Vineyards & Winery nearby and Williams Selyem winery in California, Mr. Dyson hired Shane Fraser, a master distiller from Scotland, to run the distillery. Their Little Rest Whisky, with whisky spelled as it is in Scotland since the distillery produces the spirit as is done in Scotland, is the second edition, recently released after a very limited first run. It’s light bronze and scented of toast and honey, with notes of hazelnuts on the palate, and excellent to sip with or without ice. If terroir can shape a whiskey, this one evokes the gentle, welcoming Hudson Valley. The distillery also produces gin and vodka.

headline: American Company’s Spacecraft Malfunctions on Its Way to the Moon
abstract: After a flawless launch to orbit, the privately built robotic Peregrine lander is unlikely to reach the lunar surface because of a failure in its propulsion system.
lead_paragraph: The first NASA-financed commercial mission to send a robotic spacecraft to the surface of the moon will most likely not be able to make it there.

headline: Jo Koy Responds to Golden Globes Criticism: ‘It’s a Tough Room’
abstract: In an interview on the ABC program “GMA3” the morning after the awards show, Koy said he would “be lying” if he said the criticism “doesn’t hurt.”
lead_paragraph: Hosting a Hollywood awards show can be a notoriously difficult job, with its audience of image-conscious A-list celebrities on the receiving end and a large television audience scrutinizing the material in real time. After Jo Koy’s performance as the host of this year’s Golden Globes drew criticism, he acknowledged Monday that it had been “a tough room.”

headline: Why Iowa Turned So Red When Nearby States Went Blue
abstract: Over the past 15 years, the Upper Midwest has seen a remarkable state-by-state sorting of voters along partisan lines.
lead_paragraph: With the Iowa caucuses days away, politicians will be crisscrossing the state, blowing through small-town Pizza Ranches, filling high school gyms, and flipping pancakes at church breakfasts.

headline: We Still Need to Talk About Government Debt
abstract: Last weekend’s deal is good news, but the basic problems remain.
lead_paragraph: I’m near-term slightly more optimistic but long-term pessimistic about the ability of the United States to deal with its budget problems. My uptick in optimism comes from a deal in Washington, while the pessimism comes from what I heard at an economics conference in San Antonio that I attended last weekend.

headline: Ukrainian Residential Buildings Destroyed by Russian Air Assault
abstract: Some civilians sheltered in subway stations as Russia launched a widespread missile attack on regions across Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Some civilians sheltered in subway stations as Russia launched a widespread missile attack on regions across Ukraine.

headline: Chairman of Florida Republican Party Is Ousted Amid Scandal
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis and Senator Rick Scott had called for the resignation of the chairman, Christian Ziegler, who is being investigated for sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party of Florida ousted its chairman on Monday, more than a month after the police in Sarasota confirmed that he was under criminal investigation for sexual assault.

headline: ‘Oppenheimer’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The writer and director Christopher Nolan narrates the opening sequence from the film.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Christopher Nolan narrates the opening sequence from the film.

headline: Watch the Opening Scene of ‘Oppenheimer’
abstract: The writer and director Christopher Nolan narrates a sequence from his film, which won the Golden Globe for best drama.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Send Us Your Questions About the 2024 U.S. Presidential Election
abstract: Got a query, or just curious about the election? The On Politics newsletter team can help: We’re answering reader questions.
lead_paragraph: If you’re wondering: What’s the difference between a caucus and a primary? How does the Electoral College work, again? Which important voting deadlines should be on my calendar?

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Israel’s New Phase in Gaza
abstract: Also, a recap of the Golden Globes.
lead_paragraph: Israel has begun a new and less intense phase of its invasion of Gaza, its military said, after weeks of pressure to scale back its offensive. But its chief of staff said that the country was ready for “another war” against Hezbollah, which said a commander was killed in a strike in Lebanon.

headline: Here’s What to Know About Hezbollah’s Radwan Force
abstract: The elite unit of the Lebanese armed group lost a commander in a strike on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Israel has long seen Hezbollah, with thousands of trained fighters and a deep arsenal of rockets and other weapons, as the most formidable foe on its borders. And Israeli officials say Hezbollah’s elite Radwan force, in particular, poses a major threat.

headline: New President of Realtors Group Abruptly Resigns
abstract: Tracy Kasper, who took over as president of the National Association of Realtors after the sudden resignation of her predecessor, has quit after what the group described as a threat.
lead_paragraph: The president of the embattled National Association of Realtors has resigned, just four months into her tenure. Tracy Kasper is the second president to abruptly step down from N.A.R. — an organization that has seen its power and influence wane in recent months in the wake of losing a major antitrust lawsuit and amid allegations that leaders had ignored sexual harassment allegations.

headline: Science Teacher Finds Missing Piece of Boeing Jet’s Fuselage in His Yard
abstract: Bob Sauer said that his 50-foot cedar trees had acted on the same scientific principle as an airbag, disrupting the door plug’s fall in an act known in physics as impulse.
lead_paragraph: Bob Sauer went into his backyard in suburban Portland, Ore., on Sunday night, flashlight in hand, to check if any pieces of the Alaska Airlines plane that had lost a part of its fuselage in midair had landed nearby.

headline: Apparent ‘Swatting’ Incidents Target Judge and Prosecutor in Trump Election Case
abstract: The police were called to the homes of Judge Tanya S. Chutkan and the special counsel, Jack Smith, in separate incidents after false reports of shootings there.
lead_paragraph: Police officers and emergency personnel were sent on Sunday night to the Washington home of the federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s election interference case in what appeared to be an incident of “swatting,” according to three people familiar with the matter.

headline: 4 Aides to Austin Waited 2 Days to Tell White House About His Hospitalization
abstract: The defense secretary remains in the hospital but is in “good condition” and conducting official business, the Pentagon spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: Four top aides to Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III were informed last Tuesday that he had been hospitalized a day earlier but did not notify the White House until two days later, the Pentagon said on Monday.

headline: Golden Globes Draws 9.4 Million Viewers
abstract: The number of viewers was higher than last year, but still down significantly compared with prepandemic audience totals.
lead_paragraph: The Golden Globes averaged 9.4 million viewers on Sunday night, according to Nielsen, an increase over the 2023 ceremony ratings but still significantly lower than the audience totals of just a few years ago.

headline: Supreme Court Appears Split Over Notice Requirements for Immigration Court
abstract: Although the legal question was narrow, the argument reflected broader debates about the immigration system.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court appeared divided on Monday over what counted as proper notice for the government to give to people facing deportation hearings.

headline: Video Shows Aftermath of Strike in Southern Lebanon
abstract: A video circulating on social media on Monday showed the scene of a strike in Khirbet Selm, a village in southern Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: A video circulating on social media on Monday showed the scene of a strike in Khirbet Selm, a village in southern Lebanon.

headline: Trump’s Pattern of Pressure to Overturn the 2020 Election
abstract: Donald J. Trump pressured state and federal government officials to overturn results of the 2020 election in more than 30 phone calls or meetings, according to The Times’s analysis of the indictments related to those efforts.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump pressured state and federal government officials to overturn results of the 2020 election in more than 30 phone calls or meetings, according to The Times’s analysis of the indictments related to those efforts.

headline: 21 Injured in Explosion at Fort Worth Hotel
abstract: The episode, which the authorities said was most likely caused by a gas leak, caused substantial damage to the Sandman Signature hotel in downtown Fort Worth.
lead_paragraph: At least 21 people were injured in an explosion that was most likely caused by a gas leak and substantially damaged a hotel in downtown Fort Worth on Monday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: Impeachment and Border Talks Put G.O.P. at Odds Over Mayorkas
abstract: House Republicans are pressing to impeach the homeland security secretary just as Senate Republicans look to him to help cut a border security deal.
lead_paragraph: This week in the Republican-led House, G.O.P. representatives plan to kick off their formal effort to impeach Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary who has been one of their favorite punching bags.

headline: Hotel in Downtown Forth Worth Damaged After Explosion
abstract: Witness videos showed debris strewn across the street outside the Sandman Signature hotel in Fort Worth.
lead_paragraph: Witness videos showed debris strewn across the street outside the Sandman Signature hotel in Fort Worth.

headline: The State of Play in Iowa: What to Know About the G.O.P. Presidential Caucuses
abstract: Donald Trump leads the polls by more than 30 points.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Iowa are about to cast their ballots, and we’re back, ready to guide you through what promises to be an election year like no other.

headline: Israel Said It Had Begun a Less Intense Phase of the War
abstract: Also, the investigation into Boeing planes. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Israel announced today that its military had begun a new and less intense phase of its war against Hamas, after weeks of pressure to curtail its large-scale ground and air campaign. Israeli officials privately told their American counterparts they hoped the transition would be completed by the end of the month.

headline: JetBlue Chief Executive to Step Down
abstract: Robin Hayes described the decision to retire as “bittersweet,” and suggested that unspecified health concerns had driven it.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of JetBlue Airways, Robin Hayes, said on Monday that he planned to step down after nine years in the role and while in the middle of trying to carry out a merger with Spirit Airlines that could reshape the industry, if it isn’t blocked in court.

headline: Alexis Smith, Artist With Eclectic Eye on American Culture, Dies at 74
abstract: She used installations, assemblage and three-dimensional murals in her commentary on Hollywood, fame and more. “I’ve made stuff out of everything,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Smith, an artist who expressed a searing though affectionate vision of American culture in assemblages, installations and public art projects, died on Tuesday at her home in Venice, Calif. She was 74.

headline: Don’t Be Surprised if Trump Starts Attacking the Fed
abstract: Forewarned is forearmed: It will be bad-faith bullying.
lead_paragraph: Interest rates are heading down. Maybe not today, and maybe not tomorrow, but soon, and for the rest of this year (at least).

headline: Tony Fortuna, Restaurateur With a Congenial Flair, Dies at 76
