abstract: He turned running a dining room into a fine art at each of his restaurants over a 40-year career, most notably TBar on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: Tony Fortuna, a longtime Manhattan restaurateur who turned running a dining room into a fine art as a consummate host who treated customers as friends, died on Friday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 76.

headline: 52 Places to Go in 2024
abstract: No matter why you travel, our list offers inspiration.
lead_paragraph: No matter why you travel, our list offers inspiration.

headline: Biden Is Trying to Jolt Us Out of Learned Helplessness About Trump
abstract: We need to stay outraged about the ex-president’s plot against America.
lead_paragraph: After Joe Biden’s speech on Friday marking the anniversary of the Jan. 6 insurrection and laying out the democratic stakes of the next election, Mitt Romney pronounced himself unimpressed. “As a Biden campaign theme, I think the ‘threat to democracy’ pitch is a bust,” the Utah Republican told a New York Times reporter. “Biden needs fresh material, a new attack, rather than kicking a dead political horse.”

headline: Unity Software to Cut 25% of Its Work Force
abstract: The cuts follow a tough year in which the tech industry laid off tens of thousands of workers.
lead_paragraph: The videogame software provider Unity Software said on Monday that it would cut its work force by 25 percent, or roughly 1,800 jobs, in one of the first major tech industry layoffs this year.

headline: Challenged on Policy Views in Town-Hall Event, Haley Doesn’t Budge
abstract: Nikki Haley took pointed questions from both Iowans and Fox News hosts.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley was repeatedly challenged over policy views that veer away from her more conservative rivals during an hourlong town-hall event on Fox News on Monday, but she stood her ground — and called Donald J. Trump an agent of chaos and Ron DeSantis a liar.

headline: Israeli Strikes in Lebanon Kill Hezbollah Commander, Militia Says
abstract: The latest strikes across Israel’s northern border came as the U.S. secretary of state made another trip to the Middle East in efforts to prevent a wider war.
lead_paragraph: Israel launched strikes into southern Lebanon on Monday against Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed militia, which said one of its senior commanders had been killed there, adding to concerns that Israel’s fight against Hamas in Gaza could erupt into a wider regional war.

headline: Oct. 7 Assaults, Including Sexual Violence, Could Be Crimes Against Humanity, 2 U.N. Experts Say
abstract: The experts’ statement came after the United Nations had been the focus of months of frustrated accusations that it was ignoring the rape and mutilation of women during the Oct. 7 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Violence that included sexual atrocities committed during the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7 in Israel amounts to war crimes and may also be crimes against humanity, two United Nations human rights experts said on Monday, following months of frustrated accusations from Israel and women’s groups that the U.N. was ignoring the rape and sexual mutilation of women during the Oct. 7 invasion.

headline: Filing in Georgia Trump Case Claims ‘Improper’ Relationship Between Prosecutors
abstract: A defendant in the election interference case is arguing that the district attorney overseeing it and a special prosecutor she hired should be disqualified.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for one of the defendants charged along with former President Donald J. Trump in the Georgia election interference case said in a court filing on Monday that the district attorney overseeing the case, Fani T. Willis, had engaged in a “clandestine” relationship with the special prosecutor she hired to help handle it.

headline: Driver in Custody After Crashing Into Gate Near the White House
abstract: The Secret Service said that the driver’s motives were still unclear, but that there was no threat to the White House complex or the public.
lead_paragraph: A driver crashed into an exterior gate near the White House shortly before 6 p.m. Monday and was taken into custody, the Secret Service said, adding that the agency was still investigating whether the crash was intentional.

headline: Be Wide-Open
abstract: Adam Wagner reveals his hidden agenda.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: While Defending Trump, Ramaswamy Insists He’s More Electable in the Fall
abstract: On the snowy campaign trail in Iowa, he said the “system” would keep Donald Trump from reaching the White House.
lead_paragraph: In northwestern Iowa on Monday, Vivek Ramaswamy addressed, unprompted, a question that has trailed him throughout his presidential bid: Why should voters choose him instead of Donald J. Trump, the former president whom he routinely and staunchly defends?

headline: OpenAI Says New York Times Lawsuit Against It Is ‘Without Merit’
abstract: The artificial intelligence start-up said that it collaborated with news organizations and that The Times, which accused it of copyright infringement, was not telling the full story.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI said on Monday that a New York Times lawsuit against it was “without merit” and that it supported and created opportunities for news organizations, as it waded further into a debate over the unauthorized use of published work to train artificial intelligence technologies.

headline: ‘The Trees Saved Me’
abstract: In Romania, a walk in the woods blossomed into a mission to safeguard centuries-old beeches and the history that shaped them.
lead_paragraph: The story of the Forest of Immortal Stories begins not so long ago, in 2019, when Elena-Mirela Cojocaru, beloved wife of Ion Cojocaru, mayor of the hamlet of Nucsoara, died after a struggle with cancer. Mr. Cojocaru himself soon fell ill with a heart ailment; as a remedy his doctor told him to walk in the countryside, 6,000 or more steps a day.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Israel’s next phase of the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Israel said its military was starting to shift from a large-scale ground-and-air campaign in the Gaza Strip to a more targeted phase, with fewer troops and airstrikes, in its war against Hamas. Israeli officials have privately told their U.S. counterparts that they hoped the transition would be completed by the end of the month, U.S. officials said.

headline: Quotation of the Day:A ‘Leap Forward’ for A.I. May Occur in 2024
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “The rapid progress of A.I. will continue. It is inevitable.”

headline: Blinken begins meetings in Israel amid deepening disagreements over the war.
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was meeting with top Israeli officials on Tuesday, continuing diplomatic efforts to avert a broader war in the region.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was meeting with top Israeli officials on Tuesday, continuing diplomatic efforts to avert a broader war in the region.

headline: South Korea Bans Dog Meat, a Now-Unpopular Food
abstract: Breeding, killing and selling dogs for their meat will be banned in a country where it has fallen out of favor. Hundreds of thousands of the animal were still being bred for human consumption.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s lawmakers on Tuesday outlawed the breeding, slaughter and sale of dogs for human consumption, a centuries-old practice that is unpopular and rare today.

headline: Word of the Day: portentous
abstract: This word has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word portentous has appeared in 25 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 3 in “Is Fluminense the Team of the Future?” by Rory Smith:

headline: The New Space Race Is Causing New Pollution Problems
abstract: Earth’s stratosphere has never seen the amounts of emissions and waste from rockets and satellites that a booming space economy will leave behind.
lead_paragraph: The high-altitude chase started over Cape Canaveral on Feb. 17, 2023, when a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launched. Thomas Parent, a NASA research pilot, was flying a WB-57 jet when the rocket ascended past the right wing — leaving him mesmerized before he hit the throttle to accelerate.

headline: How Astronomers Are Saving Astronomy From Satellites — For Now
abstract: Even the most powerful telescopes are in peril as orbits above Earth fill with thousands of new satellites. But scientists aren’t ready to give up the night sky.
lead_paragraph: In December 2020, astronomers documented a burst of highly energetic light in one of the most distant galaxies ever observed. But less than a year later, the paper’s claims lay in limbo. Other scientists said it had merely been a passing satellite.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: When ‘Contemporary Issues’ and Campus Politics Collide
abstract: Colleges across the United States have been roiled by controversy. Anemona Hartocollis, a reporter on the higher education beat, discussed how she approaches it all.
lead_paragraph: Anemona Hartocollis, a New York Times reporter who covers higher education, was at a holiday party when she overheard revelers talking about Claudine Gay, the president of Harvard University.

headline: This Venezuelan Family Won Asylum. Days Later, They Lost It.
abstract: Millions of asylum seekers have overwhelmed the immigration system. A confusing mix-up is keeping one family in limbo.
lead_paragraph: Dyluis Rojas and his wife and children fled first from Venezuela and later from Colombia and Chile, crossing deserts, jungles and rivers with one goal: to make it to the United States and stay there.

headline: A Famous Explorer, an Obsessive Son and the Reappearance of Flag No. 98
abstract: Adm. Richard E. Byrd was once known around the world for his expeditions to Antarctica. His son was determined to preserve his legacy.
lead_paragraph: It arrived without fanfare or explanation, marked Lot No. 313 at the J. James Auction House in Plymouth, Mass. A simple flag, bearing an “E” and a “C” alongside a compass star, against a red, white and blue background.

headline: Coveted Cup
abstract: The latest phone? Special-edition sneakers? A trendy tumbler? What would you be willing to camp out — even fight — for?
lead_paragraph: Have you heard about people camping out for and fighting over a special Valentine’s Day cup at Target stores? Yes, a cup!

headline: No, That’s Not Taylor Swift Peddling Le Creuset Cookware
abstract: The singer did not promote a giveaway of the popular cookware, but an artificially generated version of her voice suggested otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift’s affinity for Le Creuset is real: Her collection of the cookware has been featured on a Tumblr account dedicated to the pop star’s home décor, showcased in her gift choices at a fan’s bridal shower and shown in a Netflix documentary that was highlighted by Le Creuset’s Facebook page.

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Isn’t Expecting an Apology From Aaron Rodgers
abstract: Kimmel said although the N.F.L. star may believe that Kimmel is linked to Jeffrey Epstein, it’s more likely that Rodgers “is mad at me for making fun of his topknot.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Under the White Mask: The Film That Haesaerts Could Have Made
abstract: In this short film, Congolese artworks voice the poet and author Aimé Césaire’s words: “Colonization is thingification.”
lead_paragraph: In this short film, Congolese artworks voice the poet and author Aimé Césaire’s words: “Colonization is thingification.”

headline: Art’s Colonial Legacy: ‘It Would Have Been Better Not to Have Needed Museums.’
abstract: In this short film, Congolese artworks voice the poet and author Aimé Césaire’s words: “Colonization is thingification.”
lead_paragraph: The idea for this film began when a friend was planning an exhibition featuring Congolese artwork. She was considering including the documentary “Under the Black Mask” (1958), by the Belgian filmmaker Paul Haesaerts, but was unsure how to present the piece, which contains voice-over and images that stereotype and exoticize Congolese culture. How could we adequately contextualize a work by a filmmaker from Belgium created in the final years of that country’s decades-long, brutal colonial occupation of what is now the Democratic Republic of Congo?

headline: Can I Fix the Spider Veins on My Face?
abstract: These broken blood vessels can be unsightly, but they’re not a nuisance you have to live with.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’ve noticed some red, squiggly blood vessels just under the skin of my cheeks and around my nose. What are they, exactly? And is it possible to get rid of them?

headline: Breathing Their Way to an Altered State
abstract: As psychedelics move from the underground to mainstream medicine, clinicians aspiring to work in the field are inducing altered states with deep breathing.
lead_paragraph: The instructions were simple: Lying on cots while wearing eyeshades, participants were directed to take deep belly breaths without pause to the beat of fast-paced music booming from loudspeakers.

headline: In ‘My Friends’ an Exile Finds Himself Outside Libya, but Never Far Away
abstract: A rash decision to attend an anti-Qaddafi protest in London reverberates in Hisham Matar’s poignant and quietly suspenseful third novel.
lead_paragraph: In the works of the Libyan-born writer Hisham Matar, a few subjects take center stage again and again. There’s the violence of the Muammar el-Qaddafi regime: torture, assassination, disappearance, confessions broadcast on state television, government agents listening to phone calls. And there’s the experience of Libyans seeking safety in exile. Matar — himself one such exile — picks apart their psyches, analyzing at a microscopic level how violence and migration have altered how they think and feel and relate to the people closest to them. He has returned to this cluster of topics as if it’s a house he’s obsessed with, examining it from different angles, sneaking inside and finding new rooms, even new wings.

headline: Unfinished Video Games Are Turning Into Hits
abstract: When players buy games in early access, they can give studios both valuable feedback and a crucial revenue stream.
lead_paragraph: With the help of lightning rings, garlic and Bibles, players were outlasting waves of ghouls and beasts in Vampire Survivors long before the video game was released officially.

headline: How to Discover Your Own Taste
abstract: Kyle Chayka on the art of developing personal style in an age when algorithms loom over aesthetics and culture.
lead_paragraph: Being on the internet just doesn’t feel as fun anymore. As more of our digital life is driven by algorithms, it’s become a lot easier to find movies or TV shows or music that fits our preferences pretty well. But it feels harder to find things that are strange and surprising — the kinds of culture that help you, as an individual, develop your own sense of taste.

headline: In the N.F.L. and at Big Companies, Diversity Playbooks Face Hurdles
abstract: The league’s successes and struggles are playing out in hundreds of companies that have emulated its Rooney Rule in trying to hire more people from underrepresented groups.
lead_paragraph: The end of the National Football League’s regular season on Sunday triggered the start of two annual events: the playoffs, and the period when a wave of teams fire head coaches and general managers and start frenzied searches for their replacements.

headline: Waiting in the Snow for a Phone Call, Mixing Memory and Desire
abstract: Cynthia Zarin’s first novel, “Inverno,” is a tale of a woman’s incurable longing and haunted past.
lead_paragraph: I once taught a seminar for graduate fiction writers called A Poet’s Prose. The reading list consisted of prose works written by distinguished contemporary poets. I was surprised to find that several students had registered for the course because they considered their own writing poetic. I was less surprised to find that what they meant by poetic was exactly the kind of strained, showy language I’d hoped exposure to writers with a poet’s essential skills would improve. I wanted my students to read good poets’ prose for the same reason I kept encouraging them to read poetry: to learn how effective concision of language, meticulous use of detail and sensitivity to cadence can be.

headline: New Year’s Resolutions for the Anxious
abstract: Here’s how to confront your fears and seek out new perspectives this year — no therapist required.
lead_paragraph: The start of the new year often brings lofty ambitions.

headline: What Are Your Thoughts on Last Names?
abstract: Babies generally are given the father’s last name in the United States, but  a small minority of families are making different choices. What do you think?
lead_paragraph: How did you get your last name? Was it passed down to you from your father’s side of the family? That is how last names are usually given to babies in the United States, but some families are taking different approaches. They may draw from the mother’s side instead, use both parents’ last names (sometimes placing a hyphen between them), choose a name that has family history or other significance — or come up with something wholly original.

headline: State of the State: Hochul Unveils Her Agenda
abstract: In her speech, Gov. Kathy Hochul will propose providing leave for prenatal care, changing the way reading is taught and promoting artificial intelligence research.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday, the day Gov. Kathy Hochul is to deliver her State of the State address. We’ll find out what to listen for.

headline: Buy American? Easier Said Than Done.
abstract: In “Making It in America,” Rachel Slade examines the challenges of domestic production through the lens of one Maine company.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible to buy American in an age of offshoring? And is that the right goal — for workers, consumers or the planet? The journalist Rachel Slade explores these questions in “Making It in America,” which takes as a case study one small clothing manufacturer in Maine.

headline: How to Fix America’s Immigration Crisis
abstract: The system can be fixed to both benefit the country and provide order to the border.
lead_paragraph: The system can be fixed to both benefit the country and provide order to the border.

headline: Lawmakers Push U.S. to Consider Trade Limits With A.I. Giant Tied to China
abstract: A congressional committee made the demand of the Commerce Department after The Times reported on concerns among U.S. intelligence officials over the Emirati company, G42.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. congressional committee has asked the Commerce Department to look into whether a giant technology company controlled by the ruling family of the United Arab Emirates should be put under trade restrictions because of its ties to China.

headline: A City’s Campaign Against Homelessness Brings Stories of Violence
abstract: Local officials called for residents to deter the homeless in Kalispell, Mont., but unhoused residents said they were then accosted and attacked.
lead_paragraph: After watching a growing series of tents and other makeshift shelters spread into city parks and sidewalks, officials in northwestern Montana decided it was time for a crackdown on homelessness.

headline: Tired of Meditation? Try Looking for Clams.
abstract: For those of us who have difficulty finding peace while sitting in one place, clamming can be an unexpected escape.
lead_paragraph: On these dark winter evenings, when the end of the day has crept up all too quickly and both of my children are speaking to me at once while I’m trying to follow a recipe and my laptop is still open with incomplete work, I find myself daydreaming of summer. I think of the one activity and place that quiets my mind and restores my drained reserves: clamming on Cape Cod, which is foraging for clams, from large quahogs that can be baked or used for chowder to — my favorite — smaller ones, the so-called littleneck clams, that you eat raw that same day at cocktail hour.

headline: The Fading Online Celebrity of George Santos
abstract: Inside the halls of power, his performance worked for a time. Outside, he’s a flop.
lead_paragraph: George Santos was expelled from Congress on a Friday in December. On the next business day, he announced a new role: as a kind of clown-for-hire on Cameo, an app and website where he offered his services recording personalized videos for fans. First he priced the messages at $75 each, but soon he was charging $200, then $400, then $500 a pop. But last week, the market contracted. The videos dropped to $350 apiece.

headline: What You Can Learn About Job-Hunting From Dating Apps. Really.
abstract: An advice manual for navigating the “dates” we go on when we are looking for a job.
lead_paragraph: An advice manual for navigating the “dates” we go on when we are looking for a job.

headline: The False Note in Bradley Cooper’s ‘Maestro’
abstract: The film celebrates Leonard Bernstein’s musical duality, but fails to seriously engage with his bisexuality.
lead_paragraph: There’s a heartbreaking scene in Bradley Cooper’s “Maestro,” about the marriage of the composer and conductor Leonard Bernstein (Cooper) to the actress Felicia Montealegre (Carey Mulligan), in which, as the couple argue in the bedroom of their Upper West Side apartment, Macy’s parade inflatables glide past the windows. A giant Snoopy echoes a Snoopy we saw in a family scene; it also gestures at the awkward gulf between Bernstein’s private and public lives, as if the musician himself were yet another helium-propelled icon from the Thanksgiving pantheon. Montealegre’s accusation, “Your truth is a [expletive] lie!” nails Bernstein’s privilege, condemning the habits and appetites he expects his family to tolerate and support.

headline: The Hard Truth of Israel’s Endgame in Gaza
abstract: Peter Beinart warns that the country is committing a sin that “cannot be atoned for.”
lead_paragraph: What are Israel’s plans for Gaza if it succeeds in expelling Hamas? In this audio essay, Peter Beinart argues that the country’s goal is very clear: to force Palestinians to leave. Beinart believes America’s blanket support of Israel makes it complicit in crimes against humanity. “I want U.S. diplomats to understand that the forced expulsion of a population or part of a population is a war crime,” Beinart says. “I want U.S. government officials to fear that this will be their legacy and to ensure that it’s not.”

headline: A Luxurious Lean-to in Sonoma County
abstract: Bruce Falck, who left Twitter during Elon Musk’s takeover bid, had something more important going on at the time: completing a longed-for family home.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Falck, who left Twitter during Elon Musk’s takeover bid, had something more important going on at the time: completing a longed-for family home.

headline: January’s Secret: It’s the Best Month
abstract: Once you see why, you may never want it to end.
lead_paragraph: Consider the plight of January, the sad sack of months.

headline: For Gaza’s Pregnant Women and Newborns, the War Will Never Be Over
abstract: Even if the war ends tomorrow, its effects will last a lifetime for new mothers and their children.
lead_paragraph: After Israel began its invasion of Gaza shortly after Hamas’s attack on Oct. 7, Aya Khrais — a pregnant 26-year-old dentist, wife of a doctor and mother of a 2-year-old girl living in Gaza City — lost contact with the doctors and health services she needed for prenatal care and for managing her diabetes.

headline: Defying Trump, G.O.P. Congressmen Hit the Road for DeSantis
abstract: A pair of idiosyncratic, ultraconservative House Republicans are risking the ire of the former president and his supporters to try to bolster the Florida governor.
lead_paragraph: Most House Republicans operate under an unspoken but ironclad rule: Do whatever you can to avoid provoking the wrath of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Imagine if Trump Loses
abstract: Resistance to his candidacy is not futile.
lead_paragraph: The outcome of the 2016 presidential election was such a shocking event that for people of a certain cast of mind, Donald Trump is less a politician than a force of history.

headline: Appeals Court Seems Skeptical of Trump’s Immunity Claim
abstract: A three-judge panel appeared unlikely to grant the former president’s request that it throw out federal criminal charges that he plotted to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court expressed deep skepticism on Tuesday about former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he is immune from charges of plotting to subvert the 2020 election, suggesting that it is unlikely to rule in his favor on a central element of his defense.

headline: To Win Iowa, Trump Turns to Allies Like Marjorie Taylor Greene
abstract: With the former president busy defending himself in court from 91 felony charges, his campaign has deployed high-profile conservatives to help fill the gaps in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Less than a week before Iowans decide whether to slingshot Donald J. Trump toward another presidential nomination, his schedule looks like this: Go to Washington for an appeals court hearing on Tuesday. Pop into Iowa for a Fox News town-hall event on Wednesday — and then make an expected return to court on Thursday, this time in New York.

headline: A Former Twitter Exec Builds His Dream House in Wine Country
abstract: Bruce Falck, who left Twitter during Elon Musk’s takeover bid, had other things on his mind: completing a longed-for family home in Northern California.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Falck long dreamed of following the example set by his father, who ran a construction company in Johannesburg, South Africa: He wanted to build a house designed specifically for his family.

headline: The F.D.A. Warned an Asthma Drug Could Induce Despair. Many Were Never Told.
abstract: Singulair, now a generic, is still used by millions of people in the United States even after thousands of patients and dozens of studies have described harm.
lead_paragraph: In early 2020, the Food and Drug Administration responded to decades of escalating concerns about a commonly prescribed drug for asthma and allergies by deploying one of its most potent tools: a stark warning on the drug’s label that it could cause aggression, agitation and even suicidal thoughts.

headline: A Glimpse Inside a Devastated Gaza
abstract: In the ruins of two Gazan towns, New York Times journalists witnessed the sheer destruction that Israel’s war has wrought and the devastation of Hamas’s operations.
lead_paragraph: For a few fleeting moments, the two-story house on the edge of Bureij, a ruined town in central Gaza, still felt like a Palestinian home.

headline: U.S. Navy Sailor Who Helped China Is Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
abstract: Wenheng Zhao pleaded guilty to charges that he sent photos of American military installations and details of U.S. military exercises to an intelligence officer working for China.
lead_paragraph: A United States Navy sailor who sent an intelligence officer working for the Chinese government photos of American military installations and details of naval training exercises in Asia was sentenced to more than two years in prison on Monday.

headline: Trump’s Immunity Claim in Court, and a Glimpse Inside Gaza
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Afterlife of a Gun
abstract: How communities across the U.S. are fueling a secondary arms market with guns slated for destruction.
lead_paragraph: Across the United States, hundreds of towns and cities are trying to get guns off the streets by turning them over to businesses that offer to destroy them.

headline: Saudi-Israel Ties Depend on Steps Toward a Palestinian State, Blinken Says
abstract: In meetings with Israeli leaders, the U.S. secretary of state held out the prospect of Saudi recognition to prod Israel to curb combat operations in Gaza and accept a path to Palestinian statehood.
lead_paragraph: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, and a Saudi ambassador asserted on Tuesday the possibility of diplomatic recognition of Israel by Saudi Arabia if the Israeli government alleviates the suffering of residents of Gaza and puts Palestinians on a path toward statehood.

headline: A Missile, a Rocket or a Satellite? Chinese Flyover Sows Confusion in Taiwan.
abstract: A warning from Taiwan about a satellite, erroneously called a missile in English, raised concerns about Chinese harassment days before an election.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan’s defense ministry issued an urgent alert Tuesday about a Chinese satellite launched on a rocket flying over the island, an alarming message that interrupted the final days of campaigning before a major election and spurred accusations of a political ploy.

headline: A Major Trump Hearing
abstract: A case before an appeals court in Washington could influence how the former president’s trials will play out this year.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s four criminal trials can seem dizzying, including both federal and state cases, across Florida, Georgia, New York and Washington. But it’s worth remembering that the cases have different timetables. And any case that might produce a verdict before Election Day is probably more important than the others.

headline: See How 2023 Shattered Records to Become the Hottest Year
abstract: Month after month global temperatures didn’t just break records, they surpassed them by far. This year could be even warmer.
lead_paragraph: The numbers are in, and scientists can now confirm what month after month of extraordinary heat worldwide began signaling long ago. Last year was Earth’s warmest by far in a century and a half.

headline: New York Times journalists get a glimpse inside a devastated Gaza.
abstract: For a few fleeting moments, the two-story house on the edge of Bureij, a ruined town in central Gaza, still felt like a Palestinian home.
lead_paragraph: For a few fleeting moments, the two-story house on the edge of Bureij, a ruined town in central Gaza, still felt like a Palestinian home.

headline: New York Region Is Under High Wind Warning as Forecasters Warn of Flooding
abstract: Authorities in New York and the surrounding area are warning residents to prepare for treacherous weather from Tuesday night into Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A major coastal storm will bring excessive rain and damaging winds to New York City and the surrounding area from late Tuesday until midday Wednesday, the National Weather Service said. The strongest winds were expected from 10 p.m. until 3 a.m., with gusts of up to 70 m.p.h. were along the coast. A citywide flood watch was in effect until noon Wednesday, and widespread power outages were expected

headline: Boeing’s Max 9 Crisis Deepens
abstract: Safety checks have uncovered loose bolts on the grounded jetliners, raising more questions for management over how the top-selling planes are built.
lead_paragraph: The trouble at Boeing is deepening after safety inspectors at Alaska Airlines and United Airlines found loose bolts on some grounded 737 Max jetliners, drawing scrutiny to the quality control process for one of the world’s best-selling aircraft models.

headline: Who are the judges hearing the appeal?
abstract: The panel includes a Republican appointee who is no stranger to cases involving Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Best State Parks to Visit This Winter
abstract: Stargaze in the desert, see elephant seals and more.
lead_paragraph: With the new year come wonderful new opportunities to explore the Golden State.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Primary Season, Football, Mickey Mouse
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Sinead O’Connor Died of Natural Causes, Coroner Says
abstract: The Irish singer-songwriter, known for her powerful, evocative voice, died at 56 at a residence in London in July.
lead_paragraph: A London coroner’s office said Tuesday that the Irish singer Sinead O’Connor died from natural causes.

headline: Israel, Shifting War Tempo, Tailors Its Messages for Home and Abroad
abstract: Israeli officials have told foreign journalists that they are starting to slow military operations in Gaza, while assuring the Israeli public that the war against Hamas will go on.
lead_paragraph: With a vast chasm between how Israelis see the war in Gaza and how much of the world does, Israel’s leaders have taken to adopting different rhetoric when addressing the two audiences about how its military campaign against Hamas will be conducted over the year ahead.

headline: 5 Novels About Plagiarism
abstract: With plagiarism in the news, here are five novels that show it's an engrossing plot device, too.
lead_paragraph: With plagiarism in the news, here are five novels that show it's an engrossing plot device, too.

headline: France Gets Its Youngest and First Openly Gay Prime Minister
abstract: Gabriel Attal, 34, replaces Élisabeth Borne in a cabinet shuffle that President Emmanuel Macron hopes can reinvigorate a term marked by drift and division.
lead_paragraph: In a typically bold bid to revitalize his second term, President Emmanuel Macron named Gabriel Attal, 34, as his new prime minister, replacing Élisabeth Borne, 62, who made no secret of the fact that she was unhappy to be forced out.

headline: World Bank Warns of Energy Price Surge if Mideast War Spreads
abstract: A new economic report predicted a year of weak growth and said the world faced a decade of “wasted opportunity.”
lead_paragraph: The global economy is at risk of a “wasted” decade and the weakest stretch of growth in 30 years, the World Bank warned on Tuesday, saying a sluggish recovery from the pandemic and crippling wars in Ukraine and the Middle East are expected to weigh heavily on output.

headline: Here are the lawyers arguing the case.
abstract: Arguing for the special counsel: James I. Pearce, a career federal prosecutor who played a role in some Jan. 6 cases; and for former President Donald Trump, D. John Sauer, a former solicitor general of Missouri.
lead_paragraph: The two lawyers who will be squaring off in court on Tuesday to debate the issue of whether former President Donald J. Trump is immune to charges of trying to overturn the 2020 election both have experience in high-profile appeals, but they come from different sides of the legal aisle.

headline: Why Are California’s Waters Lighting Up in Blue?
abstract: It looks like the trailer for “Avatar: The Way of Water,” but it’s a natural phenomenon. And spotting it is getting increasingly popular.
lead_paragraph: California seems to be off to a glowing start to the year — and we’re not just talking about Hollywood stars assembling for awards season. We’re talking about bioluminescent algae.

headline: 4 Killed as Storms and Likely Tornadoes Tear Through Southeastern U.S.
abstract: Gusty winds ripped through the Florida Panhandle, downing power lines and trees.
lead_paragraph: At least four people died as severe thunderstorms, powerful winds and apparent tornadoes ripped across swaths of the southeastern United States on Tuesday, downing power lines and trees, and damaging buildings.

headline: Three Dancers and Three Traditions Converse, United by Rhythm
abstract: Soles of Duende, a percussive dance trio appearing at the Joyce Theater this week, situates tap, flamenco and Kathak in joyful and thrilling conversation.
lead_paragraph: “Can We Dance Here?” That’s the title of Soles of Duende’s signature work. But it’s also a question that the members of this percussive dance company often find themselves posing.

headline: Five (Easy, Fun, Quick and Completely Delicious) Weeknight Dishes
abstract: I’m in cook mode right now. What I’m making: blistered broccoli pasta, chana masala and build-your-own poke bowls.
lead_paragraph: I’m in cook mode right now in this blissful post-holiday lull, staying in more often and making more food, too: waffles and squash soup, kimchi tuna salad and rainbow sprinkle cake. (And dinner, of course. There’s always dinner.)

headline: Israel says it killed another Hezbollah commander after back-and-forth attacks.
abstract: A deadly airstrike
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Tuesday that it had killed a senior Hezbollah commander in an airstrike, further heightening tensions with the Iranian-backed militia after a day of back-and-forth attacks and the apparent Israeli killing of another Hezbollah commander on Monday.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kyle Chayka
abstract: The Jan. 9, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kyle Chayka. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Elections and Disinformation Are Colliding Like Never Before in 2024
abstract: A wave of elections coincides with state influence operations, a surge of extremism, A.I. advances and a pullback in social media protections.
lead_paragraph: Billions of people will vote in major elections this year — around half of the global population, by some estimates — in one of the largest and most consequential democratic exercises in living memory. The results will affect how the world is run for decades to come.

headline: A Sharp Warning About Donald Trump
abstract: Readers discuss an editorial that one called “the full-throated condemnation of Donald Trump that the facts demand.” Also: Taylor Swift; trucking; Canadian hockey.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Aliens Have Never Been More Alluring
abstract: Why pop culture now flirts with extraterrestrials as much as it fears them.
lead_paragraph: Every generation gets the extraterrestrial invasion its times demand. In 1938, conflicts simmering in Europe meant that a radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” became a panic-inducing news event in America. In the McCarthy era, manufactured paranoia about Communists led to movies like “Invasion of the Body Snatchers” (1956) and “I Married a Monster From Outer Space” (1958). The terrors of the Cold War coincided with the skittering xenomorph of “Alien” (1979), a conscienceless creature willing to destroy humanity to ensure its own survival.

headline: Coqodaq, From the Cote Team, Is a Temple of Fried Chicken
abstract: The Korean Chinese restaurant Octo opens in Koreatown, Bibliotheque brings a book-lined wine den to Mercer Street and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Beef or chicken? The restaurateur Simon Kim now has you covered either way. An owner of the Korean steakhouse Cote is opening what he calls a “fried chicken cathedral,” with a dining room framed by glowing, barrel-vaulted arches that disappear to infinity, thanks to a rear wall mirror. The design is by the Rockwell Group, involving David Rockwell’s personal touch. But the food is Mr. Kim’s idea, more than four years in the making, with the executive chef Seung Kyu Kim in charge (no relation to the owner, though the two met while working at Jean-Georges). Simon Kim’s notion is to offer a mix of American and Korean approaches to fried chicken and give it glamour with (supposedly) more sustainable ingredients in a more elegant setting. At Coqodaq it’s one-size-fits-all, a $38 dinner that includes chicken soup; a bucket of chicken parts fried in a gluten-free batter based on rice flour, chicken glazed with gochujang or soy and garlic; a cold perilla noodle dish; banchan, small dishes, that include palate-cleansing white radish; and soft serve frozen yogurt. Starters (extra) include some seafood options. The chickens are pasture-raised in Pennsylvania Amish country, and triple-fried in oil produced in Iowa from fermented Brazilian sugar cane. The name of the restaurant blends French, American and Korean words for chicken. The sommelier, Victoria James, who also curates the wines at Cote, has a wine list that features Champagne, which she and Mr. Kim agree is the ideal beverage for fried chicken. Her list offers 400 of them, and other sparklers by the glass and the bottle. Considering that fried chicken is finger-food, in the front of the restaurant, there’s a hand-washing area with three sinks. Some high-top tables near the entrance are for walk-ins, there’s a long bar, and garage doors will open to an outside patio in warmer weather. Tables at the leather-upholstered booths beneath the arches in the 190-seat room have lazy susans, the better for sharing. (Opens Friday)

headline: Trump says he hopes any economic crash happens in 2024 so he isn’t blamed.
abstract: Former President Trump said Monday night that he hoped any downturn would come before his possible re-election — under President Biden’s administration.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said in an interview on Monday that he believed the economy would crash — and that he hoped it would happen in the next year so the blame would fall on President Biden’s administration.

headline: ‘Fauda’ Actor Is Seriously Injured Fighting in Gaza
abstract: The actor, Idan Amedi, underwent surgery to remove shrapnel from his body and was expected to recover, Israeli news media reported.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli soldier who is an actor in the popular Israeli series “Fauda” on Netflix was seriously wounded when a truck filled with explosives blew up in the Bureij area of central Gaza on Monday, the Israeli military said.

headline: Brutal Cold Expected for Kansas City’s Playoff Game
abstract: The temperature on Saturday evening, when the team will play the Miami Dolphins, will be around minus 3 degrees.
lead_paragraph: This weekend is the first round of the N.F.L. playoffs, and because there is a home game in Buffalo, the superlatives are coming out. It will be cold, as low as 9 degrees. The players and fans will be freezing. The game will be a war of attrition played out on the frozen tundra of …

headline: For Anti-Trump Republicans, It All Might Come Down to New Hampshire
abstract: With the Iowa caucuses likely to be a battle for second place, the next nominating state appears to offer the best chance of an upset defeat of Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: With his usual bluntness, Chris Christie used a recent event in New Hampshire to lay out why he thought the state’s primary election was more important than the Iowa caucuses — and what he saw as its tremendous stakes.

headline: Surprised by New Details About Austin’s Health, White House Orders Review
abstract: The president learned only Tuesday that his defense secretary had been diagnosed with prostate cancer a month ago and had surgery under general anesthesia in December, aides said.
lead_paragraph: The White House was caught off guard once again on Tuesday when it learned that Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had been diagnosed with prostate cancer a month ago and had surgery to treat the disease under general anesthesia on Dec. 22 without notifying either President Biden or his staff.

headline: After Years of Ups and Downs, Trump Is, Once Again, Live on Fox News
abstract: A town hall in Iowa on Wednesday is the network’s first live interview with the former president in nearly two years, the latest twist in a long-running drama.
lead_paragraph: One of television’s longest-running soap operas is about to start a new chapter.

headline: What happens next in Trump’s immunity case?
abstract: The court has already moved the case along at an exceptionally brisk pace and is expected to make its decision fairly quickly by the standards of a typical appeal.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court in Washington has now heard arguments on former President Donald J. Trump’s sweeping claim that he is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: How to … : An Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers
abstract: We invite students to explain how to do any task in 400 words or fewer. Contest dates: Jan. 10 - Feb. 14, 2024
lead_paragraph: Do you know how to fix a brake light? What about how to memorize Shakespeare? How to keep a goldfish alive? Spot a shooting star? Write a love letter? Forgive someone?

headline: How to Write a ‘How-To’: A Step-by-Step Guide to Our Contest
abstract: We walk you through how to brainstorm a topic, interview an expert and write your own original “How to ….”
lead_paragraph: “If you want to know how to do something, don’t just search the internet,” advises Malia Wollan, the longtime writer of Tip, a how-to column that ran weekly in The New York Times Magazine for seven years. “Instead, find a person who already knows how and ask them.”

headline: Norway Moves to Allow Seabed Mining Exploration
abstract: The decision in Parliament, opposed by environmentalists, will allow prospectors to start surveying the country’s waters.
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian Parliament voted on Tuesday to authorize the opening of parts of the Norwegian Sea to seabed mining exploration, a move that reflects rising international demand for the metals needed to build batteries for electric vehicles worldwide.

headline: For the Lakota, Creativity Thrives Where There’s No Word for Art
abstract: A Native-run studio, the Artspace is a beacon of hope, nurturing talent amid a resurgence of Indigenous traditions.
lead_paragraph: There is no word for art in the Lakota language. But the power of art, in every facet of life, has drawn a boisterous group of moccasin beaders, painters, regalia artists and producers of Native hip-hop down a two-lane road that undulates through the tawny hills of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, eight miles from the nearest intersection.

headline: Editor of The Los Angeles Times Steps Down
abstract: Kevin Merida, who took over the job in 2021, said in an internal note that his last day would be on Friday.
lead_paragraph: When he joined The Los Angeles Times as its top editor nearly three years ago, Kevin Merida was hailed as a leader who would restore calm to a newsroom that had been buffeted by cost-cutting and corporate ownership battles.

headline: What Do You Wish You Could Do Well?
abstract: As a companion to our new “how to” contest, here are 10 questions to help you brainstorm some skills you’d like to learn — whether practical or just for fun.
lead_paragraph: Are you a karaoke enthusiast? If so, you might have a few tips to share about how to choose a song — for example, “just because you like it does not mean you should sing it.” (After all, not everybody has the vocal range for “Bohemian Rhapsody.”)

headline: In New York, Hochul Says State of the State Is Concerning, but Fixable
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul, in her annual State of the State address, trumpeted her achievements while highlighting a series of intractable problems facing New York.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Tuesday presented a stark view of New York’s challenges, highlighting crime, a failing mental health infrastructure and affordability concerns as vexing challenges that her administration was ready to tackle.

headline: Trump Shows Little Emotion During Hearing, Then Says He ‘Did Nothing Wrong’
abstract: Mr. Trump, speaking at a Washington hotel he once owned, said that “you have to have immunity” as president. It was a core element of Tuesday’s hearing.
lead_paragraph: The small courtroom was already packed when former President Donald J. Trump walked slowly inside.

headline: Ray Epps, Target of Jan. 6 Conspiracy Theory, Is Sentenced to Probation
abstract: The onetime Trump supporter was driven into hiding after Fox News and prominent Republicans spread a false narrative that he was a government agent who helped instigate the attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: Ray Epps, the former Trump supporter who became a target of a conspiracy theory that he was an undercover government agent who helped to instigate the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, was sentenced on Tuesday to a year of probation for his own small role in the riot instead of the six months in prison that prosecutors had requested.

headline: In South Carolina, Biden and Harris Test Policy-Heavy Pitch to Black Voters
abstract: The president’s re-election campaign is looking to rekindle support among a group that was pivotal to his 2020 victory, in a state that revived his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats amplify their concerns about President Biden’s status with Black voters, South Carolina has emerged as a proving ground for his campaign: one where he can test his message to a predominantly Black electorate and use it as a largely ceremonial launchpad for his re-election.

headline: NASA Delays Artemis Astronaut Moon Missions
abstract: Artemis II, a trip around the moon, will now occur no earlier than September 2025 while a moon landing, Artemis III, will move to 2026.
lead_paragraph: For NASA and its astronauts, the moon is no farther away in terms of distance, but it is slipping further into the future.

headline: What Songs Would ‘Saltburn’ Characters Have Spun in 2007?
abstract: The soundtrack to Emerald Fennell’s movie has been a talker. Hear tracks by M.I.A., Girl Talk, Nelly Furtado and others that would have been a good fit.
lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, I finally watched “Saltburn,” the provocative, polarizing and occasionally downright icky coming-of-age thriller that no one can stop talking about right now.

headline: New York Begins Evicting Migrant Families Who Hit a Shelter Time Limit
abstract: On Tuesday, families with children had to pack up their belongings and either find somewhere else to live or line up to reapply for shelter beds.
lead_paragraph: Since arriving from Venezuela four months ago, Joana Rivas has slowly found some semblance of stability in New York City, picking up occasional cleaning jobs and enrolling her 9-year-old daughter at a public school in Manhattan.

headline: A Weak Night for Trump? A DeSantis Flop? We Game Out Iowa.
abstract: A win isn’t always win in the Iowa caucuses. In the final days, the candidates are scrambling to beat each other — and expectations.
lead_paragraph: It may feel as if there is little suspense over who is likely to win the Republican presidential caucuses in Iowa on Monday.

headline: A New Era in Global Heat
abstract: Scientists are asking whether the planet’s warming is accelerating.
lead_paragraph: It’s confirmed: 2023 was the planet’s warmest year on record and perhaps in the last 100,000 years. By far.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 9, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the low use of Paxlovid among eligible patients misspelled the name of the pharmaceutical company that makes the medication ensitrelvir. It is Shionogi, not Shinogi.

headline: Austin Was Hospitalized for Complications From Prostate Cancer Surgery
abstract: A spokesman said the White House, which had been kept in the dark for three days about the defense secretary’s hospitalization, only learned of the diagnosis on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has been hospitalized for the past week because of complications after he had prostate cancer surgery, Walter Reed National Military Medical Center said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Is Poor Economic Sentiment All About MAGA?
abstract: Partisanship is having a huge effect on consumer surveys.
lead_paragraph: The economy is good, but Americans feel bad about it. Or do they?

headline: N.R.A. Lawyer Distances Gun Group From LaPierre’s Lavish Spending
abstract: A lawyer for the National Rifle Association said that Wayne LaPierre’s actions did not embody the organization. Mr. LaPierre announced his resignation as the group’s leader last week.
lead_paragraph: A defense attorney for the National Rifle Association on Tuesday fought back against a civil suit by the State of New York, arguing that the actions of the N.R.A.’s leader, who spent fortunes on luxuries and travel, were not those of the organization itself.

headline: A Giant Vegas-Style Sphere in London? Don’t Bet on It.
abstract: The American developer MSG Entertainment withdrew its bid to build a sister arena in Britain after opposition from Londoners and the city’s mayor.
lead_paragraph: What happens in Vegas, it turns out, really does stay in Vegas.

headline: 737 Max Inspections Delayed as Boeing Revises Guidance
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration said that Boeing’s instructions for how airlines should check the planes were insufficient and that the company would revise them.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Tuesday said Boeing was revising its instructions for how airlines should inspect its 737 Max 9, delaying the manufacturer’s effort to get the jet back in the air after a panel in one of the planes blew out during a flight late last week.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the Appeals Court Hearing on Trump’s Immunity Claim
abstract: A ruling by the court, and the timing of its decision, could be a major factor in determining when, or even whether, the former president will go to trial in the federal election case.
lead_paragraph: A three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in Washington heard arguments on Tuesday in a momentous case over former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he is immune from criminal charges for the efforts he took to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: ‘Pirates of Penzance,’ ‘English’ and ‘Yellow Face’ Bound for Broadway
abstract: Roundabout Theater Company, the biggest nonprofit on Broadway, said it would produce the three shows next season.
lead_paragraph: Roundabout Theater Company, the biggest nonprofit operating on Broadway, is planning to stage a jazz-inflected production of “The Pirates of Penzance,” Gilbert and Sullivan’s famed 19th-century comic operetta, in the spring of 2025, the organization said Tuesday.

headline: Paul Taylor Dance Company to Move to Midtown in Major Expansion
abstract: The renowned troupe will more than triple its footprint, growing its studio space and education programs.
lead_paragraph: The Paul Taylor Dance Company, founded in 1954 by the renowned choreographer, has long been one of the city’s most prominent troupes. But it has struggled in recent years to find space to match its ambitions for more performances, rehearsals, classes and community events.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Remember How Obnoxious I Was?’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: I’d been a disobedient teenager, eager to rebel against authority. I resisted my parents and the church. But oddly, the one adult I could actually talk to was our Presbyterian minister, Dr. Moffatt. We reunited recently for his 99th birthday. He surprised me by saying he’d once considered becoming a politician to impact peoples’ lives. “But you’ve impacted plenty of lives,” I responded. “Take me; remember how obnoxious I was?” “Oh, yes,” he said, smiling. “Remember being the only person who made me feel accepted and OK?” He nodded. Then, looking at me straight on, he said, “Lee, it’s called love.” — Lee Guthrie

headline: Menendez, in Defiant Speech, Says Bribery Case Against Him Is ‘Baseless’
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez accused prosecutors of conducting a public smear campaign and denied accepting bribes to benefit the governments of Egypt and Qatar.
lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, took to the Senate floor on Tuesday to deny charges that he accepted bribes to benefit the governments of Egypt and Qatar and defiantly warned colleagues that they could be next.

headline: Jewish Group Assails Film Academy’s Diversity Efforts
abstract: An open letter signed by notable actors and producers criticized the organization for not including Jews as an underrepresented group as part of a new initiative.
lead_paragraph: More than 260 Jewish entertainment figures — including the actors David Schwimmer, Julianna Margulies and Josh Gad, and the producers Greg Berlanti and Marta Kauffman — signed an open letter to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences on Tuesday, criticizing the organization for excluding Jews as an underrepresented group in its diversity efforts.

headline: Have You Been Overcharged for Prescription Drugs? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: The New York Times is looking into pharmacy benefit managers, which play crucial roles in determining which medications your insurance covers and how much you pay.
lead_paragraph: Most prescriptions in the United States are handled by one of three companies: CVS Caremark, Express Scripts or Optum Rx. These pharmacy benefit managers serve as middlemen between the drug companies that make the medications and the insurance plans that pay for your prescriptions.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Trump’s Immunity Claim in Court
abstract: Plus, 52 travel destinations for 2024.
lead_paragraph: At a hearing in Washington yesterday, judges expressed deep skepticism about Donald Trump’s claim that he was immune from charges of plotting to subvert the 2020 election. Trump’s lawyers argued that he should not face prosecution because the charges stem from actions that he took as president.

headline: Unstoppable in Red
abstract: As Tiger Woods ends his relationship with Nike, the sporting world will say goodbye to an iconic look that was intimidating in its consistency.
lead_paragraph: When Tiger Woods locked in on the final day of the Masters in 2019, it felt like the sporting world had stepped into a time machine. The 43-year-old golfer — 11 years removed from winning his last major tournament — was fighting against a series of devastating injuries and an entirely new generation of competition but with every precision shot he was reminding the world what he once was.

headline: Ecuador Plunges Into Crisis Amid Prison Riots and Gang Leader’s Disappearance
abstract: The president declared a state of emergency and ordered the military to “neutralize” dozens of gangs. Gunmen stormed a TV studio as cameras rolled.
lead_paragraph: Gunmen wearing masks stormed a television station in Ecuador’s largest city on Tuesday, taking anchors and staff hostage and exchanging gunfire with the police as cameras rolled before the intruders were subdued and arrested.

headline: New York City Hid Realities of Homelessness Crisis, Report Finds
abstract: City officials manipulated public data for years and delayed reporting that homeless families had stayed overnight at an intake center instead of a shelter, according to a new investigation.
lead_paragraph: As New York City faced a worsening homelessness crisis in recent years, officials repeatedly sought to hide the reality on the ground, according to a city investigation released on Tuesday.

headline: Ecuadorean Law Enforcement Searches for Escaped Gang Leader
abstract: Ecuadorean military and police patrolled the streets and searched residents following the disappearance of an imprisoned leader of a criminal gang.
lead_paragraph: Ecuadorean military and police patrolled the streets and searched residents following the disappearance of an imprisoned leader of a criminal gang.

headline: Herman Raucher, Screenwriter Best Known for ‘Summer of ’42,’ Dies at 95
abstract: His screenplay, based on his own youthful experience, was nominated for an Oscar. His other films included “Sweet November,” based on his own unproduced play.
lead_paragraph: Herman Raucher, who turned his memories of a summer as a teenager in a Massachusetts beach town, including one of a sexual encounter with a young war widow, into the screenplay for the nostalgic 1971 film “Summer of ’42,” died on Dec. 28 in Stamford, Conn. He was 95.

headline: Hilton Head Native Who Fought Developers to Save Family Land Dies at 94
abstract: Josephine Wright’s high-profile legal battle with a land developer on the picturesque South Carolina island drew support from Snoop Dogg, Kyrie Irving and Tyler Perry, among others.
lead_paragraph: A 94-year-old woman who was at the center of a legal battle with a developer to keep her family’s ancestral land on the island of Hilton Head, S.C., has died.

headline: The Truth About Airplane Safety
abstract: The Japan Airlines and Alaska Airlines incidents could have been much worse.
lead_paragraph: It was only when I attempted to make small talk with my visibly squirming seatmate on a Raleigh-Durham to New York flight that I realized it was me causing that look of horror on his face, rather than the slight turbulence we had been experiencing since takeoff. A friendly chat, I had thought, might help distract him from flight anxiety. But then I noticed his eyes — wide with fear — were fixed on my computer screen, which displayed an investigative report on an airplane crash I had been reading.

headline: Federal Judges Cast Doubt on Trump’s Claim of Immunity
abstract: Also, powerful storms across the U.S. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump appeared today in front of an appeals court panel in Washington to argue that he is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election because they arose from actions he took as president. The three judges on the panel seemed unconvinced, suggesting that they are unlikely to rule in the former president’s favor.

headline: Trump’s Immunity Claim in Court
abstract: The judges seem likely to reject a key element of Trump’s defense in the election case.
lead_paragraph: It looks like Donald Trump ran into a wall today while pushing his position that he cannot be charged criminally for his efforts to remain in power after losing the 2020 election. It came in the form of three federal appeals court judges.

headline: A Hack of the S.E.C.’s Social Media Account Caused a Bitcoin Frenzy, Briefly
abstract: The X account of the Securities and Exchange Commission announced the approval of an investment product linked to Bitcoin. It wasn’t true.
lead_paragraph: For 15 minutes, the cryptocurrency industry was euphoric.

headline: More Than 1,000 Flights Are Canceled as Extreme Weather Batters the U.S.
abstract: The cancellations were felt most acutely in Chicago, where ice and snow briefly halted all flights on Tuesday afternoon. Airports elsewhere in the Midwest and the Northeast were also affected.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 domestic and international flights in the United States were canceled on Tuesday as extreme weather pummeled the country from coast to coast.

headline: As Political Theater, Trump’s Court Appearance Wasn’t a Showstopper
abstract: The former president plans to continue showing up at various legal proceedings against him, but in this case the spotlight stayed largely on the judges and their skepticism about his immunity claims.
lead_paragraph: If Donald J. Trump’s goal on Tuesday was to turn a weighty legal proceeding in Washington into a de facto campaign appearance that galvanized media attention, he fell short.

headline: In Speech, New Jersey Governor Backs Phonics and Medical Debt Relief
abstract: “Nobody should have to worry about being able to afford critical health care,” Gov. Philip D. Murphy said in his sixth-annual State of the State address.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey embraced proposals to make it easier to build affordable housing and cut out-of-pocket expenses for abortions in his annual State of the State address on Tuesday.

headline: The Secretary of Defense Can’t Go AWOL. Neither Can America.
abstract: If we turn our back on the world, there will be consequences.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, I wrote a book with the subtitle “The New Isolationism and the Coming Global Disorder.” I’ve been wrong about a thing or two (or three) over the years. I wish I had been wrong about this.

headline: Secret Synagogue Tunnel Sets Off Altercation That Leads to 9 Arrests
abstract: Videos showed a tumultuous scene as young Hasidic men clashed with the police in the global headquarters of the Chabad-Lubavitcher movement in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A decades-old fight about the direction of one of New York’s most prominent Hasidic Jewish groups tipped into chaos this week, when one faction clashed with the police over a tunnel that had secretly been built to the movement’s main synagogue.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Hochul’s State of the State Address
abstract: The governor of New York described a state that was struggling with crime, the cost of living and a mental health crisis as she laid out her goals for the year.
lead_paragraph: In her third State of the State address, Gov. Kathy Hochul on Tuesday laid out her vision for the coming legislative session and described objectives that often were more of a reflection of her moderate roots than the state’s recent progressive slant.

headline: Allegations Against Prosecutors Bolster Trump’s Criticism of Georgia Case
abstract: A defendant in the case has accused the district attorney in charge of it and a special prosecutor she hired of being romantic partners, saying the case should be dismissed.
lead_paragraph: It seemed an unusual choice when Fani T. Willis, the district attorney in Fulton County, Ga., turned to a suburban defense lawyer to oversee what seemed the biggest task of her career: building an election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Natural Gas Played Role in Fort Worth Hotel Explosion, Officials Say
abstract: A fire official said that the authorities had yet to determine the specific cause but that there was nothing to indicate any foul play.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Texas have yet to determine exactly what caused an explosion at a hotel in downtown Fort Worth that injured 21 people, but believe natural gas was involved, Jim Davis, the city’s fire chief, said at a news conference Tuesday evening.

headline: A Look at the Panel That Ripped Open an Alaska Airlines Jet
abstract: A diagram of the door plug shows the locations of critical bolts that federal investigators said may have been missing or improperly installed.
lead_paragraph: A diagram of the door plug shows the locations of critical bolts that federal investigators said may have been missing or improperly installed.

headline: Virginia Fisherman Is Linked to Three 1980s Killings, Police Say
abstract: Alan W. Wilmer Sr., who died in 2017, was responsible for the homicides, the authorities said, including a double killing that was among a series known as the Colonial Parkway murders.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia fisherman who died in 2017 was responsible for the killings of three people in two separate cases in the southeastern part of the state that sat unsolved for more than 30 years, the police announced this week.

headline: Oligarch’s Aide Tells Court How Sotheby’s Expertise Had Role in Fraud
abstract: An adviser to Dmitry Rybolovlev said the opinions of an expert from the auction house were used to persuade him to buy overpriced art. Sotheby’s said it was not part of any scheme.
lead_paragraph: An adviser to a Russian billionaire asserted in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday that he and his boss had been tricked by a Swiss art dealer into wildly overpaying for works of art and that a Sotheby’s expert’s opinions played a role in persuading them to pay the inflated prices.

headline: Nearly 2,000 Migrants Are Evacuated From Brooklyn Tent Shelter Before Storm
abstract: The shelter housed migrant families with children. City officials said they were moved to a high school nearby to spend the night.
lead_paragraph: New York City evacuated on Tuesday about 500 families with children — nearly 2,000 people in total — from a massive tent shelter set up on a desolate former airplane runway in southern Brooklyn ahead of heavy rains and wind expected to hit the area.

headline: Amalija Knavs, Mother of Former First Lady Melania Trump, Dies at 78
abstract: A patternmaker from Slovenia, she and her husband became naturalized U.S. citizens with the help of their daughter and then a focal point in the debate around Donald Trump’s immigration policies.
lead_paragraph: Amalija Knavs, a former Slovenian factory worker who became a United States citizen with help from one of her daughters, Melania Trump, has died. She was 78.

headline: Buds Go in Them
abstract: Chloe Revery and Alissa Revness divide and conquer.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Review: For Jews, an Unanswered ‘Prayer for the French Republic’
abstract: In Joshua Harmon’s play about the legacies of antisemitism, a Parisian family must decide when it’s time to get out.
lead_paragraph: Such is the sadness of our world that plays about antisemitism, however historical, cannot help but be prescient. Take “Prayer for the French Republic,” Joshua Harmon’s sprawling family drama about the Salomons, Jews who have “been in France more than a thousand years,” as one of them puts it, still sounding provisional. With violent incidents on the rise, and a fascistic, Nazi-adjacent party gaining in the polls, should they finally seek safety elsewhere?

headline: Hochul Warns of Flooding Risks and Lingering Power Outages
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York said the most significant problems caused by the storm were likely to persist after it moved on.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York cautioned residents on Tuesday evening about two major storm-related problems that were likely to linger after the system moved on: widespread power outages and the risk of flooding in certain parts of the state.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Season 5, Episode 9 Recap: Cowboy Hitler
abstract: “The most I ever felt, I felt for that woman,” Roy confesses. It’s safe to wager Dot never felt the same.
lead_paragraph: “You Hitler at the Reichstag or Hitler in the bunker?”

headline: What to Watch at the Haley-DeSantis Debate and the Trump Town Hall
abstract: Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis will debate on CNN on Wednesday night, at the same time that Donald Trump is holding a Fox News town hall.
lead_paragraph: Only two Republicans, Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis, will take the CNN debate stage at Drake University in Des Moines on Wednesday night for the final televised clash before the Iowa caucuses next week.

headline: Italian Town Hitches Its Wagon to Plants That Bloom (Even in Winter)
abstract: Lakefront Verbania in Italy’s Piedmont seeks to attract flower lovers with its mild climate, spectacular gardens and wild nature.
lead_paragraph: Even as the group of flower aficionados flitted around a high-ceilinged room admiring just-clipped camellias with fanciful names like “Pink Lassie” and “Paradise Petite,” single petals floated lazily to the paneled wood floor, forming colorful mounds.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Donald Trump’s immunity claim in court.
lead_paragraph: At a hearing in Washington yesterday, Donald Trump appeared in front of an appeals court panel to argue that he is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election because they arose from actions he took as president. The three judges on the panel seemed unconvinced, suggesting that they are unlikely to rule in the former president’s favor.

headline: ‘Why Would Trump Win This Election When He Lost the Last One?’
abstract: Eight Republican voters from Iowa offer their thoughts on the upcoming caucuses.
lead_paragraph: Eight Republican voters from Iowa offer their thoughts on the upcoming caucuses.

headline: Quotation of the Day: How Do You Keep a Tidy House? It Helps to Have a Tidy Mouse.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 11, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Lo and behold, I got a video of the mouse. Tidying up for me.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 10, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An entry in the Dateline feature on Sunday about the places from which Times journalists are reporting misstated the results of the presidential election in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The incumbent president, Felix Tshisekedi, was declared the winner; the country did not elect a new president.

headline: What to Know About the Chaos in Ecuador
abstract: Violence erupted across the South American country this week after a notorious gang leader disappeared from prison. The president has declared a state of emergency.
lead_paragraph: Violence erupted across Ecuador this week after a well-known gang leader disappeared from prison. Explosions, looting, gunfire and burning vehicles were reported, and there were uprisings in several prisons. In the largest city, Guayaquil, gunmen stormed a TV studio during a live broadcast on Tuesday.

headline: Late Night Recaps Donald Trump’s Latest Day in Court
abstract: Jimmy Fallon joked that Trump has so many trials that “at this point, the courtroom sketch artist doesn’t even draw him — she just traces the grooves in her desk.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Guards Beat and Waterboarded Prisoners in New York, Lawsuits Say
abstract: A guard placed a cloth over a prisoner’s face and poured water over him, creating a sensation that mimics drowning, according to court papers.
lead_paragraph: Two prisoners in upstate New York say they were brutally beaten by guards and taken to a different facility to be waterboarded — a method of torture once used by C.I.A. interrogators on terrorism suspects, according to newly filed lawsuits.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: In Newark, 16-Year-Olds Win the Right to Vote in School Board Races
abstract: New Jersey’s largest city will allow 16- and 17-year-olds to vote. Supporters hope it’s the start of a statewide and national movement.
lead_paragraph: Residents as young as 16 have been granted the right to vote in school board elections in Newark, New Jersey’s largest city, beginning in April, after the City Council unanimously approved an ordinance Wednesday lowering the voting age.

headline: East Coast Faces Flooding After Day of Rain
abstract: Millions of people from the Mid-Atlantic to New England faced the risk of flooding as rivers rose after a day of rain.
lead_paragraph: The heaviest rain from a widespread storm that drenched the eastern United States appeared to have ended in much of the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast by Wednesday morning, but meteorologists said the risk of flooding had just begun.

headline: As U.S. Support for Ukraine Falters, Europe Splits on Filling the Gap
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is likely to find strong backing on a trip to the Baltic States, but other nations are increasingly wary.
lead_paragraph: In Estonia, a four-story banner that combines the flags of Ukraine and Estonia hangs over a main square in the capital, Tallinn. In Latvia, Foreign Minister Krisjanis Karins is calling for allies to “ramp up military support to Ukraine without delay.”

headline: ‘We Live in Constant Fear’: Violence Erupts Across Ecuador
abstract: Chaos has consumed Ecuador after gang leaders escaped prisons and armed men commandeered a live TV broadcast.
lead_paragraph: Chaos has consumed Ecuador after gang leaders escaped prisons and armed men commandeered a live TV broadcast.

headline: Knife Attacker Hoped to End South Korean’s Presidential Bid, Police Say
abstract: The suspect had planned the attack last week on the country’s opposition leader for months, the police said, and had written an eight-page manifesto.
lead_paragraph: The man who stabbed the main opposition leader of South Korea in the neck last week wanted to kill him so that he would never become president, the police said, in an alarming escalation of the country’s political polarization.

headline: A Closer Look at What the U.S. Lets You See of Its War Court at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: The Times explores the place where photography is allowed at Guantánamo's secretive war court — and explains what you can and cannot see.
lead_paragraph: The Times explores the place where photography is allowed at Guantánamo's secretive war court — and explains what you can and cannot see.

headline: Inside Guantánamo Bay
abstract: Take a look inside the detention and court operations with Carol Rosenberg, the New York Times Guantanamo Bay correspondent.
lead_paragraph: Take a look inside the detention and court operations with Carol Rosenberg, the New York Times Guantanamo Bay correspondent.

headline: The EGOT Winner Behind Sondheim’s Signature Sound
abstract: For Jonathan Tunick, an early love of “Tubby the Tuba” led to a career as an orchestrator. He talks about his Sondheim partnership, and creating a sound that “can hint at unspoken secrets.”
lead_paragraph: To understand the role of the Broadway orchestrator, seek out the composer Stephen Sondheim’s piano demo for the song “Losing My Mind” from the musical “Follies” and then compare it to the version on the original cast recording. The demo’s tone is wistful and resigned, with a touch of the whiskey bar about it. In the finished version, the song sounds transformed: Ascending notes on the strings, interjections from the brass and crashing cymbals build to a powerful climax, evoking the heartache and inner turmoil contained in the lyric.

headline: Your Workout Routine Isn’t Complete Without Strength Training
