abstract: Aerobic exercise is hugely beneficial for health. But research increasingly shows you also need some resistance training. Here’s how to work it in.
lead_paragraph: Anh Bui’s main focus as a physical therapist is to treat and prevent running injuries. Her most common prescription for patients? Lifting weights.

headline: These Wedding Vendors Get Paid to Work on Their Phones
abstract: Brides and grooms are hiring content creators to film, edit footage and produce Instagram and TikTok posts with music, transitions and behind-the-scenes moments.
lead_paragraph: While searching on TikTok for ideas for her April 22, 2023 wedding, Mila Tweel came across several videos of former brides discussing what they would have done differently. Many regretted not hiring someone to capture behind-the-scene videos and photos of their wedding day.

headline: Inside the Mayor’s Closet
abstract: Ten suits, 19 ties, crisp white shirts and pin collars — a 30-day snapshot of Mayor Eric Adams’s style.
lead_paragraph: When Mayor Eric Adams emerges from his official limousine, so too does a glimpse of poplin, chambray and gabardine: some of the New York City mayor’s collection of crisp shirts, tailored suits and custom neckties often travels with him, swinging from a rack in the back seat of his black Chevrolet Suburban.

headline: Our Predictions for 2024
abstract: Stiff drinks, molten chocolate and logging off for good.
lead_paragraph: Every January, we ask our most trend-obsessed colleagues to make predictions about the year ahead. Here are their best guesses about what 2024 will hold for fashion, food, technology and culture.

headline: The Agony and Determination of Sderot
abstract: The mayor of an Israeli town attacked by Hamas on Oct. 7 describes the devastation, the will to recover and the source of its resilience.
lead_paragraph: Until the morning of Oct. 7, the town of Sderot in southern Israel was a parable of hope and success. Less than a mile from the Gaza border, it emerged a few years after the 1948 Arab-Israeli war as a haven for Jewish refugees fleeing antisemitic persecution — from North Africa, Kurdish lands, Ethiopia and the former Soviet Union. I am a second-generation Israeli; my parents found refuge in Israel from Iran.

headline: Tina Fey on ‘Mean Girls’ Then and Now
abstract: With a new version of Regina George and the Plastics headed to theaters, she reflects on how different generations have reacted over the years.
lead_paragraph: Tina Fey spent the summers of 2002 and 2003 hunched over an old desk in the mildewy back room of a Fire Island rental home. Fueled by coffee and Entenmann’s chocolate-covered doughnuts, Fey, at the time the head writer for “Saturday Night Live,” cracked the script that became “Mean Girls” on her laptop.

headline: In Florida, New School Laws Have an Unintended Consequence: Bureaucracy
abstract: Under recent rules, some students can’t take a vision test or get a Band-Aid without permission slips. And it’s up to schools to hunt them down.
lead_paragraph: Got a cut and need a Band-Aid? Want to be called Will instead of William? Or get your vision checked?

headline: A Match Made in Heaven: Pimento Cheese and Flaky Pie Crust
abstract: It used to feel impossible to improve on something as tasty as pimento cheese. That was before I started collaborating with other chefs.
lead_paragraph: In a world in which we hope to be seduced and moved by food, mayonnaise just sits there, daring us all to love it.

headline: How to Make the Most of Your At-Home Covid Test
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about when to take a test for accurate results, and how to get kits for free.
lead_paragraph: While Covid has become a regular part of respiratory virus season, community testing centers and drive-through sites where you could determine whether it’s the source of your sniffles have all but vanished.

headline: Food Assistance for Mothers and Children Faces Funding Shortfall
abstract: The Agriculture Department has warned that millions of eligible pregnant and postpartum women and their children could risk missing out on nutrition assistance if Congress does not increase funding.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in decades, many states could begin turning away eligible applicants from an assistance program that provides low-income women and their children critical access to food.

headline: Writing Is Doomed to Fail. That’s Why Hisham Matar Loves It.
abstract: Matar won a Pulitzer Prize for his memoir, “The Return,” mourning his homeland and his father. In his new novel, he turns to the untranslatability of exile — and friendship.
lead_paragraph: Talk to any friends of the writer Hisham Matar, and he has many, and soon they’ll bring up one of his more notorious pastimes: Have you ever seen how he looks at art?

headline: Then and Now: Revisiting the Sopranos’ New Jersey 25 Years Later
abstract: On the anniversary of the show’s premiere, its creator and location manager reflect on some of its iconic settings and why they were chosen.
lead_paragraph: As much as it was a show about Italian American mobsters, “The Sopranos” was a show about New Jersey. From scenes of domestic life in a North Caldwell McMansion to after-hours debauchery at a strip club in Lodi, the show captured a snapshot of the Garden State in the late 1990s and 2000s, beguiling viewers with its regional authenticity.

headline: For This Reporter, the War in Ukraine Is Also Personal
abstract: Yaroslav Trofimov grew up in Kyiv. “Our Enemies Will Vanish” records his experience as a journalist for The Wall Street Journal assigned to cover the war.
lead_paragraph: “Kyiv was still a city at peace,” Yaroslav Trofimov writes about the afternoon of Feb. 23, 2022, the day before Russian forces invaded Ukraine. The sun was shining, the bars were full; he saw no scenes of panic buying at the shops or snaking lines at the A.T.M.s.

headline: The Next Front in the U.S.-China Battle Over Chips
abstract: A U.S.-born chip technology called RISC-V has become critical to China’s ambitions. Washington is debating whether and how to limit the technology.
lead_paragraph: NASA has chosen the technology to help it land future spacecraft on unmapped planets. Meta uses the technology for artificial intelligence. Chinese engineers have turned to it to encrypt data.

headline: Mortgage Rates and Inflation Could Draw Attention to the Fed This Election
abstract: The Federal Reserve is poised to cut rates in 2024 while moving away from balance sheet shrinking. Yet a key event looms in the backdrop: the election.
lead_paragraph: This year is set to be a big one for Federal Reserve officials: They are expecting to cut interest rates several times as inflation comes down steadily, giving them a chance to dial back a two-year-long effort to cool the economy.

headline: Was This Man’s Weakness Related to Recent Oral Surgery?
abstract: His doctor had darker suspicions.
lead_paragraph: It was early morning when the woman crept into the living room, where her 82-year-old partner was sleeping. He didn’t usually sleep in his recliner but was in and out of bed so many times with diarrhea two nights earlier that she was relieved when he decided to sleep in his favorite chair. His eyes opened as she started to close the door. “I can’t get out of the chair,” he said quietly. His feet were on the floor, but, he told her, he didn’t have the strength to rise or even move. This was a man who, in the 21 years she’d known and loved him, was still only when he was asleep. Now, with his arms hanging limply beside him, his face pale behind his constant New Mexico tan, he looked weaker and sicker than she had ever seen him.

headline: The Shadow War to Determine the Next Trump Administration
abstract: The king hasn’t returned from exile, but he is already inspiring acrimony and disarray among his courtiers.
lead_paragraph: A disturbing sense of inevitability hangs over the Iowa caucuses on Monday. Donald Trump, with a 34-point lead in the polls, is the all but certain Republican nominee. And despite his legal troubles, Mr. Trump leads Joe Biden in several general election polls in swing states.

headline: An Ultrasound Experiment Tackles a Giant Problem in Brain Medicine
abstract: The effects of drugs that treat Alzheimer’s, cancer and other illnesses are often limited by the blood-brain barrier. A small study suggests a way forward.
lead_paragraph: There is a problem with the recently approved Alzheimer’s drug, Aduhelm. It can remove some of the amyloid that forms brain plaques that are hallmarks of the disease. But most of the drug is wasted because it hits an obstacle, the blood-brain barrier, that protects the brain from toxins and infections but also prevents many drugs from entering.

headline: We Are in a Big Covid Wave. But Just How Big?
abstract: Wastewater data has become perhaps the best metric to track the spread of the virus in the U.S., but it’s an imperfect tool.
lead_paragraph: The curves on some Covid graphs are looking quite steep, again.

headline: U.S. Carbon Emissions Fell in 2023 as Coal Use Tumbled to New Lows
abstract: The drop was big, but emissions will need to fall three times as fast for the rest of the decade if the country wants to meet its climate goals.
lead_paragraph: America’s greenhouse gas emissions fell 1.9 percent in 2023, in large part because the burning of coal to produce electricity plummeted to its lowest level in half a century, according to estimates published on Wednesday by the Rhodium Group, a nonpartisan research firm.

headline: Why Are American Drivers So Deadly?
abstract: After decades of declining fatality rates, dangerous driving has surged again.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1999, a few years after graduating from medical school, Deborah Kuhls moved from New York to Maryland, where she had been accepted as a surgical fellow at the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore. Founded by a pioneer in emergency medicine, Shock Trauma is one of the busiest critical-care facilities in the country — in an average year, doctors there see approximately 8,000 patients, many of them close to death.

headline: Microsoft Debates What to Do With A.I. Lab in China
abstract: Amid U.S.-China tensions, the company has faced questions over whether operating an advanced research lab in Beijing is politically tenable.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft opened an advanced research lab in Beijing in 1998, it was a time of optimism about technology and China.

headline: Setting the Stage for Iowa: ‘Trump Will Probably Be Over 50 Percent’
abstract: Two Opinion editors help raise the caucus curtain.
lead_paragraph: The Republican caucuses in Iowa are just five days away, marking the official start of the 2024 presidential election season. To kick-start Opinion Audio’s coverage, Patrick Healy, the deputy editor of Times Opinion, and the Opinion editor Katherine Miller get together to discuss their expectations for Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis, where they think the G.O.P. is headed and Donald Trump’s continued dominance. Stay tuned for more on-the-ground analysis from “The Opinions” in the coming weeks.

headline: A ‘National and Global Maelstrom’ Is Pulling Us Under
abstract: Trump has ushered in the age of the “great misalignment.”
lead_paragraph: The coming election will be held at a time of insoluble cultural and racial conflict; a two-tier economy, one growing, the other stagnant; a time of inequality and economic immobility; a divided electorate based on educational attainment — taken together, a toxic combination pushing the country into two belligerent camps.

headline: Women’s Hockey Team Breaks Into the New York Market
abstract: P.W.H.L. New York plays tonight at Belmont Park and is one of six teams in the new women’s league.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out about New York’s newest professional sports team, which is scheduled to play its first game at UBS Arena at Belmont Park on Long Island tonight. We’ll also check on the state of two states, New York and New Jersey.

headline: Why Biden Must Collide With the Democratic Party on Immigration
abstract: Brokering a deal could help the president shore up the nontraditional alliance that got him elected four years ago.
lead_paragraph: The negotiations on Ukraine funding and stricter border protections have exposed a growing rift between President Biden and his own party. Republican hard-liners have demanded a bill that mirrors policies advanced during the Trump administration, especially ones related to asylum seekers, increased border security and the mandate that companies institute the E-Verify employment eligibility system.

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in Florida, Georgia and Delaware
abstract: A coastal house in Santa Rosa Beach, an antique rowhouse in Savannah and a two-bedroom condominium in Wilmington.
lead_paragraph: This house is near 30A, a 24-mile span of road along the Gulf Coast that connects Santa Rosa Beach to other popular beach communities, including Rosemary Beach, Seaside and Seacrest. It is less than a mile from a public access point to a beach with white sand and gentle surf, and a 10-minute drive from a Publix supermarket and several casual seafood restaurants.

headline: Put a Rink on It
abstract: From 100 stories high in New York to the balmy shores of Florida, Instagrammable ice skating rinks are popping up all over America.
lead_paragraph: This winter, for the first time in recent history, it’s possible to ice skate underneath the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: One of Trump’s Oldest Tactics in Business and Politics: I’m Rubber. You’re Glue.
abstract: Whenever Donald Trump is accused of something, he responds by accusing his opponent of that exact thing. The idea is less to argue that Mr. Trump is clean than to suggest that everyone else is dirty.
lead_paragraph: Days before the Iowa caucuses, former President Donald J. Trump is appearing twice in court this week — on Tuesday in Washington and Thursday in New York.

headline: U.N. Expert Will Investigate Reports of Sex Crimes by Hamas, Israel Says
abstract: The official accepted Israel’s invitation and is expected to go there soon, the foreign ministry said. Hamas has denied that its fighters committed sex crimes during the Oct. 7 attacks.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ special representative on sexual violence in conflict has accepted Israel’s invitation to investigate allegations of sex crimes committed by Hamas on Oct. 7, a spokesman for Israel’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Tuesday.

headline: After a Day of Unsettled Weather, Here’s the Forecast
abstract: While conditions were calmer in the Southeast U.S., rain was expected in Maine, and snow in parts of the West. The New York region was facing brutal winds. Flood warnings remained in effect along the East Coast.
lead_paragraph: Much of the United States was continuing to grapple on Wednesday with a mixed bag of unsettled weather — snow, rain, strong winds, flooding and freezing temperatures — that had upended daily life for millions of people from coast to coast.

headline: Blinken Meets With Abbas to Talk About Gaza’s Future
abstract: The U.S. secretary of state spoke with Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, about the role the authority might play after Israel’s war with Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met on Wednesday with Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, to discuss Israel’s war against Hamas in Gaza and the role that the authority might play there when the conflict ebbs.

headline: All-Female City Council Marks a ‘Turning Point’ for a Twin City
abstract: For the first time in St. Paul, Minn., all seven City Council members are women. They also make up the youngest and most racially diverse council in the city’s history.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment last summer when Nelsie Yang realized that she and six other women were on the verge of making history in St. Paul, Minn. The group of City Council candidates was knocking on doors to share their joint campaign message, one that could transform the makeup of the city’s governing body.

headline: Trump’s Case for Total Immunity
abstract: Why the former president believes he should be immune from prosecution, and whether judges are likely to rule in his favor.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has consistently argued that as a former president, he is immune from being charged with a crime for things he did while he was in office.

headline: Severe Weather in U.S., and Crisis in Ecuador
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: An Immigration Shift
abstract: Leading Democrats once supported immigration enforcement measures. Today, much of the party is uncomfortable doing so.
lead_paragraph: Since Donald Trump first ran for president in 2016, the Democratic Party has changed its own approach to immigration. Not long ago, leading Democrats supported immigration enforcement measures like tough border security and deportations. Today, much of the party is uncomfortable doing so.

headline: How the War With Hamas Has Damaged Israel’s Tech Firms and Economy
abstract: Israel’s technology sector, a key part of the economy, has been jolted by worker shortages and funding fears, which could drive a wider slowdown in 2024.
lead_paragraph: At 6:45 a.m. on Oct. 7, Jack Bigio, the founder of the technology company UBQ Materials, talked to his chief operating officer, who said terrorists were on his kibbutz. Other employees texted that they were hiding in safe rooms, and one said her husband had been shot in the stomach.

headline: Papua New Guinea Orders Military to Restore Order as Unrest Rocks Capital
abstract: Angry protests started after hundreds of police officers and other public servants appeared to walk off their jobs over a wage dispute.
lead_paragraph: The government of Papua New Guinea on Wednesday ordered the military to restore order in the capital, Port Moresby, after a dispute over the wages of police officers and other public servants led to angry protests and unrest.

headline: Botox Destroyed What I Liked About My Face
abstract: I didn’t realize my wonky eyebrows were so dear to me until they were gone.
lead_paragraph: I tried Botox for the first time two years ago. I was rapidly approaching my 40th birthday, and like so many other people, I spent the early Covid years staring at my increasingly pallid and wrinkled visage through daily video calls. That I succumbed to the expensive allure of cosmetic injectables as a result of this scrutiny was both banal and mildly embarrassing.

headline: Word of the Day: kinesiology
abstract: This word has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word kinesiology has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 6 in “Uncoordinated? You Can Still Be an Athlete” by Jenny Marder:

headline: The Big Bitcoin Tease
abstract: A bogus social media post declaring that the S.E.C. had approved an E.T.F. tied to the cryptocurrency caused prices to whipsaw. A real decision could come as soon as Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The famously volatile price of Bitcoin briefly experienced more whiplash than usual on Tuesday, after a post on an official S.E.C. social media account said that the agency had approved long-awaited investment products tied to the cryptocurrency.

headline: Maps
abstract: Treasure maps. Road Maps. Fanciful Maps. What are your favorite memories with these geographic tools?
lead_paragraph: Are you fascinated by maps? Have you ever made one yourself?

headline: E. Leo Milonas, 87, a Lion and a Defender of New York Courts, Dies
abstract: As an administrator of courts in New York State and New York City, he championed judicial independence and defendants’ rights and was unafraid to speak out.
lead_paragraph: E. Leo Milonas, a resolute jurist who administered New York courts for a quarter-century and was known to rise to defend his fellow judges in public disputes, in one case sparring with Mayor Edward I. Koch, died on Jan. 2 at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 87.

headline: At an Emotional Governors Awards, Painful Losses and Heartfelt Tributes
abstract: The academy honored Mel Brooks, Angela Bassett, the recently widowed editor Carol Littleton and Sundance’s Michelle Satter, whose son died in a shooting.
lead_paragraph: Despite the chockablock ballroom full of Hollywood’s best and brightest, a jovial emcee in the comedian John Mulaney and honorees the audience seemed thrilled to celebrate, a pall of sadness was cast over the Governors Awards — an event created 14 years ago by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to shorten the Oscar telecast by relegating the honorary Oscars to its own untelevised confab.

headline: Why Does My Sister Want to Be Paid for Being the Executor of My Mother’s Will?
abstract: Months after the bulk of their mother’s estate was divided and paid, a reader’s sister is seeking to keep a remaining balance of $150,000 as payment for her work as an executor.
lead_paragraph: My mother passed away in 2021. She left her estate in equal shares to my sister, my brother and me. My siblings were named coexecutors of her will. It was relatively easy to sort out her house and belongings and to distribute the money. My sister insisted on handling everything: “I’ve got it,” she would say when we offered to help. Most of the funds were distributed soon after my mother’s death. But there remains a balance of $150,000. When my brother asked my sister to distribute it, she sent a long email saying she deserves to be paid for her work. My brother and I are surprised, sad and angry: The will doesn’t say anything about paying executors. My sister was an ample beneficiary, and her work was finished 18 months ago. If she wanted to be paid for what I view as an act of love, she should have brought it up at the beginning. Thoughts?

headline: The Tech That Needs Fixing in 2024, and What Got Fixed Last Year
abstract: The best tech, from universal power charging to foldable phones, solved practical problems. But the worst tech, including self-driving cars and cryptocurrency, put us in harm’s way.
lead_paragraph: Tech companies would like us to believe that their products tell a story about progress. Faster phones! Better cameras! Brighter screens! Yet despite all the improvements, there are pieces of tech that have been flawed for years.

headline: December Was One of the Warmest on Record in California
abstract: The state’s weather in 2023 wasn’t especially toasty overall, but December was an exception.
lead_paragraph: Despite all the holiday songs about sun-baked beaches and snowless Christmas celebrations, December in California actually tends to be cool and damp.

headline: Pat McAfee’s On-Air Slams of ESPN Executive Show a Network Power Shift
abstract: For decades, the biggest star at ESPN was ESPN. That’s changing as it transitions from cable dominance to a much less certain streaming future.
lead_paragraph: As it morphs from a television company into a streaming company, ESPN is undergoing rapid transformation. But if the extraordinary events of the past week are any indication, the transformation of its corporate culture is just as seismic.

headline: A Super PAC Forms to Support No Labels
abstract: Officials with the group said they had $2 million in initial commitments but expect up to $300 million if there’s a “viable” ticket.
lead_paragraph: A political group intending to support a presidential candidate run by the group No Labels plans to file paperwork with the Federal Election Commission on Wednesday, with a handful of Republican and Democratic strategists as advisers.

headline: How to Watch Trump’s Town Hall on Fox News
abstract: Fox News will host the event from Iowa starting at 9 p.m. Eastern time tonight.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump will join the Fox anchors Bret Baier and Martha MacCallum at 9 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday for a live town-hall event. It will be broadcast on Fox News and can be streamed at Foxnews.com with a cable login.

headline: Iowa Nice vs. New Hampshire Ornery: A Tale of Spurned Democrats
abstract: In Iowa, Democrats politely accepted President Biden’s decision to push them back on the presidential nominating calendar. In New Hampshire, they’re fighting it with live-free-or-die stubbornness.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden shook up his party’s presidential nominating calendar, Democrats in the two states that were bounced from the front of the line reacted in far different ways.

headline: Democrats Set Ambitious Spending Plan for State Legislative Races
abstract: After trying to catch up to Republicans for a decade, Democrats are stressing the importance of down-ballot positions on big political issues.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party’s organization that focuses on state legislative races is planning its largest campaign budget ever as it seeks to flip five chambers in three critical swing states, as well as defend three recently earned majorities, according to a memo of the group’s 2024 strategy obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Effort to Revamp I.R.S. Faces Challenges Despite Funding Infusion
abstract: The Office of the National Taxpayer Advocate lamented that the tax collection agency, which now faces budget cuts in Congress, is still struggling to answer the telephones.
lead_paragraph: A multibillion-dollar federal effort to modernize the Internal Revenue Service has not yet solved the agency’s struggles to answer customers’ calls, ameliorate identity theft or process amended tax returns, the agency’s watchdog wrote on Wednesday in a report to Congress.

headline: Tell Us the Little Things You Do for Love
abstract: What small acts of affection help keep you and your partner connected?
lead_paragraph: Valentine’s Day is just around the corner and, sure, plenty of people dismiss it as a commercialized scam. But for others, the holiday is a welcome occasion to pause and remind your partner what they mean to you (or, at the very least, to eat a little chocolate).

headline: At World Court, Israel to Confront Accusations of Genocide
abstract: Israel has categorically rejected the allegations being brought this week in the International Court of Justice by South Africa.
lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice, the United Nations’ highest judicial body, will begin hearings this week in a case brought by South Africa that accuses Israel of committing genocide in Gaza.

headline: How to Watch the Republican Debate Taking Place in Iowa
abstract: Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley will face off on CNN at 9 p.m. Eastern time tonight.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis will meet on Wednesday night in Des Moines for the last Republican presidential debate before the Iowa caucuses on Monday.

headline: U.S. Diet Panel Adds Another Researcher With Alcohol Industry Ties
abstract: After dropping two Harvard experts who had received industry support, the National Academies turned to a colleague with a similar background.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after dropping two Harvard scientists with financial conflicts of interest, the national organization assembling a committee to assess the evidence about drinking and health has chosen four new panelists, among them another Harvard professor who also has financial ties to the alcohol industry.

headline: Severe Storms Rip Roofs Off of Homes in the Southeast
abstract: Strong winds and likely tornadoes destroyed several buildings in the Southeast.
lead_paragraph: Strong winds and likely tornadoes destroyed several buildings in the Southeast.

headline: SAG Award Nominations 2024: It’s a ‘Barbenheimer’ Rematch
abstract: The summer blockbusters each garnered four nominations. Notable snubs included Leonardo DiCaprio of “Killers of the Flower Moon.”
lead_paragraph: Box office behemoths “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” led this year’s nominations for the Screen Actors Guild Awards, which were announced Wednesday morning. Each film picked up four nominations, including ones for the guild’s top ensemble prize.

headline: Democrats Question Semiconductor Program’s Ties to Wall St.
abstract: Two progressive lawmakers warned the Biden administration against creating a revolving door between industry and government as it prepares to hand out $39 billion in grants.
lead_paragraph: Two Democratic lawmakers on Tuesday expressed concerns about ex-Wall Street financiers overseeing the Commerce Department’s distribution of $39 billion in grants to the semiconductor industry, saying the staffing raised questions about the creation and abuse of a revolving door between government and industry.

headline: More Than 20 Million People Have Signed Up for Obamacare Plans, Blowing by Record
abstract: The Biden administration said that a record number of Americans had signed up for coverage in 2024 through the Affordable Care Act’s marketplaces, a sign of the law’s durability.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 million people have signed up for plans on the Affordable Care Act’s marketplaces during the annual open enrollment period, far surpassing last year’s record of more than 16 million enrollments, the Biden administration announced on Wednesday.

headline: Our Five-Star, Thai-Inspired Chicken Meatball Soup With Over 14,000 Reviews
abstract: Is there anything cuter or more fun to eat than a meatball? Snuggled into a sandwich, slid onto skewers or perched on top of spaghetti, meatballs are inherently playful — more than their close cousin meatloaf, which is far too square to roll off the table and out of the door.
lead_paragraph: Is there anything cuter or more fun to eat than a meatball? Snuggled into a sandwich, slid onto skewers or perched on top of spaghetti, meatballs are inherently playful — more than their close cousin meatloaf, which is far too square to roll off the table and out of the door.

headline: Ancient Skeletons Give Clues to Modern Medical Mysteries
abstract: DNA fragments from thousands of years ago are providing insights into multiple sclerosis, diabetes, schizophrenia and other illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Multiple sclerosis, an autoimmune disease that affects 2.9 million people, presents a biological puzzle.

headline: The Biggest Ape That Ever Lived Was Not Too Big to Fail
abstract: Fossil teeth reveal Gigantopithecus was doomed by a changing environment and an inflexible diet.
lead_paragraph: Standing nearly as tall as a basketball hoop and weighing as much as a grizzly bear, Gigantopithecus blacki was the greatest ape to ever live. For more than a million years during the Pleistocene, Gigantopithecus roamed southern China. But by the time ancient humans reached the region, Gigantopithecus had vanished.

headline: Climate Change Is Driving a Sharp Drop in Snow Levels, Study Finds
abstract: Parts of the Northern Hemisphere are warming enough that their prospects of future snow are rapidly declining.
lead_paragraph: Changing snow patterns have far-reaching consequences, from water shortages to shuttered ski resorts. A new study confirms that human-caused climate change has affected snow patterns across the Northern Hemisphere, including clear declines of snowpack in at least 31 individual river basins.

headline: Trump Promotes False Birther Conspiracy About Nikki Haley
abstract: False and racist attempts to sow doubt about a political rival’s eligibility for the nation’s highest office are part of the former president’s playbook.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has reached back into his brand of nativism to accuse a political opponent of color — this time, Nikki Haley — of not being a real American eligible for the presidency as he defends his own eligibility for the ballot under the Constitution.

headline: With ‘Echo,’ Alaqua Cox Smashes Boundaries, and Bad Guys’ Faces
abstract: The actress almost didn’t audition for the Marvel superhero role that now has her playing the lead of a new Disney+ series. Thank goodness for peer pressure.
lead_paragraph: “I thought in the back of my head, There’s no way I’m going to get this.”

headline: Hunter Biden Appears on Capitol Hill as House G.O.P. Votes for Contempt
abstract: Two House committees voted to approve a contempt of Congress citation for President Biden’s son after he made a surprise appearance on Capitol Hill, prompting bitter partisan fighting.
lead_paragraph: Two House committees voted on Wednesday along party lines to hold Hunter Biden, the president’s son, in contempt of Congress, hours after he surprised Republicans by appearing unannounced on Capitol Hill, prompting a partisan free-for-all.

headline: A Fellow Cop Let My Father-In-Law Slide on a Breathalyzer Test. What to Do?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to proceed in the wake of moral and civic disgrace.
lead_paragraph: My father-in-law hides his drinking and denies it, but when we visit, we see him sneak out to the car and drink vodka from the trunk many times a day. We live close by and see my in-laws quite often; hence we also see him drinking frequently, even though my husband has tried hard to get him to stop.

headline: The Saxophone Master Shabaka Hutchings Is on a Fresh Journey: Flutes
abstract: The British musician is an artist in residence at Winter Jazzfest in New York this week, playing an instrument group that he first picked up in 2019.
lead_paragraph: As Shabaka Hutchings led a concert tribute to Pharoah Sanders in early December, he returned to a familiar equation: funneling gallons of air through his tenor saxophone, transforming it into a corrosive stream of sound.

headline: Blocked Toilets Close Eton, Boarding School for Britain’s Elite Sons
abstract: Flooding and a sewer backup have delayed the start of the new term. Classes at the school, which has educated princes and prime ministers, will move online.
lead_paragraph: The first prime minister of Britain, Robert Walpole, went to Eton College. So did Boris Johnson and David Cameron and more than a dozen others.

headline: Ecuadoreans Split on President’s Drastic New Measure to Combat Drug Gangs
abstract: Vowing to bring peace back to a shattered country, President Daniel Noboa has deployed the military to take on what he calls “terrorist” groups.
lead_paragraph: A sense of dread took hold in Ecuador on Wednesday, with the streets empty, schools closed and many people afraid to leave their homes after the disappearance of two gang leaders set off prison riots, police kidnappings and the on-air storming of a TV station.

headline: Al Shabab Terrorist Group Captures U.N. Helicopter in Somalia
abstract: Somali officials said the helicopter was carrying nine passengers, one of whom was killed. The Horn of Africa nation is now grappling with how to rescue hostages from a group known for mistreating them.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations helicopter carrying nine passengers was captured in Somalia on Wednesday by the terrorist group Al Shabab after making an emergency landing because of technical difficulties in an area controlled by the group, three senior Somali officials said.

headline: OpenAI Unveils App Store for Custom Chatbots
abstract: People who subscribe to OpenAI’s ChatGPT Plus service will be able to browse the new store for tailored chatbots that perform different tasks.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI said on Wednesday that it was opening an app store for people to share customized versions of its popular chatbot, ChatGPT, as the artificial intelligence company works to expand the reach of its flagship technology and turn it into a moneymaker.

headline: ‘Gas-Station Heroin’ Sold as Dietary Supplement Alarms Health Officials
abstract: Tianeptine, found at convenience stores, at smoke shops and online, can mimic an opioid. It is among a growing class of substances that are difficult to control.
lead_paragraph: The young father headed across the parking lot to join the other parents meeting their children’s new preschool teachers. After a few steps, he began sweating and twitching. As the sky reeled, he staggered back to the car, desperate to lie down in the back seat and breathe, hidden by tinted windows.

headline: A Way to Improve How Children Read
abstract: Readers respond to a proposal by Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York. Also: Donald Trump’s immunity claim; the Biden age issue; hope when facing death.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Indian American Leaders in Iowa Say They Feel Abandoned by Nikki Haley
abstract: Ms. Haley, the daughter of Indian immigrants, has a natural constituency in Iowa’s Indian American voters, but leaders say she has not reached out.
lead_paragraph: With less than a week to go before the Iowa caucuses, leaders with some of the largest and most active Indian and South Asian American associations in the state say Nikki Haley has missed a major opportunity to run up her margins against her opponents: Engaging Indian American voters.

headline: What to Know After Severe Storms Hit Vast Areas of the U.S.
abstract: Flooding, flight delays and power outages remain widespread after hazardous weather ranged across much of the nation.
lead_paragraph: Strong winds and heavy rain left hundreds of thousands of utility customers in the eastern United States without power on Wednesday. Roads and buildings across a wide region were flooded and battered by the storm, with some rivers and streams still rising.

headline: Prolific Challenger of Trump’s Ballot Eligibility Faces Federal Tax Charges
abstract: John Anthony Castro, the long-shot G.O.P. candidate behind many suits to disqualify Donald J. Trump, is accused of preparing false tax returns.
lead_paragraph: A long-shot Republican presidential candidate who has repeatedly, and so far unsuccessfully, tried to have Donald J. Trump thrown off the primary ballot was arrested this week on federal charges of preparing false tax returns for clients.

headline: Use of A.D.H.D. Drugs Surged During Pandemic, Study Finds
abstract: Social media influencers and online marketing may have played a role, experts said.
lead_paragraph: Prescriptions for drugs used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder surged during the coronavirus pandemic, particularly among women and patients ages 20 to 39, according to new research compiled by scholars affiliated with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.

headline: To Run the British Museum, You’ll Get $275,000 and a Host of Problems
abstract: The museum is seeking a new leader to manage the fallout from recent thefts and demands to return contested items. Applicants have two weeks to apply.
lead_paragraph: Wanted: Someone to restore trust in one of the world’s most visited museums after an embarrassing scandal, handle restitution claims and raise $1.27 billion for a major refurbishment.

headline: Severe Storms Sweep Across the Eastern U.S.
abstract: Heavy rain and powerful winds stretched up the East Coast, flooding streets and buildings. In parts of the South, apparent tornadoes tore through homes.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rain and powerful winds stretched up the East Coast, flooding streets and buildings. In parts of the South, apparent tornadoes tore through homes.

headline: WordleBot’s New Preferred Opening Word: Trace
abstract: We’re adding words to the bot’s dictionary, and wiping the slate to make way for a new starter.
lead_paragraph: In our recent analysis of 515 million Wordle games played over a year, we noted that a few changes would soon be coming to WordleBot’s dictionary. As of today, those changes are now live — including a new opening word in both regular and hard mode.

headline: Menendez Lashed Out in the Senate. Now, He’s Fighting Back in Court.
abstract: Lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez filed a dismissal motion on Wednesday, offering a first glimpse into the New Jersey Democrat’s defense strategy.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat charged with accepting cash and gold bribes, asked a judge on Wednesday to dismiss the indictment, saying overzealous prosecutors were criminalizing normal legislative activity and flouting constitutional protections afforded to members of Congress.

headline: One Way to Stay Safe in a Storm: Take Care Around Trees
abstract: Roots are more likely to give way when soil is saturated and winds are high. Here’s how to protect yourself and your home.
lead_paragraph: Like homes, cars and electricity lines, trees provide vital services. But they can also be dangerous, even deadly, in storms or when they are not cared for properly.

headline: Subway Train Derails in Brooklyn in 2nd Such Episode in a Week
abstract: The train, a Manhattan-bound F, went off the tracks in Coney Island on Wednesday afternoon. No injuries were reported.
lead_paragraph: A subway train derailed in Brooklyn on Wednesday afternoon, police and fire officials said. It was the second derailment incident in New York City’s mass-transit system in less than a week.

headline: Iowa’s Governor Bet on DeSantis. Voters Aren’t Thrilled.
abstract: Kim Reynolds remains popular among Republicans in her state, but she drew grumblings from Trump supporters by throwing her weight behind his opponent.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa broke with tradition and with former President Donald J. Trump in November when she endorsed Ron DeSantis for president in her state’s first-in-the-nation caucuses, a move that surprised political observers and Iowa voters alike.

headline: Alice Parker, Composer Who Heard Music in Poetry, Dies at 98
abstract: A master of American choral music, she wrote arrangements of hymns, folk songs and spirituals used in concert halls and churches countrywide.
lead_paragraph: Alice Parker, whose arrangements of hymns, folk songs, and spirituals were used in concert halls and churches across America, and who composed 11 song cycles and four operas, died on Dec. 24 at her home in Hawley, Mass. She was 98.

headline: Amazon Cuts Hundreds of Jobs at Studios and Twitch
abstract: The layoffs add to a growing number of cuts in the tech industry this past year.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is laying off hundreds of employees at its studio division as well as its subsidiary Twitch to reduce costs, the latest in a wave of new job cuts hitting the tech industry.

headline: A Dinner Party So Easy You Don’t Even Need Recipes
abstract: A little technique is the key to this three-course meal from David Tanis, of a bright citrus salad, comforting cauliflower cheese and a pistachio chocolate bark.
lead_paragraph: People often tell me they simply can’t cook without a recipe. But often you don’t really need one: You need a technique, a method.

headline: ‘The Beekeeper’ Review: Sting Like a, You Know
abstract: In this action thriller, Jason Statham plays a man who will do whatever it takes to protect his hive.
lead_paragraph: “To bee or not to bee?” That is a question asked to Jason Statham in “The Beekeeper,” a delirious entry in the thriving genre of action flicks about gunslingers who list a different career on their LinkedIn. (See also: “The Painter” and “The Bricklayer,” both released just last week.) The director David Ayer’s previous shoot-em-up, “The Tax Collector,” was woefully short on quips about audits. He and the screenwriter Kurt Wimmer have not made that mistake here. Take a swig of mead every time Statham vows to protect the hive — by which he means society — and you’ll have a fine time. Either way, you won’t remember a thing about the plot.

headline: Christopher Nolan Continues Momentum with Directors Guild Nomination
abstract: Greta Gerwig is also nominated for “Barbie.” Most but not all of the nominees for this prize often go on to Oscar nominations.
lead_paragraph: The Directors Guild of America announced the nominations for its feature-film award on Wednesday, lending further momentum to nominee Christopher Nolan (“Oppenheimer”), who won the Golden Globe for directing on Sunday.

headline: Missing Profits May Be a Problem for the Green Transition
abstract: The inability to generate acceptable returns is impeding the switch to renewable energy.
lead_paragraph: In October, the International Energy Agency issued a brief flare of optimism when it suggested that global carbon emissions from fossil fuels may already have peaked.

headline: Menendez Motion to Dismiss
abstract: Lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez filed a motion on Wednesday arguing that the bribery case against him should be dismissed.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez filed a motion on Wednesday arguing that the bribery case against him should be dismissed.

headline: A School Sheltered Migrants in a Storm. The Hate Calls Poured In.
abstract: Migrant families were evacuated to the auditorium of James Madison High School. The school went remote the next day, and families and elected officials protested.
lead_paragraph: An angry backlash erupted at a Brooklyn high school on Wednesday, after New York City officials housed about 500 migrant families in an auditorium there overnight because of heavy rains and fierce winds at their shelter site.

headline: How a TV Show Forced Britain’s Devastating Post Office Scandal Into the Light
abstract: After years of delays, victims of one of the U.K.’s worst miscarriages of justice are finally being exonerated — thanks to a TV drama.
lead_paragraph: More than 700 people convicted of a crime they didn’t commit. At least four suicides. A woman sent to jail while pregnant. Bankruptcies. Marriages broken, lives ruined.

headline: 1 Killed in Avalanche at Lake Tahoe Ski Resort
abstract: The avalanche, at Palisades Tahoe in Olympic Valley, Calif., drew a large emergency response. One other person was treated for a minor injury, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: One person was killed and one other person was injured in an avalanche at a popular ski resort in Lake Tahoe in California on Wednesday, the authorities said.

headline: S.E.C. Social Media Hack That Sent Bitcoin Soaring Prompts Investigation
abstract: Legal experts said investigators would look into how the security breach occurred and whether anyone tried to profit from it.
lead_paragraph: The hack of a social media account used by the Securities and Exchange Commission is prompting both internal and external investigations into how the security breach occurred and whether anyone tried to profit from it, said the commission and several legal experts.

headline: Trump’s Boldest Argument Yet: Immunity From Prosecution for Assassinations
abstract: A lawyer for the former president said he would be immune from prosecution for the murder of a political rival while in office unless he was first impeached and convicted in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, just before the Iowa caucuses, Donald J. Trump crowed about his invulnerability.

headline: An Oatmeal Cookie for Raisin Haters
abstract: A puddle of blueberry maple jam is stuffed inside these tender, gently spiced treats.
lead_paragraph: It may come as a shock to legions of chocolate chip devotees, but there’s a small but passionate faction of cookie lovers who prefer oatmeal raisin.

headline: Trump Won’t Give Closing Argument at Fraud Trial After Judge Sets Limits
abstract: The former president’s lawyer said he could not abide by limitations set by the judge in the civil fraud case. “I will not hesitate to cut him off,” wrote Justice Arthur F. Engoron.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump backed down from delivering his own closing argument in his civil fraud trial after refusing to abide by a judge’s restrictions — including that he not give “a campaign speech” — in the latest clash between Mr. Trump’s political aims and American legal norms.

headline: What Did We Learn From a Year in Live Shows?
abstract: Concerts paused during the height of the pandemic, and returned at full power in 2023. Our pop music editor saw a lot of them.
lead_paragraph: No one on the New York Times pop music staff attends more live shows than Caryn Ganz, the pop music editor. On this week’s Popcast, she reflects on the first full post-pandemic year of live performances, with stadium and arena tours finally back at full strength.

headline: Norma Barzman, Blacklisted Screenwriter, Dies at 103
abstract: After she and her husband, a fellow writer, saw work in Hollywood dry up during the Red Scare, they continued their careers in self-exile overseas.
lead_paragraph: Norma Barzman, a screenwriter who moved to Europe in the late 1940s rather than be subject to the congressional investigations and professional ostracism that overtook her industry for a decade, died on Dec. 17 at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 103 and widely considered to be one of the last surviving victims of the Hollywood blacklist.

headline: G.O.P. Opens Mayorkas Impeachment Push With No Evidence of High Crimes
abstract: The first House hearing on impeaching the homeland security secretary featured Republicans accusing him of willfully failing to enforce immigration laws and an expert who testified there was no case.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans on Wednesday kicked off formal impeachment hearings against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, accusing him of willfully failing to enforce immigration laws even as leading constitutional experts said there was no basis to do so.

headline: Thursday Briefing: The Fight Against Houthi Rebels
abstract: Preview: Also, violence in Ecuador.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. and its allies are trying to figure out how to stop attacks by Houthi rebels based in Yemen against commercial ships in the Red Sea. This comes after American and British forces said yesterday that they intercepted one of the largest barrages of missiles and drones yet.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Don’t Hug Me I’m Scared’ and More
abstract: I’m an editor who works on features for The Times’s print edition. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying.
lead_paragraph: I’m an editor who works on features for The Times’s print edition. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying.

headline: The Scariest Part About the Boeing 737 Max 9 Blowout
abstract: What I heard wasn’t necessarily reassuring.
lead_paragraph: You should worry that a crying baby will be in the seat next to you. You should worry that snow in Chicago will snarl air traffic. But you should never, ever have to worry that a plug in the side of your plane — a hidden weak spot — will suddenly blow out at 16,000 feet. That is what happened to Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 shortly after takeoff from Portland, Ore., on Friday.

headline: Trump Has Suggested Violence Could Erupt if Court Cases Do Not Go His Way
abstract: In recent days, former President Donald J. Trump has warned of “bedlam in this country” and “big, big trouble” if courts were to rule against him.
lead_paragraph: Twice in recent days former President Donald J. Trump has openly suggested that there could be violence should the Supreme Court rule against him in his ballot eligibility dispute, or if the federal case against him for plotting to overturn the 2020 election proceeds, warning of “big, big trouble” and “bedlam in this country.”

headline: Standoff at Presidential Palace Shows Poland’s Right Won’t Go Quietly
abstract: The incident escalated a campaign by the ousted Law and Justice party to resist the transfer of power after it lost its parliamentary majority in October.
lead_paragraph: Poland’s bumpy transition to a new government hit dramatic turbulence on Wednesday when a prominent hard-line minister in the former right-wing administration declared himself a “political prisoner” and announced he was going on a hunger strike to protest his arrest following conviction for abuse of power.

headline: U.S. Hit by Record Number of High-Cost Disasters in 2023
abstract: There were 28 storms, wildfires or other disasters that each cost at least one billion dollars in damages, a sign of the growing economic burden of climate change.
lead_paragraph: The United States experienced 28 disasters last year that each cost at least $1 billion , the highest number on record and the latest measure of the growing toll of climate change.

headline: Regulators Approve New Type of Bitcoin Fund, in Boon for Crypto Industry
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized financial firms to offer a Bitcoin investment product that some hope will accelerate adoption of the technology.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Wednesday approved a new financial product that tracks the price of Bitcoin, a landmark moment for the cryptocurrency industry that proponents hope will increase investment in the technology.

headline: Adan Canto, ‘The Cleaning Lady’ and ‘X-Men’ Actor, Dies at 42
abstract: In a career of more than a decade, he played a range of roles, including a control-obsessed criminal, a poised politician and a fiery comic-book hero.
lead_paragraph: Adan Canto, the Mexican actor known for his roles on television series including “The Cleaning Lady” and “Designated Survivor,” as well as for playing the superhero Sunspot in the film “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” died on Monday. He was 42.

headline: Trump’s Argument for Immunity in 2024 Is the Opposite of His Stance in 2021
abstract: During his second impeachment trial, the former president argued that criminal prosecution was a more appropriate way to seek accountability since he had left office.
lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump appeared before an appeals court in Washington this week to claim he was immune from prosecution for his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, one of his lawyers argued that he should not face criminal charges because the Senate had failed to convict him of similar offenses at an impeachment trial three years ago.

headline: After Red Sea Barrage by Houthis, U.S. and Allies Weigh Retaliation
abstract: American officials and their allies warned that there would be consequences for the Houthis, the Iranian-backed armed group that has disrupted shipping in the Red Sea.
lead_paragraph: The United States and its allies are weighing how to stop attacks on commercial ships in the Red Sea after American and British officials said on Wednesday that their navies had intercepted one of the largest barrages yet of drones and missiles fired from an area controlled by the Houthis, an Iranian-backed group in Yemen.

headline: Conservatives Revolt Anew Over Johnson Deal to Avert Shutdown
abstract: A dozen hard-line Republicans ground business to a halt in protest of the deal Speaker Mike Johnson struck with Democrats to avert a shutdown, leaving the funding package in limbo.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives thrust the House back into chaos on Wednesday, grinding business to a halt in protest of the spending deal Speaker Mike Johnson struck with Democrats to avert a government shutdown and leaving the funding package in limbo.

headline: Setback for Heirs in Long-Running Nazi Art Restitution Case
abstract: A U.S. Court of Appeals decision allows a Spanish museum to keep a Pissarro in a dispute that has lasted nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: The heirs of a woman who was forced to surrender a painting to the Nazis were dealt a blow on Tuesday in a decades-long legal feud between them and the Spanish museum that now owns the work, when a Federal Court in California ruled that the museum should retain ownership.

headline: Christie’s Exit Is Jolted as Hot Mic Picks Up His Unvarnished View of Rivals
abstract: As he bowed out of the presidential race, Mr. Christie was heard mocking Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis. His departure leaves the field without its most vocal Trump critic.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey suspended his presidential campaign on Wednesday, but he undermined his effort to stop Donald J. Trump when he sweepingly dismissed his Republican rivals during a hot-mic moment.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Will Not Face Budget Cuts After All, Adams Says
abstract: The mayor said that not only would there be no police hiring freeze, but that 600 recruits were on the way. Libraries still face budget reductions.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams said on Wednesday that the city had restored funding to the New York Police Department and would add 600 recruits in April, a reversal of the dire warning he gave in November that there would be a hiring freeze.

headline: Christie Caught on Hot Mic Disparaging Haley and DeSantis
abstract: “She’s going to get smoked, and you and I both know it,” Mr. Christie seems to have said, presumably referring to Nikki Haley.
lead_paragraph: As speculation about his future in the presidential race swirled, Chris Christie was caught on a hot mic on his campaign’s livestream in a conversation before his scheduled event in Windham, N.H., discussing his Republican rivals in the race.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Capitol Visit Surprised Republicans, and His Father’s Advisers
abstract: The White House is trying to keep its distance as the president’s son deploys an aggressive new strategy.
lead_paragraph: When Hunter Biden interrupted a House Oversight Committee vote over holding him in contempt of Congress on Wednesday, Republican lawmakers were not the only ones caught off guard. President Biden’s advisers were surprised to see him there, too.

headline: Can Iowa Hold a Proper Caucus for Once?
abstract: The closely-watched contest has been a hot mess for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: The most-watched early presidential contest in America has been a hot mess for more than a decade.

headline: Chris Christie Ended His Presidential Bid
abstract: Also, the U.S. weighs retaliation after Red Sea attacks. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie, the former New Jersey governor who positioned himself as the Republican candidate for president most willing to attack Donald Trump, dropped out of the race today after months of campaigning failed to secure him more than a sliver of support in polls. In the end, Christie’s attacks against Trump, whom he called unfit for office, appear to have distanced him from the party’s base.

headline: Hamas says hostages won’t go home alive as long as Israeli forces remain in Gaza.
abstract: Netanyahu faces growing pressure to get the more than 100 hostages still held in Gaza home safely.
lead_paragraph: Israeli hostages held in the Gaza Strip “will not be returned alive” unless Israeli forces leave, a Hamas spokesman said on Wednesday, highlighting the predicament facing the Israeli government: It has vowed to free the hostages, and to pursue the war and defeat Hamas.

headline: Women With Depression During or After Pregnancy Face Greater Suicide Risk, Even Years Later
abstract: Two studies concluded that depression that began in pregnancy or soon after could have troubling implications for as long as 18 years.
lead_paragraph: Women who experience depression during pregnancy or in the year after giving birth have a greater risk of suicide and attempted suicide — risks that persist for years, two new studies report.

headline: Appeals Court Finds DeSantis Violated Prosecutor’s First Amendment Rights
abstract: The ruling deals a blow to the Florida governor on a decision he uses to bolsters his conservative credentials.
lead_paragraph: Dealing a blow to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, a federal court of appeals on Wednesday ruled that he had violated First Amendment protections when he suspended a progressive state prosecutor for political gain.

headline: Biden’s Appeal to Black Voters Needs an Overhaul
abstract: The president’s speech at Mother Emanuel was a missed opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Let’s start here: A second Donald Trump presidency is a disaster scenario.

headline: When Democracy Is a Threat
abstract: In its coming elections, Taiwan is voting in China’s shadow.
lead_paragraph: The first time I covered a Taiwan “election,” 38 years ago, the island was a dictatorship under martial law, with members of the opposition more likely to be tortured than to gain power.

headline: Why Some People Keep Serious Illnesses Private
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III is under scrutiny for concealing his prostate cancer diagnosis and treatment. But experts say it can be a common coping mechanism.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. defense secretary is facing scrutiny after failing to immediately disclose to the White House his recent prostate-cancer diagnosis and a related hospitalization, a breach of protocol for which he has apologized.

headline: Lawyer Tapped to Prosecute Trump in Georgia Is Now Under Scrutiny Himself
abstract: Nathan Wade has stayed silent since a legal filing said he was chosen for the job because he was romantically involved with the Fulton County district attorney.
lead_paragraph: Before he became the special prosecutor leading the Georgia election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump, Nathan Wade was working as a private defense lawyer and a judge for a municipal court in the Atlanta suburbs.

headline: Marisa Pavan, Oscar Nominee for ‘The Rose Tattoo,’ Dies at 91
abstract: The twin sister of the Italian ingénue Pier Angeli, she attempted to avoid the pitfalls of fame that befell her sister’s career.
lead_paragraph: The Italian actress Marisa Pavan never achieved the fame of her twin sister, Pier Angeli, a film ingénue of the 1950s who graced national magazine covers and whose romance with James Dean and subsequent marriage to the singer Vic Damone became the stuff of Hollywood lore.

headline: ‘Right Where We Want Him, 30 Points Up’: Chasing Trump in Iowa
abstract: A look at Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley’s quest to catch the former president — and finish ahead in their race for second place.
lead_paragraph: At the start of the 2024 Republican primary campaign, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida was considered by many in his party to be the biggest threat to Donald Trump. He was seen as someone who could win over the voters who were tired of Trump’s antics, and also bring along the MAGA movement. But it didn’t work out that way. And as Mr. DeSantis has struggled, one main opponent, former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina, has seen her star — and her standing in the polls — rise.

headline: Former Cardinal Is Ruled Not Competent to Stand Trial in Sex Abuse Case
abstract: Theodore McCarrick was the highest-ranking cleric in the nation to face criminal charges in the Catholic church’s sprawling abuse scandal.
lead_paragraph: The criminal case against a former cardinal who was once one of the most prominent and revered Catholic leaders in the country was suspended Wednesday, possibly ending efforts to prosecute him on sex abuse charges.

headline: At Trial, Sotheby’s Says Russian Oligarch Was Sloppy in Buying Art
abstract: Dmitry Rybolovlev accused the auction house of aiding a dealer who he says defrauded him in art sales. Sotheby’s says the oligarch spent billions without proper due diligence.
lead_paragraph: As the opening witness in a civil art fraud trial this week, Mikhail Sazonov testified that his employer, a Russian oligarch, had been tricked to overspend by a Swiss art dealer and that those markups had been boosted by the evaluations of artworks supplied by a Sotheby’s executive.

headline: Alaska Airlines and Passengers Face More Disruption Over Boeing Plane
abstract: The airline has grounded 20 percent of its fleet and canceled hundreds of flights until the 737 Max 9 can undergo safety inspections.
lead_paragraph: For Alaska Airlines and its passengers, a return to normal may take a while.

headline: Cockpit Recording’s Erasure Hampers Boeing 737 Max 9 Investigation
abstract: Cockpit voice recorders in the U.S. start rerecording every two hours, a limit that the National Transportation Safety Board says should be extended to 25 hours.
lead_paragraph: Officials investigating why a panel on a Boeing 737 Max 9 blew open during an Alaska Airlines flight last week say they are struggling to piece together exactly what happened because the plane’s cockpit voice recorder overwrote itself before it could be retrieved.

headline: Newsom Seeks to Close $37.9 Billion Deficit by Cutting Spending and Using Reserves
abstract: California is among several states tightening their belts in the post-pandemic economy.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced on Wednesday that California had a $37.9 billion budget deficit and asked state lawmakers to cover the shortfall by trimming spending and drawing down reserves in an election year.

headline: Chris Christie Goes Down Swinging at Trump and Pleading With His Party
abstract: As he ended his presidential campaign, Mr. Christie became the latest member of the Republican old guard to deliver a dark warning about the danger of Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie closed out his second presidential campaign much as he began it, with a blistering and personal takedown of Donald J. Trump designed to prompt a reckoning in his party.

headline: 60-Foot Tunnel Under Synagogue Left 2 Buildings Unstable, Officials Say
abstract: The tunnel, beneath the headquarters of the Chabad-Lubavitcher movement in Brooklyn, prompted a confrontation that led to several arrests this week.
lead_paragraph: An illegal tunnel beneath one of the most important religious sites in New York City was about 60 feet long and 8 feet across and was not sufficiently reinforced, compromising the stability of parts of two buildings, city officials said Wednesday.

headline: The Effects of a Tough Workout
abstract: Damon Gulczynski pulls a bait and switch on us.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: DeSantis and Haley Clash Over Military Aid to Ukraine
abstract: Nikki Haley said U.S. aid to Ukraine was essential to preventing a broader conflict, while Ron DeSantis said he didn’t want the U.S. to be dragged into a war with no clear end.
lead_paragraph: After about 30 minutes of debate featuring repeated promotions of campaign websites and dozens of permutations of the word “lie,” Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and Nikki Haley diverged on actual policy: the war in Ukraine.

headline: Haley Hits DeSantis on Disney: Government Shouldn’t ‘Bully’ Companies
abstract: The former South Carolina governor cast the Florida governor as anti-business.
lead_paragraph: It was a feud that cost Florida 2,000 jobs under Gov. Ron DeSantis. And Nikki Haley pounced.

headline: Trump Suggests He’s Decided on a Vice President: ‘I Know Who It’s Going to Be’
abstract: The former president, at a town hall on Fox News on Wednesday, suggested he has made up his mind on a running mate, but then he declined to provide details.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, the front-runner in the Republican presidential primary, said on Wednesday that he knew who he would choose to be his running mate.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Houthi attacks in the Red Sea.
lead_paragraph: U.S. and British warships intercepted 21 drones and missiles fired on Tuesday from areas of Yemen controlled by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia, officials said. The U.S. and its allies are now weighing how to shut down other attacks against commercial ships in the Red Sea.

headline: Haley and DeSantis Call Each Other Liars
abstract: Several times during the debate, Nikki Haley referred the audience to a website called DeSantisLies.com, while Ron DeSantis compared her to Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Several times during the debate, Nikki Haley referred the audience to a website called DeSantisLies.com, while Ron DeSantis compared her to Democrats.

headline: Google Cuts Hundreds of Jobs in Engineering and Other Divisions
abstract: The company, which has been working to trim expenses, laid off employees who worked on core engineering, the Google Assistant product and hardware such as the Pixel phone.
lead_paragraph: Google laid off hundreds of workers in several divisions Wednesday night, seeking to lower expenses as it focuses on artificial intelligence and joining a wave of other companies cutting tech jobs this year.

headline: ‘I’m Not Going to Have Time for Retribution,’ Trump Says at Town Hall
abstract: The town hall on Fox News was the former president’s counterprogramming as Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis debated on CNN.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, who for months has expressed openness to retaliating against his political enemies if he returns to the White House and has vowed to have federal prosecutors investigate them, downplayed his interest in pursuing retribution at a televised town hall on Wednesday.

headline: Haley and DeSantis Go After Trump
abstract: Ron DeSantis said that if Donald J. Trump were the Republican nominee, it would give Democrats the upper hand, while Nikki Haley called for bringing “sanity back to America.”
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis said that if Donald J. Trump were the Republican nominee, it would give Democrats the upper hand, while Nikki Haley called for bringing “sanity back to America.”

headline: 5 Takeaways From the Haley-DeSantis Debate and Trump’s Town Hall
abstract: Trading attacks at a rapid clip, Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis largely ignored the existence of the Republican front-runner, who basked in his solo event before a friendly crowd.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis traded attacks on a debate stage on Wednesday night as Donald J. Trump basked in the applause of a friendly audience on a different television network, dueling appearances that showcased how the Republican primary race increasingly feels like a contest for second place.

headline: Who Won the Debate? Haley Struggled to Outshine DeSantis, Analysts Say
abstract: The fifth Republican presidential debate featured just two candidates and grew testy. But analysts saw little that would change the race ahead of Monday’s caucuses.
lead_paragraph: With the Iowa caucuses days away, two of the remaining Republican presidential candidates — Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley — clashed on the debate stage on Wednesday night over the economy, foreign policy and their records in their states, Florida and South Carolina.

headline: Chris Christie, We Miss You!
abstract: Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis summon the right fury for the wrong target.
lead_paragraph: I wish Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis had shown a quarter as much contempt for Donald Trump as they did for each other.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A TV Drama Finally Forces Action on Britain’s Post Office Scandal
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 11, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Everyone likes an underdog, and we had underdogs in spades.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 11, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the Federal Aviation Administration’s decision to delay safety inspections of Boeing’s 737 Max 9 referred incorrectly to the feedback that prompted a revision of inspection instructions for the airliners. The F.A.A. said the changes were based on feedback the manufacturer had received, but it did not say that the feedback came from the agency.

headline: Word of the Day: obfuscation
abstract: This word has appeared in 36 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word obfuscation has appeared in 36 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 25 in “Everybody Knows Flo From Progressive. Who Is Stephanie Courtney?” by Caity Weaver:

headline: Stephen Colbert Prays That Trump Can Deliver
abstract: “That is a terrible idea, and please, Jesus, let it happen,” Colbert said of the former president’s initial desire to deliver his own closing argument in his fraud trial.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Rare North Atlantic Right Whale Calf Is Expected to Die From Injuries
abstract: Efforts to reduce boat speed limits near the habitat of the critically endangered species have been unsuccessful, with fewer than 360 of the whales remaining.
lead_paragraph: A rare North Atlantic right whale calf spotted off the coast of South Carolina is expected to die after its head, mouth and lips were split open, likely by a boat propeller, officials said.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Subway Delayed Again? Might Be Caused by a Brake Prank.
abstract: Each year, hundreds of subway riders pull the emergency brake for no good reason. Last week, that kind of vandalism led to a derailment that injured dozens.
lead_paragraph: The collision between two subway trains that injured dozens of people in Manhattan last week began with what has become a routine problem in New York City’s mass transit system — pranksters pulling emergency brakes.

headline: Civil Conversation
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: The Quest to Unlock New Haven’s Pizza Moment
abstract: This was, by far, one of the most delicious stories I ever reported. And I used to be a food reporter.
lead_paragraph: New Haveners and Yale graduates alike size one another up with a handshake and a single question: What’s your favorite pizza place?

headline: Trump’s Fraud Trial Draws to an End With Closing Arguments
abstract: The former president unexpectedly spoke in his own defense, directly attacking New York’s attorney general and the judge overseeing the case.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial concluded on Thursday much as it unfolded over the past three months: in chaos, with the former president insulting the judge to his face, lashing out at the New York attorney general who brought the case and declaring himself “an innocent man.”

headline: Common Credits Ralph Ellison for Pointing Him Toward Music
abstract: “Invisible Man” “made me feel seen and heard,” the rapper-actor says. “I can return the favor.” His new book, “And Then We Rise: A Guide to Loving and Taking Care of Self” is out this month.
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Clown Cardio Doesn’t Take Exercise Seriously
abstract: Fitness and improv unite to form one wacky workout in — where else? — Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Whenever Alex Lee mentions Clown Cardio, he is met with some confusion.

headline: Sweetie, I’ll Be Back at 2 A.M.
abstract: Some parents, anxious about their child staying in someone else’s home, are choosing “sleepunders” — picking kids up just before bedtime — or even staying over with them.
lead_paragraph: Brianna Michaud’s ’90s childhood was filled with sleepovers at friends’ houses. Her mother sometimes came inside the house and chatted with the parents for a few minutes, but sensitive topics like bodily autonomy, gun safety or technology use — except for the rule that she not watch anything rated PG-13 or higher — weren’t the kinds of things discussed.

headline: Can Dieting Actually Lead to Long-Term Weight Loss?
abstract: We asked experts to explain what diets can (and can’t) do for our health.
lead_paragraph: Dieting has long been viewed as the path to smaller bodies and better health. Stick to the right diet, the $75 billion U.S. weight loss industry may have you think, and you, too, can lose weight and keep it off.

headline: ‘The Book of Clarence’ Review: Messiahs Wherever You Look
abstract: LaKeith Stanfield leads a predominantly Black cast in a retelling of the story of Jesus that’s both irreverent and devoted.
lead_paragraph: The subject of a Jesus movie is technically Jesus. But every movie based on the biblical account of Jesus — and there are many such movies, stretching back to 1898 — says at least as much about the people who made it as it does about the man himself.

headline: ‘Apolonia, Apolonia’ Review: A Whole Life in Art
abstract: The painter Apolonia Sokol is the ostensible subject of a wide-ranging documentary about life itself.
lead_paragraph: “For as long as I can remember, I’ve seen the world through my camera,” a woman’s voice says in the early moments of “Apolonia, Apolonia.” Onscreen, we’re watching — presumably through that same camera — a young woman, strong features, entrancing smile, dark circles under her eyes, bearing the expression of a person who’s not afraid of the lens one bit. “But no motif,” the voice continues, “has caught my eye as she did.”

headline: ‘Inshallah a Boy’ Review: Where the Male Line Is the Only Line
abstract: In this film by Amjad Al Rasheed, a young widow in Jordan strains against the tradition, underpinned by law, that without a man she is nothing.
lead_paragraph: Before things take an unjust turn in Amjad Al Rasheed’s tense and accomplished directorial debut, “Inshallah a Boy,” a wife and husband lie in bed discussing the timing to conceive a second child. There is something sweet in the exhaustion of the husband, Adnan (Mohammad Suleiman), and surprising in his admission to his wife, Nawal (Mouna Hawa), that he’s the cause of their fertility issues. This promising exchange will be their last.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the ‘Frosty Slaw Man Salad’ Recipe
abstract: Should a 1960s mayo-gelatin-cottage-cheese-cabbage creature be revived?
lead_paragraph: Ryley writes: My future mother-in-law, Maria, recently discovered the “Frosty Slaw Man Salad,” a recipe from a 1960s mayonnaise marketing campaign. It’s a mayo-gelatin-cottage-cheese-cabbage concoction in the shape of a demonic snowman. She is determined to make it! Her husband, Daniel, is vehemently opposed. Who is right?

headline: Will Chatbots Teach Your Children?
abstract: New A.I. tools could enable a Silicon Valley dream: bots that customize learning for pupils. Prior attempts have not lived up to the hype.
lead_paragraph: Sal Khan, the chief executive of Khan Academy, gave a rousing TED Talk last spring in which he predicted that A.I. chatbots would soon revolutionize education.

headline: Fresh Inflation Data Shows Intact, but Bumpy, Cool-Down
abstract: Inflation remains faster than usual — and month-to-month bumps are still likely as volatile prices fluctuate — but it is making progress back toward a normal pace.
lead_paragraph: Consumer price data released Thursday showed Federal Reserve officials, the White House and American households that inflation continued to slow at the end of 2023, capping a year in which the price increases bedeviling families and policymakers cooled in earnest.

headline: Elton John’s First Auction in 21 Years Has It All: Boots to Banksy.
