abstract: The 900 items from his Atlanta home include blue-chip art by Julian Schnabel and Richard Avedon, Versace dinnerware and flamboyant costumes.
lead_paragraph: Elton John is downsizing — and the superstar’s former penthouse residence in Atlanta has been emptied for a series of auctions at Christie’s starting on Feb. 21. The items are expected to bring in an estimated $10 million.

headline: State Legislators, Wary of Deceptive Election Ads, Tighten A.I. Rules
abstract: Sophisticated political deepfakes have warped elections overseas. Can U.S. legislators act fast enough to make A.I. campaign ads more transparent?
lead_paragraph: When experts in artificial intelligence recently showed a gathering of state legislators a deepfake image that had been generated by A.I. in early 2022, depicting former presidents Donald J. Trump and Barack Obama playing one-on-one basketball, the crowd chuckled at how rudimentary it was.

headline: When You Return Those Pants, There’s a Price You Don’t See
abstract: The next stop for online purchases that are sent back may be the dump.
lead_paragraph: January is a time to redo, revise and recommit. It is also the time to return things.

headline: Inflation Is Moderating, but Pressure Remains on Biden
abstract: Voters have taken a downbeat view of the economy because costs have remained stubbornly high.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has yet to benefit from moderating inflation, and data set for release on Thursday could complicate the White House’s attempts to show progress on rising prices.

headline: Does Learning to Be a Good Writer Still Matter in the Age of A.I.?
abstract: A New York Times columnist worries that programs like ChatGPT threaten the future of writing — and the benefits and joys of excelling at it. Do you agree?
lead_paragraph: Are you a good writer? Do you enjoy the craft?

headline: Andy Reid, the All-Time-Great Chiefs Coach, Makes Football Fun
abstract: His diligence and sense of mischief have made him one of the game’s best-ever coaches.
lead_paragraph: Andy Reid, the coach of the Kansas City Chiefs, has won more than 250 games in his career, fourth all-time, which puts him high on any list of the N.F.L.’s greatest coaches. Most of the others in that pantheon are men who personify the sport’s militaristic soul — Vince Lombardi, for example, the fabled coach of the 1960s-era Green Bay Packers, or Reid’s contemporary, the grim Bill Belichick of the New England Patriots. But Reid is no Lombardi or Belichick; he’s Steve Jobs. He’s a designer, a tinkerer, a product engineer who imbues his football with creativity and even an occasional touch of whimsy.

headline: Six Degrees of Self-Help, Nora Ephron and ‘Mommie Dearest’
abstract: Fifty years ago this week, “How to Be Your Own Best Friend” nipped at the heels of “The Joy of Sex.” Here’s the story behind its longevity.
lead_paragraph: “How do people get to be the insecure, weak, self-deprecating wretches to whom this book is addressed?” Harry Schwartz wrote in his Times review of “How to Be Your Own Best Friend,” a self-help book that celebrated its 26th week as a best seller 50 years ago this week.

headline: Is What’s Good for Taylor Tomlinson’s Career Bad for Her Life?
abstract: The stand-up has a new TV gig and a spot on the list of top-grossing comedy tours. Still, “there sometimes feels like there isn’t anyone my age to talk to.”
lead_paragraph: In September, the night before the comic Taylor Tomlinson made her Radio City Music Hall debut, she called one of her three siblings in tears, asking: “Why do I feel like it’s not enough?”

headline: Will You Vote for Trump Again?
abstract: It’s the question weighing on Republicans across the country. But Iowans get to decide first. We listened as they grappled with their choices.
lead_paragraph: There is no way around it: The Iowa caucuses on Monday, the kickoff of the 2024 presidential election, are not really about competing visions for the future of the Republican Party. They are not a battle between dueling ideologies or policy priorities or America’s role in the world.

headline: I Have Covid. Should I Take Paxlovid?
abstract: We asked experts about who should take the antiviral medication, how well it works and where to get it for free.
lead_paragraph: As hospitalizations and deaths from Covid-19 rise, fueled by a fast-moving new variant that now accounts for a majority of U.S. cases, Paxlovid can help protect patients from some of the worst outcomes of the illness.

headline: How a Congressman Wants to Honor Roberto Clemente
abstract: The right fielder for the Pittsburgh Pirates deserves to be commemorated with a coin, Representative Adriano Espaillat says.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out why a congressman from the Bronx is pressing for a coin to commemorate a baseball player from the Pittsburgh Pirates. We’ll also see what to expect as Donald Trump’s civil fraud trial moves into its final phase.

headline: For the Sake of College Athletes Everywhere, Jim Harbaugh Should Remain at Michigan
abstract: Let’s hope this stubborn, delightful man stays where he is.
lead_paragraph: Some 25 million Americans watched with heavenly joy (or as the case may be, in Ohio, infernal dread) as the Michigan Wolverines defeated the Washington Huskies in the college football national championship on Monday. This was Michigan’s first national title since 1997, and only its second since 1948.

headline: Seeing Isamu Noguchi Through Someone Else’s Eyes
abstract: Marie Menken’s film ‘‘Visual Variations on Noguchi,’’ shot nearly 80 years ago in the sculptor’s Greenwich Village atelier, has never shown at his namesake museum — until now.
lead_paragraph: One of the more revolutionary works of art on display in New York right now is a four-minute-long film nearly 80 years old. Called “Visual Variations on Noguchi,” it was shot in Isamu Noguchi’s Greenwich Village studio sometime in 1945 or ’46. Wielding the camera was Marie Menken, a Brooklyn-born daughter of Lithuanian immigrants who had, until this studio visit, chiefly been a painter.

headline: Scientists Scramble to Keep Dog Aging Project Alive
abstract: The National Institute on Aging may let funding lapse for a yearslong study of nearly 50,000 pet dogs, which could also offer insight into human health.
lead_paragraph: In late 2019, scientists began searching for 10,000 Americans willing to enroll their pets in an ambitious new study of health and longevity in dogs. The researchers planned to track the dogs over the course of their lives, collecting detailed information about their bodies, lifestyles and home environments. Over time, the scientists hoped to identify the biological and environmental factors that kept some dogs healthy in their golden years — and uncover insights about aging that could help both dogs and humans lead longer, healthier lives.

headline: The Case for Trump … by Someone Who Wants Him to Lose
abstract: You can’t defeat an opponent if you refuse to understand what makes him formidable.
lead_paragraph: Barring a political miracle or an act of God, it is overwhelmingly likely that Donald Trump will again be the Republican Party’s nominee for president. Assuming the Democratic nominee in the fall is Joe Biden, polls show Trump with a better-than-even chance of returning to the White House next year.

headline: After Years in Washington, a Couple Found More Value in Baltimore. What Could They Afford?
abstract: Figuring they would need to retire and sell their business before they could afford a new home in the D.C. area, two empty nesters pulled up stakes and tried a place with ‘more bang for your buck.’
lead_paragraph: Figuring they would need to retire and sell their business before they could afford a new home in the D.C. area, two empty nesters pulled up stakes and tried a place with ‘more bang for your buck.’

headline: A Frugal Opera Superfan’s Surprise Gift: $1.7 Million for the Arts
abstract: Lois Kirschenbaum, who died in 2021, made the donations to cultural groups from unexpectedly large life savings.
lead_paragraph: When Lois Kirschenbaum, a cultural aficionado who was a fixture in the standing room section of the Metropolitan Opera for more than half a century, died in 2021 at 88, star singers gave tributes and fellow fans offered remembrances.

headline: A Clash of Civilizations Brought to Life
abstract: For Álvaro Enrigue, a novelist fascinated with historical detail, the first meeting of the Aztecs and Spanish conquistadors is the obsession of a lifetime. He brings it to life in “You Dreamed of Empires.”
lead_paragraph: The Aug. 13, 2021 edition of The New York Times failed to mention the 500th anniversary of the fall of Tenochtitlan, the erstwhile Aztec capital out of which Mexico City was born. Álvaro Enrigue noticed. Of course.

headline: The Winner of Last Night’s Debate ‘Owned the Stage’
abstract: Opinion columnists and contributors assess the candidates in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Opinion columnists and contributors assess the candidates in Iowa.

headline: Christie’s Exit Should Give Haley a Chance in New Hampshire. Will It Be Enough?
abstract: A group of moderate voters is now available, but it may not put her over the top against Trump.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, Chris Christie gave Donald J. Trump the biggest political assist of the 2016 campaign.

headline: ‘Frozen Garlic!’ Taiwan Likes Its Democracy Loud and Proud
abstract: At the island’s election rallies, warming up the crowd for candidates is crucial. “You have to light a fire in their hearts,” one host says.
lead_paragraph: Huang Chen-yu strode onto an outdoor stage in a southern Taiwanese county, whooping and hollering as she roused the crowd of 20,000 into a joyous frenzy — to welcome a succession of politicians in matching jackets.

headline: With Chris Christie Out, Nikki Haley Is Poised to Benefit in New Hampshire
abstract: Ms. Haley has cut into former President Donald J. Trump’s lead in the state where Mr. Christie had spent significant time wooing voters opposed to Mr. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The former New Jersey governor Chris Christie’s decision on Wednesday to drop out of the presidential race shook up a contest for the Republican nomination that had appeared to be former President Donald J. Trump’s for the taking, giving a huge shot of adrenaline to Nikki Haley just five days before ballots begin to be cast in the monthslong nomination fight.

headline: Peacock Enters Uncharted Waters by Streaming N.F.L. Playoff Game
abstract: The game, between the Kansas City Chiefs and Miami Dolphins, is the biggest test yet for whether live sports will find a comfortable home on streaming services.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, NBCUniversal will make media history. For the first time, a National Football League playoff game — this one featuring the Kansas City Chiefs and the Miami Dolphins — will appear exclusively on a streaming service.

headline: What Does a Hard-Boiled Detective Do in Retirement?
abstract: In “Monsieur Spade,” a new AMC show, Clive Owen plays the inscrutable Sam Spade, attempting to put his past behind him in the South of France.
lead_paragraph: In an early scene in “Monsieur Spade,” a new six-part series from AMC, the American detective Sam Spade, played by Clive Owen, is lying on his side, grimacing as a doctor examines his nether regions. “Best prostate of the morning,” the doctor says cheerfully, snapping off his rubber gloves. Then he motions Spade to his office to tell him he has emphysema and must stop smoking.

headline: The Parade of Unsettled Weather Will Continue Into the Weekend
abstract: Severe weather will again sweep the South, while blizzard conditions are forecast to hit the Midwest starting Friday. Some cities will see subzero temperatures through the long weekend.
lead_paragraph: There has been a pretty remarkable parade of intense storm systems this past week, Greg Carbin, the branch chief of forecast operations for the National Weather Service, said on Wednesday. And it isn’t over.

headline: Food Delivery Workers, Overlooked in Life, Are Honored in Death
abstract: A Facebook page chronicles the deaths of dozens of bike-riding workers who delivered food in New York City, lionizing them as fallen heroes.
lead_paragraph: After the brass band packed up its instruments, Sergio Solano and two other food delivery workers walked a white bicycle to an overpass within view of the United Nations headquarters.

headline: The Threat of a Wider War in the Middle East
abstract: A string of attacks have heightened fears that the war in Gaza could become a regional conflict.
lead_paragraph: A recent string of attacks across the Middle East has raised concerns that the war between Hamas and Israel is spreading, and might put pressure on other countries like Iran and the United States to get more involved.

headline: Blinken Meets With el-Sisi in Egypt to Discuss Plight of Palestinians in Gaza
abstract: The U.S. secretary of state also planned to talk about how to prevent the violence in the Mideast from escalating further, as Iran-backed militias ramp up attacks.
lead_paragraph: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met on Thursday with President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt in Cairo to discuss the dire situation of Palestinian civilians in the Israel-Hamas war and what will happen in Gaza when the conflict ends.

headline: Republican Debate Takeaways, and Hunter Biden on Capitol Hill
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Inspections, Bottlenecks and Safety Concerns Hinder Gaza Aid
abstract: Obstacles at two border crossings are exacerbating a growing humanitarian crisis, according to two U.S. senators and officials with the U.N. and other groups.
lead_paragraph: The trucks carrying aid for Gaza stop for exhaustive inspections by Israeli authorities. They can pass through two border crossings only during limited hours. Inside the territory, vehicles travel over a landscape of rubble and ruined roads to distribute the aid to desperate, hungry crowds.

headline: Israel Adesanya, M.M.A. Star, Narrowly Avoids Drunk-Driving Conviction
abstract: Within hours, the former middleweight mixed martial arts champion risked more legal trouble by posting provocative content on social media.
lead_paragraph: Just weeks after being charged with driving under the influence in Auckland, New Zealand, last year, Israel Adesanya, a former two-time middleweight mixed martial arts champion, sought to project humility and remorse.

headline: Top Natural Gas Producers Announce Multibillion-Dollar Merger
abstract: The deal, between Chesapeake Energy and Southwestern Energy, would create one of the largest energy producers in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Chesapeake Energy and Southwestern Energy, two of the largest natural gas producers in the United States, announced plans to merge on Thursday, in an all-stock deal worth $7.4 billion. The new company would become one of the largest energy producers in the United States, with a significant presence in Louisiana and Texas.

headline: Crime on the Decline
abstract: Murders likely fell at record speed last year.
lead_paragraph: In the chaotic early months of the Covid pandemic, when the U.S. was also going through the aftermath of George Floyd’s murder, violent crime rose across the country. Murders in 2020 increased at the fastest rate since national statistics began in 1960. Other crimes, like shootings and car thefts, also increased.

headline: ‘Driving Madeleine’ Review: A Nonagenarian in Paris
abstract: The beloved French singer Line Renaud plays a woman who forms an unlikely bond with a surly cabdriver in this heart-warmer.
lead_paragraph: A prickly cabdriver gains perspective thanks to a chatty nonagenarian.

headline: ‘Household Saints’: Miracles on Mulberry Street
abstract: Nancy Savoca’s 1993 film, a mystical, multigenerational Italian American family saga, opens for a revival run at IFC Center.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Savoca’s 1993 film “Household Saints,” a warmhearted fable spiced with magic realism and zesty performances, may be the most endearing of multigenerational Italian American family sagas and is likely the most mystical. Heavy on folk belief, it flirts with Bresson’s “Diary of a Country Priest” and the divine madness the Greeks called theia mania.

headline: Papua New Guinea Leader Declares State of Emergency After Violent Riots
abstract: There were signs the authorities had regained some control, but the extent of damage and casualties from the unrest remained unclear.
lead_paragraph: The prime minister of Papua New Guinea on Thursday declared a two-week state of emergency in the capital, Port Moresby, and suspended the Pacific island nation’s chief of police after violent protests left the city shellshocked.

headline: Judge in Trump’s Civil Fraud Trial Is Swatted at His Home
abstract: Authorities responded to a fake bomb threat at the home of Justice Arthur F. Engoron on the day he was set to hear closing arguments in New York’s suit against Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Nassau County authorities on Thursday responded to a hoax bomb threat at the house of the judge presiding over the civil fraud trial of Donald J. Trump.

headline: Bitcoin Heads to Wall Street. Now What?
abstract: A new kind of exchange-traded fund linked to the cryptocurrency could begin trading as soon as Thursday, and the investment world is buzzing.
lead_paragraph: A new era of crypto trading is expected to begin as soon as today, after the S.E.C. finally approved the creation of new exchange-traded funds that would allow investors to more easily buy and sell Bitcoin.

headline: How Much Space Do You Get for $1,700 a Month?
abstract: The average national rent affords a wildly varied amount of space from city to city.
lead_paragraph: The past year gave many house hunters a sobering realization: For now, they remain among the ranks of renters. While 2023 also came with a slight easing of competition among renters and somewhat lower rents, the market remains tight.

headline: The End of the Bill Belichick Hoodie Era
abstract: The Patriots coach is out. And so is his trademark sweatshirt.
lead_paragraph: In all the words currently being written about the end of the Bill Belichick era in Boston — or, technically, the Boston suburbs — which reportedly finally came to a close on Jan. 11 after weeks of speculation, the end of the N.F.L. season and the Patriots’ dismal loss to the Jets, the one that sticks in my mind is “hoodie.”

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, on the Lower East Side and in Greenpoint.
lead_paragraph: A roughly 450-square-foot co-op studio with an updated kitchen, a breakfast bar, a sleeping alcove, overhead storage and 10-foot ceilings, on the eighth floor of a 16-story doorman building from 1890 that has basement storage cages, a live-in super, a bike room, shared laundry, a courtyard and a roof deck. Lily Wong, Brown Harris Stevens, 917-312-3892; bhsusa.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and Greenwich, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, six-and-a-half-bath, 4,990-square-foot house built in 1925, with a covered entryway; a formal living room with a fireplace and deck access; an expansive eat-in kitchen with marble countertops, built-ins, original exposed brick and a butler’s pantry; an en suite primary bedroom with west-facing windows, chair rail molding and a walk-in closet; a walk-out lower-level workshop and office with a private entrance and driveway, full bath and mudroom that leads outside to the in-ground pool; on 0.93 acres surrounded by the Ardsley Country Club golf course. William Ford-Sussman, Coldwell Banker Realty, 914-420-6161, coldwellbankerhomes.com

headline: What You’re Looking Forward to in 2024
abstract: Graduating from Harvard, trips abroad, a 75th birthday and more.
lead_paragraph: January is a month for feeling hopeful. The year is new and offering us all a chance to re-evaluate and reset.

headline: Finland Extends Closure of Border With Russia
abstract: Late last year, Finland accused Moscow of facilitating an influx of migrants and shut its land border crossings with Russia.
lead_paragraph: Finland said on Thursday that it would keep its eastern border with Russia closed for another month amid an ongoing dispute about increased numbers of migrants in the area.

headline: Iranian Navy Says It Seized an Oil Tanker Off the Coast of Oman
abstract: The same vessel was involved last year in the U.S. government seizure of Iranian oil that was being transported in violation of American sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s navy said it had seized a tanker loaded with crude oil off the coast of Oman on Thursday, apparently in retaliation for the United States confiscating oil from the same ship last year.

headline: U.S. Military Aid to Ukraine Was Poorly Tracked, Pentagon Report Says
abstract: The report found that American officials and diplomats had failed to quickly or fully account for all of the nearly 40,000 weapons sent to the front.
lead_paragraph: More than $1 billion worth of shoulder-fired missiles, kamikaze drones and night-vision goggles that the United States has sent to Ukraine have not been properly tracked by American officials, a new Pentagon report concluded, raising concerns that they could be stolen or smuggled at a time when Congress is debating whether to send more military aid to Kyiv.

headline: Bottled Water Is Full of Plastic Particles. Can They Harm Your Health?
abstract: Here’s what scientists know so far about the health effects of nanoplastics, and what you can do to reduce your exposure.
lead_paragraph: A liter of bottled water contains nearly a quarter of a million pieces of nanoplastic on average, according to new research published this week in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

headline: ‘Mean Girls’ Review: ‘Get in, Loser,’ Regina George Is Back
abstract: Still puffily padded but no longer particularly tart, this shape-shifting classic about the girls you love to hate retains its ingratiating charms.
lead_paragraph: Can a movie musical based on a Broadway musical based on a film comedy that in turn was based on a parenting book be any good? Sure — if only because the writer-producer Tina Fey and the producer Lorne Michaels have made sure that little has changed in their money-printing property since the first movie hit theaters in 2004. Few stories, it turns out, are as comically and horrifyingly reliable as those set in high school; few villains are as dependably hissable as a desirable young woman with an ostensibly cold heart.

headline: Secretary Austin Should Resign
abstract: The issue here is maintaining standards, not passing judgment.
lead_paragraph: I have great respect for Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin. He has served the United States honorably and heroically for decades. He earned a Silver Star during the invasion of Iraq in 2003. He commanded American forces during the successful counteroffensive against ISIS. He has done his job admirably, helping shepherd the United States through two of the most dangerous international military crises in decades. Nonetheless, he should resign or, failing that, be fired.

headline: As Utility Bills Rise, Low-Income Americans Struggle for Access to Clean Energy
abstract: The Biden administration has deployed various programs to try to increase access to clean energy. But systems that could help lower bills are still out of reach for many low-income households.
lead_paragraph: Cindy Camp is one of many Americans facing rising utility costs. Ms. Camp, who lives in Baltimore with three family members, said her gas and electric bills kept “going up and up” — reaching as high as $900 a month. Her family has tried to use less hot water by doing fewer loads of laundry, and she now eats more fast food to save on grocery bills.

headline: How a Former N.F.L. Player Started Designing Sculptural Furniture
abstract: Plus: hand-painted sweatpants, a chef’s hotel in Seattle and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Michael Bennett, the former N.F.L. player, started designing furniture as a way to reconsider architecture and the spaces that Black people occupy. Inspired by his upbringing in Louisiana and Texas, as well as by trips to Senegal, where his ancestors are from, Bennett began to think about the objects that “bring Black people together in public spaces” as a way to deepen his longtime activism work focused on racial justice. After retiring from football in 2020, he founded the design practice Studio Kër. Bennett’s exploration of the Black home led him to create an 11-piece collection of sculptural furniture that he’s debuting this month in “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib,” his inaugural exhibition for the Los Angeles art gallery Marta, presented at Theaster Gates’s Rebuild Foundation in Chicago. (In the spring, the show will travel to Houston.) The collection reimagines objects of communal gatherings; pieces include the Gumbo lounge chair, a lush take on the stackable monobloc chair, and the Pew couch, a nod to the church bench, made of leather and ekki wood. “For me, the show is about celebrating Black ingenuity and connecting back to that African diasporic design language,” says Bennett. “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib” is on view from Jan. 12 through Feb. 10, marta.la.

headline: Man Reaches $25 Million Settlement After 44 Years of Wrongful Imprisonment
abstract: The city of Concord, N.C., acknowledged that “significant errors in judgment and willful misconduct” led to the wrongful conviction of Ronnie Long, 68, on rape and burglary charges.
lead_paragraph: A man who spent 44 years in prison after a jury in North Carolina wrongfully convicted him of raping a woman in 1976 has settled a lawsuit against state and local law enforcement officials for $25 million.

headline: Kim Reynolds Has Another Account, @Kimberl26890376, and Opinions About Donald Trump
abstract: In recent months, the Republican governor of Iowa has used a secondary account on X to share her unfiltered feelings on the Republican presidential primary race.
lead_paragraph: Not long after the calendar turned to 2024, Kim Reynolds, the Republican governor of Iowa, signed into X, the platform formerly known as Twitter, and posted about the presidential primary, where she has emerged as a key backer of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida over former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: On ‘Orquídeas,’ Kali Uchis Gets All She Wants
abstract: The fourth album by the Colombian American songwriter makes bliss triumphant.
lead_paragraph: Kali Uchis basks in pleasure on her fourth studio album, “Orquídeas.” Make that pleasures: carnal, material, romantic, sonic, competitive and, if necessary, vengeful, all with a girlish nonchalance. The album begins with loops of laughter and ethereal oohs and ahs; it ends with Uchis thanking listeners with a “mwah” kiss. It’s an album of breezy confidence and sly ingenuity, easily moving among futuristic electronics, 1990s nostalgia and Latin roots.

headline: Indiana University Cancels Major Exhibition of Palestinian Artist
abstract: Samia Halaby, an 87-year-old artist, has been outspoken in her support of Palestinians during the Israel-Gaza war.
lead_paragraph: The first American retrospective of Samia Halaby, regarded as one of the most important living Palestinian artists, was abruptly canceled by officials at Indiana University in recent weeks.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Regulating Inventions
abstract: Congress has tended to be slow to respond to revolutionary technologies. How long do you think it will take to regulate artificial intelligence?
lead_paragraph: This graph was previously published in The New York Times, five months after President Biden announced the voluntary commitments by seven of the major A.I. companies to standards of safety, security and trust to manage the risks associated with this emerging technology. Currently, there is no agreement on enforceable regulations for A.I. companies or A.I.-generated materials.

headline: A Use-What-You-Have Frittata That Won’t End Up a Mess
abstract: Sohla El-Waylly’s cheesy frittata recipe is as foolproof as it is versatile.
lead_paragraph: As Emily Weinstein says in this week’s Five Weeknight Dishes newsletter — you are subscribed to Five Weeknight Dishes, yes? — a dish like a frittata, that clean-out-the-fridge standard, walks a fine line between delicious and disaster. This new cheesy frittata recipe from Sohla El-Waylly, however, keeps you safely on the stellar side of things, since it comes with a video of Sohla walking you through every step. (She also explains the differences between all those terms on egg cartons and has more kitchen tips to share: 11, to be exact.) The recipe is clear, informative and friendly — everything you’d expect from a series called Cooking 101.

headline: Scaly Fossil Is the Oldest-Known Piece of Skin
abstract: The specimen came from a 289 million-year-old fossil deposit and might offer clues to how skin evolved.
lead_paragraph: Dry, scaly skin may be one of the least fun parts of winter. But in the broad scheme of things, a tough, watertight hide is part of what enabled the ancestors of modern reptiles, birds and mammals to move inland while their thin-skinned amphibian cousins remained close to water.

headline: New Origin Story for Tyrannosaurus Rex Suggested by Fossil
abstract: Researchers say the species they named Tyrannosaurus mcraeensis predated the dinosaur era’s great predator.
lead_paragraph: A team of researchers have announced the discovery of a new species of Tyrannosaurus from New Mexico, one that appeared in the fossil record five million to seven million years before the familiar tyrant lizard. Their research, published Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, suggests a new chapter could be added to the origin story of Tyrannosaurus rex.

headline: How Belichick Helped Patriots Go From Laughingstock to Economic Powerhouse
abstract: For most of its existence, New England was a terrible team. But a two-decade run of success turned it into one of the most recognizable sports brands in the world.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine now, after six Super Bowl titles and two decades atop the N.F.L., but for most of their existence the New England Patriots were awful.

headline: Mexican Whiskey Is on the Rise, Powered by Ancient Corn
abstract: Several distillers are using local heirloom grain and exporting to the United States, the heart of another corn-based spirit: bourbon.
lead_paragraph: Of the 59 varieties of native corn in Mexico, nal t’eel is one of the oldest, having emerged in the Yucatán Peninsula some 4,000 years ago. It grows quickly, largely unbothered by heavy rains or drought — so robust that the Mayans called it “rooster corn.”

headline: Trump Seeks Details of Atlanta Prosecutor’s Communications with Biden Aides
abstract: Nathan Wade talked to White House staff members in 2022, when he was seeking witnesses for the investigation into whether Donald J. Trump interfered in the 2020 election in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump are seeking more information about discussions Atlanta prosecutors had with the Biden White House, as well as with the House committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol.

headline: Hunter Biden Pleads Not Guilty to Tax Evasion Charges
abstract: A judge set a tentative trial date for June 20, raising the possibility that Mr. Biden could be on trial twice in the thick of the 2024 presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to charges of evading taxes on millions in income from foreign businesses, six months after the collapse of a plea deal that would have brought an end to the long-running investigation into him.

headline: Why Bill Belichick Fit In So Well, for So Long, in New England
abstract: The head coach of the Patriots, who has parted ways with the team after 24 years, won six Super Bowls with a taciturn approach that rewarded performance over potential.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to make an impression, and even harder to make history in a place as old and momentous as New England. The measuring stick is so high.

headline: What Happens When There Is No Food: Experts Say Severe Malnutrition Could Set in Swiftly in Gaza
abstract: Nutrition experts say the progression from hunger to severe malnutrition can be rapid, especially in children.
lead_paragraph: A panel of experts affiliated with the United Nations has warned that the population of the Gaza Strip is at imminent risk of famine, with more than 90 percent of its 2.2 million people facing “acute food insecurity” and a quarter of the population experiencing “catastrophic levels of hunger.”

headline: Looming Starvation in Gaza Shows Resurgence of Civilian Sieges in Warfare
abstract: A U.N.-affiliated panel said the territory could tip into famine very soon. International laws to protect people from human-made famines offer little help.
lead_paragraph: The number of people facing possible starvation in the Gaza Strip in the coming weeks is the largest share of a population at risk of famine identified anywhere since a United Nations-affiliated panel created the current global food-insecurity assessment 20 years ago.

headline: ‘Echo’ Review: Marvel Tries to Have It Both Ways
abstract: The entertainment behemoth’s latest series for Disney+ minimizes superheroics in favor of Southwestern noir, but there’s a tug of war between its action-thriller and cultural-historical imperatives.
lead_paragraph: Maya Lopez is, in the Marvel television universe, a deaf Choctaw girl whose mother dies and whose father then moves from Oklahoma to New York City to work for a criminal kingpin (conveniently known as Kingpin). After her father also dies, Maya — embittered and alienated — is groomed for a life of crime by Kingpin and becomes a deadly underworld enforcer. Eventually, one betrayal leads to another and Maya heads back to Oklahoma and the real family that she hasn’t seen for years.

headline: Film Club: ‘Visible Mending’
abstract: What can knitting teach us about embracing life’s messy imperfections?
lead_paragraph: “Visible Mending” is a nine-minute animated film about the simple but extraordinary power of knitting and how the craft can help us heal, even at our most broken. As one older knitter says, “When your life is sort of falling apart you need to create a purpose in it for yourself. And if that purpose is quite small, it doesn’t matter. It’s important. It’s something tangible.”

headline: Bud Harrelson, Shortstop for ‘Miracle Mets’ of 1969, Dies at 79
abstract: An outstanding fielder, he helped the team win the World Series that year and reach another in 1973. He stayed with the Mets as a coach and, briefly, manager.
lead_paragraph: Bud Harrelson, the slick-fielding shortstop who helped take the Mets to their astonishing 1969 World Series championship and the 1973 National League pennant, and who remained in a Mets uniform as a coach in the 1980s and their manager in the early ’90s, died on Thursday in East Northport, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 79.

headline: Scotland, Joining England and Wales, Will Restrict Bully XL Dogs
abstract: The dogs, seen as dangerous by many, will have to be muzzled in public, neutered and microchipped, among other regulations.
lead_paragraph: Scotland will join England and Wales in strictly regulating the bully XL dog breed, after some of the dog breed owners in those two countries scrambled to send their dogs north to avoid rules already in place at home.

headline: Double-Decker Electric Bus Catches Fire in London
abstract: The London Fire Brigade reported no injuries after a red electric bus caught fire during the city’s rush hour.
lead_paragraph: The London Fire Brigade reported no injuries after a red electric bus caught fire during the city’s rush hour.

headline: F.A.A. Investigating Whether Boeing 737 Max 9 Conformed to Approved Design
abstract: Regulators are examining whether Boeing complied with safety rules on a plane that lost a fuselage panel while in flight last week.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Thursday that it had opened an investigation into whether Boeing failed to ensure that its 737 Max 9 plane was safe and manufactured to match the design approved by the agency.

headline: Donald Trump and the 14th Amendment
abstract: Responses to four columnists’ discussions about keeping the former president off the ballot. Also: Running mate choices; joy and sorrow; drug overdoses.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Self Reliance’ Review: Find a Friend, Save a Life
abstract: In this fleetingly amusing comedy, a lonely loser becomes the target of reality-show killers.
lead_paragraph: The R rating awarded to “Self Reliance” for its language only proves the heavy-handedness of our rating system, as you’ll strain to hear anything in this genially bonkers comedy that couldn’t have been written by an 11-year-old. Which is exactly the age group most likely to enjoy it.

headline: Federal Regulator Questions Carmakers About Unwanted Tracking via Their Apps
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is concerned about abusive partners using connected car apps to harass and track their victims.
lead_paragraph: Many modern cars are internet-connected and have apps that allow an owner to see a car’s location, turn it on remotely, honk its horn and even adjust the temperature. These apps for car control and tracking are designed for convenience, but a New York Times article last month detailed how they have been weaponized in abusive relationships, allowing for unwanted stalking and harassment.

headline: N.F.L. Awards Voters Hit the Tape (or YouTube Highlights)
abstract: Deciding who should be M.V.P. or make an All-Pro team means keeping up with 272 three-hour television episodes a season.
lead_paragraph: On the Sundays that Peter King is not reporting at a football stadium, he watches television from home in Brooklyn, switching between the most important afternoon game and NFL RedZone, a channel that showcases various games during their most dramatic moments.

headline: ‘The Settlers’ Review: Writing the History of Modern Chile, in Blood
abstract: This harrowing drama takes place in Tierra del Fuego, an archipelago in the southernmost part of South America, in 1901.
lead_paragraph: Not long after the Chilean film “The Settlers” opens — after the first shot has been fired and the first blood spilled — an aristocratic-looking horseman rides up to some workers on a grassy plain. Wearing a wide-brim hat and a mustache, a scarf around his neck, he settles into a spacious tent. There, seated at a desk set on a handsome rug, he summons his foreman, whom he instructs to find a route to the Atlantic for his sheep. To accomplish this, he coolly explains, “you will have to clean the island” — a grotesque, civilized euphemism for murder.

headline: Four Festival Shows Offering Soul-Enriching Experiments in Theater
abstract: Buckle up for “Open Mic Night” and “Search Party” at Under the Radar and two wildly adventurous works at the Exponential Festival.
lead_paragraph: For about two-thirds of Peter Mills Weiss and Julia Mounsey’s new show, “Open Mic Night,” Weiss alternated between reminiscing about a now-closed space and asking audience members a series of rapid-fire questions, like “Vipers or moles?” “Vacation or voting?” Mounsey was sitting behind a laptop, which she used to drop sound cues, and the blinding house lights remained on as Weiss engaged in crowd work.

headline: Israel and Hamas Are in Talks to Deliver Medicine to Hostages in Gaza
abstract: More than 120 hostages are believed to still be held in Gaza and many suffer from health conditions that require regular medical care.
lead_paragraph: Qatar is engaged in high-level discussions with Hamas to deliver vital prescription medicines to Israeli hostages in the Gaza Strip at the same time it is making progress with Israel about allowing more medicine into the enclave for Gazan civilians, officials said.

headline: Daring to Create Art Freely Behind the Iron Curtain
abstract: The Walker Art Center stages a rare survey of the courageous work that bloomed in the Eastern bloc, as artists struggled against state repression.
lead_paragraph: To say what you want, to act how you want, to live and fear no reprisals: there are some rights you can start to take for granted. Liberal democracy has been having a rough ride this century, and maybe it was inevitable, as elite institutions sputtered and populist reaction mounted, that some American artists and writers would forget just why free expression matters. Why has the recent reaction to free-speech hypocrisy and misinformation, at least in some cultural sectors, been to denigrate free speech itself? From Turkey to China and India to Zimbabwe, artists still face censorship, lawsuits, imprisonment or worse for the crime of creativity; perhaps some of us are too comfortable to take it seriously.

headline: Heiress Seeks 50 Austrians to Give Away $27 Million
abstract: Marlene Engelhorn has sent invitations to 10,000 Austrians. Once that group is narrowed to 50, it will spend six weekends this year discussing the best way to spend the money.
lead_paragraph: In the coming days, about 10,000 Austrians will find an invitation in their mailboxes from an heiress asking for their help spending 25 million euros, or about $27.4 million, of her inheritance.

headline: Send In the Beans
abstract: Swap in beans for protein-rich, vegetarian takes on classic dishes: beans Marbella, beans and greens alla vodka, and Buffalo white beans.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, I was having drinks with some friends when one of them uttered an absolutely baffling phrase: “beans alla gin with oat milk.” I laughed so hard I was moved to tears. What, pray tell, were beans alla gin with oat milk?

headline: ‘Everything Has a Time’: Cleveland’s Longest-Serving Conductor Plans His Departure
abstract: Franz Welser-Möst, the Cleveland Orchestra’s music director since 2002, is beginning to wind down his career.
lead_paragraph: One night last fall, Franz Welser-Möst, the music director of the Cleveland Orchestra, walked onto the stage of Severance Hall, crossed over to the podium and faced the audience. He was neither solemn nor particularly expressive; he just flashed a Mona Lisa smile before turning to the players and gesturing the downbeat of a Mozart symphony.

headline: In the Bronx, Trump’s Name Is Replaced at a Golf Course
abstract: The removal of the sign by the golf course’s new owner, Bally’s Corporation, was another example of Trump’s withdrawal from New York City.
lead_paragraph: As closing arguments began in President Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial in Manhattan on Thursday, his name disappeared from a golf course in the Bronx that had long welcomed drivers to the borough with a large sign reading “TRUMP LINKS.”

headline: Electric Double-Decker Bus Catches Fire During London’s Morning Rush Hour
abstract: There were no injuries, and the London Fire Brigade said it would investigate the cause of the fire on the iconic red double-decker bus.
lead_paragraph: An electric double-decker bus caught fire on Thursday in London, the authorities said, causing road closures during the morning rush hour.

headline: Inspector General to Investigate Handling of Austin’s Hospitalization
abstract: The independent review will be conducted in addition to assessments by the defense secretary’s chief of staff and the White House after top officials were not notified of the episode for days.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon’s inspector general said on Thursday that he would investigate the handling of Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III’s continuing hospitalization, which Mr. Austin and his top aides failed to disclose to President Biden and Congress for days after he developed serious complications from prostate cancer surgery.

headline: Maryland Elections Official Resigns After Arrest in Jan. 6 Attack
abstract: Carlos Ayala, a member of the Maryland State Board of Elections, was charged in the District of Columbia with civil disorder, a felony, for participating in the breach of the Capitol in 2021.
lead_paragraph: A Maryland elections board official resigned this week after he was arrested on federal charges related to his participation in the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, the authorities said.

headline: Sununu Commits to Backing Trump if He Is the G.O.P. Nominee
abstract: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire, a Trump critic who has endorsed Nikki Haley, said that if the former president won the nomination he would support him, even if convicted.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire, who has been a vocal critic of former President Donald J. Trump, nonetheless committed on Wednesday to supporting him if he won the Republican nomination, even if he were convicted of a felony.

headline: Trump Tried to Clean Up His TV Remarks. Social Media Was Another Story.
abstract: The former president presented a more restrained front on air Wednesday, but he resumed his more incendiary comments soon after.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the last year, former President Donald J. Trump’s rhetoric has been in line with his longstanding impulses. He’s aired his lies about the 2020 election, vowed to be people’s “retribution” if he wins a second term and described undocumented immigrants as “poisoning the blood of our country,” an echo of language used by fascists like Adolf Hitler.

headline: Many Laws to Protect Sharks Have Backfired, Researchers Find
abstract: A few countries have successful policies, but well-intentioned rules in others appear to have inadvertently increased demand for shark meat.
lead_paragraph: Many of the policies enacted around the world to curb the mass killing of sharks have backfired, partly because well-intentioned rules against taking the predators solely for their fins have led to an increase in demand for shark meat, according to a study published on Thursday.

headline: What to Watch This Weekend: A Powerful Australian Drama
abstract: Newly arrived to Hulu, the brisk four-part series stars Aisha Dee of “The Bold Type.”
lead_paragraph: Aisha Dee (“The Bold Type”) stars in “Safe Home,” now on Hulu, a brisk Australian miniseries about domestic violence that blends a few formats, sometimes to powerful effect.

headline: Discord Cuts 17% of Workers in Latest Tech Layoffs
abstract: In an internal memo, Discord said it had grown five times its size since 2020.
lead_paragraph: Discord, the social chat and messaging start-up beloved by gamers, told employees on Thursday that it would cut 17 percent of its staff, adding to the string of recent jobs reductions by tech firms.

headline: Grand Jury Declines to Indict Ohio Woman Who Miscarried at Home
abstract: In a case that had drawn international attention, Brittany Watts had been charged with abuse of a corpse after miscarrying and disposing of the nonviable fetus.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury in Ohio on Thursday declined to indict a woman who had miscarried a nonviable fetus at home on a felony charge of abuse of a corpse, ending a case that had drawn international scrutiny from lawyers and reproductive health advocates who had argued the charge was baseless and could endanger other patients.

headline: Fruit Stripe Gum, Famous for Short Bursts of Flavor, Is Discontinued
abstract: Its disappearance from store shelves invited nostalgic posts on social media. “Best two seconds of flavor you’ve ever had,” one person wrote on Reddit.
lead_paragraph: Fruit Stripe, the striped chewing gum known for its short burst of flavor, has been discontinued after more than a half-century, inspiring nostalgic tributes across social media.

headline: How Trump Is Connecting With Evangelical Voters
abstract: The Times’s Charles Homans reports on why Donald J. Trump is so popular among evangelical Christian voters.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Charles Homans reports on why Donald J. Trump is so popular among evangelical Christian voters.

headline: A Convicted Criminal as the Nominee? Trump’s Rivals Avoid Even Raising It
abstract: The former president’s legal jeopardy offers an obvious line of attack for Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis, but fears of voter blowback mean that cudgel remains largely unused.
lead_paragraph: It is an obvious line of attack that has been creeping into the arsenal of rivals trying to stop former President Donald J. Trump ahead of the Iowa caucuses on Monday — if nominated to be the Republican Party’s White House standard-bearer, the former president could very well be a convicted criminal by Election Day.

headline: Right Wing Pressures Johnson to Abandon Spending Deal to Avert Shutdown
abstract: Speaker Mike Johnson said he was talking with his ultraconservative colleagues about walking away from the agreement he struck with Democrats but had “made no commitments.”
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson came under mounting pressure on Thursday from House G.O.P. hard-liners to renege on the spending deal he struck with Democrats over the weekend for avoiding a government shutdown, as ultraconservatives demanded he put forward a new plan with deeper cuts.

headline: Did This Couple Inspire Edward Albee’s ‘Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf’?
abstract: A newly preserved Andy Warhol film documents a combative artist couple the playwright knew. The movie is premiering in MoMA’s To Save and Project.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton put their marital demons on film in “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” (1966). But neither they nor their director, Mike Nichols, can take credit for being the first to try to bring Edward Albee’s 1962 play to the screen, or even for being the first movie couple to draw on their own real-life discord in that context.

headline: $4 Billion of New Bitcoin Funds Change Hands in First Trading Day
abstract: The products, known as exchange-traded funds, were approved by federal regulators this week, a watershed moment for the crypto industry.
lead_paragraph: More than $4 billion of a newly approved investment product tied to Bitcoin changed hands in the first day of trading on Thursday, as cryptocurrency enthusiasts celebrated a watershed moment for the industry.

headline: Tackling Climate Change in the Birthplace of Oil
abstract: Azerbaijan is where the petroleum era began.
lead_paragraph: For the second year in a row, the United Nations climate summit known as COP will take place in a petrostate.

headline: What Students Are Saying About New Year’s Resolutions
abstract: We invited teenagers to weigh in on the practice of setting goals on Jan. 1 and then tell us what plans, if any, they have for 2024.
lead_paragraph: “What will you do — right now, this week, this month — to make a better world?” Roger Rosenblatt asks in the guest essay “This Year, Make a Resolution About Something Bigger Than Yourself.” Rather than making the self-oriented promises typical of New Year’s resolutions, he suggests turning our attention to others.

headline: Elmore Nickleberry, 92, Sanitation Worker in ’68 Memphis Strike, Dies
abstract: He was one of the last survivors of a historic walkout that demanded respect and a living wage and that drew Martin Luther King to their cause.
lead_paragraph: Elmore Nickleberry, one of the last living participants in the Memphis sanitation workers’ strike of 1968, a historic walkout that sought to win respect and equal rights for African American workers and that drew the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King to their side, died on Dec. 30 in Memphis. He was 92.

headline: The Inscrutable Glamour of Melania Trump’s Mother
abstract: In public, Amalija Knavs did not adhere to the stereotypes of an American grandmother.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the Trump presidency, Amalija Knavs — mother to first lady Melania Trump — was something of a mysterious figure. Mrs. Knavs, who died earlier this week, rarely made public comments or gave interviews. Striking and perfectly coifed, Mrs. Knavs was a recurring but almost entirely silent presence during the Trump presidency, much like her daughter.

headline: Friday Briefing: Taiwan Prepares to Vote
abstract: Also, an interview with Naomi Osaka.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan is heading to the polls tomorrow to elect a new president and legislature. The election will be watched closely by the world for how it will affect the island’s relations with China and the U.S.

headline: Airing of Trump’s Fusillade in Full Is a Reminder of His Media Advantage
abstract: The coverage was a stark reminder that the former president’s legal troubles offer an outsize media platform as he pursues the Republican nomination.
lead_paragraph: CNN, Fox News and MSNBC all carried a live news conference by Donald J. Trump on Thursday on the final day of his civil fraud trial, a stark reminder that the former president’s legal troubles offer a uniquely outsize media platform as he pursues the Republican nomination.

headline: Are You a Meatball Fanatic? Here’s Where to Go.
abstract: Maybe they should call the city “The Big Meatball.”
lead_paragraph: When my teenage sons were younger, I worked a recurring theme into the meals I cooked for them. I called it the Meatball of the Month Club. The idea is just what you’d imagine. The fun of it was in tracking down meatball recipes from different cultures in cookbooks and recipe sites, and then using them as the centerpiece for meals that introduced my family to new cuisines.

headline: Blinken Talks a Grand Vision for Mideast Peace but Hits a Wall in Israel
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken conducted marathon diplomacy around the region, but Israeli leaders, focused on war with Hamas, showed no interest in meeting demands like Palestinian statehood.
lead_paragraph: As Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken stood on the tarmac of an airport in Cairo on Thursday before flying back to the United States, he expressed confidence in the support he said he had gotten from leaders across the Middle East for a vision of postwar Gaza, eventually including a Palestinian state alongside Israel.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Can we pause a moment to appreciate the excellent work that independent and university presses consistently put out? That’s no knock on the so-called Big Five — the publishing conglomerates who dominate the industry the way the 1990s Yankees dominated baseball — but given the discrepancy in resources and depth, I’ll always nurture a soft spot for the scrappy small-market teams who hold their own. (In publishing, they don’t necessarily come from literal small markets: There are plenty of impressive indies right here in New York City.)

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): ‘Saltburn,’ Jacob Elordi and the New Heartthrob Era
abstract: Plus: Barry Keoghan’s “Murder on the Dancefloor,” Jeremy Allen White’s stripped-down moment and Nathan Fielder’s “The Curse” wraps up.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: ‘Nowhere Is Safe in Gaza’: South Africa Accuses Israel of Genocide
abstract: South Africa began laying out its case that Israel is acting with “genocidal intent” in Gaza to the International Court of Justice in The Hague.
lead_paragraph: South Africa began laying out its case that Israel is acting with “genocidal intent” in Gaza to the International Court of Justice in The Hague.

headline: Drought Touches a Quarter of Humanity, U.N. Says, Disrupting Lives Globally
abstract: The crisis, worsened partly by climate change, has been accompanied by soaring food prices and could have consequences for hunger, elections and migration worldwide.
lead_paragraph: Pandemic. War. Now drought.

headline: Field Museum Covers Some Native Displays as New Rules Take Effect
abstract: The Chicago institution’s move is in response to updated federal regulations that require museums to consult with tribes before exhibiting Native American cultural items.
lead_paragraph: The Field Museum in Chicago has covered up several display cases that feature Native American cultural items in response to new federal regulations that require museums to obtain consent from tribes before exhibiting objects connected to their heritage.

headline: Hertz Will Shrink Electric Fleet After Being Burned by Tesla’s Price Cuts
abstract: The rental car company blamed the sharp drop in the value of electric vehicles and higher repair costs for its decision to sell 20,000 cars.
lead_paragraph: The rental car company Hertz will be selling about one-third of the electric vehicles in its fleet after they lost value more quickly than expected, the company said on Thursday. The drop in value is a blow to the company’s efforts to replace gasoline vehicles with cars that do not produce tailpipe emissions.

headline: Listen: Iowa, Immunity and Living Well
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Hello audiophiles!

headline: What We Learned From Bogotá’s Buses
abstract: Transformative projects don’t conform to election cycles. They’re not the work of any single person.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I traveled to Bogotá, Colombia, which is twice the size of New York, to report on a transit system that was once the envy of cities around the world. The system, a rapid bus network called TransMilenio, rolled out in 2000. Its buses weren’t as big or as fast as trains, but they were up and running in a fraction of the time and at a vastly lower cost. Millions of residents living in far-flung, formerly disconnected slums suddenly gained access to jobs and schools.

headline: Biden Campaign to Send Top Allies to Iowa to Spread Democrats’ Message
abstract: The Hollywood mogul Jeffrey Katzenberg, Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois and Senator Tina Smith of Minnesota are expected to appear on Monday, as Republicans hold their caucuses.
lead_paragraph: Iowa is dominated by Republicans right now. The events by presidential candidates are for Republicans, the voters who come to see them are Republicans and the main event, Monday’s caucuses, will feature Republicans.

headline: Take a Look at the First Major Offshore Wind Farm to Power U.S. Homes
abstract: South Fork Wind, the first large-scale offshore wind farm to supply electricity to U.S. consumers, may have more company one day. For now, see how the construction off the coast of New York is wrapping up.
lead_paragraph: South Fork Wind, the first large-scale offshore wind farm to supply electricity to U.S. consumers, may have more company one day. For now, see how the construction off the coast of New York is wrapping up.

headline: Did Ron DeSantis Shake His Wife’s Hand?
abstract: Their businesslike grasp of hands set off chatter at Wednesday’s debate — and showed the risks of interacting with your family when you’re a presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: In a campaign full of strained social interactions and clumsy pantomimes of warmth, Ron DeSantis’s encounter with his wife at the presidential primary debate in Des Moines on Wednesday night was one of the more curious.

headline: Saban, Never Showy, Almost Always Successful, Leaves a Legacy Beyond Football
abstract: Alabama’s longtime football coach won more national championships than anyone in modern history and helped change the image of the state.
lead_paragraph: Throughout a national era of disillusionment, institutional failure and turmoil, Alabama football, of all things, has been a machine of astonishing consistency, humming for nearly two decades at peak performance.

headline: Suspect Pleads Guilty in 2022 New Year’s Eve Attack on N.Y.P.D. Officers
abstract: Trevor Bickford, who used a machete to attack an officer near Times Square “in the name of jihad,” pleaded guilty to attempted murder and assault.
lead_paragraph: A man who the authorities said carried out an attempt “in the name of jihad” to kill three New York City police officers near Times Square during the 2022 New Year’s Eve celebration pleaded guilty to federal charges on Thursday.

headline: Larry Collins, Rockabilly Guitar Prodigy, Is Dead at 79
abstract: He and his sister became child stars in the 1950s by making exuberantly unhinged music. “I had so much energy,” he said, “they didn’t know what to do with me.”
lead_paragraph: Larry Collins, the prodigious child guitarist who worked with his sister Lorrie as the exuberant 1950s rockabilly duo the Collins Kids, died on Friday in Santa Clarita, Calif. He was 79.

headline: Trump Rebuked the Judge in His Fraud Trial
abstract: Also, Bill Belichick is out after 24 years with the Patriots. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: On the final day of his civil fraud trial in Manhattan, Donald Trump unleashed a spate of insults directed at the New York attorney general and the judge overseeing the case. He accused both of them of pursuing their own political agendas and declared himself “an innocent man.”

headline: Israel Faces Accusation of Genocide as South Africa Brings Case to U.N. Court
abstract: Arguing to a packed courtroom at the International Court of Justice in The Hague, South African lawyers cited the words of Israeli officials as evidence in their case. Israel has categorically denied the accusation.
lead_paragraph: After three months besieging and bombarding the Gaza Strip in its war against Hamas, Israel faced a charge of genocide at the International Court of Justice on Thursday, as South Africa argued that Israel “means to create conditions of death” in Gaza, and demanded the court order an emergency suspension of the military campaign.

headline: ‘Sopranos’ Cast Reunites in Little Italy for 25th Anniversary
abstract: And the art world podcast “Nota Bene” hosts a group show in TriBeCa followed by a bash in Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: Out & About covers the events where notable, powerful and influential figures gather. Plus the outfits. This week: a reunion for the “Sopranos” cast and a gathering for the podcast “Nota Bene.”

headline: Purina Rebuts TikTok Rumors About Pet Food Safety
abstract: As reports of dog illnesses linked to Purina’s Pro Plan food caused a stir on TikTok in recent weeks, a Purina spokeswoman said that the rumors “are not true and that our food is safe to feed.”
lead_paragraph: Purina has been forced to rebut what it described as “online rumors” that have caused a frenzy on TikTok in recent weeks alleging that its Pro Plan food had sickened dozens of pets, mostly dogs.

headline: Edward Jay Epstein, Author and Stubborn Skeptic, Dies at 88
abstract: He questioned the findings of the Warren Commission, called Edward Snowden a prized Russian asset and exposed the diamond industry’s economic impact.
lead_paragraph: Edward Jay Epstein, an iconoclastic author whose deeply researched books challenged conventional wisdom about controversies ranging from whether John F. Kennedy was killed by a lone assassin to whether the whistle-blower Edward Snowden was really a Russian spy, has died in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Haley Created a Site to Fact-Check DeSantis. It Could Use More Context.
abstract: During this week’s debate in Iowa, Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, tirelessly promoted a website to fact-check Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. We took a closer look, and here’s what we found.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen times during Wednesday night’s Republican presidential debate, Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, directed viewers to a website purporting to correct what she called Ron DeSantis’s “lies.”

headline: U.S. Missiles Strike Targets in Yemen Linked to the Houthi Militia
abstract: The American-led strikes came in response to more than two dozen Houthi drone and missile attacks against commercial shipping in the Red Sea since the Israel-Hamas war began.
lead_paragraph: The United States and five of its allies on Thursday carried out military strikes against more than a dozen targets in Yemen controlled by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia, in an expansion of the war in the Middle East that the Biden administration had sought to avoid for the past three months.

headline: Alice Mason, Real Estate Fixer and Hostess to the Elite, Dies at 100
abstract: She was the queen of Manhattan real estate when power brokers jockeyed for places in stately co-op buildings. Her dinners for them made the gossip columns.
lead_paragraph: Alice Mason, a real estate broker and hostess whose talent at social engineering reworked the populations of Manhattan’s most restrictive co-ops — the tony apartment buildings that lined Park and Fifth Avenues — and for a time altered the nightlife of what used to be known as New York society, died on Jan. 4 at her home in Manhattan. She was 100.

headline: Lynn Yamada Davis, Whose Cooking TikToks Delighted Millions, Dies at 67
abstract: Older than most social media stars, she attracted a large following with her Cooking With Lynja videos, which were both wholesome and zany.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Yamada Davis, a TikTok creator who entertained millions of people with her zany style and cooking tips on her account, Cooking With Lynja, died on Jan. 1 in Red Bank, N.J. She was 67.

headline: Trump Dreams of Economic Disaster
abstract: Why, exactly, do so many Americans admire this guy?
lead_paragraph: Did Donald Trump just say that he’s hoping for an economic crash? Not exactly. But what he did say was arguably even worse, especially once you put it in context.

headline: U.S. Criminally Charges EBay in Cyberstalking Case
abstract: The case involves eBay employees trying to intimidate a Massachusetts couple who write and produce an e-commerce newsletter. The company will pay a criminal penalty of $3 million.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department charged eBay on Thursday with stalking, witness tampering and obstruction of justice in a rare criminal case against a well-known Silicon Valley company.

headline: Tracking Freezing Temperatures in the U.S.
abstract: See detailed maps of the latest forecast for freezing temperatures in the United States.
lead_paragraph: See detailed maps of the latest forecast for freezing temperatures in the United States.

headline: Atlanta Prosecutor Faces Upheaval in Trump Inquiry
abstract: Accusations involving her relationship with the lead prosecutor she hired are seen as unlikely to derail the case but could cause serious distractions.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years after she began investigating former President Donald J. Trump and his allies, Fani T. Willis is facing the biggest test of her handling of the landmark election interference case.

headline: Who Are the Houthis and Why Is the U.S. Attacking Them?
abstract: The Iranian-backed militia has launched dozens of attacks on commercial ships in the Red Sea since the war between Israel and Hamas started.
lead_paragraph: Since mid-November, the Houthis, the de facto government in northern Yemen that is backed by Iran, have launched dozens of attacks on ships sailing through the Red Sea and the Suez Canal, a crucial shipping route through which 12 percent of world trade passes.

headline: Russian Oligarch Who Says He Was Cheated Testifies at Art Fraud Trial
abstract: Dmitry Rybolovlev took the stand to accuse Sotheby’s of aiding a Swiss art dealer who he says tricked him into overspending by tens of millions on art.
lead_paragraph: As the owner of Monaco’s beloved soccer team, Dmitry Rybolovlev, who is often photographed at matches, has hardly kept a low profile. Yet his appearance on Thursday when he took the witness stand in Manhattan was still rare: a Russian oligarch seeking justice in an American courtroom.

headline: Iowa Pastors Say Video Depicting Trump as Godly Is ‘Very Concerning’
abstract: The viral video shows the former president, in starkly religious, almost messianic tones, as the vessel of a higher power sent to save the nation.
lead_paragraph: A viral video praising former President Donald J. Trump has offended a key Iowa constituency in the lead-up to next week’s critical Iowa caucuses: faith leaders.

headline: Read Biden’s Full Statement on the Strikes in Yemen
abstract: The president directed U.S. military forces to strike a number of targets used by the Houthi militia after attacks on ships in the Red Sea.
lead_paragraph: Here is President Biden’s full statement on the strikes conducted against the Houthi militia in Yemen by the United States and allies, as released by the White House on Thursday:

headline: ‘Role Play’ Review: Mommy by Day, Killer by Night
abstract: Kaley Cuoco plays a woman balancing a life of domesticity with her career as an assassin in this spineless comedy thriller.
lead_paragraph: Kaley Cuoco may be our newest caper girl Friday, but even her flame of charisma tapers off early in “Role Play,” directed by Thomas Vincent. Calling on the same knack for high jinks that she perfected on the Max series “The Flight Attendant,” the onetime sitcom actress plays Emma, a suburban mom with a secret: she is actually an internationally-wanted assassin.

headline: Three Republican Candidates, Three Very Different Styles
abstract: Hundreds of events over the course of the year reveal distinct campaigning styles among the top three Republican presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of events over the course of the year reveal distinct campaigning styles among the top three Republican presidential candidates.

headline: ‘Lift’ Review: Thin as Thieves
abstract: This poorly written action vehicle pits Kevin Hart as a hero against an eco-terrorist villain.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Hart plays Cyrus, a master thief, in the undercooked heist flick, “Lift,” directed by F. Gary Gray. Written by Daniel Kunka, the film consists of luxurious locations like Tuscany and Venice and elaborate set pieces including a speedboat chase in the opening scene, but they are not infused with any sense of suspense or danger.

headline: Of a Feather
abstract: Hemant Mehta opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: David Balton and Jane Stewart’s puzzle reveals a timely quotation and a human truth.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — This coming Monday is Martin Luther King Jr.’s actual birthday as well as the day that the United States celebrates him with a holiday. He would have turned 95 this year.

headline: U.S. and Allies Hit Yemen With Airstrikes
abstract: Videos verified by The New York Times show explosions in Yemen that targeted the Houthi militia group, which has been responsible for attacks against commercial shipping in the Red Sea.
lead_paragraph: Videos verified by The New York Times show explosions in Yemen that targeted the Houthi militia group, which has been responsible for attacks against commercial shipping in the Red Sea.

headline: Blizzard Warning in Iowa Slows Campaigns as Race Barrels to a Close
abstract: Nikki Haley has canceled her in-person events on Friday. Ron DeSantis and Vivek Ramaswamy are still planning some, for now.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina canceled her town-hall events in Iowa that had been scheduled for Friday, citing what forecasters for the National Weather Service called “life-threatening winter weather.”

headline: Students Sue Harvard, Calling It a ‘Bastion’ of Antisemitism
abstract: A group of students, citing a litany of instances on campus they claimed were antisemitic, said that Harvard professors had long promulgated antisemitism in their courses, among other claims.
lead_paragraph: Six students sued Harvard on Wednesday, claiming that the renowned university had become a “bastion of rampant anti-Jewish hatred and harassment” that was exacerbated by the Hamas attack on Israel last October.

headline: Sharing an Airbnb With My Parents for Seven Weeks
abstract: Korea was my parents’ country. They wouldn’t need me there as they did in Canada … right?
lead_paragraph: I was sitting in between my parents on a 15-hour direct flight from Toronto to Seoul.

headline: A Relationship Fast-Tracked by an Impending Move
abstract: When Leslie Marshall and Tamar Malloy began dating, Dr. Malloy was just weeks away from relocating to Colorado for a teaching job.
lead_paragraph: In June 2019, Leslie Marshall locked eyes with Tamar Malloy at a bus stop in Pittsburgh. As Dr. Malloy walked down the sidewalk, “I really wanted to know this person, but didn’t even know if they remembered my name,” Dr. Marshall recalled. “We took this half-step toward each other, where you’re like, ‘Will they reciprocate?’”

headline: An Off-the-Cuff Remark That Proved True
abstract: After friends hassled Andrew Tolman about spending so much time with Jenna Santoro one summer weekend, he replied: “I’m going to marry this girl.”
lead_paragraph: Andrew Warren Tolman relaxed into a lounge chair next to Jenna Lynn Santoro on July 20, 2019, as the weekly Saturday beach club party was winding down at Gurney’s Montauk Resort in Montauk, N.Y.

headline: After Six Years of Friendship, Came Love —Fast and Furious
abstract: Once Kelsey Kiyota and Elliott Lin discovered a love of the same movie franchise, there was no looking back.
lead_paragraph: Kelsey Masako Fumiko Kiyota and Elliott Lin met through a mutual friend in 2012, but it wasn’t until six years into their friendship that they realized they had something important in common — a love for the “Fast & Furious” movie franchise. The discovery happened in January 2018 while at a party at their friend’s house in San Francisco, where they both lived.

headline: Embracing Love While Becoming Their Authentic Selves
abstract: Spencer Hatcher and Crystal Carmichael met in 2012 through a dating app, and at the time, both were going through transitions in their lives.
lead_paragraph: Spencer Ter Hatcher and Crystal Marie Carmichael can’t quite agree on who noticed whom first. They first connected on the dating app Plenty of Fish on Sept. 5, 2012, and “I reached out first,” Ms. Carmichael said. “His blue eyes really drew me in. He claims he saw me first.”

headline: Taiwan Party, Reviled by China, Battles to Prove Its Staying Power
abstract: The Democratic Progressive Party has transformed Taiwan into a bastion against Chinese power. Now it is promising a mix of change and continuity.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four decades ago, a group of lawyers, intellectuals and activists assembled in a hotel ballroom in Taipei to found an illegal political party dedicated to ending authoritarian rule in Taiwan.

headline: Taiwan Holds an Election That Could Reshape Global Affairs
abstract: Voters headed to the polls to choose a new president who could alter the complicated, risky balance between Taiwan, China and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan will choose a new president on Saturday, bringing new leadership to volatile relations with an increasingly belligerent Beijing. The outcome could raise or lower the risks of a crisis, giving China a potential transition point to revive engagement, or to increase the military threats that could ultimately draw the United States into a war.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: What’s at stake in Taiwan’s election.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Taiwan will elect a new president and legislature tomorrow, a much-watched process that could affect the island’s relations with China and the U.S.

headline: Taiwan’s Tightrope Has Become a Knife Edge
abstract: I will go to the polls on Saturday worried about our future and whether we can preserve and maintain what we’ve achieved.
lead_paragraph: My home, Taiwan, is a shining example of freedom, democracy and inclusivity. We have one of the world’s most open societies, the highest percentage of female legislators in Asia and a government minister who is transgender. Decades of hard work, smart policies and entrepreneurial mindsets have led to enviably high standards of living and made us the global heart of the semiconductor industry.

headline: Quotation of the Day: 2 Coaches Close the Book. It’s the Stuff of Legends.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 12, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “As much as I like to think I can see far ahead, I never would have imagined this much success.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 12, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the start of U.N. hearings on allegations of genocide against Israel brought by South Africa referred incorrectly to the laws of war as they apply to Hamas. Hamas is bound by the laws of war, but the International Court of Justice cannot compel the group to stop fighting because it only handles disputes between states.

headline: Word of the Day: kvetch
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word kvetch has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 30 in “‘Doormat Treatment’: Congestion Pricing Plan Riles New Jersey Leaders” by Tracey Tully and Elise Young:

headline: Late Night Finds Trump Incapable of Dealing With Facts
abstract: A judge initially denied Trump the chance to speak at his criminal fraud trial, “but, as 27 women can tell you, Trump doesn’t take no for an answer,” Stephen Colbert said on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Exploring the 3-Year Cruise That Never Set Sail
abstract: When a voyage around the world fell apart before it ever left the dock, Ceylan Yeginsu, a travel reporter, wanted to understand how it all went wrong.
lead_paragraph: Last February, I was scrolling through Instagram when a peculiar ad appeared on my feed. The ad boasted of a three-year cruise called Life at Sea — said to be the longest cruise ever, with 382 port calls around the world — set to depart from Istanbul on Nov. 1.

headline: Break Time
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
