lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: These Democrats and Republicans Have Something in Common. It’s a Bar.
abstract: It has been a bad decade — or three — for political nightlife in Albany, N.Y. Can a Manhattan P.R. man bring back the bipartisan schmoozefest?
lead_paragraph: It was 10 p.m. on the eve of the governor’s State of the State address, and all of political New York, it seemed, was trying to jam into two adjoining brick townhouses within stumbling distance of the State Capitol.

headline: What to Know After Closing Arguments in Trump’s Civil Fraud Trial
abstract: A judge’s decision lies ahead, and appeals are highly likely. But this case could end Mr. Trump’s decades-long role in the New York real-estate business.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial went out with a bang on Thursday, with the former president delivering an impassioned defense during closing arguments.

headline: U.K. Pledges $3 Billion in Military Aid to Ukraine
abstract: The annual British package is about $255 million more than in the past two years and is part of an effort to reassure Kyiv amid concerns about a potential shortfall in Western support.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain visited Kyiv on Friday to announce that he would send more than $3 billion in military assistance to Ukraine in the next financial year, his country’s largest annual commitment since the start of Russia’s full-scale invasion.

headline: Accused of Genocide, Israelis See Reversal of Reality. Palestinians See Justice.
abstract: Israel stands accused of committing genocide in Gaza. To Israelis, the charge is a perversion of history. But for Palestinians it creates a fleeting sense of justice.
lead_paragraph: Whatever its outcome, the accusation of genocide leveled this week against Israel at the world’s top court is an epochal intervention imbued with profound symbolism for both Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: Audiobook of the Week: Arnold Schwarzenegger’s ‘Be Useful’
abstract: The audiobook might be less, well, useful than it is entertainingly honest, unfiltered and even bizarre.
lead_paragraph: Listen to enough hours of Arnold Schwarzenegger reciting his new audiobook, “Be Useful,” and I promise you too will be annoying your loved ones by speaking in Aaahnold. (“Der is no Plon B. Plon B is to succeed at Plon A.” “Verk your azz off.”)

headline: Four Fiendish Tales of Murder
abstract: In these novels, detectives — some real, others self-appointed — investigate deaths in a small town, on board a train, in a haunted French chateau.
lead_paragraph: Ernest Cunningham, the star of Benjamin Stevenson’s second meta-mystery, EVERYONE ON THIS TRAIN IS A SUSPECT (Mariner, 336 pp., $30), promises at the outset “to be that rarity in modern crime novels: a reliable narrator. You can count on me for the truth at every turn. No hoodwinking.” Of course, any seasoned mystery reader knows that a reliable narrator doesn’t really exist. They may faithfully convey the truth, only to fool themselves.

headline: A Pilates Routine You Can Do Anywhere in Under 10 Minutes
abstract: Studies suggest the workout method can improve strength and posture, but it’s not cheap to join a studio. Here’s how to test the waters at home.
lead_paragraph: Pilates has been hugely popular for the last 10 years, and for good reason. But joining a studio with a professional instructor or buying home equipment is expensive, especially if you have never even tried the workouts. Fortunately, you can get many of the same benefits of studio-based Pilates at home with nothing more than a mat and your body.

headline: A $25,000 Makeover for a Tiny Sarajevo Apartment
abstract: How do you create a relaxing home in a stressful city? Two architects came up with a solution in the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
lead_paragraph: How do you create a relaxing home in a stressful city? Two architects came up with a solution in the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

headline: The Billionaires Spending a Fortune to Lure Scientists Away From Universities
abstract: Arena BioWorks is promising big paydays to nearly 100 researchers from Harvard, M.I.T. and other prestigious institutions.
lead_paragraph: In an unmarked laboratory stationed between the campuses of Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, a splinter group of scientists is hunting for the next billion-dollar drug.

headline: How Do You Create a Calm Living Space in a Nerve-Racking City?
abstract: Two architects came up with a solution in a city that was once among the most stressful in the world: Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 years have passed since Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia and Herzegovina and once a model for multicultural harmony, became a shooting gallery.

headline: Voices of Peaceful Protest
abstract: How John Lewis and Coretta Scott King embodied the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s legacy while each creating their own.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 40 years since Martin Luther King’s Birthday became a national holiday, and the question of how to celebrate it was probably best answered by the late John Lewis. The Georgia representative called it “a day on, not a day off,” “a day of action, a day of love, to give of ourselves to others and begin anew the building of the beloved community.” A new picture book about Lewis and two about Coretta Scott King make for illuminating reading on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s holiday and throughout the year.

headline: Our Kids Are Living in a Different Digital World
abstract: Enormous numbers of kids follow social media influencers who boost addictive drugs to audiences who are too young to legally buy them.
lead_paragraph: Do you know what a Zynbabwe is? Or an upper-decky lip pillow? OK, here’s an easier one — how about just Zyn?

headline: A Huge Underground Battery Is Coming to a Tiny Utah Town
abstract: The project is part of an audacious plan to create hydrogen, which produces no carbon dioxide when burned, and store it in caverns until  electricity is needed.
lead_paragraph: Outside Delta, a one-stoplight town in the scrublands of central Utah, a giant battery is taking shape underground.

headline: Jessie Homer French Paints Infernos but She Sees Rainbows
abstract: The self-taught artist, at 83, has a newly flourishing career. In Southern California’s high desert she fishes for trout and finds beauty in devastation.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny autumn morning, in Jessie Homer French’s garage-studio, up several miles of mountain switchbacks from Palm Desert, Calif., a dozen canvases are propped on shelves in various stages of completion. Most are landscapes. Three depict cemeteries, a recurrent subject for the 83-year-old self-taught artist. Standing out among the browns and the greens, however, are two pictures of wildfires, in furious tones of orange, yellow and black.

headline: ‘The Curse’ Ending: What Just Happened?
abstract: The season finale of Nathan Fielder and Benny Safdie’s horror-comedy arrived on Friday. Three New York Times critics discuss the show’s curses, blessings and confounding conclusion.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the first season of “The Curse,” Nathan Fielder and Benny Safdie’s cringe horror-comedy on Showtime and Paramount+, came to an audaciously unpredictable end. Three New York Times critics — James Poniewozik, chief TV critic; Alissa Wilkinson, movie critic; and Jason Zinoman, critic at large — discussed the confounding conclusion, the show’s religious themes and the sublime inscrutability of Emma Stone’s performance. Spoilers follow.

headline: The Emergency Brake Dilemma
abstract: Pranksters pulling the subway brakes for no reason are abusing the system, but sometimes the brakes are important safety devices.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at when activating the emergency brakes on the subway is no prank. We’ll also find out about a golf course that no longer has a sign reading “Trump Links.”

headline: When Mean Girls Grow Up
abstract: Two decades ago, Rosalind Wiseman defined teen-girl dynamics and inspired Tina Fey’s cult classic movie. Now she helps the adult women who can’t escape high school.
lead_paragraph: Rosalind Wiseman regularly receives emails from women who think they are going to surprise her with the following divulgence: “You are never going to believe this: My work is like middle school.”

headline: Where in the World Would You Most Like to Travel?
abstract: This year’s “52 Places to Go” list suggests plenty of destinations to consider.
lead_paragraph: Do you like to travel? Where have you been that you’ve loved? Where have you always wanted to go?

headline: The Constitution Says Insurrectionists Can’t Hold Office. So What Is Trump?
abstract: David French walks us through the constitutional battle over whether the ex-president can run again.
lead_paragraph: There’s this incredible dissonance at the center of our politics right now. On the one hand, all the polling suggests that Donald Trump is about to win Iowa Republican caucuses and the New Hampshire primary. He seems overwhelmingly likely to be his party’s nominee, and so possibly our next president. On the other hand, he could be constitutionally disqualified from taking office.

headline: Picking a Trump V.P.: The Field of Dreams or a Field of Nightmares?
abstract: The road beyond Iowa is paved with potential running mates.
lead_paragraph: This week on “Matter of Opinion,” the hosts do the dirty work of strategizing the best vice-presidential candidate for Donald Trump to campaign with, and break down what goes into consequential (and not so consequential) V.P. picks.

headline: The Greatest Threat Posed by Trump
abstract: However much a second term would harm America’s politics, it would harm America’s moral culture even more.
lead_paragraph: If Donald Trump storms through Iowa and easily seizes the G.O.P. nomination, as presumed, and then goes on to win back the presidency, his victory will trigger a wild political and legal melee. The primary motivating purpose of his campaign is vengeance. He’s told his base that he is their retribution and has promised to “totally obliterate” the deep state. If he faces protests, he may immediately invoke the Insurrection Act and deploy troops, under his command, to American cities.

headline: Are Iowa Evangelicals on the Trump Train? These Pastors Offer Clues.
abstract: In 2016, evangelicals fueled a victory in Iowa for Ted Cruz. Since then, they’ve tilted toward Donald Trump and been courted by Ron DeSantis. We asked several conservative Christian pastors where they’re leaning.
lead_paragraph: Before he clinched the 2016 Republican nomination, won the presidency and remade the party in his nativist, norm-shattering image, Donald J. Trump lost the Iowa caucuses to a conservative Texan who had consolidated the support of evangelical leaders and voters in the state.

headline: New Music for Your Weekend
abstract: From Pan-African pop to a “Rhapsody in Blue”-grass.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, our chief pop music critic, picks his favorite new tracks for you to listen to this week:

headline: 15 States Shut Out Food Aid for 8 Million Children
abstract: Congress approved a Biden administration initiative to feed poor children during the summer. But 15 states opted out.
lead_paragraph: More than eight million children in 15 states will be shut out of a new federal food assistance program intended to help needy families during the summer months.

headline: This Distant Planet Has a 350,000-Mile-Long Cometlike Tail
abstract: The stream of helium trailing WASP-69b, a “Hot Jupiter,” allows astronomers to study how planets lose their atmospheres.
lead_paragraph: Humanity has spied more than 5,500 worlds orbiting other stars, and some are truly exotic. One seems to have titanium clouds, while on another, storms of glass may rain down.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the updated movie musical “Mean Girls.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the updated movie musical “Mean Girls.”

headline: Trumpism Is Devouring the Evangelical Movement
abstract: It will take a miracle to avoid a Trump blowout in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Tim Alberta’s recent book about the Christian nationalist takeover of American evangelicalism, “The Kingdom, the Power, and the Glory,” is full of preachers and activists on the religious right expressing sheepish second thoughts about their prostration before Donald Trump. Robert Jeffress, the senior pastor at First Baptist Dallas — whom Texas Monthly once called “Trump’s apostle” for his slavish Trump boosterism — admitted to Alberta in 2021 that turning himself into a politician’s theological hype man may have compromised his spiritual mission. “I had that internal conversation with myself — and I guess with God, too — about, you know, when do you cross the line?” he said, allowing that the line had, “perhaps,” been crossed.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Jan. 12, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Don’t Turn Away From the Charges of Genocide Against Israel
abstract: South Africa’s case before the International Court of Justice is crammed with evidence of breaches of the 1948 international genocide convention.
lead_paragraph: With the question of whether Israel is committing genocide in Gaza now before the International Court of Justice, the Biden administration has struck a tone of glib dismissal.

headline: ‘The Curse’ Season 1 Finale Recap: Things Are Looking Up
abstract: A jump ahead in time finds the Siegels almost seeming happy, or at least faking it well enough. Then something absolutely bonkers happens.
lead_paragraph: Certain kinds of surprises are de rigueur in television. The shock of when a character unexpectedly dies, for instance. It’s jolting, sure, but it’s nothing too out of the ordinary. Television writers do it all the time.

headline: Asa Hutchinson, Tilting at a Trump-Branded Windmill, Hangs On
abstract: The former Arkansas governor, nowhere in the polls, is running on principle — and on fumes, financially speaking.
lead_paragraph: Asa Hutchinson sat under the fluorescent lights of a windowless conference room just off the main convention hall at the Prairie Meadows Casino and Hotel in Altoona, Iowa, on Thursday, explaining why there was a mission to the madness of his 2024 campaign for the presidency.

headline: Just How Wild Is This Week’s Weather? One Image Tells the Tale.
abstract: Each weekday morning, FEMA releases a map showing weather hazards around the country. It’s starting to get a little out of hand.
lead_paragraph: No single image could fully capture the confluence of extreme weather events that is disrupting the United States this week, buffeting the country from coast to coast with snowstorms, intense flooding, high winds and even tornadoes.

headline: Why Casey Left Substack, Elon Musk and Drugs, and an A.I. Antibiotic Discovery
abstract: It’s a drug episode.
lead_paragraph: Casey is taking his newsletter Platformer off Substack, as criticism over the company’s handling of pro-Nazi content grows. Then, The Wall Street Journal spoke with witnesses who said that Elon Musk had used LSD, cocaine, ecstasy and psychedelic mushrooms, worrying some directors and board members of his companies. And finally, how researchers found a new class of antibiotics with the help of an artificial intelligence algorithm used to win the board game Go.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Including titles by Janet Malcolm, Patricia Engel, Tracy Kidder and more.
lead_paragraph: Including titles by Janet Malcolm, Patricia Engel, Tracy Kidder and more.

headline: How to Reset Your Relationship With Tech (for Real This Time)
abstract: I spent a week without tech. Here’s what I learned.
lead_paragraph: Hi there. I’m Melissa Kirsch. I’m the deputy editor for Culture & Lifestyle at The Times and I write The Morning newsletter on Saturdays. Jancee Dunn is off this week, so I’ll be filling in.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews David French
abstract: The Jan. 12, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with David French. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Trump Is Playing With Fire
abstract: The former president manipulates the threat of violence as a form of political control.
lead_paragraph: To be a Republican politician in the age of Donald Trump is to live under the threat of violence from his most fanatical and aggressive followers.

headline: The Midwest Braces for a Blizzard, and More Severe Storms Will Slam the South
abstract: More than a foot of snow is expected in parts of Michigan and Wisconsin, forecasters said. Severe weather, with the possibility of tornadoes, will sweep states from Mississippi to the Carolinas.
lead_paragraph: A relentless weather pattern that caused headaches for large portions of the United States this week will deliver blizzard conditions across the Midwest and Great Lakes on Friday and into the holiday weekend, while severe weather will again settle over the South and East, forecasters said.

headline: What Is the ‘Wind Chill Index,’ Anyway?
abstract: Sure, it’s cold out. But how do meteorologists measure how cold it feels?
lead_paragraph: When Natalie Hasell, a warning preparedness meteorologist for the Canadian government, lived in Montreal, she used her own informal system for measuring cold that went beyond the thermometer. “I used to describe how cold it was by how long it took my nostril hairs to freeze walking from home to the bus stop,” she said.

headline: In Iowa, Two Friends Debate DeSantis vs. Trump
abstract: As the first contest in the Republican primary race draws near, we consider Gov. Ron DeSantis’s challenges on the ground.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Iowa holds the first contest in the Republican presidential nominating process and nobody will have more on the line than Ron DeSantis. The Florida governor staked his candidacy on a victory in Iowa, a victory that now seems increasingly remote.

headline: Removal of Netflix Film Shows Advancing Power of India’s Hindu Right Wing
abstract: The movie “Annapoorani” was about a female chef overcoming caste prejudice. Hindu activists said it hurt their feelings.
lead_paragraph: The trailer for “Annapoorani: The Goddess of Food” promised a sunny if melodramatic story of uplift in a south Indian temple town. A priest’s daughter enters a cooking tournament, but social obstacles complicate her inevitable rise to the top. Annapoorani’s father, a Brahmin sitting at the top of Hindu society’s caste ladder, doesn’t want her to cook meat, a taboo in their lineage. There is even the hint of a Hindu-Muslim romantic subplot.

headline: U.S. Strikes in Yemen, and Taiwan’s High-Stakes Election
abstract: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Taiwan Goes to the Polls
abstract: The election could reshape international affairs.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow is Election Day in Taiwan, where the selection of a new president will shape the island’s relationship with China — and, by extension, shape international affairs.

headline: When Trailers Hit Mute on the Musical
abstract: With “Mean Girls,” “Wonka” and “The Color Purple,” why have studios spent much of their marketing budget downplaying and disguising their movie musicals?
lead_paragraph: Regina George has a secret. She sings.

headline: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a bevy of animated critters and a science-fiction fantasy.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Bill Burr as the voice of a jaded animated turtle in a kids’ movie may be enough to pique the curiosity of some parents. In “Leo,” Burr’s Squirtle is the grouchy sidekick to Leo, a septuagenarian lizard (voiced by Adam Sandler). They share a terrarium in a fifth grade classroom in Florida, and when Leo realizes he’s reaching the end of his reptilian life span, he has a sudden urge to escape and see the world. When the humorless substitute teacher Ms. Malkin (Cecily Strong) tells the students that they each have to take one of the two creatures home for the weekend to learn responsibility, Leo sees his chance. He goes home with the chatty Summer (Sunny Sandler), and reveals that he can speak. Once each kid stops freaking out about bringing home a talking lizard, Leo turns into a life coach/therapist for them. Through old-school wisdom, the children learn lessons about kindness, acceptance and confidence. The script — by Sandler, Robert Smigel (“Saturday Night Live,” “Hotel Transylvania”) and Paul Sado (“Sandy Wexler”) — doesn’t break any new ground, but there are enough cute jokes, so-so musical numbers and visual gags to hold the interest of preschool- and elementary-aged kids. Smigel directed the movie with “S.N.L.” alums Robert Marianetti and David Wachtenheim.

headline: U.S.-Led Strikes Draw Fury From Iran
abstract: Other critics also included militias allied with Iran, as well as Oman, a U.S. ally that often mediates between the Houthis and international parties.
lead_paragraph: Iran and allied militias in the Middle East, along with at least one U.S. ally, condemned the American-led airstrikes against Houthi targets in Yemen on Friday and warned that they risked causing a broader conflict in the region.

headline: A Dinner Party Menu for When You Want More Dinner Than Party
abstract: David Tanis’s new menu, featuring cauliflower cheese and a snappy citrus salad, is just the thing to serve to a few friends (not all of them).
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’m done with feasting for a while. I’ve had my holiday turkeys and hams and meat pies and trifles, my stacks of New Year’s oysters, my showstopper project recipes, that cake you need to start a month in advance. I want intimate dinner party food, simple and delicious and elegant, something to enjoy with a few friends, not all of them.

headline: BlackRock’s Giant Bet on Infrastructure
abstract: The Wall Street giant agreed to buy Global Infrastructure Partners, whose assets include airports and oil pipelines, in its biggest takeover in 15 years.
lead_paragraph: BlackRock is already Wall Street’s dominant player in stocks and bonds with $10 trillion in assets. Now the company plans to go big on the business of investing in airports, bridges, oil pipelines and more.

headline: F.A.A. to Increase Oversight of Boeing and Audit 737 Max 9 Production
abstract: The heightened scrutiny comes a day after the agency opened an investigation into whether Boeing failed to ensure that its 737 Max 9 plane was safe.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Friday that it was expanding its scrutiny of Boeing, increasing oversight of the company with an audit of production of the 737 Max 9, a week after a panel in the body of one of those planes was blown out during flight.

headline: For Taiwanese Americans, Voting Back Home Takes More Than a Postage Stamp
abstract: Dual citizens are flying across the Pacific to participate in this weekend’s presidential election. Many of them are motivated by Taiwan-China tensions.
lead_paragraph: They are some of the most determined voters in the world.

headline: Lugging Credit Card Debt Into 2024? Now’s the Time to Make a Plan.
abstract: Most Americans with card debt have not outlined a way to bring it down, a new report says. There are ways to get help.
lead_paragraph: As 2024 dawns, Americans’ credit card debt and late payments are rising, and card interest rates remain high, but many people lack a plan to pay down their debt. If your balances are ballooning, a New Year’s resolution to tackle them would be timely.

headline: An Income Gap Is Jeopardizing Retirement for Millions of Americans
abstract: Older Americans in the lower middle class are losing ground financially, Paula Span says in her New York Times column, The New Old Age.
lead_paragraph: Getting by in America can be difficult these days for many middle-class people — especially older Americans who find themselves toward the lower end of the income bracket.

headline: Biggest U.S. Banks Earn Billions, Even After Insurance Bill
abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America and Wells Fargo reported healthy quarterly profits. Citigroup said its ongoing restructuring would result in about 20,000 job cuts.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s largest banks are churning out profits as interest rates remain high, even though the lenders have had to set aside billions of dollars to replenish a deposit insurance fund that was heavily depleted by a crisis among midsize banks last spring.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Pay $249 Million in Block Trading Investigation
abstract: Federal prosecutors found at least one employee at the Wall Street firm had committed deceptive practices in handling trades of large blocks of stock from 2018 to 2021.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley agreed to pay $249 million in penalties to resolve investigations by federal prosecutors and securities regulators into the firm’s practices in handling some large stock trades, authorities and the bank said on Friday.

headline: Russell Hamler, Last of World War II’s Merrill’s Marauders, Dies at 99
abstract: The foot soldiers marched and fought through harsh mountainous jungle on a mission to seize a Japanese-held airfield. Dozens did not survive.
lead_paragraph: The soldiers’ mission was as dangerous as it was audacious: a trek of more than 500 miles through mountainous jungle in northern Burma to seize a Japanese-held airfield in World War II.

headline: As Storms Freeze the Midwest, ‘It’s Just Rough Out There’
abstract: Heavy snow fell on Friday across much of the northern United States, disrupting schools and travel. Dangerous cold followed.
lead_paragraph: High winds and heavy snow turned much of the Midwest into a frosty mess on Friday. Roads and sidewalks across the region became treacherous, forcing some highways to close and grounding thousands of flights.

headline: A Science Writer Gets Personal
abstract: In a series of revealing essays, the NPR contributor Nell Greenfieldboyce views the events of her life through the lens of natural phenomena.
lead_paragraph: For almost 30 years Nell Greenfieldboyce has been a science writer and broadcaster, and heard regularly on NPR since 2005. Her pieces are objective, accessible and newsworthy, but scarcely involve her as an individual. In “Transient and Strange” — the title is taken from Walt Whitman’s description of the “huge meteor procession” that “sail’d its balls of unearthly light over our heads” — she narrates a sequence of events that, like those meteors, are both passing and unsettling. The project is ambitious, sometimes intimate, occasionally painful and always private — but set within the frame of a more public, scientific sensibility.

headline: Strikes Are ‘Extremely Unlikely’ to Deter Houthis, Experts Say
abstract: U.S.-led airstrikes in Yemen could play into the agenda of the Houthis, who have built their legitimacy on hostility toward the United States and Israel, scholars said.
lead_paragraph: The American-led airstrikes in Yemen on Friday could play into the agenda of the Houthis, the Iran-backed militia that rules much of northern Yemen, and are unlikely to stop the group’s campaign of attacking commercial ships, scholars who study the group said.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: On his first show of the new year, Jimmy Kimmel addressed inflammatory comments from the N.F.L. quarterback Aaron Rodgers. The hosts also discussed the near-disastrous accident of an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 jet and former President Donald Trump’s civil trial.
lead_paragraph: On his first show of the new year, Jimmy Kimmel addressed inflammatory comments from the N.F.L. quarterback Aaron Rodgers. The hosts also discussed the near-disastrous accident of an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 jet and former President Donald Trump’s civil trial.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The 52 places to go in 2024. Also: Tina Fey on “Mean Girls” and the end of the Bill Belichick hoodie era.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a bizarre Mexican-Spanish thriller, a Canadian drama about immigrants, a documentary set in a Parisian dance school and more.
lead_paragraph: Hard-core pornography, international drug mafias and a doctoral candidate’s literary explorations of critical gender theory: True to its title, this dark comedy, adapted from a novel by Juan Pablo Villalobos, involves such a bizarre mishmash of references and tones that it stretches plausibility — albeit to wonderfully entertaining ends.

headline: An Actor Channeling the Folklore of His Ancestors
abstract: In his theater work, Eric Berryman injects forgotten voices from the past into the present moment.
lead_paragraph: Two of Eric Berryman’s favorite things are drinking tea and telling stories, both of which were on the agenda on a recent rainy afternoon in the Manhattan neighborhood of SoHo.

headline: What to Know About the International Court of Justice
abstract: The United Nations’ highest judicial body held two days of hearings this week in a case by South Africa accusing Israel of committing genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice, the United Nations’ highest judicial body, held two days of hearings this week in a case brought by South Africa accusing Israel of committing genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.

headline: Macron’s New Cabinet Tilts Right With Old Pillars and Some Surprises
abstract: A reshuffle brought in a handful of new ministers, including a high-profile conservative and a Europe-focused foreign minister. But several key officials remained.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France convened a new, smaller cabinet for the first time on Friday, a day after a government reshuffle that brought in a handful of new ministers — including one poached from the right and a Europe-focused foreign minister — but that left most key positions untouched.

headline: Some Student Loan Borrowers May Be Eligible for Forgiveness Sooner
abstract: Next month, federal student loan borrowers may have their debt canceled if they are enrolled in the SAVE plan, initially borrowed $12,000 or less and made 10 years of payments.
lead_paragraph: Federal student loan borrowers who initially took out smaller loan amounts may be eligible for debt cancellation sooner than they anticipated.

headline: Biden, Trump and the ’24 Election: Playing Political Pundit
abstract: Readers discuss whether President Biden should run, the effect of third parties and campaign strategy. Also: The G.O.P. debate; surrogacy; Gaza; the Sphere.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: In ‘Cosmos,’ Female Astronauts Dance Toward the Stars
abstract: A new show in Paris by Maëlle Poésy tells the story of the Mercury 13 space program, with choreographed movement and acrobatic sequences.
lead_paragraph: Early on in “Cosmos,” a new production by the French theater director Maëlle Poésy, three performers walk slowly onstage, their bodies hidden in full spacesuits. There are plenty of clues in the playbill. After all, “Cosmos” was inspired by the Mercury 13, a group of American women who took part in a ’60s program that proved their fitness for space travel, but who never blasted off.

headline: The Secret Ingredient Your Rice Krispies Treats Are Missing
abstract: Simple to make but complex in taste, these marshmallow confections highlight the delicious balancing act of black sesame and sugar.
lead_paragraph: In the early 2000s, when Tomoko Yagi and her husband went to the movies in New York City, Ms. Yagi couldn’t find anywhere she could hang out afterward with a nice cup of tea and dessert. Back in her hometown in Japan, she could go to the ubiquitous wagashi (Japanese dessert) cafes that served not-too-sweet confections, such as the fresh fruit and jelly-based anmitsu or the shaved ice treat kakigōri, with a beautiful pot of green tea.

headline: U.S. to Seek Death for Man Who Killed 10 in Racist Supermarket Massacre
abstract: The decision to seek the execution of the man who carried out the slaughter in Buffalo is a first for the Biden administration. The president ran in open opposition to the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors will seek the death penalty against the gunman who killed 10 Black people in a racist massacre at a Buffalo supermarket in May 2022, according to court papers filed on Friday. It is the first time that President Biden’s administration has sought the death penalty in a new case.

headline: A Japanese Holiday Feast, by Way of California
abstract: Sylvan Mishima Brackett, the chef-owner of the San Francisco restaurant Rintaro, hosted family and friends for an intimate meal to start the year.
lead_paragraph: The chef Sylvan Mishima Brackett’s San Francisco izakaya, Rintaro, will turn 10 next year, and in a city crowded with good places to eat, and a state with access to spectacular ingredients year-round, it still stands out. The restaurant’s courtyard, hidden from the street behind a nondescript door, is filled with fragrant fruit trees (including a persimmon and four yuzu) and in the main dining rooms, guests can watch cooks grilling skewers of chicken behind a hinoki counter or preparing glossy sashimi in the open kitchen. Brackett worked at the chef Alice Waters’s farm-to-table institution Chez Panisse in Berkeley, Calif. — first as her assistant and later as a creative director — before opening his own restaurant, and he shares her commitment to seasonal and local ingredients, putting them to use in dishes informed by the food of his mother’s native Japan.

headline: Review: Hilary Hahn Gives, and Gets, at the Philharmonic
abstract: The star violinist’s appearance as artist in residence included an announcement that she had received the $100,000 Avery Fisher Prize.
lead_paragraph: After the concerto, after the encore, there was still more business to take care of when Hilary Hahn appeared with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday.

headline: The Meme King of Longevity Now Wants to Sell You Olive Oil
abstract: Bryan Johnson, a data-obsessed Silicon Valley centimillionaire, is promoting food and supplements that promise to help people live longer. Scientists say his program is highly questionable. So why are people flocking to it?
lead_paragraph: “Ready, on three,” Jamie Love said to the group of hikers as they huddled for a photo. “One, two, three …”

headline: Pope Cites Bronchitis as He Skips Speaking to an Audience
abstract: Instead, the pontiff’s words were handed out in written form. He seemed to be in good spirits, though his health has become an increasing concern.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis on Friday chose not to read out a prepared speech, lamenting a “touch of bronchitis,” and instead delivered his remarks in printed form to a delegation of French religious communications experts gathered at the Vatican, adding a few impromptu words.

headline: Severe Storms Threaten the South With High Winds and Tornadoes
abstract: Gusts up to 70 miles an hour are possible over the same wide area from Mississippi to the Atlantic where another storm system earlier in the week spawned 20 reports of tornadoes.
lead_paragraph: Severe storms, with winds gusting up to 70 miles an hour and the chance of tornadoes, will lash a large portion of the Southeast on Friday afternoon and into the night. People living anywhere from the Mississippi River to the Atlantic Ocean face at least some threat.

headline: Hunter Biden, Facing Contempt Referral, Says House Subpoenas Are Invalid
abstract: With House Republicans on the brink of pushing through a contempt of Congress referral against President Biden’s son, his lawyers argued the subpoenas they have issued for his testimony carry no legal weight.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden argued Friday that the subpoenas House Republicans have issued to him are invalid, his latest attempt to counter the contempt of Congress case that Republicans are pursuing against him as part of their impeachment inquiry into his father.

headline: Johnson Says He’ll Stand by Deal to Avert Shutdown, Spurning Hard-Right Demands
abstract: The House speaker is facing intense pressure from far-right Republicans to abandon the agreement he struck with Democrats to keep the government from partially shutting down next week.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson said on Friday that he stood by the spending deal he negotiated with Democrats to avert a government shutdown, spurning demands from ultraconservatives who have pressured him to jettison the agreement.

headline: Steven Soderbergh’s Year in Reading
abstract: Each January, the director Steven Soderbergh lists his previous year’s cultural consumption — every movie and TV series watched, every book read. On this week’s episode, we talk books!
lead_paragraph: Every January on his website Extension765.com, the prolific director Steven Soderbergh looks back at the previous year and posts a day-by-day account of every movie and TV series watched, every play attended and every book read. In 2023, Soderbergh tackled more than 80 (!) books, and on this week’s episode, he and the host Gilbert Cruz talk about some of his highlights.

headline: Red Paden, Juke Joint ‘King’ Who Kept the Blues Alive, Dies at 67
abstract: His unassuming Mississippi Delta nightspot is one of the last of its kind, giving blues musicians a welcoming venue and lately drawing visitors from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Red Paden, who as the self-proclaimed “king of the juke joint runners” spent four decades as the owner of Red’s, an unassuming music spot in downtown Clarksdale, Miss., and one of the last places in the United States to offer authentic Delta blues in its natural setting, died on Dec. 30 in Jackson, Miss. He was 67.

headline: Wild Weather Is Affecting N.F.L. Wild-Card Games This Weekend
abstract: The Dolphins will face “dangerously cold temperatures” in Kansas City, and the game between the Bills and Steelers in snowy Buffalo was moved to Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Kansas City Chiefs will play at home against the Miami Dolphins on Saturday night in what are likely to be “dangerously cold temperatures,” but your sympathies should probably be directed toward the visiting team.

headline: With Producers Guild Nominations, the Oscar Picture Gets Clearer
abstract: “Barbie,” “Oppenheimer” and “Killers of the Flower Moon” made the cut as they did for the directors and actors groups. But “The Color Purple” was left out.
lead_paragraph: Rounding out a busy awards-season week that included the Golden Globes and nominations from Hollywood’s directors and actors guilds, the Producers Guild of America announced the 10 films nominated for its best feature award on Friday. As expected, the group included “Oppenheimer” and “Barbie,” twinned box-office behemoths that have so far dominated awards season just as they ruled the summer.

headline: ‘True Detective: Night Country’ Review: Iced In
abstract: HBO’s eerie crime drama returns after a five-year break and trades in Southern gothic for Arctic horror.
lead_paragraph: “True Detective” was never a series that went in for tender moments, but “True Detective: Night Country” — the show’s fourth season, after a five-year hiatus — takes a particularly unforgiving approach to the human condition. There is a moment late in the six-episode season, however, when the dour pop soundtrack turns sentimental and it’s clear that we are supposed to be tenderly moved by what is happening. What is happening is that someone is disposing of the dismembered body of the close family member they have just killed.

headline: Ariana Grande’s House-Groove Kiss-Off, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Lil Nas X, Waxahatchee, serpentwithfeet and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes), and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Snow Hits Iowa, Disrupting Final Campaign Days
abstract: A winter storm on Friday brought heavy snow, wind and dangerously low temperatures across the state.
lead_paragraph: A winter storm on Friday brought heavy snow, wind and dangerously low temperatures across the state.

headline: It’s a monster election year. Don’t let the horse race distract you.
abstract: Our institutions are in decline, and we need to pay attention.
lead_paragraph: I have no idea how I got to my office this morning. I mean, I do know: I walked to the tube station near my house, got on a train, transferred a few stops later to another one, got off near my office and then walked in, making the briefest of stops at a coffee shop to pick up a breakfast sandwich on the way.

headline: Inside Our 52 Places to Go List
abstract: This year’s 52 Places to Go list includes something for everyone — from remote villages to pristine waters to science centers to a region celebrating 150 years of Impressionism.
lead_paragraph: This year’s 52 Places to Go list includes something for everyone — from remote villages to pristine waters to science centers to a region celebrating 150 years of Impressionism.

headline: How to Prepare Your House for Extreme Winter Weather
abstract: Follow these steps to protect yourself and your home.
lead_paragraph: Here are steps to take to prepare for bitter cold, strong winds and other severe winter conditions.

headline: Why Are So Many Companies ‘Rightsizing’?
abstract: Various companies have used the term to describe job cuts, but some criticize the language as opaque.
lead_paragraph: Various companies have used the term to describe job cuts, but some criticize the language as opaque.

headline: The Regional War No One Wanted Is Here. How Wide Will It Get?
abstract: With the U.S.-led attacks in Yemen, there is no longer a question of whether the Israel-Hamas war will escalate into a wider conflict. The question is whether it can be contained.
lead_paragraph: From the outbreak of the Israeli-Hamas war nearly 100 days ago, President Biden and his aides have struggled to keep the war contained, fearful that a regional escalation could quickly draw in American forces.

headline: The Big Number: 171
abstract: Dozens of Boeing 737 Max 9s have been grounded since the accident on an Alaska Airlines flight last week.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of Boeing 737 Max 9s have been grounded since the accident on an Alaska Airlines flight last week.

headline: With Genocide Case Against Israel, South Africa Challenges Western-Led Order
abstract: After arguing its genocide case against Israel at the International Court of Justice, South Africa won praise for standing up for Palestinians under Israeli bombardment in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: After arguing its genocide case against Israel at the International Court of Justice, South Africa won praise among pro-Palestinian activists globally for standing up against Israel’s war in Gaza and what many saw as the interests of Western countries.

headline: C.I.A. Homes In on Hamas Leadership, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: A new task force at the spy agency is also working to boost intelligence collection on hostages still held in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The C.I.A. is collecting information on senior Hamas leaders and the location of hostages in Gaza, and is providing that intelligence to Israel as it carries out its war in the enclave, according to U.S. officials.

headline: The Story Ron DeSantis Does Not Tell Is His Own
abstract: Ron DeSantis has made lots of changes to try to revamp his struggling campaign. But he rarely tries talking about himself.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has a classic American dream story.

headline: Oregon Supreme Court Lets Trump Stay on Primary Ballot, for Now
abstract: The court denied a challenge to former President Donald J. Trump’s ballot eligibility under the 14th Amendment, saying it would wait for the U.S. Supreme Court to rule in a similar case.
lead_paragraph: Oregon’s Supreme Court said on Friday that former President Donald J. Trump could remain on the state’s 2024 primary election ballot, at least for now. The court opted to defer any decision on the merits of his eligibility until after the U.S. Supreme Court considers a similar challenge out of Colorado.

headline: 7 Great Songs From Great 7th Albums
abstract: Inspired by Ariana Grande’s return, hear tracks from U2, Sleater-Kinney, Guided by Voices and more.
lead_paragraph: The music video for “Yes, And?,” Ariana Grande’s first new solo single in more than three years, opens with a tight shot of a ruby-red business card bearing the phrase “ag7.” In modern pop parlance, this is a way of hinting that her seventh album is coming soon.

headline: Biden Administration to Fine Oil and Gas Companies for Excess Methane
abstract: A plan to impose a fee of $900 to $1,500 on every excess ton of methane emissions would be the first federal price on greenhouse gas pollution.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced new moves on Friday to curb the release from oil and gas facilities of methane, a potent greenhouse gas that is responsible for more than a quarter of the warming the planet is currently experiencing.

headline: Silent No More, Women’s Pros Make Mental Health a Priority
abstract: Elite soccer didn’t always welcome players’ requests for help. Scandals, attitudes and support programs are changing that.
lead_paragraph: The one thing she could not do, Sinead Farrelly knew, was talk. Nobody had ever told her that explicitly, of course. It was just something she understood. Soccer, her first time around, operated under what she can now call a “culture of silence.”

headline: Haley PAC Airs New Ad Calling DeSantis a Trump ‘Suck Up’
abstract: The ad draws on old photos and videos to portray Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida as a Trump acolyte.
lead_paragraph: A super PAC supporting Nikki Haley’s presidential campaign on Friday unveiled an advertisement in Iowa that accuses Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida of being a “suck up” to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Trump’s Dominance and Snowy Weather Put Iowa’s Caucus Economy on Ice
abstract: Republican candidates have spent heavily in Iowa, but the state is seeing fewer visitors, and winter storms have upended events and travel plans.
lead_paragraph: Even before a snowstorm brought Des Moines to a near standstill on Friday, the city felt decidedly more subdued than it usually does around the Iowa caucuses: quiet restaurants, empty streets, bartenders with little to do.

headline: An Editor Who Earned His Following
abstract: Joseph Lelyveld leaves behind a legacy of journalists motivated by the desire to be worthy of his trust.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Lelyveld, who worked as a reporter and editor at The New York Times for 39 years, the last seven of them as executive editor, died on Jan. 5. He was 86. Below, Bill Keller, who served as a managing editor under Mr. Lelyveld, and later as The Times’s executive editor from 2003 to 2011, remembers Mr. Lelyveld as a journalist.

headline: Man Killed Son in 1989, Then Staged Tearful TV Discovery, Officials Say
abstract: After a fresh investigation into the death of 5-year-old Justin Lee Turner, the South Carolina authorities have charged his father, Victor Lee Turner, and stepmother with murder.
lead_paragraph: After a 5-year-old South Carolina boy disappeared in South Carolina in 1989, a news camera rolled as his father appeared to discover his son’s strangled body inside a camping trailer on the family’s property.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case Over Homelessness Rules in Oregon
abstract: The case could have major implications for cities throughout the country grappling with a homelessness crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to hear a challenge to cities using local ordinances to enforce bans on public camping, a case that could reshape policy on homelessness for years to come.

headline: Chicago Warms New Migrants in Idling Buses as the Weather Turns Nasty
abstract: With snow and sleet falling on Friday and frigid air expected to follow, Mayor Brandon Johnson said the city would not leave anyone out in the cold.
lead_paragraph: Chicago could see its coldest temperatures since 2019 over the next few days, city officials said on Friday. Mayor Brandon Johnson said the city was ready to keep both residents and newly arrived migrants safe during the unusually brutal winter conditions.

headline: With Roe Gone, Some House Republicans Back Away From National Abortion Ban
abstract: Nearly three dozen House Republicans who supported a federal abortion ban in the last Congress have yet to sign on this year, reflecting a shifting political calculus after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, Representative Michelle Steel, a California Republican whose district President Biden won in 2020, cosponsored the Life at Conception Act, a bill to recognize a fertilized egg as a person with equal protections under the 14th Amendment.

headline: The Price of Carbon Emissions Plunged in 2022, and That’s Not Good
abstract: New data shed light on how difficult choices stemming from the war in Ukraine changed energy policy.
lead_paragraph: This chart, which hasn’t been published elsewhere, is disappointing. It shows a steep drop in 2022 in the global weighted average price per metric ton of carbon dioxide emissions:

headline: Why Bill Belichick’s Genius Can’t Be Replicated
abstract: The way this 24-year relationship came to an end tells us everything we need to know about why it succeeded.
lead_paragraph: When Robert Kraft traded a first-round draft pick to the New York Jets in 2000 in exchange for the right to hire Bill Belichick, N.F.L. insiders considered it “an awfully steep price,” as one put it, and a journalist mocked him for being “snookered.”

headline: Adams, Under Pressure, Drops Some of His School Cuts in Latest Reversal
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams said he would restore previously announced reductions in financing for schools that offer social services for low-income students.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams said on Friday that he would reverse a small portion of previously announced cuts to New York City’s education budget that would have slashed money for dozens of high-needs schools.

headline: At Sam’s Club, a Human Will No Longer Check Your Receipt at the Door
abstract: Instead, artificial intelligence technology will scan carts, the company says, eliminating annoying bottlenecks at the exit.
lead_paragraph: Buying things in bulk at wholesale retailers can be an all-day affair. Sam’s Club, the store chain owned by Walmart, is trying to make that time shorter: by using artificial intelligence to scan shoppers’ carts so they no longer have to show a receipt at the exit upon checking out.

headline: Former D.C. Police Officer Convicted of Selling Information About Crash Victims
abstract: Vincent Forrest made more than $15,000 in a bribery scheme, according to prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: A former patrol officer in Washington, D.C., was convicted on Thursday in a bribery scheme in which he sold private information about hundreds of traffic crash victims in exchange for payments that totaled more than $15,000, federal prosecutors said.

headline: E. Jean Carroll Doesn’t Want Trump to Make Defamation Trial a ‘Circus’
abstract: The writer next week will seek a second round of damages from the former president for his denials that he sexually assaulted her.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for the writer E. Jean Carroll, whose latest defamation lawsuit against Donald J. Trump is scheduled for trial next week in Manhattan, asked a judge Friday to ensure that if the former president testifies, that he does not stray beyond the narrow issue in the case, with the goal of “turning this trial into a circus.”

headline: Frigid Air Follows the Blizzard and Will Overtake the U.S.
abstract: Cold air is forecast to spread into the Deep South through the weekend, bringing freezing temperatures.
lead_paragraph: Daily high temperatures will struggle to get above zero in many parts of the central United States through the holiday weekend. Overnight lows will be even more frigid.

headline: Why Jan. 6 Wasn’t an Insurrection
abstract: Comparing the Capitol riot to the Beer Hall Putsch and the Whiskey Rebellion.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written several times about the case for disqualifying Donald Trump via the 14th Amendment, arguing that it fails tests of political prudence and constitutional plausibility alike. But the debate keeps going, and the proponents of disqualification have dug into the position that whatever the prudential concerns about the amendment’s application, the events of Jan. 6, 2021, obviously amounted to an insurrection in the sense intended by the Constitution, and saying otherwise is just evasion or denial.

headline: Three Festival Shows Explore Toxic Society
abstract: “Queens of Sheba” and “Volcano” at Under the Radar, and “Bacon,” at International Fringe Encore Series, expound on identity, captivity and violence.
lead_paragraph: Theater makes much of the element of catharsis, but rarely is a show purgative all the way through, as the choreopoem “Queens of Sheba” is. A celebration of Black women, and a ticked-off commiseration for all the nonsense thrown their way, it names a host of psychic poisons and puts them on display.

headline: Does Prenatal Testing for Down Syndrome Amount to Eugenics?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the moral concerns associated with certain medical exams.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I are planning on having children soon. We are very excited but also very scared, because we know that there is always a chance that our child comes with challenges, one of them being Down syndrome. We know that there are tests that can be done before the child is born that might tell us if he or she comes with any health challenges and allow us to terminate the pregnancy if we decide that we do not want the added responsibility (and medical bills). We’re worried this course of action might constitute practicing eugenics. Is this decision morally wrong? — Name Withheld

headline: Gaza is facing yet another communications blackout.
abstract: It is the ninth blackout the enclave has endured since the war began in early October.
lead_paragraph: The Gaza Strip was plunged into another communications blackout on Friday, with internet and phone service cut off for most of its more than two million residents as Israeli bombardment continued.

headline: Manchin, ‘Not Here Campaigning,’ Stirs 2024 Chatter in New Hampshire
abstract: The attention-seeking West Virginia senator, who has teased a late third-party presidential bid, tried to keep up the suspense at a Friday appearance in the state.
lead_paragraph: During an eyebrow-raising visit to New Hampshire on Friday, Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia name-checked friends who are elected officials in the Granite State and complimented the discerning nature of its voters.

headline: Reggie Wells, 76, Dies; Makeup Artist for Oprah Winfrey and Other Black Stars
abstract: At a time when cosmetic brands did not cater to Black women, Mr. Wells found a niche working with Black stars and models who had struggled to find makeup options for their skin tones.
lead_paragraph: Reggie Wells, who parlayed a background in fine art into a trailblazing career as a makeup artist for Oprah Winfrey, Whitney Houston, Beyoncé, Michelle Obama and other Black celebrities, died on Monday in Baltimore. He was 76.

headline: Tesla and Volvo to pause production in Europe after Red Sea attacks.
abstract: The carmakers said they would suspend production at their plants in Germany and Belgium because of supply chain snarls linked to the attacks in the Red Sea.
lead_paragraph: Tesla and Volvo said their assembly lines in Europe would be suspended in coming weeks because of attacks in the Red Sea that have forced cargo ships to take longer routes, disrupting supply chains.

headline: An Iowa Farmer Hopes G.O.P. Candidates Take on Carbon Pipeline
abstract: A proposed carbon pipeline could cut through Thomas Fehr’s Iowa farmland. He’s urging Republican candidates to take the issue seriously, and possibly earn his vote.
lead_paragraph: A proposed carbon pipeline could cut through Thomas Fehr’s Iowa farmland. He’s urging Republican candidates to take the issue seriously, and possibly earn his vote.

headline: 5 Alternative Uses for Yoga Blocks
abstract: It can do so much more than help you exercise.
lead_paragraph: It can do so much more than help you exercise.

headline: After Fake Basquiats, Orlando Museum Faces ‘Severe Financial Crisis’
abstract: The Orlando Museum of Art, which mounted a major Basquiat exhibition of works that were later exposed as forgeries, is facing a large shortfall amid high legal fees.
lead_paragraph: It was just days before Christmas, but Cathryn Mattson, the executive director of the Orlando Museum of Art, sounded anything but festive. During a specially called meeting, she addressed several trustees and influential donors, confronting the fallout from the institution’s last 18 months.

headline: DeSantis Adviser Continues Campaign’s Sharp Attack on Haley
abstract: Ron DeSantis’s deputy campaign manager accused Nikki Haley of “greed.” A Haley spokeswoman shot back, saying Mr. DeSantis would “say anything to distract from his flailing campaign.”
lead_paragraph: A top adviser to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Friday accused Nikki Haley of “greed” as a candidate, saying that she’s trying to damage him to help former President Donald J. Trump in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Microsoft Tops Apple to Become Most Valuable Public Company
abstract: The shift is indicative of the importance of new artificial intelligence technology to Silicon Valley and Wall Street investors.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Apple was the stock market’s undisputed king. It first overtook Exxon Mobil as the world’s most valuable public company in 2011 and held the title almost without interruption.

headline: House Spends $40,000 on New Member Pins as Republicans Fume Over Spending
abstract: Republicans, some of whom are threatening to shut down the government over excessive spending, ditched their identification pins a year early and bought new ones in different colors.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through a congressional session already set apart by extraordinary chaos and a lack of productivity, the Republican-led House rang in the new year with a new set of identification pins for every member that cost a cool $40,000, according to a congressional aide familiar with the purchase.

headline: Bradley Cooper, Paul Giamatti and Lily Gladstone Pick Up Awards in New York
abstract: The stars were among the 17 honorees at the annual National Board of Review gala, as awards season ramps up.
lead_paragraph: On a not-at-all red carpet inside Cipriani 42nd Street in Midtown Manhattan on Thursday night, Da’Vine Joy Randolph was glowing.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, January 14, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Robert Andrew Parker, 96, Dies; Prolific Magazine and Book Illustrator
abstract: His loose style of watercolor painting brought him work for nearly 70 years. He also created about 100 fake van Goghs for the biographical film “Lust for Life.”
lead_paragraph: Robert Andrew Parker, a prolific watercolorist whose impressionistic paintings illustrated books, album covers and magazines for nearly 70 years, and who continued to work into his 90s even though his vision was diminished by macular degeneration, died on Dec. 27 at his home in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 96.

headline: Howard Weaver, Who Helped an Alaska Newspaper Win 3 Pulitzers, Dies at 73
abstract: The Anchorage Daily News was the smallest newspaper and the first in the state to earn the medal for public service in 1976. It then won two more.
lead_paragraph: Howard Weaver, a self-described “poor kid from a shabby neighborhood,” was 24 years old and terrified when he was assigned by the floundering Anchorage Daily News to expose a rapacious chapter of the Teamsters union that was corruptly profiting from Alaska’s oil pipeline boom.

headline: Court Papers Offer Glimpse of Trump’s Defense in Classified Documents Case
abstract: The former president’s lawyers may question whether the documents he took from the White House were related to national defense and whether the country’s security was damaged.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump on Friday told the federal judge overseeing his prosecution on charges of mishandling classified documents that they intended to ask the government for new information, including assessments of any damage to national security.

headline: Biden Said the U.S. Is Ready to Strike in Yemen Again
abstract: Also, a Midwest blizzard snarled roads and airports. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, who last night approved air and naval strikes against dozens of targets in Yemen controlled by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia, said today that the U.S. would “make sure that we respond” if the Houthis continue to attack commercial ships in the Red Sea.

headline: This Year’s Iowa Caucuses are Ice-Cold
abstract: And it’s not just the sub-zero temperatures.
lead_paragraph: It’s the Friday before Caucus Day, and in any other year, Iowa would be humming: candidates racing across the state, answering questions in living rooms, coffee shops and high school gyms. Last-minute get-out-the-vote speeches. Volunteers knocking on doors and handing out leaflets on street corners and in shopping malls.

headline: Read the document
abstract: Read the document.
lead_paragraph: Read the document.

headline: Battered by Storms, Maine Picks Up the Pieces and Braces for More
abstract: Maine fears it is losing not just washed-out roads and missing piers, but key parts of its coastal identity.
lead_paragraph: As tiny towns and fishing ports along the coast of Maine picked up the pieces from Wednesday’s devastating storm — and braced for more damage from another bearing down — not all the losses they counted were financial.

headline: Trump Lawyer Reviewing ‘Salacious’ Allegations Against Georgia Prosecutors
abstract: The lawyer said the former president may join a motion accusing the lead prosecutors in the election interference case of being romantic partners and seeking to disqualify them.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s lawyer in Atlanta asked a judge on Friday for more time to review “salacious” allegations against two prosecutors leading the racketeering case against Mr. Trump, saying he may join an effort to disqualify them.

headline: North Jersey Towns, Already Swamped, Brace for More Heavy Rain
abstract: Several communities already flooded by a winter storm this week  prepared for another one Friday night .
lead_paragraph: Several New Jersey communities were bracing on Friday for more rain and flooding after a winter storm earlier in the week caused several rivers in the northern part of the state to overflow.

headline: U.F.O.s Remain a Mystery to Lawmakers After Classified Briefing
abstract: Members of the House went into a confidential briefing hoping for answers about what the government knows about alien life. They emerged with more questions.
lead_paragraph: Alien bodies allegedly hidden by the United States government. Suspected Pentagon cover-ups of secret spending programs. Retaliation against any official who dares speak out. Perhaps no congressional briefing offers up more titillating claims — or does less to illuminate them — than one about U.F.O.s.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Starbucks Bid to Overturn Labor Ruling
abstract: The coffee chain has challenged a federal judge’s order to reinstate a group of union activists who were fired at a store in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to hear a case brought by Starbucks challenging a federal judge’s order to reinstate seven employees who were fired at a store in Memphis amid a union campaign there.

headline: Biden Faults Austin for Judgment Lapse, but Says He Still Has Faith in Him
abstract: The Pentagon took days to tell the White House that the defense secretary had been hospitalized, raising grave questions about national security and the chain of command.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said on Friday that he maintained confidence in Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III, but faulted him for not notifying the White House for days this month about his hospitalization after complications from prostate cancer surgery.

headline: Phill Niblock, Dedicated Avant-Gardist of Music and Film, Dies at 90
abstract: Making music with no melody or rhythm and films with no plot, he became a darling of New York’s experimental underground.
lead_paragraph: Phill Niblock, an influential New York composer and film and video artist who opened new sonic terrain with hauntingly minimalist works incorporating drones, microtones and instruments as diverse as bagpipes and hurdy-gurdies, often accompanied by his equally minimalist moving images, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Federal Scientists Recommend Easing Restrictions on Marijuana
abstract: In newly disclosed documents, federal researchers find that cannabis may have medical uses and is less likely to cause harm than drugs like heroin.
lead_paragraph: Marijuana is neither as risky nor as prone to abuse as other tightly controlled substances and has potential medical benefits, and therefore should be removed from the nation’s most restrictive category of drugs, federal scientists have concluded.

headline: Jay Clayton, Vocal Innovator in Jazz and Beyond, Is Dead at 82
abstract: She sparred with avant-garde instrumentalists and used electronics to alter and extend her vocal palette. She was also at home in more conventional settings.
lead_paragraph: Jay Clayton, a singer whose six-decade career encompassed freewheeling improvisation, lyrical songs and poetry, and the prescient use of electronics, died on Dec. 31 at her home in New Paltz, N.Y. She was 82.

headline: Teenager Killed While ‘Subway Surfing’ in Brooklyn, Officials Say
abstract: Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said it was the second subway surfing death in the past two months.
lead_paragraph: A teenage boy was killed Friday afternoon in Brooklyn while riding on the outside of a subway train in a so-called subway surfing incident, transit officials said.

headline: Sotheby’s to Oligarch at Art Fraud Trial: The Buck Stopped With You
abstract: A Russian billionaire has accused the auction house of aiding a scheme that led him to hugely overpay for artworks. Sotheby’s said the billionaire had simply not done his homework.
lead_paragraph: Dmitry Rybolovlev survived the turmoil of the collapse of the Soviet Union, founded a bank in Russia in the 1990s and built a fortune of roughly $7 billion from the sale of a potash fertilizer company.

headline: Man Who Threatened Police With Ax Handle on Jan. 6 Gets Nearly 5 Years in Prison
abstract: William Chrestman of Olathe, Kan., a Proud Boys member, was sentenced to 55 months for breaching the U.S. Capitol and threatening officers, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A member of the Proud Boys extremist group who threatened police officers with an ax handle and breached the U.S. Capitol during the attack on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced on Friday to nearly five years in prison, federal prosecutors said.

headline: U.S. Strikes Against Houthis in Yemen for Second Day, as Conflict Escalates
abstract: The military fired at a target in response to rising attacks on Red Sea shipping, which the Houthis linked to the war between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: The United States carried out another strike against the Houthi militia in Yemen, the U.S. Central Command said on Friday night, bombing a radar facility as part of an effort to further degrade the Iran-backed group’s ability to attack ships transiting the Red Sea.

headline: FKA Twigs Assails ‘Double Standards’ After Her Calvin Klein Ad Is Banned in Britain
abstract: A British advertising watchdog agency said it was reviewing complaints about a new, similarly steamy Calvin Klein campaign featuring the actor Jeremy Allen White.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after a British advertising watchdog group ruled that Calvin Klein posters showing the singer FKA twigs with part of her breast exposed “presented her as a stereotypical sexual object” and could not be shown in Britain, the singer denounced “double standards” on Instagram, an apparent reference to a new Calvin Klein campaign featuring the actor Jeremy Allen White.

headline: DeSantis, Once a Darling of Conservative News Media, Now Rails Against It
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida appears to have turned on many of the news outlets that once promoted his candidacy for the G.O.P. nomination for being unfair in their coverage.
lead_paragraph: As the Iowa caucuses draw near, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has increasingly focused on a peculiar target as he looks to win the Republican nomination: the conservative news media ecosystem that supports former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Smitten
abstract: Hoang-Kim Vu’s latest themeless knocks solvers for a loop.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a really smooth, understated solve from Hoang-Kim Vu. It’s his second Saturday grid for The Times and ninth overall. He nimbly switches between themeless constructions like this one and themed puzzles, which might be flashier (I think his Monday puzzle from September was among the more memorable grids of 2023). However, this puzzle is loaded with charm — animal factoids, frothy love language, colorful expressions — and enough difficulty to make it satisfying to get through.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Food Delivery Workers, Overlooked in Life, Are Honored in Death
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 13, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “In the eyes of society, they don’t exist. They start to exist when you start to give them visibility.”

headline: U.S.-Led Strikes Leave Yemen Back on the Brink of War
abstract: Yemen’s Houthi militia, shaped by years of civil war, says that it welcomes a battle with the United States and that strikes will not stop its Red Sea attacks.
lead_paragraph: The explosions woke Ali Al-Sunaidar and his children in the middle of the night — a familiar feeling after years of war.

headline: Ecuador’s Attorney General Took on Drug Gangs. Then Chaos Broke Out.
abstract: Explosive revelations by the country’s top prosecutor showed links between cartels and officials, a move that might be “kicking the hornet’s nest.”
lead_paragraph: Just weeks before Ecuador descended into chaos, with prison riots, two escaped criminal kingpins and the brief siege of a television station, the country’s top prosecutor launched a major operation aimed at rooting out narco-corruption at the highest levels of government.

headline: In a Setback for Beijing, Taiwan Elects Lai Ching-te as President
abstract: Taiwan’s vice president, whose party has emphasized the island’s sovereignty, defeated an opposition party that favors reviving engagement with China.
lead_paragraph: The Taiwanese politician Lai Ching-te has for years been reviled by China’s Communist Party as a dangerous foe who, by its account, could drag the two sides into a war by pressing for full independence for his island democracy. Right up to Saturday, when millions of Taiwanese voted for their next president, an official Beijing news outlet warned that Mr. Lai could take Taiwan “on a path of no return.”

headline: ‘A Lifelong Nightmare’: Seeking Justice in India’s Overwhelmed Courts
abstract: With 50 million criminal and civil cases pending, it would take 300 years to clear the country’s judicial backlog.
lead_paragraph: When the armed men stormed into the village of lower-caste Indians, fanning out through its dirt lanes and flinging open the doors of its mud homes, Binod Paswan jumped into a grain silo and peered out in horror.

headline: Loyal to Their Soccer Team, and to Their Burger Van
abstract: As Premier League clubs create fan zones to collect yet more money from stadium visitors, a local economy of food trucks, pubs and small restaurants is holding its ground.
lead_paragraph: Surveying his territory, Tony Aujla is pleased. His business, after all, is all about location, and he has a prime one. Like a general surveying a battlefield, he points to his right: a short walk that way is Aston train station. Over to the left is Villa Park, with its grand, brick-lined facade, home of the city’s Premier League soccer team, Aston Villa.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 13, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the start of U.N. hearings on allegations of genocide against Israel brought by South Africa referred imprecisely to South Africa’s accusations. South Africa said Israel’s actions in Gaza against Palestinians were “genocidal in character,” not its actions against Hamas.

headline: Capping 5 Years of Speculation, Jacinda Ardern Gets Married
abstract: New Zealand’s pathbreaking former prime minister became a global celebrity noted for, among other things, a very long engagement.
lead_paragraph: She steered New Zealand through volcanic eruptions, terrorist attacks and a pandemic, won her party a record-breaking majority and, at age 37, became the world’s youngest female head of government.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How a Drag Performance Artist and Educator Spends Sundays
abstract: For Kelindah Schuster, who performs as Theydy Bedbug and helps people develop their own drag characters, Sundays are “a sacred day of rest.”
lead_paragraph: When Kelindah Schuster entered the Brooklyn drag scene, the idea of someone assigned female at birth performing high femme drag was controversial.

headline: Many Older Immigrants in New York Are Struggling: ‘I Have No Future’
abstract: Immigrants are the majority of New York City’s 65-and-over population. Many have no nest egg, and some are coping with social isolation.
lead_paragraph: Francisco Palacios, who grew up poor in Ecuador, came to New York City in 1986 so that he could earn enough to someday retire back home.

headline: Russia Targets Ukraine With Large-Scale Missile Attack
abstract: The assault was in line with a wider air campaign that Russia began in late December, seeking to wear down Ukrainian air defenses.
lead_paragraph: Russia attacked Ukraine with several waves of missiles on Saturday morning, the Ukrainian and Russian militaries said, putting the entire country under an air-raid alert and sending people rushing for shelter as bangs were heard in several cities.

headline: The Family Secrets Are Coming Out in This Queer Jewish Novel
abstract: In Temim Fruchter’s debut, “City of Laughter,” a grieving daughter dives into her ancestors’ hidden pasts to find closure and meaning in her own life.
lead_paragraph: Like desire and secrets, “laughter is no controlled substance,” Temim Fruchter writes in “City of Laughter,” her brainy and richly textured debut novel. “It goes where it wants to go.” Grief, too, is hard to contain. In the wake of both her father’s death and a difficult breakup, Fruchter’s 32-year-old heroine, Shiva Margolin, attempts to unravel 100 years of tangled generational trauma in order to find inner peace. The more complicated fate she ultimately embraces makes this unabashedly queer Jewish family story a new take on our uncertain age.

headline: In This Spy Novel, Business Is Very Much Personal
abstract: “Ilium,” by Lea Carpenter, follows a young woman torn between opposing forces in her double life.
lead_paragraph: The end of the Cold War may have been a godsend for the world, but it sure was a buzzkill for spy novelists. Once upon a time, the Soviet Union and its K.G.B. operatives were boogeymen that filled lengthy library shelves, and John le Carré, Ian Fleming and Robert Ludlum got generations of readers addicted to stories about them. Now, thanks in part to Vladimir Putin, the K.G.B. officer and aspiring Bond villain who ascended to President of Russia — a guy who, before invading Ukraine, was accused of executing an adversary with radioactive tea — the Russian boogeymen have returned.

headline: How to Call Off Your Wedding
abstract: Along with the emotional turmoil, there are logistics to navigate. Here are tips on what to do next from people who have been through it.
lead_paragraph: In February 2016, the parents of Dr. Tristan Lue’s fiancée flew in from Korea to meet his family for the first time. Dr. Lue, a dentist based in Edgewater, N.J., felt a sudden shift in his yearlong relationship. It became clear that his would-be in-laws did not approve of their union.

headline: Beverly Johnson, ‘the Model With the Big Mouth’
abstract: In her new one-woman show, she details her 50-year modeling career, her tumultuous relationships — and an unsettling encounter with Bill Cosby.
lead_paragraph: She was 18, new to New York, a tenderfoot in an industry said to eat its young. But Beverly Johnson was not short on brass.

headline: Their Songs Were Stolen by Phantom Artists. They Couldn’t Get Them Back.
abstract: Bad Dog, a group from D.C., was forced to take a crash course in streaming fraud, a shadowy realm that costs musicians $2 billion a year.
lead_paragraph: The guys in Bad Dog, a folkie duo from Washington, D.C., weren’t hoping to get rich off the album they recorded this summer.
