David Post and Craig Blackwell have been devoted amateurs for decades, and they’re long past dreams of tours and limos. Mostly they wanted a CD to give away at a house party in December.

headline: Mom’s in Rehab
abstract: And she’s not exactly following the rules.
lead_paragraph: It was January 2015, and all anyone could talk about was Ebola, Boko Haram, and Charlie Hebdo. I was 23, and I didn’t care about any of it. The world was ending? Of course the world was ending. My mom was gone. I was the one who sent her away.

headline: I’ve Got Bedbugs! How Do I Get Out of My Lease?
abstract: Breaking your lease comes with obvious risks, but they could be worth taking. On the other hand, you could help solve the infestation.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’ve been unable to live in my rent-stabilized apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, because of a bedbug infestation. The landlord hired an exterminator, who has come three times, but the bedbugs are still there. The exterminator said they might be resistant to the chemical spray. My lease isn’t up until September, and I want out of it, though I have a roommate. My landlord has refused, unless I get someone to take over the lease, but I can’t do that while it’s still infested. This experience has been mentally and financially debilitating. Is there a way out of the lease?

headline: Alina Cojocaru: A Freelance Ballerina, Forging Her Own Path
abstract: At 42, Cojocaru has no desire to stop dancing. Instead, she commissioned and is producing a ballet, “La Strada,” in which she will dance.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible for a great ballerina to take control of her destiny outside of a company and find fulfilling creative expression? Alina Cojocaru, a former principal dancer with the Royal Ballet and the English National Ballet, and an adored guest star at major companies worldwide, is certainly trying.

headline: After a Rip-Roaring 2023, the Markets Are Taking a Breather
abstract: The stock market’s long-term path has been persistently upward, our columnist says, but there have been plenty of setbacks and it’s wise to prepare for more.
lead_paragraph: It was a great year for the stock market and for the vast majority of investors in  workplace retirement accounts.

headline: This Language Was Long Believed Extinct. Then One Man Spoke Up.
abstract: Blas Jaime has spent nearly two decades resurrecting Chaná, an Indigenous language in Argentina that he learned from his mother.
lead_paragraph: As a boy, Blas Omar Jaime spent many afternoons learning about his ancestors. Over yerba mate and torta fritas, his mother, Ederlinda Miguelina Yelón, passed along the knowledge she had stored in Chaná, a throaty language spoken by barely moving the lips or tongue.

headline: The ‘Mean Girls’ Costume Designer Has Heard Your Complaints
abstract: Some people have roasted the outfits in the new film, but there were reasons the Plastics got a Gen Z spin. (Among them: social media, fast fashion and the pandemic.)
lead_paragraph: When fans first glimpsed outfits in the new adaptation of “Mean Girls,” they were not shy with feedback on the film’s pink miniskirts and mesh bustiers.

headline: Russia Regains Upper Hand in Ukraine’s East as Kyiv’s Troops Struggle
abstract: Ukrainians are weary, short of ammunition and outnumbered, and their prospects look bleak. “We can stop them for now, but who knows,” one soldier said. “Tomorrow or the next day, maybe we can’t stop them.”
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian soldier stared at the Russian tank. It was destroyed over a year ago in the country’s east and now sat far from the front line. He shrugged and cut into its rusted hull with a gas torch.

headline: ‘Succession’ Auctions Off ‘Ludicrously Capacious Bag’ and Other, Less Capacious Props
abstract: Bidding on memorabilia from the Emmy-winning drama ended on Saturday, drawing over $600,000 in total sales. A viciously mocked tote bag was among the auction’s most expensive items.
lead_paragraph: An auction house in Dallas that is usually stocked with fine art and rare baseball cards now holds a six-foot dog mascot suit last seen in Episode 1 of the HBO drama “Succession.” Audiences may recall a nauseated Cousin Greg (Nicholas Braun) putting on the costume and puking through its eyeballs.

headline: For Some Young People, a College Degree Is Not Worth the Debt
abstract: Because of high costs, some high school graduates have opted to delay, drop out of or forgo attending college altogether to avoid student debt that could hang over them for decades.
lead_paragraph: When Alex, my elder child, who identifies as nonbinary, was ready to apply for college in 2022, I felt ill-equipped to help them navigate the process. I was raised in a low-income household and had been unprepared to figure out how to make my own college experience affordable.

headline: Pikachu Just Wants to Help You Relax These Days
abstract: On Netflix’s “Pokémon Concierge,” the hyperactivity of the original gives way to soothing sights and tones that can help grown-up fans calm down.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Pokémon Resort, where you and your adorable pocket monster can indulge in such amenities as the spa, zip-lining and extreme yoga. If that sounds like paradise, then you’re probably in the target demographic for “Pokémon Concierge,” Netflix’s unassuming yet refreshing new stop-motion series.

headline: The Rise of the N.F.L.’s 2-Point Conversion: A Guide to Strategy
abstract: A look at the trends, the data and how to sound like an analyst wherever you watch the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. playoffs, which begin Saturday afternoon, will probably bring high-stakes moments around a simple decision: After a touchdown, should your team kick for one point, or go for two?

headline: Texas Says Its Power Grid Is Strong. It’s About to Get Tested.
abstract: State officials took steps to improve the grid after a disastrous failure in 2021. Demand for power next week is expected to break wintertime records.
lead_paragraph: Like many Texans, Jarrett Milton has been getting ready for the blast of freezing weather expected in the coming days. The owner of two food trucks near downtown Houston, Mr. Milton has coats for his workers and a stock of propane, extra firewood and lots of food.

headline: How a Polyamorous Mom Had ‘a Big Sexual Adventure’ and Found Herself
abstract: In her memoir, “More,” Molly Roden Winter recounts the highs and lows of juggling an open marriage with work and child care.
lead_paragraph: For anyone prone to experiencing secondhand embarrassment, there’s a scene in Molly Roden Winter’s debut, “More: A Memoir of Open Marriage,” that should come with a warning.

headline: On the Ballot in Iowa: Fear. Anxiety. Hopelessness.
abstract: As Monday’s caucuses approach, voters casually throw around the prospect of World War III and civil unrest, anxious of divisions they fear are tearing the country apart.
lead_paragraph: Presidential elections traditionally speak to future aspirations, offering a vision of a better tomorrow, the hope and change of Barack Obama or the compassionate conservatism of George W. Bush. Yet this year, even before a single vote has been cast, a far darker sentiment has taken hold.

headline: How to Watch the 75th Emmy Awards
abstract: TV’s top honors will finally be handed out on Monday, four months later than usual. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of the 75th Emmy Awards ceremony.

headline: A Russian Dissident’s Fraught Path to Canadian Citizenship
abstract: Maria Kartasheva was sentenced in absentia by a Moscow court for criticizing the war in Ukraine, threatening her citizenship application in Canada.
lead_paragraph: When Maria Kartasheva appeared at a Canadian citizenship ceremony last June, she thought she would be cutting up her permanent resident card and taking an oath. Instead, officials blocked her from participating, saying that her criminal charges in Russia, for criticizing the war in Ukraine, might disqualify her from citizenship.

headline: Emmys Night Is Finally Upon Us, but Who Will Watch?
abstract: The long-delayed ceremony may mark the end of an era for the show and for peak TV.
lead_paragraph: The nominations for the 75th annual Emmy Awards were announced on July 12, 2023. The next day, the Screen Actors Guild voted to go on strike, joining the Writers Guild of America in a work stoppage that shut down Hollywood for months. As a result of the strikes, the Emmys were postponed until January.

headline: Antihero Worship
abstract: The Emmy Awards are next week. Does it matter if you like the characters on the nominated shows?
lead_paragraph: The Emmy Awards are on Monday, after being postponed four months because of Hollywood’s labor disputes.

headline: U.N. Warns Gaza Is Heading for Famine as Specter of Wider War Looms
abstract: Officials of the Iran-backed Houthi militia in Yemen threatened to respond to American-led airstrikes over the past two days.
lead_paragraph: The twin specters of a widening regional war and intensified suffering of civilians loomed over the Middle East on Saturday, after the Iran-backed Houthi militia in Yemen threatened to respond to American airstrikes and a senior U.N. official warned that the humanitarian crisis in Gaza was hurtling toward famine.

headline: ‘A Broken Health Care System’ for Ill People and Their Caregivers
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay about caregiving by the wife of Ady Barkan, who died of A.L.S.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Makes Nikki Haley Tougher Than the Rest
abstract: She’s seen as a descendant of the Republican establishment, but she’s actually the kind of bruiser who’s in line with the current G.O.P. vibe.
lead_paragraph: Politics is a tough business, so you’d think most politicians would be tough people. In fact, in my experience, they’re often not. A lot of people go into politics because they want to be universally liked, and from Abraham Lincoln on down, many of them have detested personal confrontation. Several years ago it occurred to me that in every administration I had covered to that point — from Reagan through Obama — the White House staff seemed to fear the first lady more than they feared the commander in chief.

headline: To Reward or Punish: How the Culture Wars Came for Dogs
abstract: On the internet, everything is polarized — even dog training.
lead_paragraph: How you train your dog was once a fairly innocuous decision — to leash or not, to reward with treats or not. The internet changed that. Now training styles and methods can be as much about identity as efficacy: Are you imposing colonial concepts on your dogs? Are you harming their mental health? Is your style of training woke?

headline: The Things We Disagree on About Gaza
abstract: Readers challenge me on my criticism of Israel’s bombardment.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been very critical of Israel’s counterattack on Gaza, which appears to have killed a woman or child about once every eight minutes for the past three months. Many of my readers and friends disagree with these columns and are pained by what they see as my unfairness toward Israel.

headline: How to Thrive in an Uncertain World
abstract: It’s harder than ever to predict the future. That should be a positive to embrace.
lead_paragraph: A close friend’s daughter was getting married in the pandemic summer of 2021. “We can’t invite friends to the wedding,” in order to keep it small and safe, my pal told me. But she did invite friends, I learned from a Facebook post. Just not me. Feeling humiliated, I initially kept quiet. But being together grew awkward and I sensed a growing distance. And when I tried to discuss the widening rift, she called a “pause” in our relations by text and stopped reaching out for a year.

headline: The Necessary Risk of America’s Military Strikes in Yemen
abstract: Given the increasingly critical threat the Houthis pose to the freedom of commerce and navigation in the Red Sea, the United States had to act.
lead_paragraph: By striking Houthi rebel targets in Yemen with Britain on Thursday, Washington sent a searing message to both the Houthis and its Iranian backers that the United States has ended its longstanding defense-only posture in the Red Sea and is determined to stop the group’s attacks against commercial ships in regional waters.

headline: Here Comes Trump, the Abominable Snowman
abstract: The truth and the media are slip-sliding around in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: It’s the latest hot TV genre: a woman in a frigid outpost, bundled in puffy outerwear, trying to uncover truths buried in ice.

headline: The DeSantis Campaign Is Revealing What Republican Voters Really Want
abstract: The G.O.P. coalition is poised to choose irresistible theater over a more effective but lower-drama alternative.
lead_paragraph: If Ron DeSantis surprises in Iowa and beyond, if he recovers from his long polling swoon and wins the Republican nomination, it will represent the triumph of a simple, intuitive but possibly mistaken idea: that voters should be taken at their word about what they actually want from their leaders.

headline: What’s Going On in There?
abstract: The reality of a situation is often more interesting on the inside.
lead_paragraph: Often, we see someone’s situation from the outside and think we know exactly what’s going on. In this episode, stories that go inside a situation and uncover just how much more interesting the reality is.

headline: 2 Novels About What’s-Their-Name
abstract: Not all books tell readers what to call the main character. An editor recommends two that don’t.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: D.E.I. Goes Quiet
abstract: As corporate diversity, equity and inclusion programs come under attack, some companies are rebranding their efforts.
lead_paragraph: Joelle Emerson’s D.E.I. consultancy, Paradigm, works with more than 500 companies. The growing backlash against D.E.I., she said, “is usually the first agenda item on every call.”

headline: Chicago’s Latest Attraction? A Rat-Shaped Hole.
abstract: A decades-old hole in the sidewalk has recently drawn millions of views online and inspired Chicagoans to visit and even make offerings. No one knows where it came from.
lead_paragraph: Winslow Dumaine was heading to a store on Chicago’s North Side when he saw it: a hole in the sidewalk on Roscoe Street with an uncanny resemblance to a rodent.

headline: Lloyd Austin Confronts the Perils of Being a Private Man in a Public Job
abstract: President Biden said his defense secretary made an error in judgment in not keeping the White House informed of his hospitalization. But keeping a low profile has long defined the Pentagon chief.
lead_paragraph: For three years, President Biden has been just fine with the private nature of his media-shy, introverted defense secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III.

headline: China Failed to Sway Taiwan’s Election. What Happens Now?
abstract: Beijing loathes the new president, Lai Ching-te. He aims to protect the status quo with caution and American help, but tensions are likely to rise.
lead_paragraph: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, has tied his country’s great power status to a singular promise: unifying the motherland with Taiwan, which the Chinese Communist Party sees as sacred, lost territory. A few weeks ago, Mr. Xi called this a “historical inevitability.”

headline: Go Fish (and Tofu and Beans and Grains)
abstract: Poke bowls, glazed tofu with chile and star anise, and braised white beans with greens make it easy to keep those cooking resolutions going strong.
lead_paragraph: If one of your 2024 resolutions is to cook more fish, you’ve probably already trawled New York Times Cooking’s recipe collections for foolproof fish and easy weeknight salmon. And if your resolution is simply to eat more fish — not necessarily to cook it — there’s this new recipe for poke bowls from Naz Deravian. It’s a wonderful way to let a beautiful piece of fish shine while mingling with all sorts of delicious friends: cucumber, avocado, radish, pickled ginger. Poke piqued your attention? Try these other recipes for raw fish: Ali Slagle’s crispy rice with salmon and avocado, and a new one from the chef Sheldon Simeon for hamachi sashimi with ginger ponzu.

headline: Coast to Coast, a Brutal Mix of Snow, Rain and Bitter Cold
abstract: More than 40 million Americans were under winter weather advisories on Saturday, with blizzards in the Midwest, flooding in the Northeast and freezing temperatures across much of the country.
lead_paragraph: Residents in Billings, Mont., woke up to a temperature of minus 25 degrees Fahrenheit. In Des Moines, homeowners were digging out snow and facing wind gusts of 45 miles per hour. Residents in Paterson, N.J., were evacuated from flooded homes. And communities near the Gulf Coast were preparing for a deep freeze.

headline: After Years of Delays, Amtrak Moves Toward Faster Trains in the Northeast
abstract: A new train for the busy Washington to Boston route has finally passed a computer modeling test and is set for tryouts on the tracks. Amtrak has no date yet for when it can carry passengers.
lead_paragraph: After years of delays and safety and design disputes, Amtrak is one step closer to bringing new high-speed trains to the busy Northeast Corridor.

headline: What Inspires Peter Capaldi: Vermeer, ‘Demon Copperhead,’ ‘The Wire’
abstract: Seeing “A Maid Asleep” at the Met, he said, “without wishing to sound pretentious about it, it was the first picture that I developed a relationship with.”
lead_paragraph: Sometimes it pays to stick close to home.

headline: Subzero Temperatures Are Set to Make Iowa’s Caucuses the Coldest in History
abstract: Temperatures are not forecast to rise above minus 2 degrees on Monday, and by the time caucusing begins, the wind chill could make it feel more like minus 35 degrees.
lead_paragraph: When Iowa voters brave frigid weather to caucus on Monday, they will be participating in one of the coldest caucuses in decades — perhaps ever.

headline: Much of Houthis’ Offensive Ability Remains Intact After U.S.-Led Airstrikes
abstract: The strikes damaged the group’s ability to carry out complex missile and drone attacks, U.S. officials said, but identifying targets has proved to be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: The United States-led airstrikes on Thursday and Friday against sites in Yemen controlled by the Houthi militia damaged or destroyed about 90 percent of the targets struck, but the group retained about three-quarters of its ability to fire missiles and drones at ships transiting the Red Sea, two U.S. officials said on Saturday.

headline: In Iowa, Nikki Haley Has the Attention of Democrats and Independents
abstract: Ms. Haley has attracted the interest of non-Republicans who say they’ll caucus for her, as rivals attack her for an insufficiently conservative message.
lead_paragraph: With temperatures threatening to dip below zero in Iowa on Monday, some of the voters preparing to caucus for Nikki Haley have already overcome a different hurdle: a long history of voting for Democrats.

headline: John Kerry Bows Out as U.S. Climate Envoy
abstract: Mr. Kerry, 80, is expected to work on President Biden’s re-election campaign to stress the administration’s climate achievements.
lead_paragraph: John Kerry, President Biden’s special envoy for climate, plans to step down by spring, ending a three-year run in a major diplomatic role that was created especially for him and which will face an uncertain future with his departure.

headline: Two SEAL Team Members Missing After Incident Off Somalia Coast
abstract: The sailors were said to have disappeared into the water after a vessel boarding attempt. Pentagon officials said the episode was not related to recent clashes with the Houthi militia in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: Two members of the Navy SEALs remained missing on Saturday after a mishap two days ago while they were attempting to board a ship off the coast of Somalia, two current and two former Pentagon officials said.

headline: Leon Wildes, 90, Immigration Lawyer Who Defended John Lennon, Dies
abstract: Battling the government for more than three years, he was able to prove that the Nixon White House was trying to deport the former Beatle for political reasons.
lead_paragraph: Leon Wildes, a New York immigration lawyer who successfully fought the United States government’s attempt to deport John Lennon, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Four Stories From 52 Places
abstract: Each year, The New York Times Travel desk relies on its globe-trotting contributors to nominate the Places to Go. Four journalists share the stories behind their selections.
lead_paragraph: This year’s list of 52 Places to Go from The New York Times Travel desk features destinations for every kind of globe-trotter. Some places that made the list will usher in extraordinary events in 2024. Paris, for one, is hosting the 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games; Mexico, Canada and 13 U.S. states will offer paramount views of the total solar eclipse crossing North America this spring. Other destinations, like Morocco and Maui, Hawaii, are hoping to welcome back visitors after devastating natural disasters last year.

headline: Quaker Oats Recalls More Products Over Potential Salmonella Contamination
abstract: Several cereals, granola bars and other snack foods were recalled in December. The company added more products to the list this week.
lead_paragraph: The Quaker Oats Company added more products this week to a recall that started last month over possible salmonella contamination, raising the total number of products to more than 60.

headline: Lawsuit Challenging University of California’s D.E.I. Statements Is Tossed
abstract: A federal judge ruled that the plaintiff, who said the diversity statements act as a “functional loyalty oath,” did not have standing.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge threw out a lawsuit that challenged the University of California system’s requirement that applicants for faculty positions must file diversity statements.

headline: Er, In Other Words
abstract: John Kugelman’s puzzle gives a solver pause.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: How Do the Iowa Caucuses Work?
abstract: The Iowa caucuses will be the first time that Republican voters get to decide between the candidates in the field. Astead Herndon, host of The New York Times podcast “The Run-Up,” explains how the caucuses work.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa caucuses will be the first time that Republican voters get to decide between the candidates in the field. Astead Herndon, host of The New York Times podcast “The Run-Up,” explains how the caucuses work.

headline: Extreme Weather Batters Cities Across America
abstract: Millions of Americans were under winter weather warnings, as blizzards and freezing temperatures hammered the Midwest and flooding inundated the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans were under winter weather warnings, as blizzards and freezing temperatures hammered the Midwest and flooding inundated the Northeast.

headline: In Race to Replace George Santos, Financial Questions Re-emerge
abstract: Mazi Pilip, the Republican candidate running in New York’s Third District, drew scrutiny after her initial financial disclosure was missing required information.
lead_paragraph: The Republican nominee in a special House election to replace George Santos in New York provided a hazy glimpse into her personal finances this week, submitting a sworn financial statement to Congress that prompted questions and led her to amend the filing.

headline: Peter Crombie, a Menacing Presence on ‘Seinfeld,’ Dies at 71
abstract: He had an impressive list of acting credits. But he was probably best known for playing “Crazy” Joe Davola on five episodes of the hit sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Peter Crombie, an actor who was probably best known for his memorable portrayal of “Crazy” Joe Davola on five episodes of the hit sitcom “Seinfeld,” died on Wednesday in a health care facility in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 71.

headline: Trump Turns on Ramaswamy Just Days Before the Iowa Caucuses
abstract: Ramaswamy, the wealthy entrepreneur, had been the Republican candidate most closely aligned with Mr. Trump before the former president recently went on the attack.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump attacked Vivek Ramaswamy, who is most closely aligned with him in the race for the Republican nomination, accusing the wealthy entrepreneur of engaging in “deceitful campaign tricks.”

headline: Trump Far Ahead, With Haley Edging DeSantis for Second, Key Iowa Poll Finds
abstract: The Iowa Poll, one of the most closely watched political surveys in the country, showed Donald Trump with 48 percent, Nikki Haley at 20 percent and Ron DeSantis at 16 percent.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has the backing of 48 percent of likely caucusgoers ahead of Monday’s election, a commanding lead for the former president, according to the Iowa Poll by The Des Moines Register, NBC News and Mediacom.

headline: Whisky From Wales? Believe It, Say the Welsh.
abstract: It is no simple task to get an official seal of approval for a bottle of Welsh spirits. Persuading purists to give it a try may also be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: It is famed for a love of singing and a passion for rugby. It has a distinctive Celtic language and is the birthplace of the poet Dylan Thomas. But few would claim that Wales, a nation of three million people outnumbered by sheep, is well known for whiskey, or whisky, as it is known in Wales.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 14, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about U.S. missile strikes against Houthi targets in Yemen misstated when Abdul-Malik al-Houthi spoke about a confrontation with the United States. It was on Thursday, not Wednesday.

headline: U.S. Releases Navy Officer Imprisoned After Causing Fatal Crash in Japan
abstract: Lt. Ridge Alkonis, who was sentenced to three years in prison in Japan after a traffic accident in 2021, was moved to a U.S. prison last month.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Ridge Alkonis, a Navy officer, was released from prison on Friday, about a month after he was transferred to the United States following his conviction in Japan for causing a deadly traffic accident, a case that had strained relations between the two countries.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Fishing for Scallops When the Scallops Are Nearly All Dead
abstract: Bay scallops brought prosperity and community to the people of Shelter Island. Today, most of the scallops are gone, but some fishermen haven’t given up hope.
lead_paragraph: Mike Tehan pilots a fishing boat called Nibbles out of Shelter Island. An hour before sunrise on the first day of scallop season in November, as he unwound the ropes, started the outboard motor and piloted the 25-foot fiberglass boat from an island cove into the open waters of Peconic Bay, Mr. Tehan knew just what he’d find.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: ‘My Husband and I Went to a Diner on Broadway for Breakfast’
abstract: An encounter with a loud talker, unplugged on the subway and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Hit Men Are Easy to Find in the Movies. Real Life Is Another Story.
abstract: Many attempted murder plots, whether instigated by amateurs or professionals, are marred by ineptitude, experts say, despite what happens in “Goodfellas” and “The Sopranos.”
lead_paragraph: It’s a scene as old as celluloid: a shadowy figure named Luca Brasi or John Wick or Barry Berkman lurking in the darkness, outfitted with sinister intent and nifty weapons, effortlessly committing a murder for cash, animus or cold political calculations.

headline: Investigators Find Hospital Error Caused Mother’s Death in Brooklyn
abstract: Christine Fields, a 30-year-old Black woman, bled to death after giving birth at Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn. State investigators said the cause was a doctor’s mistake.
lead_paragraph: Investigators with the New York State Department of Health have concluded that a troubling lapse by a surgical team at a hospital in Brooklyn resulted in the recent death of a 30-year-old mother who gave birth by cesarean section, according to a document obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Picking Pockets, Moving Fast and Working Hard: the History of ‘Hustling’
abstract: The word “hustle” was first recorded in the 17th century. In the 20th, it took on an economic context in African American communities.
lead_paragraph: In 1892, The New York Times printed an account from a reporter in St. Petersburg, Russia. The reporter said Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich, posing as a “peasant,” got into a “squabble with a baker.” Not knowing who he was, police officers “hustled” the duke. They were about to arrest him when he revealed his identity.

headline: A Few Words About Netflix’s Success: Vivid. Snappy. Tags.
abstract: The descriptive tags that the streaming service runs near each title — like “slick” for the show “Suits” — have proved crucial to getting people to click play.
lead_paragraph: “Grey’s Anatomy” is “soapy” and “emotional.” “Emily in Paris” is “campy” and “quirky.” “Our Planet II” is “relaxing” and “captivating,” while “Gravity” is “suspenseful” and “visually striking.”

headline: ‘Would a Call From Tammy Help?’ Pressure Grows in Race to Oust Menendez
abstract: In a series of calls, a person in contact with the Senate campaign of Gov. Philip Murphy’s wife pressured a student Democratic group not to endorse her chief rival in the New Jersey race.
lead_paragraph: The College Democrats of New Jersey were preparing to make an endorsement in one of the country’s most closely watched U.S. Senate primaries when calls began to come in from someone in touch with the campaign of Tammy Murphy, the presumptive front-runner and the wife of the state’s governor.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Flickers of Hope Amid a Scallop Die-Off
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “So we’re averaging half a scallop per dredge. That’s not going to pay the bills.”

headline: Volcano Erupts in Iceland, Sending Lava Flowing Into Small Town
abstract: The latest eruption happened along a row of volcanoes on the Reykjanes Peninsula, where a fissure opened in December, creating a river of lava.
lead_paragraph: A volcano in Iceland erupted on Sunday, after hundreds of earthquakes shook the Reykjanes Peninsula, cracking open a fissure that sent lava spewing into a residential neighborhood for the first time in more than four decades.

headline: How Taiwan’s Election Fits Into the Island’s Past, and Its Future
abstract: Tensions over the island’s status have flared repeatedly for decades, especially as Washington’s relationship with China has grown more strained.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan’s election on Saturday has big implications not only for the 23 million people who live on the island, but also for China’s superpower rivalry with the United States.

headline: A Canadian Short Story Master Comes to the U.S.
abstract: The anthology “Burn Man” selects from decades of Mark Anthony Jarman’s work, bringing the writer’s lush and searing stories to new readers.
lead_paragraph: Many writers are content to light one or two well-placed lyrical firecrackers in a short story. Others, like Mark Anthony Jarman, set off entire fireworks displays on every page. “Propane slept in the tank and propane leaked while I slept, blew the camper door off and split the tin walls where they met like shy strangers kissing,” opens the visceral “Burn Man on a Texas Porch,” the first entry in “Burn Man,” an anthology of 21 stories culled from Jarman’s four-decade career. The rest of the story is, like many of Jarman’s tales, a hallucinatory rummaging through the mind of a broken man. After receiving skin grafts that “didn’t quite fit,” the narrator fumes: “Hate is everything they said it would be, and it waits for you like an airbag.” In Jarman’s stories and sentences, things seem always ready to explode.

headline: Can You Escape the Algorithm? ‘Filterworld’ Gives It a Try.
abstract: An experiment in digital disengagement prompts Kyle Chayka to consider how technology has narrowed our choices and dulled the culture.
lead_paragraph: This dispatch began from an uptown location of Dig (formerly Dig Inn), a small chain of “fast casual” restaurants headquartered in New York City. The walls are white-painted brick, the tables are marble and the cardboard bowls are packed with colorful, healthy foodstuffs. Only the insipid pop music that blares through the speakers discourages lingering.

headline: How to Win More Games Than Anyone
abstract: At 70, Tara VanDerveer will soon be the most successful college basketball coach of all time. She believes in experimentation, asking for help, and the art of the controlled meltdown.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the next few weeks, when she wins her 1,203rd game, Tara VanDerveer at Stanford will pass Mike Krzyzewski at Duke as the college basketball coach — man or woman — with the most wins of all time.

headline: How College-Educated Republicans Learned to Love Trump Again
abstract: Blue-collar white voters make up Donald Trump’s base. But his political resurgence has been fueled largely by Republicans from the other end of the socioeconomic scale.
lead_paragraph: Working-class voters delivered the Republican Party to Donald J. Trump. College-educated conservatives may ensure that he keeps it.

headline: Is Israel Part of What It Means to Be Jewish?
abstract: Some progressive Jews are embracing “diasporism” — reimagining their faith as one that blesses their lives in America and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Last month, on the first night of Hanukkah, more than 200 people packed an old ballroom on the third floor of a restored synagogue in Brooklyn. A few came fresh off the subway from a protest in Manhattan that was organized by left-wing Jewish groups calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: ‘Mean Girls’ and the New (Home-Schooled) Kid in Class
abstract: As our critic knows, missing out on the shared experience of school is deeply strange. It’s something Hollywood rarely acknowledges, except in these films.
lead_paragraph: The original 2004 movie “Mean Girls” contained something unusual, both then and now: a main character who was home-schooled. But not that kind of home-schooled.

headline: How This Climate Activist Justifies Political Violence
abstract: “The reason that people contemplate escalation is that there are no risk-free options left,” says the author of "How to Blow Up a Pipeline."
lead_paragraph: “The reason that people contemplate escalation is that there are no risk-free options left,” says the author of "How to Blow Up a Pipeline."

headline: Why the Definition of ‘Extreme Cold’ Is Different in Duluth and Dallas
abstract: “Everyone’s extreme is a different level,” said a meteorologist in Minnesota, which is much more familiar with subzero conditions than much of the U.S.
lead_paragraph: With a mass of frigid Arctic air descending on much of the United States this upcoming week, meteorologists and public health officials are well aware that a North Dakotan and a South Texan are unlikely to agree on what amounts to “extreme cold.”

headline: The Whale Who Went AWOL
abstract: Hvaldimir escaped captivity and became a global celebrity. Now, no one can agree about what to do with him.
lead_paragraph: On April 26, 2019, a beluga whale appeared near Tufjord, a village in northern Norway, immediately alarming fishermen in the area. Belugas in that part of the world typically inhabit the remote Arctic and are rarely spotted as far south as the Norwegian mainland. Although they occasionally travel solo, they tend to live and move in groups. This particular whale was entirely alone and unusually comfortable around humans, trailing boats and opening his mouth as though expecting to be fed. And he seemed to be tangled in rope.

headline: 7 Numbers That Tell the Tale of the G.O.P. Primary
abstract: There’s $46,499,124.63. There’s 3 percent. Here are five other figures that shed light on the dynamics at play before Monday’s caucuses.
lead_paragraph: The only numbers that will truly matter in the Iowa caucuses on Monday will be the number of votes tallied for Donald J. Trump, Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley and Vivek Ramaswamy.

headline: California Has Dealt a Blow to Renewable Energy, Some Businesses Say
abstract: Some companies are leaving the state or reducing their presence there after California greatly reduced incentives for homeowners to install rooftop solar panels.
lead_paragraph: California has long championed renewable energy, but a change in the state’s policies last year has led to a sharp decline in the installation of residential rooftop solar in the state.

headline: War or No War, Many Older Ukrainians Want to Stay Put
abstract: The front line in Ukraine is largely peopled by the elderly these days. Some can’t afford to get out. Others say they won’t abandon their homes.
lead_paragraph: They sit in ones and twos in half-destroyed homes. They shelter in musty basements marked in chalk with “people underground” — a message to whichever troops happen to be fighting that day. They venture out to visit cemeteries and reminisce about any time other than now.

headline: New Leader Set to Take Over in Guatemala, Raising Hopes for a Fragile Democracy
abstract: Bernardo Arévalo, an anticorruption crusader, had to fight to make it to Sunday’s inauguration. His challenges are just beginning.
lead_paragraph: Since Bernardo Arévalo burst onto Guatemala’s political scene last year as an anticorruption crusader, he has faced an assassination plot, his party’s suspension and a barrage of legal attacks aimed at preventing him from taking office as president.

headline: ​North Korea Test-Fires Intermediate-Range Ballistic Missile
abstract: The launch, the first by the North this year, indicates that the country may be developing a new missile that could threaten U.S. military bases in the region.
lead_paragraph: North Korea launched an intermediate-range ballistic missile off its east coast on Sunday, an indication, analysts said, that it has started testing a new and harder-to-intercept weapon capable of reaching American military bases in the Western Pacific, including those on Guam.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘How an Ordinary Football Game Turns Into the Most Spectacular Thing on TV’
abstract: Months of preparation, hundreds of workers, convoys of cutting-edge gear: inside the machine that crafts prime time’s most popular entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Arrowhead Stadium, the home of the Kansas City Chiefs, the N.F.L.’s defending champions, is a very loud place. During a 2014 game, a sound meter captured a decibel reading equivalent to a jet’s taking off, earning a Guinness World Record for “Loudest crowd roar at a sports stadium.”

headline: Dangerous Subzero Wind Chills Blanket Much of the U.S.
abstract: More than 100 million people were under a wind chill warning or advisory on Sunday as an “Arctic blast” blanketed the country. Two people were killed in Oregon after trees fell on their homes.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 million people in the United States were under a wind chill warning or advisory on Sunday as an “Arctic blast” enveloped huge parts of the country, while the South was expected to get snow and the Northeast braced for blinding wind-driven squalls, forecasters said.

headline: As War Enters 100th Day, Netanyahu Vows to Keep Fighting in Gaza
abstract: The prime minister of Israel struck a defiant tone after hearings at The Hague, where Israel has been accused of genocide.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel struck a defiant tone in marking 100 days of war against Hamas in Gaza, vowing to keep fighting despite growing uncertainty over the outcome, international alarm over the mounting loss of life in the enclave and fears of a broader regional conflagration.

headline: It’s Dangerously Cold in Iowa. What Does That Mean for Voting?
abstract: The state’s historic weather is upending plans for everyone — candidates, reporters and voters.
lead_paragraph: Iowa is in a deep freeze. Subzero temperatures — and a blizzard — have thrown many of the weekend’s highly choreographed events into question, leaving observers wondering if the weather could alter the election results. In this audio report from the frozen Hawkeye State, the Opinion writer Katherine Miller describes what it’s like to cover the caucuses and considers how the inclement weather might affect voting.

headline: Rebooting a Classic
abstract: Nearly 20 years after “Mean Girls” was released, a new version is in theaters.
lead_paragraph: There’s a stickiness to “Mean Girls” quotes. For a certain generation, long passages can be plucked from the mind and performed, cadence-perfect, on demand. As a child, I watched the movie over and over on DVD, and the words wormed their way into my impressionable mind.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 22, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Who Is Lai Ching-te, Taiwan’s Next President?
abstract: A former doctor with a humble background, Mr. Lai is seen as more attuned to the mood of Taiwan’s people than to the perilous nuances of dealing with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, when Lai Ching-te was a rising political star in Taiwan, he visited China and was quizzed in public about the most incendiary issue for leaders in Beijing: his party’s stance on the island’s independence.

headline: At Least 5 People Die Trying to Cross Icy English Channel
abstract: French authorities said that a ship carrying migrants trying to reach Britain had been “reported in difficulty” off the coast of northern France. More than 30 people were rescued.
lead_paragraph: At least five people died in icy waters off a beach in northern France early Sunday as they tried to traverse the English Channel to Britain, the latest in a string of tragedies in recent years that have underlined the inability of governments on both sides of the waterway to deter attempts of the perilous crossing.

headline: Martin Luther King Jr. Wasn’t a Lone Messiah
abstract: He built a movement more collaboratively than history gives him credit for.
lead_paragraph: Almost 56 years after his death, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. stands apart from the other civil rights leaders of the 20th century. He was the most visible, the most frequently heard and seen on television and, in many ways, the most creative in his approach to fighting American apartheid. King loomed so large in his time that he fueled the F.B.I. director J. Edgar Hoover’s paranoia that a Black messiah would emerge to provoke this nation’s oppressed Black masses to revolution.

headline: What Nikki Haley — and I — Learned at a Segregation Academy
abstract: What segregation academies taught the governor of South Carolina — and me — about slavery.
lead_paragraph: After her failure to identify slavery as the cause of the Civil War generated a wave of criticism last month, Nikki Haley assured her potential constituents that she had Black friends and that she understood the war’s origins. She said that in South Carolina, “literally in second and third grade, you learn about slavery.” Conveniently producing Black friends is, alas, not surprising, but claiming she learned that the Civil War was a battle over slavery in second and third grade is.

headline: Why This Could Be a Dangerous Year for the Iowa Caucuses
abstract: The political rules in the state were already convoluted, but judging this year’s results may be unusually difficult.
lead_paragraph: Ah, the Iowa caucuses. So much drama. So much antici … pation. So much money and energy spent on an antidemocratic process in a state with a pretty dismal track record of picking presidential nominees.

headline: A Strongman President? These Voters Crave It.
abstract: Authoritarian leaders project qualities that many voters — not just Trump voters — admire.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl Sharp, a 47-year-old sales associate who was among the many Iowans turned away from a filled-to-capacity Trump rally last month, sounded pretty confident she knew why Donald Trump was so appealing to many voters. For her and many others, she said, his most important quality was strength: He had the fortitude to keep the country safe, avoid new wars and ensure the economy hummed along.

headline: This Is the Actual Danger Posed by D.E.I.
abstract: The problem is when admirable goals are pursued through illiberal or unconstitutional means.
lead_paragraph: There are few national conversations more frustrating than the fight over D.E.I. Short for “diversity, equity and inclusion,” the term — like the related progressive concepts of wokeness and critical race theory — used to have an agreed-upon meaning but has now been essentially redefined on the populist right. In that world, D.E.I. has become yet another catchall boogeyman, a stand-in for actual policies and practices designed to increase diversity, as well as a scapegoat for unrelated crises.

headline: Cheered by Thousands, Denmark’s New King Takes His Throne
abstract: The prime minister publicly presented the new monarch, King Frederik X, after his mother formally completed her abdication as queen in a private meeting.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people gathered on the streets of Copenhagen to celebrate the accession of Denmark’s new king, Frederik X, on Sunday, just two weeks after his mother, Queen Margrethe II, made the dramatic announcement that she would abdicate.

headline: The Top-Reviewed Chicken Recipe in Our Cooking Database
abstract: I’ve been making my five-star oven-roasted chicken shawarma for decades.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Recipes are sheet music. Cooks are musicians. They interpret the notes differently; they play the chords differently. Arrangements can change on the fly. My Boston baked beans taste different from Amanda Hesser’s now that I’ve made the dish a gajillion times. They’re both excellent, though. They’re both the same recipe.

headline: Larry Hogan Backs Nikki Haley for G.O.P. Presidential Nomination
abstract: The former governor of Maryland, a moderate Republican, said that he thinks “Nikki Haley’s got all the momentum.”
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland, a moderate Republican who decided not to enter the party’s presidential primary last year but has not ruled out a third-party run, backed Nikki Haley on Sunday as the anti-Trump minority of the G.O.P. coalesces around her.

headline: Review: A Dance Duo’s Committed High Jinks Interruptus
abstract: Lisa Fagan and Lena Engelstein’s picaresque “Deepe Darknesse” models itself on the randomness of an ancient Roman novel, “The Golden Ass.”
lead_paragraph: A woman in a sparkly red dress makes a grand gesture. Then she notices that she’s being watched and suddenly looks like a squirrel that has realized it isn’t alone. She tries to make another grand gesture only to be stymied when the Bubble Wrap under her feet pops. Soon she is joined by a woman in a sparkly black dress who seems trapped in the same situation, reaching for elegance only to have that ideal pop, again and again. The second woman hunches over and hyperventilates.

headline: Joyce Randolph, Last of the ‘Honeymooners,’ Is Dead at 99
abstract: She played Trixie Norton in the classic sitcom and was the last survivor of a cast of four that dominated Saturday night TV in the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: Joyce Randolph, who played Trixie Norton, the wife of a guffawing, rubber-limbed sewer worker forever mired in a blowhard neighbor’s get-rich-quick schemes and other hazards of life on the classic 1950s sitcom “The Honeymooners,” died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 99.

headline: Opera Greets the Morning at the Prototype Festival
abstract: The offerings at this annual presentation of new opera and music theater tend to be politically charged, scrappy and stirring.
lead_paragraph: “These people are not drunk,” a choir in quirkily customized blue robes sang on Saturday, “because it’s nine in the morning.”

headline: Democrats Fret That Biden’s Power Players Are Not at His Campaign Base
abstract: President Biden has a re-election campaign with two distinct centers of gravity — the White House and his Delaware headquarters — and advisers who are juggling two jobs at once.
lead_paragraph: With less than 10 months to go until the 2024 election, the nerve center of President Biden’s bid for a second term is stationed not at his campaign’s headquarters in Delaware but within feet of the Oval Office.

headline: Ron DeSantis’s Campaign Trail Quirk: The Word ‘Do’
abstract: For Mr. DeSantis, “do” is not just a verb. It can be an idea, a promise or a way to solve the problems that bedevil America.
lead_paragraph: All humans have oddities in the ways they speak. But those of presidential candidates are exposed more than most. All day, the candidates talk. And talk. And talk. Sometimes in scripted stump speeches, sometimes in off-the-cuff remarks to voters and the news media.

headline: ‘Mean Girls’ Musical Triumphs at Box Office, With a TikTok Assist
abstract: The musical rendition of the 2004 original took first place over the holiday weekend, after Paramount used TikTok to introduce young audiences to the cult classic.
lead_paragraph: The theatrical box office this holiday weekend was awash in “Mean Girls,” and TikTok may have been at least partly responsible for its domination.

headline: Atlanta D.A. Defends Qualifications of Outside Lawyer She Hired for Trump Case
abstract: At a historic Black church, Fani T. Willis pushed back against an accusation that Nathan Wade, the special prosecutor she brought on, was unqualified for the job.
lead_paragraph: Fani T. Willis, the district attorney in Fulton County, Ga., pushed back on Sunday against the criticism and questions about her judgment that have followed a court filing accusing her of being romantically involved with an outside lawyer she hired to lead the racketeering case against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Next Battle in Higher Ed May Strike at Its Soul: Scholarship
abstract: Cases involving Stanford, Harvard and M.I.T. are fueling skepticism over the thoroughness of research — even from the academic world’s biggest stars.
lead_paragraph: Marc Tessier-Lavigne, president of Stanford, resigned in August after an investigation found serious flaws in studies he had supervised going back decades.

headline: What to Expect at the Iowa Caucuses
abstract: Former President Donald Trump leads the other candidates by a wide margin in the latest polls. Jonathan Weisman, a Times correspondent, explains how Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis are competing for second place.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald Trump leads the other candidates by a wide margin in the latest polls. Jonathan Weisman, a Times correspondent, explains how Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis are competing for second place.

headline: Ex-G.O.P. Mayoral Candidate Pleads Guilty to Charge Tied to Jan. 6 Riot
abstract: Gino DiGiovanni Jr., who lost in the general election in Derby, Conn., in November, pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor trespassing charge.
lead_paragraph: A former Connecticut alderman who won his city’s Republican mayoral primary while facing criminal charges stemming from the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, has pleaded guilty to trespassing for his role in the attack.

headline: Trump Has Made Claims About Caucus Fraud. What if He Underperforms?
abstract: The former president’s high expectations for the caucuses and history of election denial have many wondering what he’ll do if he doesn’t like the results.
lead_paragraph: The last time Donald J. Trump participated in competitive Iowa caucuses, he lost narrowly, accused Senator Ted Cruz of Texas of stealing the contest, claimed fraud, demanded that Iowa Republicans nullify the results, and called for a rerun.

headline: Monday Briefing: Houthis Hold Firm After Strikes
abstract: Also, Taiwan’s president-elect and India’s court case backlog.
lead_paragraph: After U.S.-led strikes against Houthi-controlled sites in Yemen on Thursday and Friday, U.S. officials said that the militia had retained about three-quarters of its ability to target ships transiting the Red Sea.

headline: Scenes From a Harsh Winter Sweeping the U.S.
abstract: As temperatures dipped to as low as minus 45 degrees in some parts this past weekend, here’s a look at how Americans have faced the brutal weather.
lead_paragraph: Plunging temperatures have put much of the country in a deep freeze this holiday weekend, combining with snow, freezing rain, ice or gusty winds in some places to endanger nearly 100 million people from Northern California to coastal Maine.

headline: Besieged Influencer Chiara Ferragni Is the Talk of Milan Fashion Week
abstract: Embroiled in a scandal, the social media queen faces criminal charges, sponsor defection and a loss of faith among her 29 million Instagram followers.
lead_paragraph: What becomes of a famous influencer when followers suddenly drop her by the hundreds of thousands, sponsors start running for the exits and the reputation underpinning all that influence is suddenly derailed?

headline: U.S. and Iran Battle Through Proxies, Warily Avoiding Each Other
abstract: Iran wants to flex its muscles without directly taking on the U.S. or Israel, but that cautious strategy is subject to miscalculation on all sides.
lead_paragraph: For all the fears of an outbreak of fighting in the Middle East that could draw the United States, Israel and Iran into direct combat, a curious feature of the conflict so far is the care taken — in both Tehran and Washington — to avoid putting their forces into direct contact.

headline: Critics Choice Awards 2024: All the Must-See Red Carpet Looks
abstract: Dizzying necklines, shimmering fabrics and bows that would not be ignored: Here’s what you missed as the stars arrived.
lead_paragraph: A four-month postponement of the 75th Emmy Awards because of last year’s actors’ and writers’ strikes resulted in an oddity of Hollywood scheduling: back-to-back awards shows.

headline: Guatemala’s New President Is Sworn In, Despite Efforts to Stop Him
abstract: For hours, it was unclear whether Bernardo Arévalo, an anticorruption crusader, would take office at all, as lawmakers delayed the transfer of power.
lead_paragraph: Despite staunch resistance from his opponents in the government, the anticorruption crusader Bernardo Arévalo was inaugurated early Monday morning as Guatemala’s president, a turning point in a country where tensions have been simmering over widespread graft and impunity.

headline: Four Dead and One Critically Hurt in Hot-Air Balloon Crash, Police Say
abstract: The balloon crashed in Eloy, Ariz., on Sunday morning during a skydiving excursion, officials said. The cause of the crash is under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Four people were killed and one person was critically injured after a hot-air balloon crashed in a desert area about 50 miles northwest of Tucson, Ariz., on Sunday morning, the police said.

headline: Eye Drop
abstract: Peter A. Collins gets a running start.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Iowa High School Principal Injured in Perry Shooting Has Died
abstract: The principal, Dan Marburger, 56, died early Sunday after he was shot earlier this month in a shooting at Perry High School in Perry, Iowa.
lead_paragraph: A principal shot earlier this month in a school shooting in Perry, Iowa, has died from his injuries, the funeral home handling the services confirmed on Sunday.

headline: How the Iowa Caucuses Work
abstract: The parties, not the state government, run the caucuses, which have a different feel from most other balloting.
lead_paragraph: The Iowans who will brave frigid temperatures Monday for the first test of support for Republican presidential hopefuls will be caucusing — a process that’s distinct from other ballot-box affairs.

headline: Critics Choice Awards 2024: The Complete Winners List
abstract: “Oppenheimer” wins the top honor and continues its tremendous run. “The Holdovers” wins best actor, supporting actress and newcomer.
lead_paragraph: “Oppenheimer” continued its explosive awards campaign at the Critics Choice Awards on Sunday night, earning eight top trophies including best picture, best director for Christopher Nolan and best supporting actor for Robert Downey Jr.

headline: After Criticism From Pope, Nicaragua Hands Jailed Clerics Over to Vatican
abstract: Two bishops and 17 other clergymen were freed after Pope Francis drew attention to the government’s persecution in his New Year’s Day address.
lead_paragraph: The Nicaraguan authorities said on Sunday that they had released 19 clergymen who had been jailed and handed them over to the Vatican, the latest development in the autocratic government’s longstanding persecution of the Roman Catholic Church.

headline: 3 Migrants, Including 2 Children, Drown Near Texas Border
abstract: According to Customs and Border Protection, federal agents were “physically barred” by state officials from responding to the situation. Texas officials said that was “wholly inaccurate.”
lead_paragraph: Three migrants drowned in the Rio Grande by Eagle Pass, Texas, officials said Saturday, setting off a dispute among state and federal officials in what seemed to escalate the feud between the Biden administration and Gov. Greg Abbott over the stringent security measures the state has imposed to keep migrants from entering the country.

headline: ‘True Detective: Night Country’ Season Premiere Recap:
abstract: The new season, starring Jodie Foster and Kali Reis, moves north of the Arctic Circle. Unsurprisingly, the crimes are as bleak and chilly as the setting.
lead_paragraph: In the absence of any other connective tissue, the “True Detective” series continues to move forward on bad vibes and attitude, a darker-than-dark noir ambience propped up by gruesome crimes, hard-living sleuths and philosophical discourse that dances on the edge of self-parody. When Evangeline Navarro (Kali Reis), a state trooper in the Arctic hinterland of Ennis, Alaska, is asked whether she believes in God, it doesn’t seem very “True Detective” for her to affirm that she does. “Must be nice,” says her inquisitor. “Knowing we’re not alone.”

headline: Congressional Leaders Unveil Stopgap Bill to Head Off Shutdown
abstract: The bill would extend government funding through early March, teeing up a race to pass the bipartisan deal into law before an end-of-week deadline.
lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders unveiled stopgap legislation on Sunday to avert a partial government shutdown, teeing up a race to pass the bipartisan spending deal into law before a deadline at the end of the week.

headline: What to Watch For in the 2024 Iowa Caucuses
abstract: Republican voters will render a first verdict on the entreaties Donald J. Trump’s rivals have made to move the party past his grip, as he seeks a turbocharged launch to the nomination.
lead_paragraph: The coldest Iowa caucuses in history arrive Monday night amid expectations that Republicans in the state will put former President Donald J. Trump on the march to a third G.O.P. presidential nomination.

headline: ‘The Social Contract Has Been Completely Ruptured’: Ireland’s Housing Crisis
abstract: Soaring rents have left many struggling to afford homes in Dublin and have created a generational divide. Two-thirds of younger adults in the city live with their parents.
lead_paragraph: Before sunrise each day, Aoife Diver, a teacher in Dublin, gets into her car and drives for up to 90 minutes from her uncle’s house to the opposite side of the Irish capital.

headline: As Development Alters Greek Islands’ Nature and Culture, Locals Push Back
abstract: As a proliferation of pools threatens some water supplies and housing costs skyrocket, people of the Cycladic islands say the Aegean islands’ character is being lost to real-estate homogenization.
lead_paragraph: With a deluge of foreign visitors fueling seemingly nonstop development on once pristine Greek islands, local residents and officials are beginning to fight back, moving to curb a wave of construction that has started to cause water shortages and is altering the islands’ unique cultural identity.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: 100 days of war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The war in Gaza has entered its 100th day. Since Hamas led its deadly Oct. 7 assault on Israel, more than 23,000 Palestinians have been killed in Gaza and most of the enclave’s population has been displaced by the Israeli military’s war, according to Gazan health officials. More than 120 hostages are believed to be held by Hamas and other militant groups, according to Israeli officials.

headline: The Responsibility of Republican Voters
abstract: In Iowa and other states, Republican voters have the opportunity and the obligation to select a presidential candidate who will uphold the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: Republicans who will gather to cast the first votes of the 2024 presidential primary season have one essential responsibility: to nominate a candidate who is fit to serve as president, one who will “preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘The Kindest Player,’ Who Can Turn Into a Madman, Is Searching for Peace
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You get mad with yourself, then you get mad because you got mad with yourself.”

headline: What’s on TV This Week: Emmy Awards and ‘Fargo’
abstract: The television awards show that was postponed from 2023 airs on Fox, and the FX drama wraps up its season.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 15-21. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: No Corrections: Jan. 15, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Hochul to Propose $25 Million in State Funding for A.L.S. Research
abstract: It would be one of the largest state appropriations for research into the neurodegenerative disease. Ms. Hochul’s mother died from A.L.S.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul is set to propose an appropriation on Tuesday that would provide one of the largest sums ever invested by a state into research of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the neurodegenerative disease known as A.L.S.

headline: Gilgo Beach Serial-Murder Case Hangs on a Single Strand of Hair
abstract: Prosecutors put their faith in complex scientific evidence gathered painstakingly from burial sites and garbage cans.
lead_paragraph: After 13 years of dead ends and blown leads, the Gilgo Beach murder investigation finally turned on pizza crusts that Rex Heuermann had tossed in a trash can in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: As Trump Continues to Insult E. Jean Carroll, 2nd Defamation Trial Opens
abstract: The writer has already won $5 million for his sexual abuse and his subsequent denials. But the former president still claims he does not know who she is.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan jury will be asked a narrow question this week: How much money must former President Donald J. Trump pay the writer E. Jean Carroll for defaming her after she accused him of raping her?

headline: On the Ground in Iowa, a Reporter on the Move
abstract: Kellen Browning, a reporter based in San Francisco, recently relocated to Des Moines to cover the 2024 Republican campaign in Iowa, the first state to vote.
lead_paragraph: Kellen Browning had been covering the gig economy and the video game industry from San Francisco for three and a half years when he approached The New York Times’s politics team last fall: Could they use a hand with the 2024 campaign?

headline: Negative, Defensive and Dark: The Final Ads of the Iowa Campaign
abstract: Super PACs supporting Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis are closing with attacks on each other, while the front-runner, Donald J. Trump, looks past them.
lead_paragraph: Subzero temperatures and swirling snow squalls have hampered campaign events around Iowa this weekend, but Iowans are getting plenty of exposure to the Republican presidential candidates through a last-minute blitz of advertising before Monday’s caucuses.

headline: Swim Lessons for N.Y.C. Children Were at Risk. A Billionaire Helped Out.
abstract: During a period of painful budget cuts, New York City lawmakers secured private funding to pay for free swim lessons for 2,000 second graders starting in June.
lead_paragraph: With New York City making deep budget cuts to key programs, two City Council members persuaded a philanthropist to help finance a city initiative to provide swim lessons to young children.

headline: Taiwan Loses Ally to China After Electing President Loathed by Beijing
abstract: The tiny Pacific island of Nauru severed relations with Taiwan, a move that boosts China’s regional sway and was seemingly timed to Taiwan’s contentious recent election.
lead_paragraph: Just two days after Taiwan elected as its next leader Lai Ching-te, whom Beijing sees as a staunch separatist, it lost a diplomatic ally in its rivalry with China. Nauru, a tiny freckle of land in the Pacific Ocean, announced that it would be severing diplomatic relations with Taiwan, effective immediately.

headline: Diving Into the Dominican Republic’s Springs and Rivers
abstract: A world away from the country’s luxury all-inclusive beach resorts, cool, aquamarine natural pools tempt travelers to jump in and feel the tingle.
lead_paragraph: The tree-ringed lagoon glowed a color you usually see only in the mouthwash aisle, and under the surface of its glassy water, fallen branches looked like open hands ready to make a catch. The boulders at the bottom were either a few feet down or impossibly deep — the clarity of the water made it impossible to tell.

headline: In San Francisco, Tenants Use Labor Tactics to Challenge Their Landlords
abstract: A small group of residents in San Francisco apartments are on a rent strike. Can a union model work for residents the same way it does for laborers?
lead_paragraph: Auto workers in Detroit. Actors and screenwriters in Hollywood. Teachers in Portland, Ore.

headline: Lose Yourself in Three Absorbing New Historical Novels
abstract: In the midst of chaos, the characters in these books find their own ways to metabolize real-life tragedy.
lead_paragraph: “It is up to us to write our own history,” declares the organizer of the desperate project at the heart of Lauren Grodstein’s latest novel, WE MUST NOT THINK OF OURSELVES (Algonquin, 304 pp., $34). He’s speaking on a bleak afternoonomg in one of the bleakest places in Poland, the Warsaw ghetto in December 1940. Those he will secretly assemble in the upstairs room of a library are intent on preserving the biographies of at least some of the hundreds of thousands of Jews imprisoned by the Nazis in three square kilometers of the city.

headline: Indigenous Tourism Goes Deeper Than ‘Dinner and a Show’
abstract: Around the globe, travelers are looking to get beyond superficial interactions with Native cultures for more in-depth experiences, like tours led by Indigenous guides and stays at Native-owned lodges.
lead_paragraph: For visitors to New Zealand, the chance to see a haka, the ceremonial Maori dance, has long been as much a part of the country’s allure as its glaciers, geysers and glowworm caves.

headline: In Tokyo, Rescuing the Residential Spaceship That Fell to Earth
abstract: Fifty years ago, the Nakagin Capsule Tower was hailed as a marvel of organic architecture. Now its legacy lives on through 23 orphaned capsules.
lead_paragraph: In 1972, residents of Tokyo looked up to see something extraordinary looming over downtown. It looked like something out of a science-fiction film — a futuristic tower composed of 140 detachable capsules, each suitable for a single resident and with a porthole looking out, like a pile of eyes fixed on the city.

headline: When We Look at the Moon, We See Ourselves — Craters and All
abstract: In “Our Moon,” Rebecca Boyle elucidates how Earth’s closest neighbor makes us what — and who — we are.
lead_paragraph: I had two memorable experiences with the moon this year. The first was seeing the “blue supermoon” rise over Lake Michigan in August. The second, a few weeks later, was watching it quietly slip in front of our sun, casting the world below in an eerie, ethereal glow.

headline: What Trump Voters Understand About the Economy
abstract: Condescending to Trump voters will not win many of them over; we should not shrink from honestly assessing economic performance under Trump as well as under Biden.
lead_paragraph: Why is Donald Trump continuing to poll so strongly with voters?

headline: Flush With Investment, New U.S. Factories Face a Familiar Challenge
abstract: Worries are growing in Washington that a flood of Chinese products could put new American investments in clean energy and high-tech factories at risk.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has begun pumping more than $2 trillion into U.S. factories and infrastructure, investing huge sums to try to strengthen American industry and fight climate change.

headline: They Thought They Knew Death, but That Didn’t Prepare Them for Oct. 7
abstract: Volunteers with ZAKA, an Israeli group that recovers dead bodies, were among the first to reach the victims of the Hamas-led attacks. The trauma of what they witnessed may last a lifetime.
lead_paragraph: At 76, David Weissenstern has collected the remains of the dead for most of his adult life. But after the Oct. 7 attacks, in which Hamas-led fighters killed about 1,200 people along Israel’s border with Gaza, he can no longer stand the smell of grilled meat. The odor, he says, reminds him too much of burned human flesh.

headline: ‘Happy Days’ at 50: ‘The Fonz Bought Me a House’
abstract: In an interview, the surviving members of the original cast — Ron Howard, Donny Most, Anson Williams, Henry Winkler and Marion Ross — look back on the nostalgic hit, which premiered Jan. 15, 1974.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, Jan. 15, 1974, Richie, Potsie, Ralph and Fonzie entered our living rooms for a visit that would end up lasting more than a decade.

headline: The Crochet Coral Reef Keeps Spawning, Hyperbolically
abstract: The long-running project, sometimes described as the environmental version of the AIDS quilt, thrives on convoluted math and a sea of volunteers.
lead_paragraph: Every year after the full moons in late October and November, Australia’s Great Barrier Reef begins its annual spawning — first the coral species inshore, where waters are warmer, then the offshore corals, the main event. Last year, this natural spectacle coincided with the woolly propagation of two new colonies of the Crochet Coral Reef, a long-running craft-science collaborative artwork now inhabiting the Schlossmuseum in Linz, Austria, and the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh.

headline: A Fight Over a Fishing Regulation Could Help Tear Down the Administrative State
abstract: The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Wednesday over whether to overturn a key precedent on the power of executive agencies.
lead_paragraph: On a blustery fall morning in southern New Jersey, the weather was too rough for the fishing boats at the center of a momentous Supreme Court case to set out to sea.

headline: The War Has Reined In Ukraine’s Oligarchs, at Least for Now
abstract: Oligarchs have lost billions from the shelling of their factories, and the government has used its wartime powers to break their political influence.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, they fended off Russian assaults, holed up in a vast steel mill under barrages of missiles and mortars. And when the Ukrainian troops defending the Azovstal plant finally surrendered in May 2022, the mill had been reduced to rubble and twisted metal.

headline: ‘Happy Days’ Got Us Unstuck in Time
abstract: At 50, the classic sitcom is the model of a kind of nostalgia that’s as much about what we forget (the bad stuff) as what we remember. (Aaaay!)
lead_paragraph: Mention “Happy Days” to TV viewers of a certain age (raises hand) and the first thing they remember might be not an episode or a scene or a catchphrase but a lunchbox. I’m specifically thinking of a cool Thermos-brand one — featuring Henry Winkler as the show’s pop-phenom greaser, Arthur Fonzarelli, a.k.a. Fonzie, a.k.a. the Fonz — which luckier ’70s kids than I got to schlep their PBJs to school in and which is now in the collection of the Smithsonian.

headline: This Border Deal Is a Political Trap for Democrats
abstract: What we need are ambitious solutions that can address the scope of today’s migration challenge.
lead_paragraph: For the past two months, a small group of senators from both parties has been negotiating a deal to address the crisis at our southern border. The lawmakers are united in their desire to stop unauthorized migrants from entering the United States — an ambitious objective that has eluded past administrations.

headline: Looking for Little Ways to Eat Healthier? Start With Whole Grains.
abstract: Crusty bread, brown rice, nutty farro. Our guide is packed with inspiration for nutritious cooking.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 1 of Well’s Mediterranean Diet Week.

headline: Is Trump Steaming Toward a Candidacy-Sinking Iceberg? Three Writers Look at Iowa and Beyond.
abstract: Is there more than one ticket out of Iowa?
lead_paragraph: Update: On Monday night, Donald Trump won the Iowa caucus. Ron DeSantis finished a distant second, and Nikki Haley came in third.

headline: Workplace Wellness Programs Have Little Benefit, Study Finds
abstract: An Oxford researcher measured the effect of popular workplace mental health interventions, and discovered little to none.
lead_paragraph: Employee mental health services have become a billion-dollar industry. New hires, once they have found the restrooms and enrolled in 401(k) plans, are presented with a panoply of digital wellness solutions, mindfulness seminars, massage classes, resilience workshops, coaching sessions and sleep apps.

headline: Do You Have ‘Bookshelf Wealth’?
abstract: A TikTok home-décor trend has irked some bibliophiles.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to aesthetic trends, social media loves a catchy name.

headline: ‘The Run-Up’ Guide to Iowa
abstract: From under a snowdrift and an Arctic chill, 2024 voting is underway.
lead_paragraph: Finally. More than a year after Donald Trump first announced his 2024 presidential run, six months after Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida refocused his campaign strategy to be all-in on Iowa, and right in the midst of debilitating winter weather, the Iowa caucuses are upon us.

headline: $1.1 Million Homes in California
abstract: A chalet-style retreat in Idyllwild, a two-bedroom cottage with a guesthouse in Mendocino and a midcentury-modern home in Riverside.
lead_paragraph: This house is less than 10 minutes from a brewpub, a bakery, a grocery store and a number of restaurants and inns at the center of this small mountain community. But the location’s big draw is its proximity to Mount San Jacinto State Park, where hiking trails wind up Mount San Jacinto, offering views of the forest on one side and the desert on the other.

headline: How Trump, DeSantis and Haley’s Teams Are Thinking About Turnout in Iowa
abstract: Republican campaigns are battling cold, complacency and voter discontent as they push voters to caucus on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Follow for live updates on the Iowa caucuses.

headline: How Many Rings Is Too Many?
abstract: A reader wonders if stacking jewelry can look tacky. Recent red carpets suggest otherwise, our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: When Ariana Greenblatt, the 16-year-old “Barbie” actress, made her red carpet debut at the Golden Globes this month, she did so in a plain white Saint Laurent tuxedo shirt, black trousers, a black cummerbund and about eight Chopard diamond rings, one on nearly every finger, which she proudly fluttered at the watching paparazzi. And she wasn’t the only attendee so adorned.

headline: Butchering Before Dinner at Leland Eating and Drinking House
abstract: Make Peter Luger burgers at home, learn about feasting in Middle Ages and more food news.
lead_paragraph: A demonstration last week involving butchering half an heirloom pig, and showing how to use various parts, kicked off a series in the basement workshop and bakery at Leland Eating and Drinking House in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. It was followed by a five-course tasting dinner in the wine cellar, starring pork. The restaurant, which does its own butchering as a matter of course, has scheduled subsequent classes monthly throughout the year, with the next one on Feb. 21, followed by March 13, both pork-centric. Later in the year there will be sessions about duck and fish. The classes and dinners, starting at 6 p.m., are $100 plus tax, tip and beverages.

headline: A Big Reason to Pay Attention to Iowa? New Hampshire.
abstract: Second place could mean a lot to Nikki Haley tonight as a showdown with Donald Trump looms in the next primary contest.
lead_paragraph: The long road to the Republican presidential nomination begins tonight in Iowa, where voters will gather at their neighborhood precinct caucuses to cast the first votes of the 2024 election campaign.

headline: Another Gun Fight Is Looming in Tennessee
abstract: Shunned by their own representatives, Republican gun-safety advocates are throwing in their lot with Democrats.
