lead_paragraph: Red-state legislatures are the incubator and the proving ground of many varieties of right-wing nutjobbery that go on to affect national policy, but most people give no thought to what happens in their chambers. Even here in the South — where, to all appearances, our legislatures gather mainly to subvert democracy and rend the social safety net — few people seemed to be paying attention last week when the Tennessee General Assembly convened in Nashville for the new legislative session.

headline: The Weather in Iowa Is Not the Only Thing That Is Bitterly Cold
abstract: It might as well be “Frozen III” in Des Moines. And what a cast of characters.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Gail, we are conversing on the eve of the Iowa caucuses — not yet knowing who came in second but not in much doubt about who’ll come in first. I’m trying to remember the last time the Republican winner went on to win the nomination: Ted Cruz in 2016? Rick Santorum in 2012? Mike Huckabee in 2008?

headline: A Death Row Lawyer Blunders. Must His Client Pay the Price?
abstract: The Supreme Court will consider whether to hear an appeal from an inmate who says his lawyer filed shoddy papers, including a brief saying the inmate must lose.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Gamboa, a death row inmate in Texas, says his court-appointed lawyer robbed him of the chance to challenge his murder conviction in federal court. Among other things, court records show, the lawyer ignored evidence supplied by Mr. Gamboa, filed a cut-and-paste habeas corpus petition that still bore the name of an earlier client and submitted a brief admitting that his client must lose.

headline: Meet the Little-Known Biggest Players in the Iowa Caucuses
abstract: At every precinct from Sioux City to Davenport, captains will give speeches on behalf of their preferred candidates and try to persuade their neighbors at the last minute.
lead_paragraph: Follow for live updates on the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Biden and Democratic Allies Announce $97 Million Fund-Raising Haul
abstract: The president’s campaign, together with two allied committees, said they were entering 2024 with more than $117 million in cash.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s re-election campaign said on Monday that, along with two allied committees, it had pulled in $97 million during the most recent fund-raising period. Together, they entered 2024 with more than $117 million in cash on hand, the campaign said.

headline: The Smoothie Stop-By: When a President Tries to Be a Regular Joe
abstract: For a commander in chief, retail campaigning isn’t easy, what with the counterassault team that follows him everywhere. But President Biden is starting to hit the hustings on every Main Street he can find.
lead_paragraph: It was a quiet day in Emmaus, Pa. The only sound on Main Street was the idling engine of the sleek black truck that some call a rolling doomsday communications control center, which was parked outside the bike shop. The men with guns dressed all in black were perched on the roof using binoculars to scan the area for terrorists or other bad guys.

headline: Winter Storm Blankets South and May End Snow Drought in Northeast
abstract: A storm bringing freezing temperatures to the South could end a snowless streak in the Northeast later in the week, the National Weather Service said.
lead_paragraph: A winter storm was pushing east over large parts of the Southeast on Monday, bringing more snow and freezing temperatures to the region before reaching the Mid-Atlantic and the Northeast on Tuesday, where forecasters said it could end a nearly two-year drought without snow.

headline: Apple to Offer Rare Discount on iPhones in China
abstract: Facing a weak consumer appetite and fierce competition from domestic rivals amid U.S.-China tensions, a typically discount-wary Apple is offering a four-day sale.
lead_paragraph: Ever bought a discounted new phone from Apple? For most people, the answer is no. That’s because Apple doesn’t really do discounts.

headline: The Iowa Caucuses, and 100 Days of War in Gaza
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Three Questions About Iowa
abstract: What to watch for in tonight’s caucuses.
lead_paragraph: So far, the 2024 presidential campaign looks to be the least competitive in decades. The incumbent president is likely to win the Democratic nomination easily, while a former president seems to be running away with the Republican nomination.

headline: Soccer Player Detained by Turkey After Message of Support for Israel
abstract: The player, Sagiv Jehezkel, displayed a pro-Israel message after scoring on Sunday and was promptly suspended by his club. He was released after questioning and returned to Israel.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli soccer player for a Turkish club was briefly detained by the Turkish authorities and suspended by the club after he displayed a message of support for Israel during a game on Sunday.

headline: Hamas Says Two More Israeli Hostages Are Dead
abstract: The group said the two were killed by Israeli airstrikes, which the Israeli military said was at least partly false.
lead_paragraph: Hamas said on Monday that two of the hostages captured on Oct. 7 had been killed in Israeli airstrikes and released images that appeared to show their bodies, but the Israeli military cast doubt on the claim.

headline: Among Linguists, the Word of the Year Is More of a Vibe
abstract: The American Dialect Society selected a term that refers to the deterioration of online platforms.
lead_paragraph: “So here’s blorbo,” said a man to my left, pointing to a word on his phone. I looked, and there was “blorbo,” next to its definition: “Beloved fictional character from television or other media, often appearing in the phrase blorbo from my shows.”

headline: Car-Ramming Attack in Israel Kills 1 and Wounds 17, Officials Say
abstract: Two Palestinian men were arrested, according to the police, who said the incident was being treated as a terrorist attack. The French government said two of those injured were French nationals.
lead_paragraph: Two Palestinian men stole cars and ran over Israelis in a suburb of Tel Aviv on Monday, the Israeli police said. One person was killed and 17 others injured, according to emergency officials.

headline: Iran Adds Prison Time for Nobel Winner and Frees 2 Journalists on Bail
abstract: Narges Mohammadi, the jailed human rights activist, was sentenced to additional prison time, while journalists who reported on the death of Mahsa Amini were freed for now.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian regime sentenced Narges Mohammadi, the jailed human rights activist who received the 2023 Nobel Peace Prize, to 15 more months in prison, her family said on Monday.

headline: Iceland Faces ‘New Chapter’ of Seismic Activity as Lava Menaces Town
abstract: The country has many earthquakes and eruptions, but now, “a daunting period of upheaval has begun” in the southwest, the president said.
lead_paragraph: Living in a country that straddles two tectonic plates and has 130 or so volcanoes, Icelanders are no strangers to earthquakes and eruptions.

headline: ‘Not Where We Need to Be’: Boeing to Make Changes in Quality Control
abstract: The plane manufacturer said it would add additional inspections, including at the supplier of a panel that blew off during a recent Alaska Airlines flight.
lead_paragraph: Boeing said Monday that it would make changes to quality control processes after one of its 737 Max 9 jets lost a portion of its body during a nearly catastrophic Alaska Airlines flight this month.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Key Trump Lawyer Withdraws as Manhattan Criminal Trial Nears
abstract: Joseph Tacopina brought extensive experience with high-profile cases to former president Donald J. Trump’s legal team.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Tacopina, the trial lawyer on Donald J. Trump’s legal team with the most successes defending high-profile clients, will no longer represent the former president in his criminal trial in Manhattan, according to a notice sent to the court on Monday.

headline: This Again? In Frozen Iowa, the Press Corps Ponders a Slog of a Campaign.
abstract: Snowstorms, a thinning field of candidates and Donald Trump’s polling lead contributed to a smaller media turnout for the nation’s first caucus.
lead_paragraph: Follow for live updates on the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Horseradish-Roasted Salmon With Mustard Potatoes Packs a Solid Punch
abstract: It’s the sort of gleefully pungent dish that brightens up the dullest winter weeknight.
lead_paragraph: Is it me, or is a clear sky bluer in winter than in summer? Maybe it’s because, on my daily jaunts in the park, everything else is muted with little or no greenery or blossoms to compete with, so the blue always seems ready to burst between the bare branches.

headline: What America’s Eating Affects Its Water Supply
abstract: Responses to an article in the “Uncharted Waters” series. Also: Paxlovid and Covid; Taylor Swift’s fans; Democratic vice-presidential choices.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Months After Cyberattack, British Library Crawls Back Online
abstract: Britain’s national library made the first major steps in its recovery process after a ransomware group took down its website and online catalog.
lead_paragraph: The British Library on Monday began restoring its online catalog, which holds details of books, journals and music scores, the first step in its recovery from a brazen cyberattack in October, the library said.

headline: Everton Faces Second Points Penalty in New Financial Case
abstract: The Premier League announced charges against Everton and Nottingham Forest, increasing the risk that both clubs could be relegated at the end of the season.
lead_paragraph: Everton, which tumbled down the Premier League standings after receiving a record 10-point deduction in November, faces the prospect of a second points penalty for new violations of the competition’s financial regulations.

headline: Biting Cold Sweeping U.S. Hits the South With an Unfamiliar Freeze
abstract: In Texas, where a 2021 storm killed 246 people and knocked out electricity for millions, officials urged residents to conserve power.
lead_paragraph: Extreme weather gripped large parts of the Southern United States on Monday, with ice and snow hampering plans to commemorate the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday, and several governors declaring states of emergency.

headline: Roy Calne, Pioneering British Organ-Transplant Surgeon, Dies at 93
abstract: His innovations in the use of drugs to prevent organ rejection helped bring a remarkable increase in the one-year survival rate.
lead_paragraph: Roy Calne, a British surgeon whose work on organ transplantation helped turn what was once considered impossible into a lifesaving procedure for millions of people around the world, died on Jan. 6 at a retirement home in Cambridge, England. He was 93.

headline: When Will Iowa Caucus Results Be In?
abstract: Some states have consistent enough histories to allow that question to be answered with relative confidence. Iowa is not one of them.
lead_paragraph: Check here after initial votes are reported to get our live estimates of the race’s outcome.

headline: Grandfather Who Tried to Break Up Fight Is Killed in Subway Shooting
abstract: The victim, Richard Henderson, “got shot stepping into an altercation that he had nothing to do with,” his wife said. He was killed on a No. 3 train.
lead_paragraph: Next month would have marked the 30th year that Richard and Jakeba Henderson had been together, and March the 20th year they had been married.

headline: Museum Director Laura Raicovich Gets a Second Act: Barkeep
abstract: At the Francis Kite Club, a collectively-built space for artists people debate culture and politics over cocktails.
lead_paragraph: There is something bigger than beer brewing at the Francis Kite Club, a new haunt in the East Village whose artists hold performances, shape its programming and debate politics from their barstools.

headline: National Gallery of Art Receives Major Gift of Joseph Cornell Boxes
abstract: Collectors give the museum 27 box constructions and collages by the homebody artist who rarely left Queens but became a central figure in 20th century art.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Cornell, who died in 1972 at the age of 69, belongs to the tradition of the homebody-artist. A gray whisper of a man, he eschewed the excitements of travel in favor of a tea-filled life in his house on Utopia Parkway in Queens. His medium was the Box — that is, the Victorian-era shadow box, and he spent his days in his basement workshop, assembling cork balls, paper cutouts of birds and other dime-store material into improbably poetic arrangements that owed something to French Surrealism.

headline: U.S. Defense Secretary Is Released From the Hospital After 2 Weeks
abstract: The secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III, kept the White House in the dark about his hospitalization for several days, a major breach of protocol at the highest national security levels.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III was released from the hospital on Monday, after a two-week stay for complications from prostate cancer surgery that he had kept secret from the White House for several days, the Pentagon announced.

headline: How Trump Sidestepped the Tradition of Iowa Pandering
abstract: Presidential candidates often enmesh themselves in the state’s politics to woo voters, but the nature of this race means much less focus on local issues.
lead_paragraph: Campaigning in Iowa in the months leading up to the caucuses has traditionally involved candidates’ embracing local customs, visiting familiar locations and championing policies aimed at helping the state’s farm-driven economy.

headline: Iowa Caucus Results
abstract: Get live election results, maps and our live forecast of the outcome from the Iowa Republican caucus.
lead_paragraph: Get live election results, maps and our live forecast of the outcome from the Iowa Republican caucus.

headline: Our DeSantis and Haley Reporters Switched Places. Here’s What They Found.
abstract: The candidates — and their campaigns — are a study in contrasts, from the vibes of their events to how they interact with voters and the press.
lead_paragraph: For months, Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis, Republican contenders locked in a heated rivalry for second place in their party’s 2024 presidential nominating contest, have been crisscrossing Iowa ahead of the first-in-the-nation caucuses.

headline: Britain Moves to Ban the Islamist Group Hizb ut-Tahrir
abstract: The government said it would designate the international Islamist political group a terrorist organization, citing what it said was Hizb ut-Tahrir’s praise for the Oct. 7 attack on Israel.
lead_paragraph: The British government plans to ban Hizb ut-Tahrir, an international Islamist political group, by designating it a terrorist organization, the government announced on Monday, citing what it said was the group’s praise for the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel.

headline: Is the Fed Falling Prey to Groupthink?
abstract: None of the governors who set interest rates have dissented from a rate decision since 2005.
lead_paragraph: For governors of the Federal Reserve, dissenting from rate-setting decisions has become as gauche as wearing tie-dye to a funeral. As the chart below shows, dissents by governors went out of fashion around 1995. The last time any governor cast a contrary vote on a decision by the Federal Open Market Committee was September 2005. (For your next Fed trivia contest: That was Mark Olson, an appointee of President George W. Bush, who thought monetary policy should be more dovish.)

headline: Norm Snead, Skillful Loser as an N.F.L. Quarterback, Is Dead at 84
abstract: A four-time Pro Bowl selection, he spent seven years with the Philadelphia Eagles, where his record was better than the team’s.
lead_paragraph: Norm Snead, a National Football League quarterback for 16 seasons in the 1960s and ’70s and a four-time Pro Bowl selection, died on Sunday at his home in Naples. Fla. He was 84.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Houthis Attack a U.S. Ship
abstract: Also, the Iowa caucuses and Indigenous tourism.
lead_paragraph: Houthi fighters fired a missile yesterday that caused limited damage to a U.S.-owned cargo vessel off the coast of Yemen, the U.S. military said.

headline: Israeli Teenager Recounts Her Time as a Hostage in Gaza
abstract: Hila Rotem Shoshani, 13, is the youngest of the hostages freed from Gaza to speak out about the harsh conditions in which they were held.
lead_paragraph: Hila Rotem Shoshani had invited her friend Emily Hand over for a sleepover in Kibbutz Be’eri, Israel. The girls, then 12 and 8, woke early the next morning, Oct. 7, to the sound of thundering booms — the start of the deadliest attack in the history of their country.

headline: Arctic Air Freezes Parts of the South
abstract: Ice and snow created dangerous driving conditions in parts of the southern United States and led several governors to declare states of emergency.
lead_paragraph: Ice and snow created dangerous driving conditions in parts of the southern United States and led several governors to declare states of emergency.

headline: ‘Oh No, They’re Both Gone’: Beloved Maine Fishing Shacks Tumble Into Bay
abstract: A video captured the moment when a winter storm surge knocked the last of the historic shacks, a local attraction and backdrop for paintings and photos, into Casco Bay.
lead_paragraph: The fishing shacks that once perched on the rocks at Willard Beach in South Portland were part of a childhood that Maureen Connolly described on Monday as “quintessential Maine.”

headline: Pritzker Is Among Democrats Making Case for Biden in Iowa
abstract: They argued that the future of the nation would be at risk if former President Donald J. Trump were re-elected.
lead_paragraph: All the political action in Iowa may be among Republicans, but President Biden’s campaign sought on Monday to get a piece of the action, sending three top surrogates to Des Moines to promote his agenda and trash his potential opponents.

headline: The Joy of Defeat in the Iowa Caucuses
abstract: Coming in second can be a win in early-state contests.
lead_paragraph: One thing is certain in tonight’s Iowa caucuses: The loser will make a triumphant victory speech.

headline: The Needle Returns for the New Hampshire Republican Primary
abstract: The Needle can offer a much clearer picture of the outcome of an election than the early returns, which are often biased toward a particular candidate.
lead_paragraph: Once polls close in the New Hampshire primary tonight, The Times will start publishing a live estimate of the final result, better known as the Needle.

headline: Winter Jazzfest Has Company: Unity Jazz Festival
abstract: The decision to place another festival right on top of Jazzfest highlighted how much has been flipped upside-down in jazz over the past 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2005 — when the first NYC Winter Jazzfest was held at the Knitting Factory in Lower Manhattan, and Jazz at Lincoln Center’s multimillion-dollar facilities had recently opened on the Upper West Side — it was clear which represented the establishment, and which was proposing an alternative. Today, it’s not such an easy distinction.

headline: Why are the 2023 Emmy Awards taking place in 2024?
abstract: The trophies were supposed to have been handed out in September, but were delayed by Hollywood’s labor problems.
lead_paragraph: Nominations were announced six months ago. The ceremony was supposed to take place in September. So why on earth are the Emmys happening now?

headline: Emmy Winners: The Full List
abstract: Here are the winners from the 75th Emmy Awards, which took place Monday night.
lead_paragraph: [See all of our Emmys night coverage here.]

headline: My Iowa: Covering the Caucuses as a Native or a Newcomer
abstract: One of our reporters grew up in Iowa City and was inspired to become a journalist after witnessing the caucuses in action. Another touched down here for the first time two months ago. They compared notes.
lead_paragraph: KELLEN BROWNING If you were trying to think of a city that feels like the polar opposite of San Francisco, Des Moines would be a pretty good bet.

headline: See the Looks From the Emmys Red Carpet
abstract: Stars brought fringe, floral and skin to the 75th Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: Television’s big night is finally here. Last summer, one day after the 75th Emmy Award nominations were announced, the Screen Actors Guild voted to strike, postponing the ceremony to January.

headline: Full Employment Is Good for Society
abstract: Inequality and racial disparities are finally falling.
lead_paragraph: On the day in 1968 when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was shot, he was in Memphis to show support for striking sanitation workers. By then, he had come to see fighting for economic equality as a crucial part of the struggle for civil rights.

headline: What to Make of the Iowa Caucus Entrance Polls
abstract: The Times will be considering two exit-type polls — but in the context of our own polling, as well as other factors.
lead_paragraph: Organizations are starting to release so-called entrance polls — final polls taken right before the caucuses. These polls, which are also sometimes known as exit polls in non-caucus states, have taken on outsize importance in the minds of politicos.

headline: Iran Launches Missile Strikes in Iraq and Syria, Citing Terrorist Attacks
abstract: Explosions shook Erbil, a city in northern Iraq, and at least four civilians were killed, local officials said. Syrian targets were also hit, Iran’s Revolutionary Guards said.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s Revolutionary Guards launched a missile attack against what they called “anti-Iranian terrorist groups” in a northern Iraqi city, setting off large explosions and sirens, including at the American Consulate, around midnight on Tuesday.

headline: Houthis, Undeterred by Strikes, Target More Ships in Red Sea
abstract: The Iranian-backed militants launched a fresh round of attacks days after their military sites were hit by U.S. and British forces.
lead_paragraph: Iranian-backed Houthi militants in Yemen have launched a fresh round of attacks in shipping lanes critical for global trade, damaging a U.S.-owned commercial ship on Monday after attempting to hit an American warship the day before.

headline: Quinta Brunson Becomes First Black Woman in More Than 30 Years to Win Best Actress in a Comedy
abstract: Brunson won for “Abbott Elementary,” making her the first Black woman to win the category since Isabel Sanford won in 1981 for “The Jeffersons.”
lead_paragraph: Quinta Brunson won best actress in a comedy for her role as the relentlessly optimistic second-grade teacher Janine Teagues on ABC’s “Abbott Elementary,” making her the first Black woman to win the category since Isabel Sanford won in 1981 for “The Jeffersons.”

headline: How the Iowa Caucuses Work, Step by Step
abstract: There is mingling and speech-giving, all attempts at last-minute persuasion. And then the caucusgoers vote.
lead_paragraph: To people accustomed to voting in primaries by walking into a polling site, privately completing a ballot and walking out — which is to say, most of the country — caucuses may seem bewildering.

headline: Voters Look Past Legal Problems to Give Trump a Big Victory
abstract: The possibility of a two-person race remains elusive for Trump foes, who fear a split field will ease his path to the nomination.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump won the Iowa caucuses in a landslide on Monday, a crucial first step in his bid to claim the Republican nomination in a third consecutive election as voters looked past his mounting legal jeopardy and embraced his vision of vengeful disruption.

headline: Christina Applegate Presents the First Emmy
abstract: The “Dead to Me” actress makes a rare public appearance to present the first Emmy, for supporting actress in a comedy series.
lead_paragraph: Christina Applegate made a rare public appearance to present the first Emmy, for supporting actress in a comedy series. Glamorous in a plunging gown and visibly overcome by the long standing ovation she received, she still made self-deprecating jokes about Ozempic and disability. “You’re totally shaming me with disability by standing up,” she told the crowd. “It’s fine.”

headline: Jeremy Allen White Wins His First Emmy for ‘The Bear’
abstract: The actor, who last week won his second Golden Globe for his performance as the driven chef Carmy, added his first Emmy to his trophy case for best actor in a comedy.
lead_paragraph: The year of “The Bear” continues. Jeremy Allen White, who last week won his second Golden Globe for his performance as the driven chef Carmy, added his first Emmy to his trophy case on Monday night, for best actor in a comedy. (Because this year’s ceremony was delayed by the writers’ and actors’ strikes, White was recognized for his performance in Season 1 of the show; his Golden Globe was for Season 2.)

headline: Nadine Menendez Wants Her Own Trial. So Does Her Husband.
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez and his wife both face federal charges of accepting bribes, including gold bars. Now their marriage is central to a new dispute in the case.
lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey and his wife, Nadine Menendez, were both charged last fall in a broad federal corruption case in which they were accused of accepting cash and gold bribes.

headline: John Oliver Changes Categories but Keeps Winning
abstract: HBO’s “Last Week Tonight With John Oliver” bested NBC’s “Saturday Night Live” by winning scripted variety series.
lead_paragraph: HBO’s “Last Week Tonight With John Oliver” bested NBC’s “Saturday Night Live” by winning scripted variety series in a clash between two titans accustomed to dominating the Emmys from opposite sides of the variety fence.

headline: Niecy Nash-Betts Honors Sandra Bland and Breonna Taylor in Her Emmy Speech
abstract: The actress, who played a neighbor in Netflix’s “Dahmer,” won her first Emmy for best supporting actress in a limited series.
lead_paragraph: Niecy Nash-Betts, who played a neighbor in Netflix’s “Dahmer,” won her first Emmy on Monday night for best supporting actress in a limited series.

headline: ‘Grey’s Anatomy,’ ‘Cheers’ and ‘Martin’ Casts Reunite at Emmys
abstract: The reunions included Katherine Heigl making a rare appearance with some of her former “Grey’s” co-stars.
lead_paragraph: This year, there was an extra line item in the Emmys budget: for intricate recreations of some of the most iconic sets in television history, down to the red bar seats from “Cheers,” the dark green living room couch where much of the action in the 1990s sitcom “Martin” took place and the beeping patient monitor in “Grey’s Anatomy.”

headline: Results: The Most Detailed Maps of the Iowa Republican Caucuses
abstract: See results from every precinct and demographic analysis of the vote in the Iowa G.O.P. caucuses.
lead_paragraph: See results from every precinct and demographic analysis of the vote in the Iowa G.O.P. caucuses.

headline: Baltimore Sun Sold to Chairman of Sinclair TV Stations
abstract: David D. Smith bought the newspaper and its sister publications in a private deal with Alden Global Capital, their owner since 2021.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Sun, the largest newspaper in Maryland, has been sold to David D. Smith, the executive chairman of the nationwide Sinclair network of television stations and other media.

headline: This Year’s Iowa Caucus Is On Track For Lowest Turnout Since 2000
abstract: Voters at some locations overcame the extreme weather to make strong showings, but turnout overall fell short of expectations.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 Iowa Republican caucuses are on track to have the lowest turnout since 2000 after bitter cold and a snowstorm kept many voters at home.

headline: Steven Yeun Wins His First Emmy
abstract: The actor captured the Emmy for best actor in a limited series for his role as Danny Cho in “Beef.”
lead_paragraph: Steven Yeun captured the Emmy for best actor in a limited series for his role as Danny Cho in “Beef,” the heralded Netflix series that portrays a seemingly low-stakes road-rage incident both intertwining and dominating the lives of Cho and Ali Wong’s Amy Lau.

headline: An Especially Good Thing to Follow
abstract: Marshal Herrmann makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Ali Wong Wins Her First Emmy
abstract: Wong won best actress in a limited series for her role in Netflix’s “Beef.”
lead_paragraph: Ali Wong won best actress in a limited series for “Beef,” her first Emmy, capping a strong start to the year for her and the Netflix series.

headline: Elton John Secures EGOT With Emmy Win
abstract: With “Elton John Live: Farewell From Dodger Stadium,” he becomes the 19th person to win all four prestigious entertainment awards.
lead_paragraph: Elton John secured an EGOT on Monday night, joining the select group who have won all four major entertainment awards — an Emmy, a Grammy, an Oscar and a Tony — when he won an Emmy for outstanding variety special for his livestreamed farewell concert at Dodger Stadium.

headline: News Outlets Make an Early Call in Iowa, and a Backlash Ensues
abstract: No votes had been cast at some locations when The Associated Press and TV networks projected Donald Trump as the winner, half an hour after the caucuses began.
lead_paragraph: The smartphones started to buzz at 7:30 p.m. Central time on Monday, just half an hour after the Iowa caucuses had begun. Many Iowans had not yet had a chance to cast a vote when The Associated Press and the major TV networks began to declare former President Donald J. Trump as the winner.

headline: Harris Warns of ‘Profound Threat’ to America’s Freedoms
abstract: In a speech honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the vice president denounced laws rolling back civil rights and emphasized the fights that await future generations.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris warned on Monday that American freedom was “under profound threat” in a speech honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in South Carolina, amplifying a message that the Biden administration has made a rallying cry of its re-election bid.

headline: At a Strike-Delayed Emmys, ‘Succession’ Succeeds One Last Time
abstract: “The Bear” was named best comedy and “Beef” best limited series at the 75th Emmy Awards.
lead_paragraph: “Succession” triumphed one last time.

headline: Tributes to Norman Lear and Matthew Perry Mark the ‘In Memoriam’ Segment
abstract: The Emmys paid tribute to the actors, writers and producers who died since the last awards.
lead_paragraph: The Emmys paid tribute to the actors, writers and producers who died since the last awards, taking an extra beat to honor Norman Lear, the famed TV writer and producer who died last month at 101.

headline: Vivek Ramaswamy, Wealthy Political Novice Who Aligned With Trump, Quits Campaign
abstract: A self-funding entrepreneur, Mr. Ramaswamy peaked in late August but deflated under attack from his rivals. He dropped out after the Iowa caucuses and endorsed Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy, the 38-year-old entrepreneur and political newcomer who briefly made a splash with brash policy proposals and an outsize sense of confidence, dropped out of the race for the Republican White House nomination after a disappointing fourth-place finish in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: 15 Looks That Did the Most at the Emmys
abstract: These outfits stood out on a carpet full of feathers, beads, sequins, diamonds and lots of well-tailored suits.
lead_paragraph: After being postponed because of labor strikes in Hollywood, the Emmy Awards returned on Monday night and with the ceremony came what might be the television industry’s biggest fashion show.

headline: Quotation of the Day: War in Ukraine Pulls Oligarchs Off Their Perch
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “In the fight against dragons, we have to be cautious not to become dragons ourselves.”

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A Houthi attack on a U.S.-owned ship.
lead_paragraph: An anti-ship ballistic missile fired by Houthi fighters struck the Gibraltar Eagle, a U.S.-owned cargo vessel, off the coast of Yemen yesterday. The ship and its crew, which had been headed toward the Suez Canal, were not seriously harmed, according to the U.S. military’s Central Command. The ship turned around to leave the area.

headline: DeSantis Supporters ‘Mad and Frustrated’ at Fast Race Call
abstract: Representative Chip Roy of Texas, who spoke for the DeSantis campaign, said he was told the results before he even got onstage to make the case for the governor.
lead_paragraph: The mood at the Ron DeSantis watch party was anger and disbelief — not at Mr. DeSantis’s clear loss to former President Donald J. Trump, but at how early The Associated Press called the race.

headline: DeSantis’s Iowa Letdown: A Distant Second Place Behind Trump
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis is running low on campaign cash and faces tough tests ahead in New Hampshire and South Carolina, but vowed to stay in the race.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida may have done just enough in the Iowa caucuses on Monday night to argue that he still belongs in the race to defeat Donald J. Trump for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Trump’s Runaway Victory in the Iowa Caucuses
abstract: The former president crushed Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley and also benefited from their close battle for second, which seems set to prolong a three-way race.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a year of campaigning, more than $123 million in advertising and an inglorious, frozen-over finish, the Iowa caucuses ended much as the race began: Donald J. Trump, the dominant front-runner, was declared the winner before most of the votes had even been cast.

headline: The Most Durable Force in American Politics: Trump’s Ties to His Voters
abstract: If Donald Trump’s rivals want to stop his rise, they’ll need to break his bond with his supporters. They didn’t come close in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton once explained the nation’s two political parties by saying that Democrats want to fall in love while Republicans want to fall in line.

headline: Putin Is Making His Plans Brutally Clear
abstract: Ukrainians know that when it comes to Vladimir Putin, one must not trust what he says, but watch what he does.
lead_paragraph: New Year’s Eve is an important holiday in Ukraine. At the end of December, I asked my sister how she would be celebrating this year. “In the bomb shelter,” she said, matter-of-factly. She planned to cook sandwiches, which would be easier to carry down to the safe room from the 10th floor if there was an air-raid siren.

headline: How Trump’s Opponents Made Iowa Easy for Him
abstract: It’s absurd that there was no unified opposition candidate again.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s victory in the Iowa caucuses was resounding enough to make the race for the Republican nomination look essentially finished at the start. But it wasn’t resounding enough to remove the sense that it could have been otherwise, that yet again his opposition within the Republican Party made things ridiculously easy for his candidacy.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 16, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A photograph with an article on Friday about a scheme in which ESPN submitted fake names on its Emmy Award entries in order to acquire statuettes for on-air talent ineligible to receive them was published in error. It showed Rece Davis, not Chris Fowler. Mr. Davis was not named among those who received an Emmy statuette for which they were not eligible.

headline: Word of the Day: orotund
abstract: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word orotund has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 28 in “Zadie Smith Makes 1860s London Feel Alive, and Recognizable” by Karan Mahajan:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: An Idealistic Cop, a Forbidden Ticket and a Police Career on the Brink
abstract: Mathew Bianchi took routine traffic stops seriously and handed out tickets regardless of people’s connections within the Police Department. He says he was punished for it.
lead_paragraph: A red Mazda sped past a police officer’s unmarked car stationed at a tree-lined Staten Island intersection. The officer inside, Mathew Bianchi, clocked the Mazda at well over the limit and prepared to make a stop at a nearby streetlight. But the car blew through a red light. Bianchi turned on his siren.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: N.Y. Reconsiders Capitol Artworks That Offend Native Americans
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul has ordered a review of art in the Capitol that depicts Native Americans, often in ways that glorify violence against Indigenous people.
lead_paragraph: At an informal gathering last summer at the Executive Mansion in Albany, N.Y., Gov. Kathy Hochul shared an anecdote about making an unpleasant discovery there, not long after taking residence: a painting depicting the marriage of Pocahontas.

headline: Can Mike Tyson Become a Heavyweight in the New York Marijuana Industry?
abstract: The retired boxer’s foray into the cannabis market in New York is a test of how far a celebrity can carry a brand.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weekend, fans of Mike Tyson, one of the greatest boxers ever, lined up by the hundreds at dispensaries in New York for a chance to meet him and to support his latest business move: selling weed in his home state.

headline: Jury Selection in Trump’s Defamation Trial Has Watchful Eyes: His
abstract: As E. Jean Carroll, whom Donald Trump assaulted decades ago, seeks millions to deter his verbal attacks, the former president tries to make a political virtue of his legal travails.
lead_paragraph: Hours after Donald J. Trump cemented his political standing with a romp through the caucus rooms of Iowa, he arrived Tuesday morning in his other world: a courtroom.

headline: Where Anteaters and Anacondas Roam, and Ranchers Are Now Rangers
abstract: Colombia created its latest, and perhaps last, national park by befriending the traditional ranching culture that surrounds it.
lead_paragraph: The llanos region spans more than 200,000 square miles through Colombia and Venezuela. Hot winds blow over its grassy hills, and scattered forests of Mauritius palms shelter hidden streams and lagoons. For centuries this landscape, shaped by ancient rivers, has been shared by ranchers and cattle, which learned to coexist with jaguars, panthers, anacondas, electric eels and crocodiles.

headline: What Happened at the Iowa Caucuses
abstract: Former President Donald Trump won the Iowa caucuses, while Ron DeSantis took second and Nikki Haley came in third.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald Trump won the Iowa caucuses, while Ron DeSantis took second and Nikki Haley came in third.

headline: ​North Korea Says It Is No Longer Interested in Reunifying With the South
abstract: Abandoning the longtime goal, however unlikely, Kim Jong-un, the North’s leader, instead threatened to subjugate South Korea in war.
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s approach toward South Korea has swayed widely over the past decades. While it has often called the South its “sworn” and “principal enemy” and threatened to “annihilate” it with nuclear weapons, at times it has also engaged in dialogue and discussed a possible reunification.

headline: How a Young Woman From the Ozarks Wound Up an ISIS Wife in Syria
abstract: Jessica Roy’s “American Girls” traces the divergent fates of two sisters through a saga of poverty, misogyny, abuse and terrorism.
lead_paragraph: The narrative at the heart of Jessica Roy’s “American Girls” is so remarkable it could have been scripted for Hollywood: Sam and Lori Sally are sisters from the Ozarks, raised as strict Jehovah’s Witnesses. As young adults, they abandoned their faith and eventually married a pair of Moroccan-born brothers, Moussa and Yassine Elhassani, who proved domineering and violent. Lori divorced Yassine, but Sam stayed with Moussa. In 2015, she followed him from their home in Indiana all the way to Syria, where Moussa, radicalized by online propaganda, became a fighter with the Islamic State.

headline: Can Learning a New Language Stave Off Dementia?
abstract: Research suggests that bilingual people enjoy some cognitive benefits later in life, but it probably requires more than a few Spanish lessons in your 60s.
lead_paragraph: My father decided to start learning French when he was 57. He hired a tutor to meet with him twice a week and diligently completed his homework before every lesson. Before long, he was visiting the French bakery across town to practice his pronunciation (and buy macarons). Now, 20 years later, he’s on his third tutor.

headline: Could LSD Have Achieved World Peace? Ask Margaret Mead.
abstract: In “Tripping on Utopia,” Benjamin Breen chronicles the legendary anthropologist’s doomed effort to save the world through hallucinogens.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through “Tripping on Utopia: Margaret Mead, the Cold War and the Troubled Birth of Psychedelic Science," the historian Benjamin Breen presents a tantalizing hypothetical, one that would have had an inestimable impact on culture, medicine and perhaps the whole of civilization had it come to pass: What if, in the mid-1950s, Margaret Mead had publicly endorsed psychedelics?

headline: How to Put Fruits and Vegetables at the Center of Your Plate
abstract: From frozen berries to leafy greens, here’s inspiration for eating more of these Mediterranean diet superstars.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 2 of Well’s Mediterranean Diet Week. Start at the beginning here.

headline: Why This Unlikely Washington Friendship Endures
abstract: The surprising friendship that has made Donald Trump’s trade policies so durable.
lead_paragraph: They met in the 1990s, at an event about the North American Free Trade Agreement, where they were the only people arguing against it. He was a conservative trade lawyer who filed anti-dumping cases on behalf of American steel companies and predicted that the treaty would hurt American jobs. (It did.) She was a liberal activist with a consumer advocacy organization who planned protests featuring giant puppets. Her worry was that NAFTA’s rules would hurt working people and override U.S. legal standards on food safety and the environment. (They did.)

headline: Michelle Goldberg Imagines a Second Trump Inauguration
abstract: Sounding the alarm on “the utter bleakness.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald Trump handily won the Iowa caucuses on Monday night, bringing him one step closer to the Republican nomination. But was his victory inevitable?

headline: A Potentially Huge Supreme Court Case Has a Hidden Conservative Backer
abstract: The case, to be argued by lawyers linked to the petrochemicals billionaire Charles Koch, could sharply curtail the government’s regulatory authority.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on Wednesday that, on paper, are about a group of commercial fishermen who oppose a government fee that they consider unreasonable. But the lawyers who have helped to propel their case to the nation’s highest court have a far more powerful backer: the petrochemicals billionaire Charles Koch.

headline: Diabetes Is Fueling an Amputation Crisis for Men in San Antonio
abstract: A lethal combination of genetics, poor access to health care and diets high in processed foods is fueling a diabetes crisis in Latino communities, especially in Texas.
lead_paragraph: At a medical facility on the west side of San Antonio, the patients show up with disturbing regularity — most of them men. They have sores on their feet that won’t go away. And they leave with the same devastating news: Their diabetes has progressed to the point that their leg must be amputated to save their lives.

headline: The Man in the Sequined Tuxedo Who Built a Dance Community
abstract: Joe Lanteri, whose New York City Dance Alliance turns 30 this year, wants his dancers to have opportunities beyond competitions, including as college students.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar winner Ariana DeBose. The “Dancing With the Stars” judge Derek Hough. The ballet luminaries Catherine Hurlin, Tiler Peck and Taylor Stanley. Eleven cast members of last year’s Broadway production of “Bob Fosse’s Dancin’.”

headline: Best and Worst Moments From the 2023 Emmys
abstract: Most of the awards on Monday night went to favored shows like “Succession” and “The Bear.” But the ceremony, delayed from September, still had a few surprises.
lead_paragraph: The 2023 Emmys finally happened. In 2024.

headline: At Home with Patrick Page and Paige Davis
abstract: When Nate Berkus decorates your apartment, it’s best not to change a thing. Just ask this couple, who haven’t moved almost anything in 20 years.
lead_paragraph: When Nate Berkus decorates your apartment, it’s best not to change a thing. Just ask this couple, who haven’t moved almost anything in 20 years.

headline: When Nate Berkus Decorates Your Home, It’s Best Not to Change a Thing
abstract: Just ask the actors Patrick Page and Paige Davis, whose Upper West Side apartment has remained virtually untouched for two decades.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Page and Paige Davis met in the mid 1990s, during New York rehearsals for the first national tour of the musical “Beauty and the Beast.” But with Mr. Page working on his scenes in one studio (he played Lumière), and Ms. Davis, an ensemble member, singing and dancing in another, they didn’t really get acquainted until performances began in Minneapolis.

headline: How Much Water Do I Need to Drink?
abstract: Your water needs change as you age, and can also depend on your exercise habits and even where you live.
lead_paragraph: Q: How much water does the average person really need to drink? And is there such a thing as too much?

headline: Are You Growing Tired of Superhero Movies?
abstract: Or do you still eagerly await the latest film release in the genre?
lead_paragraph: Are you a fan of comic books and superhero movies? Have you seen every film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe? Do you eagerly mark your calendar when the latest release date is announced? Or are you growing a little tired of the genre?

headline: What the Child Care Crisis Does to Parents
abstract: The child care crisis, which has intensified since pandemic-era funding expired in September, is placing an undue and unhealthy burden on American parents.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday morning last May, Julia Sachdev, a mother of a 2-year-old and 4-year-old, woke up to an email from her children’s preschool. The school — which her children adored and had been in operation for over 50 years — announced that it would be closing in a month.

headline: Gucci’s Reboot Brings Back Old-School Cool
abstract: Delving into the archives, the label’s new creative director ditches his predecessor’s pussy bows and tweaks the classics.
lead_paragraph: The headline was Gucci. The headline was always going to be Gucci, in the same way the Ever Given was destined to dominate the news cycle when the mammoth vessel, one of the largest container ships ever built, got stuck in the Suez Canal back in 2021.

headline: In the Ozempic Age, Has ‘Craveable’ Lost Its Selling Power?
abstract: The food industry has long touted its products as impossible to resist. But with a spotlight on the perils of compulsive eating, that tactic is getting another look.
lead_paragraph: One day about 60 years ago, the comedian Bert Lahr put on a devil suit, held up a potato chip and uttered a phrase that would become a food-marketing milestone: “Betcha can’t eat just one.”

headline: How Group Chats Rule the World
abstract: They quietly became the de facto spaces to share dumb jokes, grief or even plans for an insurrection.
lead_paragraph: I am texting all the time. I am, at the very least, receiving texts all the time, a party to conversations in which I am alternately an eavesdropper and an active participant. This is because I am in a lot of group chats — constant, interlinked, text-message-based conversations among multiple friends that happen all day long. I dip into and out of these conversations, on my phone and on my computer. Sometimes I will put both away for two hours and return to find 279 new messages waiting.

headline: A Republican Pollster on Trump’s Undimmed Appeal
abstract: Kristen Soltis Anderson unpacks why Republican voters want stability — and how Trump represents it.
lead_paragraph: The fact that Donald Trump is the front-runner for the G.O.P. nomination in 2024 has created a chasm in our politics. In the past, Democrats and Republicans at least understood why members of the other party liked their chosen candidates. Most conservatives weren’t confused why liberals liked Barack Obama, and vice versa for George W. Bush. But for a lot of Democrats, it feels impossible to imagine why anyone would cast a vote for Trump. And as a result, the two parties don’t just feel hostile toward each other; they feel increasingly unknowable.

headline: A New Republican Mom Wants to Change House Rules for Postpartum Voting
abstract: Inspired by her own experience, Representative Anna Paulina Luna of Florida has broken with her party to call for proxy voting for female members of Congress for six weeks after giving birth.
lead_paragraph: When she arrived in Congress last year, Representative Anna Paulina Luna, a hard-right Republican from Florida, joined the rest of her party in staunchly opposing proxy voting, a practice adopted by House Democrats to allow for remote legislating during the pandemic.

headline: The U.S. Lacks What Every Democracy Needs
abstract: We should amend the Constitution to grant an affirmative right to vote.
lead_paragraph: The history of voting in the United States shows the high cost of living with an old Constitution, unevenly enforced by a reluctant Supreme Court.

headline: Senate Rejects Israel Human Rights Measure, but Skepticism on Aid Persists
abstract: Senators voted to kill a resolution that would have ordered the administration to assess whether Israel has violated human rights. But the debate highlighted Democratic resistance to providing unfettered aid.
lead_paragraph: When Hamas unleashed a bloody attack against Israel in October, there was a swift and strong bipartisan clamor of support in Congress for the United States to spare no expense in backing a robust military response by the Jewish state. More than 100 days later, that consensus on Capitol Hill shows signs of fraying, as left-wing Democrats alarmed by the rising human toll of the war in Gaza press to limit aid to Israel or impose strict conditions on it.

headline: Despite Frigid Cold, Texas Power Grid Has Kept the Heat On So Far
abstract: The state’s electric infrastructure, which failed during a winter storm in 2021, withstood the worst of this week’s Arctic chill.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Texans endured wickedly cold air on Tuesday, but the Texas power grid, which failed spectacularly during a deep freeze in 2021, held firm.

headline: Haley’s Missed Opportunity: Iowa Slows Her Roll Into New Hampshire
abstract: A third-place finish didn’t deliver the boost Nikki Haley wanted as she tries to turn the race into a one-on-one with Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley had hoped to vault into New Hampshire ahead of next Tuesday’s first-in-the-nation primary with a head of steam from a second-place finish in Iowa and a powerful case to make that the 2024 nomination fight was a two-candidate race between her and Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Rare and Punishing Cold Shuts Schools Across the South
abstract: The cold-weather closures affected about a million children in a region known for its mild winters.
lead_paragraph: Because of severe cold weather, schools across a wide swath of the South — from Texas and Tennessee to Alabama and Arkansas — were closed on Tuesday, affecting about one million children in a region known for its mild winters.

headline: Migrant Costs Help Push New York State’s Budget to $233 Billion
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s new spending plan, unveiled on Tuesday, also called for investments in mental health care and for an important change to the way that cannabis is taxed.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Tuesday unveiled a $233 billion budget for New York State that includes $2.4 billion to help New York City manage its migrant crisis — a $500 million increase reflecting the mounting costs as immigrants continue to arrive.

headline: A $75 Million Gift for CUNY Dedicated to A.I.
abstract: The Simons Foundation is to provide the largest gift in the history of New York City’s public university.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at how Gov. Kathy Hochul’s artificial intelligence initiative is taking shape. We’ll also look at a key lawyer’s decision to drop Donald Trump as a client in two cases in Manhattan.

headline: Even the Battle for Second Turned Out Well for Trump in Iowa
abstract: A dominant victory and little momentum for his rivals.
lead_paragraph: If there was any question whether Donald J. Trump was on track to win the Republican nomination, it was answered Monday night by the voters of Iowa.

headline: How Much Do You Know About San Marino?
abstract: Can you find San Marino on a map? What else do you know about this European nation with 33,000 people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find San Marino on a map? What else do you know about this European nation with 33,000 people?

headline: Frigid Temperatures Are Expected Across the U.S. on Tuesday
abstract: “Dangerously cold” wind chills were forecast for the Great Plains and Midwest, with record lows reaching into the Gulf Coast.
lead_paragraph: A blast of Arctic air was expected to reach into the Deep South on Tuesday morning, potentially breaking or tying low-temperature records for the day from Texas to Mississippi, according to forecasters at the National Weather Service.

headline: Israel Unearths More of a Subterranean Fortress Under Gaza
abstract: The Israeli military has been surprised by the extent, depth and quality of the tunnel network beneath Gaza.
lead_paragraph: One tunnel in Gaza was wide enough for a top Hamas official to drive a car inside. Another stretched nearly three football fields long and was hidden beneath a hospital. Under the house of a senior Hamas commander, the Israeli military found a spiral staircase leading to a tunnel approximately seven stories deep.

headline: Trump’s Domination and the Battle for No. 2 in Iowa
abstract: The 2024 presidential race began with a hefty win for Donald Trump. Can any Republican challenge his command of the party?
lead_paragraph: At the Iowa Republican caucuses on Monday night, Donald J. Trump secured a runaway victory. The only real drama was the fight for second place.

headline: Trump Wins Iowa, and Iceland’s Volcanic Eruption
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Trump’s Big Win in Iowa
abstract: The Times’s chief political analyst explains the caucus results.
lead_paragraph: If there was any question whether Donald Trump was on track to win the Republican nomination, it was answered Monday night by the voters of Iowa.

headline: Kids, get in the car. We’re taking a road trip to the caucuses.
abstract: Suri Botuck and her husband, Jacob Botuck, brought five of their children to Iowa from St. Louis for an up-close look at the political process.
lead_paragraph: Suri Botuck was eager to hear Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida deliver his closing pitch to Iowans on Sunday in Cedar Rapids — but she didn’t caucus for him on Monday night. Nor is she even from Iowa.

headline: Contenders
abstract: Why is this image in the news? What does it show, and why is that information important?
lead_paragraph: The image above was published on The New York Times homepage on Jan. 16.

headline: It’s January at a Big Himalayan Resort. Where’s the Snow?
abstract: A dry winter has been devastating to Gulmarg, one of Asia’s highest ski resorts, in Indian-controlled Kashmir.
lead_paragraph: Every morning, Ishfaaq Ahmad Malik, a ski instructor in Indian-controlled Kashmir, opens his bedroom window and, like many others in the region, wonders: Where is the snow?

headline: New York City Sees Significant Snowfall for First Time in 701 Days
abstract: More than an inch of snow fell in Central Park, ending a lengthy dry spell. Then it turned to rain.
lead_paragraph: New York City saw its biggest single-day snowfall in nearly two years on Tuesday, and while the total amount was less than two inches, it was enough to break the city’s longest recorded streak of no significant accumulation.

headline: Chinese Leader Gives Early Estimate of Economic Growth
abstract: Speaking at the Davos global forum a day before China is set to release economic data, Premier Li Qiang said the economy grew “around 5.2 percent.”
lead_paragraph: China’s second-highest leader said Tuesday that his country’s economy had grown “around 5.2 percent” last year, providing an unusual early glimpse of important economic data a day before its official release.

headline: 2 Missing SEALs Were on Mission to Stop Yemen-Bound Iranian Weapons, U.S. Says
abstract: The seized items, including missile guidance systems and warheads, were for the Iran-backed Houthi militia, which has been targeting ships in the Red Sea, the Pentagon said.
lead_paragraph: Two members of the Navy SEALs who were reported missing last week off the coast of Somalia were part of a nighttime commando operation that seized a small boat carrying lethal aid from Iran to the Houthi militia in Yemen, the U.S. military said on Tuesday.

headline: Do You Recognize These Lines From Classic Young-Adult Novels?
abstract: Test your memory with this short quiz featuring popular and award-winning books.
lead_paragraph: Test your memory with this short quiz featuring popular and award-winning books.

headline: Zelensky Calls for Peace, Not More Weapons, in Davos
abstract: In a speech in Switzerland, the Ukrainian president asked for more sanctions on Moscow, but he did not appeal for weaponry for new offenses.
lead_paragraph: With fighting still raging in Ukraine, and a front line that has barely shifted in more than a year, the country’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, headed on Tuesday to the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, amid a swirl of diplomatic discussions about possible peace talks.

headline: The Big Buzz at Davos: A.I., Ukraine, China, and the Middle East
abstract: C.E.O.s and world leaders gather in the Swiss Alps this year as war, trade risks and disruptive new technologies loom large.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of global leaders have once again descended on snowy Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting. The theme of this year’s event: “rebuilding trust.”

headline: Goldman Sachs Sticks the Landing at End of Tumultuous Year
abstract: The Wall Street bank earned $2 billion in the fourth quarter, beating expectations, after a period marked by management missteps.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs on Tuesday reported its second consecutive quarter of steady profits, a return to form for the bank, which has struggled with management missteps that tarnished its once untouchable reputation on Wall Street.

headline: Why a Faculty Strike Looms at the State University System
abstract: A walkout at the nation’s largest four-year public university system would affect hundreds of thousands of students.
lead_paragraph: Faculty members at the California State University system, the nation’s largest four-year public university system, are planning to cancel classes and strike next week as they demand higher pay and better benefits.

headline: Lawmakers Strike Tax Deal, but It Faces Long Election-Year Odds in Congress
abstract: A $78 billion package to revive an expansion of the child tax credit and expired business breaks has drawn bipartisan support in the House and Senate.
lead_paragraph: Top Democrats and Republicans in Congress on Tuesday released a $78 billion compromise they have reached to expand the child tax credit and restore three popular expired business tax breaks, but the package faces a challenging road to enactment in an election year.

headline: Musk Demands Bigger Stake in Tesla as Price for A.I. Work
abstract: Elon Musk, the electric car company’s chief executive, said he would “build products outside of Tesla” unless the board raises his stake to 25 percent.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, stunned investors by demanding that the company’s board give him shares worth more than $80 billion if it wants him to continue developing products based on artificial intelligence.

headline: A ‘Great Gatsby’ Musical Is Coming to Broadway in March
abstract: The latest adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic novel will feature Jeremy Jordan (“Newsies”) as Jay Gatsby and Eva Noblezada (“Hadestown”) as Daisy Buchanan.
lead_paragraph: “The Great Gatsby,” F. Scott Fitzgerald’s 1925 novel of garish glamour and dashed dreams, is coming to Broadway as a musical this spring.

headline: Congrats, and Goodbye, to Peak TV
abstract: The Emmys on Monday night felt in many ways like a bookend to one of the defining features of the streaming era: a never-ending supply of new programming.
lead_paragraph: As “Succession” cast members marched up to the Emmy stage on Monday night to grab their statues for the show’s final season, they used it as one last opportunity to say goodbye.

headline: New York City Snowfall Ends Nearly Two-Year Dry Spell
abstract: Commuters navigated snowy sidewalks as the city ended a streak of 701 days without significant accumulation.
lead_paragraph: Commuters navigated snowy sidewalks as the city ended a streak of 701 days without significant accumulation.

headline: One Plane Clips Another at Japan Airport, Weeks After Deadly Runway Blaze
abstract: Nobody was injured in the episode on Tuesday, which took place on the country’s northern island of Hokkaido amid heavy snow.
lead_paragraph: One plane clipped another at an airport on Japan’s snowy northern island of Hokkaido on Tuesday, according to the airlines involved, just weeks after a deadly runway blaze in Tokyo.

headline: ‘The Emigrants’ Review: A Troubled Show Finally Debuts
abstract: Krystian Lupa’s latest work had its premiere in Paris after an earlier attempt collapsed. The delay would have been a good time to rethink the four-and-a-half-hour show.
lead_paragraph: The spotlight is rarely on them. Yet as the technical crew moved furniture between scenes of Krystian Lupa’s new play “The Emigrants,” which finally had its world premiere in Paris on Saturday, they were watched as carefully as headline performers.

headline: New Zealand Lawmaker Resigns After Shoplifting Allegations
abstract: Golriz Ghahraman was the first refugee to be sworn in as a member of the country’s Parliament. She did not directly address the accusations but said her behavior “fell short.”
lead_paragraph: A lawmaker from New Zealand quit her job on Tuesday after allegations emerged that she had shoplifted from two clothing stores, actions she said were caused by stress affecting her mental health.

headline: Bringing a Diversity of Hip-Hop Dance to the Concert Stage
abstract: The highlight of the street dance festival “Motion/Matter” at the Perelman Performing Arts Center came at the end: an all-styles battle that honored roots.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years into the history of hip-hop, street to stage transfers remain tricky. Hip-hop dance is diverse and globally dominant, but when it’s put on concert stages, something often gets lost.

headline: Rex Heuermann Faces Fourth Murder Charge in Gilgo Beach Serial Killings
abstract: Mr. Heuermann is accused of killing Maureen Brainard-Barnes, the last of the so-called Gilgo Four, whose bodies were found along a desolate beach.
lead_paragraph: When Rex Heuermann was arrested and charged in July as the Gilgo Beach serial killer, prosecutors outlined a narrative against him that his defense lawyer, Michael Brown, attacked as cherry-picked and DNA evidence that Mr. Brown derided as shaky.

headline: Shell to Sell Its Onshore Nigeria Oil Business for $1.3 Billion
abstract: The energy company’s exit from onshore petroleum drilling in Nigeria is aimed to reduce risks, while it continues to produce oil and gas offshore.
lead_paragraph: Shell said Tuesday that it had agreed to sell its onshore oil and gas business in Nigeria to a group dominated by local companies for $1.3 billion.

headline: Asa Hutchinson Suspends Republican Presidential Bid
abstract: The former governor of Arkansas was the last major candidate remaining in the G.O.P. field who was vocally critical of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas, who entered the presidential race as an outspoken critic of former President Donald J. Trump but never gained traction, suspended his bid for the Republican nomination on Tuesday.

headline: Go Ahead and Double the Greens in These Recipes
abstract: Gochujang potato stew, buttery lemon pasta with arugula and skillet hot honey chicken are all excellent places to hide additional greens.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Mia here, the newsletter editor for New York Times Cooking, filling in for Emily. I hope everyone is enjoying a happy and healthy new year.

headline: The Ancient Back Story of the Slimiest Animal in the Sea
abstract: Researchers found that the slime eel, or hagfish, known for deluging predators with mucus, tripled the size of its genome hundreds of millions of years ago.
lead_paragraph: The hagfish, a deep-sea scavenger about the size and shape of a tube sock, has the curious ability to smother itself in its own snot. The mucus is a defense mechanism, released into the water (or in one unfortunate incident, all over an Oregon highway) when the fish feels threatened. Once it hits seawater, a tiny amount of the ooze expands to 10,000 times its original size in a fraction of a second, forming a tenacious web of goo. A shark trying to take a bite of a hagfish will find itself suddenly unable to breathe, its gills clogged with the slime.

headline: Lawsuit Claims James Dolan Pressured Woman Into Sex
abstract: In the court filing, the woman also says Harvey Weinstein sexually assaulted her in a 2014 encounter that she believes was set up by Mr. Dolan. Both men denied her accusations.
lead_paragraph: A woman filed a federal lawsuit Tuesday accusing James L. Dolan, the entertainment and sports mogul behind Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks, of pressuring her into unwanted sex and then coordinating an encounter with Harvey Weinstein, whom she accused of sexually assaulting her.

headline: Morgan Wallen’s Latest Album Reclaims No. 1 for a 17th Time
abstract: “One Thing at a Time,” the country star’s 2023 release, tops the Billboard chart in a slow sales week.
lead_paragraph: So far in 2024, the Billboard album chart is looking a lot like 2023.

headline: You Don’t Need a Ticket for Weill Café at Carnegie Hall
abstract: Thai tea service in Woodside Queens, Northern Mexican cuisine from a Contra alum and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Yes, we know, you get to Carnegie Hall with “practice, practice.” And once you get there, starting Saturday for dinner and Monday for breakfast, lunch and coffee, you can have something to eat. On Monday, the new Weill Café, occupying the stately, cream-colored room, recently renovated with gold and burgundy accents, that has long been serving snacks and drinks during intermissions, will be open to the public from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., Mondays through Fridays. Breakfast items, coffee and tea, soups, salads, quiches, sandwiches and pastries will be available, and there is a bar. It will have a street entrance, so a concert ticket is not required. That’s not the case when it comes to preconcert dining however. Those with tickets to select performances in the Stern Auditorium can book tables starting at 6 p.m. for a three-course dinner, $139 including unlimited beverages, tax and service. An initial menu by the executive chef, Derek Prough, working for Constellation Culinary Group, which is running the cafe, includes burrata with vegetables, citrus and beet carpaccio with shrimp, seared branzino, glazed short rib, roasted acorn squash tower, and dessert bites like chocolate lava cakes and apple-spice Bundt cakes. The cafe area will be open to concertgoers during intermissions. (Opens Jan. 20, 22)

headline: After Iowa, Trump Is Back to Command the National Psyche. He Never Actually Left.
abstract: The former president’s detractors own no earplugs effective enough to block out his steamrolling bid for a third nomination.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, not so long ago, when those wearied and horrified by the presidency of Donald J. Trump could almost convince themselves that the man was gone.

headline: A Fed Governor Reiterates That Rate Cuts Are Coming
abstract: Christopher Waller, one of seven Washington-based Fed governors, said officials should cut rates as inflation cools — though timing was uncertain.
lead_paragraph: A prominent Federal Reserve official on Tuesday laid out a case for lowering interest rates methodically at some point this year as the economy comes into balance and inflation cools — although he acknowledged that the timing of those cuts remained uncertain.

headline: Exploring Caribbean Food, Island by Island
abstract: A new guard of chefs is getting specific about a cuisine that is often flattened into one large region.
lead_paragraph: When the chef Tavel Bristol-Joseph was opening Canje in Austin, Texas, in 2021, he did something he had yet to do as a restaurant owner: He decided to tell his own story. Namely, the story of growing up in Georgetown, Guyana, a South American country with deep ties to the Caribbean through food and culture.

headline: U.S. Strikes Houthi Targets in Yemen for a Third Time
abstract: The American strikes destroyed four missiles that posed a threat to ships in the Red Sea, the Pentagon said. They came on the third day in a row the Houthis have defiantly fired at passing ships.
lead_paragraph: The United States carried out a new military strike against Houthi ballistic missiles in Yemen on Tuesday, the U.S. military said, but the latest salvo against the Iran-backed group left the White House grappling with how to stop a battle-hardened foe from disrupting shipping lanes critical for global trade.

headline: Three Myths Around the U.K.’s Rwanda Push for Asylum Seekers
abstract: The British government’s plan to send asylum seekers to Africa is back in Parliament this week. Here’s a guide to some of the difficult realities behind the issue.
lead_paragraph: The debate about Britain’s asylum system has been cloaked in layers of misunderstanding, misinformation and even propaganda as the issue has become increasingly politicized.

headline: Trump’s Landslide Victory in Iowa
abstract: Readers offer their takeaways from the Republican caucuses. Also: Young voters; U.S. strikes in Yemen; genocide charges against Israel.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Charlotte St. Martin to Step Down as President of Broadway League
abstract: No reason was given for her unexpected retirement after 18 years in the pivotal role.
lead_paragraph: In a surprise announcement on Tuesday, Charlotte St. Martin, who has led the Broadway League since 2006, said she would be stepping down from her current role next month.

headline: Synopsys Strikes $35 Billion Deal to Buy Ansys
abstract: The deal was the latest sign of changes in the tech sector, as artificial intelligence booms and sales of some hardware slows.
lead_paragraph: Synopsys, a key Silicon Valley supplier to the chip industry, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to pay $35 billion for Ansys, a Pennsylvania company that makes software used to simulate and analyze product designs for electronics manufacturers, car makers, defense contractors and others.

headline: Was Bobi Really the World’s Oldest Dog? His Guinness Record Is in Doubt.
abstract: His owner’s claim that Bobi, a Rafeiro do Alentejo from Portugal, was more than 31 drew skepticism. His title is on hold pending an investigation.
lead_paragraph: When Bobi died in October in Portugal, he was hailed as the oldest dog ever to have lived, at 31 years, 5 months.

headline: ABC News Cancels G.O.P. Debate After Haley Demands Trump Appear, Too
abstract: Nikki Haley said she would not agree to more debates unless Donald Trump was onstage with her. Another debate, on CNN, was in doubt before the New Hampshire primary next week.
lead_paragraph: ABC News canceled a Republican presidential debate scheduled for Thursday in New Hampshire, after Ron DeSantis was the only candidate who had agreed to participate.

headline: Zvi Zamir, Israeli Spy Chief in a Critical Period, Dies at 98
abstract: He led the Mossad’s response to the massacre of 11 Israelis at the 1972 Olympics. A year later, he learned that Egypt and Syria were about to attack Israel.
lead_paragraph: Zvi Zamir, who as the director of Israel’s Mossad spy agency led a violent campaign to crush Palestinian terrorism after 11 Israelis were killed at the 1972 Munich Summer Olympics — and who a year later relayed a warning to his government that Egypt and Syria were about to start the Yom Kippur War but was not taken seriously — died on Jan. 2. He was 98.

headline: Christina Applegate’s Resilience Shone Through at the Emmys
abstract: The actress referenced her chronic illness with humor — as a defense mechanism and a disarmament.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night at the 75th Emmy Awards in Los Angeles, Christina Applegate, a presenter of the award for supporting actress in a comedy series, used a cane and walked to the podium with effortful dignity. The 52-year-old actress, who was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 2021, wore a red, silk-velvet dress, her signature blond hair parted to the side, cascading down her shoulders like a golden curtain.

headline: Brent Sikkema, Influential Gallerist, Is Found Dead in His Rio Apartment
abstract: The Brazilian police said they were investigating the art dealer’s death and looking for witnesses.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan art dealer Brent Sikkema, who represented prominent artists like Kara Walker, Jeffrey Gibson and Vik Muniz, was found dead in his Rio de Janeiro apartment on Monday night.

headline: Judge Blocks JetBlue From Acquiring Spirit Airlines
abstract: The ruling is a victory for the Justice Department, which had argued that the merger would reduce competition.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday blocked JetBlue Airways’ proposed $3.8 billion acquisition of Spirit Airlines, a victory for the Department of Justice, which argued that the deal would harm travelers.

headline: Covid, Crutches, Surgery: For Christopher Abbott the Show Somehow Went On
abstract: “I thought this could be my swan song, in terms of the angry-young-man thing,” said the actor of his rocky run of “Danny and the Deep Blue Sea.”
lead_paragraph: Christopher Abbott was about halfway through a performance of “Danny and the Deep Blue Sea” when he felt something go wrong. The 37-year-old actor had been sitting onstage — his character, a brutish trucker, proposing marriage to a tormented woman played by Aubrey Plaza — and as he went to get up, he couldn’t straighten his leg.

headline: 8 Upcoming Albums to Get Excited About
abstract: Sample songs from LPs by Waxahatchee, the Smile, Helado Negro and more.
lead_paragraph: Now that 2023 and all of its best-of-the-year lists are finally in the rearview, it’s time to look ahead to the music being released in 2024.

headline: Haley Looks to New Hampshire With a Focus on Independents
abstract: The former South Carolina governor has banked her campaign on the state, buoyed by an influx of cash and an advertising blitz as she looks to rebound from Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s resounding victory in Iowa significantly raises the stakes of next week’s New Hampshire primary for Nikki Haley and the increasingly desperate contingent of Republicans who want to move on from Mr. Trump.

headline: Biden Invites Congressional Leaders to White House to Discuss Aid to Ukraine
abstract: President Biden’s request for more than $110 billion in assistance for Ukraine, Israel and the border, has been held up by a dispute with Republicans on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: President Biden invited congressional leaders to a meeting at the White House on Wednesday to discuss his funding request for Ukraine, Israel and the border, which has been stalled for weeks on Capitol Hill.

headline: ‘June’ Review: The Enduring Appeal of June Carter Cash
abstract: A new documentary by Kristen Vaurio details the life and career of the singer-songwriter, who was a member of country music royalty.
lead_paragraph: The singer June Carter Cash was born in 1929 into the Carter Family, an influential early country music group, and toured with Elvis Presley in the 1950s. She married Johnny Cash in 1968 and became part of his touring show. She also wrote, with Merle Kilgore, of one of Cash’s greatest hits, “Ring of Fire.”

headline: Climate is on the Ballot Around the World
abstract: About half of the world’s population will be electing leaders this year.
lead_paragraph: More than 40 countries that are home to about half of the world’s population — including the United States, India and South Africa — will be electing their leaders this year.

headline: Deadly Iranian Strikes in Iraq and Pakistan Inflame Regional Tensions
abstract: Iran says its missile strikes were aimed at militant groups behind attacks on its territory, but Pakistan and Iraq rejected that explanation.
