lead_paragraph: Iran hit its neighbors Pakistan and Iraq with missile strikes on Tuesday, prompting strong denunciations from both countries and raising fears that upheaval in the Middle East could spiral out of control.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Something Told Me to Stay’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: Vietnam and New York, our worlds were far apart. Camp for me meant refugee sites, ration lines; for Adam, summer and water sports. After we met in college, he gave me my first bouquet. I plucked flowers from his gift (and the college grounds) to create my own bouquet for him. “You don’t rebundle a gift,” he said. “Why waste money?” I countered. It took us 30 years as a couple to finally agree that both are true: A gift shouldn’t be re-gifted, but once given, a gift is no longer yours. Now, we’ve moved on to new disagreements! — Oanh Ngo Usadi

headline: Brian Barczyk, a Reptile Evangelist on YouTube and TV, Dies at 54
abstract: A snake breeder, Mr. Barczyk amassed an online following in the millions with cheerful videos that captured his passion for snakes, lizards and other types of reptiles.
lead_paragraph: Brian Barczyk, a reptile expert whose upbeat videos attracted millions of fans on social media and who starred in the reality TV show “Venom Hunters,” died on Sunday at his home in Michigan. He was 54.

headline: The House G.O.P.’s Incredible Shrinking Majority
abstract: Another Republican resignation and medical absences are cutting into the party’s already shaky hold on the chamber.
lead_paragraph: When Republicans assumed control of the House early last year after winning a narrow majority in the 2022 midterms, Representative Earl Blumenauer, a veteran Democrat from Oregon, made a bold prediction: His party had a slight chance of reclaiming power before the next election — through sheer attrition.

headline: Should We Be Seeing Red Over the Red Sea?
abstract: It’s a major choke point, but some perspective is in order.
lead_paragraph: There are many reasons to be horrified about recent events in the Middle East, and the prospect that attacks on shipping might undermine progress against inflation is way, way down the list. Nonetheless, if you are trying to forecast inflation, disruption of a major choke point for global commerce — the Red Sea is how ships get to and from the Suez Canal — isn’t what you want to see. But how big a deal is it?

headline: Restaurant Review: At Eulalie, a Warm Welcome Is a Phone Call Away
abstract: This new place in TriBeCa, a successor to the Simone uptown, offers old-fashioned values and an old-fashioned way of taking reservations.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, when I had my first meal at the Simone, you could have described it as slightly behind the times.

headline: Authorities Investigate Threats to Democratic Lawmakers
abstract: The inquiry by the Capitol Police and the F.B.I. came after a website released a recording that it said captured Roger J. Stone Jr. in 2020 expressing a desire for the deaths of two Trump critics.
lead_paragraph: The Capitol Police and the F.B.I. are investigating remarks reported to have been made by Roger J. Stone Jr., a longtime Republican operative and informal adviser to former President Donald J. Trump, in which he expressed a desire for the deaths of two Democratic lawmakers in the weeks before the 2020 election, a government official familiar with the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: The Harriet Tubman? The Anne Frank? House Layout Names Draw Criticism.
abstract: A listing in Albuquerque drew the ire of Zillow’s social media watchers. A design firm said the names were meant to honor both women and changed the descriptions referencing them after criticism.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, the adobe-style ranch house on the outskirts of Albuquerque appears to be like any other three-bedroom house. But its designers took inspiration from an unusual source.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Trump’s Momentum After Iowa
abstract: Also, the afterlife of a Japanese marvel.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump swept the Iowa caucuses, the first Republican primary of the 2024 election. He got 51 percent of the vote — a clear sign of his enduring command of the Republican Party. Here are takeaways.

headline: Tom Shales, TV Critic Both Respected and Feared, Dies at 79
abstract: An incisively funny Washington Post columnist, he earned nicknames like Terrible Tom and had the clout to make or break shows.
lead_paragraph: Tom Shales, the Pulitzer Prize-winning television critic for The Washington Post whose scalpel-sharp dissections of shows he deemed dead on arrival earned him nicknames like the Terror of the Tube, as well as a reputation for the power to make or break shows, died on Saturday in Alexandria, Va. He was 79.

headline: Adele, Beyoncé, the Sphere: How Es Devlin Reinvented Modern Spectacle
abstract: The  Cooper Hewitt shows, in mini-scale,  the designer’s monumental success building metaphors for the mind, from opera to theater to pop.
lead_paragraph: As visual storytelling presses toward new technological heights, it is worth recalling that some of the oldest and richest tactics of illusion — from the proscenium arches of the Renaissance to the lintels and lightboxes of Robert Wilson — originated onstage.

headline: 4.3 Million Watched the Emmys, a New Low
abstract: The Emmys had a lot going against it, including a ceremony delayed months by the Hollywood strikes, and stiff competition from other events.
lead_paragraph: The Emmy Awards ratings collapse continues.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Tries Creating Own Party to Get on Ballot in 6 States
abstract: Filing to form a new party is a way for the independent to get his name on the ballot with fewer voter signatures.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who is running for president as an independent, announced on Tuesday that he had filed paperwork to create his own political party in six states — an effort to get his name on the ballot with fewer voter signatures than would be required for an unaffiliated candidate.

headline: Here Are the Winners of the ‘Castle Quest’ Contest
abstract: See the answers to the 2023 “Puzzle Mania” contest.
lead_paragraph: More than 50,000 in-person escape rooms are said to be in operation worldwide. “Castle Quest,” by Jason Boomer, is a virtual escape room, and was the subject of one of two contests included in the 2023 Puzzle Mania print section of the New York Times. By Jan. 7, the contest deadline, we had received 1,836 correct solutions to the puzzle.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kristen Soltis Anderson
abstract: The Jan. 16, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kristen Soltis Anderson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Aunjanue Ellis-Taylor and Ava DuVernay on the Emotional Journey of ‘Origin’
abstract: For their unconventional adaptation of Isabel Wilkerson’s “Caste,” the writer-director and star tapped into the best-seller’s poignant back story.
lead_paragraph: Ava DuVernay and Aunjanue Ellis-Taylor were in the middle of shooting their new drama, “Origin,” when Ellis-Taylor gave the writer-director some last-minute homework.

headline: After Gloomy Warnings, Adams Unveils N.Y.C. Budget That’s Not So Dire
abstract: Proposing a $109 billion budget, Mayor Eric Adams said that New York City’s financial outlook had improved, but he still called for more federal funding to help pay for the migrant crisis.
lead_paragraph: After months of warning New Yorkers of an imminent fiscal crisis, Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday proposed a $109 billion budget that he framed as far less dire than expected.

headline: U.S. Faults Mississippi Poultry Plant in Death of 16-Year-Old
abstract: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration cited Mar-Jac Poultry with 17 violations in the death of a teenager who was caught in a machine. It faces more than $200,000 in fines.
lead_paragraph: A Mississippi poultry plant’s disregard of safety policies was directly to blame for the death of a 16-year-old boy who was fatally injured in July after being pulled into a machine there, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration said on Monday.

headline: Macron, Promising a More Dynamic France, Vows to Break Taboos
abstract: The president also said during a televised appearance he would fight to the last to prevent the far-right leader Marine Le Pen from succeeding him.
lead_paragraph: Vowing to “break taboos,” deregulate the economy and fight to the last against the extreme right, President Emmanuel Macron presented his vision of a stronger, more just France during a televised news conference that lasted deep into the Parisian night on Tuesday.

headline: Trump Left Iowa With Momentum and a Court Date
abstract: Also, the U.S. struck Houthi targets for a third time. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa caucuses could hardly have gone better for Donald Trump. The former president won the first presidential nominating contest by 30 percentage points — more than double the record in the state’s competitive Republican races. His dominance codified, yet again, his double-fisted hold on the Republican electorate.

headline: Bloomberg and Crypto Billionaire Among Donors to Adams’s Legal Defense
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams of New York set up the fund amid a broad federal corruption investigation into his campaign’s fund-raising practices.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams raised $732,000 in less than two months to pay for legal expenses related to a federal investigation into his campaign fund-raising, according to a filing submitted Tuesday.

headline: New York Reminds Itself How to Dress for Snow
abstract: Locals and visitors layered up for the city’s first major snowfall in nearly two years.
lead_paragraph: At 8 a.m. on Tuesday, a basset hound ambled through Prospect Park in Brooklyn in an extra-long turtleneck sweater. The dog’s ears swept the ground, which was covered in snow — real, fluffy, not-yet-yellow snow — for the first time in nearly two years.

headline: ‘Harmony,’ Barry Manilow’s Passion Project, to Close on Broadway
abstract: The musical, which Manilow wrote with Bruce Sussman, is about a German singing ensemble that collided with the rising Nazi regime.
lead_paragraph: “Harmony,” Barry Manilow’s long-in-the-works musical about an early-20th-century German sextet that ran afoul of the Nazi regime, will end an abbreviated Broadway run on Feb. 4.

headline: Malaysian Prisoners Plead Guilty to Conspiring in 2002 Bali Bombing
abstract: The men, who have been held by the United States for two decades as lieutenants to a Southeast Asian terrorist, entered pleas at Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: Two Malaysian prisoners at Guantánamo Bay pleaded guilty on Tuesday to conspiring in the October 2002 nightclub bombings in the resort island of Bali, Indonesia, that killed more than 200 people.

headline: The Genocide Charge Against Israel Is a Moral Obscenity
abstract: In a war, the killing ends when one side stops fighting. In a genocide, that’s when the killing begins.
lead_paragraph: In recent decades, as many as three million people perished in a famine in North Korea that was mainly government-induced. Hundreds of thousands of Syrians were gassed, bombed, starved or tortured to death by the Assad regime, and an estimated 14 million were forced to flee their homes. China has put more than a million Uyghurs through gulag-like re-education camps in a thinly veiled attempt to suppress and erase their religious and cultural identity.

headline: For Biden, Another Trump Nomination Presents Opportunity, and Great Risk
abstract: Some Democrats consider the former president the Republican they would have the best chance against this fall, but also the one they most fear the consequences of losing to.
lead_paragraph: To be clear, no one in President Biden’s White House would ever root for Donald J. Trump. To a person, they consider him an existential threat to the nation. But as they watched Mr. Trump open the contest for the Republican presidential nomination with a romp through Iowa, they also saw something else: a pathway to a second term.

headline: Hamas Rocket Barrage Stirs Debate in Israel Over Direction of War
abstract: Right-wing lawmakers said the attack on Tuesday showed the folly of withdrawing some troops from the Gaza Strip, while Israel’s government faces international pressure to scale back further.
lead_paragraph: Hamas fighters in the northern Gaza Strip fired at least 25 rockets toward a nearby Israeli city on Tuesday, renewing right-wing criticism in Israel of the government’s decision to scale back some military operations in the war.

headline: 98-1: A Single Iowa County Prevented a Trump Shutout in the Caucuses
abstract: Nikki Haley won Johnson County, the state’s bluest, by a single vote.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump won 98 of 99 counties in the Iowa caucuses on Monday, according to preliminary results published by the state Republican Party, demonstrating just how broadly he swept the first-in-the-nation contest.

headline: 2 N.Y.P.D. Officers Shot After Man Grabs Gun From One, Officials Say
abstract: The shooting came after the officers responded to a family dispute at a Brooklyn apartment, officials said. The man who grabbed the gun was also shot, they said.
lead_paragraph: Two New York City police officers were shot in a Brooklyn apartment on Tuesday after a man grabbed a service weapon from one officer during a skirmish that unfolded as the officers responded to a call about a domestic dispute, officials said.

headline: China’s Economy Grew Last Year, but Strains Lurk Behind the Numbers
abstract: Gross domestic product expanded 5.2 percent, as China worked to export more to make up for weak demand, high debt and a steep property contraction at home.
lead_paragraph: Car production set records in China last year. Restaurants and hotels were increasingly full. Construction of new factories surged.

headline: China Told Women to Have Babies, but Its Population Shrank Again
abstract: Faced with falling births, China’s efforts to stabilize a shrinking population and maintain economic growth are failing.
lead_paragraph: China’s ruling Communist Party is facing a national emergency. To fix it, the party wants more women to have more babies.

headline: Senate Advances Stopgap Bill to Avert a Partial Shutdown
abstract: The lopsided vote reflected broad backing for the measure in the Senate. It faces a more fraught reception in the House, where hard-right Republicans are opposed.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Tuesday took the first step in advancing a stopgap spending bill to avoid a partial government shutdown at the end of the week, buying time to enact a broader bipartisan funding agreement for the remainder of the year.

headline: Votes for Multiple Parties
abstract: Things turn out all right in Morton J. Mendelson’s crossword.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Tacoma Officers Cleared in Black Man’s Death Will Get $500,000 Each to Resign
abstract: The three police officers were found not guilty last month in the death of Manuel Ellis, who died in custody in 2020 after pleading that he could not breathe.
lead_paragraph: Three Tacoma police officers who were acquitted in the death of Manuel Ellis, a Black man who died in police custody in 2020 after pleading that he could not breathe, will each receive $500,000 for resigning from the Tacoma Police Department, according to documents released by the city on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Fargo’ Season 5 Finale Recap: Debts
abstract: Dot sees an opportunity. Ole Munch sees an account that needs settling.
lead_paragraph: The show may be called “Fargo,” but setting aside the Upper Midwest setting and colloquialisms, this fifth season has been more in conversation with a different Coen Brothers thriller, “No Country for Old Men,” their faithful rendering of the Cormac McCarthy novel. From the beginning, Roy Tillman has served as a malevolent twist on Tommy Lee Jones’s Ed Tom Bell in “No Country,” both hailing from a long line of county sheriffs patrolling arid stretches of countryside occasionally pocked with outlaws.

headline: U.S. to Return Houthis to Terrorism List
abstract: The move is a partial return to a tougher Trump administration stance toward the Iran-backed group, which has attacked commercial ships in the Red Sea and the Gulf of Aden.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration will designate Yemen’s Houthi militia as a terrorist organization, partly reimposing penalties it lifted nearly three years ago on the Iran-backed group whose attacks on regional shipping traffic have drawn a U.S. military response.

headline: Trump Signals Plans to Go After Intelligence Community in Document Case
abstract: Court papers filed by his lawyers, formally a request for discovery evidence, sounded at times more like political talking points.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump said in court papers filed on Tuesday night that they intended to place accusations that the intelligence community was biased against Mr. Trump at the heart of their defense against charges accusing him of illegally holding onto dozens of highly sensitive classified documents after he left office.

headline: Airbus Is Pulling Ahead as Boeing’s Troubles Mount
abstract: With quality control essential, Airbus gains in the rivalry between the world’s biggest plane makers by being seen as “competent.”
lead_paragraph: Airbus cemented its position last week as the world’s biggest plane maker for the fifth straight year, announcing that it had delivered more aircraft and secured more orders than Boeing in 2023. At the same time, Boeing was trying to put out a huge public-relations and safety crisis caused by a harrowing near disaster involving its 737 Max line of airliners.

headline: The ‘Five Families’: Why Sunak’s Conservatives Have Splintered Into Factions
abstract: The biggest challenge to Britain’s prime minister comes from his own divided party, which is triggering resignations and a mutiny over immigration.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain faces a litany of woes, from a double-digit deficit in the polls to a grinding cost-of-living crisis. But this week, his biggest source of agita comes from the “five families,” a loose coalition of right-wing factions in his Conservative Party that is threatening, yet again, to torpedo his asylum policy.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: U.S. attacks in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. carried out a third military strike against Houthi ballistic missiles in Yemen, the U.S. military said. The strike destroyed four missiles that the Pentagon’s Central Command said posed an imminent threat to merchant vessels and Navy ships traveling through the Red Sea and nearby waters.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Russia Sows Instability, Davos Forum Is Cautioned
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t believe Putin is capable of changing, only humans can do that.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 17, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about strikes by the United States in response to attacks from proxies of Iran and efforts to avoid direct confrontation misspelled the given name of a Yemen analyst. He is Raiman al-Hamdani, not Rainam.

headline: In New Hampshire, Haley and DeSantis Were Asked About Race in America. It Got Awkward.
abstract: Nikki Haley said in an interview that “America has never been a racist country.” DeSantis responded in a town hall that “we had challenges with how race was viewed.”
lead_paragraph: When Ron DeSantis was asked on Tuesday night in a televised town hall in New Hampshire if he agreed with Nikki Haley that “America has never been a racist country,” as she had said earlier in the day, it seemed like an easy opportunity to hit his rival.

headline: A Peaceful Solution on Taiwan Is Slipping Away
abstract: Taiwan’s election showed that the island’s people want their freedom, leaving China few options aside from war to achieve the unification it desires.
lead_paragraph: Conflict between China and the United States just got a little more likely.

headline: Team Biden Needs a Reset on Israel
abstract: The administration has failed to achieve its goals on Israeli policies and actions. It should change course.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2001, in a visit to the illegal West Bank settlement of Ofra, an out-of-office Benjamin Netanyahu, apparently unaware he was being recorded, boasted to his hosts that “America is a thing you can move very easily — move it in the right direction.”

headline: Word of the Day: entreat
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word entreat has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 8 in the Opinion essay “In Paris, I Get Judged on What I Speak, Not How I Look” by Euny Hong:

headline: Late Night Laments Donald Trump’s Sweeping Victory in Iowa
abstract: “Even though he barely spent any time in Iowa, it somehow made voters love him more,” Jimmy Kimmel said. “It’s the same strategy he used raising Eric and Don Jr.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: China’s Youth Unemployment Rate Is Back, and Better
abstract: The government stopped releasing the jobless rate for young workers when it was soaring. It says its “optimized” new method is more accurate.
lead_paragraph: After suspending the public release of youth unemployment rates last year, China started distributing the information again on Wednesday, using different measurement criteria that lowered the figure significantly.

headline: U.K. Inflation Edges Higher, Halting 10-Month Decline
abstract: Britain’s inflation rate ticked up to 4 percent in December, driven by an increase in tobacco taxes.
lead_paragraph: Inflation in Britain rose slightly in December, picking up for the first time in almost a year, after a change in tobacco taxes pushed up prices.

headline: China’s Economy Spooks Markets, and Hong Kong Stocks Sink
abstract: Pessimism among investors was most pronounced in Hong Kong, where stocks have plunged by 10 percent so far this year.
lead_paragraph: China’s No. 2 leader, Li Qiang, traveled to Switzerland with a message for the titans of the business world gathered for the World Economic Forum.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Wild Weather
abstract: Snow? Wind? Cold? Rain? Floods? Has your area experienced hazardous weather recently?
lead_paragraph: If you live in the United States, chances are you’ve experienced some extreme weather recently. The map above, created by FEMA, the Federal Emergency Management Agency, shows a “hazards outlook” for weather they expected to start last weekend.

headline: Hakim, Meet Hakeem: How a Young City Farmer Got to Know a Congressman
abstract: For most of his life, Hakim Jeffrey’s only connections to Representative Hakeem Jeffries were Brooklyn and their similar names. Then they crossed paths.
lead_paragraph: Growing up, Hakim Jeffrey did not think much about politics. But people would often point out that his name sounded very similar to the name of his representative in Congress, a rising star in the House and fellow Brooklyn native.

headline: Migrants Sleep in the Snow in Desperate Wait for ID Cards
abstract: As the migrant crisis entered a precarious new phase in New York City, some families hoped an identification card could help them find work.
lead_paragraph: As snow swirled down after midnight on Tuesday, about three dozen migrants, including two families with children, huddled on the sidewalk under thin blankets outside a city office in Brooklyn.

headline: Frankfurt Airport Halts Takeoffs Because of Snow and Ice
abstract: About 700 flights were canceled on Wednesday at Germany’s largest airport because of severe weather. Departures resumed later in the day.
lead_paragraph: Heavy snow and freezing rain grounded hundreds of flights in Germany on Wednesday, including at Frankfurt Airport, one of Europe’s busiest, where no flights were taking off at midday as a blast of Arctic air made its way across the continent.

headline: How to Protect Millions of Workers Without a Union
abstract: There’s more than one way for workers to organize.
lead_paragraph: There’s more than one way for workers to organize.

headline: Tight on Time? How to Make the Most of a Short Workout.
abstract: Combining resistance training and cardio will get your heart pumping, even if you only have 15 or 20 minutes to spare.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to exercise, there’s a difference between what’s ideal and what’s, well, possible.

headline: 3 Sumptuous Palaces to Explore on Your Spanish Vacation
abstract: The storied Alba family has thrown open the doors of its art-filled homes in Madrid, Seville and Salamanca, inviting visitors inside for a taste of a bygone era.
lead_paragraph: One of the most important cultural events in Madrid in recent years was the public opening, just before the pandemic, of a collection that had been sitting behind the closed doors of a private palace for about 200 years.

headline: If You’re Thinking About Growing Onions From Seed, It’s Time to Get Started
abstract: Now is the time to buy onion seeds, which are cheaper and come in more interesting varieties than mail-order transplants. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: There are some things I never forget: Where each plant in my garden came from. Who unlocked the secret of successfully growing carrots for me (John Navazio, then a senior scientist at Organic Seed Alliance). Who shared the best strategy for keeping tomato diseases at bay (Tom Stearns, the founder of High Mowing Organic Seeds).

headline: Prince of Persia Goes 2.5-D, Testing the Faith of Fans
abstract: There was a divisive trailer for Prince of Persia: The Lost Crown, the franchise’s first game in 14 years. But the developers behind Rayman Legends are confident in their approach.
lead_paragraph: There had been more than a decade of anticipation for Prince of Persia: The Lost Crown when its debut trailer was unveiled last year. Fans hoped the first major installment in the video game series since 2010’s Prince of Persia: The Forgotten Sands would be another lavish 3-D adventure, with state-of-the-art graphics and boundary-pushing sword-and-sandals action.

headline: The New Labor Playbook
abstract: There’s more than one way for workers to organize.
lead_paragraph: As the Opinion video above explores, these are heady times for organized labor.

headline: To Be a ‘Palatable Jew’ — in Germany in 1940, in the U.S. Today
abstract: Victor Klemperer considered himself a German above all else. His diaries of life in the Third Reich chronicle his painful awakening to violent antisemitism.
lead_paragraph: I am sitting in the lobby of my son’s Brooklyn school, reading the diaries of Victor Klemperer. The diaries have sat on my shelf for years — invaluable, excruciating records of daily life in the Third Reich. Occasionally, I’ve paged through them. But in the fall of 2023, they play on a different register. Here is a portrait of a man confronting a surging antisemitism he hadn’t known — or wanted to know — existed.

headline: A Reporter’s Journey Into How the U.S. Funded the Bomb
abstract: Watching “Oppenheimer,” a journalist wondered (perhaps a bit obsessively): How did the president get the $2 billion secret project past Congress?
lead_paragraph: As I sat in a dark, cavernous movie theater in Berlin watching the film “Oppenheimer,” my mind was thousands of miles away.

headline: It’s Probably Time to Clean Your Water Bottle
abstract: Yes, that black stuff is mold.
lead_paragraph: Reusable water bottles are a great way to get hydrated and stay energized. Many can help minimize your exposure to nanoplastics. They’re trendy, and better for the environment than plastic bottles.

headline: Can This Viral Bedtime ‘Mocktail’ Actually Help You Fall Asleep?
abstract: We asked experts about the effectiveness of the homemade ‘Sleepy Girl Mocktail’ taking over TikTok.
lead_paragraph: The recipe for a “sleepy girl mocktail” is simple, and its promise is alluring: Swirl a spoonful of magnesium into a fizzing glass of seltzer and tart cherry juice, take a big sip and get the best sleep of your life.

headline: For More Plant-Based Protein in Your Diet, Try These Legumes
abstract: You don’t even need to turn on the stove.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 3 of Well’s Mediterranean Diet Week. Start at the beginning here.

headline: This Month, Warm Up With a Sizzling-Hot Romance Novel
abstract: Our romance columnist on four saucy January releases.
lead_paragraph: January is the month for second chances, so it’s fitting that this year’s first book is one I had to try twice before we clicked.

headline: Are You a Super Driver? Some States Want to Help You Go Electric.
abstract: A small share of motorists burns about a third of America’s gasoline, a study found. Switching to electric vehicles would make a huge dent in climate-warming emissions.
lead_paragraph: The key to cutting emissions from cars and light trucks that are heating the planet could lie with the nation’s super drivers, the small percentage of American motorists who drive, on average, about 110 miles per day.

headline: Living With Fire When It’s Fire Season All Year Round
abstract: In a new book, Manjula Martin explores her accommodation to life in Northern California in an era of increasingly extreme weather.
lead_paragraph: Even after evacuating her home in Sonoma County, Calif., as wildfires burned nearby, Manjula Martin reflected on her stubborn longing to exempt herself from what was happening.

headline: When There’s Pasta in the Soup, Everybody’s Happy
abstract: This light winter minestrone is the perfect antidote to the excess of the holidays.
lead_paragraph: How big is an appetite? Your appetite? My appetite? My children’s appetites? I constantly return to these questions at home, when I cook for my family or plan a dinner party, and at work, when creating recipes or judging portion sizes in my restaurants. I want people to feel satisfied and well looked after, but I don’t like waste or excess.

headline: What Is the Best Month of the Year? What Is the Worst?
abstract: Some people say January is secretly great. Do you agree?
lead_paragraph: It’s January, a month that many would call the worst of the year. What do you think? Do you find January dreary and dull?

headline: At 70, the Composer Georg Friedrich Haas Encourages Self-Discovery
abstract: One of Haas’s former students reflects on his time with a teacher who had lessons to offer in music, doubt and influence.
lead_paragraph: One evening in 2013, during my graduate recital in composition at the City of Basel Music Academy in Switzerland, an instrument I had built went flying into the audience. It was a small loudspeaker duct-taped to a string — I called it a sound pendulum — and when the musician twirled it, the tape didn’t hold.

headline: New (and Old) Moves for a Choreographer to Hip Hop’s Stars
abstract: For Fatima Robinson, choreographing “The Color Purple” was far more than a job. It was a callback to her youth, before becoming known for her pop work.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Fatima Robinson made her name, at 21, with an epic Michael Jackson video. Two decades later, she orchestrated the moves for 1,000 performers at a Super Bowl halftime show. Then she rose to become Beyoncé’s director of choreography.

headline: What Will Be Nominated for Oscars Next Week, and What Won’t?
abstract: While “Oppenheimer,” “Barbie” and “Killers of the Flower Moon” are likely to do well, the directors race is hardly set and other categories are open, too.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2024 Oscar nominations.

headline: Stop Ignoring All the Mundane Miracles in Your Life
abstract: Turn your monotonous moments into monuments by taking notes of what you observe. It only takes 15 minutes a day.
lead_paragraph: After a long day at work, I absent-mindedly boarded an express train. What should’ve been an 18-minute commute home turned into a 50-minute journey from Manhattan to Brooklyn and back. Sitting on that last train to my apartment, I felt a digital dreariness overcome me. I’d spent all day responding to emails, Slacks and DMs. I just wanted to not look at a screen. I didn’t have a book with me, so I took out my notebook and jotted down everything I saw, heard or smelled: A backpack occupying a seat for a human. A woman wearing a spiky hat. Shoelaces, untied. Shoelaces, tied. An aggressively yellow ad for something called Mullvad. “Do Not Lean on Door.” Snoring. The person next to me typing out in a text, “Dinner next week?” before quickly deleting it and locking his phone.

headline: TikTok Invaded This Cruise for Content. Maybe Someday It’ll Come for You.
abstract: Even if you didn’t sign up for the reality-TV treatment, your life may be mined for drama and packaged for consumption by influencers.
lead_paragraph: “The people on this cruise ship continue to give me dirty looks everywhere I go,” Marc Sebastian announces to his 1.5 million followers on TikTok. He is filming in a cabin onboard the ship, addressing the camera in classic reality-TV confessional style. Text floats above his head. It reads: “day one on the 9 month cruise.”

headline: Need a Passport? You’re in Luck.
abstract: The wait for a U.S. passport may be back to normal after a pandemic-induced backlog.
lead_paragraph: Among the many aspects of travel that the pandemic disrupted, one issue was more bureaucratic — but no less frustrating — for some Americans: an enormous backlog of U.S. passport applications.

headline: $370,000 Homes in Washington, New York and Michigan
abstract: A one-bedroom condominium in Seattle, a renovated 1988 home in Eagle Bridge and a 1916 house once owned by the champion boxer Joe Louis in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: This home is in the Capitol Hill neighborhood, half a block from a Trader Joe’s, an organic grocery co-op and several popular nightlife spots on a bustling stretch of Madison Street. It is within walking distance of Italian, Korean and Mexican restaurants, as well as Northwest Film Forum, an independent movie theater.

headline: Amtrak Moves Slowly Toward an Acela Successor
abstract: A long-overdue replacement for the trains on the Boston-to-Washington corridor finally passed computer-modeling tests.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at how Amtrak is moving toward faster trains in the Northeast. We’ll also get details on a fourth murder charge in the Gilgo Beach serial killings on Long Island.

headline: Is This Lil Nas X’s Final Troll?
abstract: The rapper and singer has always been a master of the internet, not of music. But with his latest release, “J Christ,” he’s lost his grip on virality, too.
lead_paragraph: More than any working pop star, Lil Nas X understands how music is consumed in the contemporary landscape: in pieces, in memes, in reaction videos, in snippets of audio used to soundtrack get-ready-with-me clips on social media. In intimations and nudges. In discourse that may or may not have much to do with said music at all.

headline: 3-Year Cruise Passengers Seek Fraud Charges Over Cancellation
abstract: After more than a month of missed deadlines for refunds, a group of hard-hit passengers who signed up for the failed Life at Sea cruise is pursuing legal intervention.
lead_paragraph: By now, they were supposed to be well into the first leg of the three-year Life at Sea cruise, sailing from Ushuaia, Argentina, to Punta Arenas in Chilean Patagonia.

headline: Ann Arbor School Board Set to Vote on Israel-Gaza Ceasefire Resolution
abstract: The proposed resolution has divided the left-leaning Michigan college town, home to sizable Arab and Jewish populations.
lead_paragraph: Update: The Ann Arbor school board voted in support of a cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: Auction of Nelson Mandela Items Set After Court Fight With Government
abstract: South Africa tried to force the return of what it deemed “heritage objects.” But a court sided with Mandela’s daughter, who plans to use the sale to finance a memorial garden.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Mandela’s eldest daughter is moving forward with an auction next month of the former president’s personal belongings after a two-year legal battle with the South African government, which had tried to block such a sale saying the items were artifacts of national heritage.

headline: The Deification of Donald Trump Poses Some Interesting Questions
abstract: Why do so many evangelicals see the former president as God’s anointed one?
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 15, 2020, in a rare display of humility, Donald Trump told a campaign rally in Greenville, N.C., that he was not as famous as Jesus Christ.

headline: After Five Seasons of ‘Fargo,’ Noah Hawley Is Still Rooting for America
abstract: In an interview, Hawley discussed darkness, putting nipple rings on Jon Hamm and using “Fargo” as a vehicle for stories that champion decency.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for the fifth season of “Fargo.”

headline: Why Nikki Haley Can’t Win
abstract: Trump connects with the G.O.P. in a way that she can’t muster.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley did well enough in the Iowa caucuses Monday night to keep her supporters’ hopes alive. But her third-place showing, on the heels of Ron DeSantis and a mile behind Donald Trump, was also just disappointing enough to raise doubts about her candidacy.

headline: Conservative Justices Appear Skeptical of Agencies’ Regulatory Power
abstract: The Supreme Court considered whether to overrule the seminal 1984 Chevron decision, which requires judges to defer to agencies’ interpretations of ambiguous statutes.
lead_paragraph: Members of the Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed inclined on Wednesday to limit or even overturn a key precedent that has empowered executive agencies, threatening regulations in countless areas, including the environment, health care and consumer safety.

headline: Hospitals Are Desperate for Workers. They Might Find Them in High Schools.
abstract: Boston is one of 10 places where Bloomberg Philanthropies will spend a total of $250 million preparing high school students to start health care jobs as soon as they graduate.
lead_paragraph: Public school students in Boston will have a direct route to guaranteed jobs with the city’s largest employer, the Mass General Brigham health system, via a new initiative that will pair high schools eager to expand career training with hospitals desperate for workers.

headline: Don’t Ditch Standardized Tests. Fix Them.
abstract: Assessing the academic skills of elementary and middle school students matters more than ever.
lead_paragraph: According to The New York Post’s analysis of New York State Education Department data, “Nearly 200,000 students — or one out of five — refused to sit for the state’s standardized reading and math exams for grades 3-8 administered in the spring” of 2023.

headline: Consumer Bureau Proposes Overdraft Fee Limits for Large Banks
abstract: The options would include charging a benchmark fee, set by the bureau, that would be significantly lower than the current $35 standard.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Wednesday proposed a rule that would sharply limit overdraft charges at the largest banks and credit unions in the United States, a change that the agency estimated could save households up to $3.5 billion a year in fees.

headline: Electric Car Owners Confront a Harsh Foe: Cold Weather
abstract: In freezing temperatures, the batteries of electric vehicles can be less efficient and have shorter range, a lesson many Tesla drivers in Chicago learned this week.
lead_paragraph: With Chicago temperatures sinking below zero, electric vehicle charging stations have become scenes of desperation: depleted batteries, confrontational drivers and lines stretching out onto the street.

headline: Is the New ‘Mean Girls’ Movie as ‘Fetch’ as the Original?
abstract: A musical remake arrives in theaters two decades after the release of the beloved teen comedy.
lead_paragraph: The world first met Cady Heron, Regina George and the Plastics when “Mean Girls” hit movie theaters in 2004. Written by Tina Fey and based on a nonfiction book about social dynamics among high school girls, “Mean Girls” tells the story of a formerly home-schooled 16-year-old who becomes entangled with a group of popular students at her new high school. The movie was a cultural sensation. Its stars became famous, its quotable lines were ubiquitous and young people started wearing pink on Wednesdays.

headline: The Messy Fight Over the SAT
abstract: Many U.S. colleges have stopped requiring standardized tests on the theory that they hurt diversity. That view might be misguided.
lead_paragraph: Concerned about the effect on diversity, many colleges have stopped requiring standardized tests. New research suggests that might be a mistake.

headline: U.S. Strikes Houthis Again, and China’s Population Decline
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: A 2024 Vulnerability
abstract: The Democrats are out of step with public opinion when it comes to immigration.
lead_paragraph: I keep a running list of issues on which either the Republican Party or the Democratic Party is out of step with public opinion.

headline: Polish Truckers Lift Border Blockade With Ukraine
abstract: The suspension of the protest until March, while its leaders talk with the Polish government, promises some relief for Ukraine’s flagging economy.
lead_paragraph: Polish truckers have lifted their blockade of checkpoints on the border with Ukraine after reaching an agreement with their government, putting an end for now to a two-month protest that has delayed tons of goods from reaching Europe and strained the Ukrainian economy.

headline: Cancer Deaths Are Falling, but There May Be an Asterisk
abstract: The American Cancer Society found many deaths prevented, but an uptick in incidence of a variety of cancers.
lead_paragraph: Cancer deaths in the United States are falling, with four million deaths prevented since 1991, according to the American Cancer Society’s annual report.

headline: Iranian Strike Leaves Pakistan With No Easy Options for Response
abstract: Retaliation could risk drawing the country, which is already mired in political and economic crises, into Middle East upheaval that it has so far avoided.
lead_paragraph: An Iranian airstrike inside Pakistan on Tuesday that Iran said was aimed at militant training camps has left Pakistani officials facing a difficult decision about whether to retaliate and potentially expand the turmoil that has swept the Middle East.

headline: 3 Killed in Oregon as Northwest Braces for More Freezing Rain, Ice and Snow
abstract: Three people died in Portland after a power line fell on a car. Widespread power outages were affecting parts of the state, and some counties declared states of emergency.
lead_paragraph: Three people were killed when a power line fell on a car in Portland, Ore., Wednesday morning as parts of the Northwest continued to suffer from a brutal weather pattern this week, officials said.

headline: Fireworks Factory Explosion in Thailand Kills at Least 20
abstract: The blast leveled the facility and was the second such deadly accident in the country since 2022. The police are investigating the cause.
lead_paragraph: A fireworks factory exploded in central Thailand on Wednesday, killing at least 20 people and injuring many others, according to the Thai police.

headline: It’s Always Summer Somewhere
abstract: In Melbourne, Australia, people recently dressed for the season in chunky fringed skirts, tattoo-exposing tank tops and blazers (even at the beach).
lead_paragraph: On a recent trip to Melbourne, several locals described the city as Australia’s version of New York. Melbourne might not be as pretty as Sydney, which has a beach culture similar to that of Los Angeles, but they said that it was more interesting.

headline: The Zelensky-Trump Divide at Davos
abstract: Ukraine’s leader and the potential re-election of Donald Trump as president are dominating discussion at the World Economic Forum.
lead_paragraph: Two people are having an outsize impact at the World Economic Forum, and one of them isn’t even there.

headline: How Texas Kept the Lights On in the Recent Deep Freeze
abstract: Frozen gas infrastructure was the main culprit in the disastrous power failures of 2021. After changes, the grid appears to be holding, with help from wind power.
lead_paragraph: Texas has invested more in wind and solar power than any other state in recent years, but during the current cold snap, natural gas has played a key role in keeping the lights on.

headline: An Enemy Has Infiltrated My Walking Group. Help!
abstract: A reader is distraught that a woman she’s estranged from has been added to her most treasured circle of friends. Is there anything she can do to reclaim the group chat?
lead_paragraph: For 10 years, I’ve belonged to a walking group of 12 women. We all raised our children together. We take long walks on Saturday mornings and have a lively group chat. We also go to dinner once a month. I feel lucky to be friends with these women. The problem: A woman who coordinates the group with me recently added her best friend, with whom I had a falling-out several years ago. She broached the idea of including her on the group chat on a day when I wasn’t checking my phone. (She knows about our falling-out.) I have not seen this other woman in years, and I have no interest in reconciling with her. This group was my most cherished social outlet; now, I no longer want to participate. What should I do?

headline: California’s Most Iconic Roadside Attractions
abstract: The sudden closure of Pea Soup Andersen’s on the Central Coast got us thinking about other notable landmarks across the state.
lead_paragraph: The news last week that Pea Soup Andersen’s restaurant on the Central Coast had suddenly closed elicited a wave of nostalgia among Californians, even those like me who had never actually eaten there.

headline: ‘Stereophonic,’ a New Play About Making Music, to Open on Broadway
abstract: Written by David Adjmi and featuring songs by Will Butler, the drama follows five musicians making an album in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: “Stereophonic,” an acclaimed behind-the-music play about a disputatious band recording a studio album, will transfer to Broadway this spring following a buzzy and sold-out Off Broadway run.

headline: How to Cut Down Your Screen Time but Still Get Stuff Done
abstract: Google’s Routines and Apple’s Shortcuts combine multiple steps into one command to make your phone or tablet do more of the work for you.
lead_paragraph: Worried about smartphone addiction after seeing your latest screen-time statistics? A certain amount of phone use is often necessary these days, but repetitive tasks pile on the minutes. Google’s Assistant Routines and Apple’s Shortcuts app are two free options that may help — by condensing several actions into one tap or command. Here’s how to get started.

headline: Iran Says Missile Strikes Show It Will Be ‘Tough and Decisive’ With Foes
abstract: The country has hit targets in Syria, Iraq and Pakistan with missiles this week, signaling to hard-line supporters that it is not passive in the face of threats.
lead_paragraph: After hitting targets in neighboring Pakistan, Iraq and Syria with missiles, Iran talked tough on Wednesday, playing up — to friends and foes alike — not only its military capabilities but its determination to strike enemies at will.

headline: Princess of Wales to Be Hospitalized for 10 Days After Abdominal Surgery
abstract: Kensington Palace said Catherine, the wife of Prince William, would not return to public duties until after Easter. Separately, King Charles will receive prostate treatment next week.
lead_paragraph: Two of the most senior members of Britain’s royal family have been hit by health concerns, with Catherine, the Princess of Wales and the wife of Prince William, undergoing abdominal surgery in London on Tuesday, while King Charles III will receive treatment for an enlarged prostate next week.

headline: ‘For all Mankind’ Ends Its Greediest Season
abstract: In an interview, the showrunners discuss the space drama’s just-concluded fourth season, in which exploration gave way to exploitation.
lead_paragraph: This interview includes spoilers for Season 4 of “For All Mankind.”

headline: Six Reasons Drug Prices Are So High in the U.S.
abstract: Research shows prices in the United States are nearly double those in other well-off countries.
lead_paragraph: Florida’s plan to save money by importing medications from Canada, authorized this month by the Food and Drug Administration, has renewed attention on the cost of prescription drugs in the United States.

headline: CNN cancels its Republican debate in New Hampshire for lack of participation.
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis was the only candidate willing to debate. Nikki Haley said she would participate only if it included Donald Trump, who refused again.
lead_paragraph: Neither of the two Republican debates planned for the days before the New Hampshire primary will be happening.

headline: Hybrid Cars Enjoy a Renaissance as All-Electric Sales Slow
abstract: Automakers like Ford, Kia and Toyota are offering more hybrid options to appeal to buyers who aren’t ready for fully electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: As Teslas and other electric vehicles dazzled car buyers with futuristic technology and dreams of a gasoline-free future, hybrid cars began to seem like yesterday’s news. Sales of the Toyota Prius, the standard-bearer for hybrids, fell 85 percent over a decade.

headline: A.I.’s Latest Challenge: the Math Olympics
abstract: Watch out, nerdy high schoolers, AlphaGeometry is coming for your mathematical lunch.
lead_paragraph: For four years, the computer scientist Trieu Trinh has been consumed with something of a meta-math problem: how to build an A.I. model that solves geometry problems from the International Mathematical Olympiad, the annual competition for the world’s most mathematically attuned high-school students.

headline: A Marinade for Every Chicken
abstract: Boneless breasts, wings, bone-in thighs — even a whole bird works in this bracing mix of mustard, soy sauce, lemon and garlic.
lead_paragraph: It is a truth universally acknowledged that meat tastes better when seasoned ahead. Even a brief 20-minute rest with a sprinkle of salt will help bring out the best in most cuts. But when it comes to chicken, a long soak in a pungent marinade pays off exponentially, sparking the mild meat with a good jolt of flavor.

headline: Some Movies Hit Close to Home. His Was Filmed There.
abstract: Andrew Haigh wanted to infuse “All of Us Strangers” with elements from his own life, which included shooting it in his childhood residence.
lead_paragraph: “I got called a gay elder the other day,” Andrew Haigh said. This title, bestowed by a group of younger gay men, initially rankled him. It’s true that Haigh — the director of acclaimed films like “45 Years” and “Weekend” — had recently turned 50, but he still found that landmark age hard to believe.

headline: How Much Ice Is Greenland Losing? Researchers Found an Answer.
abstract: The island is shedding 20 percent more than previously estimated, a study found, potentially threatening ocean currents that help to regulate global temperatures.
lead_paragraph: Greenland’s expansive ice sheet is known to be shrinking, especially since the 1990s, because of warming from climate change. It’s a fate shared by the Antarctic Ice Sheet as well as glaciers around the world. Now, a new study reveals that about 20 percent more of the Greenland ice sheet has disappeared than previous estimates show.

headline: Shake-Up by a Desperate DeSantis Opens Wider Path for Haley in New Hampshire
abstract: Ron DeSantis’s super PAC began layoffs on the same day he signaled he would largely bypass New Hampshire’s primary election and train his efforts on South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Straining to recover after a bruising defeat in Iowa, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and his allies moved on Wednesday to shake up his operation yet again, with his super PAC carrying out layoffs and the campaign signaling that it would largely bypass New Hampshire’s primary election next week in favor of competing in South Carolina.

headline: Cult Leader in Kenya to Face 191 Charges of Child Murder
abstract: The authorities say Paul Nthenge Mackenzie told his followers to starve themselves and their children to death in the Shakahola Forest, where hundreds of bodies have been exhumed.
lead_paragraph: A Kenyan judge on Wednesday said that a doomsday cult leader who the authorities say directed his followers to starve themselves must undergo a mental health evaluation before prosecutors formally charge him with the murders of 191 children.

headline: Phone and Internet Service in Gaza Is Down for a Seventh Day
abstract: It is the longest blackout since the start of the war, according to the strip’s main communications company, which says it is unable to make repairs amid the fighting.
lead_paragraph: A near-total communications blackout across the Gaza Strip extended for a seventh consecutive day on Thursday, leaving besieged civilians unable to call for help and aid workers struggling to reach them, as Israeli airstrikes continue to rain down on the south.

headline: Ancestry Tests Produced Shocking Results. Should I Tell My Family?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the burden that comes with obtaining genealogical information.
lead_paragraph: My cousin recently told me that he would never sign up on the 23andMe or Ancestry sites because “that’s how suckers find out they’re adopted.” Maybe I should have listened to him. Last June, my stepfather and I visited Norway to meet paternal relatives I’ve heard about and spoken with but never met. It was the most amazing trip I’ve taken in my life. These relatives were so kind and loving — we hit it off like we’d known one another forever. They showed me where my great-grandfather grew up and detailed my family history all over the country.

headline: King Charles to Have Prostate Treatment Next Week
abstract: The announcement from Buckingham Palace came shortly after the news that Catherine, Princess of Wales, had abdominal surgery on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: King Charles III will undergo treatment for an enlarged prostate next week, according to Buckingham Palace, which described his operation as a “corrective procedure” for a benign condition. The announcement came shortly after news that Catherine, the Princess of Wales and the wife of Prince William, had abdominal surgery in London on Tuesday.

headline: In Norway, a Proposed Ban on Foreign Adoptions Rattles All Sides of a Heated Debate
abstract: A policy body recommended this week that the country halt all foreign adoptions amid allegations of stolen children, falsified paperwork and for-profit adoption schemes.
lead_paragraph: One Norwegian woman only discovered via an old letter, hidden for 50 years, that she had been taken from her Korean parents. Another was taken from her home while she was stricken with polio; a woman had arrived and said she was taking the girl to medical care but instead took her to an orphanage. Yet another woman was given up to an orphanage by a vindictive grandmother, trying to break up her son’s marriage.

headline: F.A.A. Says Initial Round of 737 Max Inspections Has Been Finished
abstract: The agency said it would review the data from the inspections of 40 planes, a subset of the 171 Boeing Max 9 aircraft that have been grounded.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Wednesday that an initial round of inspections of 40 Boeing 737 Max 9 planes had been completed, but that those aircraft and scores of other Max 9 planes would remain grounded as the agency finalized an inspection process for them.

headline: Johnson Casts Doubt on Border Deal to Unlock Ukraine Aid, Defying Biden
abstract: A White House meeting between the president and congressional leaders did little to break the stalemate over aid to Ukraine, as the Republican speaker insisted on a tougher immigration crackdown.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson on Wednesday dug in against President Biden’s efforts to revive stalled legislation to send aid to Ukraine, saying the Republican-led House would not entertain it unless Democrats agreed to a far more severe crackdown at the U.S.-Mexico border than they have been willing to consider.

headline: Happily Ever After Is Beside the Point
abstract: Nadya Tolokonnikova, a founding member of Pussy Riot, and John Caldwell have always prioritized being “helpful,” he said, over being happy.
lead_paragraph: When Nadya Tolokonnikova, one of the founding members of the anti-establishment punk collective Pussy Riot, reached out to John Caldwell on Discord, an encrypted messaging app, he asked if she was a bot.

headline: He Killed a Man. Turks Wonder Why a Well-Connected Somali Went Free.
abstract: After a crash that killed a motorcycle courier, a son of Somalia’s president faced prison. Now it will be a fine of about $900.
lead_paragraph: First he was allowed to leave Turkey after he hit a motorcycle courier with his car in November. Then the police blamed the courier, who later died in the hospital, before reversing course.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Armchair Expert’ and More
abstract: I’m a reporter for the Culture desk at The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve recently watched, read and listened to.
lead_paragraph: I’m a reporter for the Culture desk at The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve recently watched, read and listened to.

headline: Treating Pain and Those Who Suffer
abstract: Responses to an Opinion guest essay by Maia Szalavitz. Also: Strolling in New York; food aid at risk; the threat to beech trees.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tom Shales Took TV Seriously Even When Its Creators Didn’t
abstract: Shales admired nothing so much as ambition, but he also managed the feat of having high standards about lowbrow things.
lead_paragraph: “How-word Co-sell — you heard the bell and you came out talking.”

headline: Claire M. Fagin, Powerful Advocate for Nurses and Nursing, Dies at 97
abstract: “It is really hard,” a colleague said, “to identify anyone who has had a larger impact on nursing than Claire.”
lead_paragraph: Claire M. Fagin, a leading expert on, advocate for and change agent in the profession of nursing, and one of the first women to lead an Ivy League university, the University of Pennsylvania, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 97.

headline: France Rejects Genocide Accusations Against Israel in Gaza
abstract: “To accuse the Jewish state of genocide is to cross a moral threshold,” France’s foreign minister said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: France on Wednesday became the latest Western country to reject accusations that Israel is committing genocide against Palestinian civilians in Gaza, a charge that was recently brought before a United Nations court in The Hague.

headline: Goldman Files Censure Against Stefanik for Calling Jan. 6 Defendants ‘Hostages’
abstract: The resolution accuses the No. 4 House Republican of helping to peddle the voter fraud conspiracy theories that fueled the Jan. 6, 2021, attack at the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: Representative Dan Goldman, Democrat of New York, on Wednesday announced he would file a formal censure of Representative Elise Stefanik, Republican of New York, accusing her of peddling voter fraud conspiracy theories that fueled the Jan. 6, 2021, attack at the Capitol and supporting rioters who violently threatened members of Congress, referring to them as “hostages.”

headline: Muttered Insults, Stern Warnings: Inside Trump’s Second Defamation Trial
abstract: The former president’s right to be at his trial “can be forfeited,” the judge warned. E. Jean Carroll is seeking at least $10 million in damages for his denials that he sexually assaulted her.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump shook his head. He exhaled loudly. He whispered to his lawyer. He muttered “con job” and “witch hunt.”

headline: How Hot Was It Last Year?
abstract: So hot, the global average temperature exceeded the level world leaders hoped we’d stay below until 2100.
lead_paragraph: It is notoriously tricky to synthesize data from all the world’s weather stations into one measure of global warming, but all of the major efforts to do so for 2023 are now in, and they are also all in distressing alignment: Last year was the warmest recorded in modern history, and it broke that record by an exceedingly large margin, one that conventional climate science has not yet managed to adequately explain.

headline: An Ancient Woolly Mammoth Left a Diary in Her Tusk
abstract: Scientists are looking at layers of minerals left behind on mammoth tusks to estimate where the hulking animals spent their days.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have written the biography of a 14,000-year-old female woolly mammoth by analyzing the chemicals in her tusk.

headline: Teen Tiny Memoirs: The Winners of Our 2nd Annual 100-Word Narrative Contest
abstract: We invited teenagers to write miniature memoirs about meaningful moments in their lives. Read the 15 winning stories.
lead_paragraph: Last school year, we took a departure from our traditional personal narrative contest and, instead, challenged students to see if they could write a story about a meaningful life moment in just 100 words. It turns out, they absolutely could — and very, very well. So this school year, we decided to issue that same challenge again.

headline: YouTube Cuts 100 Employees as Tech Layoffs Continue
abstract: The layoffs are part of efforts by the video platform’s parent company, Google, to trim costs and bureaucracy as it embraces artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Google will cut 100 employees at its video platform, YouTube, on Wednesday, continuing piecemeal layoffs after shedding more than a thousand jobs in the past week.

headline: Here Are 15 Winning Tiny Memoirs. Which Ones Most Resonate With You?
abstract: We’re inviting you to read our favorite teen-written 100-word stories and tell us which you most relate to and admire — and why.
lead_paragraph: The story of a first kiss gone wrong. An encounter on a snowy city sidewalk. A profound realization about a stepparent. An embarrassing moment on a soccer field.

headline: Ana Tijoux’s First Album in a Decade Fights Sorrows With Joy
abstract: On “Vida,” the Chilean songwriter celebrates the life force.
lead_paragraph: The finale of “Vida,” the new album by the Chilean songwriter Ana Tijoux, is “Fin del Mundo” (“The End of the World”). She sings and raps, in Spanish, about dire expectations: war, pollution, drought, a collision with a comet. But as a techno-tinged disco beat rises around her, she cheerfully declares, “If the end of the world is coming, let’s dance naked together.”

headline: Pierce Brosnan Pleads Not Guilty to Hiking Illegally at Yellowstone
abstract: Brosnan faces two counts of entering restricted areas of the park near hot springs.
lead_paragraph: The actor Pierce Brosnan has pleaded not guilty to hiking in a restricted area of Yellowstone National Park, according to court documents filed this month in federal court in Wyoming.

headline: Economics Textbooks Are Finally Getting a Vital Update
abstract: The Great Recession changed how the Fed steers the economy, but textbooks are still catching up.
lead_paragraph: For students, what a textbook says is ground truth. But for nearly 15 years, leading introductory economics textbooks gave students an outdated or incomplete explanation of how the Federal Reserve conducts monetary policy. Only now are the textbooks catching up with reality, and some still haven’t fully embraced the new world.

headline: Maine Judge Suspends Decision to Exclude Trump From Primary Ballot
abstract: The judge sent the matter back to Maine’s secretary of state, ordering her to modify, withdraw or confirm her ruling after the Supreme Court rules on a similar case out of Colorado.
lead_paragraph: A Maine judge ordered the state’s top election official on Wednesday to wait for a U.S. Supreme Court ruling before putting into effect her decision to exclude former President Donald J. Trump from Maine’s Republican primary ballot.

headline: Read the Maine Judge’s Ruling on Trump’s Ballot Eligibility
abstract: The judge ordered the state’s top election official to wait until the Supreme Court weighs in on the eligibility issue in a Colorado case, and then to confirm, modify or reverse her Dec. 28 decision to exclude former President Donald J. Trump from Maine’s primary ballot.
lead_paragraph: The judge ordered the state’s top election official to wait until the Supreme Court weighs in on the eligibility issue in a Colorado case, and then to confirm, modify or reverse her Dec. 28 decision to exclude former President Donald J. Trump from Maine’s primary ballot.

headline: No More Bunny Business
abstract: In a tell-all memoir, Crystal Hefner recounts her former days as a Playboy model and the third (and last) wife of Hugh Hefner.
lead_paragraph: The visible vestiges of Crystal Hefner’s days as a Playboy Playmate are mostly gone. The snowy blond hair that once characterized Ms. Hefner, the third and last wife of Playboy’s founder, Hugh Hefner, has become more dirty blond. Revealing costumes have been traded for sensible clothes like beige cardigans.

headline: Sarah Stackhouse, Star Interpreter of José Limón, Dies at 87
abstract: Her virtuosic dance technique, natural charisma and compelling acting perfectly suited Mr. Limón’s flowing movement style and abstract narrative works.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Stackhouse, a star dancer in the Limón Dance Company who became a sought-after teacher and stager of José Limón’s choreography around the world, died on Jan. 7 at her home in New Paltz, N.Y. She was 87.

headline: An-My Lê Seeks Herself in the Landscape
abstract: The artist reflects on witnessing war up close — and then photographing it at a distance.
lead_paragraph: The artist An-My Lê insists that she doesn’t photograph war. For much of her career, Lê has photographed the many preambles and the long wake of violent combat: Vietnam War re-enactments in the forests of Virginia; training exercises in the California desert for Marines headed to Iraq and Afghanistan; and the American military’s “peacetime” activities around the world. But a straightforward view from the battlefield is not her priority. “I’ve always been interested in finding ways to visualize people’s ideas of war,” Lê says, “whether my own or someone else’s construct.”

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Lil Nas X, Ariana Grande and 21 Savage Kick Off 2024
abstract: Pop’s premier troll returns while one of its biggest voices turns her attention to gossip, and the first blockbuster rap album of the year arrives.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: What Makes Chicken and Rice Even Better? A Little Bite.
abstract: In this easy sheet-pan meal, turmeric-ginger chicken roasts on a bed of crispy, scallion-flecked rice.
lead_paragraph: My first attempt at crunchy rice was not entirely on purpose. I was a young, multitasking cook with a pot of rice left on low heat until … wait, was something about to burn?

headline: ‘Gutenberg!’: A Guide to the Inventor Behind the Broadway Musical
abstract: Jokes aside: Here’s what we really know about the 15th-century figure currently appearing (sort of) on Broadway in “Gutenberg! The Musical!,” starring Josh Gad and Andrew Rannells.
lead_paragraph: “Gutenberg! The Musical!,” a comic meta-musical about two talentless dolts pitching a show about the father of the printing press, wraps up its limited Broadway run on Jan. 28.

headline: Joseph Zadroga, Who Championed 9/11 Emergency Workers, Dies at 76
abstract: After the death of his son, a police detective, was linked to toxins at the World Trade Center site, he helped win federal benefits for other emergency responders.
lead_paragraph: Joseph C. Zadroga, whose lobbying helped deliver health benefits to thousands of emergency workers whose health was impaired by inhaling dust and debris at ground zero after the 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center — although his efforts came too late for his own son, a New York City detective — died on Saturday after being hit by a car in Pomona, N.J. He was 76.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Iran Raises Military Threats
abstract: Also, how language affects memory as we age.
lead_paragraph: A day after Iran launched missile strikes in neighboring Pakistan, Iran’s defense minister vowed yesterday that his country would “not set any limits” on using its capabilities against enemies whenever necessary.

headline: Why New Hampshire Thinks It’s Smarter Than Iowa
abstract: “Iowa picks corn, New Hampshire picks presidents” is a favorite slogan in the state, where Republicans tend to have a libertarian streak.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Republican presidential primary race has moved to New Hampshire from Iowa, a few things will change.

headline: Sunak Quells Rebellion on Immigration, for Now
abstract: The British prime minister’s plan to send refugees to Rwanda passed a critical vote, but more hurdles lie ahead.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain dodged a potentially dire threat to his leadership on Wednesday, preserving for now his beleaguered government’s immigration plan to put asylum seekers on one-way flights to Rwanda.

headline: Woman Who Plotted Her Mother’s Killing in Bali Gets 26 Years in U.S. Prison
abstract: The woman, Heather Mack, conspired with her boyfriend to kill her mother, Sheila A. Von Wiese, in 2014, then stuffed her in a suitcase.
lead_paragraph: A woman who plotted to kill her mother and then stuffed her body in a suitcase in Bali, Indonesia, in 2014 was sentenced on Wednesday to 26 years in prison, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Long Island Midwife Gave Pellets Instead of Vaccines to 1,500 Children
abstract: The midwife falsified vaccine records, according to New York State health officials. She was fined $300,000.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island midwife falsified vaccine records for some 1,500 school-aged children, according to New York State’s Department of Health, which on Wednesday announced that it had fined her $300,000.

headline: Do Political Ads Even Matter Anymore?
abstract: A confluence of political forces and changing media behavior are testing their efficacy in the Trump era.
lead_paragraph: In a presidential election year, no glowing rectangle in Iowa or New Hampshire is safe from an endless deluge of political ads.

headline: The Hidden Lesson of ‘American Fiction’
abstract: If white people define Black people by our suffering, it’s often because we tell them to.
lead_paragraph: Cord Jefferson’s film “American Fiction” offers a delightful portrayal of the white fetishization of Black pain — and also, in 2024, at least, one that is more satire than documentary. In the movie, an erudite Black author writes a baldly melodramatic “ghetto” novel titled “My Pafology” in protest of the way white audiences seem to go wild for such material — and to his surprise, nobody gets the joke and white audiences do, in fact, go wild for the book.

headline: Apple Says It Will Remove a Health Feature From New Apple Watches
abstract: Starting on Thursday, the Apple Watch Series 9 and Watch Ultra 2 will no longer detect people’s blood oxygen levels, to comply with a ruling by the International Trade Commission.
lead_paragraph: Apple said on Wednesday that it would begin selling its flagship smartwatches without the ability to detect people’s blood-oxygen levels.

headline: Condé Nast Is Folding Pitchfork Into GQ, With Layoffs
abstract: Multiple employees at the storied music criticism site “will be leaving the company,” according to a memo from Anna Wintour.
lead_paragraph: Pitchfork, once a cultural bastion for music criticism, will be merged with the men's magazine GQ, leading to layoffs within the online publication, according to a memo from Anna Wintour, the chief content officer of Condé Nast, their parent company.

headline: Justices Seemed Inclined to Limit a Key Regulatory Power
abstract: Also, U.S. leaders clashed over Ukraine aid. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: During three and a half hours of lively oral arguments today, the Supreme Court’s conservative majority appeared inclined to limit or even overturn a foundational doctrine of administrative law that has empowered executive agencies for several decades.

headline: King Charles’s Prostate Treatment Is Common Among Men His Age
abstract: When medicine does not ease an enlarged prostate, known also as BPH, a common surgery with few risks is often used.
lead_paragraph: King Charles III will have a procedure to address an enlarged prostate at a hospital next week. The 75-year-old British monarch’s diagnosis is common among men his age, and experts say that typical treatments are not dangerous.

headline: Peter Schickele, Composer and Gleeful Sire of P.D.Q. Bach, Dies at 88
abstract: He wrote more than 100 symphonic, choral, solo instrumental and chamber works. But he was better known, and celebrated, as a musical parodist. Who can forget the “Concerto for Horn and Hardart”?
lead_paragraph: Peter Schickele, an American composer whose career as a writer of serious concert music was often eclipsed by that of his antic alter ego, the thoroughly debauched, terrifyingly prolific and mercifully fictional P.D.Q. Bach, died on Tuesday at his home in Bearsville, a hamlet outside Woodstock, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: How a Fishery Case Fits Into a Long-Game Effort to Sap Regulation of Business
abstract: A case before the Supreme Court appears poised to be the next step in the conservative legal movement’s yearslong effort to chip away at the administrative state.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in a set of cases that could pave the way for its conservative supermajority to undercut how American society imposes rules on businesses, advancing a key goal of the conservative legal movement.

headline: As if We Didn’t Have Enough to Frighten Us …
abstract: North Korea is acting strangely, and some veteran analysts fear war.
lead_paragraph: The globe is already pockmarked with crises, and here may be another: North Korea is acting in highly unusual ways, leading some veteran analysts to fear it is preparing a surprise attack on South Korea and perhaps on Japan and Guam as well.

headline: Turning Down Food Aid for Millions of Children Reflects Shocking Political Callousness
abstract: Some governors are putting political philosophy over badly needed aid.
lead_paragraph: Last week I read something that shocked me, even if it really shouldn’t have: Fifteen states — all but one run by Republican governors — skipped the deadline to apply for a new federally funded program that will provide $120 per child for groceries during the summer months to families of children who already qualify for free or reduced-price lunch at school.

headline: Take That, America
abstract: The Iowa caucuses are over, but we have all of 2024 ahead of us.
lead_paragraph: Well, people, Iowa has spoken. Peeped, anyhow.

headline: 3 Progressive N.Y. City Council Members Lose Roles as Committee Chairs
abstract: Adrienne Adams, the moderate Democrat who is the Council speaker, chose not to reappoint three of the City Council’s most left-leaning members as committee chairs.
lead_paragraph: Three of the most progressive members of the New York City Council were stripped of their committee chairmanships on Wednesday, eroding the power of the body’s left-leaning faction and raising concerns that the moves by the speaker, Adrienne Adams, were retaliatory.

headline: As Fighting Intensifies in Southern Gaza, Palestinians Flee Hospital Refuge
abstract: Israel and Hamas are battling near a hospital in Khan Younis, near where the military said it had detected mortar fire. About 7,000 people had sought shelter on the hospital grounds, the U.N. said.
lead_paragraph: Scores of displaced Palestinians fled the grounds of a hospital in southern Gaza as fighting raged on Wednesday in and around the city of Khan Younis, where the Israeli military says it is trying to crush a Hamas stronghold.

headline: U.S. Moves to Bar Guatemala’s Ex-President From Entry
abstract: The decision against Alejandro Giammattei, who is accused of accepting bribes, signaled U.S. support for a new anticorruption drive in Guatemala.
lead_paragraph: The State Department said on Wednesday that Alejandro Giammattei, Guatemala’s president until a tumultuous transfer of power this week, was barred from entering the United States because of what officials said was information indicating that he had accepted bribes.

headline: Sheryl Sandberg to Depart Meta’s Board of Directors
abstract: Ms. Sandberg, who left her role as Meta’s chief operating officer in 2022, said she would serve as an adviser to the company.
lead_paragraph: Sheryl Sandberg said on Wednesday that she would not stand for re-election to Meta’s board of directors in May, ending her 14½-year run in a formal role at the social networking company.

headline: Dean Phillips, Bill Ackman, a $1 Million Gift and a Website Tweak
abstract: The candidate challenging President Biden “didn’t understand DEI until recently,” Mr. Ackman said. After an endorsement and super PAC donation, the Phillips campaign site changed course.
lead_paragraph: The campaign website for Representative Dean Phillips, the Minnesota Democrat mounting a long-shot primary challenge to President Biden, has a policy platform that signals liberal bona fides tempered by a Midwestern businessman’s practicality.
