It includes headers like “Climate Action,” “Women’s Health and Economic Security” and “Immigration Reform.”

headline: At Art Fraud Trial, Sotheby’s Is Pressed on Role in Sales to Russian Oligarch
abstract: The auction house is accused of helping an art dealer who the oligarch says defrauded him in several sales. A Sotheby’s specialist involved in some of the transactions defended his conduct.
lead_paragraph: The painting Sotheby’s was trying to sell was a newly discovered work by one of the world’s greatest artists, Leonardo da Vinci. It was known as the “Salvator Mundi” and was a depiction of Christ.

headline: Man Is Arrested in Queens Stabbing Spree, Officials Say
abstract: The man was charged with attempted murder after a citywide manhunt. The authorities said he randomly attacked people with a hunting knife.
lead_paragraph: A 27-year-old man was arrested on Wednesday in connection with a series of random stabbings in southeast Queens, the New York City police said, after a citywide manhunt for the attacker.

headline: Soars Near the Shore
abstract: Jon and Carl Michnovicz make their New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Nikki Haley Ramps Up Her Case Against Trump in New Hampshire
abstract: The former South Carolina governor has been careful about how and when she criticizes the former president. New Hampshire will test her approach.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley might have come in third in the Iowa caucuses, but as she campaigns in New Hampshire for its first-in-the-nation primary next week, her attention is squarely focused on only one rival: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Man Who Assaulted Six Officers on Jan. 6 Is Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison
abstract: Kenneth Bonawitz of Pompano Beach, Fla., was described by prosecutors as “one of the most violent” people to participate in the 2021 riot at the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man was sentenced on Wednesday to five years in prison for assaulting at least six police officers during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the Capitol, including one officer who said that the attack had led him to retire early, the Justice Department announced.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Racket Makers at the Courtside Bar
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “They want to come out and enjoy every single point. I’m kind of divided.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 18, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Iranian missile strikes in Iraq and Pakistan misidentified the source of a comment about regional tensions. The remarks came from a statement from the French Foreign Ministry, not the French foreign minister. The article also misidentified the foreign minister. It is Stéphane Séjourné, not Catherine Colonna, whom he succeeded in that role last week.

headline: Pakistan Retaliates With Strikes Inside Iran as Tensions Spill Over
abstract: The exchange of attacks came as the upheaval sweeping the Middle East threatened to expand.
lead_paragraph: In an expansion of hostilities rippling through the region, Pakistan said on Thursday that it had carried out airstrikes inside Iran, a day after Iranian forces attacked what they said were militant camps in Pakistan.

headline: Germany, Once a Powerhouse, Is at an Economic ‘Standstill’
abstract: The economy shrank last year and is not predicted to grow much in 2024. Farmers are angry, industrial output is falling and the government is bickering.
lead_paragraph: Germany started the year with Berlin’s streets choked with tractors and farmers blaring horns in furious protest of proposed budget cuts. Then train engineers walked off the job to demand better pay, stranding commuters and carloads of freight and leaving the country angry and gridlocked.

headline: New Utopian Enclave? Or a Testament to Inequality?
abstract: The development of Cayalá is utopian, serene and prizewinning. As an elite stronghold in one of Latin America’s most unequal nations, it is also divisive.
lead_paragraph: Try going for a stroll in much of Guatemala City: It is a pedestrian’s nightmare.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Missile strikes by Iran.
lead_paragraph: After hitting targets in neighboring Pakistan, Iraq and Syria with missiles, Iran has played up not only its military capabilities but its determination to strike enemies at will. Iran’s show of strength was meant to reassure conservatives domestically and militant allies abroad as well as to warn Israel, the U.S. and terrorist groups that Iran will retaliate if attacked, according to two Iranians affiliated with the Revolutionary Guards.

headline: Ann Arbor School Board Passes Resolution Supporting Cease-Fire in Gaza
abstract: In a raucous meeting, the board became one of the first in the country to vote for a statement supporting an end to hostilities in the Israel-Hamas war.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, some labor unions, city governments and town councils have weighed in on the Israel-Hamas war, issuing statements in support of a cease-fire — often over vociferous objections from some of their own members and constituents.

headline: A Week After Deadly Riots, a Fragile Peace in Papua New Guinea
abstract: A wage dispute prompted violent unrest in the Pacific nation, which experts call evidence of the effects of its demographic challenges.
lead_paragraph: Bullets flew. Stores and warehouses burned. At the edge of the prime minister’s compound, hundreds of protesters tugged at the gates and set a guard booth on fire. Inside, on the 10th floor of the beige building that housed the office of the country’s leader, he was facing calls to respond forcefully, perhaps even ask the former colonial ruler for help.

headline: Word of the Day: hippocampus
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word hippocampus has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 30 in “Brain Study Suggests Traumatic Memories Are Processed as Present Experience” by Ellen Barry:

headline: Jimmy Fallon Ribs Vivek Ramaswamy for Embracing Trump
abstract: “Yep, Ramaswamy took the stage and praised Trump for eight minutes,” Fallon said. “Then he was, like, ‘Wait, Donald, this is your speech. Sorry!’”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: In-and-Out Lists
abstract: What would be on yours?
lead_paragraph: Have you been noticing a proliferation of In-and-Out lists on social media lately?

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Seeing the Forest and the Trees
abstract: A New York Times editor and a freelance photographer teamed up to document ancient trees in Romania and the people working to protect them.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2022, Nicholas J.R. White, a landscape photographer based in Scotland, was on an assignment in Romania when he was approached by the director of an environmental conservation group: Did he want to see a sprawling forest of ancient beech trees?

headline: Janice Y.K. Lee Was Thrilled to Help Adapt Her Novel for Streaming
abstract: “That you could collaborate with others and go out for boba tea was quite revelatory,” says the author of “The Expatriates,” which Nicole Kidman has produced (and stars in) for Amazon this month.
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: How Coffee Farmers in Hawaii Fought Counterfeit Kona Beans
abstract: A testing method borrowed from geology helped farmers sue a slew of stores selling supposed “Kona” coffee.
lead_paragraph: On the volcanic slopes of Hawaii’s Big Island, hundreds of farmers in the Kona region produce one of the most expensive coffees in the world.

headline: Why Is Paying for College So Complicated?
abstract: FAFSA, S.A.I., N.P.C., CSS — the acronyms never end. And that’s just the beginning of the mayhem.
lead_paragraph: Saving and paying for college is an endurance test, a forced march on an often 50-year parade, where strange numerical codes and senseless jumbles of letters mark a route that Waze can’t map.

headline: Will Tourists Return to the Middle East?
abstract: After the Israel-Hamas conflict decimated travel in the Middle East last year, some countries are seeing a rebound in bookings — welcome news to a region heavily reliant on foreign visitors.
lead_paragraph: Travelers appear to be slowly returning to some Middle East nations despite the continuation of the Israel-Hamas conflict that all but decimated the region’s tourism since it began on Oct. 7. Travel operators said that bookings to countries including Egypt, Jordan and Oman are growing, welcome news for an area that’s dependent on tourist dollars and one that had received a record number of visitors since the height of the pandemic.

headline: José Saramago’s Childhood Memoir Inspires Companion Picture Books
abstract: The Nobel laureate’s “Small Memories” is a mix of peasant life, boyhood adventure and wide-eyed wonder.
lead_paragraph: Early in José Saramago’s 2006 memoir, “Small Memories,” he tells readers that he briefly considered calling it “The Book of Temptations” instead. His reasons were characteristically elliptical and charming: something about Bosch, and sainthood, and the fat prostitute who “in a weary, indifferent voice” invited a 12-year-old Saramago up to her room. (He doesn’t report his answer, but given how candid the book is elsewhere, it’s safe to assume he declined.) In the end, though, he decided that the title “Small Memories” better suited the book’s contents: “nothing of great note,” in Saramago’s estimation; simply “the small memories of when I was small.”

headline: Why You Should Eat More Nuts and Seeds
abstract: They’re packed with protein, fiber and healthy fats. Here’s how to feature them in your meals.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 4 of Well’s Mediterranean Diet Week. Start at the beginning here.

headline: Dobbs Didn’t Reduce Abortions. The Anti-Abortion Movement Needs a New Vision.
abstract: The pro-life movement once championed a safety net for pregnant women. It should return to that idea.
lead_paragraph: Most abortion opponents did not expect the overturning of Roe v. Wade and the passage of state abortion bans to lead to the expansion of legal abortion in much of the United States.

headline: ‘I.S.S.’ Review: Ariana DeBose’s Turn as a Space Warrior
abstract: The actress stars in this low-wattage thriller about Russian and American astronauts facing off aboard the International Space Station.
lead_paragraph: Three Americans, three Russians and one exceedingly cramped office hovering 250 miles above Earth — what could possibly go wrong? Given the typical genre coordinates, the 95 minute running time and historic hostilities between Russia and the United States, the more relevant questions here are when and how quickly and entertainingly things will go kablooey in “I.S.S.,” an enjoyable, low-wattage thriller set on the International Space Station.

headline: 36 Hours in Breckenridge, Colo.
abstract: Envision the quintessential Rocky Mountain ski town and you may picture Breckenridge.
lead_paragraph: Envision the quintessential Rocky Mountain ski town and you may picture Breckenridge.

headline: Why Are Voters So Upset? Consider the Snickers Bar.
abstract: A Snickers bar illustrates how humans don’t think about inflation rationally.
lead_paragraph: The United States has just experienced one of the biggest collapses in consumer inflation in modern history. In June 2022 consumer prices had risen 9.1 percent over the previous year. By December 2023 the rate of increase had slowed to 3.4 percent. And yet, in survey after survey, voters still declare inflation to be at or near the top of their list of concerns.

headline: Will My Next Trip Be by Train Instead of Plane?
abstract: In Europe, Asia and the U.S., new and expanded train service is making rail a viable alternative to flying.
lead_paragraph: Train lovers and travelers concerned about their carbon footprint have a lot to choose from this year — especially in Europe. While some European governments are mulling short-haul flight bans, many passengers are already opting for rail, where new connections are numerous.

headline: Ashley Elston’s Signature Play? Unfurling the Butcher Paper.
abstract: The author of “First Lie Wins” explains a key move in her novel-writing process.
lead_paragraph: Index cards. Outlines. Daily word counts. Pilot Vball pens.

headline: Will the Boom in Luxury and Wellness Travel Fizzle?
abstract: Interest was high last year, and those in the travel industry say it could go higher still as travelers look to maximize their experiences.
lead_paragraph: After the travel frenzy of 2023, all signs point to increasing interest in far-flung destinations, villa rentals, private jet bookings and personal pilgrimages in 2024.

headline: Black and Jewish Activists Have Allied for Decades. What Now?
abstract: The Palestinian cause has revived a partnership forged in the civil rights era — and also created new tensions.
lead_paragraph: Eva Borgwardt first embraced the Palestinian cause the summer after she graduated from high school. It happened because of Michael Brown. It was August 2014, and in Ferguson, Mo., not far from her family’s well-off St. Louis neighborhood, protests were erupting after Brown was killed by a police officer. At home, Borgwardt had often wondered who she would have been during the civil rights movement. Would she have really stood up for what was right? Now, as the demonstrations for racial justice and against police brutality dominated the news, her mother, a history professor and scholar of human rights law, told her, “This is a ‘Where were you in history?’ moment.”

headline: Is This the Year I Should Use My Points to Travel?
abstract: Legislation targeting credit card transaction fees may undermine loyalty programs — one more reason to use those points sooner than later.
lead_paragraph: The question of whether to save or to spend miles takes on new urgency this year as lawmakers consider the Credit Card Competition Act. The legislation targets transaction fees — usually 2 to 3 percent of a sale — that retailers pay to credit card companies such as Visa and Mastercard. The fees are partially used by the companies to run loyalty programs that award points to cardholders that can be redeemed for things like flights and hotels.

headline: Will Hotels Finally Beat Rentals in the Lodging Tug of War?
abstract: New restrictions on short-term rentals in some big cities may boost occupancy in hotels, but many travelers still prefer Airbnb and the like, particularly in rural areas.
lead_paragraph: In cities from New York to Vienna, new short-term-rental restrictions — designed to improve housing availability for residents — are poised to boost the bottom lines at hotels. In New York in November, shortly after Airbnb and the like were limited to stays of 30 days or longer, hotel occupancy was up 6 percent and rates were up 8 percent, according to the commercial real estate firm CoStar.

headline: Where Are People Going This Year?
abstract: Popular spots from years past are still favorites, but 2023’s crowds and heat waves are sparking interest in alternative destinations.
lead_paragraph: London, Rome, Tokyo, Cancún and Las Vegas, some of the most visited destinations in 2023, are still among the top places travelers are searching to go to this year, according to the travel sites Kayak and Hopper.

headline: How Will A.I. Change My Vacation This Year?
abstract: As artificial intelligence improves and expands its reach, expect new ways to book online, fewer snags at the airport and, possibly, more expensive tickets.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to believe that it has only been about a year since travelers started dabbling in ChatGPT-created itineraries. This year will bring even more experimentation and innovation. “A.I. is like a teenage intern,” said Chad Burt, co-owner of the travel adviser network Outside Agents, “better, smarter, faster than you, but you need to lead them.”

headline: To Fix Our Parks, Maybe a Surcharge on Mets Tickets?
abstract: A think tank has a list of ideas to generate revenue for New York’s underfunded parks.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out about ideas to generate new revenue for city parks. We’ll also get details on a warning from the judge at Donald Trump’s defamation trial in Manhattan.

headline: Ariana Grande’s ‘Yes, And?’ Strikes a Familiar-Sounding Pose
abstract: Madonna’s 1990 hit “Vogue” has enjoyed a recent renaissance. Ariana Grande’s first solo song in three years leans on its sound, but the similarities end there.
lead_paragraph: There was never a question that Madonna’s 1990 pop-house classic “Vogue” was a tidal wave. But over the past year and a half, the song that helped bring the sounds of underground queer culture to the mainstream has continued to create powerful ripples.

headline: Do You Know How Much a Home Costs? Guess Again.
abstract: A survey found the U.S. cities where residents have the best (and worst) awareness of changing housing prices.
lead_paragraph: Following the trajectory of housing prices is no easy task. But how does the general population fare when it comes to tracking real estate prices in their areas?

headline: When Public Health Loses the Public
abstract: What role may public health officials have played in fostering public distrust of them?
lead_paragraph: “Put on your masks!”

headline: Will Passports Be Replaced by Biometrics?
abstract: Technology that uses a traveler’s unique physical identifiers, such as fingerprints and faces, will be expanded at airports in the United States and abroad.
lead_paragraph: In the year ahead, the use of biometrics — an individual’s unique physical identifiers, such as fingerprints and faces — will be expanded at airports in the United States and abroad, a shift to enhance security, replace physical identification such as passports and driver’s licenses, and reduce the amount of time required by travelers to pass through airports. Biometric technology will be seen everywhere from bag drops at the check-in counters to domestic security screening.

headline: Why Big Banks (and Some Odd Allies) Oppose a Plan to Protect Banks
abstract: Federal regulators want to raise capital requirements for big banks. Their plan is drawing criticism from groups that aren’t normally aligned with the industry.
lead_paragraph: An unlikely coalition of banks, community groups and racial justice advocates is urging federal regulators to rethink the plan they proposed in July to update rules governing how U.S. banks protect themselves against potential losses.

headline: How Hollywood Lost Its Nerve
abstract: The best shows of the last two decades were the product of unusual creativity and incredible risk. Too bad the TV business has left those qualities behind.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the results of this year’s Emmy Awards, which included wins for “Succession” as outstanding drama and “The Bear” as outstanding comedy, would seem to confirm that quality TV programming is alive and well. But if you look more closely, you’ll notice red flags flying, warning us about the future. No matter how much you like the shows that won or were nominated, don’t expect another slate this good anytime soon.

headline: It Was Only One State, Right? So Why Does This Primary Feel Over?
abstract: Trump was as dominant in Iowa as the polls said he would be, and even fans of his rivals may be coming around.
lead_paragraph: Going into the Iowa caucuses, there were a handful of key things we were watching for: Would the frigid weather hamper turnout? Would his overwhelming dominance in the polls translate to a decisive victory for Donald Trump? And finally, could the other candidates muster enough of a showing to keep the race alive?

headline: Will Airline Prices Finally Drop?
abstract: Airfares this year may signal a return to normalcy, according to one aviation analyst.
lead_paragraph: A record 4.7 billion passengers are expected to fly globally in 2024, up from the previous record of 4.5 billion in 2019, according to the International Air Transport Association. Analysts at American Express Global Business Travel say that average ticket prices across all regions are not expected to change significantly. But in the United States, domestic and international airfares are expected to move in opposite directions.

headline: What 17 of Trump’s ‘Best People’ Said About Him
abstract: It’s usually rare for a president to be criticized by his own high-level officials. But it was remarkably common for former President Trump.
lead_paragraph: It’s usually rare for a president to be criticized by his own high-level officials. But it was remarkably common for former President Trump.

headline: See the Rapid Expansion of Tent Camps in Southern Gaza
abstract: Satellite images show the huge influx of displaced people in Rafah as more evacuees have moved south to avoid areas under Israeli bombardment.
lead_paragraph: Satellite images show the huge influx of displaced people in Rafah as more evacuees have moved south to avoid areas under Israeli bombardment.

headline: After Raising a Family in the West Village, She Began Again in Her Own Place
abstract: After her husband died, a retired librarian decided to leave their townhouse and strike out on her own in a one-bedroom apartment nearby. Here’s what she found for around $800,000.
lead_paragraph: After her husband died, a retired librarian decided to leave their townhouse and strike out on her own in a one-bedroom apartment nearby. Here’s what she found for around $800,000.

headline: How to Curb Kids’ Clutter
abstract: Most children have a lot of stuff, and they aren’t always inclined to tidy it up. Here’s how to embrace the abundance — and create tools to manage it.
lead_paragraph: Most children have a lot of stuff, and they aren’t always inclined to tidy it up. Here’s how to embrace the abundance — and create tools to manage it.

headline: Fool Me Once? Stand on Business. Fool Me Twice? Keep Standing.
abstract: Part relationship philosophy, part intention-setting mantra, “stand on business” is a reminder to keep your self-respect front and center, even amid the messy business of love.
lead_paragraph: Seek so much as a kernel of advice on the internet in 2024 about conflicts in a relationship, a situationship or even an affair, and you may find yourself inundated with recommendations to “stand on business.” A Hinge match asks to reschedule your first date with 30 minutes’ notice? Stand on business. Your ex continues to hit you up months after the breakup? Stand on business.

headline: John Fetterman Endorses Andy Kim in High-Stakes New Jersey Senate Primary
abstract: The Pennsylvania senator, the first among his colleagues to weigh in on the primary battle to oust the indicted Senator Robert Menendez, said he had concerns about Tammy Murphy’s G.O.P. history.
lead_paragraph: Senator John Fetterman of Pennsylvania is endorsing Representative Andy Kim of New Jersey in the primary to unseat Senator Bob Menendez, the embattled veteran Democrat who is under indictment in a federal corruption case, taking the rare step of wading into a high-stakes intraparty fight to oust a colleague.

headline: Eyeing Super Tuesday, Trump Is Eager to Dispatch Rivals Sooner Than Later
abstract: The former president is looking to lock up the nomination by Super Tuesday on March 5, but Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis insist they plan to compete deep into March.
lead_paragraph: With five days left until the New Hampshire primary, Donald J. Trump and his allies are stepping up their efforts to muscle Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis out of the Republican presidential race by casting Mr. Trump’s nomination as inevitable.

headline: In a Rare Move, Singapore Charges a Government Minister With Corruption
abstract: Accused of accepting tickets to “Hamilton,” air travel and soccer games in Britain, the transport official resigned before he pleaded not guilty in court.
lead_paragraph: It was an unprecedented set of events in Singapore: a government minister charged with corruption and then hauled to court.

headline: Why ‘Reacher’ Is More Than Just ‘Peak Dad TV’
abstract: As its second season ends, our contributor considers the broad appeal of Amazon’s big, brawny hit.
lead_paragraph: The first season of Amazon’s “Reacher” was one of the streamer’s biggest hits, drawing critical acclaim and a massive audience. The second season, which concludes on Jan. 19, is an even bigger sensation. It became Prime Video’s most streamed title of 2023.

headline: What the Houthis Really Want
abstract: The Iran-backed militia has been targeting ships in the Red Sea and launching attacks against Western military forces.
lead_paragraph: Attacks by Houthi militants on shipping in the Red Sea, a crucial global trade route, once seemed like a dangerous sideshow to the war in Gaza. But as the attacks have continued, the sideshow has turned into a full-blown crisis.

headline: Iran’s New Missile Fleet: Part Deterrent, Part Sales Pitch
abstract: Last year, the world discovered that Iran’s drones were becoming world-class threats and a favorite of the Russians. Now, its revived missile fleet is drawing attention, too.
lead_paragraph: When Iran launched a barrage of airstrikes this week into Iraq, Syria and Pakistan, it was not just showing off the reach and sophistication of some of its newest missiles but also staking a claim: This is a new era in which Iran can flex its muscles at will and, as an added benefit, bolster its credentials as an important arms supplier.

headline: Fighting Near Gaza Hospital, and Trump Sharpens Attacks on Haley
abstract: Hear the news in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: After a Warmer Thursday, Bitter Cold Will Return Across the U.S.
abstract: Thursday will bring a slight break from the Arctic air that overtook the country this week. The chilly weather will return Friday and Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Parts of the United States will get a reprieve on Thursday from the dangerously cold weather that sent temperatures plunging well below zero, draining car batteries in Chicago and sending southerners scrambling to prep their homes for the freeze. But on Friday, the chill returns.

headline: Sophie Turner’s Lawsuit Against Joe Jonas Is Dismissed
abstract: The English actress sued the American musician weeks after they announced their split, saying he had prevented their two children from returning to Britain.
lead_paragraph: A judge in New York on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit that the English actress Sophie Turner filed last year against her husband, Joe Jonas, in which she requested that their two young children be returned to England from the United States.

headline: How Much Power Should Government Experts Have?
abstract: The Supreme Court heard oral arguments yesterday on one of the biggest cases of the current term.
lead_paragraph: Now that abortion is restricted and affirmative action is hobbled, the conservative legal movement has set its sights on a third precedent: Chevron v. Natural Resources Defense Council.

headline: ‘Inside the Yellow Cocoon Shell’ Review: A Wanderer on a Spiritual Quest
abstract: An uncommonly strong debut from the Vietnamese director Pham Thien An asks existential questions without answers.
lead_paragraph: The complex dance of doubt and religious faith is frequently cast in terms of a quest. One might be “on a faith journey,” or be “a lost soul,” or be “searching” for meaning and the divine — all images derived from the idea of starting at one place, keeping your eyes open, and ending up, ultimately, in some final destination. Small wonder that many human cultures imagine a wander in the wilderness, literal or metaphorical, as pivotal to one’s initiation into maturity. Some fresh wisdom and revelation comes from walking around in circles for a while.

headline: ‘Pasang: In the Shadow of Everest’ Review: A Barrier-Breaking Ascent
abstract: This documentary tells the story of Pasang Lhamu Sherpa, the first Nepali woman to summit Earth’s highest mountain.
lead_paragraph: Summiting Everest would be the feat of a lifetime for almost anyone. For Pasang Lhamu Sherpa, the first Nepali woman to reach the peak, it also meant challenging traditional gender norms in Nepal. And it required transcending a role that Nepali mountain guides have historically played — namely, helping tourist mountaineers rather than taking the lead.

headline: ‘The End We Start From’ Review: A Watery Apocalypse and a New Beginning
abstract: Jodie Comer stars in a lethargic adaptation of Megan Hunter’s best-selling novel.
lead_paragraph: Flooding is among the extreme weather disasters on offer on a planet with a changing climate, and that’s both catastrophic and, in a literary sense, poetic. The first apocalypse recorded in more than one ancient text is, after all, a deluge.

headline: ‘Which Brings Me to You’ Review: Out With the Old?
abstract: This rom-com boasts a clever conceit that at times feels a little cluttered.
lead_paragraph: When Will stops midway through a makeout session with Jane in the romantic comedy “Which Brings Me to You,” it signals a kind of maturity on his part. And he’s met with surprise. Jane (Lucy Hale) was cool with a purely carnal interlude. Will (Nat Wolff) wants them to connect on a deeper level.

headline: ‘The Breaking Ice’ Review: Desire on the Border of China and North Korea
abstract: A love triangle takes shape among three 20-somethings in this melancholy film by Anthony Chen.
lead_paragraph: In “The Breaking Ice,” a new film written and directed by Anthony Chen, three lost 20-somethings find one another in a liminal world. The movie takes place in Yanji, a Chinese city bordering North Korea, where two languages and cultures mix in the shadows of snow-blanketed mountains.

headline: With Adams Vulnerable, Scott Stringer Explores Run for N.Y.C. Mayor
abstract: Mr. Stringer, whose 2021 mayoralty bid was derailed by a sexual misconduct allegation, is gearing up to try again to beat Eric Adams.
lead_paragraph: Scott M. Stringer, the former New York City comptroller and 2021 mayoral candidate, said on Thursday that he would form an exploratory committee and begin raising funds for a possible primary challenge against Mayor Eric Adams next year.

headline: ‘Oppenheimer’ Leads BAFTA Nominees
abstract: Christopher Nolan’s movie received 13 nods, and will compete for best picture against the likes of “Killers of The Flower Moon” and “Poor Things,” but not “Barbie.”
lead_paragraph: “Oppenheimer,” Christopher Nolan’s movie about the development of the atomic bomb, on Thursday received the highest number of nominations for this year’s EE British Academy Film Awards, known as the BAFTAs.

headline: The TikTok ‘Tunnel Girl’ Is Not Alone
abstract: Hobby tunneling is a rare, but not unheard-of, pastime that has produced frustrated neighbors, media frenzies and at least one state landmark.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia woman who has spent more than a year digging a tunnel under her home and documenting the project on TikTok was recently stopped by officials in her town after the popularity of her account brought their attention to her project.

headline: On This Comedy Show, You’d Better Not Laugh
abstract: “Last One Laughing,” an Amazon Prime show in which contestants try not to crack up, has spawned spinoffs in more than a dozen countries — though not the United States.
lead_paragraph: In early 2016, James Farrell, then the head of content at Amazon Studios for Japan, was looking for original programming that could help the streamer gain a foothold in the region.

headline: Congress Clears Stopgap Spending Bill for Biden, Moving to Avert Shutdown
abstract: Hours after the Senate passed the measure, the House followed suit, with Democrats supplying the bulk of the votes, a day before funding for some government agencies was slated to lapse.
lead_paragraph: Congress on Thursday sent legislation to avert a partial government shutdown to President Biden, racing to fund federal agencies through early March one day before money was to run out.

headline: Why Is Antisemitism Low on the Agenda at Davos?
abstract: Some business and political leaders say more attention should be paid to a topic that is dominating discussion in U.S. boardrooms.
lead_paragraph: Attendees at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, have been speaking at length about artificial intelligence, the war in Ukraine, the U.S. election, climate change and more.

headline: Ballet Flats for the Bow Obsessed
abstract: Plus: a cafe and farm shop in Marrakesh, remedies for the under-eye area and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: When the Moroccan financier Aziz Nahas decided to buy and regenerate a farm outside Marrakesh about two decades ago, he underestimated how much would grow there. Now, the 10-acre plot produces organic vegetables and fruits as well as hosting an artist residency program and a ceramic studio, all under the name Sanctuary Slimane. In 2021, Nahas’s friend the French restaurateur Benjamin Pastor suggested they partner up to start a cafe and farm shop in the busy Marrakesh neighborhood of Gueliz. Last spring, they opened the coffee shop Blue Ribbon, with offerings including fresh salads served with halloumi or beets and almonds and a bánh mí sandwich on fresh sourdough. In the fall, they added a seating area next door and the Slimane Farm Shop, which sells vegetables and products like honey and dried herbs that are grown and produced on the farm. Up next: Farmers, a restaurant headed by Blue Ribbon’s chef and located in the same building. The 46-seat space, lined with colorful Popham tiles, is scheduled to open at the end of February. blueribbonmarrakech.com.

headline: California Now Has a State Mushroom and a State Bat
abstract: The golden chanterelle and the pallid bat join a long list of official Golden State symbols.
lead_paragraph: By now you’ve heard plenty about the new laws that went into effect as 2024 began.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in Manhattan Valley, East Chelsea and Prospect Heights.
lead_paragraph: A 900-square-foot studio with an open floor plan, marble countertops, a breakfast bar, a sleeping nook, built-ins, ample closets, through-the-wall air-conditioning and a basement storage locker, on the fourth floor of a six-story former warehouse from 1918 that has a live-in super, shared laundry and a bike room. Craig George and Kevin Brown, Sotheby’s International Realty-East Side Manhattan Brokerage, 917-886-4760; sothebysrealty.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Millstone, N.J., and Yorktown Heights, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 4,097-square-foot house built in 1996, with a striking two-story entryway with a curving staircase, a large family room with a wood-burning fireplace, a formal dining room, a primary bedroom suite with an outdoor balcony, an upper-level office, a lower-level lounge area with a fireplace and wet bar, a patio with a gazebo, an in-ground pool, a koi pond, an outdoor kitchen and an attached three-car garage, on 5.86 acres with grassy fields and wooded areas. David Borrero, ReMax Homeland West, 917-681-2603, remax.com

headline: Arnold Schwarzenegger Detained Over Pricey Watch at Munich Airport
abstract: He’ll be back … to face criminal tax charges.
lead_paragraph: For two and a half hours on Wednesday, German border officers were up against an unlikely foe: the Terminator.

headline: On the Lower East Side, a Secret Space, a Mini-Biennial
abstract: Reaching out to artists known and emerging, a little-known gallery illuminates a patch of grass-roots D.I.Y. in a time of gleaming big-box galleries.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the phrase “Dimes Square” began to flit around the art world. It had a youthful irreverence and seemed to be among those “if you know, you know” spots that only a few could point to on a map.

headline: Abortion-Rights Backers in Missouri Start Ballot Initiative to Undo Ban
abstract: Advocates present a united front after disagreements over how far they could go in asking voters to legalize abortion in the state.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of reproductive-rights groups in Missouri kicked off a campaign on Thursday to establish a right to abortion in the state constitution, setting up the nation’s next big test of public support for legalized abortion.

headline: They Abducted a River in California. And Nobody Stopped Them.
abstract: Farms drained part of the Merced for months. Officials didn’t find out until after the fact, raising questions about the state’s ability to manage supplies during droughts.
lead_paragraph: During California’s most recent drought, officials went to great lengths to safeguard water supplies, issuing emergency regulations to curb use by thousands of farms, utilities and irrigation districts.

headline: Don’t Laugh and Drive: U.S. Cracks Down on Funny Highway Warnings
abstract: Federal officials want states to “use good judgment” and avoid humorous highway signs that may confuse or distract drivers. State officials say witty signs “break through the noise.”
lead_paragraph: In recent years, drivers across the country have chuckled (or groaned) at the humorous safety messages that have popped up on America’s highways.

headline: Justice Department Finds ‘Unimaginable Failure’ in Uvalde Police Response
abstract: In a report, the department blames “cascading failures of leadership, decision-making, tactics, policy and training” in the Texas school shooting that left 21 people dead.
lead_paragraph: A near-total breakdown in policing protocols hindered the response to the 2022 school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, that left 21 people dead — and the refusal to rapidly confront the killer needlessly cost lives, the Justice Department concluded on Thursday after a nearly two-year investigation.

headline: ‘The Kitchen’ Review: No Direction Home
abstract: Directing their first feature, Kibwe Tavares and Daniel Kaluuya spin a warmly humane story of cross-generational connection.
lead_paragraph: The vitality and bonhomie that characterize many scenes in “The Kitchen,” a dystopian drama set in a near-future London, might seem at odds with the film’s focus on deprivation and persecution. Yet there’s nothing despairing about the close-knit, mostly nonwhite community that swarms and surges inside the titular public housing project, one of the last to be swallowed by private developers.

headline: Protests in Russia Put Spotlight on Wartime Ethnic Grievances
abstract: The trial and conviction of an activist in the Ural Mountains region sparked one of the biggest outbreaks of social unrest since the start of the war.
lead_paragraph: The trial of a minority rights activist in Russia this week sparked one of the biggest outbreaks of social unrest in the country since the start of the war in Ukraine, highlighting the strain the conflict has imposed on Russia’s complex ethnic relations.

headline: Ruth Wilson on the True Horrors of ‘The Woman in the Wall’
abstract: Her fictional character lives in an unstable reality and may have killed someone. But the history of Ireland’s notorious “Magdalene laundries” is all too real.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Wilson has ducked into a cabin in the French Alps, taking a break from an activity she enjoys when she isn’t acting. “I’ve been skiing this week,” she said last week in a video interview. “It’s been a passion for years. It’s very dangerous. I can go head-down into something.”

headline: Warming Recipes for Cold Days
abstract: Mushroom risotto with peas, habanero chicken and broccoli, and bricklayer-style nachos chase away winter’s chill.
lead_paragraph: We’re at that point in January when we want to keep those cooking resolutions going strong (more vegetarian meals! More fish! More whole grains!), but we also want some comfort and coziness. The weather is getting colder, our socks are getting thicker, and we’re craving meals that feel like a warm hug. Something like this mushroom risotto with peas, a Martha Rose Shulman recipe that has five stars and nearly 4,000 reviews. It’s a vegetarian dish that’s creamy, filling and umami-rich with plenty of browned mushrooms and Parmesan cheese. It does require a good bit of stirring, but some quiet time spent over a warm, steaming saucepan sounds pretty good right about now.

headline: Houthi Leader Says Clash With U.S. Will Strengthen Militia Group
abstract: Abdul-Malik al-Houthi said in a televised speech that the Houthis had always emerged stronger from confrontations with their enemies.
lead_paragraph: The leader of Yemen’s Houthi militia declared on Thursday that a direct clash with the United States would only strengthen the group, and vowed to continue attacking ships in the Red Sea.

headline: Understanding Donald Trump’s Appeal
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Bret Stephens. Also: Freedom of expression; police courtesy cards; domestic violence in New York.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: She Wrote a Best Seller on Women’s Sex Lives. Then Her Own Fell Apart.
abstract: The sex educator Emily Nagoski’s new book on maintaining intimacy in long-term relationships began at home.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, as the sex educator Emily Nagoski was researching and writing her first book, “Come as You Are” — a soon-to-be best seller exploring the science of women’s sexuality — she and her husband stopped having sex.

headline: Nikki Haley Is Chasing Independents. They Have a Mind of Their Own.
abstract: Her chance to beat Donald J. Trump in New Hampshire depends on her ability to win over its famously freethinking voters. Her challenge is that they come in all stripes.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley’s presidential aspirations may hang on a victory in the New Hampshire primary election on Tuesday, powered by her sway with people who do not belong to a political party. It’s not a bad bet in a state where about 40 percent of voters call themselves independents.

headline: The G.O.P.’s ‘Nasty’ New Religion
abstract: Bullying is boldness. Spite is strength.
lead_paragraph: We’ve spent the past few days deconstructing what happened at the Iowa caucuses. I’m still stuck on what happened before:

headline: A Deal Is Struck in a Long-Running Quarrel. Over Donkey Kong.
abstract: Billy Mitchell’s records will be listed in a “historical database” but not the leaderboard, ending a dispute familiar from the 2007 documentary “The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters.”
lead_paragraph: Back in the 1980s, it seemed as if everyone with a spare quarter was playing the arcade game Donkey Kong, scooting up ramps and climbing ladders while avoiding barrels hurled by a giant ape.

headline: Iceland Scrambles to Shelter Residents Made Homeless by Volcanic Eruption
abstract: In a country of fewer than 400,000, finding places for 3,700 residents is complicated by a tough housing market.
lead_paragraph: To house the evacuees of Grindavik, the Icelandic town where lava poured into some houses last week after a volcanic eruption, a former prime minister proposed building a new town from scratch. A politician said Airbnbs around the island nation should be restricted to make room for the residents. And a radio host suggested turning away asylum seekers to focus resources on helping “refugees” from Grindavik.

headline: What to Know About the Federal Law at the Heart of the Latest Supreme Court Abortion Case
abstract: The federal Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act, known as EMTALA, requires hospitals to provide medically necessary care to stabilize patients in emergency situations.
lead_paragraph: One of the newest battlefields in the abortion debate is a decades-old federal law called the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act, known by doctors and health policymakers as EMTALA.

headline: What We Know About Multivitamins and Memory
abstract: New research suggests a daily vitamin can improve cognition. But that doesn’t mean everyone should take one.
lead_paragraph: A new study reported that adults 60 and older who took a daily multivitamin for two years scored higher on memory and cognitive tests than those who took a placebo — a rare example of a clinical trial finding that a nutritional supplement might actually benefit healthy people.

headline: Nancy E. Adler, Who Linked Wealth to Health, Dies at 77
abstract: She documented the powerful role that education, income and self-perceived social status play in a person’s health and longevity.
lead_paragraph: Nancy E. Adler, a health psychologist whose work helped transform the public understanding of the relationship between socioeconomic status and physical health, died on Jan. 4 at her home in San Francisco. She was 77.

headline: Billionaires Wanted to Save the News Industry. They’re Losing a Fortune.
abstract: Time magazine, The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times — owned by Marc Benioff, Jeff Bezos and Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong — are still losing money.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old saying about the news business: If you want to make a small fortune, start with a large one.

headline: Applications Open for the 2024 New York Portfolio Review
abstract: Apply now for this free event for photographers
lead_paragraph: Applications are now open for the free New York Portfolio Review, which is produced by The New York Times photo department, Photoville and the Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at CUNY.

headline: Brazilian Police Make Arrest in Killing of New York Art Dealer
abstract: The suspect knew Brent Sikkema, according to the police, and was arrested at a gas station about 600 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro.
lead_paragraph: A man was arrested in Brazil on Thursday in connection with the killing of Brent Sikkema, a New York art dealer who was found with 18 stab wounds in his Rio de Janeiro apartment this week.

headline: Why Astronauts From Italy, Sweden and Turkey Are Flying Commercial
abstract: A SpaceX launch to the International Space Station led by the company Axiom Space illustrates how traditional and private space efforts are mixing.
lead_paragraph: A private mission launched four astronauts to the International Space Station on Thursday.

headline: Need a Bird Cage Shaped Like the U.S. Capitol? Try the Winter Show
abstract: The storied arts and antiques fair at the Park Avenue Armory has something for every taste. Our critic’s choice of booths to get you started.
lead_paragraph: As it has done every year for the past seven straight decades, the Winter Show, the venerable arts and antiquities fair, which benefits the East Side House Settlement in the Bronx, has brought together an incredible range of objects, most of those years under the capacious roof of the Park Avenue Armory. A concert piano with a curved keyboard, designed by the architect Rafael Viñoly and built by Chris Maene. (Bernard Goldberg Fine Arts, LLC, C1). A couple of Bonnards for the foyer (Jill Newhouse Gallery, A7). A contemporary painter responding to Italian old masters (Robert Simon Fine Art, C10). A red, white and blue Centennial-year bird cage in the shape of the U.S. Capitol (Focus: Americana, curated by Alexandra Kirtley of the Philadelphia Museum of Art). What about a butter dish shaped like a bundle of asparagus (Michele Beiny, D1)? Or first editions of Edmund Spenser’s “The Faerie Queene” and “Leaves of Grass” (Peter Harrington, C12)?

headline: It’s Potato Degrees Outside
abstract: Stay inside and tuck into potato and cheese pierogi, tacos de papa and sweet potato hash.
lead_paragraph: There are plenty of things I’d rather not hear at the crack of dawn, and near the top of that list is the stilted voice of my smart speaker saying, “Right now in Brooklyn, it’s 17 degrees. Due to current wind conditions, it feels like 5 degrees.”

headline: Davos puts Climate on the Back Burner
abstract: “Yeah, the world is going to end, but I’m still going to vacation.”
lead_paragraph: Here at the World Economic Forum in Davos, the most revealing discussions often happen not on the main stage, but at the myriad side events that transform this Swiss ski town into a high-minded networking event.

headline: Trump Prosecutor in Georgia Seeks to Avoid Testifying in Colleague’s Divorce Case
abstract: Fani T. Willis was subpoenaed in the divorce case of a colleague she hired to manage the Trump prosecution in Georgia, with whom she is accused of having a romantic relationship.
lead_paragraph: Fani T. Willis, the district attorney prosecuting the Georgia election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump, is trying to quash a subpoena seeking her testimony in the divorce proceedings of a special prosecutor she hired to manage the case.

headline: Raw Oysters May Have Sickened 200 in Southern California, Officials Say
abstract: More than 150 cases of gastrointestinal illness, most likely linked to raw oysters, were reported in Los Angeles County, and another 41 were reported in San Diego County, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Gastrointestinal illnesses potentially linked to raw oysters sickened nearly 200 people, according to health officials in Southern California, who urged residents to take extra precautions with shellfish.

headline: Netanyahu Rebuffs U.S. Calls to Start Working Toward Palestinian Statehood
abstract: The Biden administration and the Israeli government diverge sharply over how Gaza should be governed when the war ends.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday appeared to rule out a postwar peace process that would lead to the establishment of a sovereign Palestinian state, rebuffing calls from the United States and others to start working toward that goal.

headline: What to Watch This Weekend: ‘Boy Swallows Universe’
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a dreamy, violent Netflix drama from Australia, based on a book by Trent Dalton.
lead_paragraph: “Boy Swallows Universe,” a seven-part drama based on the book by Trent Dalton, puts a youthful spin on the accidental-criminal subgenre, blending dreaminess and brutality to terrific if incomplete effect. The whole show is available now, on Netflix.

headline: Joseph Esposito, Longtime N.Y.P.D. Chief, Is Dead at 73
abstract: For more than 12 years, he oversaw the city’s response to some of its most challenging disasters. He later led New York’s emergency management agency.
lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Esposito, who served longer than anyone else as the highest-ranking uniformed officer of the New York Police Department, and who oversaw the city’s response to emergencies, including the 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center and the devastation of Hurricane Sandy, died on Jan. 8 in Mineola, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 73.

headline: Judge Denies Effort to Remove Trump From the Ballot in Washington State
abstract: Voters had sought to disqualify the former president under the 14th Amendment, following the lead of Colorado and Maine.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Washington State said on Thursday that former President Donald J. Trump’s name could remain on the state’s primary ballot. The ruling was the latest in a series of battles nationwide over whether Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn his 2020 election defeat make him ineligible to hold the presidency again.

headline: A Coffee Shop Wedding Goes Viral, for the Wrong Reasons
abstract: A disagreement between a wedding party and the owners of a coffee shop in Indianapolis escalated into a social media debate over wedding etiquette.
lead_paragraph: A couple of days after Aishat Bolomope’s wedding on Dec. 31, the newlywed realized that she might be spending her honeymoon on the choppy seas of internet outrage. Friends from as far as her native Nigeria said they recognized her in a video clip that drew millions of views online.

headline: History Argues for Disqualifying Trump
abstract: The 14th Amendment has been used both to keep insurrectionists out of office and to let them back in. The latter choice has led to disaster.
lead_paragraph: One of the most difficult things to ask a judge to do is issue a ruling that he or she believes is actually dangerous. Even if you can make a strong case that the letter of the law is on your side, judges are tempted to narrow the reach of disfavored laws or sometimes virtually rewrite them in order to avoid outcomes that are deemed too radical or disruptive.

headline: Will the Supreme Court Show a Little Humility?
abstract: The justices should leave it to federal agencies to resolve ambiguities Congress creates when it writes laws those agencies enforce.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court heard arguments on Wednesday in two cases inviting the justices to drastically restrict the authority of federal agencies, upend decades of precedent and take more power for themselves.

headline: The Wine Heiresses Apparent
abstract: It used to be rare, but around the wine world, and with a particular concentration in Chianti Classico, daughters are taking on leadership roles.
lead_paragraph: As a young woman growing up in the Chianti Classico town of Radda-in-Chianti in Tuscany, Angela Fronti was sure of one thing: She did not want to join her family’s business, doing agricultural work for wineries.

headline: Spelman, a Historically Black Women’s College, Receives $100 Million Gift
abstract: The donation to the private school in Atlanta is believed to be the largest ever to an H.B.C.U.
lead_paragraph: Spelman College, the women’s school in Atlanta, announced on Thursday that it had received a $100 million donation, which its officials called the largest-ever single gift to a historically Black college.

headline: Before the Coronavirus Pandemic, Overlooked Clues From Chinese Scientists
abstract: Newly released documents indicate that a U.S. genetic database had received the sequence of the coronavirus two weeks before it was made public by others.
lead_paragraph: In late December 2019, eight pages of genetic code were sent to computers at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md.

headline: Arrest Violated County Official’s Free Speech Rights, Judge Rules
abstract: Niki Frenchko, a county commissioner in Trumbull County, Ohio, was arrested after she criticized the sheriff. A federal judge ruled that her constitutional rights were violated.
lead_paragraph: Heated disagreements were not unusual at Board of Commissioners meetings in Trumbull County, Ohio, after Niki Frenchko took office in January 2021, becoming the only Republican on the three-member board. But the tensions erupted in July 2022, ending in Ms. Frenchko’s arrest after she continued to speak her mind during a public meeting.

headline: House G.O.P. Winds Down Mayorkas Impeachment Without His Public Testimony
abstract: House Republicans are racing to charge the homeland security secretary without his in-person testimony or evidence of impeachable offenses.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans wrapped up impeachment hearings against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, on Thursday, a little more than a week after the proceedings began, racing to charge him with failing to enforce the nation’s immigration laws.

headline: South African Government Seeks to Halt Auction of Mandela Items
abstract: The government said that it is seeking to appeal a court ruling that had allowed the proposed online auction of some of Nelson Mandela’s belongings to move forward.
lead_paragraph: The South African Heritage Resources Agency is seeking to prevent an auction of dozens of Nelson Mandela’s personal belongings, saying on Thursday that it has filed court papers to appeal a ruling that had allowed the sale of the items to go forward.

headline: Why Donald Trump Is Facing E. Jean Carroll in Court a Second Time
abstract: A jury already found that the former president sexually assaulted E. Jean Carroll, a former magazine writer, and defamed her. Why is he in court again?
lead_paragraph: The accusations by the writer E. Jean Carroll that former President Donald J. Trump raped and defamed her have been the subject of two separate trials in U.S. District Court in Lower Manhattan and have unfolded as Mr. Trump campaigns for the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years after the formalist poet Anthony Hecht died, he seems to be having a mini-revival with the simultaneous release, from separate publishers, of a biography and a vast collected poems. Hecht was a complicated figure: A Jewish American veteran of World War II, he was haunted by what he saw of the Holocaust up close and also by his pacifist decision never to fire his gun at another person even in battle. He channeled that experience and its psychological burden into precisely regimented meter and rhyme, in poems that gained much of their power from the tension between their content and their technical constraints. You could read either the biography or the collected poems individually, but why not read both together? They benefit from the pairing.

headline: Read the Justice Department Report on the Uvalde School Shooting Response
abstract: The investigation found that a near-total breakdown in policing protocols hindered the response to the 2022 shooting in Texas that left 21 people dead.
lead_paragraph: The investigation found that a near-total breakdown in policing protocols hindered the response to the 2022 shooting in Texas that left 21 people dead.

headline: A Goodbye, a Return and Beef Noodle Soup
abstract: As Pete Wells finishes his time on Where to Eat, he looks back at his favorite dishes.
lead_paragraph: Have you noticed how little “news” I break in this so-called newsletter? Practically none. Well, here’s some for a change: Nikita Richardson is coming back next week.

headline: Why Iran Is the Common Link in Conflicts From Gaza to Pakistan
abstract: Iran’s long history of building up proxy forces that fight its enemies around the region, as well as its conflicts with separatist and terrorist groups, have played into a spate of recent conflicts.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Gaza. Yemen and the Red Sea. Lebanon, Syria, Iraq — and now Pakistan, too.

headline: Friday Briefing: Pakistan Retaliates With Strikes in Iran
abstract: Also, corruption accusations in Singapore and travel predictions
lead_paragraph: Pakistan announced yesterday that it had carried out strikes against what it said were terrorist hide-outs in Iran. A day earlier, Iran hit what it called militant camps in Pakistan. The military exchange is the latest example of an expanding set of hostilities connected to the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Sleater-Kinney, Out of the Woods, for Better or Worse
abstract: The band’s 11th album, “Little Rope,” was born out of tragedy, but feels curiously restrained.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 20 years ago, when Sleater-Kinney released its towering seventh album, “The Woods,” there was a convincing case to be made that the trio was the most vital, and underrated, working American rock band.

headline: Friday Briefing: Pakistan Retaliates With Strikes in Iran
abstract: Also, corruption accusations in Singapore.
lead_paragraph: Pakistan announced yesterday that it had carried out strikes against what it said were terrorist hide-outs in Iran. A day earlier, Iran hit what it called militant camps in Pakistan. The military exchange is the latest example of an expanding set of hostilities connected to the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Judge Declines to Hold Prosecutors in Contempt in Trump Election Case
abstract: Judge Tanya S. Chutkan issued her order after prosecutors continued to file court papers in the former president’s election interference case even though she had put the proceeding on hold.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the odder tit-for-tat battles to have emerged so far in the federal case accusing former President Donald J. Trump of plotting to subvert the 2020 election.

headline: War Is on the Agenda in Davos, but the Focus Is Elsewhere
abstract: The leaders and executives gathering at the World Economic Forum are obsessed with elections and artificial intelligence, not Ukraine or Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Each day this week has brought a new and fleeting reminder to the executives and politicians at the annual World Economic Forum meeting of the two wars threatening global security and clouding the economy. Ukraine’s president spoke on Tuesday. Israel’s spoke on Thursday.

headline: Trump’s Split Screen: Campaign Trail and Courtroom
abstract: The former president’s campaign and his legal strategy are now one and the same.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s presidential campaign and his courtroom strategy are now one and the same.

headline: Here Are the Winners of the 2023 Super Mega Contest
abstract: See the answers to the 50x50 puzzle and related contest.
lead_paragraph: As in previous years, solving Joe DiPietro’s 50x50 Super Mega crossword was a joint exercise for many readers — spouses, partners, parents and children, whole families, and so on. It’s heartwarming to think that the puzzle has become such a holiday tradition.

headline: No Labels Asks the Justice Department to Investigate Its Critics
abstract: The group said efforts to oppose it and incendiary statements were evidence of an unlawful conspiracy. Such a complaint is unusual in politics, where attacks and pressure campaigns are common.
lead_paragraph: No Labels, the centrist group that could field a third-party presidential bid, has asked the Justice Department to investigate what it calls unlawful intimidation by groups that oppose it.

headline: Ex-State Dept. Official Ordered to Bias Training After Anti-Muslim Rant
abstract: If Stuart Seldowitz completes the program, the charges he faces for berating a food truck vendor would be dropped, prosecutors said. A Muslim group called it a “sweetheart deal.”
lead_paragraph: A former State Department employee charged with a hate crime in November after he harassed a halal food vendor in Manhattan, calling him a “terrorist,” may have his charges dismissed if he completes a 26-week anti-bias course and fulfills other requirements, according to prosecutors.

headline: When Stars Want to Go Big, They Go Red
abstract: Selena Gomez, Ayo Edebiri, Barry Keoghan, Dua Lipa and Meghann Fahy are just some of the celebrities who have recently worn the color on red carpets.
lead_paragraph: Viewers of award shows might have noticed a trend in recent years: Some of the red carpets have been colors other than red.

headline: Three Republican Candidates, Three Very Different Styles
abstract: The Times’ Ashley Wu reports on the top three Republican candidates and how their campaign styles differ despite similar policy stances.
lead_paragraph: The Times’ Ashley Wu reports on the top three Republican candidates and how their campaign styles differ despite similar policy stances.

headline: Accused of Running a ‘Basement’ Campaign, Nikki Haley Takes Questions
abstract: In recent weeks, she had stopped taking questions from voters at her events, frustrating some attendees, particularly in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, battling attacks from Donald J. Trump that she is too liberal and accusations from Ron DeSantis that she has been hiding from voters and reporters, hit back on Thursday, taking questions and defending her conservative credentials.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the Federal Report on the Uvalde Massacre
abstract: The report found that a lack of leadership and poor decision-making created confusion at the scene and delayed a confrontation with the gunman.
lead_paragraph: More than a year and a half after the school massacre in Uvalde, Texas, the Justice Department on Thursday published a painstaking and independent examination of the law enforcement response, finding broad and “unimaginable” failures that delayed medical care to the victims.

headline: Justice Department Found ‘Unimaginable Failure’ in Uvalde Response
abstract: Also, fighting has eased in northern Gaza. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A near-total breakdown in policing protocols hindered the response to the school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, in 2022 that left 21 people dead, the Justice Department concluded today after a nearly two-year investigation.

headline: Revolutionizing Pediatric Cardiac Surger
abstract: Groundbreaking advancements are being made at Boston Children’s.
lead_paragraph: Groundbreaking advancements are being made at Boston Children’s.

headline: Trump Asks Supreme Court to Rule He Is Eligible to Hold Office
abstract: The forceful brief was the former president’s main submission in his appeal of a ruling barring him from the Colorado primary ballot on the ground that he had engaged in insurrection.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump urged the Supreme Court on Thursday to reverse a ruling barring him from the primary ballot in Colorado and to declare him eligible to seek and hold the office of the presidency.

headline: Hunter Biden Agrees to Deposition in Impeachment Inquiry
abstract: The chairmen of the Oversight and Judiciary committees set a Feb. 28 deposition date for President Biden’s son, who resisted a previous subpoena for a closed-door interview and asked to testify in public.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden, President Biden’s son, has agreed to sit for a deposition on Feb. 28 in the House impeachment inquiry into his father, relenting after Republicans threatened to hold him in contempt of Congress for refusing an earlier subpoena to testify privately.

headline: Is Your Rent Too High? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: At a time of crushing housing costs, we are looking to speak with renters who pay half of their income in rent.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times wants to hear from renters in cities around the country who pay half of their income (or close to it) on rent. How do you make ends meet? How does your high rent affect your financial and life choices? We want to hear your experiences.

headline: Death by a Thousand Paper Cuts
abstract: The swelling ranks of administrators in American life are stealing our time, our freedom and our vitality.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes in this job I have a kernel of a column idea that doesn’t pan out. But other times I begin looking into a topic and find a problem so massive that I can’t believe I’ve ever written about anything else. This latter experience happened as I looked into the growing bureaucratization of American life. It’s not only that growing bureaucracies cost a lot of money; they also enervate American society. They redistribute power from workers to rule makers, and in so doing sap initiative, discretion, creativity and drive.

headline: China’s Economy Is in Serious Trouble
abstract: And President Xi’s leadership is only part of the problem.
lead_paragraph: In 2023, the U.S. economy vastly outperformed expectations. A widely predicted recession never happened. Many economists (though not me) argued that getting inflation down would require years of high unemployment; instead, we’ve experienced immaculate disinflation, rapidly falling inflation at no visible cost.

headline: Ron DeSantis and Fox News, Old Friends, Hit Turbulence
abstract: The Fox News host Laura Ingraham called for the Florida governor to leave the Republican primary, days after he accused the network of protecting Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: When the Fox News host Laura Ingraham urged Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida “to step aside and endorse Trump” on Tuesday night, it was the latest sign of a sharp deterioration of relations between the Republican presidential hopeful and the network that made him a star.

headline: American Airlines Flight Attendant Filmed Minors Using Lavatory, U.S. Says
abstract: Estes Carter Thompson III stashed an iPhone in a first-class lavatory to film a girl, 14, on a flight in September, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: An American Airlines flight attendant was arrested on Thursday, accused of using his cellphone in an attempt to secretly record a 14-year-old girl as she used the lavatory on a domestic flight in September, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Macy’s Plans to Cut 2,350 Jobs and Close 5 Stores
abstract: The layoffs, focused on corporate positions, will reduce the retailer’s work force by 3.5 percent as a new chief executive prepares to take the reins.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s, the country’s largest department store operator, told employees Thursday that it was laying off 13 percent of its corporate work force. The move comes as the company prepares to unveil a new strategy that its incoming chief executive will oversee.

headline: How Pedro Pascal Followed Doctor’s Orders on the Red Carpet
abstract: After a shoulder injury, the actor had been making awards-season appearances in a sling. Zegna’s artistic director explained how one strikingly minimalist version came to be.
lead_paragraph: Speaking from the stage of the 75th Emmy Awards as he prepared to announce the winner for best supporting actor in a drama series, Pedro Pascal clarified for anyone wondering that it was an injury to his shoulder — not his arm — that required him to be in a sling. He also offered something in the way of an explanation for the injury.

headline: American Company’s Moon Lander Disintegrates in Earth’s Atmosphere
abstract: The Astrobotic Peregrine spacecraft launched last week for a lunar landing, but a propulsion malfunction left it unable to complete its mission.
lead_paragraph: A spacecraft that was headed to the surface of the moon has ended up back at Earth instead, burning up in the planet’s atmosphere on Thursday afternoon.

headline: House Committee Seeks Testimony From Austin on Hospitalization
abstract: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said that “Congress must understand what happened and who made decisions to prevent the disclosure of the whereabouts of a cabinet secretary.”
lead_paragraph: The House Armed Services Committee on Thursday asked Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III to testify next month about why he and his aides kept secret from the White House for several days that he was hospitalized after having complications from prostate cancer surgery.

headline: Good Speller
abstract: Jacob McDermott opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon start our cryptic year with a brilliant au revoir.
lead_paragraph: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD — According to Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, this is it — their last cryptic crossword in a run of genius puzzles that started in the 1970s. They say that they’re leaving us in good hands, and it’s true that there are far more constructors making cryptic puzzles than ever before. I’m verklempt, but still hopeful that this will be a sabbatical instead of a retirement.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 19, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about new estimates of Greenland’s ice sheet losses rendered incorrectly a quote by Laura Larocca, a climate scientist at Arizona State University. She said the new data set captured “the areal extent of the entire Greenland ice sheet.” Not the aerial extent.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Report Blames ‘Cascading Failures’ for Delayed Uvalde Police Response
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It was an unimaginable failure.”

headline: Iowa Teen Who Killed 2 Fellow Students Gets 65 Years in Prison
abstract: Preston Walls, 19, killed Rashard Carr, 16, and Gionni Dameron, 18, who were in the same alternative school program, in what the authorities called a gang-related shooting.
lead_paragraph: An Iowa teenager who shot and killed two fellow students at an alternative school program for at-risk youths last year and wounded the program’s founder was sentenced on Thursday to 65 years in prison, prosecutors announced.

headline: The One Question That Led to Love
abstract: During a night of stargazing, Ali Angco was trying to be a wing woman for a friend who liked Ian Chua. But she accidentally charmed him instead.
lead_paragraph: On Alexandria Angco’s 28th birthday in September 2022, she declared that she would not date anyone for a whole year. Dating wasn’t going so well for her, and she wanted to focus on herself instead.

headline: A Foster Cat Named Edgar Allen Potato Played Cupid
abstract: Eric Graves is a self-proclaimed dog person, but Julia Tiller, and a few of her feline friends, brought him to the other side.
lead_paragraph: Julia Kate Tiller and Eric Daniel Graves didn’t meet at her older brother’s graduation in 2019, although they both attended (Mr. Graves is Ms. Tiller’s brother’s friend). They didn’t fall in love at church in the summer of 2021, although that’s where they met.

headline: She Went on 100 Dates Before They Met. He Hadn’t Been on Any in Years.
abstract: After Molly Hunt matched with Harry Rimalower on Bumble, they went out to a bar — Mr. Rimalower’s first date since his separation.
lead_paragraph: Harry Tomás Rimalower was riding out a perfect storm on Dec. 18, 2022, when he matched with Margaret Anne Hunt on the dating app Bumble.

headline: My Relationships Have No Clothes
abstract: I have no moral objection to infidelity. For me, sex is just sex.
lead_paragraph: He and I had been friends in graduate school in New Orleans for seven months when we had sex for the first time. He was engaged at the time to someone else who lived in a different state. It was Mardi Gras, and the attraction he and I had for each other, combined with multiple beers, had exploded into consensual and sloppy intercourse.

headline: A Psychedelic Trip Leads to a ‘Cosmic and Divine’ Celebration of Love
abstract: Josh Radnor, the star of “How I Met Your Mother,” and Jordana Jacobs, a psychologist in Brooklyn, met while exploring the far reaches of consciousness and later said “I do” in a winter storm.
lead_paragraph: Josh Radnor and Jordana Jacobs were married outdoors this month, amid a snowstorm, with their 164 snow-drenched guests shivering in the 20-degree evening air, as Dr. Jacobs read a 10-minute monologue about her beloved, and Mr. Radnor responded with a 10-minute soliloquy.

headline: Macron Shifts Rightward, and Charts a New Course
abstract: With a decisive turn toward youth and conservative ideas, the French president sets a path for his reshuffled government.
lead_paragraph: The political ideology known as “Macronism” has always been about action, even agitation, at least in verbal form. Emmanuel Macron burst onto the scene in 2017 promising a “revolution.” Since then, over more than six years as France’s president, he has embraced a “refoundation” and renamed his political party “Renaissance.” Now, he’s calling for civic “rearmament.”

headline: Taiwan’s Democracy Draws Envy and Tears for Visiting Chinese
abstract: People with personal ties to China, on a tour to see Taiwan’s election up close, learned of the island’s path to democracy — messy, violent and, ultimately, inspiring.
lead_paragraph: At the Taipei train station, a Chinese human rights activist named Cuicui watched with envy as six young Taiwanese politicians campaigned for the city’s legislative seats. A decade ago, they had been involved in parallel democratic protest movements — she in China, and the politicians on the opposite side of the Taiwan Strait.

headline: Israeli Women Fight on Front Line in Gaza, a First
abstract: After a long struggle for acceptance, Israel’s female combat soldiers are pushing new boundaries after rushing into battle on Oct. 7.
lead_paragraph: When Capt. Amit Busi gets a chance to sleep, she does so with her boots on — and in a shared tent in an improvised Israeli military post in northern Gaza.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, appeared to rule out a postwar peace process that would lead to the establishment of a sovereign Palestinian state, rebuffing calls from the U.S. to start working toward that ultimate goal. He vowed not to compromise on the goal of “total victory” over Hamas and urged the public to prepare for long months of fighting.

headline: Prosecutors Seek 6-Month Prison Term for Peter Navarro in Contempt Case
abstract: Mr. Navarro would be the second Trump official to be sentenced for stonewalling Congress in its Jan. 6 investigation.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors asked on Thursday night for a sentence of six months in prison for Peter Navarro, a former White House adviser to President Donald J. Trump, for defying a subpoena from the House committee that investigated the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

headline: Word of the Day: kowtow
abstract: This word has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word kowtow has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 16 in “Every Star Wants a Documentary Now. But Is It Just P.R.?” by Calum Marsh:

headline: Late Night Chides Donald Trump for a Lack of Self-Control
abstract: “He can’t even control an umbrella,” Seth Meyers said of the former president on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
