headline: How Biden’s Immigration Fight Threatens His Biggest Foreign Policy Win
abstract: The debate over immigration in the United States is spilling over into other parts of President Biden’s agenda, particularly the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The soaring number of people crossing into the United States from Mexico has been a political vulnerability for President Biden for the past three years, chipping away at his approval rating and opening him up to political attacks.

headline: Happy Puppy
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, inspired by this A.I.-generated image of a delighted dog.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this A.I.-created illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: A Moonshot Plan to Fill a Cavernous, Dilapidated Armory in the Bronx
abstract: It was supposed to be a mall, then ice rinks. Nearly 30 years later, a community group may have the best shot at revitalizing a fortress in New York’s poorest borough.
lead_paragraph: It has been called the world’s largest armory — a palatial fortress in the middle of the northwest Bronx, with turrets overlooking the subway station.

headline: A Map Without Israel Plunges a Grade School Into a Political Firestorm
abstract: A social media post invited attacks on an Arabic arts teacher in Brooklyn. Parents say the backlash went too far.
lead_paragraph: A cherished tradition at Public School 261 in Boerum Hill, the heart of gentrified Brooklyn, is the annual march to Borough Hall in honor of Martin Luther King’s Birthday. Children prepare for weeks, making signs denouncing racism, homophobia, climate upheaval and other expressions of social and ecological pox. So the disappointment was pervasive this year, when the march was canceled and replaced by an assembly in the cafeteria.

headline: In No Position to Fight a War, Pakistan Seeks an Off-Ramp With Iran
abstract: For two years, Pakistan has struggled with economic and political crises, an increase in militant attacks and souring relations with another neighbor, Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: When Iran and Pakistan traded airstrikes this week, both targeting what they said were militant camps, the exchange raised fears that the upheaval sweeping the Middle East was moving into new territory.

headline: Audiobook of the Week: Two Broadway Stars Look Back on ‘Summer, 1976’
abstract: Laura Linney and Jessica Hecht bring David Auburn’s nostalgic play about an unlikely friendship straight to your ears.
lead_paragraph: Plays do not ordinarily lend themselves well to audiobooks. To sieve only the sound of a performance is to miss out on a world of visual and atmospheric cues, from body language to lighting to set design, not to mention audience reaction. Yet audio turns out to be the ideal way to experience “Summer, 1976,” a memory play by David Auburn that opened earlier this year at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater in New York.

headline: A Death-Haunted First Novel Incandescent With Life
abstract: In “Martyr!,” the poet Kaveh Akbar turns a grieving young man’s search for meaning into a piercing family saga.
lead_paragraph: Cyrus Shams, the aching protagonist at the heart of Kaveh Akbar’s incandescent first novel, is a veritable Rushdiean multitude: an Iranian-born American, a “bad” immigrant, a recovering addict, a straight-passing queer, an almost-30 poet who rarely writes, an orphan, a runner of open mics, an indefatigable logophile, a fiery wit, a self-pitying malcontent. But above all else Cyrus is sad; profoundly, inconsolably, suicidally sad.

headline: What Drives Kaveh Akbar? The Responsibility of Survival
abstract: Akbar had a raging addiction and little reason to believe his life would turn out well. Now he has a debut novel, “Martyr!,” which makes you want to “get up and yell.”
lead_paragraph: When Kaveh Akbar was drinking, he would regularly wake up to find new bruises or gashes on his body, or to find that he’d lost his glasses, his wallet or his car. When he opened his eyes, he might find himself in an alley instead of in his apartment. Once, he got out of bed and realized he couldn’t walk. He had broken his pelvis. There was nothing in his life at the time, he said, to indicate it would turn out terribly well.

headline: Designing a Child’s Room? Start With a Good Storage Plan.
abstract: Most children have a lot of stuff, and they aren’t always inclined to tidy it up. Here’s how to embrace the abundance — and create tools to manage it.
lead_paragraph: Susana Simonpietri, the creative director of Chango & Co., an interior design firm in Brooklyn, often electrifies social media by posting photos of children’s rooms. With their eye-catching colors, unexpected patterns and playful elements, it’s hard not to love the spaces she creates.

headline: Train Yourself to Always Show Up
abstract: Every gesture of recognition marries love and humility, vulnerability and sacred responsibility.
lead_paragraph: A somewhat obscure text, about 2,000 years old, has been my unlikely teacher and guide for the past many years, and my north star these last several months, as so many of us have felt as if we’ve been drowning in an ocean of sorrow and helplessness.

headline: Backcountry Skiing Is Booming in the Northeast. But Can It Survive?
abstract: Even as more people take up alpine touring on New England’s trails, winters are getting shorter, ‘weather whiplash’ events are eroding the snowpack and natural snow is becoming less reliable.
lead_paragraph: Early last February, at the Mount Washington Backcountry Ski Festival in New Hampshire, the organizers faced an increasingly common problem: Terrible snow.

headline: Getting Ready for the Worst. Just in Case.
abstract: In an anxious time, courses in wilderness survival and military tactics are thriving.
lead_paragraph: In the chilly dusk on a recent Saturday, nine people were creeping through the California hills. Their faces were painted in shades of green, yellow, brown and black, so that they blended into their surroundings. Moving uphill through thickets of trees, they tried to be silent, as if not to draw the attention of some unseen enemy. They were conscious of every breath, every dry leaf that crunched underfoot, every snapped twig.

headline: The Magic of Olive Oil, Fish and Other Healthy Fats
abstract: Here’s why they’re so good for you, and how to cook with them.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 5 of Well’s Mediterranean Diet Week. Start at the beginning here.

headline: How to (Calmly) Handle Head Lice
abstract: There are easy ways to treat this common scourge among schoolchildren.
lead_paragraph: For a minuscule, relatively harmless pest, the head louse is greatly feared among parents of young children. It’s understandable: Something about creepy crawly bugs that hide in your hair is unsettling. By the time you finish this article, you’ll probably feel phantom tingles on your scalp and a sudden urge to scratch.

headline: The Subversive Act of Photographing Palestinian Life
abstract: The photographer Adam Rouhana documents Palestinians in the face of imagery that often dehumanizes them.
lead_paragraph: In one of my earliest memories, I am sitting in my teta’s (grandmother’s) lap. The scent of ripe figs fills the air with the calm satisfaction of late summer. We’re in the shade of our cool limestone veranda surrounded by the family’s verdant mountain farmland in a village that is now in Israel but to me has always been Palestine.

headline: With Harsh Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Law, Uganda Risks a Health Crisis
abstract: The country had made great progress against H.I.V. Now terrified patients have fled clinics, and experts fear a resurgence.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Uganda’s campaign against H.I.V. was exemplary, slashing the country’s death rate by nearly 90 percent from 1990 to 2019. Now a sweeping law enacted last year, the Anti-Homosexuality Act, threatens to renew the epidemic as L.G.B.T.Q. citizens are denied, or are too afraid to seek out, necessary medical care.

headline: A Woman Who Shows Age Is No Barrier to Talk Show Stardom
abstract: Tetsuko Kuroyanagi has been one of Japan’s best-known entertainers for seven decades. At 90, she’s still going strong.
lead_paragraph: Pushing a walker through a television studio in central Tokyo earlier this week, Tetsuko Kuroyanagi slowly climbed three steps onto a sound stage with the help of an assistant who settled her into a creamy beige Empire armchair.

headline: Why Is There No Effective Anti-Trump Constituency?
abstract: Iowa didn’t reveal anything new. And here’s why the hosts aren’t holding their breath for New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: This week on “Matter of Opinion,” the hosts take apart why Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis can’t seem to form competitive coalitions against Donald Trump, and whether Haley, DeSantis, the Supreme Court “or God himself” can keep the former president from becoming the Republican nominee.

headline: Some States Have Removed Trump From the Ballot. Is This a Good Thing for Democracy?
abstract: Ballot challenges focus on whether Donald Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election make him ineligible to hold the presidency again.
lead_paragraph: The primaries to choose the Republican Party’s nominee for the presidential race are underway. Former President Donald J. Trump already has one important win under his belt: a landslide victory in the Iowa caucuses. The New Hampshire primary is up next.

headline: Johnson’s Big Problem: House Republicans Lack a Governing Majority
abstract: With a tiny margin in the House, right-wing rebels’ defections and Democratic control of the Senate and White House, the G.O.P. has relied on Democrats to head off calamity, sapping its leverage.
lead_paragraph: Republicans may control the House, but when it comes to enacting any significant measure this Congress, it has fallen to Democrats to supply the bulk of the votes.

headline: Is This Really ‘the Worst Time to Buy a Home’?
abstract: Maybe — but it’s not a terrible time to rent.
lead_paragraph: For four years now, the housing market has defied all logic.

headline: Why Wasn’t DeSantis the Guy?
abstract: He combines intensity and action, which might be the source of some of the weirdness that followed him and his campaign.
lead_paragraph: This essay has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: ‘I Have No Idea How This Ends. I’ve Never Seen It So Broken.’
abstract: Thomas Friedman takes stock of the war, over 100 days in.

headline: A Critical Shopper Hits the Runways of Milan
abstract: Our critic went shopping for his fantasy closet.
lead_paragraph: Fashion criticism, if you’re privileged enough to do it, is a pretty cool practice. It brings you into constant contact with creativity and beauty. It allows you to think and write about the ways that what humans choose to put on their bodies affect almost everything about how we move through social and cultural space. Often enough, it’s fun.

headline: Senators Seek Answers From Pentagon on Troops’ Blast Exposure
abstract: Lawmakers from both parties wrote to Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III on Thursday demanding to know what was being done to safeguard troops’ brains from the blasts caused by their own weapons.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of senators is demanding to know what steps the military is taking to protect troops from brain injuries caused by the blasts from firing their own weapons.

headline: An Olympic Champion Goes in Search of a New Identity
abstract: As she prepares to step away from surfing, Carissa Moore confronts a question that many people face when they make a change in life: Who am I if I don’t do this anymore?
lead_paragraph: There is a shelf at Carissa Moore’s home in Honolulu where she keeps her journals. She has carried blank pages around the globe since she was a little girl, scribbling her thoughts and worries and goals as she became one of the best surfers in the world.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including what’s coming to Broadway in the near future.
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including what’s coming to Broadway in the near future.

headline: Spirit Airlines Is on Shaky Footing After Judge Blocks JetBlue Deal
abstract: Some analysts said Spirit might have to find another buyer or seek bankruptcy protection if the airlines’ bid to overturn the ruling fails.
lead_paragraph: Spirit Airlines, once a fast-growing low-cost carrier, is struggling to convince investors that it has a clear path forward after an antitrust ruling blocked the sale of the company to JetBlue Airways.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Jan. 19, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by Geraldine Brooks, Jefferson Cowie, Parini Shroff and more.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by Geraldine Brooks, Jefferson Cowie, Parini Shroff and more.

headline: Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Collars, Captured by Camera
abstract: An exhibit at the Jewish Museum features photos of collars worn by the late Supreme Court justice.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at an exhibition of photographs of the collars that Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg wore. We’ll also look at a Manhattan Democrat whose City Hall hopes were dashed in 2021 but who is now looking into challenging Mayor Eric Adams in 2025.

headline: The A.I. Election, Bitcoin’s Wall Street Debut and TikTok’s Doodad Era
abstract: “Two truly terrible ways to make money this week.”
lead_paragraph: OpenAI has released its plan to fight disinformation in elections in 2024, but will its policies be consequential compared to those of other generative A.I. companies? Then, a watershed moment had crypto fans celebrating for the first time in maybe more than a year. And finally, what one writer’s attempt to sell a used mechanical pencil on TikTok says about how the platform is changing.

headline: Hickory Dickory Dock. It’s Andrew Dice Clay on TikTok.
abstract: In his feed on the app, the stand-up offers to help bewildered passers-by or pose for a photo. It’s an approach to fame and persona that puts his comedy in a new light.
lead_paragraph: The first shot is a crooked view of a sparse Christmas tree on a narrow median in Manhattan traffic. The second is a confused man walking his dog. Then the camera swivels to show us none other than Andrew Dice Clay, tentatively muttering in a “Guys and Dolls” accent, “You wanted a picture in front of the tree with me?”

headline: Trump Just Keeps Doing Appalling Things, and the Ranks of the Disengaged Are Growing
abstract: His return to the center of our politics won’t save the media.
lead_paragraph: In crude material terms, Donald Trump’s presidency benefited the media, with subscriptions, ratings and clicks all soaring. It’s therefore not surprising that lots of people believe his return to the center of our politics will once again generate obsessive interest. “When Trump Wins, So Does the Media,” the center-left writer Matthew Yglesias wrote in October. The Washington Post’s Philip Bump recently predicted that because of Trump’s presidential campaign, “cable news channels may soon see a resurgence.” Even warnings about the manifold ways a second Trump presidency could damage a free press tend to assume that four more years of MAGA pandemonium would be lucrative. The business model behind our ailing industry, wrote George Packer in The Atlantic, “works better with Trump.”

headline: Kali Uchis’ ‘Orquídeas’ Reviewed
abstract: Our critic calls the fourth album from the Colombian American singer “forward looking and delightful.”
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, our chief pop music critic, reviews Kali Uchis’ latest album, “Orquídeas,” which he says has “breezy confidence and sly ingenuity.”

headline: Apple Takes a Humble Approach to Launching Its Newest Device
abstract: The Vision Pro augmented reality device goes on sale Friday. Don’t expect Apple to host a splashy event to promote it.
lead_paragraph: When Apple released the Apple Watch in 2015, it was business as usual for a company whose iPhone updates had become cultural touchstones. Before the watch went on sale, Apple gave early versions of it to celebrities like Beyoncé, featured it in fashion publications like Vogue and streamed a splashy event on the internet trumpeting its features.

headline: Letting Trump Off the Hook Would Change the Shape of History
abstract: Jan. 6 cannot go down the memory hole.
lead_paragraph: After the passage of the first Enforcement Acts, written to protect the civil rights of the formerly enslaved, Congress created a bipartisan committee in 1871 to investigate reports of vigilante violence against freed people and their white allies in the states of the former Confederacy. The next year, the Joint Select Committee to Inquire into the Condition of Affairs in the Late Insurrectionary States released its report, a 13-volume collection of testimony from 600 witnesses, totaling more than 8,000 pages.

headline: Snow Closes Schools as Next Round of Arctic Air Moves East
abstract: Officials warned of slippery commutes, with snow likely from the Midwest to the Northeast on Friday. Frigid temperatures will surge east through Saturday, but warmer weather is on the way.
lead_paragraph: Another blast of Arctic air was roaring across the Midwest on Friday on its way to the eastern United States, where snow was already falling in New York and other areas, some schools were canceled and officials warned of dangerous driving conditions.

headline: Trump’s Colorado Play, a Lunar Failure and a Rental Boom
abstract: Catch up on today’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Fishermen Who Could End Federal Regulation as We Know It
abstract: The Supreme Court is to decide whether to overturn a key precedent on the power of executive agencies.
lead_paragraph: On its surface, the case before the Supreme Court — a dispute brought by fishing crews objecting to a government fee — appears to be routine.

headline: The House Speaker Is Safe (for Now)
abstract: Ultraconservative House members aren’t yet ready to depose Speaker Mike Johnson as they did with Speaker Kevin McCarthy in October.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson yesterday did exactly what got his predecessor fired last year: He pushed through legislation to keep the government open with mainly Democratic votes. So is Johnson about to lose his job?

headline: Boeing Cargo Plane Makes Emergency Landing in Miami After ‘Engine Malfunction’
abstract: The plane, a 747 operated by Atlas Air, was forced to return to Miami International Airport shortly after takeoff on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: A Boeing cargo plane headed for Puerto Rico was diverted back to Miami International Airport shortly after takeoff when an engine failed, according to the Federal Aviation Administration. The episode is another potential setback for Boeing, which has been thrust into the spotlight in recent weeks over quality control concerns.

headline: Israeli Soccer Player in Turkey Removed Over Gaza War Post
abstract: The player, Eden Karzev, was fined and moved to an Israeli team. He is the second Israeli pro this week to run afoul of a Turkish team for displaying pro-Israel messages.
lead_paragraph: A leading Turkish soccer club, Basaksehir, has fined an Israeli player and moved him to a team in Israel over a social media post about hostages held by Hamas in Gaza. It was the second time this week that an Israeli player in Turkey was dismissed over a message related to the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: As Climate Shocks Worsen, U.S. Disaster Agency Tries a New Approach to Aid
abstract: Changes include immediate cash for more evacuees, and more money for temporary housing and for repairing damaged homes.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is overhauling the country’s disaster assistance programs, expanding aid for survivors of hurricanes, wildfires and other catastrophes and making it easier to access.

headline: The World Hasn’t Seen Cicadas Like This Since 1803
abstract: Brood XIX and Brood XIII will both emerge this spring. The last time these bugs showed up at the same time in the United States, Thomas Jefferson was president.
lead_paragraph: The cicadas are coming — and if you’re in the Midwest or the Southeast, they will be more plentiful than ever. Or at least since the Louisiana Purchase.

headline: What Might Happen Next in the Genocide Case Against Israel
abstract: Exploring the role of the International Court of Justice in human rights.
lead_paragraph: Depending on the angle from which you view it, the genocide case against Israel at the International Court of Justice can embody either the promises or the failures of one of the primary aims of the international human rights project: making rights a matter of law, not just of power.

headline: Thailand Imposes Longest-Ever Sentence for Criticizing Royalty
abstract: An activist received 50 years in prison for sharing TV and film content on social media that violated the country’s law against defaming its monarchy.
lead_paragraph: Over two months in 2021, an online clothing vendor shared 27 posts on Facebook that included clips from John Oliver’s “Last Week Tonight,” a Fox animated series, and a BBC documentary. The content was deemed offensive to the monarchy, and this week his sentence was extended, to 50 years in prison.

headline: A Famed Cemetery Is Nearly Full. Can It Reuse Old Graves to Add More Space?
abstract: To lie in the vicinity of Karl Marx is competitive, with graves running upward of $31,000. Highgate Cemetery in London is trying to add more space.
lead_paragraph: In death, as in life, it is expensive to have famous people as your neighbors.

headline: Merrily We Roll (Meatballs) Along
abstract: Making these chimichurri meatballs is just the sort of serial work that delivers an antidote to a week of stress and bother.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I made dinner for 50 last weekend, a giant feast of chicken bog, braised kale and rice, with cornbread and Henley Tuthill’s exceptional brown-butter Rice Krispies treats for dessert. I flew solo in the kitchen all day to bring it to fruition, doing the prep-cook shuffle: dicing vegetables, chicken and kielbasa, stirring roux, measuring out pounds of cornmeal and whisking eggs into milk.

headline: A Consensus Emerges at Davos: Trump Will Win Re-Election
abstract: In private, many business and political leaders at the World Economic Forum say they expect Donald Trump to return to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Publicly, the global business leaders who gathered at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, haven’t wanted to predict the winner of the upcoming U.S. presidential election. The closest they’ve come? Referring to it as a “geopolitical risk.”

headline: A New York Art Debut, a Los Angeles Love Song
abstract: Film, music and scent combine in Cauleen Smith’s immersive ode to her city. Her touchstone is Wanda Coleman, a great poet of L.A.
lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago, the artist and filmmaker Cauleen Smith gathered a bare-bones crew for a guerrilla-style shoot — no permits; the locations half-scouted, half-figured-out on the fly — around the land that she calls her home and her obsession: Los Angeles.

headline: Britain’s Largest Steel Mill to Become Greener, at a Cost of Jobs
abstract: Tata Steel said it would replace blast furnaces with an electric furnace, a move that will cut emissions but also as many as 2,800 jobs.
lead_paragraph: Tata Steel said Friday that it planned to shut down the blast furnaces at Britain’s largest steel mill, in Port Talbot, Wales, and replace them with an electric furnace — a move that would cut carbon emissions but could cost 2,800 jobs.

headline: Map: 5.6-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Colombia
abstract: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

headline: ‘Terce’ Review: How the Other Half Prays, in a Reimagined Mass
abstract: Heather Christian’s latest exploration of the religious sublime is a musical spectacle about the often overlooked “caregivers and makers.”
lead_paragraph: When I’ve had the opportunity, as a wandering Jew, to visit the houses of worship of friends, I’ve never felt much in danger of conversion. But if I did, it would surely be the music that got me.

headline: Even if They Didn’t Apply, Some Students Get College Admission Offers
abstract: “Direct admission” is increasingly being offered to high school seniors who meet minimum academic qualifications. The participating schools are eager for more applicants.
lead_paragraph: Some high school seniors have already received offers of admission to college for the next academic year — even though they didn’t formally apply.

headline: Crypto Funds Have Arrived. But Who Needs Them?
abstract: Fear of missing out isn’t a great reason for investing in the new Bitcoin funds, our columnist says. Plus, Bitcoin may already be hidden in your portfolio.
lead_paragraph: Exchange-traded funds come in many shapes and sizes. Some are plain vanilla, diversified index funds that let you invest in the entire stock and bond markets, and are excellent core holdings for the great majority of people.

headline: Bitcoin E.T.F.s Come With Risks. Here’s What You Should Know.
abstract: Federal regulators have made it easier for everyday investors to buy funds that track the price of Bitcoin, using traditional brokerage accounts. Most financial advisers remain skeptical.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a dozen new investments funds that hold Bitcoin began trading last week, making it easier for anyone with a basic brokerage account to buy a slice of the digital currency.

headline: The Best Books About California
abstract: We’re adding to the catalog in our California Reading List, with entries from Octavia Butler, Joan Didion and Nathanael West.
lead_paragraph: Looking for your next absorbing read? We’re here to help.

headline: What’s in the New Tax Deal?
abstract: Budget watchdogs warn that temporary changes to the tax code that are being debated on Capitol Hill will lead to more deficits in the long run.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers on the House Ways and Means Committee achieved a feat on Friday after debating something that rarely comes together in an election year: bipartisan tax legislation.

headline: Ukraine Targets Russian Oil Plants, Aiming to Disrupt Military Operations
abstract: Kyiv hit an oil depot on Friday, the latest in recent attacks on such facilities as it seeks to inflict damage away from the largely deadlocked front line.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine hit an oil depot in Russia in a drone attack on Friday, officials on both sides said, the latest in a series of recent assaults targeting Russian oil facilities as Kyiv increasingly seeks to strike critical infrastructure behind Russian lines.

headline: Investors Pull Billions From Sustainable Funds Amid Political Heat
abstract: A new report showed that $13 billion was withdrawn last year from funds that invest in companies with environmental, social and governance principles.
lead_paragraph: The money flowing out of funds that invest in companies with environmental, social and governance principles has gone from a trickle to a torrent as investors sour on a sector hit by green-washing concerns, red-state boycotts and boardroom debates.

headline: Often Rumored Dead, Sudanese General Takes a Victory Tour
abstract: Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan was greeted by African leaders as if he had already won Sudan’s civil war. His forces have secretly been armed by the United Arab Emirates, an as-yet unpublished U.N. report found.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gen. Mohamed Hamdan, the leader of a notorious paramilitary force fighting for supremacy in Sudan’s civil war, is not the president of his country. Yet on a recent whirlwind tour of six African nations, he was treated just like one.

headline: Families Head to Guantánamo Bay Seeking Justice in Bali Bombing Case
abstract: Relatives of victims of the 2002 attack are expected to describe their loss to a U.S. military jury sentencing two Malaysian prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Frank Heffernan thought his daughter Megan was in South Korea where she was working as an English teacher when he heard the news of a devastating terrorist attack on the Indonesian island of Bali on Oct. 12, 2002.

headline: What Are We So Afraid Of? Here’s the Expert to Ask.
abstract: Christopher Bader studies Americans’ prevailing fears. If you guessed “clowns,” you’re not entirely wrong.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Bader is a sociologist at Chapman University in Orange, Calif., where he has three times been the principal investigator on the annual Chapman Survey of American Fears. The survey asks adults about dozens of topics, such as nuclear war, pollution, volcanic eruptions and zombies, and then ranks the terrors in order of prevalence. Dr. Bader also studies religion and conspiracy theories, and he finds these big issues often intersect. The most recent survey was published in October 2023. In an interview that has been edited and condensed for clarity, he discussed the latest findings.

headline: Boeing Cargo Plane Makes Emergency Landing in Miami
abstract: The Boeing 747-8 cargo plane was headed for Puerto Rico when it was diverted back to Miami because of an “engine malfunction.”
lead_paragraph: The Boeing 747-8 cargo plane was headed for Puerto Rico when it was diverted back to Miami because of an “engine malfunction.”

headline: Biden Cancels Another $5 Billion in Student Loan Debt
abstract: Most of the borrowers who will benefit from the latest wave of relief are teachers, nurses, firefighters and others in public service.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Friday canceled nearly $5 billion in student loan debt for 74,000 people, the latest effort by the administration to deliver piecemeal relief after the Supreme Court struck down Mr. Biden’s more ambitious loan cancellation plan last year.

headline: Making Changes to U.S. Immigration Policy
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay suggesting ways to fix the immigration crisis. Also: Aid to Ukraine; Nikki Haley and the Confederate flag; Botox.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Time loops, twins, twists and trysts in this month’s collection of sci-fi picks.
lead_paragraph: We are in the near future and the European space agency is preparing to launch a mission that will last years if not decades — a length that means filling it with a young crew. Teenage twins Lázaro (Pablo Cobo) and Tristán (Louis Peres) are training together for spots in the program. They are equally dedicated, but the confident Tristán is doing just a little better than his brother. Just as you settle for “Space Academy: The Early Years,” director Edouard Salier makes a sharp turn.

headline: America Stares Down a Trump-Biden Repeat in Disbelief and Denial
abstract: Unable to fathom a 2020 rematch, many Americans are clinging to forlorn hopes and floating wild theories — including that Michelle Obama might replace President Biden.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is cruising to the Democratic nomination. Former President Donald J. Trump could begin to wrap up his party’s nod within days.

headline: A Message From the Premier League’s Rules-Free Future
abstract: Clubs of all sizes complain about cost-control rules and their implementation. But what would soccer look like if they went away?
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2025, after Manchester City’s acquittal via appeal on 115 charges of breaching the Premier League’s financial regulations, the league’s clubs voted to abolish their discredited Profit and Sustainability Rules, the set of guidelines created years earlier in the failed hope they might prevent teams from spending themselves — and everyone else — into ruin.

headline: Test Yourself: Which Faces Were Made by A.I.?
abstract: People tend to overestimate their ability to spot digital fakes, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: People tend to overestimate their ability to spot digital fakes, researchers found.

headline: Ron DeSantis Is Quietly Starting to Build His Off-Ramp From 2024
abstract: Mr. DeSantis praised Donald J. Trump’s victory in Iowa. He admitted to an early strategic error. And he’s begun casting his eyes forward to 2028.
lead_paragraph: After a humbling loss in Iowa, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is starting to signal that he is building an off-ramp from the race for the Republican presidential nomination, a seeming acknowledgment of his dim prospects of defeating Donald J. Trump given his low poll numbers in New Hampshire and South Carolina.

headline: An Elastic and Impressive Moment in Jazz
abstract: A rundown of impressive recent releases and a look at who benefits (and suffers) when artists working outside formal jazz idioms are lumped into conversations about the genre.
lead_paragraph: There was much to celebrate in jazz this past year — great new albums from Meshell Ndegeocello, Ambrose Akinmusire and Immanuel Wilkins; outstanding live performances by Cecile McLorin Salvant and Brandon Woody. It was also a year of reflection, following the passing of Wayne Shorter, Ahmad Jamal, Jaimie Branch, Les McCann and others.

headline: The Farmers Had What the Billionaires Wanted
abstract: In Solano County, Calif., a who’s who of tech money is trying to build a city from the ground up. But some of the locals whose families have been there for generations don’t want to sell the land.
lead_paragraph: When Jan Sramek walked into the American Legion post in Rio Vista, Calif., for a town-hall meeting last month, everyone in the room knew that he was really just there to get yelled at.

headline: Abortion Opponents March in Washington, With Obstacles Ahead
abstract: A year after celebrating the reversal of Roe v. Wade, the annual March for Life gathered Friday in a very different political climate.
lead_paragraph: Last year, anti-abortion activists descended on the National Mall in triumph for the annual March for Life, eager to enter a new era for their ambitions to end abortion following the reversal of Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court ruling that established federal abortion rights.

headline: A Reporter at The New York Times, a Child at Heart
abstract: Laurel Graeber, who has covered kids’ entertainment at The Times for nearly three decades, shared her favorite stories and interviews from the beat.
lead_paragraph: Laurel Graeber grew up loving the theater and museums. But she never thought she would write about them for The New York Times — or that she would do so for nearly three decades.

headline: ‘Ferrari’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director Michael Mann narrates a sequence from his film starring Adam Driver.
lead_paragraph: The director Michael Mann narrates a sequence from his film starring Adam Driver.

headline: Watch Adam Driver Keep Time in a Scene From ‘Ferrari’
abstract: The director Michael Mann narrates a sequence from his biopic about Enzo Ferrari.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: With Andrew Yang in Tow, Dean Phillips Finally Draws a Crowd
abstract: Mr. Phillips is mounting a long-shot Democratic primary challenge against President Biden, whose supporters are doing a write-in campaign in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: For Representative Dean Phillips, challenging President Biden in the Democratic primary race has produced some humbling moments, like when he failed to draw a single voter to a meet-and-greet this month.

headline: ‘American Fiction,’ ‘Origin’ and the Pressures Black Writers Face
abstract: The movies explore what happens when authors who focus exclusively on racism in their work push back against political and commercial stresses.
lead_paragraph: “We younger Negro artists who create now intend to express our individual dark-skinned selves without fear or shame,” a young Langston Hughes proclaimed in an essay nearly 100 years ago. “If white people are pleased we are glad. If they are not, it doesn’t matter.”

headline: ‘The Woman in the Wall’ Review: Searching for a Daughter Taken by Nuns
abstract: Ruth Wilson plays an Irish woman with a case against the Catholic church in an ecclesiastical thriller that’s also a murder mystery.
lead_paragraph: On a road in the beautifully desolate Irish countryside, a passing steer stops to nose at the object in its path. It’s a sleeping woman whose white nightshirt is stained with blood. Jarred awake by the animal, she leaps to her feet in alarm and strides barefoot toward her village. A title tells us that it is 2015.

headline: Netanyahu Is Turning Against Biden
abstract: Israel has been at war with Hamas for over 100 days and still has over 100 hostages to recover, but Netanyahu’s No. 1 focus is Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: It looks as if President Biden will be running in two races this year: one in America against Donald Trump and one in Israel against Benjamin Netanyahu. Maybe Trump could name Netanyahu his running mate and we could save a lot of time. Biden’s support for the Israeli leader is costing him with his own progressive base, while Netanyahu is now turning on Biden in ways that could win Trump fresh support from right-wing American Jews. Trump-Netanyahu 2024 — that has a certain ring to it, not to mention an air of truth.

headline: Garland Says Justice Department Cases Are Not Political and Urges a ‘Speedy Trial’
abstract: “What we have to do is show by the acts that we take that we’re following the law, that we’re following the facts,” said Attorney General Merrick B. Garland.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Thursday defended the Justice Department against accusations that the federal cases against Donald J. Trump, which were brought by a special prosecutor, Jack Smith, were politically motivated.

headline: Tim Scott, the Former G.O.P. Presidential Contender, Will Back Donald Trump
abstract: The former president and his allies had been privately courting Mr. Scott, hoping to win his endorsement before the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina will endorse Donald J. Trump on Friday evening at a rally in New Hampshire, according to two people briefed on the matter.

headline: Japan Becomes the Latest Country to Land on the Moon
abstract: The SLIM spacecraft made a successful soft landing on the lunar surface, but a problem with its solar panels means it will soon run out of power.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese robotic spacecraft successfully set down on the moon on Friday — but its solar panels were not generating power, which will cut the length of time it will be able to operate to a few hours.

headline: Dolly Parton Covers Billy Joel, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Mumford & Sons and Pharrell Williams, Julian Lage, feeo and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes), and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: German Lawmakers Agree to Ease Path to Citizenship
abstract: Proponents say the reforms will draw more skilled workers to the country, but that opponents warn the legislation will lessen the value of German nationality.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in Berlin approved legislation allowing shorter waiting periods before naturalization and the possibility of dual citizenship, ushering in changes that proponents say will draw more skilled workers to the country and that opponents warn will lessen the value of German citizenship.

headline: The Big Number: 5.2%
abstract: While China’s economy may seem to be booming, the reality is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: While China’s economy may seem to be booming, the reality is more complicated.

headline: Annie Nightingale, Pathbreaking British D.J., Is Dead at 83
abstract: She was initially told there was no room for her on BBC Radio 1 because a woman’s voice lacked the authority of a man’s. Once she was on the air, she stayed there for 53 years.
lead_paragraph: Annie Nightingale, who became the first female disc jockey on BBC Radio 1 in 1970 and remained a popular personality there until her final show, late last year, died on Jan. 11 at her home in London. She was 83.

headline: ‘Our Class’ Review: A Town’s Horrific Past Chillingly Brought Into the Light
abstract: The story of a 1941 massacre is told through the lives of 10 Polish classmates, five Jewish and five Catholic, in this suspenseful but humane play.
lead_paragraph: A simple staging idea can have a devastating affect.

headline: Jack Burke Jr., Who Won 2 Major Golf Titles in a Season, Dies at 100
abstract: A top professional in the postwar years, he won the Masters and the P.G.A. championships in 1956. At his death he was the oldest living champion of both.
lead_paragraph: Jack Burke Jr., a top player on the P.G.A. tour in the postwar years who won two major golf championships in one season, then became a sought-after instructor to some of the game’s greatest stars, died on Friday in Houston. He was 100 and the oldest living winner of the Masters and P.G.A. championships.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The hosts returned from the long weekend to news that Trump had a sweeping victory at the Iowa Republican caucus. They also discussed Vivek Ramaswamy dropping out of the presidential race and an odd bill introduced in Kentucky.
lead_paragraph: The hosts returned from the long weekend to news that Trump had a sweeping victory at the Iowa Republican caucus. They also discussed Vivek Ramaswamy dropping out of the presidential race and an odd bill introduced in Kentucky.

headline: 15 Books Coming Soon to a Shelf Near You
abstract: The next few months look promising for readers. Here are some of the forthcoming titles that Book Review editors are excited about.
lead_paragraph: Publishers often save their biggest books for the fall season — but not always. With a presidential election on the horizon driving fears that readers will be too distracted to buy books then, the spring 2024 publishing calendar is more crowded than usual. On this week’s episode, Gilbert Cruz talks with his colleagues Tina Jordan and Joumana Khatib about some of the upcoming books they’re anticipating most keenly, including new work from Salman Rushdie, Percival Everett, Tana French and Erik Larson, among others, and buzzy debuts from Kelly Link, Kaveh Akbar and more.

headline: Biden Presses Netanyahu on Working Toward a Palestinian State
abstract: The two leaders spoke for the first time in weeks. Their call came a day after the Israeli leader rebuffed U.S. efforts to pressure him into a two-state solution.
lead_paragraph: President Biden pressed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Friday to agree to the creation of a Palestinian state after the war in Gaza is over and raised options that would limit Palestinian sovereignty to make the prospect more palatable to Israel.

headline: Prince Harry Withdraws Libel Claim Against Mail on Sunday Publisher
abstract: The prince had been suing Associated Newspapers over a 2022 article suggesting he misled the public over his security arrangements, claiming it was defamatory.
lead_paragraph: Barely a month after winning a landmark phone-hacking lawsuit against a British publisher, Prince Harry on Friday withdrew an unrelated libel suit against the publisher of another tabloid paper, The Mail on Sunday.

headline: Sports Illustrated Thrown Into Chaos With Mass Layoffs
abstract: The announcement on Friday left in doubt what lies ahead for the venerable publication, with some staff members dismissed immediately and others told they would keep their jobs for at least 90 days.
lead_paragraph: Sports Illustrated, the venerable bible of sports journalism, has been in decline for years, as the internet annihilated print magazines and cost-cutting turned the weekly publication into a monthly and whittled its staff. But on Friday, the magazine received perhaps its toughest blow yet.

headline: Istanbul Biennial Postponed as Lead Curator Resigns
abstract: The event was shunted to 2025 after a furor over the way its artistic leader was appointed made staging the exhibition this year “impossible,” the organizers said.
lead_paragraph: The Istanbul Biennial, one of the European art world’s major events, was thrown into disarray on Friday when its lead curator stepped down and the event was postponed until 2025.

headline: Maine Secretary of State to Appeal Ruling on Her Decision to Exclude Trump From Ballot
abstract: Shenna Bellows said she intended to appeal the ruling by a state Superior Court judge that placed on hold her decision to exclude Donald Trump from the Republican primary ballot.
lead_paragraph: Maine’s top election official said on Friday she intended to appeal the ruling by a state Superior Court judge this week that placed on hold her decision to exclude former President Donald J. Trump from the state’s Republican primary ballot.

headline: The Trick to the Fluffiest Muffins May Already Be in Your Kitchen
abstract: Creamy yogurt makes lemon blueberry muffins the airy, tender treat you need this winter.
lead_paragraph: As winter set in this January, Sarah Kieffer recalled how it snowed for eight months last year in her hometown, Minneapolis. For weeks on end, the temperature dipped below minus 20. Surrounded by grayness, she baked blueberry muffins for the cheer of their bright pops of blue.

headline: Republicans Predict Turnout in New Hampshire’s Primary Could Set a Record
abstract: The previous G.O.P. record of about 285,000 votes was set in the 2016 Republican primary, when Donald J. Trump defeated a crowded field.
lead_paragraph: Republicans are predicting that Tuesday’s vote in New Hampshire could break primary turnout records in the state, as former President Donald J. Trump seeks another strong showing against his rivals, Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis.

headline: Sleater-Kinney’s 10 (or Actually 11) Best Songs
abstract: As the band’s 11th album arrives, listen back through the strongest moments in its catalog.
lead_paragraph: I first heard the band Sleater-Kinney when I was a teenager, and it’s not an exaggeration to say it changed my life. The early 2000s were a particularly macho time in rock music — all wounded emo boys and nü-metal aggressors — and even in the late ’90s it was difficult to find female musicians lauded for how well they played their instruments rather than the way they looked. Then I happened upon a live recording of Sleater-Kinney playing its 1997 song “Words and Guitar,” and it blew my hair back like I’d entered a wind tunnel.

headline: The Roots of Trump Nostalgia
abstract: Why Joe Biden’s problem is bigger than just fatigue with anti-Trumpism.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait has a long lament in New York magazine about the diminishing intensity of anti-Trump politics in America. Even as the former president shoulders his way toward the Republican nomination and leads President Biden in many polls, Chait frets that “the imperative to keep Trump out of the Oval Office has become tiresome.” Indeed, a kind of “exhaustion” with anti-Trumpism, Chait writes, “may be the most dominant attribute of our national mood.”

headline: In Davos, Israel’s Hostages Get a Hearing
abstract: “I say a Jewish prayer and ask: ‘Let today be the day,’” says the mother of a hostage.
lead_paragraph: The annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is largely an opportunity for the powerful to mingle with the even more powerful. For the most part, I’ve spent my time here listening to government leaders — Iran’s foreign minister struck me as an exceptionally talented dissembler — and schmoozing with business leaders, think tankers and officials at Davos’s famous private dinners and after-parties.

headline: French Police Officer Convicted in High-Profile Abuse Case
abstract: Théo Luhaka, who was 22 at the time of the incident, sustained serious injuries when the police subdued him while conducting identity checks in a suburb northeast of Paris.
lead_paragraph: A police officer who brutalized a 22-year-old Black man with an expandable baton during an arrest nearly seven years ago was convicted by a French court on Friday of “intentional violence” in one of the country’s highest-profile cases of abuse by the police.

headline: Biden Signs Stopgap Spending Bill, Averting Partial Shutdown
abstract: The legislation will fund agencies until early March as Congress continues to negotiate funding for the government through the fall.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed legislation on Friday averting a partial government shutdown, which will fund agencies until early March as Congress continues to wrangle over spending proposals to fund the government for the remainder of the year.

headline: Credit Card Statements Suggest Prosecutors in Trump Case Traveled Together
abstract: Records included in a court filing follow claims that Fani T. Willis had begun a relationship with Nathan Wade before hiring him to help lead the Trump case.
lead_paragraph: The estranged wife of a special prosecutor accused of having a romantic relationship with Fani T. Willis, the Atlanta district attorney who hired him, offered evidence on Friday that Ms. Willis accompanied him on trips unrelated to their work: leading the Georgia case against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Alec Baldwin Is Charged, Again, With Involuntary Manslaughter
abstract: A grand jury in New Mexico indicted the actor in the shooting death of the cinematographer on the film “Rust,” months after the original case against him was dismissed.
lead_paragraph: A grand jury in New Mexico indicted Alec Baldwin on Friday on a charge of involuntary manslaughter, reviving the criminal case against him in the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust” more than two years ago when a gun he was rehearsing with went off.

headline: The U.S. Strikes More Houthi Sites in Yemen
abstract: The strikes, the sixth round in 10 days, targeted Houthi missiles that were poised to attack merchant and military vessels in the Red Sea, according to a White House official.
lead_paragraph: For the sixth time in 10 days, the United States on Friday said it had destroyed Houthi missiles in Yemen that were poised to attack merchant and military vessels in the Red Sea, a pattern of strikes that the White House says will continue for the foreseeable future to weaken the militia group.

headline: With Deal Close on Border and Ukraine, Republican Rifts Threaten to Kill Both
abstract: A divided G.O.P. coalesced behind a bit of legislative extortion: No Ukraine aid without a border crackdown. Now they are split over how large a price to demand, imperiling both initiatives.
lead_paragraph: Senator James Lankford, the Oklahoma Republican and staunch conservative, this week trumpeted the immigration compromise he has been negotiating with Senate Democrats and White House officials as one shaping up to be “by far, the most conservative border security bill in four decades.”

headline: Robert Rosenthal, Who Linked Subtle Cues to Behavior, Dies at 90
abstract: His most famous finding was the “Pygmalion effect,” in which teachers’ high expectations of students can subconsciously make them better students.
lead_paragraph: Robert Rosenthal, a psychologist renowned as an expert in nonverbal communication, and in particular what he called the “self-fulfilling prophecies” in which subtle, often unconscious, gestures can influence behavior, died on Jan. 5 in Riverside, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Can Elon Musk Really Do That?
abstract: His demand to own 25 percent of Tesla’s shares is a fascinating stress test of corporate governance.
lead_paragraph: Angela Aneiros, an assistant professor at Gonzaga University School of Law in Spokane, Wash., can’t get enough of Elon Musk.

headline: Mayor Adams Vetoes Police Transparency and Solitary Confinement Bills
abstract: The New York City Council is likely to override the mayor’s vetoes despite his objections and fervent campaign to have the bills rescinded.
lead_paragraph: After a failed and unusually protracted effort to convince the New York City Council to rescind a bill requiring the police to document more of their interactions with the public, Mayor Eric Adams vetoed the legislation Friday, arguing that it would harm public safety.

headline: You May Want to Replace These Household Essentials
abstract: It's probably time.
lead_paragraph: It's probably time.

headline: May Someone in A.A. Write About Others in Her Group?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on upholding rules of discretion in a recovery community.
lead_paragraph: We have a writing group whose members share their fiction and nonfiction with one another. One of our members attends Alcoholics Anonymous meetings and has begun to write about others who attend. She does not mention their names, but the descriptions of the members include profession, physical appearance, hobbies and other specifics that might identify them. She has not mentioned to these people that she is writing about them and does not plan to, but she would like to publish her stories for the general public. She has a degree in creative writing and notes that well-known authors have written about members of their A.A. groups, e.g. Raymond Carver. What are the ethics of writing about others in a substance-abuse support group without their consent? — Name Withheld

headline: 11-Month-Old Boy Dies After Being Burned by Steam From Radiator
abstract: Officers found the child unconscious inside a bedroom at a Brooklyn apartment building early Friday, officials said.
lead_paragraph: An 11-month-old boy died Friday morning after being burned by steam that leaked from a radiator in a bedroom at a Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Travel trends in 2024. Also, we look at pollution in space and a whale who went AWOL.

headline: Menachem Daum, 77, Filmmaker Who Explored the World of Hasidim, Dies
abstract: His acclaimed documentary “A Life Apart” presented a complex portrait of a religious group usually depicted as somber and impenetrable.
lead_paragraph: Menachem Daum, a filmmaker who co-produced a groundbreaking 1997 documentary that illuminated the cloistered world of America’s Hasidim, died on Jan. 7 in a hospital near his home in Borough Park, Brooklyn. He was 77.

headline: Stocks Climb to Record, Lifted by Big Tech and Rate Cut Hopes
abstract: The S&P 500 crossed above its January 2022 peak after weeks of wavering. Investors have been buying stocks after homing in on signals that the Fed’s campaign of raising interest rates is over.
lead_paragraph: The stock market broke through to new heights on Friday, with the S&P 500 index finally hitting a record after weeks of bumping up against its previous peak.

headline: Stocks Are in a Bull Market. What Does That Mean?
abstract: It doesn’t mean stocks will continue to rise indefinitely, but it does reflect a generally optimistic outlook on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: The S&P 500 index closed at a record on Friday, crossing above its old high-water mark, set in early 2022. The gains show that investors have overcome fears of rising interest rates and panic about a recession that had governed stock trading for much of the past two years.

headline: Sundance Diary: Buoy Meets Satellite
abstract: An unusual triple feature covered lonely machines, sasquatches, and a trope about Black characters. Sometimes it worked; sometimes not so much.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to movies, we live in a high-concept world. Whether you’re a Marvel movie or a microbudget indie, you’ve got to sell moviegoers on a premise that can cut through the content and get them into a theater.

headline: Overlooked No More: Beatrix Potter, Author of ‘The Tale of Peter Rabbit’
abstract: She created one of the world’s best-known characters for children, and fought to have the book published, but she never sought celebrity status.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Smart Watches in the Bedroom
abstract: This husband thinks there is no situation where tracking his vitals isn’t appropriate.
lead_paragraph: Katie writes: I am seeking an order to prohibit my husband from wearing his smart watch during adult activities. I find it just as egregious as wearing one with formal wear. My husband thinks there is no situation where a smart watch isn’t appropriate.

headline: Louisiana Lawmakers Approve Map That Empowers More Black Voters
abstract: The Legislature passed a congressional map that creates a second majority-Black district while shielding the state’s most powerful conservatives in Washington from political jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana lawmakers on Friday approved a new congressional map that would create a second district with a majority of Black voters, after a federal court found that the existing map appeared to illegally undercut the power of Black voters in the state.

headline: Ousted Florida Republican Party Chairman Won’t Be Charged With Sexual Assault
abstract: But the Sarasota Police Department has asked prosecutors to charge the former chairman, Christian Ziegler, with video voyeurism.
lead_paragraph: The former chairman of the Republican Party of Florida who was ousted earlier this month amid a criminal investigation will not be charged with sexual battery, the Sarasota Police Department said on Friday. But the authorities will seek to charge him with video voyeurism, a felony.

headline: As a 2024 Rematch Looms, Americans Watch With Disbelief
abstract: Also, the S&P 500 hit a record high. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley began campaigning early this morning, bouncing from town to town across New Hampshire. The state’s Tuesday primary, which allows independent voters to cast ballots, is most likely her best early chance to narrow Donald Trump’s staggering lead and turn the nominating campaign into a two-person race.

headline: Can ‘Electability’ Save Nikki Haley?
abstract: “Don’t you want someone who can win?” she asks in a new ad.
lead_paragraph: A long time ago, in a Republican Party far, far away, a seasoned former governor suggested a theory for winning the 2016 election.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, January 20, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Tanya Berezin, Behind-the-Scenes Off Broadway Force, Is Dead at 82
abstract: At the Circle Repertory Company, where she said her goal was to “confuse people,” she nurtured a new generation of writers and actors in the 1980s and ’90s.
lead_paragraph: By the mid-1980s, Tanya Berezin had gone far as a New York stage actress. She had collected glowing reviews for her Off Broadway performances over the years, and she had won an Obie Award for her role in Lanford Wilson’s play “The Mound Builders” in 1975.

headline: Someone Filled the Chicago Rat Hole. Residents Took Action.
abstract: After the rodent-shaped hole, which had delighted residents for weeks, was plugged with plaster or concrete, residents braved the bitter cold to dig it out.
lead_paragraph: Where have you gone, Chicago rat hole? Our nation turns its lonely eyes to you.

headline: L.A. Innocence Project Takes Up Scott Peterson’s Case
abstract: The organization, which examines possible wrongful convictions, said it was investigating a claim of innocence by Mr. Peterson, who was convicted of murdering his wife, Laci Peterson, and unborn son.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Innocence Project, a nonprofit organization that works to overturn wrongful convictions, filed documents in court this week to re-examine the case of Scott Peterson, who is serving a life sentence in a California prison for the murders of his pregnant wife, Laci Peterson, and their unborn son in 2002.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Tom Friedman
abstract: The Jan. 19, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Tom Friedman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Divisions Emerging in Israel Over Gaza War
abstract: Protesters demanded action to free hostages, a war cabinet minister criticized the military campaign and the Israeli prime minister publicly ruled out a two-state solution, rebuffing the U.S.
lead_paragraph: After nearly 15 weeks of war, sharp divisions within Israel over the path forward in the Gaza Strip are increasingly coming into the open.

headline: Quebec Man Pleads Guilty to What He Accused the Government Of: Starting Wildfires
abstract: A man who pleaded guilty to setting 14 fires in 2023 also shared misinformation and conspiracy theories about wildfires and climate change.
lead_paragraph: A Quebec resident who last summer had shared conspiracy theories online suggesting that the Canadian government was deliberately starting wildfires to convince people climate change is happening has now pleaded guilty to setting more than a dozen fires.

headline: Inside CNN, a Debate Over Taking Trump Live
abstract: Tensions over the network’s airing of 10 minutes of the former president’s speech after he won the Iowa caucuses on Monday burst into the open during an internal call.
lead_paragraph: Tensions within CNN over coverage of former President Donald J. Trump burst into the open on Thursday during an internal call with the network’s journalists, as an executive candidly questioned the approach of the channel’s new chief executive, Mark Thompson.

headline: Electric Vehicle Charging Tax Credits Will Be Available in Much of Country
abstract: Biden administration officials opted to make a broad set of locations eligible for the tax credits, covering much of the country outside of major cities.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Friday issued guidance that makes much of the country eligible for tax credits intended to offset the cost of installing electric vehicle chargers.

headline: Sundance Kicks Off With Jodie Foster, Robert Downey Jr. and Kristen Stewart
abstract: At the opening night gala for the film festival, celebrating its 40th edition, actors and filmmakers reflected on what kept them coming back.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, which is celebrating its 40th edition this year, was bustling. Banners hung on snowy Main Street, Leon Bridges was performing at a new music venue and the Eccles Theatre was packed for one of the opening films: “Freaky Tales.”

headline: Trump falsely claims Democrats can vote in New Hampshire’s G.O.P. primary.
abstract: The former president has accused Nikki Haley of relying on “Democrats and liberals” to “infiltrate” the state’s Republican primary next week.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump has falsely and repeatedly suggested in recent days that one of his Republican rivals, Nikki Haley, is counting on Democrats to win the Republican presidential primary in New Hampshire next week. In fact, registered Democrats cannot vote in the state’s Republican primary — though voters who are not affiliated with a party can.

headline: After Uvalde, Challenges Endure for the Police Despite Clear Protocols
abstract: The failures in Texas underscored the challenge of mass shootings for all police officers: Be ready to rapidly use deadly force in some cases, but try to de-escalate in others.
lead_paragraph: In its report this week on the deadly school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, Justice Department officials strongly criticized the local police and issued blunt, unambiguous guidance for the future: Officers must rapidly confront a gunman, even if it costs them their lives.

headline: Microsoft Executives’ Emails Hacked by Group Tied to Russian Intelligence
abstract: The hackers appeared to be trying to learn what the company knew about them, a regulatory filing said.
lead_paragraph: An elite hacking group sponsored by Russian intelligence gained access to the emails of some of Microsoft’s senior executives beginning in late November, the company disclosed in a blog post and regulatory filing on Friday.

headline: A Grand Jury in Uvalde Is Set to Examine Response to School Massacre
abstract: Prosecutors are slated to begin presenting evidence to a panel days after a Justice Department report found that “unimaginable” failures hindered the police response to the shooting.
lead_paragraph: The district attorney in Uvalde, Texas, has said for months that she intended to convene a grand jury to consider evidence from the 2022 shooting at Robb Elementary School, with the possibility that state criminal charges could result over the botched police response to the massacre.

headline: Why DeSantis Says Trump’s Romp in Iowa Is Actually a Sign of His Weakness
abstract: Ron DeSantis said he thought that Donald J. Trump should have done even better in Iowa, given the low turnout.
lead_paragraph: To Donald J. Trump’s campaign, his win in the Iowa caucuses by a record 30-point margin was a sign he would steamroll to the nomination. To hear Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida tell it, the result was actually a sign of the former president’s weakness.

headline: Judge Rebukes F.B.I. and Orders Release of Man in ‘Newburgh Four’ Case
abstract: The judge said James Cromitie, like his co-defendants, should be freed because he had been duped into an “F.B.I.-orchestrated conspiracy” by an “unsavory” informant.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Friday ordered that a New York man be freed from prison because a “most unsavory” government informant had duped him into an “F.B.I.-orchestrated conspiracy” focused on attacking an upstate Air Force base and Jewish sites in the Bronx.

headline: Orlando Museum Drops Legal Claims Against Owners of Fake Basquiats
abstract: In an effort to cut its litigation costs, the museum said it was narrowing its ongoing lawsuit for fraud and conspiracy solely to its former director, Aaron De Groft.
lead_paragraph: The Orlando Museum of Art announced Friday that it was dismissing its legal claims of fraud and conspiracy against five co-owners of paintings who touted them as the creations of the art world legend Jean-Michel Basquiat and lent them for a 2022 exhibition.

headline: Trump Claims Immunity Extends Even to Acts That ‘Cross the Line’
abstract: In a social media post, Donald J. Trump appeared to take a stance that went even further than his lawyers have in court about the scope of immunity from prosecution that a president should enjoy.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Friday night that American presidents deserve complete immunity from prosecution even for acts that “cross the line,” contending for the second time this week that the holder of the nation’s highest office should effectively remain beyond the reach of criminal law.

headline: Disdaining Haley, Trump Says She ‘Probably’ Won’t Be His Running Mate
abstract: The former president said his top rival, Nikki Haley, wasn’t “presidential timber,” after collecting the spirited endorsement of her fellow South Carolinian, Senator Tim Scott.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump intensified his attacks against Nikki Haley on Friday, saying that she was not of presidential caliber and that, as a result, he was unlikely to choose her as his running mate.

headline: ‘Good Goin’!’
abstract: Caitlin Reid and Matthew Stock’s puzzle takes us to the bar.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the first New York Times collaboration between Caitlin Reid and Matthew Stock, a couple of veteran constructors who have graced us with plenty of weekend grids over the last few years. Their cluing is on point here: Most of the difficulties I experienced were because an entry was cleverly concealed rather than actually obscure. Thus, although there are some niche references in the trivia, I think this is a pretty deducible, cozy solve.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 20, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Iran’s links to regional conflicts referred incorrectly to Iran’s nuclear program. Iran has raised the prospect that it could develop nuclear weapons, maintaining that its nuclear program has only peaceful purposes, but it has not developed them.

headline: Quotation of the Day: After 7 Decades of Television Stardom, She’s Ready for 1 More
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t ever say you can’t do anything because you are a woman.”

headline: Fire Kills 13 in a School Dorm in Central China
abstract: The private school is for kindergarten and elementary school pupils. Though many details of the disaster remained unclear, it drew widespread attention on China’s internet.
lead_paragraph: A fire in the dormitory of a kindergarten and elementary school in central China killed 13 people, Chinese state-owned news media reported on Saturday.

headline: Trump Confuses Haley and Pelosi, Accusing Rival of Jan. 6 Lapse
abstract: Donald Trump has often accused former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of failing to provide adequate security for the Capitol. On Friday, he inexplicably substituted Nikki Haley’s name for Ms. Pelosi’s.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Friday appeared to confuse Nikki Haley for Nancy Pelosi during a speech in New Hampshire, accusing Ms. Haley of failing to provide adequate security during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack at the Capitol and connecting her to the House committee that investigated it.

headline: Grooms Look Beyond the Traditional Black Tuxedo
abstract: Some men are ditching standard suit options in favor of more customized looks for their wedding attire.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to wedding outfit shopping, brides seem to get all the attention.

headline: Italian Culture Official Investigated in Stolen Art Case
abstract: Prosecutors believe a painting the deputy culture minister, Vittorio Sgarbi, put on display in 2021 was in fact stolen in 2013. He says it’s a different copy.
lead_paragraph: A deputy culture minister in Italy is under investigation, accused of laundering stolen goods, in particular a Baroque painting that had been reported stolen from a castle in Piedmont, Italy, a decade ago.

headline: Germans Push Back as Far Right’s Influence Grows
abstract: News of a secret meeting among extremists to discuss mass deportations, including of citizens from immigrant backgrounds, has shaken the society.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people have taken to the streets in protest against the far-right party Alternative for Germany, known as AfD, in recent days. Legal scholars are discussing whether the party can be banned. Political leaders are warning of a fundamental threat to society.

headline: Harvard Defends Its Plagiarism Investigation of Its Former President
abstract: The university released its most detailed account of its handling of plagiarism accusations against Claudine Gay, who resigned earlier this month.
lead_paragraph: In a report to a congressional committee, released on Friday, Harvard gave its most detailed account yet of its handling of the plagiarism accusations against Claudine Gay, who resigned this month as the university’s president.

headline: ​Police Chief Is Indicted Over South Korea’s Deadly Crowd Crush
abstract: Kim Kwang-ho, charged with negligence, is one of the most senior officials to face legal consequences for the October 2022 disaster that killed nearly 160 people in Seoul.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in South Korea have indicted the head of the Seoul Metropolitan Police Agency​, charging him with contributing through negligence to the Halloween crowd crush in Seoul in 2022​ that killed nearly 160 people, officials said.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The U.S. Seems to Be Dodging a Recession. What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: Economists have become increasingly optimistic about the odds of a soft landing. But as 2024 begins to unfold, risks remain.
lead_paragraph: With inflation falling, unemployment low and the Federal Reserve signaling it could soon begin cutting interest rates, forecasters are becoming increasingly optimistic that the U.S. economy could avoid a recession.

headline: Taiwan’s Doubts About America Are Growing. That Could Be Dangerous.
abstract: Will deepening skepticism about the United States as a trustworthy nation diminish Taiwan’s belief that it could fend off China?
lead_paragraph: The collection of American memorabilia, vast and well-lit in a busy area of City Hall in the southern Taiwanese city of Tainan, reflected decades of eager courtship. Maps highlighted sister cities in Ohio and Arizona.

headline: The Legal Question at the Center of the Alec Baldwin Criminal Case
abstract: The actor was told the gun he was rehearsing with on the “Rust” set, which fired and killed the cinematographer, held no live ammunition. Can he be found guilty of manslaughter?
lead_paragraph: Now that a grand jury has indicted Alec Baldwin on a charge of involuntary manslaughter for the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust” in New Mexico in 2021, the contours of the looming legal battle are coming into focus.

headline: Congratulations, You’re the Oldest Person in Town! Please Accept This Cane.
abstract: For over a century, towns in New England have presented their oldest residents with ceremonial canes. In some places, the honor endures — for those willing to accept it, that is.

headline: The Lascivious, Decades-Long History Behind That Calvin Klein Ad
abstract: Jeremy Allen White joins the pantheon of underwear gods, balancing heroics with sleaze.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t own me/I’m not just one of your many toys/You don’t own me/Don’t say I can’t go with other boys.” It’s a strange choice to drape this song, Lesley Gore’s ode to female empowerment, over slowed-down footage ogling the actor Jeremy Allen White, whose roles have imbued him with the kind of bad-boy swagger women often associate with their own misspent youth. But in the latest commercial for Calvin Klein’s men’s underwear, Gore smolders as we watch White roll down a Manhattan street, pop up to a rooftop, strip down and ascend, muscles bulging like some half-nude Greek god, to the peak of his own personal Mount Olympus, which in this case is an ugly orange couch.

headline: After Affirmative Action Ban, They Rewrote College Essays With a Key Theme: Race
abstract: The Supreme Court’s ruling intended to remove the consideration of race during the admissions process. So students used their essays to highlight their racial background.
lead_paragraph: Astrid Delgado first wrote her college application essay about a death in her family. Then she reshaped it around a Spanish book she read as a way to connect to her Dominican heritage.

headline: For the Anti-Trump Wing of the G.O.P., It All Comes Down to Tuesday
abstract: The old guard of the Republican Party has rallied around Nikki Haley ahead of New Hampshire’s primary, in a long-shot bid to stop the former president’s march to the nomination.
lead_paragraph: The first-in-the-nation primary could be the last stand for the anti-Trump Republican.

headline: How a Designer of Upcycled Fashion Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Rebecca Chamberlain doesn’t like the waste in the fashion industry, so she turns old clothes into new outfits. But on Sundays, she also makes time for soccer and reading.
lead_paragraph: For many years, Rebecca Chamberlain designed clothes for famous brands, mostly to make ends meet. During the coronavirus pandemic, she started doing it for herself — by turning old garments into modern, sophisticated pieces.

headline: Keeping a Midlife Crisis From Wrecking Your Retirement Plan
abstract: Entering your 40s can throw you into an emotional tailspin — one that may lead you to spend more and jeopardize your nest egg.
lead_paragraph: The midlife crisis is easy to poke fun at — especially if it’s someone else’s.

headline: The N.Y.C. Mayor’s Race Could Test the #MeToo Movement’s Staying Power
abstract: Three potential candidates in the 2025 mayoral race in New York City have been accused of sexual misconduct. Voters are weighing the details of each case.
lead_paragraph: Roughly six years ago, as the #MeToo movement gathered steam, a credible allegation of sexual misconduct could end a political career.

headline: New York Is Planning to Shutter a Major Brooklyn Teaching Hospital
abstract: Officials said some services would be transferred from University Hospital at Downstate to nearby facilities, and others, including primary care, could be expanded.
lead_paragraph: The state is planning to drastically shrink or even close University Hospital at Downstate in Brooklyn, the only state-run medical hospital in New York City.

headline: Want to Help the Buffalo Bills Reach the Super Bowl? Grab a Shovel.
abstract: Buffalo’s stadium was full of snow, with a playoff game against Kansas City looming. Hundreds of fans stepped in to help.
lead_paragraph: At 2 p.m. on Friday, Highmark Stadium in Orchard Park, N.Y., home to the Buffalo Bills, was covered in snow. Mounds of white powder were piled high across the stadium, obscuring signs, burying seats and blocking the tunnels that lead from the locker rooms to the field.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Rare Earth Metals May Be Lurking in Your Junk Drawer
abstract: And that’s a good thing. They’re critical for renewable energy, and a new study says recovering them from old cellphones and other waste could help meet the demand.
lead_paragraph: A vast and largely overlooked source of rare earth metals, materials critical for clean energy, could be in our homes, sitting in the back of our cabinets and junk drawers.
