headline: Crying at Work and Other Experiments in Emotion
abstract: A member of a laboratory team wants her colleagues to share their feelings on the job.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: That Broken Intercom in Your Apartment Is Illegal. Here’s What to Do.
abstract: A working intercom isn’t just a convenience when visitors or food deliveries arrive — it’s a legal requirement in most buildings.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live on the sixth floor of a 54-unit co-op building in the West Village. Five years ago, during renovations in the apartment below mine, a wall was removed and I lost my connection to the building’s intercom system. It has never been restored. The building’s architect is supposed to review and approve all renovations, but apparently didn’t catch this problem. I have notified building management several times, to no avail. The regular doormen are aware of the problem and call my cellphone if necessary, but when others are on duty, I miss deliveries and visitors. What should I do?

headline: Words Cast in Lead, and an Era Remade
abstract: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s obituary was written well before he was killed in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: “To many millions of American Negroes, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was the prophet of their crusade for racial equality. He was their voice of anguish, their eloquence in humiliation, their battle cry for human dignity. He forged for them the weapons of nonviolence that withstood and blunted the ferocity of segregation.”

headline: The Market Has Had a Fabulous Run, but This Peak Doesn’t Really Matter
abstract: Compound returns that grow as stocks rise over the decades are far more important than the latest high, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been in the stock market for a while, congratulations. Now that the market has reached a new peak, you’ve probably made some money.

headline: What the Ultrarich Wear to the Grocery Store
abstract: The Class of Palm Beach social media accounts showcase designer-label-laden outfits spotted around that wealthy town.
lead_paragraph: As a personal assistant to a well-to-do retiree, Nora Szigeti is tasked with much of the usual fare: managing a calendar, booking travel, running errands. But after her 70-year-old boss recently came across an Instagram post shared by the account Class of Palm Beach, which documents outfits people have worn around that wealthy town, she took on another duty: publicist.

headline: ‘Heartstopper’ Star Joe Locke Has a Soft Spot for ‘The Goonies’
abstract: “It’s the peak coming-of-age adventure film,” said the actor, who is set to make his Broadway debut in “Sweeney Todd.”
lead_paragraph: Joe Locke was so moved when he saw “Next to Normal” at the Donmar Warehouse in London last fall that he called his agent with a request.

headline: In Strategic Bind, Israel Weighs Freeing Hostages Against Destroying Hamas
abstract: Some Israeli commanders said the government’s two main goals were mutually incompatible. To eradicate Hamas, the military would have to engage in a lengthy war that would most likely cost the hostages’ lives.
lead_paragraph: After more than 100 days of war, Israel’s limited progress in dismantling Hamas has raised doubts within the military’s high command about the near-term feasibility of achieving the country’s principal wartime objectives: eradicating Hamas and also liberating the Israeli hostages still in Gaza.

headline: As Missiles Strike, a Radio Station Broadcasts the Rage of a Battered City
abstract: Kharkiv, in northern Ukraine, is under almost daily bombardment. Radio Boiling Over serves as a megaphone for residents’ fears and frustrations.
lead_paragraph: It was the middle of the night in early January when a Russian missile streaked in and exploded in the center of Kharkiv, blasting down walls and shattering windows.

headline: The Growing Private-Sector Involvement in Canadian Public Health Care Systems
abstract: Ontario announced plans this week to further expand services offered through privately owned clinics under its health plan.
lead_paragraph: This week, the provincial government in Ontario announced that it was expanding the number of private clinics providing medical services.

headline: The Debate Over January
abstract: The seemingly trivial debate over the merits of winter offers an outlet for seasonal frustration.
lead_paragraph: I’m trying to catch some of the optimism from Steven Kurutz’s recent paean to January. Winter friends — those who, contrary to all hedonic and circadian sense, love dark days and black ice — have been forwarding the story to me, triumphant, as if once and for all it’s been settled, the pointless, perennial battle of the seasons. Fortified with talking points, the winter warriors are in my inbox, ticking off upsides: less traffic, fewer obligations, cheaper flights and easier dinner reservations.

headline: Why Americans Are (Still) Mad About Inflation
abstract: The price of a Snickers bar versus that of a new couch.
lead_paragraph: The United States has seen a steady decline in the rate of inflation, and yet many American voters are still upset over the cost of daily life. To understand this perception gap, Paul Donovan, the chief economist of UBS Global Wealth Management, argues, we should consider the cost of a Snickers Bar. In this audio essay, he explains that frequent smaller purchases — like candy bars — shape our experience of the economy.

headline: The People Have a Right to Climate Data
abstract: Information about climate risks is becoming increasingly valuable to companies that want to sell it.
lead_paragraph: As a climate scientist documenting the multi-trillion-dollar price tag of the climate disasters shocking economies and destroying lives, I sometimes field requests from strategic consultants, financial investment analysts and reinsurers looking for climate data, analysis and computer code.

headline: I’ve Told My Last Trump Joke
abstract: It’s easy to make fun of him. It’s also dangerous and it needs to stop.
lead_paragraph: In 1986, when I was a college student, I bristled every time I saw yet another fawning profile of a certain arrogant young real estate developer. The person of whom I speak is, of course, Donald Trump. As polarizing as he is now, Mr. Trump was then enjoying a press honeymoon — even Mike Wallace, the resident bulldog at CBS’s “60 Minutes,” went easy on him, breathlessly declaring in a 1985 profile, “He talks of millions the way most of us talk of nickels and dimes.” This repellent man needed to be knocked down a peg and I thought I knew of one effective way to do it: with jokes.

headline: Choosing How and When to Die When Life Becomes Unbearable
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay about how the writer’s terminally ill sister planned her death.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why Nikki Haley Could Be the Most Dangerous President
abstract: Her hawkish foreign policy vision won’t rescue America.
lead_paragraph: In the alternate timeline where Ron DeSantis proved to be a capable campaigner and looked poised to defeat Donald Trump in New Hampshire and beyond, we would be facing a multitude of left-leaning essays on a single theme: “Why DeSantis is actually more dangerous than Trump.”

headline: Can the MAGA Shrew Be Tamed?
abstract: Flipping back and forth between wins and losses in Hollywood and Iowa, I couldn’t help thinking that Trump was at the wrong celebration.
lead_paragraph: Maureen Dowd has a cold.

headline: When States Try to Take Away Americans’ Freedom of Thought
abstract: Government moves to limit what people can say are an escalation after years of policing speech in other ways
lead_paragraph: Universities have always been a home for the world’s great arguments. Professors and students are supposed to debate the issues of the moment, gaining understanding of the other side’s views, refining and strengthening their positions, and learning how to solve problems. Argument thrives in a culture of openness, and maintaining that culture ought to be paramount for universities, as well as any institution that wants to shape public policy or debate.

headline: New Haley Ad to Play Up Her Foreign Policy Expertise, and Subtly Hit Trump
abstract: A 3-minute commercial set to run on Monday features a mother whose son died just after his release from North Korea. It may remind voters of Donald Trump’s friendliness toward the country’s dictator.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley’s closing argument to New Hampshire primary voters will include a three-minute ad featuring the emotional story of the mother of a college student who died shortly after North Korea released him from captivity in 2017, and whose cause Ms. Haley championed as United Nations ambassador.

headline: Bill Beard Was a Good Man. Then He Committed a Terrible Crime.
abstract: When we let so many Americans fall behind, they not only suffer greatly but also inflict great suffering on others.
lead_paragraph: My old pal Bill Beard was as complicated as America, as creative, as loving and sometimes as troubled.

headline: Embrace the Suck
abstract: People find themselves in situations worse than they thought, and decide to lean in.
lead_paragraph: Stories of people finding themselves in situations worse than they thought, and deciding to lean in.

headline: The Top Takeaways From Davos
abstract: Artificial intelligence was the unofficial theme at the annual gathering of world leaders.
lead_paragraph: Panel discussions, back-to-back private meetings, negotiations to get into the best parties: The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, was back to its prepandemic form this year, as leaders convened to discuss the state of the world.

headline: 2 Books Found via Other Books
abstract: An editor recommends the literary version of nesting dolls.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: ‘No End in Sight’: Evacuated Israeli City Braces for Possible War With Hezbollah
abstract: As tensions escalated on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon after Oct. 7, Israel evacuated tens of thousands of residents from the region, including from Kiryat Shmona, a town with 24,000 people. Months later, evacuees remain in limbo, and the mayor insists they cannot return until Hezbollah militants are pushed back.
lead_paragraph: As tensions escalated on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon after Oct. 7, Israel evacuated tens of thousands of residents from the region, including from Kiryat Shmona, a town with 24,000 people. Months later, evacuees remain in limbo, and the mayor insists they cannot return until Hezbollah militants are pushed back.

headline: A Plant That Flowers Underground Is New to Science, but Not to Borneo
abstract: The Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, hailed pinanga subterranea, a palm native to the island, as a discovery, but it has long been known to local Indigenous people.
lead_paragraph: As a group of European botanists prepared to travel across Borneo by motorboat and four-wheel-drive vehicles, they heard about a species of palm with an extremely rare quirk.

headline: She’s Posing as Her Dead Brother. It’s Just Part of the Grieving Process.
abstract: In her new novel, “Dead in Long Beach, California,” Venita Blackburn explores the chaos of mourning by following a woman who stumbles into an ethically dubious way to cope with loss.
lead_paragraph: There may be no right or wrong way to grieve, but impersonating a recently departed loved one could get a person in trouble. To be fair, Coral — the protagonist of Venita Blackburn’s first novel, “Dead in Long Beach, California” — doesn’t exactly mean to pick up her brother Jay’s phone and start texting as him after she finds him dead from suicide in his apartment. It’s just something she does … and keeps doing.

headline: 6 Great Historical Y.A. Novels That Illuminate the Past and the Present
abstract: Sharon Cameron, the author of “Artifice” and other young adult novels, recommends some of her favorite Y.A. historical fiction.
lead_paragraph: I view history as the ultimate story and the ultimate mystery. It’s the vast accumulation of our shared humanity, and yet, so much of it has died in our memories.

headline: ‘No End in Sight’: Evacuated Israeli City Braces for Possible War With Hezbollah
abstract: As tensions escalated on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon after Oct. 7, Israel evacuated tens of thousands of residents from the region, including from Kiryat Shmona, a town with 24,000 people. Months later, evacuees remain in limbo, and the mayor insists they cannot return until Hezbollah militants are pushed back.
lead_paragraph: As tensions escalated on Israel’s northern border with Lebanon after Oct. 7, Israel evacuated tens of thousands of residents from the region, including from Kiryat Shmona, a town with 24,000 people. Months later, evacuees remain in limbo, and the mayor insists they cannot return until Hezbollah militants are pushed back.

headline: The Baltimore Sun’s New Owner Has the Newsroom on Edge
abstract: The news that David D. Smith, the executive chairman of the conservative Sinclair Broadcast Group, had bought The Sun has generated alarm inside and outside the newsroom.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, desperate to avoid being acquired by a hedge fund, staff members of The Baltimore Sun made public pleas for a local entrepreneur to buy their publication.

headline: The Heart Surgery That Isn’t as Safe for Older Women
abstract: Coronary artery bypass grafting, the most common cardiac procedure in the United States, was studied mostly in men. Women are paying the price.
lead_paragraph: Last Thanksgiving, Cynthia Mosson had been on her feet all day in her kitchen in Frankfort, Ind., preparing dinner for nine. She was nearly finished — the ham in the oven, the dressing made — when she suddenly felt the need to sit down.

headline: Biden Campaign Sharpens Its Post-Roe Message: Abortion Is About Freedom
abstract: In events next week, the president and vice president will argue that abortion access is crucial to personal freedoms, and warn of what is at stake if Donald J. Trump is re-elected.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris will headline events next week centered around protecting abortion rights, throwing more heft behind an issue that has galvanized voters in the 18 months since the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade.

headline: How Allegations of an Office Romance Came to Complicate the Case Against Trump
abstract: The claims involving Fani Willis and Nathan Wade, the special prosecutor she hired to manage the sprawling case in Georgia, have led to new questions about Mr. Wade’s qualifications.
lead_paragraph: Fani T. Willis ran for district attorney in Georgia’s Fulton County in 2020 with the slogan “Integrity matters!” and frequently pummeled the incumbent, her former boss, with accusations of ethical lapses. Soon after her victory, she set up a group to interview job candidates called the Integrity Transition Hiring Committee.

headline: Haley’s Policy Pitch Recalls a Bygone Era Before Trump’s Rise
abstract: Nikki Haley’s calls for muscular international engagement and cuts to future Social Security benefits have elicited withering attacks from Donald J. Trump. They used to be Republican orthodoxy.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley is appealing to voters with policies that recall an era when the Republican Party stood for a fiscal conscience and foreign policy leadership, at a time when the most sacred of federal programs and the international alliances that built the post-World War II era are under enormous strain.

headline: 3 Girls Were Abducted and Stabbed in 1975. Now They Know Who Did It.
abstract: Investigators in Indiana said genetic genealogy had helped them determine that Thomas Edward Williams attacked two sisters and a friend and left them in a cornfield. They survived. He died in prison in 1983.
lead_paragraph: Holding one another’s hands, the three women — two sisters and a friend — sat together on Thursday as police officials in Indiana shared something the women had waited nearly five decades to learn: the name of the person who stabbed them and abandoned them in an Indiana cornfield on a late summer night in 1975.

headline: Gorgeous, Golden Sheet-Pan Turmeric Chicken With Crispy Rice
abstract: Melissa Clark has a new winner of a sheet-pan dinner.
lead_paragraph: Our affinity for sheet-pan dinners is downright Seussian. We like a sheet pan with salmon and potatoes. We like a sheet pan with feta and tomatoes. We like a sheet pan with chicken and bok choy. A sheet-pan bibimbap? That’s pure joy. Now Melissa Clark has a new recipe for sheet-pan turmeric chicken and crispy rice, a dish inspired by Persian tahdig, Korean nurungji and Spanish socarrat. Lemony, gingery chicken legs with golden, chewy-crispy rice make a richly flavored dinner that’s very easy and very nice.

headline: Mocking Haley, Trump Adds to His Long History of Racist Attacks
abstract: The former president is again focusing on race and background as he campaigns against Nikki Haley in New Hampshire.

headline: Airstrike in Syria Kills 4 Iranian Military Advisers, Officials Say
abstract: Iran accused Israel of launching a strike that destroyed a building in Damascus, Syria, killing members of its powerful Revolutionary Guards forces.
lead_paragraph: Iran accused Israel of launching a strike that destroyed a building in Damascus, Syria, killing members of its powerful Revolutionary Guards forces.

headline: George Wallace Has an Heir Apparent
abstract: Trump may be from Queens, but he has deep roots in Southern populism.
lead_paragraph: In a post for the new Opinion blog — which you should read! — I argued that there’s nothing mysterious or hard to grok about Donald Trump’s appeal to a large segment of American voters.

headline: To Undercut Haley, Trump Surrounds Himself With S.C. Leaders
abstract: A traveling slate of South Carolinians joined Donald J. Trump at his rally Saturday night, a show of strength that Mr. Trump hopes will highlight Nikki Haley’s lack of support in her home state.
lead_paragraph: Three days before the New Hampshire primary, former President Donald J. Trump brought a handful of special guests onstage at his largest rally in the state this year: a slew of South Carolina Republicans.

headline: Lev Rubinstein, Russian Poet and a Critic of Putin, Is Dead at 76
abstract: He helped found an avant-garde movement fusing art and prose and was outspoken against the invasion of Ukraine. He died after he was hit by a car in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Lev Rubinstein, a Russian poet, essayist and political dissident during both the Soviet and Putin eras, died on Jan. 14 from injuries sustained after he was hit by a car in Moscow. He was 76.

headline: Palestinian American Teenager Is Killed in the West Bank
abstract: Tawfic Abdel Jabbar, 17, who was fatally shot on Friday, was raised in New Orleans and had planned to attend business school there.
lead_paragraph: Family members of a Palestinian American teenager who was fatally shot in the occupied West Bank demanded on Saturday that the authorities find the killer of the 17-year-old, who was hit by a barrage of gunfire, his cousin said, as the two were setting out to have a picnic near their village.

headline: Haley Campaign Making $4 Million Ad Buy in South Carolina
abstract: The reservation was presented as an indication of her intention to stay in the race regardless of the outcome on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley’s campaign announced on Saturday that it is making a $4 million buy for television, radio and digital advertising in South Carolina that will begin the day after the New Hampshire primary, as she seeks a one-on-one contest with Donald J. Trump.

headline: Lingering Cold Puts Millions in the South Under Harsh Conditions
abstract: The extreme cold has been particularly rough for regions not used to prolonged periods of ice and wind chills, including Tennessee, Kentucky and Arkansas.
lead_paragraph: Bitter cold is gripping large parts of the South once again this weekend, creating hazardous conditions for millions in a region not accustomed to freezing temperatures.

headline: Nikki Haley Has Written Three Books. Here Are Five Takeaways.
abstract: Her writings provide insights into her upbringing and identity, often glossed over on the stump, as well as her politics and ties with Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: If you plan to run for president, they say, write a book. Nikki Haley has written three.

headline: Haley Hits Trump on Age, Suggesting He Is ‘in Decline’
abstract: Nikki Haley’s attack on Donald J. Trump’s mental fitness was her sharpest yet, with just days before New Hampshire’s first-in-the-nation primary.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley on Saturday escalated her attacks on Donald J. Trump, directly criticizing his mental acuity for the first time a day after the former president appeared to confuse her for Nancy Pelosi, the former House Speaker, during his Friday night rally in New Hampshire.

headline: ‘America Is Under Attack’: Inside the Anti-D.E.I. Crusade
abstract: The backlash against “wokeism” has led a growing number of states to ban D.E.I. programs at public universities. Thousands of emails and other documents reveal the playbook — and grievances — behind one strand of the anti-D.E.I. campaign.
lead_paragraph: The backlash against “wokeism” has led a growing number of states to ban D.E.I. programs at public universities. Thousands of emails and other documents reveal the playbook — and grievances — behind one strand of the anti-D.E.I. campaign.

headline: Attacks in Syria and Iraq Ratchet Tensions in a Region Already on Edge
abstract: A senior Iranian intelligence official was killed in an Israeli strike in Damascus as U.S. troops came under attack in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Iran accused Israel of launching an airstrike on the Syrian capital, Damascus, on Saturday that killed senior Iranian military figures, the latest in a series of Israeli attacks on officials from Iran and two of its proxies, Hamas and Hezbollah. Iran vowed to retaliate, raising fears of even deeper regional turmoil rippling out from the war in Gaza.

headline: Bill Iffrig, Runner in Iconic Boston Marathon Bombing Photo, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Iffrig had run in more than 50 marathons but gained national attention in 2013 for being photographed after the blast knocked him to the ground.
lead_paragraph: Bill Iffrig, who became a nationwide symbol of resilience for appearing in a photo that captured his fall near the Boston Marathon finish line in 2013 after the first of two bombs exploded and who soon got up and completed the race, died on Jan. 8 in Marysville, Wash. He was 89.

headline: Experienced Hiker Found Dead on New Hampshire Trail
abstract: Christopher Roma called for help late Tuesday, telling rescuers he was “very cold.” An experienced hiker, he had completed the triple crown of America’s major trails.
lead_paragraph: The body of Christopher Roma, an experienced hiker, was recovered on Thursday after he succumbed to the elements on a day hike in New Hampshire, officials said.

headline: Funny Business
abstract: John Westwig’s puzzle tests our core competencies.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Robert Whitman, Cutting-Edge Performance Artist, Dies at 88
abstract: “I wanted something physical, almost painful, passionate,” he said of his first major work, “American Moon,” presented in 1960. That was just the beginning.
lead_paragraph: Robert Whitman, a pioneer of performance and multimedia art whose work tapped into primitive, nonverbal human ritual while also anticipating the fractured nature of 21st-century digital existence, died on Friday at his home in Warwick, N.Y., in the Hudson Valley. He was 88.

headline: Dean Phillips Floats a No Labels Bid if 2024 Is Trump vs. Biden
abstract: The Minnesota Democrat, currently challenging President Biden, said he would consider running on the ticket of the centrist group if he thought Mr. Biden would lose to Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota, a Democrat running a long-shot primary challenge to President Biden, said on Saturday that he would consider running on the ticket of No Labels, a centrist group exploring an independent bid, if it appeared the general election would be a rematch between Mr. Biden and Donald J. Trump.

headline: How Houthi Attacks Have Upended Global Shipping
abstract: Hundreds of ships are avoiding the Red Sea and sailing an extra 4,000 miles around Africa because of the Houthi attacks, and it comes at considerable economic cost.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of ships are avoiding the Red Sea and sailing an extra 4,000 miles around Africa because of the Houthi attacks, and it comes at considerable economic cost.

headline: Why This Presidential Front-Runner Is Stirring Fears of the ‘Death of Democracy’
abstract: Although he dons different personas, the strongman bona fides of Prabowo Subianto date to when Indonesia was a dictatorship led by his former father-in-law.
lead_paragraph: He hoped to succeed Indonesia’s longtime dictator. He ordered the kidnappings of pro-democracy activists. He was accused of atrocities during the ruthless military occupation of East Timor. He has said elections run counter to his country’s culture.

headline: As Switzerland’s Glaciers Shrink, a Way of Life May Melt Away
abstract: Rising temperatures and retreating glaciers threaten Europe’s water tower, forcing local farmers to adapt and presaging larger troubles downstream.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, Swiss farmers have sent their cattle, goats and sheep up the mountains to graze in warmer months before bringing them back down at the start of autumn. Devised in the Middle Ages to save precious grass in the valleys for winter stock, the tradition of “summering” has so transformed the countryside into a patchwork of forests and pastures that maintaining its appearance was written into the Swiss Constitution as an essential role of agriculture.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Taiwan’s Faith in U.S. Wavers as Tensions With China Rise
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Americans just want us to buy more weapons. They want our money, and want our chips.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: My Rick Pitino Story
abstract: A basketball coach’s persistence has a newly retired journalist reminiscing about newsgathering in a different era.
lead_paragraph: Of all the gym joints in all the towns in all the world, he walks into mine.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: ‘I Turned and Saw My Barber and His Buddies Working on a Car’
abstract: Doing errands on a grumpy Sunday, recalling a fairy-tale chapter and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Election Fraud Is Rare. Except, Maybe, in Bridgeport, Conn.
abstract: Voters say that campaigns in Connecticut’s largest city routinely rely on absentee ballots — collected illegally — to win elections. Now, the city faces a mayoral primary redo.
lead_paragraph: Two months ago, Joe Ganim received the most votes in the race for mayor of Bridgeport, Conn. This week, the city will vote again — to decide if he should even be the Democratic candidate.

headline: As Trump Treats Trials Like Rallies, Judges Study How to Rein Him In
abstract: One judge was reluctantly permissive. Another came down hard. Their contrasting approaches may inform the jurists overseeing the former president’s criminal trials.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump doesn’t change. Judges do.

headline: Leave the Poor Princess Alone
abstract: Less than 30 years after her death, fictional reincarnations of Diana are everywhere. But even icons deserve more time to rest in peace.
lead_paragraph: There she is in her pink suit, pearl earrings and feathered shag.

headline: The Hottest Buzzword in Wellness Seeps Into Real Estate
abstract: Communities certified as “blue zones,” a concept that promotes healthy living and longevity, are multiplying, but some wonder if the movement is just another gimmick.
lead_paragraph: As the director of online sales for the builder CC Homes, Lorraine Sanchez encourages prospective buyers to go see the company’s houses in Ave Maria, a town in southwest Florida.

headline: Volodymyr Zelensky’s Greatest Performance
abstract: In “The Showman,” the journalist Simon Shuster trails the entertainer-turned-wartime president as he rallies the world for support.
lead_paragraph: Nine months into Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, in 2022, the Time magazine correspondent Simon Shuster caught a ride on a presidential train that few, if any, journalists had seen from the inside. In a private carriage, with the blinds drawn, Volodymyr Zelensky was fueling up on coffee during a trip to the frontline. He’d been reading about Winston Churchill, but with Shuster he’d sooner discuss another key World War II figure: Charlie Chaplin.

headline: An Atheist Chaplain and a Death Row Inmate’s Final Hours
abstract: Devin Moss spent a year ministering to convicted killer Phillip Hancock. Together, they wrestled with one question: How to face death without God.
lead_paragraph: “God, that chicken.” Devin Moss has a voice that rumbles, low and slow like distant thunder, but this morning it was softer, more contemplative. His hands gripped the steering wheel of his rental car. He was dressed head to toe in white linen, his body glowing in an almost celestial way, as he drove toward the Oklahoma State Penitentiary.

headline: How Nikki Haley’s Lean Years Led Her Into an Ethical Thicket
abstract: From her earliest days in South Carolina politics, Ms. Haley’s public service paid personal financial dividends.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley had been serving in the South Carolina legislature for less than two years when she applied for a job in late 2006 as an accounting clerk at Wilbur Smith Associates, an engineering and design firm with state contracts.

headline: Can Everyone Be a Tastemaker?
abstract: The cult newsletter Perfectly Imperfect — known for tapping downtown scenesters, influencers and “it” girls for their personal recommendations — has a new platform where all can share their tastes.
lead_paragraph: If you wanted to explain the way a certain kind of very online tastemaking works in 2024 to an alien, or a 45-year-old, you could do a lot worse than showing them Perfectly Imperfect.

headline: Where Textile Mills Thrived, Remnants Battle for Survival
abstract: Apparel makers in the Carolinas say trade policy must change because of a boom in tariff-free shipments to U.S. consumers from foreign manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: In his 40-year career, William Lucas has seen nearly every step in the erosion of the American garment industry. As general manager of Eagle Sportswear, a company in Middlesex, N.C., that cuts, sews and assembles apparel, he hopes to keep what’s left of that industry intact.

headline: Inside the Heritage Foundation’s Plans for ‘Institutionalizing Trumpism’
abstract: “People will lose their jobs,” the think tank’s president says about federal workers. “Hopefully their lives are able to flourish in spite of that.”
lead_paragraph: Since taking over the Heritage Foundation in 2021, Kevin D. Roberts has been making his mark on an institution that came to prominence during the Reagan years and has long been seen as an incubator of conservative policy and thought. Roberts, who was not well known outside policy circles when he took over, has pushed the think tank away from its hawkish roots by arguing against funding the war in Ukraine, a turnabout that prompted some of Heritage’s policy analysts to leave. Now he’s looking ahead, to the 2024 election and beyond. Roberts told me that he views Heritage’s role today as “institutionalizing Trumpism.” This includes leading Project 2025, a transition blueprint that outlines a plan to consolidate power in the executive branch, dismantle federal agencies and recruit and vet government employees to free the next Republican president from a system that Roberts views as stacked against conservative power. The lesson of Trump’s first year in office, Roberts told me, is that “the Trump administration, with the best of intentions, simply got a slow start. And Heritage and our allies in Project 2025 believe that must never be repeated.”

headline: ‘Who Owns This Sentence?’ Increasingly, Who Knows?
abstract: Plato and Pushkin, Mickey Mouse and “The Simpsons” make (permissible) appearances in this surprisingly zippy history of copyright protection.
lead_paragraph: David Bellos and Alexandre Montagu’s surprisingly sprightly history “Who Owns This Sentence?” arrives with uncanny timing.

headline: California and Oregon Ease Covid Isolation Rules, Breaking With C.D.C.
abstract: Two of the most cautious states have bypassed the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention by letting students and workers who have the virus but are asymptomatic avoid isolation.
lead_paragraph: From the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, it has been doctor’s orders in this country: If you test positive, stay away from other people, even if you aren’t coughing or feverish. In recent months, however, that rule has been relaxed in two of the unlikeliest places.

headline: In France, a Conviction for Police Brutality, but Little Expectation of Change
abstract: A police officer who seriously injured a 22-year-old Black man with a baton during an arrest in 2017 was convicted, but given only a suspended sentence.
lead_paragraph: When a French police officer was found guilty on Friday of assaulting Théo Luhaka, a 22-year-old Black man, during a 2017 identity check that led to his arrest, lawyers on both sides left the courthouse claiming victory in one of France’s most publicized cases of police abuse.

headline: In Frigid New Hampshire, Haley Turns Up the Heat. But Is It Too Late?
abstract: On the last weekend before the state’s primary on Tuesday, Nikki Haley made her most forceful case yet in her long-shot bid to defeat Donald Trump for the G.O.P. nomination.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley on Saturday blasted Donald J. Trump’s dishonesty and his relationships with “dictators,” questioned his mental acuity and dismissed his mounting stack of endorsements, sharpening her attacks on him as she headed into the final two days of New Hampshire campaigning.

headline: Trump Tries to Turn the G.O.P. Race Into a Vice-Presidential Casting Call
abstract: Painting himself as inevitable, and seeing who will butter him up the most, Donald Trump has paraded a series of possible running mates, including Tim Scott, Elise Stefanik and J.D. Vance.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has won just a single nominating contest, but his potential running mates already outnumber his presidential rivals on the campaign trail.

headline: Is Kim Jong-un Really Planning an Attack This Time?
abstract: An intensification of nuclear threats from North Korea while the world is preoccupied with other wars has ignited an urgent debate over Mr. Kim’s motives.
lead_paragraph: North Korea fired hundreds of artillery shells in waters near South Korean border islands on Jan. 5. Last week, it said it no longer regarded the South as inhabited by “fellow countrymen” but as a “hostile state” it would subjugate through a nuclear war. On Friday, it said it had tested an underwater nuclear drone to help repel U.S. Navy fleets.

headline: He Loved Basketball and Wanted to Help His Family Stores. A Bullet Ended It All.
abstract: A Palestinian-American teenager was killed by gunfire the West Bank. “This is a shock to the whole family, the community and anyone else with a heart that knows him,” a relative said.
lead_paragraph: He loved to play basketball with his friends. He dreamed of studying business administration to help his family’s stores. He enjoyed taking care of his younger siblings and was “very polite, very respectful, very intelligent,” according to his mosque’s president. Then, suddenly, a bullet to his head ended everything.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Turns Back to Its Favorite Topic, Trump
abstract: Jacob Elordi hosted an episode in which Alaska Airlines was mocked with a parody ad about finding the upside in a flight where a door plug blew out.
lead_paragraph: With 2024 underway and the presidential race in full swing, it was time for “Saturday Night Live” to get back to doing what it loves best: lampooning former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Netanyahu Restates Opposition to Two-State Solution, Despite Pressure From Biden
abstract: The Israeli prime minister said that he had long opposed a Palestinian state because it would constitute “an existential danger to Israel.”
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel doubled down on his opposition to the creation of a Palestinian state this weekend, again rebuffing pressure from President Biden to agree to that path after the war in Gaza is over.

headline: The Nicest Place on the Internet
abstract: Communities around the Crossword, Spelling Bee and more help beginners fall in love with puzzles.
lead_paragraph: New York Times Games — which includes the Crossword, Spelling Bee, Wordle, Connections and more — has a devoted fandom. But I think the word “community” is a better way to describe them.

headline: War Has Already Hurt the Economies of Israel’s Nearest Neighbors
abstract: The impact on global growth of the Middle East violence has so far been contained. That’s not the case for Egypt, Lebanon and Jordan, which were already struggling.
lead_paragraph: In the Red Sea, attacks by Iranian-backed Houthi militants on commercial ships continue to disrupt a crucial trade route and raise shipping costs. The threat of escalation there and around flash points in Lebanon, Iraq, Syria, Yemen and now Iran and Pakistan ratchets up every day.

headline: Critics of D.E.I. Forget That It Works
abstract: As the will to engage in D.E.I. programs is waning, it can be tempting to make superficial fixes to achieve the optics of inclusion. But inclusion is how everyone can thrive.
lead_paragraph: Support for corporate and academic diversity, equity and inclusion efforts appears to be shrinking, even though most people want the same thing: competitive organizations where everyone who shows up to work has a fair shot at success.

headline: What We Do to the Moon Will Transform It Forever
abstract: Commercial moon landings will change how we look at our future in space.
lead_paragraph: The moon stands alone. It is unique in the known cosmos: a solitary rock one-fourth the width of its host planet, the only place life has ever been found. And the moon is alone: It is a desolate, sunbaked and crater-pocked wasteland that harbors little except what we bring to it, either with our minds or with our spaceships. But that is about to change.

headline: I Am Going to Miss Pitchfork, but That’s Only Half the Problem
abstract: The middle is collapsing in media.
lead_paragraph: I’m gutted to see Condé Nast folding the online music magazine Pitchfork into GQ. I won’t try to improve on the eulogies written for the site already. (Casey Newton and Eric Harvey have good ones.) But even today, if you look at the first screen of my iPhone, below The New York Times app and to the left of the Notes app, I keep a tile that’s just a direct link to Pitchfork’s page of music reviews. It’s one of the few corners of the internet I still love, no matter how often I find myself in disagreement. Disagreeing is part of the delight. The writing is beautiful, the reviewers encyclopedic, the point of view bracing.

headline: Only Voters Can Truly Disqualify Trump
abstract: Who is sovereign, the people or the courts?
lead_paragraph: Intense debate has accompanied the decision by the Supreme Court to review the decision by Colorado’s highest court to bar Donald Trump from the state’s primary ballots based on Section 3 of the 14th Amendment — about the precise meaning of the word “insurrection,” the extent of Mr. Trump’s culpability for the events of Jan. 6 and other legal issues.

headline: This Is Why Americans Are So Cynical About Politics
abstract: The problems of government insiders behaving like outsiders.
lead_paragraph: Last week, a group of federal employees organized a protest of the Biden administration’s support of Israel in its war with Hamas. Although a snowstorm in Washington complicated their plans, some federal employees from a range of agencies declined to work for a day. Meanwhile at the Capitol, Republican members of the House of Representatives were once again threatening to throw their institution into chaos to prevent their leader from negotiating a spending package with Democrats.

headline: Overturning Chevron Can Help Rebalance the Constitutional Order
abstract: As Congress has abdicated authority, the executive branch has seized it. We need to start fixing that.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Wednesday heard oral arguments in a case that could go a long way toward fixing some of the systemic dysfunction in American government. The case, which revisits a judicial doctrine known as Chevron deference, has been widely described as a conservative effort to limit government. But that’s not entirely correct. The case is better understood as a key part of the effort to restore the proper balance of power among the three branches of government.

headline: First Black Women to Cover the White House Are Honored in the Briefing Room
abstract: Alice Dunnigan and Ethel L. Payne had to fight sexism and racism to cover one of the most prominent beats in the world. Now, they are being honored for their contributions to journalism.
lead_paragraph: On her first day covering the White House, Alice Dunnigan had every reason to stand out.

headline: When Violence Was What the Doctor Ordered
abstract: Adam Shatz’s “The Rebel’s Clinic,” a new biography of the psychiatrist and revolutionary Frantz Fanon, aims to restore complexity to a man both revered and reviled for his militancy.
lead_paragraph: Rhetoric that is polemical, that is caustic, that is ruthlessly extreme is potent in one sense yet vulnerable in another. It seizes attention and attracts acolytes; it is memorable and therefore memeable. But such strength can also be brittle. Writers who deploy it are susceptible to being cherry-picked and caricatured. They get enlisted in disparate causes and excerpted in college syllabuses. They become icons — whether to be smashed or revered.

headline: Biden Ad Shows Woman Forced to Leave Texas to End Dangerous Pregnancy
abstract: The new ad from the president’s campaign features the testimonial of Dr. Austin Dennard, who left Texas to end a life-threatening pregnancy because of the state’s abortion ban.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s campaign is releasing a new advertisement featuring the testimonial of a woman who was forced to leave Texas to end a planned pregnancy that put her life at risk.

headline: Haley Picks Up Endorsement of New Hampshire’s Largest Newspaper
abstract: The Union Leader did not endorse Donald J. Trump in the previous two cycles, either.
lead_paragraph: The Union Leader, New Hampshire’s largest newspaper and one that reliably picked Republicans for a century before the rise of Donald Trump, endorsed Nikki Haley on Sunday in the Republican primary.

headline: Sundays Are for Bolognese
abstract: Marcella Hazan’s Bolognese, to be exact, which has five stars and over 20,000 reviews.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. If there’s a better scent in the world than Marcella Hazan’s Bolognese sauce (above), I’m unaware of it.

headline: Should Historic Buildings Give Way to New Housing?
abstract: Responses to Opinion pieces about historic preservation and housing shortages. Also: Changing minds on Donald Trump; Russian vs. Russian; social media.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Deadly Blast Hits Market in Ukrainian City Controlled by Russia, Officials Say
abstract: The pro-Moscow authorities in the eastern city of Donetsk said 25 people were killed and 20 others were wounded. It was not possible to independently confirm which side launched the strike.
lead_paragraph: At least 25 people were killed on Sunday when artillery shells hit a market in Donetsk, a city in eastern Ukraine occupied by Russian forces, the pro-Moscow head of the region said, blaming Ukrainian forces for the strike.

headline: Brent Sikkema, Influential New York Gallerist, Dies at 75
abstract: As the founder of the Sikkema Jenkins gallery, he discovered, guided, exhibited and sold a diverse and international rotation of distinguished artists.
lead_paragraph: Brent Sikkema, an influential and well respected New York City gallerist, was found dead on Jan. 15 in an apartment he owned in Rio de Janeiro. He was 75.

headline: Deep Under Gaza, Evidence of Cells and Hostages, Israel Says
abstract: The Israeli military took reporters on a tour of an underground compound in the Gazan city of Khan Younis, where it says about 20 hostages were held by Hamas.
lead_paragraph: In a subterranean compound deep below Khan Younis, a Hamas stronghold in the southern Gaza Strip, the five cells with barred doors that the Israeli military says held hostages abducted from Israel had clearly been constructed long in advance.

headline: Why I’m Voting: A Fisherman Urges Republicans to Confront Climate Change
abstract: Peter Whelan is a lifelong conservative from Portsmouth, N.H. He wants Republicans to respond to the warming waters that threaten the fishing industry and his livelihood.
lead_paragraph: Peter Whelan is a lifelong conservative from Portsmouth, N.H. He wants Republicans to respond to the warming waters that threaten the fishing industry and his livelihood.

headline: U.N. Chief Says Gaza Death Toll Is ‘Unacceptable’ as It Passes 25,000
abstract: Palestinian authorities said on Sunday that more than 25,000 people had been killed in the Gaza Strip in the Israel’s military response to the Oct. 7 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military operation in Gaza has led to destruction and killing on a scale that is “utterly unacceptable,” the United Nations’ secretary general, António Guterres, said on Sunday as the Gazan Health Ministry said the death toll in the territory since the start of the offensive had surpassed 25,000.

headline: As One Dangerous Winter Storm Exits Britain, Another Is Expected on Tuesday
abstract: Powerful winds swept the region overnight into Monday, causing travel disruptions and power outages. A second powerful storm is expected to bring similarly windy conditions.
lead_paragraph: As a powerful storm was moving away from Britain on Monday afternoon after battering the country overnight with a top gust of wind of 99 miles per hour, another was forecast to settle over the region beginning Tuesday, according to the Met Office, the country’s weather service.

headline: Newspapers Stolen After Reporting on Rape Investigation at Police Chief’s Home
abstract: More than 200 copies of The Ouray County Plaindealer, a weekly newspaper in Colorado, were stolen after it published a front-page article about the investigation.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado man was cited after more than 200 newspapers were stolen from distribution boxes, stopping people from buying The Ouray County Plaindealer the day it published a front-page story about an investigation into sexual assault at the home of the Ouray city police chief.

headline: Ron DeSantis Ends Campaign for President
abstract: The Florida governor, who once appeared to be Donald Trump’s most daunting challenger, ran a costly, turbulent campaign that failed to catch on with Republican voters.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida suspended his campaign for president on Sunday and endorsed former President Donald J. Trump, marking a spectacular implosion for a candidate once seen as having the best chance to dethrone Mr. Trump as the Republican Party’s nominee in 2024.

headline: U.S. and European Officials Push for Gaza Aid to Pass Through an Israeli Port
abstract: The ultimate goal, officials said, is to establish a workable alternative to delivering aid via Egypt in a way that satisfies Israel’s demand for security checks.
lead_paragraph: American, British and European officials are pressuring Israel to let aid for Gaza transit through the Israeli port of Ashdod to help alleviate a metastasizing humanitarian crisis, according to six U.S. and European officials.

headline: Charles O. Jones, Expert on Congress and the Presidency, Dies at 92
abstract: As a professor of political science and an author, he displayed a distinctive gift for simplifying the complexities of the American political system.
lead_paragraph: Charles O. Jones, an American political scientist who was a leading authority on Congress and the United States presidency, died on Jan. 3 in Fishersville, Va. He was 92.

headline: Monday Briefing: U.S. Pushes for New Hostage Talks
abstract: Plus the meaning of North Korea’s threats.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s Middle East coordinator, Brett McGurk, will travel to Egypt and Qatar to meet with top leaders about a deal for the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for a temporary pause in fighting.

headline: Three Killed in Medical Helicopter Crash in Oklahoma
abstract: The three crew members onboard lost contact with their company’s control center on Saturday night after completing a patient transfer in Oklahoma City, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Three crew members died in a medical helicopter crash in Oklahoma on Saturday after transporting a patient, according to the company that runs the service.

headline: At Least 72 Deaths in U.S. Are Connected to Severe Winter Weather
abstract: The number from officials and news reports is likely to rise as authorities assess the fallout from the extreme conditions in many parts of the country.
lead_paragraph: At least 72 people across the United States have died from weather-related causes after more than a week of frigid winter storms and brutally cold temperatures, according to reports from state officials, police departments, medical examiners and news outlets.

headline: Is Kristen Stewart the Queen of Sundance This Year?
abstract: She stars in two of the festival’s most discussed films so far: “Love Me,” opposite Steven Yeun, and “Love Lies Bleeding,” with Katy O’Brian.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Parker Posey was dubbed the queen of Sundance in the late ’90s, festival-watchers have been eager to pass that title on each year to whichever actress proves most ubiquitous.

headline: As U.S. and Militias Engage, White House Worries About a Tipping Point
abstract: The number of attacks on American troops in the Middle East increases the risk of deaths, a red line that could lead to a wider war.
lead_paragraph: Another day, another barrage of rockets and another spark that American officials fear could set off a wildfire of violence across the Middle East.

headline: Berish Strauch, Path Breaker in Reconstructive Surgery, Dies at 90
abstract: He developed a wide variety of procedures and devices to reattach or replace vital body parts, including the first inflatable prosthetic penis.
lead_paragraph: Berish Strauch, a plastic surgeon whose pioneering procedures and devices to reattach or replace vital body parts included one of the first toe-to-thumb transplants, a device to reverse vasectomies and, perhaps most notably, the first inflatable penile prosthesis, died on Dec. 24 in Greenwich, Conn. He was 90.

headline: DeSantis Appears to Misattribute a Quote to Churchill as He Drops Out of Primary
abstract: The International Churchill Society has a long list of quotes that are often wrongly attributed to Winston Churchill, the former British prime minister.
lead_paragraph: There is no record of the former British prime minister, who died in 1965, saying those words, according to the International Churchill Society, which features the statement on a list of quotes that are wrongly tied to Mr. Churchill.

headline: Marie Irvine, Makeup Artist to Marilyn Monroe, Dies at 99
abstract: Late in Ms. Monroe’s life, Ms. Irvine was her go-to makeup artist in New York City. Earlier this month, she became a TikTok sensation.
lead_paragraph: Marie Irvine was 99 years old when a chapter in her long-ago career became a TikTok sensation. During a crucial period late in Marilyn Monroe’s life, Ms. Irvine was her makeup artist in New York City, and when a TikTok star learned of her story, it blew up the internet this month.

headline: Lover Boys
abstract: There’s something for everyone to adore in this Monday debut from Jake Halperin.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Haley on DeSantis’s Withdrawal: ‘May the Best Woman Win’
abstract: Nikki Haley and allies have long sought to frame the race as a one-on-one contest with Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley entered a seafood shack in Seabrook, N.H., on Sunday afternoon with some news for the crowd: Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, was no longer running for president.

headline: Trump Campaign Bars an NBC Reporter From a New Hampshire Event
abstract: NBC’s Vaughn Hillyard, who was representing a pool of five major TV networks, said the Trump campaign objected to his presence.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, who popularized the term “fake news” and as president declared the news media “the enemy of the people,” is again clashing with journalists over press access, this time to his 2024 campaign events.

headline: Trump Thanks DeSantis for Endorsement, Calling Him ‘Gracious’
abstract: “He ran a really good campaign,” Donald Trump said of Ron DeSantis, who dropped out of the presidential race and backed Mr. Trump earlier on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday thanked Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida for endorsing him after suspending his campaign, calling Mr. DeSantis — once a top rival whom Mr. Trump spent significant time bashing in his speeches — “gracious.”

headline: ‘DeSanctimonious’ No More: Trump Says He’ll Drop Ex-Rival’s Nickname
abstract: “That name is officially retired,” Donald Trump declared after Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida ended his campaign and endorsed the former president.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take long.

headline: David Gail of ‘Beverly Hills, 90210’ Dies at 58
abstract: Mr. Gail was known for his role as Stuart Carson on Season 4 of “Beverly Hills, 90210” and had dozens of other television show credits in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: David Gail, who played Dr. Joe Scanlon on the ABC soap opera “Port Charles” and appeared on “Beverly Hills, 90210,”  died on Tuesday. He was 58.

headline: G.O.P. Voters Said No to Tim Scott. His Girlfriend Said Yes.
abstract: The couple’s relationship became public after Mr. Scott’s final turn on the debate stage. He proposed on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, who for years faced speculation about his marital status, on Saturday proposed to Mindy Noce, his girlfriend and an interior designer who lives in Charleston. She said yes.

headline: ‘True Detective’ Season 4, Episode 2 Recap: ‘Corpsicle’
abstract: This week’s installment offered a lot of strong procedural work, suggesting that the season’s central mystery isn’t purely supernatural but can be solved.
lead_paragraph: During last week’s episode, as Liz and her team were puzzling over the sudden disappearance of eight scientists at the Tsalal Research Station, Hank mused, “Just the third day of darkness and it’s already getting weird.” Based on some of the mysterious events we witnessed that episode, like the gyrating spirit that leads Rose to a grisly tableaux of frozen bodies, a word like “weird” seems woefully insufficient. One question we might have asked ourselves was whether “Night Country” would become a genuine ghost story or a hybrid, blending the noir sleuthing of previous “True Detective” seasons with mere intimations of the supernatural.

headline: Winter Storm Makes Landings Difficult at Heathrow
abstract: Planes struggled to stick their landings, as Storm Isha brought powerful winds across Britain.
lead_paragraph: Planes struggled to stick their landings, as Storm Isha brought powerful winds across Britain.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Fading Swiss Glaciers Force Traditions to Bend
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I bring them salt, cookies and love.”

headline: No Corrections: Jan. 22, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Modi Opens a Giant Temple in a Triumph for India’s Hindu Nationalists
abstract: The temple inaugurated by the prime minister is on the disputed site of a centuries-old mosque destroyed in a Hindu mob attack that set a precedent of impunity in cases of violence against Muslims.
lead_paragraph: They fanned out across the vast country, knocking on doors in the name of a cause that would redefine India.

headline: Why India’s New Ram Temple Is So Important
abstract: Its site is sacred to Hindus, and it also represents the much more recent victory of Hinduism as a political identity.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurated a gigantic new temple in the Indian city of Ayodhya on Monday, concluding a long campaign in which Hindu nationalists tore down a centuries-old mosque and replaced it with a structure devoted to the Hindu deity Ram.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: The latest from the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Brett McGurk, President Biden’s Middle East coordinator at the White House, departed for Cairo yesterday for talks aimed at the release of more hostages held by Hamas in exchange for a pause in Israel’s military campaign in the Gaza Strip, U.S. officials said.

headline: F.A.A. Tells Airlines to Check Panels on a Second Boeing Plane
abstract: The agency issued a safety alert recommending that airlines inspect door plugs on a Boeing 737 plane that has the same design for the panels as the 737 Max 9.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration recommended late Sunday night that airlines begin visual inspections of door plugs installed on Boeing 737-900ER planes, the second Boeing model to come under scrutiny this month.

headline: Why India’s Ram Temple Is a Big Win for Modi
abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi fulfilled a decades-long promise with the inauguration of the temple, which his Hindu nationalist base has compared to the Vatican. But it also stirs memories of a violent past.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi fulfilled a decades-long promise with the inauguration of the temple, which his Hindu nationalist base has compared to the Vatican. But it also stirs memories of a violent past.

headline: Why Iran Doesn’t Want a War
abstract: Iran is asserting its military strength amid the widening regional turmoil in the Middle East. That doesn’t mean its leaders want to be drawn into a wider war.
lead_paragraph: The war in Gaza has now gone where many feared it would, expanding into conflict in Lebanon, Syria, Iraq and the Red Sea. With America’s repeated strikes against the Houthis in Yemen this month, fears of a larger regional conflagration are steadily growing.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Below Deck Mediterranean’ and ‘The Bachelor’
abstract: The Bravo show wraps up its eighth season. Joey Graziadei leads the 28th season of the reality dating show.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 22-28. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: 2 Navy SEALs Declared Dead After Mission to Stop Iranian Weapons
abstract: The U.S. military has ended a 10 day search for the commandos who went overboard during the mission off the Somalia coast.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. military said on Sunday that it had declared two Navy SEALs dead after they went missing 10 days ago during an operation at sea to intercept weapons from Iran headed to Houthi fighters.

headline: Israel’s foreign minister speaks in Brussels amid discord at home over the war.
abstract: Israel’s foreign minister was in Brussels on Monday to address his counterparts from the European Union, as part of a “diplomatic battle” to win support from the bloc amid deepening criticism over the human toll of the war and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s refusal to consider Palestinian statehood.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s foreign minister was in Brussels on Monday to address his counterparts from the European Union, as part of a “diplomatic battle” to win support from the bloc amid deepening criticism over the human toll of the war and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s refusal to consider Palestinian statehood.

headline: Landslide in Southern China Buries Dozens and Sends Hundreds Fleeing
abstract: At least 11 people died, and several dozen were under the rubble, the state media reported.
lead_paragraph: A landslide in southwestern China’s Yunnan Province on Monday left at least 11 people dead and more than 30 others buried, according to the Chinese state media, as a cold wave blanketed much of the country.

headline: Word of the Day: klaxon
abstract: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word klaxon has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 14 in “He Was a Revolutionary at the Birth of a Nation. Does Anyone Care?” by Alex Traub:

headline: Landslide in China Wipes Out Fields and Houses
abstract: Footage from China Central Television, a state media outlet, showed a landslide that flowed down a snowy mountain in Yunnan Province.
lead_paragraph: Footage from China Central Television, a state media outlet, showed a landslide that flowed down a snowy mountain in Yunnan Province.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Trump Defamation Trial Is Delayed Until Wednesday for Illness
abstract: The judge hearing the case, in which E. Jean Carroll is suing Donald J. Trump, put the trial on hold Monday and Tuesday after a juror and the parents of one of Mr. Trump’s lawyers fell sick.
lead_paragraph: The trial of E. Jean Carroll’s defamation suit against Donald J. Trump was delayed until Wednesday after a juror fell ill.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Reading, Writing, Math … and Climate Change?
abstract: New York may soon join a growing number of states seeking to incorporate climate change into school lesson plans.
lead_paragraph: Third graders at Public School 103 in the north Bronx sat on a rug last month while their teacher, Kristy Neumeister, led a book discussion.

headline: An Italian Town Full of the Elderly Wants to Feel Young Again
abstract: San Giovanni Lipioni, a tiny town in central Italy, has one of the oldest average populations in the country but hopes a marketing push will attract younger people.
lead_paragraph: As the traveling brass band ended San Giovanni Lipioni’s annual holiday concert with a rendition of Wham’s “Last Christmas,” the gray-haired villagers seated in the old church of the central Italian hill town gazed dotingly at the few young children clapping to the music.

headline: Take the 30-Second Power Test
abstract: You need more than strength to age well — you also need power. Here’s how to measure how much you have.
lead_paragraph: If you want to stay healthy as you age, experts say you have to keep moving with a mix of cardio, strength and balance training. But there’s another critical element, one that doesn’t get as much attention. It’s what gives you the ability to toss a heavy trash bag into a can or lift a suitcase into an overhead compartment.

headline: 7 Yoga Books to Deepen Your Practice
abstract: Fourteen teachers shared recommendations for students at all levels.
lead_paragraph: Whether you’re an aspirant, a beginner or a seasoned practitioner, yoga can have positive effects on your mental and physical health. While some people unroll their mats to develop flexibility and strength, others might be drawn to the discipline for improved focus, relaxation or spiritual growth.

headline: These Seven Tech Stocks Are Driving the Market
abstract: See how a handful of stocks have had an outsize impact on the performance of the S&P 500
lead_paragraph: See how a handful of stocks have had an outsize impact on the performance of the S&P 500

headline: The Power-Building Workout
abstract: Power is essential for aging well. Here’s how to increase yours.
lead_paragraph: Over the past several years, experts have increasingly recognized the importance of building power — using muscles in explosive bursts — for healthy aging. Power helps you heave a bag of mulch into the trunk and allows your arms or legs to stop or catch yourself when you slip. While strength helps you sit down in a chair, power brings you out of it.

headline: How a Diversity Initiative Changed Course With the Times
abstract: Amid a fresh backlash against D.E.I. efforts, OneTen met resistance as a program for Black workers only. It has shifted its emphasis to “equity for all” and a more hands-on approach.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, dozens of big companies formed a coalition and declared an ambitious goal: to lift one million Black workers into good-paying jobs over the next 10 years, by hiring or promoting them.

headline: Snowy Peaks, Rushing Rivers and Schnapps to Warm Your Soul
abstract: All across the Tyrol region of Austria, Alpine farms and distilleries tempt skiers and other wintertime visitors with a strong nip of a local tradition.
lead_paragraph: When winter arrives in western Austria and the sun disappears all too quickly behind the snow-capped Alps, you can stand in bare orchards and still taste the sun-ripened fruit that the trees once bore — just sip a glass of schnapps.

headline: Down and Out in American Suburbia
abstract: “Disillusioned,” by Benjamin Herold, follows five families living in the burbs — where they contend with struggling schools, degraded infrastructure, poverty and discrimination.
lead_paragraph: When Benjamin Herold returned in 2020 to his childhood home, in a hilly bedroom community tucked along the Allegheny River 10 miles from downtown Pittsburgh, he saw a crisis.

headline: What Is ‘Settler Colonialism’?
abstract: A look at the academic roots of the idea, which has stirred fierce debate when applied to Israel.
lead_paragraph: In the intense war of words over the Israel-Gaza war, a particular phrase has popped up repeatedly. At protests, on fliers and in some mainstream publications, it is common to see Israel described — or more likely, assailed — as a “settler-colonial” state.

headline: Do You Ever Host or Attend Sleepovers?
abstract: Are slumber parties, or nights staying over at a friend’s house, a part of your social life? Were they ever?
lead_paragraph: Have you ever slept over at a friend’s house? Have you ever hosted a sleepover? Are sleepovers popular with you and your friends? What do your parents think about them?

headline: How ‘Days of Wine and Roses’ Became Their Passion Project
abstract: Kelli O’Hara and Brian d’Arcy James didn’t let the door close on their new Broadway musical about a couple undone by addiction.
lead_paragraph: As origin stories go, the transformation of “Days of Wine and Roses” from a movie into a musical is a straight shot, with a twist. Kelli O’Hara and Adam Guettel had the inkling more than 20 years ago, when she was a Broadway ingénue, working on what became her breakthrough Tony-nominated role in “Light in the Piazza.” Guettel had written the music and lyrics for that musical, which went on to earn him a Tony Award for best score. They talked through their coordinating vision for evolving “Wine and Roses,” the midcentury classic of a romance ruined by addiction. “I think I used the words ‘a weird dark opera,’” O’Hara recalled.

headline: Facing Backlash, Some Corporate Leaders Go ‘Under the Radar’ With D.E.I.
abstract: New hurdles and opposition to diversity programs have pushed some business leaders to approach their D.E.I. initiatives “in a less in your face way,” while others are doubling down.
lead_paragraph: Over the past two years, as Ishan Bhabha and his colleagues at the law firm Jenner & Block prepared briefs for the affirmative action case the Supreme Court ruled on last year, Mr. Bhabha had a realization: If higher education institutions like Harvard were the first target of litigation about diversity, equity and inclusion, America’s corporate boardrooms were probably next.

headline: After My Heroin Addiction, Would Pain Medicine Set Me Back?
abstract: No one should be left in agony because of false beliefs that withholding pain treatment protects against addiction.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, I learned that I needed major oral surgery, including having some teeth removed, bone grafts and implants. I’d dreaded the prospect for years, but it could no longer be postponed. Beyond fear of pain and temporary disfigurement from missing teeth, I had another major concern: I was addicted to heroin in my 20s. If the pain after the two scheduled procedures was severe enough, I might need to take opioids.

headline: A Border Wall to the North? Republicans Want to Discuss.
abstract: Presidential candidates, warning of terrorists, criminals and traffickers, have drawn a national spotlight to the nation’s border with Canada. But proposals for a southern-style wall have not exactly appeared to catch on.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump paved a path to the presidency in 2016 by calling for a “big, beautiful wall” along the United States border with Mexico.

headline: How Did New Hampshire Shift to Blue-ish?
abstract: Why is New Hampshire actually competitive? How has Donald Trump changed politics there? Jane Coaston interviews Dante Scala about what matters this week.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump won Iowa and wants to win New Hampshire and seal up the nomination. Nikki Haley wants to come from behind, win New Hampshire, and gain some momentum before heading to her home state of South Carolina.

headline: The Ghosts of Black Appalachia Visit Her Kitchen
abstract: In her new book, “Praisesong for the Kitchen Ghosts,” the poet Crystal Wilkinson explores her family history through cooking and recipes.
lead_paragraph: When Crystal Wilkinson wants to summon her kitchen ghosts, she retrieves a fuchsia-hued dress from her closet and hangs it in the doorway. The sturdy, double-hemmed garment invites her grandmother Christine, who sewed it by hand and wore it often before she died in 1994, to join her.

headline: A ‘Revolutionary’ Way to Feed the World That’s Very Old
abstract: The U.S. global food security envoy is pushing to bring back traditional African crops that American policies helped to sideline.
lead_paragraph: Cary Fowler once helped build an Arctic vault to save the world’s great variety of crop seeds from extinction. Now, as the State Department’s global envoy for food security, he is trying to plant a new seed in U.S. foreign policy.

headline: With Wit and Understatement, a Press Veteran Reflects on His Trade
abstract: Calvin Trillin collects many of his inimitable profiles and essays about journalism in “The Lede.”
lead_paragraph: “People feel so special, so wise, when somebody they know drops dead,” Ottessa Moshfegh wrote in “Homesick for Another World,” her 2017 story collection. The newly dead might have felt special and wise in advance of their demises if they were friends with Calvin Trillin and could be reasonably sure he would speak at their wakes.

headline: Here Is One Way to Steal the Presidential Election
abstract: The most dangerous strategy we could imagine to subvert the vote was made possible by the Supreme Court itself.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you stress-test America’s system for electing a president? How well does it hold up?

headline: 24 Breakfast Recipes to Make You a Morning Person
abstract: Don’t rise and grind. Rise and dine.
lead_paragraph: I didn’t grow up in a breakfast household — not in any traditional sense, anyway. It was both a requirement and an afterthought: a stop at the gas station for some packaged muffins or the Cuban bakery for a ham croqueta in a roll, often eaten in my dad’s car on the way to school. But breakfast still managed to present its own kind of thrill, a moment to bond with my dad when he was most pressed for time.

headline: $2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A Tudor Revival house in Berkeley, a two-bedroom condominium in Los Angeles and a 10-acre retreat in Murrieta.
lead_paragraph: This house, which has been owned by the same family for 50 years, retains many of its original architectural details, including hardwood floors, built-ins and molding. It is on a tree-lined street where many houses date to the 1920s, in the Claremont district, a few blocks from Claremont Club & Spa, a hotel that opened in 1915.

headline: There Is Another Passenger on the Trump Train
abstract: And it’s getting very crowded.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, I have a feeling this is the last time I’m going to ask you about the Republican presidential primaries. Things seem to be winding up fast. Ron DeSantis is out — don’t think we’re gonna miss him.

headline: Can I Wear My Vintage Concert Tees to Work?
abstract: How to style the shirts is one question, our critic writes. Deciding whether to display personal passions at the office is another.
lead_paragraph: The vintage T-shirt sector — especially the vintage concert T-shirt sector — has become an increasingly rarefied collecting space, one that inspires the same level of connoisseurship, obsession and knowledge as any decorative art. Often such T-shirts exist in extremely limited numbers (and sizes), have their own graphic value and represent a specific moment in culture and politics.

headline: Last Exit Before Trump: New Hampshire
abstract: Tuesday’s primary election will probably decide whether there will be a race at all.
lead_paragraph: Let’s be blunt about the stakes of the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday.

headline: $30,000 a Year for Housing? That’s Average in New York.
abstract: A report from the state comptroller found that housing costs in the city rose 68 percent in the decade ending in 2022.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at housing costs in New York City. We’ll also look at the state’s plans to close a hospital it runs in Brooklyn.

headline: Biden and Harris Target Abortion Laws, and Trump, on Roe’s 51st Anniversary
abstract: The president said abortion restrictions “have no place” in the United States. The vice president was more blunt: “These extremists are trying to take us backward, but we’re not having that.”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris visited Wisconsin on Monday to begin a national tour in support of reproductive rights and highlight steps the Biden administration has taken to navigate around restrictive abortion laws in the United States.

headline: What That DeSantis Smile Showed
abstract: The governor of Florida lacks a certain quality that says, “I am human.”
lead_paragraph: And just like that, Ron DeSantis’s quest for the presidency is kaput. In a short video on Sunday, the Florida governor looked natty in a blue suit and red tie, every hair perfectly in place as he papered over his deeply imperfect campaign. He touted his leadership and, perhaps with an eye toward running again in 2028, endorsed the Republican kingmaker, Donald Trump. It wasn’t a terrible performance, especially under the circumstances. But watching Mr. DeSantis’s now-famous awkward smile and listening to his unnatural cadence, it was hard not to think: Yeah. I can see why this guy’s candidacy is deader than disco.

headline: The Lost DeSantis Moment
abstract: For months, he routinely led Donald Trump in head-to-head polls and gave a possible glimpse at a post-Trump Republican future.
lead_paragraph: Ron DeSantis began the 2024 campaign as a formidable candidate, with early poll numbers that rivaled or even exceeded the likes of Ronald Reagan and Barack Obama.

headline: When the Sky Offers an Unexpected Gift of Time
abstract: For the better part of a week we were hermits, the calendar wiped clean of all appointments.
lead_paragraph: Middle Tennessee has one metaphorical foot in the Midwest and one in the Deep South. We expect a certain amount of weather whiplash here, even without factoring in the extremities of climate change, but January has been a carnival ride. Thunderstorms and tornadoes followed by brutal cold and then by snow the likes of which we haven’t seen in years. Eight inches at our house, up to 10 in other Nashville neighborhoods.

headline: The Unthinkable Mental Health Crisis That Shook a New England College
abstract: Over six terrible months, professors and administrators at Worcester Polytechnic Institute took on the unofficial role of counselors during a spate of campus suicides.
lead_paragraph: The first death happened before the academic year began. In July 2021, an undergraduate student at Worcester Polytechnic Institute was reported dead. The administration sent a notice out over email, with the familiar, thoroughly vetted phrasing and appended resources. Katherine Foo, an assistant professor in the department of integrative and global studies, felt especially crushed by the news. She taught this student. He was Chinese, and she felt connected to the particular set of pressures he faced. She read through old, anonymous course evaluations, looking for any sign she might have missed. But she was unsure where to put her personal feelings about a loss suffered in this professional context. What was the appropriate channel for processing, either with co-workers or students, the sorrow and fear that the death of a student inspired? Foo went on preparing for her fall classes.
