headline: Russian Celebrities Caught ‘Almost Naked’ Are Now Dressing to Appease
abstract: President Vladimir Putin derided those “jumping around without pants,” at a party, while some guests have tried to make amends through donations and adopting a cat.
lead_paragraph: The Russian pop star winced as the black kitten he was cuddling in Russian-occupied Ukraine licked the crook of his neck for about the 15th time.

headline: Haley Gets a Trump Matchup, but Now Faces the Trump Machine
abstract: As Nikki Haley celebrated Ron DeSantis’s departure from the Republican primary, Donald J. Trump turned his firepower toward his final rival.
lead_paragraph: With only about 48 hours left to campaign in the New Hampshire primary, Nikki Haley finally got the two-person race she wanted.

headline: The Rules of War
abstract: What does international law say about Israel’s attack on Gaza?
lead_paragraph: In the International Court of Justice, South Africa is accusing Israel of committing genocide in Gaza.

headline: DeSantis Bows Out, and So Does This Winter Freeze
abstract: Catch up on today’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Decline of Deaths in Gaza
abstract: The daily death toll in Gaza has fallen in half over the past month, reflecting a change in war strategy.
lead_paragraph: For more than a month now, the Biden administration and other allies of Israel have been urging its leaders to scale back the war in Gaza. A more targeted battle plan, these allies have said, could reduce civilian casualties while still weakening Hamas. Some Israeli officials have made the same argument.

headline: Sarah Ferguson, Duchess of York, Diagnosed With Skin Cancer
abstract: The ex-wife of Prince Andrew said it was a “shock” that doctors had discovered melanoma, a deadly form of skin cancer, just months after a breast cancer diagnosis last summer.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York and the former wife of Prince Andrew, said on Monday that it had been a “shock” to receive a second diagnosis of cancer within a year, after doctors found melanoma, a serious type of skin cancer.

headline: In a sign of the war’s shift, daily deaths in Gaza are falling, data shows.
abstract: For more than a month now, the Biden administration and other allies of Israel have been urging its leaders to scale back the war in Gaza and reduce civilian casualties. It’s now clear that Israel’s leaders have followed the advice, at least partially. The most tangible sign of the change is the decline in deaths among Gazan residents, as reported by the Hamas-controlled local government.
lead_paragraph: For more than a month now, the Biden administration and other allies of Israel have been urging its leaders to scale back the war in Gaza and reduce civilian casualties. It’s now clear that Israel’s leaders have followed the advice, at least partially. The most tangible sign of the change is the decline in deaths among Gazan residents, as reported by the Hamas-controlled local government.

headline: G.O.P. Donors Face a Dilemma as Another Trump Rival Falls
abstract: Ron DeSantis’s exit, and Nikki Haley’s struggle to make headway against Donald Trump, are forcing Republicans to make a tough choice.
lead_paragraph: The effort to pick anyone but Donald Trump as the Republican presidential nominee took another big, if expected, blow on Sunday when Ron DeSantis dropped out of the race and endorsed the former president. (Other former hopefuls, including Vivek Ramaswamy and Tim Scott, have also endorsed Trump.)

headline: What Stylish Men Are Wearing
abstract: The men’s fashion weeks in Milan and Paris offered a look at how originals dress.

headline: ‘Patriots,’ About Putin’s Falling Out With an Oligarch, Is Broadway Bound
abstract: The play, by Peter Morgan of “The Crown,” will star Michael Stuhlbarg and is scheduled to open in April.
lead_paragraph: “Patriots,” a well-received British play about a Russian oligarch’s ill-fated role in the rise of Vladimir V. Putin, will transfer to Broadway in April, adding a dose of international intrigue to a packed spring season.

headline: Catching Chess Cheaters Is Tricky Work
abstract: While cheating at the game’s top level is rare, platforms and mathematicians alike work tirelessly to ensure the game’s integrity.
lead_paragraph: The mechanics of how chess players might cheat increasingly occupies the minds of professional chess players, academics who build models to catch cheating and top chess platforms.

headline: California Senate Candidates Face Off in First Debate
abstract: The race to replace Dianne Feinstein features three Democratic members of Congress and a former major-league baseball star.
lead_paragraph: When Dianne Feinstein died in September, she left vacant the U.S. Senate seat that she had held for more than three decades.

headline: A Leading Land Art Installation Is Imperiled. By Its Patron.
abstract: The Des Moines Art Center says it will dismantle Mary Miss’s celebrated work because it does not have the money to repair it.
lead_paragraph: The American land artist and designer Mary Miss was traveling in Europe in October when she received the kind of news that no one in her line of work wants to hear. One of her most significant artworks, owned by an Iowa museum, would need to be closed to the public because it had fallen into disrepair and parts of it were at risk of collapsing.

headline: ‘Forgotten’ Black Cemetery Found at Florida Air Force Base
abstract: MacDill Air Force Base has identified potential gravesites dating from the 1840s through the 1920s that are part of the Port Tampa Cemetery, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Officials at the MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Fla., say they have confirmed the location of a lost former Black cemetery on the grounds of the base, and identified 121 potential gravesites, capping three years of archaeological surveys and building on earlier findings.

headline: Americans Feel Better About the Economy. Will That Help Biden?
abstract: The White House is embracing a nascent uptick in economic sentiment. It is likely good news — but how it will map to votes is complicated.
lead_paragraph: Low approval ratings and rock-bottom consumer confidence figures have dogged President Biden for months now, a worrying sign for the White House as the country enters a presidential election year. But recent data suggests the tide is beginning to turn.

headline: Top Economic Aide to Biden Pitches ‘Comeback’ in Hard-Hit America
abstract: Lael Brainard, the National Economic Council director, contends the administration deserves credit for recent gains in areas battered by past job losses.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s top economic adviser argued on Monday that the administration is engineering a revival of economically disadvantaged communities across the nation, citing patterns of new federal spending and signs of economic progress in places like Eastern Pennsylvania and Milwaukee, Wis.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case of Oklahoma Death Row Inmate
abstract: The court acted after the state’s attorney general, a Republican, agreed that Richard Glossip had not received a fair trial.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether Richard Glossip, a death row inmate in Oklahoma, deserves a new trial in light of newly disclosed evidence and an extraordinary concession from the state’s Republican attorney general.

headline: He’s Not on the N.H. Ballot, but Biden’s Allies Hope He’ll Still Win
abstract: Democrats have undertaken a write-in campaign for him after a clash over his move to push back New Hampshire on the nominating calendar. They are growing increasingly hopeful.
lead_paragraph: If President Biden’s re-election campaign can feel like a slog elsewhere, the write-in effort for him in New Hampshire’s primary election is infused with the sort of joy found in spirited underdogs.

headline: Green Day Gets Loud Again
abstract: On “Saviors,” its 14th studio album, the pop-punk trio returns to stadium-sized rock.
lead_paragraph: Praising a return to form is a barbed compliment at best. It implies recent missteps, a decline, the waning of youthful inspiration, the toll of a long career — perhaps all of them at once. It suggests that the sensible way forward is to double back. Still, “Saviors,” Green Day’s new album, is a decisive, even overdetermined return to form.

headline: Exxon Sues to Prevent Climate Proposal From Getting a Shareholder Vote
abstract: The complaint, filed in a U.S. District Court in Texas, said a proposal by activist investors calling for the oil giant to cut emissions faster would not create shareholder value.
lead_paragraph: Exxon Mobil is suing two activist investors to prevent their proposal calling for emissions cuts at the oil giant from going to a vote of shareholders.

headline: Macy’s Rejects Takeover Bid, but Remains ‘Open to Opportunities’
abstract: The retailer, which has struggled to increase its sales as shoppers cut back, acknowledged that it had received an unsolicited buyout offer, which it said “lacks compelling value.”
lead_paragraph: Macy’s rejected a $5.8 billion takeover bid late Sunday that valued the struggling department store chain at roughly 20 percent above its closing share price on Friday, but suggested it was “open to opportunities.”

headline: Can You Find the 14 Best Sellers Hidden in This Text Puzzle?
abstract: The titles of more than a dozen popular books are concealed within a short fictional passage and are just waiting to be discovered.
lead_paragraph: The titles of more than a dozen popular books are concealed within a short fictional passage and are just waiting to be discovered.

headline: 21 Savage Returns to No. 1 With Solo Album ‘American Dream’
abstract: Kali Uchis’s “Orquídeas” opens at No. 2, giving the Colombian American songwriter her highest chart position yet on the Billboard 200.
lead_paragraph: 21 Savage, the London-born mainstay of Atlanta rap, has the first new No. 1 album of 2024 with “American Dream,” following holdovers by Taylor Swift and Morgan Wallen.

headline: Mary Weiss, Who Sang ‘Leader of the Pack,’ Is Dead at 75
abstract: As the lead singer of the Shangri-Las, she conveyed passion, pathos and toughness — and reached the Top 40 six times while still in her teens.
lead_paragraph: Mary Weiss, who in 1964 was the lead singer of the Shangri-Las’ No. 1 hit, “Leader of the Pack,” extracting every ounce of passion and pathos available in a three-minute adolescent soap opera, died on Friday at her home in Palm Springs, Calif. She was 75.

headline: Enchiladas Verdes, But Make It Beans
abstract: Ali Slagle’s new cheesy green chile bean bake works as both satisfying dinner and party-pleasing dip.
lead_paragraph: A skillet dinner of spicy beans is a speedy winter staple at my house. Whether cumin-scented and chili-adjacent, or zapped with red pepper flakes, loads of garlic and olive oil, it’s a weeknight go-to when work runs long and evenings are short. Is there anything easier or more satisfying on a cold January night?

headline: A Riveting Thriller Spun From Texts, Emails and WhatsApp Messages
abstract: “The Mysterious Case of the Alperton Angels,” a modern take on the epistolary novel, is hard to put down.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a key to a safe deposit box, Janice Hallett tells us at the beginning of her ingenious jigsaw puzzle of a book, “The Mysterious Case of the Alperton Angels.” Inside we’ll find a thick packet of material — interview transcripts, news clippings, texts, WhatsApp messages, excerpts from novels and screenplays, email exchanges and other seemingly random scraps of information.

headline: Chris Sununu, Nikki Haley’s ‘Best Friend,’ Won’t Stop Believing
abstract: The New Hampshire governor has been an energetic, unusually involved ally in what looks like a do-or-die state for her.
lead_paragraph: As he introduced Nikki Haley at a bar in Milford, N.H., Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire was in a comfortable place — surrounded by a swarm of media cameras and local voters.

headline: Protesters Storm Meeting at Israel’s Parliament to Demand More Action on Hostages
abstract: Advocates and relatives of hostages urged lawmakers to do more to free their loved ones. “Shame on you!” one yelled.
lead_paragraph: Supporters and relatives of hostages captured in the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attacks burst into a meeting at Israel’s Parliament on Monday to demand that lawmakers take greater action to secure the captives’ release from Gaza.

headline: Fighting Intensifies in Southern Gaza and Its Main City, Khan Younis
abstract: “The whole district of Khan Younis is essentially besieged,” a spokeswoman for the Palestinian Red Crescent Society said.
lead_paragraph: Fighting intensified in southern Gaza on Monday, with medical personnel reporting heavy exchanges of gunfire and a surge of Israeli tanks and troops into areas around hospitals.

headline: Cal State Faculty Begin Largest U.S. Strike of University Professors
abstract: Thousands of professors, lecturers and other academic staff members walked off the job in a protest that was expected to cancel most classes early in the academic period. They plan to strike for five days.
lead_paragraph: In the largest university faculty strike in U.S. history, thousands of professors and lecturers throughout the California State University system walked off the job on Monday to demand higher compensation, a protest that was expected to cancel most classes early in the academic period.

headline: ‘Hazbin Hotel’ Is a Childhood Dream Streamed Out to the World
abstract: Vivienne Medrano’s animated musical series went from middle-school sketches to YouTube to a series streaming on Amazon.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 28, 2019, the animator and YouTube personality Vivienne Medrano celebrated a milestone: the release of “Hazbin Hotel,” a 30-minute pilot for an animated musical-comedy about a rehabilitation program that aspires to help Hell’s repentant demons get to Heaven.

headline: A Story of Mothers and Daughters, Race and Medicine
abstract: In “Legacy,” Dr. Uché Blackstock writes about losing her pioneering physician mother and the pervasive health woes of Black Americans.
lead_paragraph: As children, Uché Blackstock and her twin sister, Oni, delighted in riffling through their mother, Dale’s, doctor’s bag, both at home and when they visited her at the Brooklyn hospital where she was a kidney specialist.

headline: A New Concern on the Ukrainian Battlefield: North Korea’s Latest Missiles
abstract: As the war approaches its second anniversary, the Russians are beginning to deploy North Korean arms, worsening Ukraine’s troubles while it still awaits new air defenses from the United States.
lead_paragraph: When Russia turned to Kim Jong-un of North Korea to help it through its war with Ukraine, it came with a big shopping list that included a million rounds of artillery to shoot at Ukrainian troops dug into trenches across the south and east, and dozens of North Korea’s newest, barely tested missiles.

headline: The Cleveland Orchestra Says a Lot, but Only Through Music
abstract: With neither encores nor speeches, this ensemble presented a subtly clever, cogent and complete pair of concerts at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The conductor Franz Welser-Möst is a man of few words. Or, judging by his two concerts with the Cleveland Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last weekend, no words.

headline: On a Remote Island, Blinken Signals U.S. Attention to Africa
abstract: The secretary of state is beginning a tour of four African countries, hoping to promote positive news on the continent.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken touched down on a remote African island chain before heading on to the Ivory Coast on Monday, kicking off a four-nation swing through the continent intended to show the Biden administration’s continued interest in Africa amid major conflicts in the Middle East and Europe.

headline: Global Galleries Return to an Expanding London Scene
abstract: After a four-year break, the collaborative exhibition Condo is again luring international dealers to the city, where contemporary art is buoyant, against the odds.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s economy is stagnant, the international art market is in a downturn and the wider world is weighed down with ongoing geopolitical crises in the Middle East, Ukraine and beyond.

headline: Critics Protest Harvard’s Choice to Lead Antisemitism Task Force
abstract: Bill Ackman and Lawrence Summers decried the choice of Derek J. Penslar, a professor of Jewish history, who had signed a letter describing Israel as an apartheid regime.
lead_paragraph: A Harvard task force on antisemitism has gotten off to a rocky start, with complaints that the professor chosen to help lead the panel had signed a letter that was critical of Israel, describing it as “a regime of apartheid” for its treatment of Palestinians.

headline: Review: Searching for the Superstar in Ivo van Hove’s Jesus Christ
abstract: The Belgian director’s revival of “Jesus Christ Superstar” showcases some of his signature aesthetic techniques. But it’s an odd pairing.
lead_paragraph: On a dark, featureless stage in Amsterdam, a soon-to-be-crucified Jesus Christ laments his predicament while sporting a shimmery tank-top and gray New Balance sneakers. His followers, gathered around him, look like they have raided an Urban Outfitters store sometime around 2012.

headline: DeSantis Drops Out, While Haley Is Still In
abstract: Readers discuss what they see as failed strategies in trying to vanquish Donald Trump. Also: Diverse experiences; landmarked buildings; books as decoration.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Digital World Shares Surge as Republican Primary Field Narrows
abstract: Shares of the SPAC that plans to merge with Trump Media jumped after Donald Trump’s rival Ron DeSantis quit the primary race.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Digital World Acquisition Corporation, the cash-rich shell company that plans to merge with former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company, soared 88 percent on Monday, a day after Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida dropped out of the race for the Republican presidential nomination and brought Mr. Trump even closer to securing it.

headline: New York Settles Suit That Said Its Housing Rules Worsened Segregation
abstract: The city agreed to reduce the share of affordable apartments set aside for people living near new developments, nine years after a lawsuit called the preferential policy discriminatory.
lead_paragraph: New York City has agreed to change the way it selects tenants for affordable housing in order to settle a long-running civil rights case that asserted the city’s housing system reinforced segregation

headline: Map: 7.0-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Western China
abstract: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

headline: Judge Unseals Records in Divorce Case That Has Entangled Trump Prosecutors
abstract: A judge in Georgia also delayed a deposition of Fani T. Willis, the district attorney accused of having a romantic relationship with a prosecutor she hired.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia judge unsealed a divorce case on Monday that has entangled the Atlanta district attorney prosecuting former President Donald J. Trump, but halted plans to force the testimony of the prosecutor, Fani T. Willis.

headline: Why I’m Voting: A Gun Store Owner Faces a Difficult Choice
abstract: “I don’t fit on any one side,” says gun shop owner Ben Beauchemin. He’s a Second Amendment advocate who also supports women’s reproductive rights, and says he’s undecided about who to vote for in the primary.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t fit on any one side,” says gun shop owner Ben Beauchemin. He’s a Second Amendment advocate who also supports women’s reproductive rights, and says he’s undecided about who to vote for in the primary.

headline: Review: The Composer Joseph Boulogne, a Polymath for All Seasons
abstract: “The Chevalier,” an intriguing music-theater hybrid, unwraps the still little-known life and work of this 18th-century composer.
lead_paragraph: Now, the composer Joseph Boulogne would be hailed as a Renaissance man: artist, athlete, intellectual, soldier. Born in Guadeloupe in 1745, the son of a white French plantation owner and an enslaved mother of Senegalese origin, Boulogne became a virtuoso violinist, prodigious composer, champion fencer, the general of Europe’s first Black regiment and an avid abolitionist.

headline: 1924: Protests Will Continue on Rum-Ship Seizures
abstract: The British authorities accused their American counterparts of seizing rum-runners outside an agreed-upon three-mile zone.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British Government will continue to make protests to Washington in all cases of seizures of suspected rum-runners outside of the three-mile limit until the reciprocal rum treaty is ratified by the two countries, the correspondent of The New York Herald was informed today at the Foreign Office.

headline: Ewa Podles, a Rare Contralto With Sweeping Range, Dies at 71
abstract: With her molten chest voice and commanding presence, Ms. Podles, a galvanizing Polish opera singer, developed a cult following.
lead_paragraph: Ewa Podles, the Polish contralto whose darkly molten, three-octave-plus voice and commanding presence made her a favorite of opera connoisseurs, died on Friday in Warsaw. She was 71.

headline: 500,000 New Yorkers Could Have Medical Debt Erased Under New Program
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams announced that the city would invest $18 million to buy up and then erase medical debt for New Yorkers who meet certain qualifications.
lead_paragraph: New York City will buy up millions of dollars of medical debt and erase it in a program that officials hope will ultimately help as many as 500,000 New Yorkers.

headline: More Regulation? Big Banks Say They’re Safe Enough Already.
abstract: With unlikely allies, big banks are resisting regulators’ plan to strengthen them.
lead_paragraph: Making banks safer would seem like an easy thing for Americans to agree on, especially after the wipeouts of the global financial crisis in 2007-9, followed by the failure last year of three big ones: Silicon Valley Bank, Signature Bank and First Republic Bank.

headline: Depardieu Sexual Assault Suit Dropped Over Statute of Limitations
abstract: Hélène Darras, a French actress, had accused Gérard Depardieu of groping her in 2007 on a movie set. A separate investigation of the actor is proceeding, Paris prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A sexual assault lawsuit filed against Gérard Depardieu by a French actress has been dropped because it was past the statute of limitations, prosecutors in Paris said on Monday, but the French actor is still under investigation in a separate case.

headline: New Hampshire Officials to Investigate A.I. Robocalls Mimicking Biden
abstract: The calls, in a voice most likely artificially generated, urged people not to vote in Tuesday’s primary.
lead_paragraph: Voters in New Hampshire received robocall messages over the weekend in a voice that was most likely artificially generated to impersonate President Biden’s, urging them not to vote in Tuesday’s primary election, according to the state attorney general’s office.

headline: Supreme Court Backs Biden in Dispute With Texas Over Border Barrier
abstract: A federal appeals court had ruled that Border Patrol agents may not remove concertina wire erected by the state except for medical emergencies.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court sided with the Biden administration on Monday, allowing federal officials to cut or remove parts of a concertina-wire barrier along the Mexican border that Texas erected to keep migrants from crossing into the state.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 21, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend about the challenges of saving for college and navigating financial aid programs misspells the given name of the former president of Vassar College and managing director at Ithaka S+R, a consulting firm. She is Catharine, not Catherine, Bond Hill.

headline: Pentagon Names Two SEALs Lost in Raid in Arabian Sea
abstract: Preliminary accounts of how the two Navy SEALs were lost at sea during a boarding mission raised questions about how the raid was conducted.
lead_paragraph: The Defense Department identified on Monday the two Navy SEALs who were lost at sea and died this month during a nighttime commando raid on a small ship carrying weapons components bound for Yemen.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: North Korean Missiles in Ukraine
abstract: Plus, a “revolutionary” way to feed the world.
lead_paragraph: Russians are beginning to deploy North Korean arms on the battlefield in Ukraine.

headline: Sunak’s Flagship Immigration Plan Fails First Test in House of Lords
abstract: In the latest setback to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s Rwanda policy, the upper house of the British Parliament voted to delay a crucial treaty with the African country.
lead_paragraph: Four days ago, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain urged the House of Lords, the unelected upper chamber of Parliament, not to block his plans to put asylum seekers on one-way flights to Rwanda, describing his contentious migration policy as “the will of the people.”

headline: Mocked as ‘Pokémon With Guns,’ Palworld Becomes an Instant Hit
abstract: The survival game started as a meme and became a miracle for its developers, who have insisted they are not copying the popular Nintendo series.
lead_paragraph: A video game once ridiculed for putting machine guns into the hands of cute creatures, eerily similar to the ones in Pokémon, was downloaded by an enormous audience over the weekend.

headline: Fierce Storm Sends Flights Bound for One Country to Another
abstract: Ferocious winds forced pilots to abort landings and divert passengers hundreds of miles from their original destinations.
lead_paragraph: A powerful storm diverted dozens of flights in Britain and Ireland on Sunday and Monday, sending passengers to Germany, France and northern Britain, and stranding some at airports overnight.

headline: Tensions Erupt at Los Angeles Times as Owner Weighs Deep Cuts
abstract: The biggest news organization on the West Coast has been roiled by the potential layoffs of roughly 100 newsroom employees.
lead_paragraph: Around twilight on Thursday, Los Angeles Times journalists gathered at Flora, a rooftop bar not far from the paper’s headquarters, to toast their departing editor, Kevin Merida.

headline: Elon Musk, on Rehabilitation Tour, Calls Himself ‘Aspirationally Jewish’
abstract: His remarks, part of an effort to atone for comments many called antisemitic, came after a visit to the Auschwitz death camp site.
lead_paragraph: Pushing back against accusations of antisemitism, Elon Musk has in recent months visited Israel, hosted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at a Tesla factory in California and repeatedly insisted he bears no animus toward Jews.

headline: Norman Jewison, 97, Dies; Directed ‘In the Heat of the Night’ and ‘Moonstruck’
abstract: His genre-spanning movies — dramas, comedies and musicals, like “Fiddler on the Roof” — were magnets for Oscar nods, but he was best known for socially conscious films.
lead_paragraph: Norman Jewison, whose broad range as a filmmaker was reflected in the three movies that earned him Academy Award nominations for best director — the socially conscious drama “In the Heat of the Night,” the big-budget musical “Fiddler on the Roof” and the romantic comedy “Moonstruck” — died on Saturday at his home. He was 97.

headline: How Does the New Hampshire Primary Work?
abstract: It’s the nation’s first primary contest, following the caucuses in Iowa. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: New Hampshire voters will head to the polls Tuesday for the nation’s first primary election, where Nikki Haley is hoping to make a dent in former President Donald J. Trump’s delegate lead after his big win in the Iowa caucuses. Voting in the state technically starts at midnight, but the vast majority of polling places will open at 7 a.m. Eastern time.

headline: The Hot New Accessory From the Paris Runways: A Robot Baby
abstract: The internet went into meltdown after a Schiaparelli couture show featured a cameo by a tiny bedazzled figure inspired by the “Alien” movies.
lead_paragraph: It wouldn’t be the Monday morning of Paris couture week unless Schiaparelli used its runway show to produce a viral internet moment.

headline: Bali Bombers May Return to Malaysia After Sentencing
abstract: The two prisoners have admitted to conspiring with an affiliate of Al Qaeda that carried out a deadly bombing in Indonesia two decades ago.
lead_paragraph: When a jury of military officers is assembled this week at Guantánamo Bay, it will be asked to choose a sentence in the 20- to 25-year range for two Malaysian prisoners who admitted to conspiring with an affiliate of Al Qaeda that carried out a deadly bombing in Indonesia two decades ago.

headline: Tolo Serves Up a Lunar New Year Feast With Wines to Match
abstract: High-fiber bread from Hero Bread, something of a rustic Wellington from Dominique Ansel Workshop and more food news.
lead_paragraph: Restaurants have started gearing up for the Lunar New Year, with Year of the Dragon starting on Feb. 10 and New Year celebrations lasting about two weeks. Tolo, the chef Ron Yan’s restaurant which opened in early November, will offer a special $100 per person menu for parties of six to 12 that includes classics like longevity noodles, duck confit spring rolls, jiaozi dumplings, lawei fried rice and lion’s head meatballs, typically from Yangzhou, Mr. Yan’s birthplace. Poon choi — a communal dish of seafood, pork and duck, with vegetables and tofu — is included and will also be served à la carte ($150 to order in advance). Mr. Yan has taken a clever approach to wines for the occasion. Working with Parcelle, the wine retailer with a shop and a wine bar nearby, where he is the chef, there will be a stunning and well-priced selection from vintages that coincide with other Years of the Dragon. They include Pio Cesare Barolo 1964, $125; Jordan Cabernet Sauvignon, 1976, $200; and Taittinger Comtes de Champagne Blanc de Blancs, 2012, $225.

headline: U.S. Expands Attacks on Houthis With New Strikes in Yemen
abstract: The strikes against eight sites come as the Iran-backed militant group remains defiant and the region teeters on the edge of a wider war.
lead_paragraph: The United States and Britain carried out large-scale military strikes on Monday against eight sites in Yemen controlled by Houthi militants, according to the two countries. The strikes signaled that the Biden administration intends to wage a sustained and, at least for now, open-ended campaign against the Iran-backed group that has disrupted traffic in vital international sea lanes.

headline: Joseph Hayden, Who Fought for Ex-Felons’ Voting Rights, Dies at 82
abstract: A former lieutenant in a Harlem drug gang, he earned two academic degrees in prison and became an advocate for parolees and convicts.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Hayden, a former lieutenant in a notorious Harlem drug gang who had cycled in and out of prison for decades before turning his life around to become an activist for criminal justice reform and a well-known figure in Harlem, wielding a camera to document possible police harassment, died on Jan. 6 in Northampton, Pa. He was 82.

headline: After Freeze Grips Much of U.S., a Warm Respite Beckons
abstract: Some cities could see a temperature swing of more than 50 degrees. Time to hit the zoo.
lead_paragraph: In Dallas, where temperatures dropped as low as 10 degrees last week, highs were forecast to reach the 60s on Wednesday. In New York City, where the low dropped to 17 on Wednesday, unseasonably high temperatures in the 50s were expected by Thursday. And in St. Louis, which was covered in ice on Monday, a high of 50 was expected on Wednesday.

headline: Ruth Ashton Taylor, Early Radio and TV Newswoman, Dies at 101
abstract: In the late 1940s, she was the only woman working on radio documentaries for CBS’s Edward R. Murrow. In Los Angeles, she was a pioneering newscaster and anchor.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Ashton Taylor, who was the only woman on the CBS newsman Edward R. Murrow’s postwar radio documentary unit and was widely believed to be the first female newscaster in Los Angeles, died on Jan. 11 in San Rafael, Calif. She was 101.

headline: New York City Schools Will Teach About Antisemitism and Islamophobia
abstract: All middle and high school principals will receive new training, after the system faced criticism for doing too little to address the Israel-Hamas war.
lead_paragraph: New York City will offer new curriculum materials on antisemitism and Islamophobia in its public schools and train principals and teachers on how to have difficult conversations about politically charged issues, officials said on Monday in response to criticism that the system has done too little to address the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Top Cancer Center Seeks to Retract or Correct Dozens of Studies
abstract: A British biologist and blogger discovered faulty data in many studies conducted by top executives of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.
lead_paragraph: A prominent cancer center affiliated with Harvard said it will ask medical journals to retract six research papers and correct dozens of others after a British scientist and blogger found that work by some of its top executives was rife with duplicated or manipulated data.

headline: Nikki Haley Mounts a Last Stand in New Hampshire
abstract: Also, a large university walkout in California. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley finally got what she has desired since the very beginning of her campaign for the Republican presidential nomination: a one-on-one showdown with Donald Trump. The field was cleared for her yesterday when Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida ended his bid, leaving Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, as the only real threat to a third consecutive Trump nomination.

headline: Reading the Signs in New Hampshire
abstract: This street corner tells the tale of the Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: If you want to understand the New Hampshire primary, stand at the corner of West Broadway and Valley Street in Derry, N.H.

headline: Biden, Harris Criticize Republican Efforts to Ban Abortion
abstract: On the 51st anniversary of Roe v. Wade, President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris denounced former President Trump and congressional Republicans for expanding restrictive abortion laws across the nation.
lead_paragraph: On the 51st anniversary of Roe v. Wade, President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris denounced former President Trump and congressional Republicans for expanding restrictive abortion laws across the nation.

headline: In San Diego, Furious Deluge Floods Homes and Freeways
abstract: An intense downpour brought more rain to the city on Monday than Tropical Storm Hilary did last year.
lead_paragraph: An unusual torrent of rain and flash flooding hit the San Diego area on Monday, shutting down highways, swamping roads and leaving some residents to watch helplessly as water swept away their cars or wreaked havoc on their homes.

headline: Trump Plays Up His Former Rivals’ Endorsements. Haley Has Judge Judy.
abstract: Judy Sheindlin’s backing of Nikki Haley is a rare foray into presidential politics for the television star.
lead_paragraph: While former President Donald J. Trump enlists several former rivals to help him deliver a closing argument to New Hampshire primary voters, Nikki Haley, his last remaining Republican opponent, has approached a different kind of bench: Judge Judy.

headline: Netflix’s Head of Film to Depart
abstract: Scott Stuber attracted Oscar-winning filmmakers to the streaming service and helped usher the entertainment industry into the streaming era.
lead_paragraph: Scott Stuber, who brought Oscar-winning filmmakers like Martin Scorsese, Spike Lee, Jane Campion and Alfonso Cuarón to Netflix and in doing so helped to usher the entertainment industry into the streaming era, is leaving as the service’s film chairman, the company said on Monday.

headline: Lawyer and Son Ensnared Hundreds of Immigrants in Fraud Scheme, U.S. Says
abstract: The men directed clients to falsely claim they had been abused by their own children in attempts to get green cards, federal prosecutors said. Some people ended up being deported.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx lawyer and his son were arrested on Monday and charged with orchestrating a seven-year immigration scheme that defrauded hundreds of immigrants and caused some of them to be deported, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Dexter Scott King, Younger Son of Martin Luther King Jr., Dies at 62
abstract: As the longtime chairman of the King Center, he worked closely — and clashed at times — with his siblings over control of their father’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: Dexter Scott King, who as one of four children of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. worked closely with — but also frequently fought against — his siblings and the civil rights community over his father’s legacy, died on Monday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 62.

headline: Trump and Haley Gear Up for New Hampshire Primary
abstract: Nick Corasaniti, a political reporter for The New York Times, explains the importance of the New Hampshire primary and what potential results could mean for the race going forward.
lead_paragraph: Nick Corasaniti, a political reporter for The New York Times, explains the importance of the New Hampshire primary and what potential results could mean for the race going forward.

headline: 9 Democratic Governors Push Biden and Congress to Address Migrant Crisis
abstract: The effort is being led by Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York, a Biden ally whose state has been inundated with arrivals from the southern border.
lead_paragraph: Nine Democratic governors have joined together to urge the Biden administration and congressional leaders to address what they call “a humanitarian crisis” created by the surge of migrants seeking refuge in the United States.

headline: The Emasculation of Ron DeSantis by the Bully Donald Trump
abstract: The former president’s brutal, yearlong campaign of humiliation helped torpedo the Florida governor’s White House hopes and left his next moves in politics uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump plumbed new depths of degradation in his savage takedown of Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, a yearlong campaign of emasculation and humiliation that helped force one of the party’s rising stars out of the presidential race after just one contest and left him to pick up the pieces of his political future.

headline: Is the Vibecession Finally Coming to an End?
abstract: Suddenly, Americans are feeling better about the economy.
lead_paragraph: In 2022, Republicans seemed to have an easy path to regaining the White House, no actual policy proposals required. All they had to do was contrast Donald Trump’s economic record — which they portrayed as stellar — with the lousy economy under President Biden.

headline: Arno A. Penzias, 90, Dies; Nobel Physicist Confirmed Big Bang Theory
abstract: His 1964 discovery with Robert W. Wilson settled a debate over the origin and evolution of the universe.
lead_paragraph: Arno A. Penzias, whose astronomical probes yielded incontrovertible evidence of a dynamic, evolving universe with a clear point of origin, confirming what became known as the Big Bang theory, died on Monday in San Francisco. He was 90.

headline: With Border Deal Near, Parole and Money Take Center Stage in Senate Talks
abstract: Republicans and Democrats have agreed to try to reduce the number of migrants granted parole to stay in the United States, but cementing the compromise will take money and persuasion on both sides.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of senators has agreed on a compromise to crack down on the surge of migrants across the United States border with Mexico, including reducing the number who are allowed to live and work in the country temporarily, but a final deal depends on resolving critical funding disputes.

headline: Israel-E.U. Meeting on Gaza’s Future Yields Division and Confusion
abstract: Europeans, insisting on Palestinian statehood, are frustrated by Israel’s opposition and lack of a postwar plan for the devastated Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: European foreign ministers pressed their Israeli counterpart on Monday to agree to the creation of a Palestinian state, in a meeting that left European diplomats bewildered about postwar Israeli plans for the Gaza Strip and reinforced the deep disconnect between Israel and much of the world.

headline: Trump Rakes In Endorsements in Final Hours Before New Hampshire Votes
abstract: In a show of unity, three of Donald Trump’s former rivals for the nomination are appearing alongside him at a rally on Monday night in Laconia, N.H.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has received a flood of endorsements in the final countdown to New Hampshire’s primary, as his allies argue that the 2024 Republican nominating contest is all but over.

headline: Ex-U.S. Soldier Who Killed Iraqi Civilian Charged with Attacking Police on Jan. 6
abstract: Edward Richmond Jr., 40, of Geismar, La., was convicted of manslaughter after he shot a cow herder in Iraq in 2004. He now faces felony assault charges in connection to the 2021 Capitol riot.
lead_paragraph: A former U.S. Army soldier who was convicted of voluntary manslaughter in the killing of an Iraqi civilian in 2004 was charged on Monday with assaulting police officers with a baton during the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, the Justice Department announced.

headline: The Menu Trends That Define Dining Right Now
abstract: We gathered 121 menus from restaurants all over the country. Together, they offer a glimpse into the tastes and values of today.
lead_paragraph: We gathered 121 menus from restaurants all over the country. Together, they offer a glimpse into the tastes and values of today.

headline: Appeals Court Revives Mexico’s Lawsuit Against Gunmakers
abstract: The decision, which is likely to be appealed, is one of the most significant setbacks for the gun industry since passage of a federal law that provided immunity from some lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals panel in Boston ruled on Monday that a $10 billion lawsuit filed by Mexico against U.S. gun manufacturers whose weapons are used by drug cartels can proceed, reversing a lower court that had dismissed the case.

headline: Suspect in Fatal Shootings of 8 in Illinois Is Found Dead in Texas
abstract: Romeo Nance, 23, is believed to have fatally shot himself on Monday night in Texas following the spate of shootings on Sunday and Monday in Joliet, Ill., the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in the fatal shooting of eight people in Joliet, Ill., fatally shot himself Monday evening after an hours-long manhunt and confrontation with law enforcement in South Texas, the authorities said.

headline: How a Ballerina Pirouettes
abstract: Patrick Maher makes a chic debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Norman Jewison Was a Versatile Director. These 6 Films Show His Range.
abstract: From “In the Heat of the Night” to “Fiddler on the Roof” and “Moonstruck,” the director always brought heart and humanity to his work.
lead_paragraph: The oeuvre of director Norman Jewison, who died this past weekend at the age of 97, can’t be simply categorized. His versatility was rarely matched by any of his peers. He made epic musicals like “Fiddler on the Roof,” heart-stirring romantic comedies like “Moonstruck” and tense social thrillers like “In the Heat of the Night.” Over his decades in Hollywood, he directed everything from the Cold War comedy “The Russians Are Coming, the Russians Are Coming” (1966) to the sexy heist feature “The Thomas Crown Affair” (1968) to the based-on-a-true-story drama “The Hurricane” (1999). While the divergent tones could imply that Jewison was something of a journeyman, instead he brought a humanity to every story he touched, treating each one, regardless of subject matter, with the grace it deserved. Here are some films of his available to stream, no matter your mood.

headline: At Columbia, Student Protesters Say They Were Attacked With Chemicals
abstract: After pro-Palestinian students said they had been sprayed with a foul-smelling substance during a demonstration, the university began an investigation and barred those accused from campus.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University and the Police Department are investigating reports that pro-Palestinian student demonstrators were sprayed with a foul-smelling chemical during a protest last week, leading the university on Monday to bar the people accused of spraying it from campus.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 23, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about Israeli female combat soldiers misidentified the type of weapon that Israeli troops were equipped with during a 12-hour battle along the Gaza border. They had Light Antitank Weapons, or LAWs, not Lau missiles.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Elections and Disinformation Collide in Year Ripe for Chaos
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We’re going to hit 2025 and the world is going to look very different.”

headline: San Diego Floods Sweep Away Cars
abstract: In one video, the floodwaters lifted a car and carried it away. Another showed water spewing from a sewer onto a parked car.
lead_paragraph: In one video, the floodwaters lifted a car and carried it away. Another showed water spewing from a sewer onto a parked car.

headline: What to Watch in the New Hampshire Primary
abstract: A crowded G.O.P. field is down to only two: former President Donald J. Trump, and former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina. Democrats have mounted a write-in campaign for President Biden.
lead_paragraph: New Hampshire voters head to the polls on Tuesday for the first presidential primary of the 2024 nomination cycle, in a state that has been known to throw curveballs at overwhelming favorites.

headline: China’s Travel Economy Is Slowly Coming Back. Here’s Where It Stands.
abstract: Over a year after China opened its borders following the pandemic, international trips are still lagging, although domestic travel is more popular.
lead_paragraph: Since China reopened its borders in 2023 after three years of Covid isolation, domestic travel has thrived and high-speed rail has grown increasingly popular. But international trips in and out of the country are lagging, and flight capacity is still just two-thirds of prepandemic levels.

headline: Remote African Hub Reopens for Migrants Headed Toward Europe
abstract: Agadez, a desert outpost in the West African country of Niger, was officially closed to migration for years in a deal with the European Union. Now, the gate has reopened.
lead_paragraph: The bus station in Agadez, a remote city of low mud-brick buildings in the West African nation of Niger, is buzzing again.

headline: Our Rodent Selfies, Ourselves
abstract: A photographer trained two rats to take photographs of themselves. They didn’t want to stop.
lead_paragraph: When Augustin Lignier, a professional photographer in Paris, was in graduate school, he began to ponder the point of picture-taking in the modern world: Why did so many of us feel compelled to photograph our lives and share those images online?

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Strikes by Britain and the U.S. in Yemen.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. and Britain carried out large-scale military strikes against eight sites in Yemen controlled by Houthi militants, according to the two countries. The strikes — the eighth in two weeks — signaled that the Biden administration was intending to wage a sustained campaign against the Iran-backed group, which has disrupted traffic in vital international sea lanes.

headline: Shih Ming-teh, Defiant Activist for a Democratic Taiwan, Dies at 83
abstract: He spent 25 years in prison for campaigning for Taiwan’s independence and democratization. After his release, he led protests to oust one its presidents.
lead_paragraph: Shih Ming-teh, a lifelong campaigner for democracy in Taiwan who spent over two decades in prison for his cause and later started a protest movement against a president from his former party, died on Jan. 15, his 83rd birthday, in Taipei, the island’s capital.

headline: Cal State Professors Reach Tentative Deal to End Strike
abstract: Faculty members and other academic workers in the nation’s largest four-year public university system walked out on Monday just as classes were scheduled to begin at many campuses.
lead_paragraph: The California State University system and the union representing thousands of professors and lecturers reached a tentative deal on Monday to raise wages, ending what was the largest strike by university faculty members in U.S. history.

headline: Last Known Remains Tied to Green River Killer Are Identified
abstract: A Texas lab helped Washington State officials identify the bones more than 40 years after the teen went missing.
lead_paragraph: Investigators have identified the last known remains linked to the Green River Killer, one of the most prolific serial killers in American history, concluding a decades-long effort to identify each of the 49 women and girls he was convicted of killing.

headline: Word of the Day: proportionate
abstract: This word has appeared in 42 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word proportionate has appeared in 42 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 2 in “No Tip for Your Delivery Driver? Then Be Prepared to Wait, DoorDash Says” by Christine Hauser:

headline: Late Night Bids Adieu to G.O.P. Dropout Ron DeSantis
abstract: The now-former presidential candidate “knew it was time to go four months after the rest of us did,” said Jimmy Fallon.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: A Post on Gaza Leads to Turmoil at Australia’s Public Broadcaster
abstract: The hiring and forced departure of a Lebanese Australian journalist has exposed long-simmering issues at one of the country’s most trusted institutions.
lead_paragraph: The social media post simply pointed to a report from Human Rights Watch, but it was critical of Israel and came from a Lebanese Australian journalist whom critics considered biased.

headline: We Talked to the Dixville 6, the Midnight Voters Who All Went for Haley
abstract: Nikki Haley took all six votes in Dixville Notch, but it could be a different story in the rest of the state, as Donald J. Trump has a comfortable lead in the polls.
lead_paragraph: The first votes in the New Hampshire primary have been cast in the township of Dixville Notch.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Walking and Using a Phone is Bad for Your Health
abstract: Hunching over a device can mess with your gait, slow you down and poison your mood. And that’s before you trip and fall.
lead_paragraph: Spend time on any crowded sidewalk and you’ll see heads bent over and eyes cast downward. One recent study of college students found that a quarter of people crossing intersections were glued to a device.

headline: Nikki Haley Wins the First Six Votes in New Hampshire Primary
abstract: Six residents of Dixville Notch, N.H., cast the first ballots of the New Hampshire primary shortly after midnight on Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Six residents of Dixville Notch, N.H., cast the first ballots of the New Hampshire primary shortly after midnight on Tuesday morning.

headline: Takeaways From the Senate Debate in California
abstract: Weeks before the March 5 primary, the four leading candidates for the open Senate seat sparred over Donald Trump, the Middle East and homelessness.
lead_paragraph: In a fiery debate that underscored both California’s generational political shift and Donald J. Trump’s enduring influence even over liberal political races, three of the state’s best known congressional Democrats and a Republican ex-baseball star faced off over a U.S. Senate seat on Monday in Los Angeles.

headline: Things Fall Apart: How the Middle Ground on Immigration Collapsed
abstract: Politicians from both sides used to agree on immigration policy. What happened?
lead_paragraph: Politicians from both sides used to agree on immigration policy. What happened?

headline: 91 Years in a Segregated Mental Institution
abstract: In “Madness,” the journalist Antonia Hylton explores the hidden history of Crownsville Hospital, and America’s continuing failure to care for Black minds.
lead_paragraph: The United States has a long and troubled history of manipulating psychology to control Black Americans, quell resistance, rationalize unpaid labor and justify cruelty.

headline: After a Botched Execution, Alabama Is Trying an Untested Method
abstract: The state plans to carry out the first U.S. execution via nitrogen hypoxia with Kenneth Smith, who survived an earlier attempt to execute him by lethal injection.
lead_paragraph: It was Nov. 17, 2022, and Kenneth Smith was lying on a gurney inside Alabama’s execution chamber, his arms and legs strapped down as he waited to be put to death. Mr. Smith, who had been on death row for more than a quarter-century after being convicted of murdering a woman, recalled thanking God for his final week alive and thinking of his family.

headline: January May Be the Best Month to Get Married. Here’s Why.
abstract: With more vendor availability and less social competition, the drearier months can actually be an ideal time to tie the knot.
lead_paragraph: Consider this one more win for fans of January: Not only does the first month bring less highway traffic, cheaper flights, easier-to-secure restaurant reservations and the accompanying sense of calm, it also comprises part of the slow season in the wedding industry, along with its neighbors December, February and March. In Clark County, Nev., where marriage statistics are publicly available, these are the months when the fewest marriages take place.

headline: Things Fall Apart: How the Middle Ground on Immigration Collapsed
abstract: Politicians from both sides used to agree on immigration policy. What happened?
lead_paragraph: Why have Republicans and Democrats moved so far apart on immigration? That’s the question that drives the Opinion video above.

headline: Swatting and the Dangerous Rise of Political Violence
abstract: Swatting isn’t a harmless prank; it’s a sign of a deeper disorder in American politics.
lead_paragraph: In a year with so much political and legal tension, law enforcement is seeing a disturbing trend: targeting public officials with swatting, or false emergency calls intended to draw a heavily armed police response. This conduct isn’t a harmless prank; it’s a symptom of a deeper disorder in American politics. Recent incidents involving officials who have taken stands seen as hostile to Donald Trump and bomb threats in multiple state capitols are signs of a troubling escalation in political violence.

headline: Jury to Decide if Mother of Michigan School Shooter Is Guilty, Too
abstract: Jury selection began on Tuesday in the trial of Jennifer Crumbley, whose son, Ethan Crumbley, killed four students in 2021. In a rare move, prosecutors have charged both of his parents with involuntary manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: Frequently left home alone, Ethan Crumbley texted his mother in March 2021 that he had seen a demon in their house, one that hurled dishes across the kitchen. Days later, his parents, James and Jennifer Crumbley, discussed how their teenage son was “worked up and agitated,” weighing whether to give him Xanax.

headline: ‘Barbie,’ ‘Saltburn,’ Louis Vuitton: When Culture Becomes a TikTok Craze
abstract: Marketing is consuming our culture to the point that the product seems almost irrelevant to its own success.
lead_paragraph: In today’s creative economy, the tail increasingly wags the dog. Marketing is driving culture as promotional campaigns overshadow the offerings they seek to elevate — in fashion, music, art and film. With fashion weeks taking place around the world and awards season well underway, the hype machine is operating at full throttle. But few products, if any, can compete with such fanfare. On the runway, the red carpet and beyond, culture is at risk of being subsumed by the sound and the fury, the hype and the buzz, of its own promotion.

headline: With Melodrama and Memes, a Yakuza Game Series Charms America
abstract: The Like a Dragon role-playing games follow a gangster through facsimiles of Japanese cities. With earnest goofiness, they’ve found an international audience.
lead_paragraph: It all started with a chicken named Nugget.

headline: The Man Who All but Created Vintage Fashion
abstract: Fifty years ago Didier Ludot opened his couture resale boutique in Paris and changed style forever.
lead_paragraph: In July 2022, just before the Balenciaga couture show, Didier Ludot returned from lunch to discover “the longest, most beautiful legs I have ever seen” at his namesake vintage couture boutique in the shopping arcades of the Palais-Royal. They belonged to Nicole Kidman, who was in Paris to walk in the Balenciaga show and was patiently waiting with her husband, Keith Urban.

headline: Brittany Howard Taps Into the Ancestors, and Finds a New Groove
abstract: The singer and guitarist socked away songs grappling with frustration, pain and love during the pandemic. They became her powerful second solo LP, “What Now.”
lead_paragraph: When Brittany Howard was 17, she lived alone, in a haunted house in Athens, Ala., that had belonged to her great-grandmother.

headline: National Association of Realtors Faces Competition From New Group
abstract: Mauricio Umansky, a celebrity agent, and Jason Haber, a vocal critic of N.A.R., say it’s time for an alternative to the longtime organization.
lead_paragraph: Two prominent real estate agents have started a new trade association in a direct swipe at the embattled National Association of Realtors.

headline: How Trial Delays Could Pay Off for Trump
abstract: Donald J. Trump faces four criminal trials this year, but appeals and postponements could mean only one or two finish before the election.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump faces four criminal trials this year, but appeals and postponements could mean only one or two finish before the election.

headline: Boeing Made a Change to Its Corporate Culture Decades Ago. Now It’s Paying the Price.
abstract: What will it take for the airline company to recover?
lead_paragraph: We often use the word “iconic” to describe companies such as Xerox, U.S. Steel and General Electric when we really mean “no longer great.” And Boeing no longer is.

headline: What’s a Never-Trump Conservative to Do?
abstract: On the eve of New Hampshire’s primary, David French makes a final plea.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is expected to win decisively in New Hampshire’s primary on Tuesday. For Republican voters who don’t want Trump as their nominee, what alternatives exist?

headline: I Didn’t Want Wedding Presents. But Gifts Helped Me Survive My Divorce.
abstract: The case for a new ritual that acknowledges this strange, tender moment of rupture.
lead_paragraph: When I married, we didn’t have a registry. We’d already combined two households; we had plenty of things. Downsizing felt more important than acquiring. But we ended up getting gifts anyway, and I treasured many of them: a ceramic plate painted with the mountains my friend loved so dearly; a tear-shaped nautical storm glass meant to divine the weather. These objects, incongruous and surprising, nothing we had chosen for ourselves, felt like ways our friends were co-signing on our new life together and stitching themselves into its daily weave. When we divorced, five years later in 2019, it felt — among other things — like a betrayal of those early vouches of faith. Standing in an empty kitchen in a bare apartment, tasked with building a new household from scratch, I started thinking, I wouldn’t mind a registry now.

headline: How to Talk About Auschwitz
abstract: “Lovers in Auschwitz” and “Cold Crematorium,” two works by journalists published 74 years apart, offer different ways of representing the horrors of the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: “Lovers in Auschwitz” is, as the title portends, a nonfiction account of two Jews who became lovers in Auschwitz. The journalist Keren Blankfeld adapted it from her viral 2019 New York Times article and structured the book as a kind of braided biography; alternating chapters tell the story of David, a boy from Poland who dreams of becoming a singer, and of Zippi, a confident, talented girl from Slovakia.

headline: The Cosmic Genius of Iris van Herpen
abstract: Her one-woman exhibition at the Musée des Arts Décoratifs redefines the couture show.
lead_paragraph: It is possible that the most dazzling couture show in Paris this week is not actually taking place on a runway at all, but in an entirely different sort of setting. Possible that said couture show is not an invitation-only affair with gold ballroom chairs and the latest celebrity du jour, but rather one open to the public. And certain that it is less about nostalgia for a past when couture was defined by the whispering of silk satin ball gowns, and more about a dream of the future.

headline: To Slash Carbon Emissions, Colleges Are Digging Really Deep
abstract: A growing number of colleges and universities are using deep underground pipes to heat and cool their buildings without burning fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: When administrators at Princeton University decided to cut the carbon emissions that came from heating and cooling their campus, they opted for a method that is gaining popularity among colleges and universities.

headline: George Santos, Clinging to His 15 Minutes
abstract: “People still want to hear what I have to say,” said the disgraced ex-congressman, who will be in court today.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about where former Representative George Santos is expected this morning. We’ll also get details on a city plan to eliminate up to $2 billion in unpaid medical debt for as many as 500,000 people.

headline: Everything You Need to Know About New Hampshire
abstract: It’s Trump vs. Haley in the second contest of the 2024 race. Here’s what we’re watching.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language.

headline: The Great Freight-Train Heists of the 21st Century
abstract: The explosion of the e-commerce economy has created an opportunity for thieves — and a conundrum for the railways.
lead_paragraph: Of all the dozens of suspected thieves questioned by the detectives of the Train Burglary Task Force at the Los Angeles Police Department during the months they spent investigating the rise in theft from the city’s freight trains, one man stood out. What made Victor Llamas memorable wasn’t his criminality so much as his giddy enthusiasm for trespassing. He was a self-taught expert of the supply chain, a connoisseur of shipping containers. Even in custody, as the detectives interrogated him numerous times, after multiple arrests, in a windowless police-station room in the spring of 2022, a kind of nostalgia would sweep over the man. “He said that was the best feeling he’d ever had, jumping on the train while it was moving,” Joe Chavez, who supervised the task force’s detectives, told me. “It was euphoric for him.”

headline: Did No One Tell Ron DeSantis That Trump Was Running, Too?
abstract: It sure felt that way sometimes.
lead_paragraph: Despite the early enthusiasm for his policies and political persona in various corners of the conservative media, it was easy to see from the start that Ron DeSantis would not — and clearly does not — have the juice to defeat or supplant Donald Trump in a Republican presidential primary.

headline: Detroit Businesses Are Loving the Lions’ Playoff Run
abstract: The N.F.L. team’s success in the playoffs has provided much joy and a boost for local businesses around the team’s stadium.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Lions, whose roots stretch back to 1930, are just one of four N.F.L. teams to have never played in the Super Bowl. (Pop quiz: Can you guess the other three?) Before this season, the team had won only one playoff game since Dwight D. Eisenhower was president. So Lions fans were justifiably delirious when their team won its division for the first time in three decades and broke its playoff drought this month, beating the Los Angeles Rams and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. The team’s playoff run has provided much joy and a boost for local businesses around Ford Field, the team’s stadium.

headline: A Moody Renovation in Melbourne
abstract: The reimagined home in Australia is ‘just joyful and really easy to live in.’
lead_paragraph: The reimagined home in Australia is ‘just joyful and really easy to live in.’

headline: In Australia, an Old Victorian With a Moody Modernist Vibe
abstract: It’s not as scary as it sounds: ‘It’s just joyful and really easy to live in.’
lead_paragraph: Ariane and Andrew Vincent’s former home in Melbourne, Australia, was the kind of place people dream about: a three-story house near the beach with views of Port Phillip Bay.

headline: Stripped, Beaten or Vanished: Israel’s Treatment of Gaza Detainees Raises Alarm
abstract: A U.N. office said Israel’s detention and treatment of detainees might amount to torture. It estimated thousands had been detained and held in “horrific” conditions. Some were freed wearing only diapers.
lead_paragraph: Cold, almost naked and surrounded by Israeli soldiers with M16 assault rifles, Ayman Lubbad knelt among dozens of Palestinian men and boys who had just been forced from their homes in northern Gaza.

headline: Israel Says Its Military Has Encircled Khan Younis in Gaza
abstract: The fighting in the southern city has involved heavy exchanges of gunfire and a surge of tanks and troops into areas around hospitals.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military said on Tuesday that it had encircled the city of Khan Younis in southern Gaza, part of a push that has resulted in intense fighting and bombardments in an area packed with civilians who have fled their homes in other parts of the territory.

headline: China Appears to Backpedal From Video Game Crackdown
abstract: A proposal to tighten restrictions on online video games disappeared from a regulator’s website, weeks after the plan prompted a sell-off in tech stocks.
lead_paragraph: Chinese regulators on Tuesday appeared to backpedal from a plan to reduce how much money people spend on online video games, after the proposal had tanked video gaming companies’ stocks and raised doubts about the government’s commitment to reviving China’s slowing economy.

headline: The Shadowy Story of Oppenheimer and Congress
abstract: A reporter’s journey into how the U.S. funded the bomb.
lead_paragraph: Nominations for the Oscars are announced on Tuesday and “Oppenheimer,” a film about the father of the atomic bomb, is expected to be among the front-runners.

headline: Trump vs. Haley in New Hampshire, and North Korean Missiles in Ukraine
abstract: Plus, menu trends to watch.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The End of Economic Pessimism?
abstract: Seven reasons Americans are down on the economy.
lead_paragraph: By many measures, the U.S. economy is strong right now. Unemployment is near its lowest point in decades. Inflation has slowed down. Wages have grown faster than prices since last year. Stock prices have surged.

headline: Russian Missiles Hit Ukrainian Cities Amid Fears Over Air Defenses
abstract: The assault killed at least five people and wounded scores in Kyiv and Kharkiv. Ukraine is pushing for further American military aid, which has been stalled in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Russia launched a combination of cruise and ballistic missiles at Ukrainian cities on Tuesday in a large volley that killed at least 19 people and injured another 120, according to local authorities. The assault added to concerns about the state of Ukraine’s air defenses as Russian barrages continue on its largest cities.

headline: Should Colleges Consider Standardized Tests in Admissions?
abstract: Many colleges have stopped requiring the SAT and ACT. Is that a mistake?
lead_paragraph: Many colleges have stopped requiring standardized tests like the SAT and ACT for admissions. Are you planning on going to college? If so, are you planning to take the SAT and ACT? Or do the schools you want to attend no longer require them?

headline: Breakfast
abstract: Do you eat a balanced, healthy meal to start your day?
lead_paragraph: How important is breakfast to you? Do you have a favorite morning meal? Cereal? Eggs and toast? Pancakes? A bagel with cream cheese?

headline: When Will We Get Results for the New Hampshire Primary?
abstract: The Associated Press made its race call in the 2016 Republican primary right at 8 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: The very first results in the New Hampshire primary became available within minutes of midnight on Tuesday.

headline: Oscar Nominees 2024: See the Full List
abstract: The complete list of Academy Award nominees for 2024.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2024 Oscar nominations.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: U.S. Airstrikes, Extreme Cold, 'Mean Girls'
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Jack Ma Doubles Down on Alibaba
abstract: China’s most famous entrepreneur has been out of the spotlight after clashing with officials. But in recent months, he has been buying shares in the tech giant he co-founded as its stock has plunged.
lead_paragraph: Jack Ma, the co-founder of Alibaba, has largely disappeared from public view after clashing with Chinese officials over his outsize persona and critical comments about the government. And he had appeared to distance himself from the tech giant last year by giving up control of Ant Group, a fintech sister company of Alibaba.

headline: An English Mystery: What Killed 7 Giant Tortoises Found in the Forest?
abstract: Several giant tortoises were found dead in Ashclyst Forest in Southwest England. What happened is anyone’s guess.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t your usual crime scene. And they weren’t your usual victims. But it was a tragedy nonetheless, one that has grabbed the authorities’ attention in a sleepy corner of England.

headline: In Vietnam, Star-Crossed Lovers Brave the Tides of War
abstract: Andrew X. Pham’s first novel, “Twilight Territory,” imagines an unlikely romance during a nation’s fight for independence.
lead_paragraph: On a recent trip back through the pages of Andrew X. Pham’s 1999 memoir, “Catfish and Mandala,” a line jumped out that felt almost like the seed of his new book, planted 25 years ago. Pham, about to leave his home in the United States and set off on a solo bicycle voyage through Japan and Vietnam, briefly recaps these countries’ violently intertwined histories. His reason for starting in Japan, he writes, is “to see for myself the third link of this love triangle.” In Pham’s first novel, “Twilight Territory,” a figurative connection between Vietnam and Japan takes the form of a literal one: the tragic love story between a Vietnamese woman and a Japanese soldier.

headline: Who Says a Novel About Guns and Opioids Can’t Be Funny?
abstract: “Last Acts,” by Alexander Sammartino, is a satire of contemporary America set at a firearms shop in Phoenix.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Sammartino’s exceptional, hilarious debut novel, “Last Acts,” is the tale of two salesmen in Phoenix: David Rizzo and his estranged son, Nick. Both men’s lives are floundering. Rizzo Sr. is drowning in debt and about to lose his firearms store because of several failed moneymaking and promotional schemes; his son has drifted from a gig-economy career as a digital marketer to become a full-time heroin addict.

headline: A Hazard for Visitors to Colombia: ‘Devil’s Breath’
abstract: Powerful sedatives are behind a spate of violent crimes, U.S. officials say. Many victims are Americans in Medellín who use dating apps.
lead_paragraph: Steven Valdez thought he recognized the woman in the Medellín park. Chatting, the two realized they had matched on the dating platform Tinder. They exchanged numbers and made plans.

headline: Lily Gladstone on Her History-Making Oscar Nomination
abstract: “I didn’t expect that I would cry the way that I did,” said the actress, who is up for best actress for her role in “Killers of the Flower Moon.”
lead_paragraph: Lily Gladstone shed a few tears when she heard Jack Quaid read her name in the best actress Oscars category on Tuesday morning. “I didn’t expect that I would cry the way that I did,” she said. But it was nothing compared with the reaction of her parents.

headline: Colman Domingo’s Oscar Nomination Is Only the Second of Its Kind
abstract: For his role in “Rustin,” Domingo became only the second openly gay man to earn a nomination for playing a gay character.
lead_paragraph: Colman Domingo joined a rarefied club on Tuesday: With an Oscar nomination for his performance as the civil rights activist Bayard Rustin in “Rustin,” he became only the second openly gay man to be nominated for playing a gay character. Ian McKellen was the first, in 1999, for “Gods and Monsters” and his portrayal of James Whale, the real-life director of the iconic 1930s horror films “Frankenstein” and “Bride of Frankenstein.”

headline: Cal State and Its Faculty Reach a Tentative Deal
abstract: The agreement between the California State University system and the faculty union ended what was the largest strike by university professors in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: The California State University system and the union representing thousands of professors and lecturers said Monday night that they had reached a tentative deal to raise wages, quickly ending what was the largest strike by university faculty in U.S. history.

headline: Iran Executes 23-Year-Old Man in Further Crackdown on Protests
abstract: Dozens of psychiatrists had appealed for Mohammad Ghobadlou’s mental state to be examined before sentencing.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian authorities hanged a 23-year-old man early Tuesday, the latest in a string of executions linked to the large-scale protests that shook the country in the fall of 2022.

headline: Germany’s Top Court Bans Public Financing for Neo-Nazi Party
abstract: The ruling also denies the tax advantages that are normally granted to political organizations, a decision that could offer a path for government efforts to head off a resurgence of the far right.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s top court on Tuesday stripped a neo-Nazi party of the right to public financing and the tax advantages normally extended to political organizations, a decision that could provide a blueprint for government efforts to head off a resurgence of the far right.

headline: Police Officer Who Threw Cooler at Fleeing Man Charged With Manslaughter
abstract: Erik Duran, a police sergeant, was part of drug-sting operation in the Bronx when he tried to stop a suspect on a motorbike. The man lost control, crashed and died.
lead_paragraph: A police sergeant who threw a cooler at a Bronx man in August, knocking him off a motorbike and killing him, has been arrested and charged with manslaughter, assault and criminally negligent homicide.

headline: Nikki Haley Memo Ahead of New Hampshire: ‘We Aren’t Going Anywhere’
abstract: Donald Trump and his allies have worked to make her departure from the race feel inevitable, if not immediate. With voting underway, Ms. Haley’s camp is pushing back.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley’s campaign has a message for all those who are declaring her presidential candidacy all but over should she lose in New Hampshire to Donald J. Trump on Tuesday.

headline: Read the document
abstract: In a memo, Nikki Haley’s campaign manager wrote that “We aren’t going anywhere.”
lead_paragraph: In a memo, Nikki Haley’s campaign manager wrote that “We aren’t going anywhere.”

headline: The Biggest Oscar Snubs and Surprises 2024: Greta Gerwig and Margot Robbie Miss Out in Key Races
abstract: It was a strong year for female directors overall, though the academy still seems to frown on younger male actors.
lead_paragraph: Though “Oppenheimer” made an explosive showing when the Oscar nominations were announced on Tuesday morning, plenty of other would-be contenders failed to launch. As your Projectionist, here’s my analysis of the morning’s biggest surprises and omissions.

headline: Remnants of Sprawling Ancient Cities Are Found in the Amazon
abstract: Archaeologists, relying on laser technology and decades of research, mapped a cluster of ancient cities in eastern Ecuador. Their findings add to evidence of dense settlements in Amazonia.
lead_paragraph: The Amazon valley looked like so many others, with a muddy river snaking through dense forest, except that this one had earthen mounds rising at clear right angles and ditches carving long straight lines through the soil.

headline: Dominic Sessa: Fashion’s Latest Obsession
abstract: With his debut in “The Holdovers,” the actor, in Paris for the men’s wear shows, has caught the eye of fashion brands.
lead_paragraph: This is a season of firsts for Dominic Sessa — a wondrous Cinderella moment on the threshold of further adventures in fame. Not yet two weeks out from the Golden Globes, when the 21-year-old actor sauntered onto the red carpet — tousle-haired in a Saint Laurent suit, his black silk shirt unbuttoned, his eyes hidden behind dark shades — unleashing a million online stans, he arrived in Paris for his first time at the fashion shows.
