lead_paragraph: An unexpected surge of waves crashed through a set of doors at U.S. Army Garrison Kwajalein Atoll on Roi-Namur, causing significant damage.

headline: New Hampshire and Iowa Reveal Broader Weaknesses for Trump
abstract: As Donald J. Trump pivots to a general election, early results point at the rough road ahead with critical independent voters.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Donald J. Trump has romped through Iowa and New Hampshire without breaking a sweat, muscling out rivals for the Republican nomination and soaking up adoration from crowds convinced he will be the next president of the United States.

headline: Hillary Clinton on ‘Barbie’ Snubs: You’re ‘More Than Kenough’
abstract: The former presidential candidate joined the chorus of disappointment in the omission of Greta Gerwig and Margot Robbie from the best director and best actress Oscar categories.
lead_paragraph: It was hard for fans of last year’s blockbuster film “Barbie” to ignore the twist of fate on Tuesday when Greta Gerwig, the movie’s director, and Margot Robbie, its titular star, were shut out of the best director and best actress Oscar categories. It could have quite literally been a plot point in the movie, which serves as a lesson on the patriarchal structures that shape our institutions and our ways of thinking.

headline: Review: They Fly. They Spin. They Change How You See the Amazing.
abstract: In Compagnie Hervé Koubi’s “Sol Invictus” at the Joyce Theater, the dancers’ extraordinary moves are integrated into a poetic vision.
lead_paragraph: The dancers of Compagnie Hervé Koubi spend a lot of time upside down. Inverted, they spin on one or both hands or on their heads, legs spiraling. Upright, they bound into the air, as if off trampolines, ball up their bodies and rapidly rotate in high-flying arcs. They toss one another even higher.

headline: Israel and Hamas’s Cease-Fire and Hostage Deal Proposals: What to Know
abstract: The negotiations continue, but the sides are far apart on issues including the fate of Hamas’s top leadership in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: The director of the C.I.A. is set to make a renewed push for negotiations over the release of hostages held in Gaza and an extended cease-fire, according to U.S. officials, who said he would meet with senior Israeli, Egyptian and Qatari officials in Europe.

headline: Europe Faces a Measles Outbreak
abstract: When vaccinations begin to lag, as they did during the pandemic, measles is often the first disease to resurge. “It’s the canary in the coal mine,” one expert said.
lead_paragraph: Measles, a disease preventable by vaccination, is resurgent in parts of Europe, including Britain. Small outbreaks have also popped up in multiple parts of the United States.

headline: How Haley Lost New Hampshire: Ignoring Lessons From Underdogs of the Past
abstract: The state has offered defeated candidates second chances and improbable victories, but Nikki Haley couldn’t get voters to throw her a life vest.
lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain’s first town hall in May 1999 was awful. Thirteen people milled around at a nearly empty American Legion Hall in Manchester, and only nine of them were still deciding whom to vote for in the first-in-the-nation primary.

headline: Howard Golden, Who Led, and Defended, Brooklyn, Dies at 98
abstract: Before it staged a revival, he was the borough’s president and Democratic leader for a quarter-century, sometimes clashing with mayors.
lead_paragraph: Howard Golden, who as Brooklyn borough president for a quarter-century pressed to strengthen the borough economically and defended it against slights real or perceived in the years before it experienced a gentrifying revival, died on Wednesday at his home in the Kensington section of Brooklyn. He was 98.

headline: Dan Wagoner, Acclaimed Modern Dancer, Is Dead at 91
abstract: He worked with the Martha Graham and Paul Taylor troupes and then created his own group, Dan Wagoner and Dancers.
lead_paragraph: Dan Wagoner, who danced with Martha Graham, was an early member of the Paul Taylor Dance Company and led his own well-regarded troupe for 25 years, died on Friday in Oakland, Md. He was 91.

headline: Katherine Maher Named C.E.O. of NPR
abstract: Ms. Maher was previously chief executive of the Wikimedia Foundation, a nonprofit that supports the online encyclopedia Wikipedia.
lead_paragraph: NPR announced on Wednesday that Katherine Maher would be its next chief executive, picking a leader with an extensive track record in the nonprofit world but without one in the realm of public radio.

headline: Powerful Waves Slam U.S. Army Base in the Marshall Islands
abstract: A video circulating on social media showed water rushing into a room at U.S. Army Garrison Kwajalein Atoll as a series of unexpected waves surged across the low-lying island of Roi-Namur.
lead_paragraph: A surge of unexpected waves swamped the island of Roi-Namur in the Marshall Islands on Saturday, forcing evacuations from a U.S. military base and causing damage that could take months to repair.

headline: ‘Tired of Being Quiet,’ Sarah Jarosz Tests the Mainstream
abstract: With her new album, “Polaroid Lovers,” a luminary of Americana broadens her sound.
lead_paragraph: In modern Nashville, songwriting is often a matter of professionalized co-writing: planned, mix-and-match collaborations by appointment, musicians sharing a room to come up with sturdy material.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? Drake and More
abstract: I’m a New York Times reporter on the Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve been watching, listening to and playing.
lead_paragraph: I’m a New York Times reporter on the Culture desk. Here are five things I’ve been watching, listening to and playing.

headline: Shipping Costs Soar in Wake of Red Sea Attacks
abstract: Ships risking Houthi attacks must pay high insurance premiums, while vessels avoiding the region lose time going around Africa.
lead_paragraph: For about two months, a barrage of missile and drone attacks in the Red Sea by Houthi militants has posed a difficult choice to shipowners using the Suez Canal: risk an airborne strike and pay sharply higher insurance rates, or forgo the canal and take the longer route around Africa, snarling schedules and entailing higher fuel charges.

headline: A.I. Should Be a Tool, Not a Curse, for the Future of Work
abstract: Maybe machines will be able to take our jobs. But it doesn’t have to be that way.
lead_paragraph: If you aren’t already scared about artificial intelligence, you will be after you read the next sentence: “If science continues undisrupted, the chance of unaided machines outperforming humans in every possible task was estimated at 10 percent by 2027, and 50 percent by 2047.”

headline: After Early Primary Victories, Republicans in Congress Fall in Line Behind Trump
abstract: The former president’s win in New Hampshire has melted away much of the remaining opposition to him among Republicans on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, the Georgia Republican and die-hard ally of former President Donald J. Trump, was exasperated with her colleagues as she left the House floor last Thursday evening.

headline: This Simple Ingredient Makes So Many Meals Shine
abstract: Coconut milk effortlessly lends its subtly sweet flavor and richness to countless recipes.
lead_paragraph: As much as I worship the seasonal and the fresh when it comes to ingredients, there are a handful of canned products that are sacred in my kitchen. Coconut milk is one of them.

headline: Ohio to Ban Transition Care After Lawmakers Override Governor’s Veto
abstract: The law bans gender-affirming care for minors and prohibits transgender girls and women from playing on high school or college sports teams that match with their gender identity.
lead_paragraph: Ohio lawmakers on Wednesday overrode Gov. Mike DeWine’s veto of a bill that would bar transgender minors from receiving puberty blockers, hormone therapy or gender transition surgery.

headline: New York City Is ‘Back From the Brink,’ Mayor Says in Upbeat Speech
abstract: In his third State of the City speech, Mayor Eric Adams played down the migrant crisis and focused on a dip in crime and rise in jobs in the city.
lead_paragraph: After facing mounting challenges in his second year in office, Mayor Eric Adams on Wednesday used his third State of the City address to deliver a rah-rah overview of his tenure, highlighting improvements in public safety and jobs while playing down the migrant crisis that has overwhelmed New York City’s shelter system.

headline: At White Columns Annual, Outsiders Mix With Insiders
abstract: “Looking Back,” the nonprofit gallery’s group show, brings together self-taught and highly trained artists. It isn’t obvious who’s who.
lead_paragraph: It’s pleasantly disorienting to enter the White Columns Annual in New York in 2024 and see so much work that could have been, and was, made any time in the last half century. There’s not a screen, QR code or 3-D print in sight. But since its inauguration in 2006, the nonprofit gallery’s “Looking Back” series has made an old-school proposition: to curate a group show around one person’s (or collective’s) taste, shorn of commercial or institutional impulses to either move product or capture a zeitgeist.

headline: MoMA Sued by Artist Who Performed Nude in Marina Abramovic Work
abstract: The artist, John Bonafede, says museum officials failed to prevent visitors from sexually assaulting performers in the 2010 show.
lead_paragraph: A performance artist has sued the Museum of Modern Art, saying that officials neglected to take corrective action after several visitors groped him during a nude performance for the 2010 retrospective “Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present.”

headline: Brad Stone Named Editor of Bloomberg Businessweek
abstract: Mr. Stone will take the helm as the 94-year-old magazine shifts from weekly to monthly publication.
lead_paragraph: Brad Stone, a veteran technology journalist, will be the next editor of Bloomberg Businessweek, the company said on Wednesday.

headline: San Francisco Tried to Build a $1.7 Million Toilet. It’s Still Not Done.
abstract: An expensive public bathroom project has come to symbolize the city’s bureaucratic inefficiencies.
lead_paragraph: You could say San Francisco’s charming Noe Valley neighborhood has it all.

headline: Naomi Feil, Who Promoted Empathy as a Response to Dementia, Dies at 91
abstract: She trained caregivers to “validate” the delusions of older people with dementia, rather than try to wrest them into the real world.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Feil was only 8 years old when she moved into what was then known as a home for the aged, where her parents worked. Living there until she left for college, she learned firsthand, by trial and error, how to comfort and communicate with older adults.

headline: ‘Barbie’ Is Bad. There, I Said It.
abstract: There’s a crucial difference between liking the idea of a movie and liking the movie itself.
lead_paragraph: We can all agree 2023 was a good year for the movies. Critically and commercially, several movies did well, and only one of those successes took place within the Marvel cinematic universe. Even the 10 Oscar nominees for best picture, announced on Tuesday, included nine actually good films.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Military Plane Crashes in Russia
abstract: Plus, can the world’s biggest cruise ship be climate friendly?
lead_paragraph: A large Russian military transport plane crashed yesterday in the Belgorod region near the border with Ukraine, killing everyone onboard, the Russian Defense Ministry said.

headline: Haley’s Fancy-but-Not-So-Fancy Dress May Have Been Just What She Intended
abstract: What Donald J. Trump meant as a barb at his rival, Nikki Haley, may have ultimately highlighted the look, and the message, she was going for.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t only Nikki Haley’s promise after the New Hampshire Republican primary that she would continue to fight that got under Donald J. Trump’s skin, apparently; it was her clothes, too.

headline: Utility Must Pay $85 Million to People Affected by Oregon Wildfires, Jury Rules
abstract: The verdict is the latest legal development against PacifiCorp, which was found liable for damages for not cutting power to its customers during the devastating wildfires.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Portland, Ore., awarded $85 million on Tuesday to nine people who had losses from wildfires that devastated communities and burned millions of acres in September 2020. The verdict is the latest development against the electric utility company PacifiCorp over its responsibility for the fires.

headline: Tesla Profit From Car Sales Falls as Price Cuts Hurt
abstract: A tax benefit boosted quarterly earnings, but that masked a decline in earnings from carmaking caused by intensifying competition.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s profit from sales of electric cars slumped in the last three months of last year because of price cuts intended to thwart increasingly intense competition, the company said on Wednesday as it warned of a tough year ahead.

headline: ‘The Daily’: Stories on the Conflict Between Israel and Gaza
abstract: Listeners of “The Daily” hear Israelis and Gazans express their fears, hopes and experiences in real time.
lead_paragraph: When Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, “The Daily” began conceiving a series of personal stories. These five episodes are based on reporting, interviews and ideas original to “The Daily,” and reflect the goal of telling the story of the war with complexity and nuance through the voices of those living it in real time. Together, they form a mosaic that captures human stakes and heartbreak.

headline: Carl Andre, 88, Austerely Minimalist Sculptor, Is Dead
abstract: He worked with elemental metals, granite, wood and brick in sculpture “free of human association.” His career was marred by accusations that he had a role in his wife’s fatal plunge.
lead_paragraph: Carl Andre, one of the most influential and ascetic pioneers of Minimalist sculpture, whose career was overshadowed by the accusation that he played a role in the death of his wife, the Cuban American artist Ana Mendieta, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Naomi Watts, Demi Moore and Diane Lane Swan at the Plaza
abstract: The stars of Ryan Murphy’s new series, “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans,” celebrated the premiere at the site of the famed 1966 Black and White Ball.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, actresses, producers and television executives, many draped in black and white feathered gowns, trickled into the Plaza Hotel to celebrate the premiere of FX’s “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans,” a limited series starting on Jan. 31.

headline: Dozens Feared Dead in Collapse of Informal Gold Mine in Mali
abstract: The episode in the country’s southwest highlights the risks faced by miners working in environments with little to no safety measures.
lead_paragraph: Scores of people have died in the West African nation of Mali after an informal gold mine collapsed last week, the country’s Ministry of Mines said on Wednesday, highlighting the risks that countless artisanal miners face in one of Africa’s largest gold-producing countries.

headline: Bounty Hunter Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison for Kidnapping Woman
abstract: Prosecutors said Wayne D. Lozier Jr., 45, of Louisiana, traveled to Missouri to apprehend a woman for a bail bond company that had hired him. But he wasn’t properly licensed in Missouri, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A bounty hunter convicted of kidnapping a woman from her home in Missouri and trying to take her to Louisiana was sentenced on Wednesday to 10 years in prison, prosecutors said.

headline: Arizona G.O.P. Chairman Resigns After Tape Suggests Attempt to Bribe Kari Lake
abstract: The chairman, Jeff DeWit, denied the conversation amounted to bribery, and said Ms. Lake, a Senate candidate, had threatened to release another damaging recording if he did not step down.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of Arizona’s Republican Party resigned abruptly on Wednesday, a day after the publication of a 10-minute recording of a conversation between himself and Kari Lake, a former nominee for governor, in which he appeared to offer a bribe to persuade Ms. Lake to drop her 2024 Senate campaign.

headline: New Hampshire Showed Trump’s Strengths and Weaknesses
abstract: Also, a Russian military plane crashed near Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s comfortable victory last night in New Hampshire’s Republican presidential primary demonstrated his ironclad control of the party’s right-wing base and set him on what could very well be a short march to his third nomination.

headline: Tell Us What Happened to Your House in the Divorce
abstract: The New York Times is looking to talk to people about how they divided their property assets during a divorce.
lead_paragraph: Do you have a story to tell about what happened to your house during a divorce? The New York Times wants to hear how couples divided the value of their homes, likely their largest asset, and what the experience was like for them: Did you sell it and split the proceeds? Did you continue to live in it together, but in separate spaces? Did you alternate who lived in the house to accommodate custody arrangements? We are particularly interested in speaking with people who learned or discovered something new during the process, or had a memorable experience.

headline: How to Exercise When It Feels Impossible
abstract: We all have reasons we can’t work out as much as we want. You can get over them — just don’t call them excuses.
lead_paragraph: We all have reasons we can’t work out as much as we want. You can get over them — just don’t call them excuses.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Playboi Carti, Waxahatchee and 12 More to Watch
abstract: A breakdown of new albums and songs for 2024 (and a handful of possible but dubious releases).
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Male Vanity as Political Weakness
abstract: On the campaign trail, Nikki Haley questioned Donald J. Trump’s vitality. Her jabs seemed to penetrate.
lead_paragraph: If vanity is the soft underbelly of maleness, a vulnerable area between the armor of masculinity and the kill zone, it appears it was Donald J. Trump’s famous self-regard that was the target when Nikki Haley ramped up her attacks on her opponent in New Hampshire this week.

headline: Poor Nikki, Poor Us
abstract: Nikki Haley is the only thing saving us from a full year of just Trump vs. Biden.
lead_paragraph: Two possible ways of looking at New Hampshire’s vote:

headline: Visiting the Most Important Company in the World
abstract: Replicating the chip-making power of T.S.M.C. in the United States will be much harder than Americans realize.
lead_paragraph: “If China takes Taiwan, they will turn the world off, potentially,” Donald Trump told Fox News recently, apparently referring to a potential seizure of one company that is central to, well, pretty much everything. Indeed, it’s arguably the most important company in the world.

headline: Haley Can’t Beat Trump, but She Can Sting Him
abstract: By staying in the race, she’s softening him up for the general election.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley absorbed a double-digit loss to Donald Trump in the New Hampshire Republican primary, but vowed to soldier on: “This race is far from over,” she said Tuesday night. But in truth, as the saying goes, it’s all over but the shouting.

headline: Melanie, Singer Who Made a Solo Splash at Woodstock, Dies at 76
abstract: Just 22 when she charmed the festival crowd, she went on to enjoy success with songs like “Lay Down (Candles in the Rain)” and “Brand New Key.”
lead_paragraph: Melanie, the husky-voiced singer and songwriter who was one of the surprise stars of the Woodstock music festival in 1969 and two years later had a No. 1 single with the disarmingly childlike “Brand New Key,” died on Tuesday. She was 76.

headline: Boeing Reinstalled Panel That Later Blew Out of 737 Max Jet
abstract: Employees at its Washington State factory are said to have removed the door plug for further work before the plane was delivered to Alaska Airlines.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three weeks after a hole blew open on a Boeing 737 Max 9 during an Alaska Airlines flight, terrifying passengers, new details about the jet’s production are intensifying scrutiny of Boeing’s quality-control practices.

headline: That Spotify Daylist That Really ‘Gets’ You? It Was Written by A.I.
abstract: The music-streaming platform’s new “daylist” feature serves users three personalized playlists a day, with titles ranging from quirky to bewildering.
lead_paragraph: Have your Sunday scaries ever given way to a “Nervous Ocean Monday Morning”? Does the weekend truly begin on Friday, or on a “Wild and Free Chaotic Thursday Afternoon”? How should one dress for a “Paranormal Dark Cabaret Evening”?

headline: United Automobile Workers Union Endorses Biden’s Re-Election Bid
abstract: Shawn Fain, the U.A.W. president, said that President Biden had earned the union’s endorsement when he joined striking members on the picket line last fall in an unprecedented show of support by a sitting president.
lead_paragraph: Shawn Fain, the U.A.W. president, said that President Biden had earned the union’s endorsement when he joined striking members on the picket line last fall in an unprecedented show of support by a sitting president.

headline: U.N. Shelter in Besieged Khan Younis Is Struck, and at Least 9 Die
abstract: United Nations officials said a building that was being used as a shelter by about 800 people had been “clearly marked” as one of their facilities. Israel denied responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces pushed deeper into southern Gaza’s largest city on Wednesday, surrounding two major hospitals where thousands of people were seeking safety as a strike on a United Nations shelter killed at least nine people, according to U.N. officials and local health officials.

headline: Six Bodies Found in Mojave Desert in Southern California
abstract: A call for a wellness check led the authorities to the gruesome discovery.
lead_paragraph: A call for a wellness check led the authorities in Southern California to make a gruesome discovery this week: They found six bodies at a remote crossroads in the Mojave Desert.

headline: Biden Vetoes Republican Measure to Block Electric Vehicle Charging Stations
abstract: Republicans and some Democrats tried to repeal a waiver issued by the Biden administration that allows federally funded E.V. chargers to be made from imported iron and steel.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Wednesday vetoed a Republican-led effort that could have thwarted the administration’s plans to invest $7.5 billion to build electric vehicle charging stations across the country.

headline: Supreme Court Declines to Stop Nitrogen Execution in Alabama
abstract: Both the Supreme Court and a federal appeals court denied stays sought by Kenneth Smith, who is scheduled to die on Thursday in the nation’s first nitrogen gas execution.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court and a federal appeals court each declined on Wednesday to intervene to stop Alabama from conducting the nation’s first-ever execution by nitrogen gas, putting the state on track to use the novel method to kill a death row prisoner.

headline: Grounded Boeing Max 9 Jets Could Resume Flying Within Days
abstract: The F.A.A. approved inspection guidelines for the 737s, one of which lost a body panel in flight. Alaska Airlines planned to start using them again on Friday and United on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators on Wednesday cleared the way for Boeing 737 Max 9 jets to fly again — but also said they would put new limits on production of the troubled planes.

headline: Show of Hands
abstract: Sam Ezersky raises the temperature in his grid.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Haley Looks to Fight on Home Turf, Which Her Rival Claims as Trump Country
abstract: Nikki Haley, facing growing doubts and pressure to drop out, has winnowed the race to a one-on-one contest and is looking to make her case in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: A combative Nikki Haley brought her presidential campaign back to South Carolina on Wednesday after a disappointing defeat the night before in New Hampshire, and told a boisterous crowd in a cavernous ballroom in North Charleston that she would fight Donald J. Trump for the Republican nomination.

headline: How Did These Strange Songs Hit No. 1?
abstract: Melanie’s “Brand New Key” is just one of many weird songs that somehow topped the Billboard charts.
lead_paragraph: When Melanie’s “Brand New Key” debuted in 1971, some people were confused. What did the singer, who died on Tuesday at 76, mean when she sang about having a brand-new pair of roller skates and someone else having a brand-new key?

headline: Biden Urges Congress to Quickly Approve F-16 Sale to Turkey
abstract: The White House sent a letter to four senior lawmakers, one day after Turkey’s Parliament voted to allow Sweden to join NATO.
lead_paragraph: President Biden sent a letter to four senior members of Congress on Wednesday urging them to quickly approve a $20 billion sale of F-16 fighter jets to Turkey, following the vote one day earlier by Turkey’s Parliament to allow Sweden to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, according to three U.S. officials.

headline: Florida Eliminates Sociology as a Core Course at Its Universities
abstract: In December, Florida’s education commissioner wrote that “sociology has been hijacked by left-wing activists.”
lead_paragraph: Students can no longer take sociology to fulfill their core course requirements, Florida’s state university system ruled on Wednesday. Instead, its board of governors approved “a factual history course” as a replacement.

headline: Israel Tries to Rebut Genocide Charge by Declassifying Cabinet Decisions
abstract: South Africa has accused Israel of committing genocide in Gaza. Israel’s legal team has challenged the charge by providing the court with secret orders made by Israel’s civilian and military leaders.
lead_paragraph: Israel has declassified more than 30 secret orders made by government and military leaders, which it says rebut the charge that it committed genocide in Gaza, and instead show Israeli efforts to diminish deaths among Palestinian civilians.

headline: From Opposite Sides of War, a Hunt for Elusive Facts
abstract: The Israel-Hamas conflict has produced a prodigious amount of disinformation, putting people who fact-check claims — especially those who live in the region — back on their heels.
lead_paragraph: In the frantic early hours of Oct. 7, amid wailing sirens and word of gunfights along Israel’s southern border, Achiya Schatz rushed with his toddler and heavily pregnant wife into a bomb shelter near Tel Aviv.

headline: In a New Cannabis Landscape, a Navy Veteran Battles for Racial Equity
abstract: Wanda James is on a mission to empower entrepreneurs from communities harmed by racial disparities in marijuana arrests.
lead_paragraph: “Transforming Spaces” is a series about women driving change in sometimes unexpected places.

headline: More Renters Than Ever Before Are Burdened by the Rent They Pay
abstract: A new Harvard report says 22.4 million households in the United States now spend more than 30 percent of their income in rent, with 12.1 million spending more than 50 percent.
lead_paragraph: Half of all renters in the United States spend more than 30 percent of their income on rent and utilities, more than at any other time in history, according to a new report by Harvard’s Joint Center for Housing Studies.

headline: ‘No Time to Go Wobbly’: Why Britain Is Lobbying U.S. Republicans on Ukraine
abstract: The U.K., often a wingman to the United States in defense, is pushing its ally to stand firm against President Vladimir V. Putin, amid fears that Russia poses an existential threat to Europe.
lead_paragraph: When David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary and onetime prime minister, visited Washington last month, he took time out to press the case for backing Ukraine with Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, the far-right Georgia Republican who stridently opposes further American military aid to the country.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: A military plane crash near the Russian border.
lead_paragraph: A large Russian military transport plane crashed yesterday near the border with Ukraine, killing the 65 Ukrainian prisoners of war, six crew members and three other people on board, the Russian Defense Ministry said, accusing Ukraine of shooting down the plane with missiles.

headline: When Chaos Erupted in Ecuador, Disinformation Followed
abstract: As violence broke out, an overwhelming flood of online disinformation further disoriented the nation.
lead_paragraph: One of the most terrifying spates of violence in Ecuador’s modern history began on Jan. 7. In quick succession, two jailed gang leaders escaped, riots broke out in the country’s main prisons and bombs exploded in several cities. A national television network was stormed by masked gunmen during a live broadcast. A little over a week later, the prosecutor investigating that attack was shot and killed. More than 20 people have been killed in the turmoil.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Six-Day Strike Halts Most German Trains
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I try to use the train for environmental reasons. But then they really should function.”

headline: Corrections: Jan. 25, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Jan. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about religious groups using their land to build affordable housing misstated the connection between Arlington Presbyterian Church and Gilliam Place, an affordable housing complex. The church no longer owns the building or the land it is on; Arlington Partnership for Affordable Housing, a nonprofit developer, does.

headline: Word of the Day: hydrologic
abstract: This word has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word hydrologic has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 27 in “Old Faithful Is Boiling, Smelly and the Perfect Home for These Living Things” by Sarah Derouin:

headline: Late Night Sums Up the New Hampshire Primary
abstract: Jimmy Kimmel joked that Donald Trump beat Nikki Haley by 11 points and that he’s “also leading Haley by double digits in felony charges, 91 to zero.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: A College Essay, Revisited Over 10 Years Later
abstract: After affirmative action fell, students began rewriting their application essays to emphasize race. The moment led a reporter and former essay coach to reflect on the power of the personal statement.
lead_paragraph: The college application essay challenges high school students to distill a formative experience in around 650 words. It may be the first time students write about themselves, the first time they are compelled to meditate on the moments that have shaped who they are, and commit those reflections into words.

headline: He Died in a Tragic Accident. Why Did the Internet Say He Was Murdered?
abstract: Within a day of the death of Matthew Sachman, 19, on New York City subway tracks, so-called obituary pirates had flooded search results with false information.
lead_paragraph: It was the kind of tragic accident that reverberates through a community: a first-year college student, out late in New York City on New Year’s Eve, falls onto the subway tracks and is killed by an oncoming train.

headline: In Trump’s Defamation Trial, the Nine Most Important People Are Enigmas
abstract: The identities of the jurors deciding how much the former president will pay E. Jean Carroll are secret, thanks to a judge’s order.
lead_paragraph: Attorneys for E. Jean Carroll and Donald J. Trump, pitted against each other in a civil defamation trial in Manhattan, know little about the nine people considering her claim for millions of dollars in damages against the former president.

headline: Manhattan’s District Attorney Is Quietly Preparing for a Trump Trial
abstract: As prosecutors navigate calendars and appeals, Alvin L. Bragg may take the former president’s first criminal case to trial. He has said that covering up a hush-money payment was a fraud on voters.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have accused Donald J. Trump of plotting to subvert American democracy and mishandling nuclear secrets. But with those cases in limbo, state prosecutors in Manhattan are gearing up as though they will be the first to try the former president on criminal charges — for covering up a potential sex scandal.

headline: Climbing a Ladder
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: After Its Big Setback, New Jersey Awards 2 Offshore Wind Contracts
abstract: The awards came just three months after a developer backed out of two contracts to supply power to New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey awarded two additional contracts for electricity from offshore wind farms on Wednesday, moving forward with the state’s ambitious plans to turn to the Atlantic Ocean for power after a surprising blow to them last year.

headline: Top Official’s Resignation Reveals Tension Atop European Soccer
abstract: The official, Zvonimir Boban, said he was quitting UEFA because of a proposal that could allow the organization’s leaders to extend their terms, and their power.
lead_paragraph: Zvonimir Boban, a top aide and longtime confidant to the powerful president of European soccer’s governing body, resigned abruptly on Wednesday, a departure that laid bare a deep rift inside the leadership of one of the world’s richest sports organizations.

headline: Whitney Biennial Names Its ‘Dissonant Chorus’ of Artists to Probe Turbulent Times
abstract: The 2024 survey focuses less on American art, more on America itself at a raw, vulnerable time.
lead_paragraph: The last time the Whitney Biennial came around, in 2022, its production had been extended an extra year by the Covid pandemic, and the curators had to plan the exhibition and meet artists in virtual visits over Zoom.

headline: Dan Jones Turned to Fiction After Dinner With George R.R. Martin
abstract: “You’ve got to know when you’re onto a good thing,” says the prolific historian, British TV personality and author of “Wolves of Winter,” the second novel in his Hundred Years’ War trilogy.
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: My Mosque Preached Damnation, but Grand Theft Auto Offered Thrills
abstract: The sprawling and violent world of Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas was a complicated indulgence for a Black Muslim teenager.
lead_paragraph: My mother had no idea I was picking up sex workers. My sex appeal wasn’t very high, but I figured the paint job of my lowrider was attractive enough for me to get lucky.

headline: What Brings You Delight?
abstract: Where do you find joy and happiness in your everyday life?
lead_paragraph: Did anything happen today that changed your mood for the better or even just took your mind off your concerns for a moment? Was it something big or small? Silly or important? Beautiful or surprising? Something else?

headline: 36 Hours on Grenada
abstract: Scuba dive through an underwater art gallery, grind your own chocolate and chill at a beach barbecue in this often-overlooked Caribbean island nation.
lead_paragraph: Scuba dive through an underwater art gallery, grind your own chocolate and chill at a beach barbecue in this often-overlooked Caribbean island nation.

headline: 4 New Horror Novels That Are as Fresh as They Are Terrifying
abstract: New books by Emily Ruth Verona, Jenny Kiefer, Christopher Golden and Tlotlo Tsamaase riff on classic tropes and deliver thrilling scares.
lead_paragraph: Emily Ruth Verona’s MIDNIGHT ON BEACON STREET (Harper Perennial, 195 pp., paperback, $17.99) is a lot of things. It’s a taut thriller about a babysitter and two kids surviving one weird night. It’s a celebration of classic horror movies. It’s a creepy narrative that involves a ghost and late night home break-ins. And, most important, it’s a lot of fun.

headline: A Beacon of Modern Architecture Lands in the Desert
abstract: The Aluminaire House drew crowds, and ridicule, in 1931. After several moves and a brush with demolition, it has found a home in Southern California.
lead_paragraph: The Aluminaire House, one of the earliest and edgiest examples of the International Style of modernist architecture in America, was never meant to withstand a harsh desert climate. Originally it wasn’t even designed to be outside.

headline: ‘Sometimes I Think About Dying’ Review: Life, in Drab Gray
abstract: Daisy Ridley stars as an office worker who’s just going through the motions.
lead_paragraph: Fran thinks about dying, but not gruesomely. Her mental tableaux of death look as if they were staged by the artist Gregory Crewdson. Sometimes her body is draped dramatically over driftwood on a serene beach or posed in a foggy forest on a soft green bed of moss. She imagines standing alone in a nondescript finished office basement as a giant snake slithers by. She imagines death, essentially, as peace in the midst of ever-changing nature.

headline: Feeling Stuck? Here Are 5 Ways to Jumpstart Your Life.
abstract: Mental health experts suggest exercises to knock down the internal roadblocks that are causing burnout and holding you back.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, it looked as though Adam Alter was gliding along.

headline: Judge John Hodgman’s Case for Categorizing ‘Star Wars’ as Fantasy
abstract: The series has never been science fiction.
lead_paragraph: Michelle writes: Every time “Star Wars” is referenced in an article as science fiction, my husband rants about it. He says it’s fantasy. I’ve read him multiple definitions of science fiction, but he refuses to acknowledge that he’s wrong.

headline: Will a New Monument for Those Enslaved by France Heal or Divide?
abstract: The memorial will list the names of those freed in 1848, a design some say does more to glorify France for abolition than to atone for slavery itself.
lead_paragraph: As the color drained from the sky, a group gathered before the white-stoned basilica of St. Denis, where dozens of French kings are buried, to pay homage to their ancestors.

headline: ‘Tótem’ Review: The Girl Who Sees Too Much
abstract: In Lila Avilés’s second feature, a 7-year-old girl begins to grasp the severity of her father’s illness while birthday preparations are underway at home.
lead_paragraph: There are worlds inside worlds in “Tótem,” a soulful drama populated by an array of creatures, some with two legs and sad smiles, others with feathers, fur and shells. Set largely in a rambling house on a single momentous day, it focuses on a serious-eyed girl, Sol, who serves as the story’s luminous celestial body. You see much of what she sees, the warmth and disorder. Yet because Sol is just 7, you also see what it means to be a child in that messy reality known as adulthood.

headline: ‘The Underdoggs’ Review: Guess Who the New Coach Is, Kids
abstract: Snoop Dogg, as an egomaniacal retired football star, turns community service into a sport when he sees a chance to rekindle romance with a player’s mom.
lead_paragraph: It’s not until the film’s postscript that “The Underdoggs” suddenly makes sense: The movie, starring Snoop Dogg as a retired athlete coaching a Pop Warner team, is inspired by the Snoop Youth Football League, the real-life organization that he started in 2005. The film, directed by Charles Stone III, is perhaps best understood as something meant as a fun dedication to the program — but it makes for a forgettable, often aggressively perfunctory work.

headline: ‘Every Politician Has Got to Have Somebody That’s the Hit Man’
abstract: A Republican state lawmaker devised a bribery scheme that ended in a trial and a death — and showed why corruption has become harder to prosecute.
lead_paragraph: Back in Ohio, Neil Clark went by many names: “most powerful lobbyist in Ohio,” “bully,” “superlobbyist,” “godfather of lobbyists.” Clark blamed his “dark Sicilian features and demeanor” for the last epithet, though it might also have had something to do with his fondness for Al Capone and the fact that his father was a soldier for the Cleveland Mafia. He wore each distinction with pride, the complimentary and derogatory alike. As he saw it, a lobbyist without enemies wasn’t much of a lobbyist. But the label Clark relished most of all was “prince of darkness.” It suited his sense of himself: a master of political devilry.

headline: C.J. Box Isn’t Afraid to Wrangle With Issues Close to Home
abstract: The creator of two mystery series has the latitude — and the attitude — to address matters other writers wouldn’t touch with a 10-foot pole.
lead_paragraph: “I’m looking at the ridge outside my window,” C.J. Box said in a phone interview. “There’s one antelope going over the top to the other side.”

headline: She Looked for Her Missing Brother. Now, People Are Looking for Her.
abstract: The violent abduction of volunteer searcher Lorenza Cano is yet another fresh wound for the hundreds of mothers looking for Mexico’s missing.
lead_paragraph: Only a few torn pieces of the crime scene tape around Lorenza Cano’s house are left. The shards of glass from the front door are gone. So are the bullet casings.

headline: Gypsy Rose Blanchard and the Big Shift in True Crime
abstract: Not long ago, true crime storytellers had little in the way of first-person footage captured in real time to rely on. Now, as much of our daily lives are documented, the genre is transforming.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment near the end of the 2017 documentary “Mommy Dead and Dearest” where Gypsy Rose Blanchard is filming her boyfriend at the time, Nicholas Godejohn, as he lies nude in a hotel room bed. A day earlier, Godejohn had stabbed to death Gypsy’s mother, Dee Dee Blanchard. The killing was part of a plot the couple hatched to free Gypsy, who was then 23, from her mother’s grip so they could be together. In the short video, we hear Gypsy make a playful sexual comment amid her copious, distinctive giggling.

headline: The Paris Olympics Promise to Be Stunning. The Prices Already Are.
abstract: Want a prime spot to watch 10,000 athletes float by on the Seine or to catch beach volleyball in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower? Get ready for sticker shock.
lead_paragraph: The opening ceremony of the 2024 Paris Olympics promises to be spectacular: On the glittering waters of the Seine, a flotilla of barges will carry about 10,000 athletes to the foot of the Eiffel Tower, as nearly half a million spectators line the four-mile route to cheer on the event of the century.

headline: Philippe Petit Returns to the High Wire at Age 74
abstract: Mr. Petit, who walked on a wire between the World Trade Center towers in 1974, will be performing at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. This morning we’ll find out where Philippe Petit, who walked on a wire between towers of the World Trade Center in 1974, plans to stroll next week. We’ll also find out why Mayor Eric Adams says New York City is “back from the brink.”

headline: How ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ Presses Up Against the Limits of Empathy
abstract: The movie offers clues about how a reckoning with American colonialism must begin.
lead_paragraph: “Can you find the wolves in this picture?” Ernest Burkhart asks, with the faltering pace of a child, from his home within the Osage Nation — lands only recently annexed by the United States to form Oklahoma. Ernest is seemingly reading both to himself and the audience of Martin Scorsese’s monumental “Killers of the Flower Moon,” which was nominated on Tuesday for 10 Academy Awards, including best picture. The film offers more than three hours of violent detail from a period in Native American history during the 1920s that newspapers called the “Reign of Terror” — a period that included the slaughter of dozens, possibly hundreds, of the Osage Nation’s citizens by non-Native people.

headline: ‘The Strongest Democratic Party That Any of Us Have Ever Seen’
abstract: A Democratic political strategist says things are looking up.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a Democrat, how worried should you be right now? It’s strangely hard to answer that question. On the one hand, polls suggest Democrats should be very worried. President Biden looks weaker than he did as a candidate in 2020, and in matchups with Donald Trump, the election looks like a coin flip. On the other hand, Democrats staved off an expected red wave in the 2022 midterm elections. Biden has a strong record to run on, and Trump has a lot more baggage than he did in 2020.

headline: How Often Is Taylor Swift Actually Shown at N.F.L. Games?
abstract: A romance between the pop star and Travis Kelce has dominated social media, but TV broadcasts are focusing on it less than many seem to think.
lead_paragraph: As Taylor Swift’s N.F.L. adventure began in earnest at a Kansas City Chiefs game against the Chicago Bears on Sept. 24, the reaction of the Fox broadcast crew — and much of the N.F.L. world in general — was summed up by Erin Andrews, a veteran sideline reporter.

headline: The ‘People’s President’ vs. the Donor Class
abstract: There’s a war raging inside the Republican Party. And the matchup between Donald Trump and Nikki Haley lays it bare.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s victory over Nikki Haley in the New Hampshire primary made two things clear: The MAGA wing of the G.O.P. is ready for his coronation, while anti-Trump Republicans believe the race is far from over.

headline: Fire Blanketed Lahaina in Toxic Debris. Where Can They Put It?
abstract: Crews are sending thousands of truckloads of debris to a temporary disposal site, alarming Native Hawaiian residents and those seeking to protect a prized coral reef.
lead_paragraph: When a firestorm consumed the Hawaii town of Lahaina last year, killing 100 people, it left behind a toxic wasteland of melted batteries, charred propane tanks, and miles of debris tainted by arsenic and lead.

headline: The Sleepy Copyright Office in the Middle of a High-Stakes Clash Over A.I.
abstract: The office is reviewing how centuries-old laws should apply to artificial intelligence technology, with both content creators and tech giants arguing their cases.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Copyright Office has been a small and sleepy office within the Library of Congress. Each year, the agency’s 450 employees register roughly half a million copyrights, the ownership rights for creative works, based on a two-centuries-old law.

headline: We Asked A.I. to Create the Joker. It Generated a Copyrighted Image.
abstract: Artists and researchers are exposing copyrighted material hidden within A.I. tools, raising fresh legal questions.
lead_paragraph: Artists and researchers are exposing copyrighted material hidden within A.I. tools, raising fresh legal questions.

headline: A Young Family That ‘Could Move Anywhere’ Chose Denver. But What Could They Afford There?
abstract: Life in Cambridge, Mass., wasn’t working out, so two parents introduced their daughter, who has cerebral palsy, to a new city and a new way of life.
lead_paragraph: Life in Cambridge, Mass., wasn’t working out, so two parents introduced their daughter, who has cerebral palsy, to a new city and a new way of life.

headline: 2024 Oscar Nominations
abstract: Our Awards Season reporter helps us sift through the snubs and surprises of this year’s awards.
lead_paragraph: Pop culture reporter Kyle Buchanan has been covering the long campaign leading up to the Oscar nominations. He helps make sense of who is being recognized and who’s been left behind for the most prestigious award in the film industry.

headline: Glen Powell at Sundance: ‘I’m Buzzing Right Now, Man!’
abstract: The star and co-writer of “Hit Man” heard that his film had wowed audiences, but because of the actors’ strike, he couldn’t see for himself until now.
lead_paragraph: Glen Powell doesn’t want for much these days, after co-starring in “Top Gun: Maverick” and watching his new film, the romantic comedy “Anyone but You,” cross $100 million at the worldwide box office. Still, for the past few months, there was one little thing he felt he had missed out on.

headline: The Looming Contest Between Two Presidents and Two Americas
abstract: The general election matchup that seems likely between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump is about fundamentally disparate visions of the nation.
lead_paragraph: Each of them has sat behind the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office, signed bills into law, appointed judges, bartered with foreign leaders and ordered the armed forces into combat. They both know what it is like to be the most powerful person on the planet.

headline: A Titanic Geopolitical Struggle Is Underway
abstract: This is no ordinary moment in world affairs.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect new developments.

headline: For Second Time This Month, a Politician Is Attacked in South Korea
abstract: Bae Hyunjin, of the country’s governing party, was assaulted in Seoul and taken to a hospital. The attack came three weeks after another politician was stabbed.
lead_paragraph: A person struck a South Korean lawmaker in the head with a blunt object in Seoul on Thursday, causing injuries that were not life-threatening, according to her staff and physicians.

headline: Alabama Carries Out First U.S. Execution by Nitrogen
abstract: The state executed Kenneth Smith on Thursday using the untested method of nitrogen hypoxia after the Supreme Court declined to intervene.
lead_paragraph: Alabama carried out the first American execution using nitrogen gas on Thursday evening, killing a convicted murderer whose jury had voted to spare his life and opening a new frontier in how states execute death row prisoners.

headline: Luis Rubiales, Ex-Chief of Spanish Soccer, to Face Trial Over World Cup Kiss
abstract: The ruling by a National Court judge resulted from a pretrial inquiry into an unsolicited kiss that set off a widespread debate about sexism in Spanish women’s soccer.
lead_paragraph: Luis Rubiales, Spain’s onetime soccer chief, is due to be tried over his nonconsensual kiss of a star player during the Women’s World Cup medal ceremony last summer after a judge recommended on Thursday that he face a court’s judgment in a high-profile case that has upended the sport in Spain.

headline: Israel Tries to Rebut Genocide Charge, and a Drought in the Amazon
abstract: Plus, Jon Stewart’s return to late night.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Hybrid Worker Malaise
abstract: Tens of millions of Americans now mix office and remote work. What challenges does this new model bring?
lead_paragraph: The era of hybrid work has spawned a new kind of office culture — one that has left many workers less connected and less happy than they have ever been.

headline: Donald Trump’s Second-Term Agenda
abstract: With Trump on his way to securing the Republican nomination, we speak with three Times politics writers about how he might govern.
lead_paragraph: My colleagues Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Charlie Savage are writing a continuing series on what Donald Trump plans to do during a second term as president. With Trump on his way to winning the Republican nomination, I want to devote today’s newsletter to a conversation with the three of them.

headline: ‘American Star’ Review: Armed and Vacationing
abstract: Ian McShane stars as an assassin killing time in the Canary Islands.
lead_paragraph: “American Star,” the latest film to showcase the travel benefits of being a professional killer, opens with Wilson (Ian McShane) arriving in Fuerteventura, one of the Canary Islands. After parking his rental car off the side of a desert road, he peeks in the trunk to find a photograph of his latest mark, who of course lives in a sleek, modernist home nearby.

headline: ‘The Peasants’ Review: A Village Rendered in Oils
abstract: The filmmakers DK and Hugh Welchman apply a painstaking oil painting technique to render this sweeping drama set in a 19th century Polish village.
lead_paragraph: The painstaking process behind “The Peasants,” the new painted film exercise from DK and Hugh Welchman, is only laid out after the film ends. As the credits roll, the directors show clips of painters viewing reference footage and then reproducing the images in oil on canvas, sometimes frame by frame.

headline: ‘Lil Nas X: Long Live Montero’ Review: A Hip-Hop Trailblazer
abstract: The documentary, streaming on Max, follows the queer singer-rapper on the road and at home, but the best scenes by far are when he is onstage.
lead_paragraph: To watch the singer-rapper Lil Nas X in the documentary “Lil Nas X: Long Live Montero” is to witness a Black queer man embody a power that still feels very new.

headline: ‘Miller’s Girl’ Review: Teacher’s Dirty Looks
abstract: Martin Freeman and Jenna Ortega fight pheromones and cliché in this eye-rolling duel between a teacher and his student.
lead_paragraph: You can almost smell the arousal wafting from the screen as “Miller’s Girl” wends its overheated way through lubricious conversations and a comically on-the-mark soundtrack. Even the camera turns dreamy whenever the improbably named Cairo Sweet (Jenna Ortega) — a microskirted tease and the film’s linchpin — activates her pout, especially if she’s chewing or smoking. It should be said that either is preferable to her talking.

headline: ‘Mambar Pierrette’ Review: Cosmic Misfortunes
abstract: A gifted seamstress, played by the filmmaker Rosine Mbakam’s cousin, has to put out a string of fires in this rich portrait of Cameroonian womanhood.
lead_paragraph: Pierrette, a gifted seamstress and a mother of three, can’t seem to catch a break. After a hard day’s work at her humble shop in Douala, a busy city in Cameroon, she’s mugged by a motorcycle taxi driver. It’s also the rainy season and her home — and later her shop — is flooded overnight. It’s a foul time to be broke: The kids are heading back to school and their supplies aren’t cheap.

headline: Arsonist Sentenced to Death for Killing 36 People in 2019 Kyoto Studio Fire
abstract: Shinji Aoba was charged with murder in 2020 after dousing a studio with gasoline and lighting it on fire. On Thursday he was found guilty.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese judge sentenced to death a man who killed 36 people in an arson attack at an anime studio in Kyoto in 2019, one of the country’s deadliest attacks in decades, after he was found guilty of murder on Thursday.

headline: Louisiana and Texas Face Flooding, With More Rain Expected Across the South
abstract: Parts of the South will see additional rain on Thursday after days of soaking rain, meteorologists said, raising concerns of flash flooding.
lead_paragraph: Heavy downpours over parts of Louisiana and Texas this week have caused significant flooding, meteorologists and officials said, and more rain is forecast to soak the region through the end of the week.

headline: Ukraine Searches for Answers on Russian Plane Crash
abstract: Moscow has accused Ukraine of downing the craft, which it says carried 65 Ukrainian P.O.W.s. The claims cannot be independently verified. Kyiv says Russia is exploiting the episode for propaganda.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian officials pressed their efforts on Thursday to uncover the details of a deadly plane crash over the border in Russia, asking for patience from citizens while they investigated Moscow’s claims that Ukraine had shot down a Russian military aircraft carrying Ukrainian prisoners of war.

headline: Journalists at New York Daily News Walk Off Job for a Day
abstract: Newsroom workers at The Daily News Union, which formed in 2021, are in negotiations for their first contract.
lead_paragraph: Journalists at The New York Daily News walked off the job on Thursday for the first time in more than three decades.

headline: Tesla Tumbles as Growth Slows
abstract: Shares in Elon Musk’s electric vehicle maker fell sharply after the company delivered lackluster quarterly results and declined to give full-year guidance.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk and Tesla shareholders are at a crossroads.

headline: When Will the European Central Bank Start Cutting Rates?
abstract: Interest rate cuts could start as soon as April, investors say. But the eurozone’s central bank, which held rates steady on Thursday, has said it will probably wait longer.
lead_paragraph: If what goes up must come down, then the urgent question on the minds of many in Europe is when will interest rates begin dropping? For months, rates have been set at the highest in the European Central Bank’s history.

headline: Where Can Gen Z Buy a Home?
abstract: Older members of the generation are early in their careers, and they face increases in inflation, home prices and interest rates.
lead_paragraph: If Gen Z can’t afford the rent, how are they ever going to buy a home?

headline: U.S. Economy Grew at 3.3% Rate in Latest Quarter
abstract: The increase in gross domestic product, while slower than in the previous period, showed the resilience of the recovery from the pandemic’s upheaval.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy continued to grow at a healthy pace at the end of 2023, capping a year in which unemployment remained low, inflation cooled and a widely predicted recession never materialized.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey.
abstract: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom in Port Washington, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Belle Mead, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A three-bedroom, two-bath house built in 1951 with hardwood floors, a living room with a wood-burning fireplace, a formal dining room with sliders to the landscaped backyard, an eat-in kitchen, a laundry room in a partially finished basement, and an attached one-car garage, on 0.14 acres. Beth Catrone, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 516-647-1729; danielgale.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are in Lincoln Square, the financial district and Astoria.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath, roughly 750-square-foot apartment with a galley kitchen, an open living/dining area, a walk-in closet and through-the-wall heating and air-conditioning, on the fourth floor of an 18-story doorman building from 1963 with a live-in resident manager, shared laundry, a private parking garage and a bike room. Michael Biryla and Kyle Ramdeen, 914-299-5377, The Agency New York; theagencyre.com

headline: A Red Velvet Bistro in an Istanbul Villa
abstract: Plus: jewelry handmade with Roman coins, vintage Estée Lauder fragrances and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: During the 49 years that Estée Lauder worked at her namesake company, she oversaw the creation of a dozen scents and encouraged women to create fragrance “wardrobes” tailored to every occasion and mood. The brand’s Legacy Collection, which comes out on Feb. 1, revives five of Lauder’s creations with the help of Frédéric Malle (whose perfume brand was acquired by the Estée Lauder Companies in 2015) and the perfumers Anne Flipo, Carlos Benaïm and Bruno Jovanovic, all of whom have worked with Malle on previous fragrances. During an interview inside Lauder’s well-preserved office near Central Park, Malle explained how he retooled the scents using more modern fragrance-making techniques. He noted that, in Lauder’s day, perfumers combined base scents that were “like premixed mini-perfumes” to create a final fragrance. “They contained things that weren’t necessary and created background noise,” Malle said. To update the formulas, any nonessential ingredients in those bases were stripped away — “it’s like cleaning up,” he said. The new collection has notes that range from fresh and herbaceous to musky and sweet. Azurée, initially released in 1969, evokes dry Mediterranean shores with herby notes like basil and tarragon as well as jasmine, spicy cardamom, bergamot, and cumin, which Malle amplified in his edition. For White Linen, a classic floral bouquet of rose and jasmine, Malle used pure labdanum, an ambery resin from the rockrose plant, which wasn’t available when the scent debuted in 1978. Knowing, a seductive scent from 1988, “contained a little bit of the Muzak of the ’80s,” Malle said. The modernized version is a fruity chypre with raspberries, black currant, rose and patchouli. The overall goal of the collection, Malle said, “is to revive this work and show how good Mrs. Lauder was.” The Legacy Collection is available from Feb. 1, $280, esteelauder.com.

headline: In Winter, California Is for the Birds
abstract: Millions of birds migrate through the Golden State each year along the Pacific Flyway, which stretches from Alaska to the tip of South America.
lead_paragraph: Blackbirds flit between reeds jutting out of the marshy waters. A bald eagle perches in a tree, far above clusters of bobbing ducks. In a mesmerizing display, hundreds of snowy white geese take flight in an undulating swarm that mottles the gray sky.

headline: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
abstract: Igor Levit’s response to tragedy, Ethan Iverson’s first piano sonata and a personal recording by Gidon Kremer are among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Music doesn’t have the power to end wars. Peace, said Daniel Barenboim, whose West-Eastern Divan Orchestra brings together Israeli and Palestinian artists, “needs something else.”

headline: The One Part of the Housing Market That’s Growing
abstract: As owners remain reluctant to put their properties on the market, developers are rushing to build new homes to meet demand.
lead_paragraph: When Joel Adler decided it was time to downsize from his six-bedroom house in Parkland, Fla., where he had lived for more than 20 years, he was disappointed with the lack of options.

headline: Microsoft Cuts 1,900 Jobs in Its Video Game Division
abstract: The reductions come three months after the tech giant completed its $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said Thursday that it would eliminate 1,900 roles in its video game division, including at Activision Blizzard, which it acquired for $69 billion three months ago.

headline: Russian Court Jails Woman Over Blast That Killed Influential Military Blogger
abstract: Daria Trepova gave Maksim Fomin, who was known more popularly as Vladlen Tatarsky, a statuette that contained a bomb.
lead_paragraph: A Russian court on Thursday sentenced a woman to 27 years in prison for delivering a bomb that killed an influential military blogger in a St. Petersburg cafe last year, a lengthy sentence that underscored the Kremlin’s efforts to deter violent opposition to its war in Ukraine.

headline: The Secretive Court Fight Roiling New York’s Democratic Socialists
abstract: The state’s elections watchdog says a socialist group improperly spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on the 2022 elections. Clawing it back could upend the movement’s finances.
lead_paragraph: As New York socialists looked to expand an electoral beachhead in 2022, they tried something ambitious. They steered supporters to a special campaign committee set up to advance not just a single candidate, but a whole socialist slate.

headline: John Pilger, 84, Dies; Journalist and Filmmaker on Human Rights Abuses
abstract: A prolific documentarian and writer who took sides, he was best known for a film about the Khmer Rouge’s genocide in Cambodia in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: John Pilger, a muckraking foreign correspondent and documentarian who trained his often righteous anger on injustices around the globe, like the Khmer Rouge’s genocide in Cambodia and human rights abuses in East Timor, died on Dec. 30 in London. He was 84.

headline: Mail 3 Days a Week? Idea Meets Resistance in Britain.
abstract: Letter volumes have halved since 2011. Without significant changes, the beleaguered Royal Mail services will become “out of date,” according to a report.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s postal service could consider cutting deliveries to five days a week, or even three, from six, the country’s regulator said on Wednesday, drawing resistance from lawmakers and businesses.

headline: Comfort Cooking Beyond Casseroles
abstract: Chicken mei fun, plump roasted peppers and a plate of bangers and mash are effortless victories.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been in comfort-cooking mode for a while now, and this last stretch of January really has us reaching for recipes that soothe and nourish. Soups and stews, yes, and generous casseroles, but also dishes that feel like effortless victories, filling the home with wonderful smells and making us do that satisfied, mmm-shrugging thing with our shoulders.

headline: Do Not Fear the Robo-Dinosaur, Learn From It
abstract: Scientists built a working model of an early winged dinosaur to test a hypothesis about how the appendages evolved.
lead_paragraph: The origin of bird wings has long presented a puzzle to paleontologists: Why did these structures develop in the age of the dinosaurs? And what were some of the earliest wings used for, if not for flight?

headline: The Sex-Obsessed Marsupials That Will Sleep When They’re Dead
abstract: Scientists find that male antechinuses, rodent-like animals from Australia, will forgo sleep for sex during their breeding season, after which they die.
lead_paragraph: Scurrying along the dense brush of coastal woodlands and forests, the small, mouselike antechinus appears more unassuming than many of Australia’s marsupials. But for the three weeks of their breeding season, the males transform into absolute sex-obsessed lotharios.

headline: New Resources for Teaching About the Israel-Hamas War
abstract: Here is an updated collection of New York Times articles, essays, podcasts and videos to help students learn about the war, media literacy, dueling historical narratives and more.
lead_paragraph: In the week after Hamas’s deadly attack on Israel on Oct. 7, we published an extensive teaching resource and a forum for students to help classrooms learn more about the conflict. Nearly four months later, with the subsequent Israeli bombardment and ground war that have killed thousands of civilians in Gaza, we know that schools are still wrestling with how — and whether — to talk to their students about the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Institutions Are (Quietly) Taking Sackler Money
abstract: Financial accounts show that the Sackler Trust, a British nonprofit that the family set up, pledged over $6 million in 2022. But few organizations will admit to taking it.
lead_paragraph: When arts organizations began shunning the Sackler family over its role in the U.S. opioid crisis, it wasn’t just American institutions that cut ties. Museums in Britain that had accepted Sackler largess were among the first to take action.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Jan. 31, 2024
abstract: How are the chances of being admitted to an elite college affected by income and by being a legacy applicant?
lead_paragraph: This graph was previously published in The New York Times. It is based on the findings of a study of college applicants to 12 highly selective colleges: the Ivy League (Brown, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Princeton, University of Pennsylvania, and Yale), plus Duke, M.I.T., the University of Chicago and Stanford. The anonymous data is from the years 1999 to 2015.

headline: Trump Says Haley Donors Will Be ‘Barred From the MAGA Camp’
abstract: Far from trying to unite Republicans as he seeks to cast himself as their inevitable nominee, Donald Trump threatened supporters of his last major primary rival, Nikki Haley.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump essentially threatened Nikki Haley’s donors with excommunication from his political movement on Wednesday night, declaring that he would refuse contributions from anyone who donated to her primary campaign.

headline: ‘Pictures of Ghosts’ Review: Layers of Love and Memory
abstract: The Brazilian director Kleber Mendonça Filho draws on fact and fiction in this image-rich documentary that moves fast and far, but always returns home.
lead_paragraph: Early in “Pictures of Ghosts,” an exhilarating documentary about specters onscreen and off, the Brazilian director Kleber Mendonça Filho, pulls out a VHS tape. It’s of a 1981 TV interview with his mother, Joselice, a historian who died at age 54. In close-up, she discusses gathering information left out of history, an approach that her son has embraced here. After the tape abruptly cuts off, he says in voice-over, “it may seem like I’m discussing methodology” — as if speaking now both for his mother and for himself — “but I’m talking about love.”

headline: Top Council Rejects Much of France’s Tough Immigration Law
abstract: The Constitutional Council, which reviews laws to ensure that they conform to the Constitution, struck down many measures that President Emmanuel Macron’s government had added under right-wing pressure.
lead_paragraph: France’s Constitutional Council struck down large chunks of a tough new immigration law on Thursday, issuing a widely expected ruling that many provisions added by President Emmanuel Macron’s government under right-wing pressure were unlawful.

headline: McConnell Casts Doubt on Border Deal, Saying Trump Opposition May Sink It
abstract: The minority leader privately told Republicans that the former president had put his party “in a quandary,” casting further doubt on the deal’s chances and the fate of Ukraine aid that the G.O.P. has tied to it.
lead_paragraph: The emerging bipartisan border deal is hitting fresh snags among Republicans on Capitol Hill because of the opposition of former President Donald J. Trump, who is closing in on his party’s presidential nomination at a critical time for the agreement.

headline: Qatar Expresses Anger Over Netanyahu’s Leaked Criticism
abstract: In a recording that aired on Israeli television, a voice that appears to be Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s called Qatar’s role as a mediator “problematic” because of its relationship to Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Qatar has accused Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of hurting efforts to secure the release of hostages after a leaked recording appeared to catch the Israeli leader criticizing the country, which has been a key mediator in talks.

headline: The Victorious, Censorious, Malicious Donald Trump
abstract: He won New Hampshire — and showed us exactly who he is.
lead_paragraph: About an hour and a half after Donald Trump was declared the winner of the Republican primary in New Hampshire, he appeared onstage at a victory rally in Nashua, N.H., to bask in his accomplishment and bash lesser mortals. Bask-and-bash is his preferred M.O., an indulgence of the love he feels for himself and the contempt he feels for almost everybody else, and his bearing and remarks indeed had a familiar, compulsory ring. As Trump performances go, it was an unremarkable one.

headline: As Changes Come to Boston Symphony, Conductor’s Contract Is Extended
abstract: The music director, Andris Nelsons, was moved to an evergreen contract, with an expanded role at Tanglewood. And Carlos Simon was named to a new composer post.
lead_paragraph: The tenure of Chad Smith, the innovative arts leader who last year left the Los Angeles Philharmonic to run the comparatively old-fashioned Boston Symphony Orchestra, is beginning to take shape.

headline: Are His Parents Responsible? A Mass Shooter’s Mother Goes on Trial.
abstract: A teenager killed four students at his high school in Oxford, Mich., in 2021. At his mother’s trial, prosecutors said his parents could have stopped him.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Jennifer Crumbley, whose son carried out the worst school shooting in Michigan history, began on Thursday with dueling portraits: one of a mother whose negligence  was so extreme that it caused a tragedy, and another of a good, even “hypervigilant” mother who was in the dark about her son’s troubles until that tragedy unfolded.

headline: Inflation Worries and Snickers Bars
abstract: Readers discuss an essay that argued their worries were irrational. Also: Tuning Donald Trump out; Mayor Adams’s veto; a U.S.-Canada wall; a refuge from politics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Elon Musk Is Spreading Election Misinformation, but X’s Fact Checkers Are Long Gone
abstract: Civil rights lawyers and Democrats are sounding alarms about Mr. Musk’s claims about voting. The Biden campaign called his posts “profoundly irresponsible.”
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2020, when President Donald J. Trump wrote messages on Twitter warning that increased reliance on mail-in ballots would lead to a “rigged election,” the platform ran a corrective, debunking his claims.

headline: Federal Trade Commission Launches Inquiry Into A.I. Deals by Tech Giants
abstract: The agency plans to scrutinize Microsoft, Amazon and Google for their investments in the A.I. start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission opened an inquiry on Thursday into the multibillion-dollar investments by Microsoft, Amazon and Google in the artificial intelligence start-ups OpenAI and Anthropic, broadening the regulator’s efforts to corral the power the tech giants can have over A.I.

headline: Review: A Japanese ‘Boléro’? It’s a Spooky Ride of Revenge.
abstract: At Japan Society, “Nihon Buyo in the 21st Century,” a rare showcase in New York of this style of Japanese dance, forges a link between the past and present.
lead_paragraph: For better or worse, Ravel’s “Boléro,” with its churning swell of sound, has stirred the imagination of artists over time, among them the choreographer Maurice Béjart and the ice dancing team of Torvill and Dean. It even found a seductive partner, Bo Derek — along with her cornrows — in the Blake Edwards movie “10.”

headline: Plans for Gaza’s ‘Day After’ Seem Ever Distant
abstract: The very idea that there will be a clear line between war and peace is misleading, given the politics, security needs and anxieties of all sides.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Gaza grinds on, there is increasing talk of some “day after” formula for the broken territory. But that notion is an ephemeral one — there is not going to be a bright line between war and peace in Gaza, even if some sort of negotiated settlement is reached.

headline: U.S. Is Watching North Korea for Signs of Lethal Military Action
abstract: A shift by Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, toward open hostility against South Korea is alarming but does not indicate he is about to start a full-scale war, officials say.
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, could take some form of lethal military action against South Korea in the coming months after having shifted to a policy of open hostility, U.S. officials say.

headline: Bill Hayes, Enduring Soap Star With a ‘Davy Crockett’ Hit, Is Dead at 98
abstract: He logged more than 2,000 episodes on “Days of Our Lives” and rode the Crockett craze to a hit single in 1955.
lead_paragraph: Bill Hayes, an actor and singer whose 2,141 episodes of “Days of Our Lives” over five and a half decades constituted the daytime drama version of an ultramarathon, and whose top-selling 1955 single, “The Ballad of Davy Crockett,” remains seared into the memories of the baby boom generation, died on Jan. 12 at his home in Studio City, Calif. He was 98.

headline: Fred Chappell, Admired but Unsung Writer of the South, Dies at 87
abstract: He wrote lyrical poetry and novels about life in North Carolina’s Appalachian Piedmont and was considered the South’s “premier contemporary person of letters.”
lead_paragraph: Fred Chappell, a poet, novelist and critic whose Faulknerian capacity to express universal themes of love, loss and memory through his evocations of North Carolina’s rural, mountainous west earned him a reputation as the South’s “premier contemporary person of letters,” in the words of one reviewer, died on Jan. 4 in Greensboro, N.C. He was 87.

headline: Navarro Is Sentenced to 4 Months in Prison for Stonewalling Congress
abstract: Peter Navarro was found guilty in September of criminal contempt of Congress, making him the second Trump aide to face penalties related to one of the chief investigations into Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: Peter Navarro, a trade adviser to former President Donald J. Trump who helped lay plans to keep Mr. Trump in office after the 2020 election, was sentenced on Thursday to four months in prison for defying a subpoena from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

headline: Japan Explains How It Made an Upside-Down Moon Landing
abstract: The SLIM spacecraft survived its trip to the surface, but ended up pointing in a direction that now limits the duration of its mission.
lead_paragraph: Japan became the fifth nation to land on the moon on Saturday, but its spacecraft ended up in an awkward position, with its engine nozzle pointed up toward space.

headline: Here Comes the Broccoli
abstract: Stewed with farro, puréed into pesto, sizzled with dates and seared with halloumi.
lead_paragraph: In the doldrums of January, it can feel most natural to eat like the weather: beige foods inside to match the shades of taupe outside. But inevitably, when that little voice inside my head cries out for something green, there is one vegetable that comes to mind first: broccoli.

headline: Apple Overhauls App Store in Europe, in Response to New Digital Law
abstract: An E.U. law taking effect in March forced Apple to loosen its grip on the App Store, changes it had long resisted.
