lead_paragraph: Since Apple introduced the App Store in 2008, it has tightly controlled the apps and services allowed on iPhones and iPads, giving the company an iron grip on one of the digital economy’s most valuable storefronts.

headline: Haley Super PAC Says It Raised $50.1 Million, Eclipsing Trump
abstract: The figure for the second half of last year outstripped the $46 million that Donald Trump’s super PAC announced. But the Haley PAC has spent heavily, and it’s unclear how much is left.
lead_paragraph: The main super PAC backing Nikki Haley said Thursday that it had raised $50.1 million in the second half of 2023, a hefty sum that eclipses the amount brought in by the leading super PAC backing former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Rihanna, Natalie Portman, Kylie Jenner, Zendaya and More Gallivant in Paris
abstract: Dresses, kisses, fan girls: the best celebrity moments at couture.
lead_paragraph: Haute couture is a celebration of artisanship — and one-upmanship — as the world’s top fashion houses gather in Paris to compete with one another and show off new designs.

headline: Sweden’s Leader Says He Will Meet With Orban to Advance NATO Bid
abstract: The Hungarian leader, Viktor Orban, invited his Swedish counterpart to Budapest for talks. Hungary is the last country to vote to accept Sweden’s bid to join NATO after Turkey’s Parliament did so this week.
lead_paragraph: Bowing to a Hungarian demand for negotiations over the expansion of NATO, the prime minister of Sweden on Thursday agreed to hold talks with Hungary’s leader, Viktor Orban, the last obstacle blocking the Nordic nation’s admission to the military alliance.

headline: R.N.C. Says It Looks Like Michigan G.O.P. Leader Was ‘Properly Removed’
abstract: Kristina Karamo, the state party’s embattled chairwoman, is disputing the legality of her ouster earlier this month by Republican leaders.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for the Republican National Committee say it looks like Kristina Karamo was “properly removed” as chairwoman of the Michigan Republican Party earlier this month, but Ms. Karamo and her newly-elected replacement both maintain that they are in charge.

headline: Business Insider Laying Off 8% of Staff
abstract: In an internal note about the job cuts, the company’s chief executive cited its plan to shift focus solely to news coverage of business, tech and innovation.
lead_paragraph: Business Insider said on Thursday that it was laying off 8 percent of its staff, the latest in a wave of sharp job cuts in the media industry this month.

headline: It’s Boom Times for Obamacare. Will They Last?
abstract: A record 21 million people signed up for marketplace plans for 2024, drawn in part by more generous federal subsidies. But the expanded subsidies are set to expire after next year.
lead_paragraph: Carley Calvi came to the second floor of a public library in suburban Milwaukee one morning this month without health insurance to cover the vertigo medication she needed. Worse, she said, was not having a doctor she trusted.

headline: Drivers Navigate Flooded Louisiana Roads
abstract: Parts of Louisiana and Texas faced significant flooding as heavy rain inundated the region.
lead_paragraph: Parts of Louisiana and Texas faced significant flooding as heavy rain inundated the region.

headline: Yellen, Criticizing Trump, Says Biden’s Economy Has Delivered Gains
abstract: The Treasury Secretary acknowledged that consumer prices, which have weighed on economic sentiment, continue to be too high.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen defended the Biden administration’s economic agenda on Thursday, drawing sharp contrasts with the policies of the Trump administration as President Biden begins to make the general election argument that he has been a stronger steward of the economy than his predecessor.

headline: Inside Trump’s Cutthroat Conquest of Iowa and New Hampshire
abstract: The former president’s victories in Iowa and New Hampshire were the product of a win-or-else ethos, a fractured opposition and his power to make the party stand for whatever he stands for.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign couldn’t have scripted the results in Iowa any better.

headline: A Huge Win for Activists Puts Climate on the 2024 Agenda
abstract: The Biden administration will examine how a natural gas mega-project will impact the climate.
lead_paragraph: This is just what the climate activists wanted.

headline: What to Know About the U.N. Court’s Initial Ruling in the Genocide Case Against Israel
abstract: The International Court of Justice ruled that Israel must take steps to prevent genocide in Gaza, but stopped short of demanding a stop to its military offensive.
lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice issued an interim ruling on Friday in a wider case about whether Israel is committing genocide against Palestinians in the enclave.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Our recommended books this week include two surveys of modern science: one by an astrophysicist explaining the weirder aspects of her field, the other by a science reporter connecting the dots between natural phenomena and her own life. Also up, the biography of a celebrated war correspondent, a serious look at the business of comedy and a volume of essays that Christopher Hitchens wrote for The London Review of Books over the years. In fiction, we recommend a novel of friendship among exiles and a story collection by a Canadian master of the form, along with a romance novel and a buzzy fiction debut by the poet Kaveh Akbar. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

headline: Bernard Arnault Names 2 More Sons to LVMH Board, Cementing Family Control
abstract: The move by France’s richest man extends a carefully planned succession strategy for the world’s biggest luxury company.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Arnault, the head of the LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton luxury goods empire, announced on Thursday that he had nominated two more of his children to sit on the company board, a move to cement his family’s control of Europe’s most valuable conglomerate.

headline: After Days of Waiting, Trump Spends Minutes on the Witness Stand
abstract: The former president, constrained by a judge’s orders, testified briefly in a defamation trial brought by the writer E. Jean Carroll.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates from today’s closing arguments.

headline: Nitrogen Hypoxia: What to Know About This New Method of Execution
abstract: Alabama will be the first state to use nitrogen in an execution. If it goes smoothly, other states are likely to follow.
lead_paragraph: The planned execution of a death row inmate by the state of Alabama on Thursday evening will be carried out by a procedure that has never been used for capital punishment in the United States.

headline: Hands-On Art at the Brooklyn Museum’s New Education Center
abstract: “Artland,” an ever-expanding fantasy world designed and molded by children, inaugurates the newly renovated 9,500-square-foot wing.
lead_paragraph: It could easily be an alien civilization: Its citizens have no gender, no organized religion, no formal government. They inhabit a lush ecosystem of candy-colored vegetation, where plants can grow infinitely tall. Residents travel on driverless, ring-shaped buses that hover in the atmosphere. A single year lasts more than two centuries.

headline: Cruise Says Hostility to Regulators Led to Grounding of Its Autonomous Cars
abstract: A law firm’s review found that executives had failed to fully explain an October crash, which the Justice Department is also investigating.
lead_paragraph: Cruise, the driverless car subsidiary of General Motors, said in a report on Thursday that an adversarial approach taken by its top executives toward regulators had led to a cascade of events that ended with a nationwide suspension of Cruise’s fleet and investigations by California and federal authorities, including the Justice Department.

headline: A Shocking Confession Upends the Case of a Fatal Fire in South Africa
abstract: Activists fear that one man’s sudden admission that he lit a crowded building ablaze to cover up a murder will let officials off the hook for failing to correct unsafe conditions there.
lead_paragraph: It was time, the witness said, to tell the whole truth about the awful things he had done.

headline: A Norwegian Official Fought Plagiarism. Then She Was Caught Copying.
abstract: Norway’s higher education minister, Sandra Borch, resigned after admitting she “took text from other assignments without stating the sources,” in her master’s thesis.
lead_paragraph: As Norway’s higher education minister, Sandra Borch was responsible for making sure that students played by the rules. When one of those students was acquitted of the offense of plagiarism, Ms. Borch appealed, taking the case to the nation’s Supreme Court.

headline: Can Nicotine Pouches Like Zyn Harm Your Health?
abstract: What we know about the new products, addiction and cancer.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer called this week for a crackdown on ZYN, a nicotine pouch that has become increasingly popular in the United States, alongside the rise of so-called Zynfluencers who tout the product online.

headline: What Students Are Saying About Learning to Write in the Age of A.I.
abstract: Does being able to write still matter when chatbots can do it for us? Teenagers weigh in on an essay from Opinion.
lead_paragraph: With artificial intelligence programs like ChatGPT that can generate prose for us, how much should we care about learning to write — and write well?

headline: What to Watch This Weekend: Something Hot
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a wild and wide-ranging documentary series about the world of hot pepper enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries about niche subcultures abound: dog dancing, science fairs, yo-yos. Few if any include as much on-screen vomiting as the Hulu series “Superhot: The Spicy World of Pepper People,” but then, few cover quite as much ground.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Simon Rosenberg
abstract: The Jan. 25, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Simon Rosenberg. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Friday Briefing: Will North Korea Attack?
abstract: Plus, when A.I. generates copyrighted images.
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, could take some form of lethal military action against South Korea in the coming months after having shifted his policy to one of open hostility, U.S. officials say.

headline: Film Club: ‘How to Protect Millions of Workers Without a Union’
abstract: In a Times Opinion video, Jeff Seal, a journalist and comedian, makes a colorful case that there’s more than one way for workers to organize. Is he convincing?
lead_paragraph: Unions have recently scored big victories in the auto industry and Hollywood. However, the percentage of workers who belong to a union plunged to its lowest level on record in 2022.

headline: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’ Book Recommendations (2023)
abstract: Readings that the podcast’s guests say shaped their thinking.
lead_paragraph: “The Ezra Klein Show” explores ideas with some of today’s most dynamic thinkers. We cover politics, culture, history, philosophy, psychology, technology and more. The topics are wide-ranging, but every episode ends with Ezra asking his guest (or guests) to recommend a few books that have shaped their thinking. Below is a list of all the books recommended on the show in 2023, in reverse-chronological order.

headline: Never-Trumpers Never Had a Chance
abstract: Animosity proved stronger than character or ideology.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential primary is all but over. Even if Nikki Haley stays in the race, it’s hard to see her winning a single primary, including the one in her home state of South Carolina next month. Even though Haley received an impressive 43 percent of the New Hampshire vote, her electoral reality is grim. According to the most recent FiveThirtyEight polling averages, she trails Donald Trump by more than 56 points nationally and by 37 points in South Carolina.

headline: A Hello, a Return and a Chicken Potpie
abstract: Nikita Richardson is back with recommendations for a funky breakfast sandwich at an all-day restaurant and more.
lead_paragraph: Fancy seeing you here. If you’ve only started reading “Where to Eat” in the last four months, then you may not know me: I’m Nikita Richardson, and I’m freshly returned from a stint on The Times’s Live team covering breaking news. (Thank you so much to Pete Wells for covering for me while I was away. If you’d like him to keep appearing in your inbox, be sure to subscribe to the Restaurant Review newsletter so you can keep up with his way-more-official eating adventures.)

headline: N.S.A. Buys Americans’ Internet Data Without Warrants, Letter Says
abstract: The disclosure comes amid congressional scrutiny and a Federal Trade Commission crackdown on commercial data brokers.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency buys certain logs related to Americans’ domestic internet activities from commercial data brokers, according to an unclassified letter by the agency.

headline: A Stranger Bought a Set of Highly Personal Letters. Can I Call Him Out?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether the intimate details of one’s life should ever be sold by someone else.
lead_paragraph: I recently learned that my former husband’s stepmother put up her and his father’s estate at auction and included all of his keepsakes stored in their attic. This included a large collection of letters that my former husband received as a young man.

headline: Scheduled to Fly on a Boeing Max 9? Here Are Your Options.
abstract: With inspection guidelines set for the grounded planes, airlines could start flying the 737 Max 9 later this week. Here’s what travelers should know.
lead_paragraph: After a portion of an Alaska Airlines Boeing 737 Max 9 jetliner’s fuselage blew out in midair minutes after the plane had taken off from Portland, Ore., on Jan. 5, the Federal Aviation Administration grounded about 170 Max 9 planes, causing airlines that rely heavily on the aircraft to cancel thousands of flights and inconveniencing many passengers.

headline: Taking on Trump, Biden Promotes ‘Infrastructure Decade’ in Wisconsin
abstract: The president made the trip to promote a $1 billion infrastructure project, contrasting his performance with the chaotic “Infrastructure Week” plans of former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Consumer confidence is up. Fears of a recession are abating. The economy is growing. And a corroded bridge in Wisconsin is receiving more funding.

headline: Trump Strengthens Grip on Capitol Hill as He Presses Toward Nomination
abstract: The former president’s opposition has all but killed the prospects for a bipartisan border deal, reflecting how his influence in Congress has grown as he gains ground in the Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: For months, Senate Republicans have been working with Democrats on a deal they have described as a once-in-a-generation opportunity for a conservative border security bill, and for weeks, they have hinted that they are tantalizingly close to an agreement.

headline: Edward E. Crutchfield, 82, Dies; Banker’s Deals Reshaped the Industry
abstract: He built a small Southern bank into a regional powerhouse, helping to turn Charlotte, N.C., into a national financial hub.
lead_paragraph: Edward E. Crutchfield, who grew a small North Carolina bank into one of the nation’s largest through a deal-making spree that earned him the nickname Fast Eddie and helped establish Charlotte, N.C., as a national financial hub, died on Jan. 2 at his home in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 82.

headline: U.S., Sensing Opportunity, Makes New Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
abstract: William Burns, the C.I.A. director, planned to meet Israeli, Egyptian and Qatari officials in Europe to try to secure a deal to release the Hamas hostages and a pause in the combat.
lead_paragraph: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, plans to travel to Europe to meet with senior Israeli, Egyptian and Qatari officials, in a sign the United States is pushing to secure a deal to release the hostages being held in the Gaza Strip and broker a prolonged cease-fire, according to U.S. officials.

headline: Ingenuity, the NASA Helicopter Flying Over Mars, Ends Its Mission
abstract: The robot flew 72 times, serving as a scouting partner to the Perseverance rover, aiding in the search for evidence that there was once life on the red planet.
lead_paragraph: Ingenuity, the little Mars helicopter that could, can’t anymore.

headline: Met Opera Taps Its Endowment Again to Weather Downturn
abstract: The company has withdrawn nearly $40 million in additional funds from its endowment to cover expenses, but sees signs it may be emerging from its post-pandemic woes.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera, still reeling from the disruption brought by the pandemic, said on Thursday that it had withdrawn nearly $40 million in additional emergency funds from its endowment as it works to survive one of the most trying periods in its 141-year history.

headline: L.A. County to Pay $5 Million to Election Executive Wrongly Charged With Data Breach
abstract: Eugene Yu, the owner of an election software company, was arrested in 2022 on charges of breaching election data. Those charges were dropped weeks later.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles County agreed to pay $5 million to the top executive of an election software company who had been arrested and charged in 2022 with mishandling voter data in a case that prosecutors dropped a few weeks later, the executive’s lawyer said this week.

headline: The U.S. Economy Continues to Defy Expectations
abstract: Also, the U.S. said North Korean threats should be taken seriously. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The American economy grew at a healthy pace through the end of 2023, according to government data released today. Unemployment remained low, inflation continued to cool and gross domestic product rose at a 3.3 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, beating forecasters’ expectations.

headline: Cheney Says Haley Should Stay in G.O.P. Primary Through Super Tuesday
abstract: Liz Cheney, the former congresswoman and an outspoken critic of former President Donald J. Trump, made the remarks in a podcast that will be released on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Former Representative Liz Cheney urged Nikki Haley to stay in the Republican primary race through Super Tuesday in an episode of “Pod Save America” that will be released on Friday. Ms. Cheney, an outspoken critic of former President Donald J. Trump, called his candidacy an “existential threat” to the nation and commended Ms. Haley for running against him, despite her long odds.

headline: Trump Ally Withdraws Plan for a G.O.P. Resolution to Move Past Haley
abstract: David Bossie, an R.N.C. committeeman, had proposed a draft resolution declaring Donald Trump “our presumptive 2024 nominee” for president, though it would have had no practical effect on primaries.
lead_paragraph: One of Donald J. Trump’s key allies inside the Republican National Committee withdrew a planned resolution to try to force the party’s official body to say that the G.O.P. presidential nominating contest is effectively over, even though only two states have voted and Nikki Haley has vowed to continue her campaign against the dominant front-runner.

headline: Not Feeling Your Partner’s Name? Just Change It.
abstract: When Nikki Haley decided that her future husband, Bill, looked more like a Michael, a Michael he became. How unusual are name-change proclamations in the world of love?
lead_paragraph: Back when Nikki Haley, the last woman standing in the race for the Republican nomination, began dating her now-husband, she took a look at him and asked him what his name was.

headline: G.O.P. Infighting and Democratic Mischief Animate Montana Senate Race
abstract: Even as a Republican primary clash brews between an establishment-backed businessman and a far-right agitator, Democrats are subtly trying to insert themselves.
lead_paragraph: In one of the nation’s top Senate races, the most important candidate might be one who hasn’t actually entered the contest.

headline: Trump’s ‘Al Capone’ Strategy Carries Risks in November
abstract: Highlighting his own trials could backfire on Trump.
lead_paragraph: Two days after his victory in the New Hampshire primary, Donald Trump was back in court today, testifying in the defamation case brought against him in New York by E. Jean Carroll, the writer who has accused him of raping her in a department store dressing room in the 1990s.

headline: An Unlikely New Threat to Haiti’s Stability: An Armed Environmental Group
abstract: The country’s political crisis grew more volatile this week after an armed environmental brigade allied with a former coup leader began demanding the prime minister’s ouster.
lead_paragraph: In Haiti, as the number of murders soar and kidnappings rise, even the police are fleeing.

headline: Trump Joins Motion to Disqualify Prosecutor in Georgia Election Case
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s lawyers argued that Fani T. Willis violated state bar rules when she claimed in a recent speech that racism was behind the effort to remove her.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump on Thursday joined an effort to disqualify Fani T. Willis from leading the election interference case against Mr. Trump in Georgia, on the grounds that she created a conflict of interest by hiring her romantic partner to help prosecute the case.

headline: Rep. Bowman Faulted in Capitol False Alarm, but Spared Inquiry
abstract: The House’s Office of Congressional Ethics found that Jamaal Bowman’s explanation for pulling a House fire alarm last September was “less than credible.”
lead_paragraph: The House Ethics Committee on Thursday dropped its investigation into Representative Jamaal Bowman of New York for pulling a House fire alarm, but released a report that found his explanations “less than credible and otherwise misleading.”

headline: Airlines Hoping for More Boeing Jets Could Be Waiting Awhile
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration’s decision to limit Boeing’s production of 737 Max planes could hurt airlines that are struggling to buy enough new aircraft.
lead_paragraph: Boeing hoped 2024 would be the year it would significantly increase production of its popular Max jets. But less than a month into the year, the company is struggling to reassure airline customers that it will still be able to deliver on its promises.

headline: The Alabama Execution Case: What We Know
abstract: Kenneth Eugene Smith was put to death by nitrogen gas on Thursday night, the first time the method was used in capital punishment in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Alabama carried out on Thursday the first execution using nitrogen gas in the United States, an untested method that was the subject of debate before it was used. The inmate, Kenneth Smith, was pronounced dead at 8:25 p.m. Central time at the William C. Holman Correctional Facility in Atmore, Ala., after the U.S. Supreme Court denied an appeal to stay the execution.

headline: Bidencare Is a Really Big Deal
abstract: Health coverage is one area where a president’s policy makes all the difference.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, at the signing of the Affordable Care Act, a.k.a. Obamacare, Joe Biden, the vice president at the time, was caught on a hot mic telling President Barack Obama that the bill was a “big deal.” OK, there was actually another word in the middle. Anyway, Biden was right.

headline: How to Save a Sad, Lonely, Angry and Mean Society
abstract: Consuming culture gives us the emotional knowledge that can make us better people.
lead_paragraph: Recently, while browsing in the Museum of Modern Art store in New York, I came across a tote bag with the inscription, “You are no longer the same after experiencing art.” It’s a nice sentiment, I thought, but is it true? Or to be more specific: Does consuming art, music, literature and the rest of what we call culture make you a better person?

headline: Herbert Coward, Actor Who Played Toothless Man in ‘Deliverance,’ Dies at 85
abstract: The actor was killed in a motor vehicle accident in North Carolina, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Herbert Coward, the actor whose modest career included the small but memorable role of Toothless Man in the 1972 thriller “Deliverance,” was killed on Thursday in a motor vehicle accident in North Carolina. He was 85.

headline: Indigenous Australians Plan to Go Bigger on Australia Day
abstract: “Invasion Day is the reason why we’re all here today, but we must go beyond that,” one activist said.
lead_paragraph: Parades, Union Jack themed barbecues, angry protests, and reflective vigils — it’s 2024, and Jan. 26 in Australia remains a day that inspires many different reactions across the nation.

headline: Victims Describe Their Pain and Prisoners Apologize in Bali Bombing Trial
abstract: A Guantánamo military court heard anguishing testimony at the sentencing hearing for two Malaysian prisoners who pleaded guilty after 20 years of detention.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of tourists killed in the 2002 terrorist bombing in Bali, Indonesia, spoke of endless, devastating grief, and two prisoners who conspired in the attack renounced violence in the name of Islam on Thursday for a U.S. military jury assembled at Guantánamo Bay to deliberate their sentence.

headline: ‘Once Upon a Mattress’ Review: Sutton Foster as a Perfectly Goofy Princess
abstract: The Encores! series returns with a concert staging of the 1959 musical, which also stars the very funny Harriet Harris and Michael Urie.
lead_paragraph: Some casting choices are blindingly obvious. That does not make them lazy; it makes them right.

headline: Read the Supreme Court’s Decision Allowing an Alabama Execution to Proceed
abstract: The Supreme Court on Thursday allowed the first American execution using nitrogen gas to move forward, with the court’s three liberal members publicly dissenting.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Thursday allowed the first American execution using nitrogen gas to move forward, with the court’s three liberal members publicly dissenting.

headline: Jesse Jane, Pornographic Film Star, Dies at 43
abstract: She starred in the highest-budget series in pornographic film history. She was also seen in some mainstream productions.
lead_paragraph: Jesse Jane, a onetime Hooters waitress and beauty pageant contestant who went on to star in the highest-budget series in pornographic film history, was found dead on Wednesday at a home in Oklahoma. She was 43.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 26, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Jan. 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about Republicans in Congress who are now endorsing Donald Trump after his New Hampshire primary win misquoted Senator John Thune, Republican of South Dakota. He stated he has always said he would “support” the eventual Republican Party presidential nominee, not that he would “endorse” the nominee.

headline: ‘The Door’s Open!’
abstract: Sarah Sinclair and Rafael Musa invite us in.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: David Balton and Jane Stewart provide an endearing, confessional puzzle.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Solving this puzzle made me very nostalgic. It’s a passage by David Sedaris, a writer whom I discovered early in his career (via his 1994 book, “Barrel Fever”), before I myself settled into adulthood. He’s a meticulous memoirist, and I have learned so much about him over the years — from his youth spent in the oddest jobs to his current extravagant walking habit, which I envy and which will hopefully keep him alive forever. It’s almost as if we’ve grown up and old together.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Met Taps Endowment to Keep the Curtain Up
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “For most people the pandemic is over. For arts institutions, we’re still in it.”

headline: One of 2 Inmates Who Escaped Arkansas Jail Is Caught
abstract: Noah Roush, 22, was captured Thursday after he and another detainee escaped from a jail in Pine Bluff this week. The other escapee, a murder suspect, remains at large.
lead_paragraph: One of two men who escaped from an Arkansas jail this week has been captured, the authorities said, after officials received a tip that he was hiding out in an abandoned home. The other escapee, a murder suspect, was still at large.

headline: Republican-Appointed Judge Denounces Republican Distortions of Jan. 6
abstract: In a scathing statement, a Reagan appointee quoted statements about the riot that appeared to be from several Republican politicians and called them “preposterous.”
lead_paragraph: A Republican-appointed judge on Thursday denounced as “shameless” the attempts by prominent Republican politicians to recast the Jan. 6 riot in a positive light, including by portraying the Trump supporters who sacked Congress as having done nothing wrong and by calling those convicted of crimes political prisoners or hostages.

headline: Former W.W.E. Employee Accuses Vince McMahon of Sex Trafficking
abstract: In a lawsuit, the woman says Mr. McMahon hired her at the pro wrestling company in exchange for sex and then abused her for years.
lead_paragraph: A former employee of World Wrestling Entertainment sued Vince McMahon, the longtime chairman and chief executive of W.W.E., in federal court on Thursday, accusing him of physical and emotional abuse, sexual assault and trafficking.

headline: Boebert Is Target of Rivals at Debate for New-to-Her District
abstract: Seeking a better shot at victory, and after the “Beetlejuice” incident, Lauren Boebert is shifting districts for her 2024 run. Her fellow Republicans onstage reminded her of it repeatedly.
lead_paragraph: Representative Lauren Boebert, the far-right firebrand, faced off against eight Republican opponents on Thursday night in a debate in the new Colorado district she is seeking to represent in Congress.

headline: They Believed That God Had Brought Them Together
abstract: When the Rev. Peter Manning learned that Garth Wingfield had also completed the spiritual exercises of St. Ignatius, he thought, “Don’t screw this up.”
lead_paragraph: At first, the striking similarities in the Rev. Peter Manning and Garth Wingfield’s life paths made for fun first-date fodder. And then the parallels became too pronounced to chalk up to coincidence.

headline: After Divorcing, They Turned to Each Other. Again.
abstract: After Pamela Dillon and Stephen Dillon split in 2008, they became business partners. Over a decade later, they realized they were still in love.
lead_paragraph: After a brief introduction at La Terrasse, a bar on the University of Pennsylvania’s campus that has since closed, on Sept. 29, 1983, Pamela Ann Dillon spent the next few hours hanging on to Stephen Michael Dillon’s every word.

headline: They Fell in Love After She ‘Bamboozled’ Him.
abstract: During the coronavirus lockdown, Joseph Caneco and Layne Hilton were both willing to step outside their comfort zones, if not their homes.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Anthony Caneco waited a week to respond to Layne Clark Hilton when she messaged him on Tinder in May 2020 — not because he was playing games, but because he was in a semi-crisis. He had to keep bringing Beanhead, his beloved cat, back to the emergency room. “I had my hands full,” he said.

headline: The Cost of the American Dream? Our Intimacy.
abstract: A physical relationship is nearly impossible for a hard-working Bangladeshi taxi driver and his wife, who longed for each other.
lead_paragraph: Certain mornings can seem exceptionally beautiful for no apparent reason. One morning many years ago, 18 months after my wife and I had moved to New York City from Dhaka, Bangladesh, my heart felt light. The sun had risen brilliantly, dispelling the gloom that had clouded the skies for days. Maybe I was feeling good because of this.

headline: After 25 Years of Practice, They Decided to Make It Legal
abstract: In 1998, Timothy Braun and Peter Arnold fell in love fast. Once gay marriage became legal, they were so busy raising daughters and building a life that they never got around to making it official.
lead_paragraph: Over this past Thanksgiving holiday, Timothy Craig Braun and Peter David Arnold broke the news to their 19-year-old fraternal twin daughters: After 25 years together, they were finally getting married.

headline: In Angola, a Former Cold War Rival, Blinken Touts U.S. Investments
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken finished a four-nation tour of Africa with a visit to Angola, site of major new U.S. investments, which may help counter China’s influence.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken wrapped up a four-nation tour through Africa on Thursday with a visit to Angola, an oil-rich former Cold War battleground that has become the site of a struggle for 21st-century economic influence.

headline: As China’s Markets Stumble, Japan Rises Toward Record
abstract: A change in perception among investors about China and Japan is one of the biggest themes in the markets right now.
lead_paragraph: There’s a shift underway in Asia that’s reverberating through global financial markets.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: The uncertain future for Gaza.
lead_paragraph: What could happen to Gaza in the aftermath of Israel’s war? A clear line between war and peace in Gaza is deeply implausible, with Israeli forces likely to come in and out of the territory for a long time, and the future is murky at best, Steven Erlanger, our chief diplomatic correspondent, writes in an analysis.

headline: South Africa Sees Its Moral Conscience in a Genocide Case
abstract: For some South Africans, their nation’s charge of genocide against Israel evokes the ideals of the anti-apartheid struggle.
lead_paragraph: This month I went with my 18-year-old daughter to see the South African singer Thandiswa Mazwai perform with her band at a music festival in Manhattan.

headline: Explicit Deepfake Images of Taylor Swift Elude Safeguards and Swamp Social Media
abstract: Fans of the star and lawmakers condemned the images, probably generated by artificial intelligence, after they were shared with millions of social media users.
lead_paragraph: Fake, sexually explicit images of Taylor Swift likely generated by artificial intelligence spread rapidly across social media platforms this week, disturbing fans who saw them and reigniting calls from lawmakers to protect women and crack down on the platforms and technology that spread such images.

headline: Word of the Day: atavistic
abstract: This word has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word atavistic has appeared in 10 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 21 in “The Robots Can’t Take Taxi-Whistling Away From Me” by Jon Gluck:

headline: Late Night Mocks Trump’s Three-Minute Testimony
abstract: “We’re smack-dab in the heart of primary season, and Donald Trump is out there trying to win over the voters that matter most: his juries,” Stephen Colbert said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Email Misfire Adds Drama to the War for a New York Casino License
abstract: An errant email has led to collusion accusations and subpoenas, illustrating the cutthroat environment surrounding the battle for a casino license in New York.
lead_paragraph: In the billionaire-versus-billionaire contest to open a casino in the United States’ last, great untapped gambling market, an errant email can become a dangerous weapon in an opponent’s hands.

headline: Hot-Air Balloon
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Truman Capote Cashed In on His Friends’ Secrets. It Cost Him Everything.
abstract: The rarefied social circle that embraced Capote, and eventually banished him, is up for re-evaluation in the new television series “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans.”
lead_paragraph: In 1979, five years before he died and four years after his exile from the Upper East Side’s social cockpit, Truman Capote appeared on a talk show as a friend of the common man. The host, David Susskind, remained unpersuaded. “You are always on people’s yachts” and in “great mansions on Long Island,” he pointed out. “The thing in Spain with the Pamplona bull runs.” Come on.

headline: Kenyan Court Blocks Deployment of Police Force to Haiti
abstract: A contingent of 1,000 Kenyan officers was intended to lead a multinational force financed by the United States to restore security in a Caribbean country terrorized by armed gangs.
lead_paragraph: A Kenyan court on Friday prohibited the deployment of 1,000 Kenyan police officers to Haiti, jeopardizing a multinational security force charged with stabilizing the chaos-hit Caribbean island nation before it even got off the ground.

headline: King Charles Admitted to U.K. Hospital for Prostate Procedure
abstract: Buckingham Palace said the king was being treated at a London hospital. Catherine, Princess of Wales, remains hospitalized after abdominal surgery last week.
lead_paragraph: King Charles III has been admitted to a London hospital for a procedure to treat an enlarged prostate, Buckingham Palace confirmed on Friday.

headline: My Sister and I Didn’t Speak for Decades. Could a Baby Change That?
abstract: Estrangement felt like a hole that was impossible to fill. The birth of my daughter provided the impetus to try.
lead_paragraph: The woman in the vegan diner mentioned her thumbs. They looked like they had been hammered flat, just like mine. I felt the rush of connection, followed by the ache of regret. This woman, my sister, was a stranger.

headline: The Best Part of Tiny Living? The ‘Freedom We Have Created for Ourselves.’
abstract: With a little house in The Hague, a compact getaway on the Italian island of Sardinia and a well-designed camper van, who needs a conventional home?
lead_paragraph: Who says you have to live in one place? Maybe a few tiny homes would be preferable.

headline: Cupcake A.T.M.s and Fire Pits: What You Love at the Airport
abstract: We asked readers to share their favorite airport amenities. The answers: everything from a library to a swimming pool. Here’s a selection of delights, open to all, from airports around the globe.
lead_paragraph: For many travelers, airports are places to pass through as swiftly as possible, not places to savor. The incessant drone of announcements, the frustration of being shut out of increasingly exclusive lounges, the overpriced food, the serpentine lines and the fruitless search for an electrical outlet all can make for a hellish experience.

headline: What Do A.A., Burning Man and the Talmud Have in Common? This Guy.
abstract: In “Subculture Vulture,” the comedian Moshe Kasher explores the six wildly differing communities that made him who he is, for better or worse.
lead_paragraph: About three-quarters of the way through his new memoir, “Subculture Vulture,” the writer and comedian Moshe Kasher warns that, right about now, readers might want to bail and head to YouTube: He’s about to explain the Talmud.

headline: Will Fanatics Upend the World of Sports Collectibles?
abstract: Powered by its connections with leagues and star athletes, the merchandising giant has entered the hobby universe with deep pockets and sharp elbows. Not everyone is happy.
lead_paragraph: On the Saturday before Thanksgiving, thousands of people filed into a dated convention center near O’Hare Airport to participate in the very American pastime of buying and selling sports trading cards.

headline: Audiobook of the Week: Leslie Jones Riffs in the Recording Studio
abstract: The comedian goes off-script while revisiting her raw and hilarious memoir, “Leslie F*cking Jones.”
lead_paragraph: Leslie Jones has been a comedian for decades, but listening to her read her memoir, “Leslie F*cking Jones,” you get the impression that she still has all the vigor of someone only getting started.

headline: The 100-Year Extinction Panic Is Back, Right on Schedule
abstract: The end is near. Again.
lead_paragraph: “Do you think we’ll need to buy guns?” The student’s question seemed to drop the temperature in the room by several degrees. I was at a dinner with fellow academics, a few college students and a guest speaker who had just delivered an inspiring talk about climate justice.

headline: The Worst Masterpiece: ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ at 100
abstract: A jazz musician considers the legacy and unfulfilled promise of George Gershwin’s catchy — or you could say corny — repertory staple.
lead_paragraph: The work is a guaranteed success. After it is over, audience members leap out of their seats for a standing ovation.

headline: Picture Books About the Way We Look
abstract: A story of gross beauty from David Sedaris and Ian Falconer, a scabrous tale from Beatrice Alemagna, and more.
lead_paragraph: Who’s good-looking? Who’s not? Those are loaded questions that, these days, kid lit mostly avoids.

headline: Photos That Capture the Soul of 1960s Dublin
abstract: Nearly six decades ago, a German-born photographer, Evelyn Hofer, created beautifully crafted shots of the city and its people.
lead_paragraph: For six months between 1965 and 1966, the German-born photographer Evelyn Hofer worked in Dublin, creating beautifully crafted portraits of the city and its people. Hofer took her time composing each shot, whether it captured a pair of housekeepers in brief repose or James Joyce’s death mask. The results were published in book form in 1967, to accompany an extended essay by V.S. Pritchett. Now, in DUBLIN (Steidl, $58), those images stand on their own to tell a thoughtful story of the city both in black-and-white and in quiet color.

headline: Are You a Fan of Movie Remakes?
abstract: Can they be just as good, or even better, than the originals?
lead_paragraph: Have you seen any movies lately? When you choose what to watch, are you more likely to go for something new and original, or rather a remake of an old favorite?

headline: Can A.I. Help the Fire Trucks Show Up Sooner?
abstract: A research project aims to gather street-level data that can be used to help emergency responders avoid getting stuck in traffic.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at how an artificial intelligence project could help the Fire Department cut response times for firefighters and ambulances. We’ll also look at Donald Trump’s brief testimony at his defamation trial.

headline: The Enduring Appeal of Britain’s Posh Young Things
abstract: For 13 years, the reality show “Made in Chelsea” has taken viewers inside the wealthy London borough. Soon, an Australian spinoff will test if it works elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: In late 2010, on the verge of signing a contract to appear on a new reality TV series about fashionable young people in one of London’s wealthiest boroughs, Ollie Locke, then 23, had a moment of hesitation.

headline: What Do You Call a Galaxy Without Stars?
abstract: To dark matter and dark energy, add dark galaxies — collections of stars so sparse and faint that they are all but invisible.
lead_paragraph: What do you call a galaxy without stars?

headline: Is Cryptocurrency Like Stocks and Bonds? Courts Move Closer to an Answer.
abstract: Federal judges are weighing whether digital currencies should be subject to the same rules as stocks and bonds. The outcome could shape crypto’s future in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, the pioneers of the cryptocurrency industry envisioned digital coins as an alternate branch of finance, a renegade sector that would operate outside the reach of big banks and government regulators.

headline: You Saw Jason Kelce. This Guy Saw ‘The Feast of Bacchus.’
abstract: With his Art But Make It Sports social media accounts, LJ Rader connects the drama and pathos of classic artwork to viral moments in sports. And no, he’s not using A.I.
lead_paragraph: LJ Rader tries to be online as much as possible during big sporting events, but he missed the first half of last Sunday’s N.F.L. playoff game between the Buffalo Bills and the Kansas City Chiefs because of a dinner engagement. After he left the restaurant, Mr. Rader checked his phone and saw an unusual request: The N.F.L. had tagged him on X, formerly known as Twitter, hoping he would deliver one of his signature creations.

headline: Could Israel Cost Biden the Election?
abstract: The hosts unpack the truism that voters don’t care about foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: It’s an old truism that Americans don’t care about foreign policy when it’s time to cast their ballots. But with the crisis in Gaza, a prolonged conflict in Ukraine and a trade war brewing with China, could 2024 be the year that American voters finally care about what’s going on beyond the water’s edge?

headline: ‘Zoomers’ Review: Just Don’t Kill the Vibes
abstract: Gen Z’s reputation for conflict avoidance, and the way digital media abets it, is a recurring theme in the latest by the “Dimes Square” playwright Matthew Gasda.
lead_paragraph: “Zoomers,” the new play written and directed by Matthew Gasda, explores the specific milieu of artsy 20-something transplants, largely the same population that frequents the Greenpoint loft of the Brooklyn Center for Theater Research, where the show is currently running.

headline: Gen Z Is Listening to What Netanyahu Is Saying. Is Biden?
abstract: Israel is losing the support of a generation, not just a few student groups. And it is losing it because of what it does, not what it is.
lead_paragraph: “My insistence is what has prevented — over the years — the establishment of a Palestinian state that would have constituted an existential danger to Israel,” Benjamin Netanyahu said on Sunday. “As long as I am prime minister, I will continue to strongly insist on this.”

headline: A Child of Another War Who Makes Music for Ukrainians
abstract: Mirza Ramic, a Bosnian who sought refuge in the United States, is bringing his electronic music to Ukraine, “to show my support in these hard times.”
lead_paragraph: When the owner of an underground club in Kyiv reached out to Western musicians to play in Ukraine, long before the war, there were not so many takers.

headline: New Music for Your Weekend
abstract: From a stadium-size stomp to the most intimate private reflection.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, our chief pop music critic, picks his favorite new tracks to listen to this weekend:

headline: Nikki Haley and the W-Word
abstract: Haley doesn’t talk very much about her gender, even though it excites some voters.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2012, long before Nikki Haley hit the presidential campaign trail — and years before Hillary Clinton faced off against Donald Trump — Ms. Haley, then the governor of South Carolina, told this newspaper, “The reason I actually ran for office is because of Hillary Clinton.”

headline: Mediapocalypse Now, a16z’s Chris Dixon Defends Crypto, and HatGPT
abstract: Strangely a lot of pro wrestling in this episode.
lead_paragraph: Layoffs are hitting newsrooms and publishers again, as tech platforms, ad markets and artificial intelligence reshape the internet. Kevin Roose and Casey Newton have ideas for solutions. Then, one of the most influential investors in crypto companies lays out where the industry went wrong, and why he still thinks blockchains are the future. And finally, a round of HatGPT with the week’s tech headlines, including a spicy LinkedIn post and an A.I. test that disturbs Kevin and Casey’s sense of reality.

headline: With ‘Masters of the Air,’ a 10-Year Dream Lifts Off
abstract: The Apple TV+ series from Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks is an heir to their World War II epic “Band of Brothers,” set this time among a group of bomber pilots.
lead_paragraph: After Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks spearheaded the epic 2001 World War II series “Band of Brothers,” Spielberg got some feedback from one of his most important critics.

headline: One Hope From Changes at This Holocaust Museum: Fewer Nazi Selfies
abstract: A redesign at the Zekelman Holocaust Center near Detroit provides less opportunity to pose in front of Nazi images as it attempts to refocus attention on the victims, not the perpetrators.
lead_paragraph: Students on school trips to a Holocaust museum outside Detroit would stand riveted at one stark display: a Nazi officer’s black uniform with a red swastika armband, guns and a whip.

headline: Bettina Was Much More Than an Eccentric of the Chelsea Hotel
abstract: A gallery in New York’s Chinatown has brought downtown buzz to an enigmatic artist, two years after her death.
lead_paragraph: One night in November, a procession of young artists, critics and curators climbed the creaky stairs of a building in Chinatown in Lower Manhattan to attend an opening at a buzzy little gallery, Ulrik. The show, “Bettina: New York 1965–86,” was made up of rarely seen photographs and sculptures by an enigmatic artist who lived for five decades at the fabled Chelsea Hotel, where she created her works in a cluttered fifth-floor apartment until her death in 2021.

headline: The New York Times Quiz, Jan. 26, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Luxury Fireplaces Are Keeping New Yorkers Warm This Winter
abstract: Once a necessity, fireplaces are now an indulgence in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Once a necessity, fireplaces are now an indulgence in New York City.

headline: ‘Godzilla Minus One’ Stomps Into ‘Oppenheimer’ Territory
abstract: Those movies, along with “The Boy and the Heron,” are essentially in conversation about the moral weight of American and Japanese actions in World War II.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t expecting to cry as much as I did at “Godzilla Minus One.” The strong word-of-mouth made it sound like an awesome spectacle with cool action courtesy of the scaly title creature. And while there were awe-inducing showdowns with the monster, the Toho International production, written and directed by Takashi Yamazaki, is largely a meditation on sorrow and survival in the wake of World War II.

headline: Alabama Hails Nitrogen Gas Execution, a New Attempt to Address an Old Challenge
abstract: Fending off doubts and criticisms, Alabama’s attorney general hailed a new execution method as “humane and effective.”
lead_paragraph: For as long as America has had the death penalty, there have been questions about how best to carry it out. The execution of Kenneth Eugene Smith in Alabama on Thursday, the first American execution in which death was caused by suffocation with nitrogen gas, gave no indication of settling the legal, moral and technical questions that have long bedeviled states as they mete out the ultimate punishment.

headline: Midlife Doesn’t Have to Be a Crisis
abstract: We asked experts for tips on savoring and celebrating this phase of life.
lead_paragraph: My teenage daughter recently asked me what my favorite decade has been so far. “This one,” I told her. “My 50s.” She stared at me in disbelief. “But you’re middle-aged,” she said.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the new comedy from Mike Judge and Zach Woods, “In the Know”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the new comedy from Mike Judge and Zach Woods, “In the Know”

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by V.V. Ganeshananthan, John Hendrickson, De’Shawn Charles Winslow and more.
lead_paragraph: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by V.V. Ganeshananthan, John Hendrickson, De’Shawn Charles Winslow and more.

headline: Panama Canal Drought Slows Cargo Traffic
abstract: The lake that allows the Panama Canal to function is at the lowest water level ever recorded for the start of the dry season.
lead_paragraph: The lake that allows the Panama Canal to function is at the lowest water level ever recorded for the start of the dry season.

headline: MoveOn Will Spend $32 Million to Back Biden and Other Democrats
abstract: The liberal group plans to pour cash into an effort to generate enthusiasm for the president and support Democratic Senate and House candidates.
lead_paragraph: The liberal activist group MoveOn will spend more than $32 million this year to back President Biden and Democratic candidates for the House and Senate, the organization’s leader said this week.

headline: Pennsylvania Governor Proposes to Overhaul the State University System
abstract: Gov. Josh Shapiro, declaring that the system is broken, plans to place most schools under the same system and lower tuition for low- and middle-income students.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania, who has complained that his state’s higher education “isn’t working,” proposed on Friday a sweeping overhaul of the state’s sprawling college and university system that would reduce tuition for many students and determine funding for individual schools based in part on their performance.

headline: The Wrong Party May Be Worrying About Its Nominee
abstract: Trump is assured of nothing.
lead_paragraph: Technically speaking, Donald Trump is still far from winning the Republican presidential nomination, but his victory on Tuesday in the New Hampshire primary was enough to push the Republican National Committee off the sidelines and into his corner.

headline: The Costumes of the Very, Very Rich
abstract: Forget quiet luxury. Maison Margiela, Fendi and Valentino offer some singular propositions.
lead_paragraph: The night of the wolf moon — the first full moon of the new year — also happened to be the last night of the couture, when John Galliano recreated a decaying Paris nightclub in the vaulted caverns beneath Paris’s Pont Alexandre III bridge across the Seine.

headline: The Mother Who Changed: A Story of Dementia
abstract: When cognitive decline changes people, should we respect their new desires?
lead_paragraph: Across the United States, millions of families are confronting a seemingly impossible question: When dementia changes a relative, how much should they accommodate their new personality and desires?

headline: Russia Extends American Journalist’s Detention
abstract: The ruling means that Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, will spend at least a year in custody awaiting trial on a spying charge Washington says is politically motivated.
lead_paragraph: A court in Moscow on Friday extended the pretrial detention of an American reporter for The Wall Street Journal who is awaiting a hearing on an espionage charge that he, his newspaper and the U.S. government vehemently deny.

headline: U.N. Court Declines to Order Cease-Fire, and Trump Takes the Stand
abstract: Plus, alarming Taylor Swift deepfakes.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: How Donald Trump Divided Republicans on Immigration
abstract: Trump’s growing influence is dividing Republicans on an issue that once united the party.
lead_paragraph: Just as senators were closing in on a deal that Republican negotiators said would constitute the most conservative border security bill in decades, Donald Trump was closing in on the G.O.P. presidential nomination.

headline: ‘Mutt,’ ‘Unpregnant’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: The complexities of 21st-century romantic entanglements are front and center in this month’s roundup of hidden gems on your subscription streaming services.
lead_paragraph: Vuk Lungulov-Klotz’s micro-budget New York drama is everything indie movies are supposed to be: keenly observed and modestly executed, telling us a story and showing us a world we don’t usually see in mainstream cinema. In this case, it’s the world of Feña (Lío Mehiel), a transgender man and a semi-desperate pseudo-hustler whose life goes momentarily topsy-turvy when he accidentally reconnects with a former boyfriend from before his transition. Every performer is on point, natural and credible, and the screenplay is lived-in and mostly devoid of histrionics (Feña gives a big speech to his dad about how difficult it all is, and it’s the single false note, the only scene that feels like a scene from a movie instead of a scene from real life). This is a small film, but a mighty one.

headline: The F.T.C. Takes on A.I. Deals
abstract: The agency is concerned that transactions including Microsoft’s $13 billion investment in OpenAI could hinder competition and innovation.
lead_paragraph: Tech giants like Microsoft, Amazon and Google have sought an edge in the artificial intelligence race by investing in innovative start-ups like OpenAI and Anthropic.

headline: These Are Superior Potatoes
abstract: You’d expect a Kenji López-Alt recipe for roasted potatoes to produce scientifically proven, unfailingly crispy potatoes. You’d be right.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Mark Bittman is a freewheeling cook, a minimalist, open to improvisation. His recipes are often set-it-and-forget-it in style. If I were writing his biography, I’d title it “Largely Unattended.”

headline: Calista Flockhart Is Back, With a Flock of Venomous Swans
abstract: The “Ally McBeal” star takes on the darker, dagger-like role of Lee Radziwill in “Feud.”
lead_paragraph: On a chilly January weekend in Los Angeles, I turned into a truffle pig. I foraged relentlessly all over town, looking for truffle fries.

headline: A Key Inflation Measure Cooled in December
abstract: Inflation has been slowing swiftly, and fresh data showed that a core price gauge fell below 3 percent for the first time in years last month.
lead_paragraph: A measure of inflation closely watched by the Federal Reserve continued to cool in December, the latest sign that price increases are coming back under control even as growth remains solid and the labor market healthy. In particularly positive news, a key gauge of price increases dipped below 3 percent for the first time since early 2021.

headline: Read the I.C.J. ruling
abstract: The International Court of Justice issued a preliminary ruling in a case accusing Israel of committing genocide in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice issued a preliminary ruling in a case accusing Israel of committing genocide in Gaza.

headline: More Atmospheric Rivers Are on the Way. Here’s What the West Can Expect.
abstract: A sequence of atmospheric rivers will bring heavy rainfall and snow to the Western U.S. and Canada over the next week.
lead_paragraph: The Western United States and Canada are likely to see excessive rain and heavy snowfall from a sequence of back-to-back atmospheric rivers beginning this weekend and continuing into next week.

headline: Jamie Dimon Reshuffles Management Team at JPMorgan Chase
abstract: Many consider the moves a sign of a succession plan at the nation’s largest bank, although the stalwart Mr. Dimon has signaled he is not going anywhere.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is reshuffling its leadership team, a move that many consider a succession plan even though its longtime chief executive, Jamie Dimon, has signaled he is staying put.

headline: More Tenants Can Now Add Rent Payments to Their Credit Score
abstract: Policymakers view the reporting of an on-time pattern as a way to reduce disparities in homeownership.
lead_paragraph: About a third of American households rent, yet in most cases their credit score doesn’t reflect their on-time payments.

headline: ‘Dry-Clean Only’? Not Necessarily.
abstract: Forget what the label says.
lead_paragraph: Forget what the label says.

headline: China Is Trying to Have It Both Ways in the Middle East
abstract: Beijing must share more of the burden of protecting sea lanes that are vital for its trade interests.
lead_paragraph: There has been plenty of hand-wringing in the West about the prospect of China displacing — or at least rivaling — the United States as the world’s leading superpower. But the evolving security crisis in the Red Sea makes clear that this remains a distant prospect.

headline: Leading Museums Remove Native Displays Amid New Federal Rules
abstract: The American Museum of Natural History is closing two major halls as museums around the nation respond to updated policies from the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: The American Museum of Natural History will close two major halls exhibiting Native American objects, its leaders said on Friday, in a dramatic response to new federal regulations that require museums to obtain consent from tribes before displaying or performing research on cultural items.

headline: Your Favorite Roadside Attractions
abstract: It’s been delightful reading your emails about favorite stops, and seeing the state’s highways and landmarks through your eyes.
lead_paragraph: Driving to Davis from the Bay Area on Interstate 80 last week, I spotted a cow jumping over the moon.

headline: Jury Orders Trump to Pay Carroll $83.3 Million After Years of Insults
abstract: The ex-president was found liable for sexually abusing E. Jean Carroll, but called her a liar. The award was “a huge defeat for every bully who has tried to keep a woman down,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump was ordered by a Manhattan jury on Friday to pay $83.3 million to the writer E. Jean Carroll for defaming her in 2019 after she accused him of a decades-old rape, attacks he continued in social media posts, at news conferences and even in the midst of the trial itself.

headline: Jo-El Sonnier, Who Sparked a Revival of Cajun Music, Dies at 77
abstract: An accordion virtuoso and a gifted vocalist, he scored country hits in the 1980s by putting a Cajun spin on songs like Richard Thompson’s “Tear-Stained Letter.”
lead_paragraph: Jo-El Sonnier, a singer and accordionist who revived Cajun music in popular culture with hit versions of Richard Thompson’s “Tear-Stained Letter” and Slim Harpo’s “Rainin’ in My Heart,” and with appearances on recordings by Mark Knopfler and Elvis Costello, died on Jan. 13 after a performance in Llano, Texas. He was 77.

headline: Malia Obama at Sundance: A Fledgling Filmmaker Makes Her Debut
abstract: The former first daughter’s short, “The Heart,” focuses on a sensitive man racked with guilt when his mother dies after they have an argument.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a celebrity seeking to rebrand, the Sundance Film Festival can offer a useful assist. From Marvel superheroes seeking an indie turn to teenage movie stars hoping to segue into spicy adult roles, the snowy event is the perfect place to debut a new direction.

headline: Economists Predicted a Recession. So Far They’ve Been Wrong.
abstract: A widely predicted recession never showed up. Now, economists are assessing what the unexpected resilience tells us about the future.
lead_paragraph: The recession America was expecting never showed up.

headline: Israeli Leaders Slam U.N. Court Ruling but Applaud Lack of Cease-fire Order
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called the genocide charge against Israel “outrageous,” but said the U.N. court had upheld the country’s right of self-defense.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Israel on Friday denounced the International Court of Justice’s order seeking to prevent genocidal acts in its offensive against Hamas in Gaza but also expressed relief the court did not order it to halt its military campaign.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a French comedic swashbuckling adventure, Indian spy games and more.
lead_paragraph: Youssef (Nassim Lyes) is a habitual liar, a down-on-his-luck gambler and a hustler of fake luxury handbags. He is working these cons to impress his wealthy girlfriend — she thinks he has a regular office job. When Youssef reveals the truth, including his bald head underneath his wig, she leaves him. Soon Youssef has a new girlfriend, Stephanie (Zoé Marchal), a card shark with a crypto fortune. But his gambling catches up to him, and a few goons are sent to track him down.

headline: Trump Walks Out of Courtroom During Closing Arguments by Carroll’s Lawyer
abstract: The lawyer for E. Jean Carroll began by focusing her presentation on the harm Mr. Trump inflicted on her client. Soon after, he stood up and walked out.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump did not stay to hear closing arguments on Friday from the lawyer representing the woman who sued him.

headline: Phones Track Everything but Their Role in Car Wrecks
abstract: Distracted driving is a worsening problem, safety experts say. Yet there is still no definitive database of the number of crashes or fatalities caused by it.
lead_paragraph: Cellphones can track what we say and write, where we go, what we buy and what we search on the internet. But they still aren’t being used to track one of the biggest public health threats: crashes caused by drivers distracted by the phones.

headline: U.N. to Investigate Claim That Employees Participated in Oct. 7 Attack
abstract: The United States temporarily cut off funding to UNRWA, the agency that aids Palestinians, citing allegations that 12 of its workers were involved in the Hamas-led assault on southern Israel.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations on Friday fired 12 of its employees in Gaza and began an investigation into them after accusations by Israel that they had helped plan and had participated in the Oct. 7 terrorist assault that left about 1,200 Israelis dead and more than 240 others captured.

headline: Jürgen Klopp Dragged Liverpool Into the Future. Now He’ll Let It Go.
abstract: A trophy-winning manager’s announcement that he will step down at the end of the season is a chance to take the measure of success.
lead_paragraph: For Jürgen Klopp, the montages will be long and they will be emotional. There will, naturally, be artful drone shots of Liverpool’s skyline. There will be slow-motion footage of red-and-white scarves, twirling and writhing. There will, absolutely, be a stirring, possibly classical score.

headline: Biden Administration Pauses Approvals of New Gas Export Terminals
abstract: The president said the government would analyze impacts on climate, the economy and national security before approving new projects.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Friday paused the permitting process for new liquefied natural gas export facilities in order to analyze their impact on climate change, the economy and national security.

headline: Apple Takes Messaging Crackdown to Customers’ Macs
abstract: Beeper Mini customers were using their Mac computers to connect to iPhone messaging on their Android phones. Now, they say Apple has blocked the messaging service on their Macs.
lead_paragraph: When Apple blocked the Beeper Mini app last month from giving Android users access to the tech giant’s messaging service, Beeper encouraged customers to use their Mac computers instead to connect and continue sending messages.

headline: After a Boom, Craft Beer Considers a New Creed: Less Is More
abstract: Many breweries, bars and supermarkets that once offered a dizzying array of new beers are now paring back to a chosen few.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, when Ryan Guererri was in his early 20s, he became obsessed with craft beer. As breweries rolled out a nonstop roster of new products, he bought hundreds of different beers, from bitter I.P.A.s to strong Belgian ales.

headline: JetBlue Says It May Back Out of Deal to Acquire Spirit Airlines
abstract: Spirit said it saw “no basis” for termination. Just last week, both airlines said they intended to appeal a judge’s decision blocking the deal.
lead_paragraph: JetBlue Airways said on Friday that it might back out of a $3.8 billion acquisition of Spirit Airlines after a federal judge blocked the deal.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Modern train heists. Also, ghostwriters emerge from the shadows and why Gen Z believes it’s “aging like milk.”

headline: Biden Administration Faces Pushback on Another Gas Project, This Time Overseas
abstract: After the recent decision to pause the approval process on a giant new export terminal in Louisiana, activists are hoping to stop American money from supporting a project in Papua New Guinea.
lead_paragraph: Even as the Biden administration, under pressure from environmentalists, hits pause on its approval of a major natural gas export terminal in the United States, it faces another big gas decision overseas.

headline: Wayne LaPierre, Longtime N.R.A. Chief, Testifies at Manhattan Trial
abstract: Mr. LaPierre, who is testifying in a civil corruption case, claimed to have no knowledge of the prodigious amounts the National Rifle Association was spending on chartered private jets.
lead_paragraph: With less than a week left as chief of the National Rifle Association, Wayne LaPierre got to look back at his 33-year tenure in a Manhattan courtroom on Friday, when he began testifying in a civil corruption case that the New York attorney general brought against him.

headline: Genocide Ruling Has Deep Symbolism but Little Immediate Effect
abstract: The decision by the World Court did not order Israel to cease its war against Hamas in Gaza. But the court made a move imbued with historical meaning.
lead_paragraph: A ruling on Friday by the International Court of Justice on charges of genocide against Israel had deep historical resonance for both Israelis and Palestinians. But it lacked immediate practical consequences.

headline: At Sundance, a Transcendent Road Trip and Other Reasons to Love Movies
abstract: A documentary about Will Ferrell and his friend Harper Steele brought the house down. It was just one of several discoveries at this year’s festival.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, after days of tramping around Park City, Utah, griping about the movies and the logistical headaches this mountain resort town presents, I was transported into the Sundance Film Festival that I always hope for, the one in which a movie surprises and moves and maybe delights me, and so successfully makes good on its promise that, after the lights come up, the crowd delivers the festival version of hallelujah with a floor-shaking standing ovation. I admit, I wasn’t expecting that to happen when I walked into the new Will Ferrell joint.

headline: Pet Dragons Linked to Rare Salmonella Strain in U.S. and Canada
abstract: Dozens of people, including babies, were sickened, according to a C.D.C. study that highlighted the risks of snuggling with the strikingly scaly lizards, many of which carry salmonella bacteria in their gut.
lead_paragraph: The outbreak of a rare strain of salmonella that sickened scores of people, including several infants, across the United States and Canada, has been linked to pet bearded dragons, some most likely obtained from the same breeder in Southeast Asia, according to a study published by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: Does ‘Barbie’ Deserve All the Hype?
abstract: Pamela Paul thinks not. Our letter writers are split. Also: Donald Trump’s opposition to a border deal in Congress; an Israel-Hamas cease-fire?
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Suspiro a la Limeña, a Peruvian Dessert to Leave You Thunderstruck
abstract: It’s easy to fall for this caramelized custard with a dollop of meringue and a name that evokes a sigh of love.
lead_paragraph: The origin story of one of Peru’s most popular desserts is almost as romantic as its name — suspiro a la limeña, or “the sigh of a lady from Lima.”

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The presidential campaign was top of mind for the hosts, who discussed Gov. Ron DeSantis bowing out and Trump’s victory in the New Hampshire primary over Nikki Haley.
lead_paragraph: The presidential campaign was top of mind for the hosts, who discussed Gov. Ron DeSantis bowing out and Trump’s victory in the New Hampshire primary over Nikki Haley.

headline: Yes, Take Me Back to 2001
abstract: Toward a constructive politics of nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, accepting the Republican nomination for president, an aged (by his era’s standards, not ours) Bob Dole issued a stirring defense of the past against the present. “Let me be the bridge to an America that only the unknowing call myth,” he told his audience. “Let me be the bridge to a time of tranquillity, faith and confidence in action. And to those who say it was never so, that America’s not been better, I say you’re wrong. And I know because I was there. And I have seen it. And I remember.”

headline: Biden Vows Border Shutdown, Pressing Congress to Pass Immigration Deal
abstract: The president’s statement came as the Republican speaker of the House pronounced the emerging bipartisan immigration deal “dead on arrival” in his chamber.
lead_paragraph: President Biden fought on Friday to save a bipartisan immigration deal from collapse in Congress, vowing to shut down the border if the plan became law even as the Republican speaker pronounced it dead on arrival in the House.

headline: Worries in Europe Over the White House Move to Delay Gas Terminals
abstract: The Biden administration’s decision to review new liquefied natural gas projects for their impact on climate change could be a headache for overseas buyers.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s decision to delay approval of new liquefied natural gas terminals in the United States has been hailed as a major victory for environmental advocacy groups, but it is creating unease outside the United States about future energy supplies.

headline: Haley Assails Trump as ‘Unhinged’ and Dismisses Calls to Exit the Race
abstract: Nikki Haley attacked the Republican front-runner during an appearance Friday on Fox News.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley on Friday called Donald J. Trump “totally unhinged” after a failed attempt by one of his allies to push the Republican National Committee to declare him the party’s presumptive nominee, escalating her attacks on his mental acuity.

headline: Buried in Wegovy Costs, North Carolina Will Stop Paying for Obesity Drugs
abstract: Starting April 1, state employees in North Carolina will no longer have insurance coverage for costly weight-loss medications like Wegovy and Zepbound.
lead_paragraph: In June 2021, the insurance plan for North Carolina state employees was paying for 2,800 people to take weight-loss drugs.

headline: ‘In the Summers,’ a Father-Daughters Tale, Wins the Top Prize at Sundance
abstract: The jury focused largely on under-the-radar titles, though a Jesse Eisenberg-Kieran Culkin collaboration also was recognized.
lead_paragraph: “In the Summers,” an independent film about two sisters navigating fraught summer visits with their father, won the top prize in the Sundance Film Festival’s U.S. dramatic competition on Friday. The movie also won the competition’s directing award for its first-time filmmaker, Alessandra Lacorazza.

headline: A New Way to Hear The Amplifier (Plus 5 More Whistling Songs)
abstract: Listen to a deluxe edition of the playlist, including an addition from noted whistler Andrew Bird, now available on Apple Music.
lead_paragraph: Since we started The Amplifier — gasp — almost a year ago now, there is one question I’ve been asked over and over (and over): “When are you going to start putting your playlists on Apple Music?” If you are one of those many people who inquired, I have great news: That day has finally arrived.

headline: Marc Jaffe, Publisher of Paperback Hits, Is Dead at 102
abstract: He oversaw a boom in the format beginning in the 1960s, turning out best sellers like “Jaws,” “The Exorcist” and “The Catcher in the Rye.”
lead_paragraph: Marc Jaffe was at a New Year’s Eve party of Hollywood types in 1967 when a screenwriter named William Peter Blatty began chatting him up.

headline: Justin Timberlake’s Envious Comeback, and 12 More New Songs
abstract: Hear new music from Marc Anthony, Ice Spice and Hiatus Kaiyote.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes), and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: For the Most Groundbreaking Oscar Race This Year, Try Documentaries
abstract: All five nominees are international features focused on geopolitical events, and three are directed by women.
lead_paragraph: Most post-nomination Oscar chatter focuses on surprises and snubs connected to the fiction nominees. But I’m a nonfiction nerd, so for me the documentaries are where it’s at, and in recent years, the picks have grown delightfully unpredictable.

headline: David L. Mills, Who Kept the Internet Running on Time, Dies at 85
abstract: He developed and implemented the protocol that synchronizes the digital clocks nestled within billions of networked devices.
lead_paragraph: David L. Mills, an internet pioneer who developed and, for decades, implemented the timekeeping protocol used by financial markets, power grids, satellites and billions of computers to make sure they run simultaneously, earning him a reputation as the internet’s “Father Time,” died on Jan. 17 at his home in Newark, Del. He was 85.

headline: The Big Number: 3.3%
abstract: The U.S. economy grew at a vigorous pace in the last three month of 2023, despite the high interest rates handed down by the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy grew at a vigorous pace in the last three month of 2023, despite the high interest rates handed down by the Federal Reserve.

headline: Why Nikki Haley Has So Few Friends Left in South Carolina Politics
abstract: Nikki Haley could use some help rescuing her campaign. But Republicans in her home state are flocking to Donald J. Trump.
