lead_paragraph: The stories pile up one after another, of thanks not offered, allies antagonized, opponents not forgiven — a portrait of a politician who climbed the ladder with speed and skill but failed to ensure that the people who helped her would have her back if she needed them.

headline: To Fix Its Airlines, Does the U.S. Need to Rethink Regulation?
abstract: Deregulation has succeeded in some ways, but consumer dissatisfaction abounds.
lead_paragraph: I was a senior in college in 1978 when I wrote my first opinion piece that touched on airline deregulation. It was an editorial in The Cornell Daily Sun (“Ithaca’s only morning newspaper”!) titled “Our Man in Washington,” and it was about Alfred Kahn, a colorful Cornell economist who presided over deregulation of airlines at the Civil Aeronautics Board from 1977 to 1978 before becoming President Jimmy Carter’s inflation czar.

headline: The Dragon-Shaped Japanese Region Where Tokyo Locals Go to Unwind
abstract: A guide to Kagoshima, home to traditional pottery villages and the forest that inspired “Princess Mononoke.”
lead_paragraph: Kagoshima, the prefecture that wraps around the southern end of the Japanese island of Kyushu, is said by some to resemble the head of a dragon. At the mouth of this dragon stands Sakurajima, one of the country’s most active volcanoes, whose plumes of smoke can often be seen from the capital, Kagoshima City, just a short ferry ride away.

headline: Cuomo Created ‘Sexually Hostile’ Workplace, Says Justice Department
abstract: Investigators found that the executive staff of Andrew Cuomo, the former governor, prioritized protecting him rather than the women accusing him of sexual harassment.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice concluded that former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York and his executive staff subjected female employees to a “sexually hostile work environment,” and then retaliated against several who complained, according to a settlement announced on Friday.

headline: The Most Foolproof Way to Cook Fish? The Microwave.
abstract: This appliance can turn out perfectly cooked salmon in less than 10 minutes.
lead_paragraph: Gary Weinstein, a retired lawyer, has lived in Manhattan for 30 years, and for most of that time, he has used his oven for storage. “It stares at me with mockery,” he said, gesturing to the forsaken pans inside.

headline: Jon Franklin, Pioneering Apostle of Literary Journalism, Dies at 82
abstract: He won two Pulitzer Prizes by transforming accounts of doctors at work into in-depth, narrative articles that read like dramatic short stories.
lead_paragraph: Jon Franklin, an apostle of narrative short-story-style journalism whose own work won the first Pulitzer Prizes awarded for feature writing and explanatory journalism, died on Sunday in Annapolis, Md. He was 82.

headline: U.K. Newspaper Deal Seen as a Fight for the Heart of the Tories
abstract: A bid by an Arab American group, fronted by Jeff Zucker, the former CNN president, to buy The Telegraph is under scrutiny. That might leave an opening for a right-wing investor.
lead_paragraph: The Daily Telegraph has long been viewed as the house paper of Britain's Conservative Party. So, it’s perhaps not surprising that a takeover battle for the 168-year-old paper has mutated into a political struggle within the Tory ranks — one that some commentators have gone so far as to cast as a contest for the party’s future.

headline: Happily Married, and Seeing Other People
abstract: The author Molly Roden Winter discusses her new memoir, “More,” about her and her husband’s decision to have an open marriage.
lead_paragraph: Molly Roden Winter and her husband, Stewart, have been married for 24 years. But since 2008, by mutual agreement, they have also dated other people — an arrangement that Winter explains in sometimes granular detail in her new memoir, “More: A Memoir of Open Marriage.”

headline: The Biggest Surprises From the Oscar Nominations
abstract: Though “Oppenheimer” made an explosive showing when the Oscar nominations were announced on Tuesday morning, plenty of other would-be contenders failed to launch. Here is our analysis of the biggest surprises and omissions.
lead_paragraph: Though “Oppenheimer” made an explosive showing when the Oscar nominations were announced on Tuesday morning, plenty of other would-be contenders failed to launch. Here is our analysis of the biggest surprises and omissions.

headline: Voters in Colorado Case Lay Out Their Argument to Block Trump From Ballot
abstract: A group of Colorado voters urged the Supreme Court to uphold a lower court decision blocking the former president from the state’s primary ballot.
lead_paragraph: A group of Colorado voters laid out its argument to the Supreme Court on Friday for why former President Donald J. Trump should be barred from the state’s primary ballot, contending that his actions leading up to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol amounted to an insurrection.

headline: Richard Prince to Pay Photographers Who Sued Over Copyright
abstract: Shortly before trial, Prince agreed to compensate two photographers whose images he had used in an installation.
lead_paragraph: The artist Richard Prince agreed to pay at least $650,000 to two photographers whose images he had incorporated in his own work, ending a long-running copyright dispute that had been closely monitored by the art world.

headline: The meaning of the first I.C.J. ruling in the genocide case against Israel
abstract: And why alliances will determine what comes next.
lead_paragraph: Today the United Nations’ highest court, the International Court of Justice, issued its first, preliminary decision in the genocide case South Africa brought against Israel.

headline: 23andMe Breach Targeted Jewish and Chinese Customers, Lawsuit Says
abstract: The class-action suit said the genetic testing company failed to notify customers whose personal information was compiled into “curated” lists that were sold on the dark web.
lead_paragraph: The genetic testing company 23andMe is being accused in a class-action lawsuit of failing to protect the privacy of customers whose personal information was exposed last year in a data breach that affected nearly seven million profiles.

headline: U.N. Court Stops Short of Calling for Cease-Fire in Gaza
abstract: The International Court of Justice ordered Israel to take actions to prevent genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The International Court of Justice ordered Israel to take actions to prevent genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.

headline: David J. Skal, Scholar Who Took Horror Seriously, Dies at 71
abstract: In books like “The Monster Show” and “Screams of Reason,” he examined the cultural significance of movies meant to scare the bejesus out of people.
lead_paragraph: David J. Skal, a witty historian of horror entertainment who found in movies like “Dracula” and “Rosemary’s Baby” both a mirror of evolving societal fears and a pressure-release valve for those anxieties, died on Jan. 1 in a car accident in Los Angeles. He was 71.

headline: A Fond Farewell to South Korea
abstract: An editor recalls moving to Seoul during the coronavirus pandemic and watching The Times open a digital newsroom in the city.
lead_paragraph: There was no telling what I would find when I arrived in Seoul.

headline: Kim Kardashian Cozies Up to Balenciaga
abstract: And so does Patricia Field. Plus, Zac Posen creates high-society costumes, a tutu sells for $52,000 and a fashion curator gets knighted.
lead_paragraph: Is anyone still rocked by Balenciaga’s notorious ad campaign from 2022 featuring teddy bears in harnesses? Seemingly not Kim Kardashian, who was “re-evaluating” her relationship with the fashion house in the wake of the scandal those ads caused, only to be named an ambassador for the brand this week.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, January 27, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Suggest Events for Flashback, Our Weekly History Quiz
abstract: Every week, we test your knowledge. Now we want to tap your brainpower to compile events.
lead_paragraph: We invite New York Times readers to suggest events to be included in Flashback, our weekly history quiz. Our favorite events aren’t just matters of trivia — they include details that allow people to puzzle out the answers.

headline: 2 Powerful Restaurant Groups Team Up to Make Marea a Global Brand
abstract: Major Food Group, the team behind Carbone, plans to help Altamarea Group open Marea satellites around the world.
lead_paragraph: Marea, the plush Italian seafood restaurant on Central Park South, reopened last fall with subtle renovations to repair flood damage. Now the restaurant is embarking on a bigger change, joining another of New York’s premier restaurant groups to expand what it calls “the Marea brand” worldwide.

headline: Venezuela’s Highest Court Bars Opposition Leader From Running for President
abstract: The move is a crippling blow to a deal in which President Nicolás Maduro’s administration promised a free and fair election in exchange for relief from U.S. sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela’s highest court ruled on Friday that a top opposition leader cannot run for president, dealing a crippling blow to prospects for credible elections that the government had agreed to hold this year in exchange for the lifting of crippling U.S. economic sanctions.

headline: Palestinian Americans’ Lawsuit in Oakland Seeks to Halt U.S. Support for Israel
abstract: The case, filed in Federal District Court in Northern California, is unlikely to succeed, given legal precedents regarding foreign policy decisions. But it has energized pro-Palestinian activists.
lead_paragraph: Palestinian American plaintiffs asked a federal judge in California on Friday to force the White House to withdraw U.S. support for Israel pending a cease-fire in Gaza and accused President Biden and other administration officials of abetting a genocide of the Palestinian people.

headline: The Early Race for 2028
abstract: Keep an eye on Haley and DeSantis.
lead_paragraph: The race for the Republican presidential nomination is not quite over — notwithstanding what Donald Trump and many Republican leaders have asserted since Trump’s victory in New Hampshire on Tuesday. Nikki Haley is still running and attacking the former president as she moves around South Carolina, which will hold its Republican primary on Feb. 24.

headline: George Carlin’s Estate Sues Podcasters Over A.I. Episode
abstract: The lawsuit claims that an hourlong comedy special on YouTube violated Carlin’s copyright.
lead_paragraph: The estate of the comedian George Carlin sued the makers of a podcast on Thursday after they claimed to use artificial intelligence to impersonate Carlin for a comedy special.

headline: Trump Ordered to Pay Carroll $83.3 Million
abstract: Also, a U.N. court ordered Israel to prevent genocide.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury in Manhattan ordered former President Donald Trump to pay $83.3 million to the writer E. Jean Carroll for defaming her in social media posts, news conferences and on the campaign trail ever since she first accused him in 2019 of raping her in a department store dressing room decades earlier.

headline: Trump Will Be Able to Wait to Pay Full $83.3 Million Until All Appeals Are Exhausted
abstract: Donald J. Trump — the rare defendant who can afford a judgment of this size — could secure a bond to cover it while his appeals play out.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump might one day have to pay E. Jean Carroll the $83.3 million she was awarded, but that day is not today.

headline: What to Know About Nevada’s Primary and Caucus
abstract: Early voting is underway in one of the two contests in the Silver State. The process there is complex and confusing.
lead_paragraph: As the calendar gets ready to flip to February and the remaining Republican presidential candidates move on from the early nominating states of Iowa and New Hampshire, it’s Nevada — not South Carolina — that’s next on the schedule.

headline: What to Know About the U.N. Aid Agency for Palestinians
abstract: Long a vital lifeline for Gazans, the agency known as UNRWA was a point of contention with Israel long before some of its workers were accused of taking part in the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel.
lead_paragraph: The U.N. agency that provides aid to Palestinians has been a vital lifeline in the Gaza Strip for generations — and it was a point of contention with Israel long before some of the agency’s employees were accused of involvement in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 assault on Israel.

headline: France Tries to Contain Protests by Farmers as Outrage Spreads
abstract: The government announced measures to quell the anger, including the scrapping of a fuel tax increase, as thousands of tractors blocked highways across the country.
lead_paragraph: Protests by farmers angered by complex regulations, administrative hassles and low wages spread across France on Friday, blocking several highways, snarling traffic for miles and forcing the country’s new prime minister to tear up his schedule and head to a remote farm in the region where the demonstrations began.

headline: ‘Textbook’ Execution or Botched One? Alabama Case Leaves Sides Divided.
abstract: Alabama officials said the nation’s first nitrogen gas execution was a model for other states. Critics called it appalling and far from what the state promised.
lead_paragraph: A day after Alabama became the first state to execute a prisoner with nitrogen gas, officials vowed on Friday to continue using the method in executions despite witnesses’ accounts that the prisoner writhed on the gurney for at least two minutes.

headline: U.N. Court Orders Israel to Prevent Genocide, but Does Not Demand Stop to War
abstract: The top United Nations court in The Hague did not rule on whether Israel was committing genocide in Gaza, the accusation that South Africa brought before the court.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ highest court said on Friday that Israel must take action to prevent acts of genocide by its forces in the Gaza Strip, adding to the international pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to reduce death and destruction in the battered Palestinian enclave.

headline: Bali Bombing Conspirators Get 5 More Years at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: A military jury sentenced two Malaysian men to 23 years for helping perpetrators of the bombing that killed 202 people, but a side deal reduced the punishment.
lead_paragraph: A military jury at Guantánamo Bay sentenced two prisoners to 23 years in confinement on Friday for conspiring in the 2002 terrorist bombing that killed 202 people in Bali, Indonesia. But the men could be freed by 2029 under a secret deal and with sentencing credit.

headline: Woman Charged With Hiding Corpse Over Body Parts Found in Refrigerator
abstract: Heather Stines told the police the head, arms and legs belonged to a man her husband had killed in September, according to court records.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn woman was charged this week with concealing a human corpse after the police found a head and other body parts in garbage bags stuffed in her refrigerator, officials said on Friday.

headline: More Than 100 Animals Seized From Long Island Home
abstract: Animal welfare authorities say the animals were being illegally held and included a South American ostrich, a giant African snail, two prairie dogs and an endangered tiger salamander.
lead_paragraph: Animal welfare authorities seized more than 100 animals from a Long Island home this week — including a South American ostrich, a giant African snail, two prairie dogs and an endangered tiger salamander — after a tip they received about exotic animals led them to their owner’s doorstep.

headline: State Dept. Tells Congress It Has Approved Sale of F-16 Jets to Turkey
abstract: The department received documents on Friday signed by Turkey’s leader approving Sweden’s long-delayed entry into NATO. The alliance now awaits word from the lone holdout, Hungary.
lead_paragraph: The State Department notified Congress on Friday that it had approved a $23 billion sale of F-16 fighter jets and related equipment to Turkey after the country’s leader signed documents to allow Sweden’s long-delayed entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, department officials and the Pentagon said.

headline: After Carroll Verdict, Haley Says ‘America Can Do Better’ Than Trump or Biden
abstract: As Trump campaign surrogates defended the former president in light of an $83.3 million defamation verdict, Nikki Haley said his legal troubles continued to be a distraction.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley criticized Donald J. Trump on Friday, saying, “America can do better than Donald Trump and Joe Biden,” after a Manhattan jury had ordered the former president to pay $83.3 million for defaming the writer E. Jean Carroll.

headline: Vince McMahon Cuts W.W.E. Ties After Sex Trafficking Accusation
abstract: The co-founder of World Wrestling Entertainment stepped down from its parent company’s board one day after an ex-employee accused him of sexual assault in a lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Vince McMahon, the longtime chairman and former chief executive of World Wrestling Entertainment, resigned from the board of W.W.E.’s parent company on Friday, one day after a former employee accused him of sexual assault and sex trafficking in a lawsuit.

headline: Los Angeles Times Owner Clashed With Top Editor Over Unpublished Article
abstract: The owner, Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong, had raised concerns with Kevin Merida, who stepped down this month, over reporting about a wealthy doctor and his dog.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong, the billionaire owner of The Los Angeles Times, hired Kevin Merida to be the newspaper’s top editor nearly three years ago, he hailed the journalist as someone who would maintain the publication’s high standards and journalistic integrity.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 27, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Dec. 31 about details showing a pattern of rape, mutilation and extreme brutality against women in the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas on Israel misstated the age of Sapir, the woman who has become one of the Israeli police’s key witnesses to the attack. She is 26, not 24.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Djokovic’s Perfection Finally Comes to End Against Italy’s Sinner
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t feel really myself on the court during this tournament.”

headline: Tiny Scrap
abstract: Grace and Greg Warrington make their New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Prosecutors in Nashville Drop Charges Against Chris Young
abstract: The country singer had been charged with disorderly conduct, assaulting an officer and resisting arrest after an altercation at a downtown bar.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors on Friday dropped all charges that had been brought against the country music singer Chris Young in connection with an altercation with an Alcoholic Beverage Commission agent at a Nashville bar.

headline: China Acknowledges Imprisoning a British Man on Spy Charges
abstract: A businessman who had worked in China for decades vanished from view in 2018, but his fate had been unknown, and publicly unremarked upon, until now.
lead_paragraph: A British businessman who disappeared from public view in China in 2018 was sentenced to five years in prison in 2022, China’s Foreign Ministry said on Friday, in its first public acknowledgment of the case.

headline: London’s Highline Will Echo Its New York Inspiration, With Local Notes
abstract: Hoping to repeat the success of Manhattan’s park, London is transforming a disused rail line, elevated 25 feet above the city’s streets, into its own floating green space.
lead_paragraph: The derelict rail bridge stretches across a busy north London street, green foliage peeking out of the gaps between the beams overhead, where bright blue paint flakes from rusting steel.

headline: When Soccer’s Content Mine Loses Sight of Reality
abstract: As documentaries and series about teams proliferate, it’s easy to pine for the ones that offered the clearest windows into the game.
lead_paragraph: Being early, Marc Andreessen once ruefully said, is the same as being wrong. Admittedly, Andreesen, the software engineer, angel investor and all-purpose Silicon Valley maven, deployed the maxim in the context of his own somewhat bitter experiences in the world of cloud computing, but it works surprisingly well as an analysis of “Being: Liverpool.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How Frankie Grande Spends His Sundays
abstract: The actor, singer and reality TV personality fills his day with video games, comfort food with friends and a teary trip to the movies.
lead_paragraph: Frankie Grande likes to stay busy — even on Sundays.

headline: Democrats Say Biden Hasn’t ‘Made the Case’ on Climate Despite Achievements
abstract: The president likes to talk about his climate agenda as an opportunity to create jobs. Polling shows that may be the wrong way to win over voters.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has done more than any president to tackle climate change, but strategists are grappling with an uncomfortable fact: Voters don’t seem to know it.

headline: Unboxing Thousands of Photos of New York City in the ’70s and ’80s
abstract: Arlene Gottfried, a sister of the late comedian Gilbert Gottfried, memorialized a grittier era of the city. Now her family wants to share her collection with the world.
lead_paragraph: A nondescript locker in a Lower Manhattan storage center is a portal to a New York City still plagued by crack, AIDS and rampant crime.

headline: Like Nora Ephron, With a British Twist
abstract: In her second novel, “Good Material,” Dolly Alderton adds her own flair to the classic rom-com.
lead_paragraph: Andy, the 35-year-old struggling comedian who narrates most of Dolly Alderton’s new novel, “Good Material,” has been freshly dumped by his ex, Jen, for mysterious reasons. Like Rob in Nick Hornby’s “High Fidelity,” an obvious inspiration, Andy knows his relationship had its problems. He’s even compiled a list of Jen’s faults, including “lingered too long in museums” where he “once saw her nod respectfully at a TINY JADE SPOON.” It doesn’t soothe his heartbreak; Andy is obsessed with working out what went wrong. In the process, maybe he can get to the bottom of why the rest of his life has derailed, too.

headline: A Tender Debut Novel About the Beauty and Pain of First Love
abstract: In “How We Named the Stars,” a young, queer student in mourning recounts the tale of a pivotal romance.
lead_paragraph: Andrés N. Ordorica’s debut novel, “How We Named the Stars,” begins with a crushing declaration: “Sam’s dead.” It’s an opening that colors everything to come, introducing a loss that will reverberate across every page of this meditative and tender book.

headline: My Life as a Neighborhood Crank
abstract: When you have no job, and too much time on your hands, the little things begin to grate.
lead_paragraph: On a hot Tuesday afternoon, a German shepherd met my gaze as he emptied his bowels on the Brooklyn sidewalk. The man holding the leash was large and bald and wearing a tank top. As he turned to walk away, I shot him a look.

headline: Is It a Crush or Have You Fallen Into Limerence?
abstract: How an intense longing for a romantic connection can lead to a serious addiction.
lead_paragraph: For most people, crushes come and go.

headline: How Some Families Are Breaking the Rules to Apply for Financial Aid
abstract: Experts are already encouraging students and parents to exchange usernames and passwords to expedite aid applications. One problem: It’s not legal.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the good news: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or FAFSA, website is now open 24 hours a day, seven days a week after a yearslong effort to simplify the process of seeking financial assistance. This month, I watched two high school seniors and their college counselor start the forms from scratch and submit them in just over an hour.

headline: What China’s E.V. City Says About the State of the Economy
abstract: Hefei has led the country in making electric vehicles and other tech products, but it still has not escaped a nationwide housing crisis.
lead_paragraph: Ultramodern factories churn out electric cars and solar panels in Hefei, an industrial center in the heart of central China. Broad avenues link office towers and landscaped parks. Subway lines open at a brisk pace.

headline: Jake Johnson Likes to Play the Hollywood Game, Especially When It Changes
abstract: “When you get on this roller coaster, you don’t know how long you’re going to be allowed to play while you’re here,” the “New Girl” actor said about his filmmaking debut, “Self Reliance.”
lead_paragraph: If you were bored enough — a stultifying job, living with Mom after a bad breakup — you, too, might climb into a mysterious limo carrying Andy Samberg. You might even consider the offer: outwit assassins for 30 days and win $1 million.

headline: January Is Nearly Over. Have You Done Your Retirement Review?
abstract: While 2024 is still new, assessing where you stand in some key areas of personal finance can help smooth the transition to your later years.
lead_paragraph: The crash diets have crashed, the brand-new budgets won’t budge and your Peloton is now the world’s most expensive laundry rack. But even if every one of your New Year’s resolutions is toast, there’s still one start-of-the-year chore you would be wise to handle: your retirement review.

headline: The Choreographer Wore Pointe Shoes
abstract: Tiler Peck, a New York City Ballet star, is making her first work for the company. “It’s my opportunity to pass on to the next generation anything that’s been given to me.”
lead_paragraph: During rehearsals for New York City Ballet’s winter season, there was something very unusual about one of the choreographers creating a new dance. It wasn’t just that the person in charge was a woman, though that would have been uncommon until a few years ago. Nor was it that the choreographer, Tiler Peck, was one of the company’s star ballerinas, though that is still quite rare. The difference was what Peck wore on her feet as she made and rehearsed the work: pointe shoes.

headline: The S&P 500 Through the Prism of a ‘Magnificent 7’
abstract: Seven tech stocks, including Meta, Nvidia and Apple, have accounted for roughly 90 percent of the S&P’s gains over the past 12 months.
lead_paragraph: Seven tech stocks, including Meta, Nvidia and Apple, have accounted for roughly 90 percent of the S&P’s gains over the past 12 months.

headline: FIFA Convictions Are Imperiled by Questions of U.S. Overreach
abstract: Two Supreme Court decisions and a lower court’s ruling have cast doubt on the legal basis for a host of prosecutions. Several defendants want their records cleared and their money back.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a decade after police officers marched world soccer officials out of a luxury hotel in Zurich at dawn, revealing a corruption scandal that shook the world’s most popular sport, the case is at risk of falling apart.

headline: A Drug Test Cost a D.E.A. Agent His Job. He Sued, and Got It Back.
abstract: A longtime counternarcotics agent said he used CBD for chronic pain, considering it safer than opioids. The choice set off a legal fight.
lead_paragraph: The Drug Enforcement Administration regarded Anthony L. Armour as an “outstanding” special agent on the front lines of the nation’s opioid epidemic. But in 2019, a routine drug test derailed his career.

headline: Gordon Ramsay Isn’t Going Anywhere
abstract: With a new season of his series “Next Level Chef,” reality TV’s most enduring antihero still reigns supreme. How long can he keep it up?
lead_paragraph: Gordon Ramsay insists he never wanted to be the bad boy. His image as the brash, bellicose chef and restaurateur, as the master of the culinary meltdown, was, he said, largely a matter of getting off on the wrong foot.

headline: When Going Off Message Is the Message
abstract: Reneé Rapp has been going off-script on the press circuit for “Mean Girls.” Maybe she lacks media training — and maybe that’s the point.
lead_paragraph: On her press tour for the new adaptation of “Mean Girls,” Reneé Rapp has called out the owner of a bus touring company owner by name, described herself as “ageist” against millennial women, praised Megan Thee Stallion’s butt and used an interview as an opportunity to shoot her shot with Rachel McAdams, the original Regina George, whose shoes Ms. Rapp stepped into for her latest role. She also said that she might not want Ms. McAdams to see the new take on the character and suggested that she was weary of the franchise.

headline: How Leaders and Diplomats Are Trying to End the Gaza War
abstract: Top American, Israeli and Arab officials are seeking to forge three parallel but related deals that could end the war in Gaza, finalize its postwar status, and, most ambitiously, set commitments for the creation of a Palestinian state.
lead_paragraph: Top officials from at least 10 different administrations are trying to forge a head-spinning set of deals to end the Gaza war and answer the divisive question of how the territory will be governed after the fighting stops.

headline: A Famed Analyst’s Final Forecast Is the Fall of the U.S. Economy
abstract: Dick Bove, the ubiquitous banking expert, is going out swinging after more than half a century in the business.
lead_paragraph: Over his 54 years as a financial analyst, Richard X. Bove perfected the art of grabbing attention.

headline: A Collective ‘No’: Anti-Putin Russians Embrace an Unlikely Challenger
abstract: Long lines have popped up in Russia and beyond to get Boris B. Nadezhdin, an antiwar candidate, onto the ballot for Russia’s presidential election in March.
lead_paragraph: His surname comes from the Russian word for hope — and for hundreds of thousands of antiwar Russians, that is, improbably enough, what he has become.

headline: Spending More Money on Police Shows No Clear Link to Lower Crime Levels
abstract: A study led by researchers in Toronto found that crime had risen in several cities along with increases in spending.
lead_paragraph: One effect we’re now seeing from the inflation that is largely a product of the pandemic and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine are municipal tax increases on a scale that was politically unimaginable not long ago.

headline: The Words to Say It
abstract: What it means to have words — and to lose them.
lead_paragraph: In Gaza and beyond, what it means to have words — and to lose them.

headline: The Joy and Sorrow of Streaming
abstract: Streaming offers an infinity of choice. It also offers the illusion that we’ll find the perfect cinematic solution to whatever is ailing us.
lead_paragraph: The year continues to get its bearings, to establish itself. Right now, it’s still a collection of post-holiday weeks, getting-going weeks, weeks for planning the year to come. An on-ramp where we get up to speed. Soon we’ll be properly in the flow of traffic, soon we’ll really be on our way.

headline: Should SATs Be Optional?
abstract: Readers discuss an article by David Leonhardt about research showing the tests’ usefulness.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Worries Me About War With China After My Visit to Taiwan
abstract: Some well-meaning U.S. efforts to help Taiwan may end up provoking China when we should be trying to lower tensions.
lead_paragraph: Michael Mullen, the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is concerned enough about the risk of war between the United States and China that he is listening to the audiobook version of Barbara Tuchman’s “The Guns of August,” the classic history of how the major powers in 1914 stumbled into World War I.

headline: My Patients Used to Be Enthusiastic About the Covid Vaccine. What Changed?
abstract: A newer, more vague vaccine hesitancy is emerging. A New York doctor has some advice for how to stop it.
lead_paragraph: The response has been almost like clockwork, at nearly every medical visit in the past few weeks. “It’s time for the flu shot,” I’ll say to my patients, “plus the updated Covid vaccine.” And that’s when the groans start.

headline: My Sister Chose the Day She Wanted to Die
abstract: In the face of terminal illness, medical aid in dying should be a right.
lead_paragraph: Should terminally ill people be able to choose how they die? Six years after being diagnosed with advanced ovarian cancer, Julie Petrow-Cohen decided to use medical aid in dying — or MAID, as it is often called — to end her life. But for many Americans in similar circumstances, this is not an option. In this audio essay, the writer Steven Petrow shares the story of his sister’s last day and why MAID should be a right for everyone.

headline: A Radical Proposal for Nikki Haley: Try to Win More Votes
abstract: There’s no reason to imitate Chris Christie and Liz Cheney just yet.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley lost the New Hampshire primary but found a cause: getting under Donald Trump’s not exactly rhinoceros-thick skin. The story of the Republican primary campaign in the days since Trump’s victory has been one where the victor acts like a sore loser and the likely loser loosens up, goads her stronger rival and finds a pool of small-dollar donors to keep her in the race.

headline: The Ogre Gorging on America
abstract: Trump gives the whiniest victory speech ever.
lead_paragraph: If you can imagine the lobby bar of the Manchester Marriott as an Anglo-Saxon mead hall, I can explain how it felt to cover the New Hampshire primary.

headline: Netanyahu’s Cynical Political Game
abstract: He has managed to alienate Israel’s most important allies.
lead_paragraph: It has become clear that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is not the leader for this critical moment.

headline: 2 Books That Wring Every Ounce From Their Story Lines
abstract: An editor recommends an Irish novel about a banker in trouble and a Swiss novel about schoolgirl obsession.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: The Key Issues for Business in a Likely Trump-Biden Rematch
abstract: Clean energy investments, trade policy and more than one kind of uncertainty could be on the line.
lead_paragraph: After beating Nikki Haley in New Hampshire on Tuesday, Donald Trump  reaffirmed his position as the leading candidate to win the Republican nomination. That has business leaders facing the possibility of another Trump presidency, and their investors trying to figure out what it could mean for their bottom lines.

headline: A ‘Corpsicle’ Came Back to Life on ‘True Detective.’ Is That Possible?
abstract: An incident involving a group of frozen bodies on the fourth season of the HBO series has raised some scientific questions.
lead_paragraph: The men lay frozen naked in a ghoulish pile, with mouths agape and eyes glazed over, their hair encrusted with ice and snow. They were all dead — or so the investigators on the HBO series “True Detective: Night Country” thought.

headline: In Las Vegas, Trump Turns His Focus Back to Biden
abstract: At a rally in Nevada, a key battleground state, Donald Trump sought to pivot to a general election message. A mile away, Vice President Kamala Harris framed the election as a battle for democracy.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has been itching for months to focus on a likely matchup between him and President Biden in November, previewed on Saturday a likely general-election message, extensively attacking Mr. Biden at an event in Nevada, a critical battleground state.

headline: Kat Von D Wins Copyright Trial Over Miles Davis Tattoo
abstract: The photographer who took the portrait of the jazz artist Miles Davis, which inspired the tattoo, had filed a lawsuit based on copyright infringement.
lead_paragraph: Kat Von D, a celebrity tattoo artist, won a legal battle in federal court on Friday when a jury ruled unanimously that her reproduction of a photo of the celebrated jazz musician Miles Davis in a tattoo did not violate copyright law.

headline: Israel Has History of Friction With U.N. Agency for Palestinians
abstract: Palestinians see UNRWA as an essential lifeline for millions of descendants of refugees. In Israel, however, many see the agency as an obstacle to resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s accusations against 12 employees of the United Nations aid agency for Palestinians, the main aid operation in Gaza, are the latest episode of a decades-long friction between Israel and the group.

headline: I Hate Kids. Do I Have to Make Nice With My Nephew?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to manage relationships with loved ones you don’t really like.
lead_paragraph: My only sibling is an (exhausted) single parent of one son. I have always disliked being around children and know I never want any of my own (or near me). I feel pressure from my sibling and family to form a relationship with the child. I’ve been directly asked to entertain or spend time with him, despite my lack of interest or ease in doing so.

headline: On Holocaust Memorial Day, Germans Rally Against Far Right and for Democracy
abstract: Large crowds have protested since it was revealed that members of the far-right Alternative for Germany party had met with neo-Nazis and those calling for a mass deportation.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets across Germany on Holocaust Memorial Day on Saturday to demonstrate in support of democracy and against the rise of a far-right party, the Alternative for Germany, or AfD, which is on track to make political gains in state elections this year.

headline: Chips as Chicken and Wings as Dip
abstract: Sour cream and onion chicken, Buffalo chicken dip and bulgogi-style tofu make for some fun flip-flops.
lead_paragraph: Today’s newsletter is all about recipes that take the flavors of one beloved food and apply them to something else, creating a dish that’s both familiar and novel. What can we say? It’s the end of January, we’re a little stir-crazy and we love a bit of fun in the kitchen.

headline: Biden Must Campaign Against a Man Who Already Thinks He’s President
abstract: President Biden, the man actually in the White House, faces a conundrum: How do you run against a man who never conceded his election loss, and is already acting like he has the job?
lead_paragraph: He promised to repeal the Affordable Care Act. He demanded states deploy the National Guard to the U.S.-Mexico border. He warned congressional Republicans to hold out for a perfect deal on immigration — or else.

headline: When a Neighbor Dies Unattended, How Should the Building Handle It?
abstract: In situations where people have died and their estate is in court, fixing a problem in their former apartment is legally complex.
lead_paragraph: Q: Six months ago, while I was out of town, there were two unattended deaths in my 60-unit co-op building in Brooklyn. The bodies were eventually discovered and removed. My apartment is above the unit where this occurred, and I returned to flies and a smelly apartment. Two months later, the co-op board got a court order allowing it to break the NYPD seal and remove the apartment’s contents. But the smell remains, and no work is planned. The odor is weaker now, but persistent, especially when the heat comes on. It’s too cold to keep the windows open. I’m running air purifiers, but have had to abandon one room and all the closets. My household insurance won’t help, because there is no physical damage. What recourse do I have?

headline: In Trump’s Bitter, Yearslong Brawl with Roberta Kaplan, He Keeps Losing
abstract: When they faced off at E. Jean Carroll’s defamation trial, it was a clash of two New Yorkers, both formidable combatants and talkers, but products of different worlds.
lead_paragraph: The meeting turned ugly fast.

headline: Dobbs Overturned Much More Than Roe v. Wade
abstract: Lawmakers in Tennessee, Oklahoma and other Republican states want to turn the clock back to the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: Most of my writing this week was on the recent elections in Iowa and New Hampshire, but most of my reading was focused elsewhere. In particular, I want to highlight this report from Jessica Valenti, published in her excellent newsletter, on proposed travel bans for abortion care in Tennessee and Oklahoma. The Tennessee ban, proposed by State Representative Jason Zachary, would make it a felony to take a minor out of state to obtain an abortion. As Valenti notes, “That means a friend, aunt or grandmother who helps a teenager get an abortion could be sent to prison for 15 years.” The Oklahoma bill, if signed into law, would punish anyone who helped a minor obtain abortion care with up to five years in prison.

headline: New Jersey Political Races, Often Raucous, Are Bananas This Year
abstract: A Republican state senator announced a run for governor, joining a dizzying array of high-profile races playing out under extraordinary circumstances.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s first lady is running for U.S. Senate. A former governor who resigned in disgrace is trying to make a political comeback, as a mayor. Two members of Congress and a half-dozen other political luminaries are preparing to campaign for governor.

headline: Washington Man Pleads Guilty to Making Numerous ‘Swatting’ Calls
abstract: Ashton Connor Garcia, who called himself a “cyberterrorist,” made 20 calls about fake bombs, shootings and other threats that drew police responses, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A man in Washington State has pleaded guilty to federal charges stemming from several hoax calls he made to law enforcement agencies in which he falsely reported bombs, shootings and other threats that sometimes led police officers to enter victims’ homes with their weapons drawn, prosecutors said.

headline: Harry Connick Sr., New Orleans D.A. Criticized for Overreach, Dies at 97
abstract: The city’s top prosecutor from 1973 to 2003, he led an office that sent hundreds of Black men to prison and became known for its record of wrongful convictions.
lead_paragraph: Harry Connick Sr., a long-serving district attorney in New Orleans whose office gained national notoriety for prosecutorial overreach that eventually resulted in many reversed convictions, died on Thursday at his home in New Orleans. He was 97.

headline: Charles Fried, Legal Scholar Who Broke With Conservatives, Dies at 88
abstract: As solicitor general under Reagan, he argued against abortion rights and affirmative action. But he came to see the current Supreme Court as “reactionary, not conservative.”
lead_paragraph: Charles Fried, a conservative legal scholar who as President Ronald Reagan’s solicitor general argued against abortion rights and affirmative action before the Supreme Court — but who later rejected the conservative legal movement’s rightward march, calling the current high court “reactionary” — died on Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88.

headline: Major Donors Pause Funding for U.N. Agency as Scandal Widens
abstract: The actions came as specific, “horrific” details were more widely shared by the U.N. and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Germany, Britain and at least four other countries said Saturday they were suspending funding for the United Nations agency that provides food, water and essential services for Palestinian civilians in the Gaza Strip, many of whom have been described as being on the brink of starvation after 16 weeks of war between Israel and Hamas.

headline: Ukraine Criticizes HBO, Saying New ‘White Lotus’ Actor Supports War
abstract: On social media, Ukraine’s foreign ministry posted clips of the Serbian actor Milos Bikovic receiving a medal for cultural achievement from Vladimir Putin in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s foreign ministry criticized HBO this week after Milos Bikovic was cast in the third season of “The White Lotus,” saying without evidence that the Serbian actor had supported Russia since its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Hammer Time
abstract: Nathan Hasegawa’s second puzzle is a hit.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Negotiators Close In on Hostage Deal That Would Halt Fighting in Gaza for Weeks
abstract: A written draft agreement calls for the phased release of captives held by Hamas in exchange for a cessation in Israel’s military offensive for about two months.
lead_paragraph: American-led negotiators are edging closer to an agreement in which Israel would suspend its war in Gaza for about two months in exchange for the release of more than 100 hostages still held by Hamas, a deal that could be sealed in the next two weeks and would transform the conflict consuming the region.

headline: Nikki Haley Was Target of December ‘Swatting’ Incident, Authorities Say
abstract: The Republican presidential candidate was not home at the time of the episode on Dec. 30, one of several targeting politicians late last year, Reuters reported.
lead_paragraph: A bogus account of a shooting at a South Carolina home owned by Nikki Haley sent the authorities scrambling in late December, but the Republican presidential candidate and a former governor of the state, was not there at the time, Reuters reported on Saturday.

headline: Photographing the Last of the Holocaust Survivors
abstract: The artist Gillian Laub has created a new photo archive of more than 200 survivors. On Saturday, some of those portraits were projected onto buildings and structures throughout New York City.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Aliza Erber, 80, stood at the edge of a pier in Lower Manhattan and told those around her to draw closer — and to look out toward the Brooklyn Bridge.

headline: ‘Two Days of Horror’: Doctor Documents Scene at Nasser Hospital
abstract: Dr. Ahmed Moghrabi, a surgeon who has worked at Nasser Medical Complex for three years, said that the “pressure is very big” at the hospital as Israeli forces surrounded Khan Younis, Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ahmed Moghrabi, a surgeon who has worked at Nasser Medical Complex for three years, said that the “pressure is very big” at the hospital as Israeli forces surrounded Khan Younis, Gaza.

headline: Statue of Jackie Robinson Stolen From Kansas Park
abstract: A bronze life-size statue of the baseball player who broke racial barriers in 1947 was cut at its ankles, leaving behind just its shoes and the statue’s base.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Kansas are searching for the vandals who stole a life-size bronze statue commemorating Jackie Robinson, the first Black Major League Baseball player of the modern era, after they cut it off at the ankles, leaving behind just the statue’s shoes and base.

headline: 28themorning-slideshow
abstract: 28themorning-slideshow
lead_paragraph: 28themorning-slideshow

headline: Carroll Promises to Do ‘Something Good’ With a Fortune Won From Trump
abstract: The writer was awarded $83.3 million for his defamation. Now, she will have to figure out how to use it.
lead_paragraph: As soon as E. Jean Carroll heard the verdict on Friday — $83.3 million in defamation damages against Donald J. Trump — a world of possibility opened before her: How to use the money?

headline: Key Network of G.O.P. Megadonors to Meet With Trump and Haley Camps
abstract: Assessing the presidential race, the American Opportunity Alliance has invited representatives from both the Trump and Haley campaigns to make their pitches at a meeting next week.
lead_paragraph: A network of Republican megadonors has invited aides to both Donald J. Trump and Nikki Haley to make presentations at the group’s winter meeting next week, as the wealthy contributors assess the presidential race with just nine months until Election Day.

headline: In South Carolina, Biden Tries to Persuade Black Voters to Reject Trump
abstract: President Biden sought to energize his base in the state that propelled him to the White House, but some local leaders said he needed to do more to highlight his achievements.
lead_paragraph: Hoping to revitalize the momentum that propelled him to the White House, President Biden told a largely Black audience on Saturday night that “you’re the reason Donald Trump is a defeated former president,” in what was effectively his first appearance related to the Democratic primaries.

headline: Arizona G.O.P. Picks New Leader After Scandal Creates a Vacancy
abstract: Gina Swoboda, a hard-right Trump supporter, was picked to replace Jeff DeWit, who resigned after the release of a recording that appeared to suggest a bribe to Kari Lake.
lead_paragraph: Arizona Republicans chose a new party chair on Saturday, a move that tightened the grip on the state party hierarchy by far-right supporters of former President Donald J. Trump and that came days after a scandal that forced the last chairman to resign.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 28, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Jan. 21 about the former boxer Mike Tyson’s move into the cannabis market in New York misstated the year of the bout in which Mr. Tyson bit Evander Holyfield’s ear. As the article correctly notes, it was 1997, not 1987.

headline: Quotation of the Day: $1.7 Million and 3 Years for Bathroom in Bay Area?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Why isn’t there a toilet here? I just don’t get it. Nobody does.”

headline: Finland’s Presidential Election, First Since Joining NATO, Heads to Runoff
abstract: Voting took place as the alliance’s newest member grapples with concerns about potential aggression from its neighbor Russia.
lead_paragraph: Finland’s presidential election is headed for a runoff after no candidate secured a majority in Sunday’s closely watched vote, which came as NATO’s newest member faces the threat of an antagonistic Russia.

headline: For New Moms in Seoul, 3 Weeks of Pampering and Sleep at a Joriwon
abstract: Some new mothers say postpartum care centers are the best part of childbirth in South Korea, where fewer people are deciding to have children because of high costs.
lead_paragraph: Four mothers sat quietly in the nursing room around midnight, breastfeeding their newborn babies. As one mother nodded off, her eyelids heavy after giving birth less than two weeks earlier, a nurse came in and whisked her baby away. The exhausted new mom returned to her private room to sleep.

headline: What It Took Young People in China to Get Their Jobs
abstract: For many job seekers, the toughest market in years is exacting a physical and emotional toll.
lead_paragraph: For many job seekers, the toughest market in years is exacting a physical and emotional toll.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Wonders What Men Will Do After Football Season Ends
abstract: Dakota Johnson hosted and Justin Timberlake was the musical guest in an episode that brought back some old favorites and also offered a few surprises.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl may still be two weeks away, but as far as “Saturday Night Live” is concerned, this is your last weekend to experience authentic N.F.L. football.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Private Equity Is Starting to Share With Workers, Without Taking a Financial Hit
abstract: The buyout giant KKR pioneered a model of granting ownership stakes to employees at portfolio companies. Now it wants the approach to spread.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, Anna-Lisa Miller was working with agricultural cooperatives in Hawaii, helping them reinvest in their communities through shared ownership.

headline: Where Is Hamas Getting Its Weapons? Increasingly, From Israel.
abstract: The very weapons that Israeli forces have used to enforce a blockade of Gaza are now being used against them.
lead_paragraph: Israeli military and intelligence officials have concluded that a significant number of weapons used by Hamas in the Oct. 7 attacks and in the war in Gaza came from an unlikely source: the Israeli military itself.

headline: ‘We Arranged to Meet Near Her Apartment on Second Avenue’
abstract: A book critic passes by, a leaky canoe off Bergen Beach and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Tax Break New York Relied on to Build Housing Is Gone. What’s Next?
abstract: The tax exemption known as 421a expired in 2022. A fight over its replacement, called 485x, could have major implications for the city’s future.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every debate about New York’s housing crisis involves a state program called “421a.”

headline: Not a Priest, Not a Man, but Ready to Run Fordham
abstract: Tania Tetlow is the first woman and layperson to lead the Jesuit university in its 182-year history. It’s not the first time she’s done this.
lead_paragraph: Tania Tetlow, the newish president of Fordham University, was in New Orleans, isolating with a case of Covid over winter break, when she learned that Claudine Gay had been forced to resign as Harvard’s president. She did not know all the facts of the case, but it was still a sobering moment.

headline: A Pop, Dip and Spin Through the History of ‘Pose’
abstract: Though the word “pose” is associated with voguing, it is less a part of the vocabulary and more a part of the movement.
lead_paragraph: In 1924, the artist Nancy Cox-McCormack recounted her experience sculpting the bust of Benito Mussolini in an article for The New York Times Magazine, “When Mussolini Poses.” While posing, Mussolini was surrounded by opulent gifts, she wrote, including a music box that “played only the Fascisti marching song.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Talks in Paris will focus on a hostage deal that could pause the fighting in Gaza.
abstract: American-led negotiators are edging closer to an agreement in which Israel would suspend its war in Gaza for about two months in exchange for the release of more than 100 hostages still held by Hamas, a deal that could be sealed in the next two weeks and will be the subject of talks in Paris on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: American-led negotiators are edging closer to an agreement in which Israel would suspend its war in Gaza for about two months in exchange for the release of more than 100 hostages still held by Hamas, a deal that could be sealed in the next two weeks and will be the subject of talks in Paris on Sunday.

headline: A New Martha Graham Biography Is a Study in Grace and Balance
abstract: Deborah Jowitt’s “Errand Into the Maze” revels in the artistry of the dance legend, while downplaying the messy choices in her marathon career.
lead_paragraph: “Old age is a pain in the neck,” Martha Graham wrote in her 1991 memoir, “Blood Memory.” Death, though, has been good to her.

headline: 5 Podcasts for Hollywood’s Awards Season
abstract: As Oscars night approaches, these shows offer expert analysis and predictions, insight into behind-the-scenes machinations and reflections on front-runners of the past.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 awards season has felt unusually hectic so far, thanks to the strike-delayed Emmy Awards shifting from their usual fall airdate to January. To help make sense of it all — and unpack the discombobulated state of Hollywood now — these five podcasts offer a mixture of expert analysis and predictions for the major ceremonies, original reporting on the industry trends and behind-the-scenes machinations that influence voting, and reflections on Oscar front-runners of the past that probably shouldn’t have been.

headline: The Man in Room 117
abstract: Andrey Shevelyov would rather live on the street than take antipsychotic medication. Should it be his decision to make?
lead_paragraph: Alone with his mother for the first time in almost a year, Andrey Shevelyov had a question: Could he come home?

headline: After Two Years of Bloody Fighting, Ukraine Wrestles With Conscription
abstract: A proposed bill on mobilization has become the focus of a debate as more men dodge the draft and calls rise to demobilize exhausted soldiers.
lead_paragraph: When Russian troops and tanks invaded Ukraine in February 2022, tens of thousands of Ukrainians rushed to serve in the army in a surge of patriotic fervor. The influx of fighters who dutifully answered their draft notices or enlisted as volunteers helped to repel Russia’s initial assault and thwart the Kremlin’s plans to decapitate the Ukrainian government.

headline: Black Pastors Pressure Biden to Call for a Cease-Fire in Gaza
abstract: Black congregants’ dismay at President Biden’s posture on the war could imperil his re-election bid.
lead_paragraph: As the Israel-Hamas war enters its fourth month, a coalition of Black faith leaders is pressuring the Biden administration to push for a cease-fire — a campaign spurred in part by their parishioners, who are increasingly distressed by the suffering of Palestinians and critical of the president’s response to it.

headline: John Malkovich on (Really) Being John Malkovich
abstract: “So many people think a lot about this or that,” says the iconic actor. “I just do this or that.”
lead_paragraph: “So many people think a lot about this or that,” says the iconic actor. “I just do this or that.”

headline: Hark, the Millennial Death Wail
abstract: The largest living generation in America peers into the abyss of middle age. Are we really worried, or is it just a shtick?
lead_paragraph: There’s a keening sound coming from America’s co-working spaces, third-wave coffee shops, and mommy-and-me yoga classes.

headline: As Biden Judicial Confirmations Slow, Senate Gains Ground on Red-State Judges
abstract: The Democratic majority has made headway in winning confirmation of Biden nominees in G.O.P.-led states, but has fallen behind the pace of the Trump era in the overall push to remake the federal courts.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Senate Democrats have fallen behind the rapid pace set by Republicans in shaping the federal courts during the Trump era, but they have made fresh headway in advancing judicial nominees in states represented by Republicans.

headline: The Campus Wars Aren’t About Gender … Are They?
abstract: Recent Ivy League dramas have made women leaders in academia wonder how far they’ve really come.
lead_paragraph: In the first weeks of the war between Israel and Hamas, Nancy Andrews read about American college presidents under fire and something nagged at her.

headline: Trump and Biden Get Ready for the Very Long Haul
abstract: The 2024 general election campaign is set to be one of the longest in modern history. There will be no spring break.
lead_paragraph: With Donald J. Trump rapidly closing in on the Republican presidential nomination, the 2024 general election campaign is set to be one of the longest in modern history, pushing President Biden and Mr. Trump into unfamiliar territory as they struggle to engage an electorate that seems numbed by the prospect of a 2020 rematch.

headline: Since Ohio Train Derailment, Accidents Have Gone Up, Not Down
abstract: The total number of accidents for the top five freight railroads increased, and Congress still hasn’t passed legislation to prevent similar disasters.
lead_paragraph: After a freight train carrying hazardous chemicals derailed a year ago in East Palestine, Ohio, forcing the evacuation of hundreds of residents and upending life in the town for months, the rail industry pledged to work to become safer, and members of Congress vowed to pass legislation to prevent similar disasters.

headline: Street Style Levels Up to Couture
abstract: Zendaya debuted drama, Jennifer Lopez made an entrance, but style on the street was just as bold.
lead_paragraph: Couture week in Paris is by no means an outlier on the fashion calendar. It is, after all, where designers are expected to flex a bit of imaginative muscle, dare to be creative outside the margins and show what artistry looks like at the height of this medium.

headline: After Help From Kenyan Police Is Blocked, Haitians Ask: What Now?
abstract: As Haiti sank into gang-dominated chaos, Kenya promised to send officers to pacify the streets. Now a court has rejected that plan, and there does not seem to be another.
lead_paragraph: Gangs have taken over entire neighborhoods in Haiti’s capital, and killings have more than doubled in the past year, but for the organizers of the Port-au-Prince Jazz Festival, the show simply had to go on.

headline: What’s Really Behind the ‘Mob Wife Aesthetic’?
abstract: A TikTok trend that’s about more than French manicures and furs, the look focuses on conspicuous signifiers of wealth earned outside the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that Francis Ford Coppola deigns to weigh in on a TikTok trend.

headline: At Sundance, A.I., Psychics and Other Ways of Connecting With the Dead
abstract: Festival documentaries ranged across the genre map, but several explored the lengths we’ll go to communicate with lost loved ones.
lead_paragraph: Everyone from the academy to streaming services splits cinema into two buckets: movies (comedy, romance, horror, whatever) and documentaries, lumped into one unholy pile. Besides being obviously reductive, the division is false: Nonfiction movies can be comedies or romances or horror or any other genre, and they can create new indescribable genres, too. But American audiences still tend to be fed documentaries of only a few types: true crime stories, cult exposés, hagiographies, and educational disquisitions full of talking heads.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Whale Who Went AWOL’
abstract: Hvaldimir escaped captivity and became a global celebrity. Now, no one can agree about what to do with him.
lead_paragraph: On April 26, 2019, a beluga whale appeared near Tufjord, a village in northern Norway, immediately alarming fishermen in the area. Belugas in that part of the world typically inhabit the remote Arctic and are rarely spotted as far south as the Norwegian mainland. Although they occasionally travel solo, they tend to live and move in groups. This particular whale was entirely alone and unusually comfortable around humans, trailing boats and opening his mouth as though expecting to be fed.

headline: Has Hollywood Lost China?
abstract: Last year, no American movie broke the Top 10 at the Chinese box office.
lead_paragraph: “Barbenheimer” — the portmanteau given to the same-day release of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” last summer — was a genuine cultural phenomenon for much of the world. Cinemas were filled with outfits in various hues of pink. Social media frothed with opinions. And the films brought in a combined $2.3 billion globally.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 29, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Protesters Hurl Soup at the Mona Lisa
abstract: Two women from an environmental group threw pumpkin-colored soup at the artwork, which is behind bulletproof glass at the Louvre and did not appear to sustain damage.
lead_paragraph: Two protesters from an environmental group hurled pumpkin-colored soup on the Mona Lisa at the Louvre museum in Paris on Sunday, splashing the bulletproof glass that protects the most famous painting in the world, but not apparently damaging the work itself.

headline: If We Want to Live in a World With Rules, They Have to Apply to Israel, Too
abstract: Whatever the eventual outcome of the genocide case, it sets up an epic battle over the meaning and values of the so-called rules-based order.
lead_paragraph: Over the past month, we’ve watched an astonishing, high-stakes global drama play out in The Hague. A group of countries from the poorer, less powerful bloc some call the global south, led by South Africa, dragged the government of Israel and, by extension, its rich, powerful allies into the top court of the Western rules-based order and accused Israel of prosecuting a brutal war in Gaza that is “genocidal in character.”

headline: When Language Fails Us and the Moment
abstract: Plain, direct language remains rare and desirable — and risky in ways that those in authority, even more than the rest of us, try to avoid.
lead_paragraph: A writer I admire expresses in a few words his disdain for plausible but empty political language, beginning with one good example. “The word ‘fascism,’” he writes, “has now no meaning except insofar as it signifies ‘something not desirable.’” He adds other exhausted words, including “democracy,” “freedom” and “patriotic” — convenient terms for establishing righteousness, easily melting into self-righteousness.

headline: When the Right Ignores Its Sex Scandals
abstract: The case of the disgraced pastor Paul Pressler offers a window into why America is so divided as a nation.
lead_paragraph: Let me share with you one of the worst and most important recent news stories that you’ve probably never heard about. Late last month, the Southern Baptist Convention settled a sex abuse lawsuit brought against a man named Paul Pressler for an undisclosed sum. The lawsuit was filed in 2017 and alleged that Pressler had raped a man named Duane Rollins for decades, with the rapes beginning when Rollins was only 14 years old.

headline: Nikki Haley Isn’t Going Anywhere
abstract: The brightness of Haley’s past few days underscores the darkness of Trump’s.
lead_paragraph: What is Nikki Haley doing? What are her real intentions? Those questions have dominated every aspect of her candidacy.

headline: A.I. Is Coming for the Past, Too
abstract: In our focus on protecting the present and future from A.I., we have forgotten about the urgent need to protect the past.
lead_paragraph: We don’t have to imagine a world where deepfakes can so believably imitate the voices of politicians that they can be used to gin up scandals that could sway elections. It’s already here. Fortunately, there are numerous reasons for optimism about society’s ability to identify fake media and maintain a shared understanding of current events.

headline: More People Are Being Classified as Gig Workers. That’s Bad for Everyone.
abstract: The gig economy is expanding and exploiting more workers.
lead_paragraph: What comes to mind when you think of a mom-and-pop small business: A hardware store? A diner? A family-run clothing store or small-scale supermarket?

headline: House Republicans Release Impeachment Charges Against Mayorkas
abstract: The articles accuse the homeland security secretary of refusing to uphold the law and breaching the public trust in his handling of immigration. A House committee is scheduled to approve them on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans on Sunday released two articles of impeachment against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, charging President Biden’s top immigration official with refusing to uphold the law and breaching the public trust in his handling of a surge of migration at the U.S. border with Mexico.

headline: Two Masked Attackers Kill 1 in Shooting at Istanbul Church
abstract: The Islamic State has taken responsibility for the attack, according to the SITE intelligence group.
lead_paragraph: Two masked gunmen shot and killed a man during a church service on Sunday morning in Istanbul, Turkish officials said, an attack that the Islamic State later took responsibility for.

headline: Israel Moves to Block Protesters From Preventing Flow of Aid into Gaza
abstract: The Israeli military has declared the area around the Kerem Shalom border crossing a closed military zone.
lead_paragraph: Israel on Sunday stepped up efforts to prevent Israeli protesters from blocking the flow of aid into Gaza, two days after the United Nations’ highest court said it must allow more supplies to get into the enclave.

headline: In 100 Victims of the Lahaina Fire, Legacies That Live On
abstract: Authorities have identified the last known person to have died in the wildfire. Young and old, those lost won’t be forgotten.
lead_paragraph: Terri Thomas was a beloved aunt who loved outdoor adventures. Po’omaika’i Estores-Losano, a musician and father, was trying to rebuild his life. Tony Takafua, 7 years old, had barely begun his.

headline: Plush, Perfumed Pepperpot
abstract: Millie Peartree’s new recipe for this beloved Guyanese stew, rich with spices and savory-sweet cassareep, is just the thing for a winter weekend.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Time was, a goodly part of my correspondence was with readers annoyed with me or with The New York Times for publishing recipes calling for ingredients unavailable to them, either for reasons of geography or because they didn’t wish to stray beyond the aisles of their local supermarket.

headline: Is the Trump Threat Too Serious for Humor?
abstract: Readers discuss an Opinion guest essay that urges an end to Trump jokes and mockery. Also: Jan. 6; China’s birthrates; debating the Mideast war.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Haley Hits Trump on Border and His ‘Rants,’ Saying ‘He Feels Threatened’
abstract: Nikki Haley, coming off losses in Iowa and New Hampshire, also said she needed to “show momentum” in South Carolina’s Feb. 24 primary, but stopped short of saying she needed to win her home state.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley denounced former President Donald J. Trump in an interview on Sunday for his angry responses to his legal losses and suggested that his pressuring of congressional Republicans not to agree to a border-security deal before the election was a purely political ploy.

headline: Ukraine Accuses Defense Company of Embezzling $40 Million
abstract: The case comes as the Kyiv government tries to emphasize its focus on fighting graft.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s intelligence agency said it had exposed a defense company’s $40 million embezzlement scheme, money that had been intended to procure mortar rounds, as the government sought to underline its commitment to fighting corruption at a time when U.S. military aid has stalled.

headline: Obie Awards, Sans Ceremony, Honor ‘Dark Disabled Stories’
abstract: There was no formal celebration for the newest honorees. Instead, the American Theater Wing presented cash grants to sustain their work.
lead_paragraph: The Obie Awards, a scrappy but venerable annual competition honoring the best theater staged Off and Off Off Broadway, has chosen “Dark Disabled Stories,” Ryan J. Haddad’s autobiographical work inspired by his experiences navigating the city with cerebral palsy, as the best new American play.

headline: 3 American Soldiers Killed in Drone Strike in Jordan, U.S. Says
abstract: The White House blamed an Iranian-backed militia for the attack. The deaths were the first known fatalities of U.S. forces from hostile fire in the turmoil spreading in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Three U.S. service members were killed in Jordan on Sunday and at least 34 others were injured in what the Biden administration said was a drone attack from an Iran-backed militia, the first known American military fatalities from hostile fire in the turmoil spilling over from Israel’s war with Hamas.

headline: Three African Juntas Leave Regional Bloc, Accusing It of ‘Inhumane’ Sanctions
abstract: The sanctions were imposed after soldiers seized power in Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso.
lead_paragraph: Soldiers who seized power in three West African nations announced on Sunday that they would pull their countries out of their regional economic bloc.

headline: Ring to Stop Allowing Police to Request Videos From Security Cameras
abstract: Ring, a maker of internet-connected cameras that is owned by Amazon, said the police could no longer ask people to share video recordings using the company’s app, Neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Ring, a home security camera company owned by Amazon, said that it would stop letting police departments request users’ footage in its app amid longstanding concerns from privacy advocates about the company’s relationship with law enforcement.

headline: How UNRWA Donor Countries Have Responded to Israel’s Accusations
abstract: Some countries have re-evaluated their support for the main U.N. agency in Gaza after Israel accused a dozen agency employees of participating in the Oct. 7 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s accusations that a dozen United Nations workers in Gaza had participated in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks have prompted some donor nations to re-evaluate their commitments to the agency that provides food, water and other essential services to Palestinian civilians.

headline: At the Defense Table, Trump Uses the Courtroom as a Stage
abstract: In two civil trials, the former president has showcased his disdain for the legal system and provided a preview of how he might handle himself when any of his four criminal cases go to trial.
lead_paragraph: He shook his head in anger, sitting with his back hunched. He spoke to his lawyers, his words sometimes quite audible to the packed courtroom. He wrote instructions for his defense team that he shoved their way. He walked in late at one point, and at another, while a lawyer suing him was speaking to the jury, he stalked out.

headline: Sexual Assault Claims Against McMahon Shadow a W.W.E. Trying to Move Forward
abstract: Several high-profile deals have the company well-positioned for years to come, but legal entanglements involving Vince McMahon, its former, longtime leader, are not going away.
lead_paragraph: Cody Rhodes emerged victorious from World Wrestling Entertainment’s “Royal Rumble” on Saturday night, an annual marquee event for the company that culminates in a battle royale match in which 30 wrestlers enter the ring and fight it out until only one remains.

headline: Maine Town Manager Dies Saving His Son After Both Fall Through Ice
abstract: Kevin Howell, 51, the town manager in Carmel, Maine, and his 4-year-old son fell through the ice while crossing a pond. He rescued his son, who ran home to get help.
lead_paragraph: The manager of a town in Maine died after saving his 4-year-old son from a frozen pond that they both fell into while on a walk on Friday, officials said.

headline: Monday Briefing: U.S. Service Members Killed in Jordan
abstract: Also, the UNRWA is in trouble and an antiwar candidate rises in Russia.
lead_paragraph: Three U.S. service members were killed in Jordan yesterday and 25 others were injured in what the U.S. said was a drone strike from an Iran-backed militia. The deaths were the first U.S. military fatalities from hostile fire in the turmoil spilling over from Israel’s war with Hamas in Gaza.

headline: The N.Y.P.D. Pulled Over a City Councilman. Now Both Are Under Fire.
abstract: Yusef Salaam, one of the Central Park Five, said the officer who stopped him should have explained why. Some officials said Mr. Salaam had used his position to avoid a ticket.
lead_paragraph: Yusef Salaam, the newly elected New York City Council member who was wrongfully convicted in 1990 as a member of the Central Park Five, was in Harlem on Friday night, driving downtown to dinner with his wife and four of his children, when the flashing lights of a police car appeared behind him.

headline: Haley’s Dilemma: How to Diminish Trump Without Alienating Republican Voters
abstract: On “Meet the Press,” Nikki Haley said she trusted a jury’s judgment in Donald Trump’s sex-assault defamation case, while she tries to peel away the former president’s supporters.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, searching for a message to dent Donald J. Trump’s appeal with Republican voters, took him to task on Sunday for the $83 million verdict for defaming a woman he was already liable for sexually assaulting, saying she “absolutely” trusted the jury’s judgment for the writer, E. Jean Carroll.

headline: $83 Million Verdict Renews Spotlight on Trump’s Finances
abstract: The judgment for E. Jean Carroll, and another potentially much larger one on the horizon, could compel the former president to sell some of his assets.
lead_paragraph: He did not go to jail, and has not lost his grip on the race for the Republican presidential nomination, but a jury’s verdict in a civil defamation trial last week nonetheless hit Donald J. Trump where it hurts: his wallet.

headline: Biden Vows to Retaliate After Strike Against American Forces in Jordan
abstract: President Biden has carefully calibrated his responses to attacks by Iranian-backed militias since Oct. 7. Now he must decide how far he is willing to go after a drone attack killed three American service members.
lead_paragraph: This was the day that President Biden and his team had feared for more than three months, the day that relatively low-level attacks by Iranian proxy groups on American troops in the Middle East turned deadly and intensified the pressure on the president to respond in kind.

headline: The E. Jean Carroll Verdict Exposes the Limits of Libel Law
abstract: Incentives to serve up lies for politics or profit are so strong that libel damage awards and settlements may not meaningfully change behaviors.
lead_paragraph: In the days since a New York jury ordered Donald Trump to pay $83.3 million in damages to the libel plaintiff E. Jean Carroll, the question has been whether the dollar amount was high enough to put a stop to his lies.

headline: Relating to the Bottom Layer
abstract: Garrett Chalfin and Andrew Kingsley give us inside information.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Marlena Shaw, Venerable Nightclub Chanteuse, Dies at 84
abstract: She sang jazz (with Count Basie, among others) and later funk and disco, frequently in intimate venues, where she regaled audiences with tales of old love affairs.
