lead_paragraph: Marlena Shaw, who cultivated a sultry stage presence and husky voice from the final echoes of the big-band era to the go-go Playboy Clubs of the 1960s, to the rise of funk, to disco, and finally to the modern cabaret circuit, died on Jan. 19. She was 84.

headline: Pelosi Wants F.B.I. to Investigate Pro-Palestinian Protesters
abstract: The former House speaker suggested without offering evidence that some protesters calling for a cease-fire in Gaza had financial ties to Russia and Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California and the former House speaker, on Sunday called for the F.B.I. to investigate protesters demanding a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas conflict, suggesting without evidence that some activists may have ties to Russia and President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Illinois Hearing Officer, Ex-G.O.P. Judge, Says Trump Engaged in Insurrection
abstract: But the hearing officer said the State Board of Elections should let the courts decide whether Mr. Trump’s conduct disqualified him from the ballot.
lead_paragraph: A former Republican judge appointed to hear arguments on whether to disqualify former President Donald J. Trump from the Illinois primary ballot said on Sunday that he believed Mr. Trump engaged in insurrection by attempting to remain in office after the 2020 election.

headline: Details Emerge on U.N. Workers Accused of Aiding Hamas Raid
abstract: Israeli officials have presented evidence they say ties workers at a Palestinian aid agency in Gaza to violence during the Hamas-led attack on Israel.
lead_paragraph: One is accused of kidnapping a woman. Another is said to have handed out ammunition. A third was described as taking part in the massacre at a kibbutz where 97 people died. And all were said to be employees of the United Nations aid agency that schools, shelters and feeds hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.

headline: ‘Days of Wine and Roses’ Review: Romance on the Rocks
abstract: Kelli O’Hara and Brian d’Arcy James are superb as a midcentury-modern couple free-falling into addiction in Craig Lucas and Adam Guettel’s musical.
lead_paragraph: Seldom have a pair of alcoholics looked as glamorous as they do in Craig Lucas and Adam Guettel’s bruised romance of a Broadway musical, “Days of Wine and Roses,” starring Kelli O’Hara and Brian d’Arcy James as midcentury-modern Manhattan lovers free-falling all the way to hell, drinks in hand.

headline: Evergrande Will Be Dismantled, a ‘Big Bang’ End to Years of Stumbles
abstract: After multiple delays and even a few faint glimmers of hope, a Hong Kong court has sounded the death knell for what was once China’s biggest real estate firm.
lead_paragraph: Months after China Evergrande ran out of cash and defaulted in 2021, investors around the world scooped up the property developer’s discounted i.o.u.’s, betting that the Chinese government would eventually step in to bail it out.

headline: ‘True Detective’ Season 4, Episode 3 Recap: Toxicity
abstract: Danvers and Navarro both must face some cold realities about who and what they represent in a community being poisoned by its biggest employer.
lead_paragraph: In the first two episodes of “Night Country,” we knew Annie Kowtok as a dead person, a young Inupiaq activist who was stabbed 32 times and whose memory haunts the living every bit as much as the hallucinations that seem to slip in their minds during permanent darkness do.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Three U.S. service members were killed in Jordan.
lead_paragraph: Three U.S. service members were killed in Jordan yesterday and at least 34 others were injured in what the U.S. said was a drone strike from an Iran-backed militia. The deaths were the first U.S. military fatalities from hostile fire in the turmoil spilling over from Israel’s war with Hamas in Gaza.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Vanderpump Rules’ and the Grammys
abstract: The Bravo hit returns for an 11th season, and the Recording Academy hands out awards.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 29-Feb. 4. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: connoisseurship
abstract: This word has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word connoisseurship has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 20 in “Dick Wolf, ‘Law & Order’ Creator, Gives 200 Artworks to the Met Museum” by Zachary Small:

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Grim LookAt the State of the News
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Every warning light should be blinking red.”

headline: No Corrections: Jan. 29, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Toyota Halts Shipments of 10 Models Over Mishandling of Engine Tests
abstract: A unit of the company used software that made horsepower “values appear smoother.” It’s the second production problem to hit the company in two months.
lead_paragraph: Toyota Motor said it had halted the global shipments of 10 vehicles after it discovered that an affiliate had mishandled the testing of diesel engines used in the automobiles, the latest embarrassing problem to hit the world’s biggest automaker in recent months.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Trial in Jam Master Jay’s 2002 Killing Begins in Brooklyn
abstract: The killing of Jam Master Jay, the Run-DMC D.J., sent shock waves through hip-hop. On Monday, two men went on trial on charges of murdering him.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years after the hip-hop D.J. Jam Master Jay was gunned down in his Queens recording studio, two men charged in the killing faced a federal jury in Brooklyn on Monday.

headline: In the Race to Replace George Santos, National Issues Reverberate
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the special House election on Feb. 13, pitting former Representative Tom Suozzi, a Democrat, against the Republican Party’s candidate, Mazi Pilip, a local legislator.
lead_paragraph: The Israel-Hamas war. Abortion rights. Immigration policy.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: How to Set the Menu for a Special Food Project
abstract: The Food team’s interactive on restaurant menus has roots in an earlier effort.
lead_paragraph: Tanya Sichynsky likes to collect restaurant menus, and she even has a few of them framed on the walls of her apartment in New York. The menus she displays represent a few of the dinners she had during meaningful moments in her life.

headline: Are Edibles Safer Than Smoking?
abstract: The health risks of cannabis depend in part on how you use the drug.
lead_paragraph: Cannabis-infused chocolate fountains are flowing at weddings. “Budtenders” are pouring cannabis cocktails. And as sales of edibles are trending up, cannabis brands are emphasizing the idea that the products might offer a healthier alternative to bongs or blunts.

headline: Dorm Room Revelations as Microcosms of a Culture
abstract: In her second novel, “Come and Get It,” Kiley Reid uses chatty college students to make substantive statements about consumerism.
lead_paragraph: Once I realized what Kiley Reid was up to, I started jotting down brand names. Papyrus, Ziploc, Zillow, Ikea, Amy’s, Red Vines, Lubriderm — these are just a smattering of the companies and products mentioned in the first few chapters of Reid’s second novel, “Come and Get It.”

headline: She Issued a Call to ‘#MakeJewishBabies.’ Some Are Taking It Seriously.
abstract: Irina Barskaya, a 33-year-old woman in Brooklyn, felt a pull to have children with another Jew after the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks. She’s not the only one.
lead_paragraph: Marrying a Jewish man — and having Jewish children — wasn’t a top priority for Irina Barskaya. Despite pressure from her mother and her older sister, Ms. Barskaya, a 33-year-old hair and makeup artist from Brooklyn, said that in her search for Mr. Right, religion was “never at the forefront.”

headline: How Biden Beats Trump
abstract: The president has a strong populist case to make for a future in which ordinary Americans and the ideals embodied in our Constitution can prosper.
lead_paragraph: For months, battered by President Biden’s dismal 2024 re-election polls, Democrats have been undergoing a kind of collective nervous breakdown over his re-election prospects against Donald Trump.

headline: Hottest Job in Corporate America? The Executive in Charge of A.I.
abstract: Many feared that artificial intelligence would kill jobs. But hospitals, insurance companies and others are creating roles to navigate and harness the disruptive technology.
lead_paragraph: In September, the Mayo Clinic in Arizona created a first-of-its-kind job at the hospital system: chief artificial intelligence officer.

headline: What Is Your Experience With Group Chats?
abstract: Tell us how never-ending digital conversations affect you.
lead_paragraph: Are you constantly texting? How much of your time do you spend in group chats? How would you describe the role those chats play in your life?

headline: Nvidia’s Big Tech Rivals Put Their Own A.I. Chips on the Table
abstract: Chafing at their dependence, Amazon, Google, Meta and Microsoft are racing to cut into Nvidia’s dominant share of the market.
lead_paragraph: In September, Amazon said it would invest up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a San Francisco start-up working on artificial intelligence.

headline: For ‘Golden Bachelor’ Fans, a Novel About a Golden Baking Contestant
abstract: In “Mrs. Quinn’s Rise to Fame,” Olivia Ford whips up a sweet confection about a septuagenarian cook with reality TV dreams.
lead_paragraph: On the face of it, 77-year-old Jennifer Quinn lives a life that belongs on “Masterpiece Theater.” She lives in bucolic Kittlesham, an English town that makes you feel as if you’ve “stepped into a secret garden or through the back of a wardrobe,” with “delightfully uneven houses and medieval pubs.”

headline: What Might E. Jean Carroll Do With $83 Million?
abstract: A jury awarded Ms. Carroll a huge payout. She would like to do “something good” with it.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday, and we’ll look at the $83.3 million verdict in the defamation case against Donald Trump. We’ll also get details on the fallout from a traffic stop in Harlem involving a member of the City Council.

headline: For Europe and NATO, a Russian Invasion Is No Longer Unthinkable
abstract: Amid crumbling U.S. support for Ukraine and Donald Trump’s rising candidacy, European nations and NATO are making plans to take on Russia by themselves.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia once proclaimed the dissolution of the Soviet empire “the greatest geopolitical catastrophe of the 20th century.” At the time, back in 2005, few expected him to do anything about it.

headline: $2.2 Million Homes in California
abstract: A storybook cottage in Los Angeles, a Prairie-style house in Orange and a renovated 1939 home in Redwood City.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the hills above Laurel Canyon, less than a five-minute drive from Hollywood Boulevard and less than 10 minutes from the nightlife on the Sunset Strip. It is also close to Canyon Country Store, a popular neighborhood market, a Trader Joe’s and the hiking trails in Runyon Canyon Park.

headline: As Buses of Migrants Arrive in Chicago Suburbs, Residents Debate the Role of Their Towns
abstract: In recent weeks, buses have been bypassing the city for its smaller outlying communities, where people are unaccustomed to the flow of newcomers.
lead_paragraph: In different times, the tiny brick Metra station in the town of Wilmette in suburban Chicago was just a place where commuters grabbed lattes and waited on black metal benches before boarding trains to the city.

headline: Gin and Jellyfish? You Might Be at a Bar in Singapore.
abstract: Bartenders around the city are mixing up creative cocktails with unexpected, and often ecologically conscious, ingredients. Here are six spots to visit.
lead_paragraph: In the cocktail world, Singapore almost inevitably evokes the pink, gin-based, grenadine-spiked Singapore Sling, a drink born in 1915 at the stylish Long Bar at the Raffles Hotel. In those strait-laced colonial days, it was improper for women to imbibe in public, so a bartender formulated a cocktail that looked like fruit juice. Today, the creative minds at idiosyncratic bars across the city are putting the same spirit of ingenuity to work, driven by eco-consciousness and the island’s diverse heritage, and highlighting some unexpected ingredients. Here are six standout spots.

headline: GoFundMe Is a Boon for Disaster Survivors. Especially the Wealthy Ones.
abstract: Campaigns on the crowdfunding site raised more money for wildfire survivors with high incomes than for those who need help most, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: As climate-fueled disasters destroy more American homes, the crowdfunding platform GoFundMe has exploded in popularity. Its appeal is simple: People can provide cash directly to survivors, which is quicker than insurance and often more generous than government aid.

headline: 17 New Books Coming in February
abstract: New novels from Tommy Orange and Kristin Hannah; memoirs from Kara Swisher and Leslie Jamison; a biography of Medgar and Myrlie Evers — and more.
lead_paragraph: Spufford’s latest is a speculative historical noir set in a reimagined Jazz Age. The story takes place in Cahokia, a thriving Indigenous metropolis, and follows a detective who gets sucked into an ever-deepening conspiracy as he tries to solve a gruesome murder.

headline: The ABCs of Modern Life, According to Sheila Heti
abstract: In her new book, the writer presents 10 years of her diaries in an unorthodox arrangement.
lead_paragraph: “No one at this point in history knows how to live, so we read biographies and memoirs, hoping to get some clues,” Sheila Heti writes in “Alphabetical Diaries,” her powerful and intimate new book. That is why we read novels, too, of course — for the clues. Heti knows this. It is why her breakout 2010 novel had an exemplary title, one that could stand in for the title of every real novel from “Don Quixote” down the line: “How Should a Person Be?”

headline: The Supreme Court’s Mixed Record on Adhering to Precedent
abstract: The current court is not out of step with earlier ones in how often it overturns decisions. But it is more apt to do so to reach conservative results.
lead_paragraph: It can sometimes seem that the Supreme Court is on a jurisprudential rampage that has left the legal landscape cluttered with the corpses of discarded precedents.

headline: How Trump Could Institute a Backdoor Federal Abortion Ban
abstract: President Biden should be clear about the risks of a second Trump term.
lead_paragraph: For many Americans who support abortion rights, the election in November will most likely come down to a choice between voting for President Biden and staying home. They won’t vote for the man who ensured Roe v. Wade’s demise, but many of them are unenthusiastic about the prospect of Mr. Biden being the Democratic nominee.

headline: How Do I Dress While I’m Losing Weight?
abstract: A reader contemplates clothing purchases during a period in which her body is changing.
lead_paragraph: Changes in your body, whether intentional or not, are intrinsically connected to changes in your emotions and sense of self, even before you start taking into account social messaging around weight and physical beauty.

headline: Domicide: The Mass Destruction of Homes Should Be a Crime Against Humanity
abstract: What has happened to homes and lives in Gaza is a stand-alone crime. Even if it is physically rebuilt, the trauma of losing homes will last for decades.
lead_paragraph: What has happened to homes and lives in Gaza is a stand-alone crime. Even if it is physically rebuilt, the trauma of losing homes will last for decades.

headline: Where Southerners Go to Fill the Tank and Feed the Family
abstract: Are they gas stations that serve food or restaurants that pump gas? A new photography book explores the lure of these restorative community rest stops.
lead_paragraph: New York City has its bodegas. The South has its gas stations.

headline: What if We Don’t Drain the Swamp?
abstract: A Supreme Court decision last year made it much harder to protect wetlands in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Every child I have ever known is drawn to water — to running creeks and meandering rivers, to buzzing ponds and gently lapping lakes and echoing swamps and cool, mossy fens. Even toddlers who find the ocean overwhelmingly huge and alien will merrily splash in a tidal pool, dabbling their dimpled fingers in the water. To children, a puddle is for stomping. A marshy place is for barefooting, testing the ooze and suck of mud, peering through waving grasses at wild eyes peering back at them.

headline: Nikki Haley Can Do a Lot of Damage
abstract: Hounding Trump is an important task.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. It’s fair to say that Nikki Haley has next to no chance of beating Donald Trump for the Republican nomination. Give her your best advice: Give up now? Fight a guerrilla campaign right up to the G.O.P. convention? Or join forces with someone like Joe Manchin in a third party?

headline: Inside Biden’s Anti-Trump Battle Plan (and Where Taylor Swift Fits In)
abstract: Watching Donald Trump ascend, the newly energized Biden campaign is aiming to make the general election all about him. It’s also hoping for some big endorsements.
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump speeds toward the Republican nomination, President Biden is moving quickly to pump energy into his re-election bid, kicking off what is likely to be an ugly, dispiriting and historically long slog to November between two unpopular nominees.

headline: The Audacity of E. Jean Carroll
abstract: Her lawsuit against Donald Trump was about defamation. It was also about the worth of a woman, long past middle age, who dared to claim she still had value.
lead_paragraph: Today she’s typically described as a former advice columnist, but that term doesn’t really do justice to E. Jean Carroll’s career pre-Donald Trump.

headline: The Failed Promise of Police Body Cameras
abstract: The devices were supposed to be a revolution in accountability. What went wrong?
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains strong language and audio excerpts of violence.

headline: Biden Vows to Retaliate, and a Super Bowl Rematch
abstract: Plus, a new therapy lets an 11-year-old hear for the first time.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Today’s Teenagers: Anxious About Their Futures and Disillusioned by Politicians
abstract: More than previous generations, they are concerned about their mental health and educational prospects, new surveys show.
lead_paragraph: Although it has never been easy to be a teenager, the current generation of young Americans feels particularly apprehensive, new polling shows — anxious about their lives, disillusioned about the direction of the country and pessimistic about their futures.

headline: Gaza’s Food Crisis
abstract: Famine has become a central humanitarian concern in the enclave.
lead_paragraph: Mothers in Gaza are struggling to find clean water and baby formula for their newborns. Families are selling their possessions to buy sacks of flour. Some people are eating animal feed to survive.

headline: Princess of Wales Returns Home From Hospital After Abdominal Surgery
abstract: The sudden hospitalization of Catherine, the wife of Prince William, in mid-January, surprised royal watchers in Britain. She will convalesce for two to three months.
lead_paragraph: Catherine, the Princess of Wales and the wife of Prince William, has returned home from a London hospital almost two weeks after undergoing abdominal surgery, Kensington Palace said in a statement on Monday.

headline: The Results Are In: Here’s What Americans Streamed in 2023
abstract: Hollywood was on strike for much of the year. And yet the time viewers spent streaming shows and movies went up. A lot.
lead_paragraph: Last year, studios continued to pull back how much they spend on new TV shows. A pair of strikes effectively shut down Hollywood for several months, disrupting new releases of television shows and movies.

headline: Iran Denies Ordering Drone Strike as Biden Weighs a Response
abstract: The deaths of three U.S. service members were the first known fatalities from hostile fire since the start of Israel’s war against Hamas.
lead_paragraph: The deaths of three U.S. soldiers in a drone strike in Jordan — the first-known American military fatalities from hostile fire in the widening Middle East crisis — are likely to increase pressure on President Biden, who has tried to limit the American response in order to keep regional tensions from spreading further.

headline: China Evergrande Must Be Liquidated, a Judge Said. What Happens Next?
abstract: The giant real estate developer epitomized China’s real estate frenzy, and its downfall fueled the market’s downturn.
lead_paragraph: After nearly two years of false starts, last-ditch proposals and pleas for more time, China Evergrande, an enormous developer, has been ordered to dismantle itself. It’s a big moment. Evergrande’s collapse in 2021 sent China’s housing market into a tailspin. The worries in real estate, where most households put their savings, helped tip the economy into a downturn.

headline: What Evergrande’s Collapse Might Mean for Global Business
abstract: The long-embattled property developer was finally ordered to liquidate. What comes next will test Western companies’ appetite to keep operating in China.
lead_paragraph: A Hong Kong court on Monday ordered the liquidation of Evergrande, the heavily indebted Chinese property giant. The decision comes two years after the company defaulted, setting off a financial crisis at other developers and adding to the challenges facing the world’s second-largest economy.

headline: Judge Denies Alex Murdaugh’s Request for a New Murder Trial
abstract: The judge said that a court clerk had made “foolish and fleeting” comments during Mr. Murdaugh’s trial, but that they did not affect the jury’s verdict that he murdered his wife and son.
lead_paragraph: A judge declined on Monday to grant a new trial for Alex Murdaugh, the former South Carolina lawyer convicted of murdering his wife and son, who had argued that he was entitled to a redo because a court clerk had improperly influenced the jurors in his case.

headline: Why the L.A. Public Library Acquired a Book Publisher
abstract: As the library system redefines itself, it has taken the unusual step of bringing in Angel City Press.
lead_paragraph: It’s Monday. Why the Los Angeles Public Library acquired a book publisher. Plus, more on why the editor in chief of The Los Angeles Times resigned this month.

headline: How to Turn Your Catan Game Around
abstract: Klaus Teuber’s fortune-building game requires finely honed negotiation skills, a passing knowledge of probability and, in some cases, card counting.
lead_paragraph: When your journalistic beat consists of providing helpful tips on how to win games, people naturally assume that you are an expert at playing them. That’s not always true, but I like to think that I make up for it with moxie and a reasonably consistent positive attitude.

headline: Oregon Newspaper to Resume Printing After Embezzlement Forced Layoffs
abstract: The Eugene Weekly was forced to lay off all 10 of its staff members last month after it discovered tens of thousands of dollars in unpaid bills.
lead_paragraph: A weekly newspaper in Oregon that laid off all of its workers in December after an employee embezzled tens of thousands of dollars will resume its print edition on Feb. 8 after raising enough money through donations, its editor said on Sunday.

headline: Russian Figure Skater Is Handed Four-Year Ban in Olympic Doping Case
abstract: Kamila Valieva, once a 15-year-old gold medal favorite, was punished in a case that upended the Beijing Games, and kept other athletes from receiving medals.
lead_paragraph: Kamila Valieva, the teenage Russian figure skater whose positive doping test upended her sport at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics and kept more than a dozen other athletes from receiving their medals, was banned from competition for four years on Monday by the top court in sports.

headline: Walmart Offers Store Managers Company Stock to Make Them Feel Like ‘Owners’
abstract: The retailer has been raising wages for store workers. It’s now turning its attention to improving salaries and benefits for their bosses.
lead_paragraph: Walmart, the nation’s largest private employer, is raising salaries and benefits for store managers as it looks for ways to retain them.

headline: Trump Rages at U.A.W. President After Biden Endorsement
abstract: The provocation for the former president’s comments appeared to be remarks that Shawn Fain, the union’s leader, made on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A few days after the United Auto Workers endorsed President Biden for re-election, former President Donald J. Trump raged at the union’s leader, Shawn Fain, on Sunday night.

headline: Do You Know These Short Stories That Became Major Films?
abstract: Certain brief literary works have more than filled the big screen over the years. See how many stories and films you recognize in this quick quiz.
lead_paragraph: Certain brief literary works have more than filled the big screen over the years. See how many stories and films you recognize in this quick quiz.

headline: An Italian Holocaust Survivor Asks if She Has ‘Lived in Vain’
abstract: Liliana Segre, who has become Italy’s conscience on the Holocaust, says she is pessimistic in the face of rising anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Liliana Segre visited Italian classrooms to recount her expulsion from school under Benito Mussolini’s anti-Semitic racial laws, her doomed attempt to flee Nazi-controlled Italy, her deportation from Milan’s train station to the death camps of Auschwitz. Her plain-spoken testimony about gas chambers, tattooed arms, casual atrocities and the murders of her father, grandparents and thousands of other Italian Jews made her the conscience and living memory of a country that often prefers not to remember.

headline: Amazon Scraps Deal to Buy Maker of Roomba Amid Regulatory Scrutiny
abstract: Amazon walked away from the $1.7 billion acquisition of iRobot as it faces questions from regulators in the European Union and United States.
lead_paragraph: Amazon said on Monday that it was abandoning plans to buy iRobot, the maker of the self-driving Roomba vacuum, after regulators raised concerns the deal would hurt competition.

headline: King Charles Released From Hospital After Prostate Procedure
abstract: Charles was released on Monday hours after Catherine, Princess of Wales, left the same hospital following abdominal surgery.
lead_paragraph: King Charles III was released from a London hospital on Monday after undergoing a procedure to treat an enlarged prostate, Buckingham Palace officials said.

headline: Joni Mitchell Adds a Gig to Her Comeback Tour: The Grammys
abstract: The Canadian singer-songwriter joins a roster of performers at this Sunday’s awards, including Billie Eilish, Olivia Rodrigo, Travis Scott, U2 and Billy Joel.
lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, Joni Mitchell fans wondered if they might ever hear her perform again, after Mitchell — the Canadian singer-songwriter and icon of the folk movement — had an aneurysm that initially left her unable to speak.

headline: U.K. to Ban Disposable Vapes in Plan to Combat Use by Children
abstract: The British government said it would act after surveys showed that the number of young people trying vapes had risen sharply.
lead_paragraph: The brightly colored packaging is a slick mix of ombré pink and lime green. The nicotine inside comes wreathed in a “strawberry kiwi” flavor.

headline: Voting Is Bewildering This Primary Season. That Worries Experts.
abstract: New Hampshire’s ballot didn’t include President Biden. South Carolina has two primaries. Nevada has a primary and a caucus. A morass of dates and formats could keep some voters away.
lead_paragraph: Democracy is messy, but usually not this messy.

headline: The Smile Gets Wonderfully Stranger
abstract: A spinoff of Radiohead, the trio of Jonny Greenwood, Tom Skinner and Thom Yorke pushes further from the solid ground of pop on its second studio LP, “Wall of Eyes.”
lead_paragraph: “Don’t think you know me,” Thom Yorke intones near the end of the Smile’s second studio album, “Wall of Eyes.” He adds, “Don’t think that I am everything you say.” With its new LP, the Smile makes itself increasingly elusive. It’s now a band intent on destabilizing structures and dissolving expectations.

headline: Superpunchy One-Pan Eggplant Adobo
abstract: In Kay Chun’s brilliant new recipe, the eggplant stays just firm enough to hold its shape while soaking in those salty-sour adobo flavors.
lead_paragraph: Substituting vegetables in traditionally meat-centric dishes is one of my favorite hacks — whether mushrooms for beef, zucchini for shrimp, or, as in Kay Chun’s new take on Filipino adobo, eggplant for chicken. It’s a brilliant swap: The eggplant stays just firm enough to hold its shape, but gets suffused with the tangy flavors of soy sauce, vinegar and garlic and the softness of coconut milk. Serve it over rice, with a handful of basil leaves or sliced scallions at the end to add a fresh and fragrant rush.

headline: African National Congress Suspends Former President Jacob Zuma
abstract: After defending the former South African president and party leader during a slew of corruption scandals, the country’s powerful governing party punished him for endorsing the opposition.
lead_paragraph: South Africa’s governing party, the African National Congress, in a remarkable rebuke, suspended its former president, Jacob Zuma, on Monday, for launching “vitriolic attacks” against the organization after throwing his support behind a rival political party.

headline: Philips Suspends U.S. Sales of Breathing Machines After Recall
abstract: Under a settlement with regulators, the company must revamp some operations before resuming sales of its CPAP and ventilator devices in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Philips Respironics announced on Monday that it would halt sales of all of its breathing machines in the United States after reaching a settlement with the Food and Drug Administration over continuing problems with the devices.

headline: French Farmers Lay ‘Siege’ to Paris in Growing Standoff
abstract: The authorities warned residents to brace for disruptions as farmers converged on the capital to press a wide range of grievances.
lead_paragraph: Irate farmers deployed tractors to block the main roads in and out of Paris on Monday, in an intensifying standoff that has left the capital girding for disruptions and has become the first major test for France’s newly appointed prime minister, Gabriel Attal.

headline: Biden’s Options Range From Unsatisfying to Risky After American Deaths
abstract: President Biden is balancing political pressures, military calculations and regional fragility after a drone strike killed three service members.
lead_paragraph: Even before the drone strike that killed three U.S. service members in Jordan on Sunday, the Biden administration was planning for a moment just like this, debating how it might strike back in ways that would deter Iran’s proxy forces and send a message that Tehran would not miss.

headline: Teen Drug and Alcohol Use Linked to Mental Health Distress
abstract: Substance use by adolescents may prove valuable in identifying the presence of underlying disorders, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers who use cannabis, alcohol and nicotine are more likely to have underlying psychiatric symptoms, and worse symptoms, than their peers who are not regularly using substances, new research has found.

headline: A ‘Substantial’ Atmospheric River Will Soak the West Coast This Week
abstract: Extreme rainfall and heavy snow is (again) forecast across the West.
lead_paragraph: Another atmospheric river will arrive in the northwestern United States on Tuesday, bringing excessive rain and mountain snow down the entire West Coast as it drifts south through Thursday.

headline: Former N.H.L. Player Faces Sexual Assault Charges in Canada
abstract: The accusation, made in London, Ontario, in 2018, has put the country’s hockey organization into turmoil and outraged the public.
lead_paragraph: A former National Hockey League player has been charged in Canada with sexual assault, his lawyer has confirmed, the latest development in a case that has brought turmoil to the sport’s Canadian governing body and angered many people across the country.

headline: Audiobooks Are Booming. Spotify Wants in on the Action.
abstract: There are early signs that Spotify’s addition of audiobooks to its streaming service is helping drive audiobook consumption — already a growing market.
lead_paragraph: When Spotify announced last fall that it was adding audiobooks to its streaming service, reactions in the publishing world were mixed: Many publishers saw Spotify’s entrance as a chance to reach new audiences. But some agents and authors worried that streaming could erode the value of audiobooks, a lucrative and growing format.

headline: 21 Savage Holds Off Green Day for a Second Week at No. 1
abstract: The rapper’s latest, “American Dream,” easily outstreamed the veteran pop-punk band’s 14th studio album, “Saviors.”
lead_paragraph: 21 Savage, the London-born Atlanta rapper, easily fended off a challenge from Green Day to hold at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a second week.

headline: At Penn, Tensions May Only Be Growing After Magill’s Resignation
abstract: Professors at the University of Pennsylvania have begun to organize, fearing what they view as a plan by the billionaire Marc Rowan to upend academic freedom.
lead_paragraph: Campus protests are not usually aimed at a single person. But last week at the University of Pennsylvania, professors staged a rally targeting Marc Rowan, the New York private-equity billionaire.

headline: He Stole Dorothy’s Ruby Slippers. He Thought They Had Real Rubies.
abstract: Terry Martin was spared prison and sentenced instead to one year of supervised release for stealing the slippers from the Judy Garland Museum in Minnesota in 2005.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two decades after he broke into the Judy Garland Museum in Grand Rapids, Minn., and stole a pair of Dorothy’s ruby slippers used in “The Wizard of Oz,” the man who committed the theft has revealed why: He believed the slippers were adorned with real rubies.

headline: The Messages of the E. Jean Carroll Verdict
abstract: Readers discuss the $83.3 million damages award in her defamation suit against Donald Trump. Also: Advice for Joe Biden; public health; vocational education.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mix-Up Preceded Deadly Drone Strike in Jordan, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: The attack on Sunday killed three Army reservists, the first known American military deaths from hostile fire in the turmoil spilling over from Israel’s war with Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Air defenses failed to stop an attack on a U.S. military outpost in Jordan on Sunday that killed three American soldiers at least in part because the hostile drone approached its target at the same time an American drone was returning to the base, two U.S. officials said on Monday.

headline: A Climate Change Success Story? Look at Hoboken
abstract: This flood-prone city on the Hudson River balances climate infrastructure with resident needs.
lead_paragraph: Note: This newsletter was sent to readers in November 2023. Headway is publishing the newsletter as an article to bring them together with other newsletters on site. Read them all here.

headline: The Lessons of the Crime Wave That Didn’t Happen
abstract: Fears of violence in the 1980s and ’90s resulted in life sentences for minors that are now being reversed.
lead_paragraph: Note: This newsletter was sent to readers in October 2023. Headway is publishing the newsletter as an article to bring them together with other newsletters on site. Read them all here.

headline: Three Days That Changed the Thinking About Black Women’s Health
abstract: Four decades ago, 2,000 Black women converged on Spelman College for a conference on health.
lead_paragraph: Note: This newsletter was sent to readers in December 2023. Headway is publishing the newsletter as an article to bring it together with other newsletters on site. Read them all here.

headline: Hate Crimes Reported in Schools Nearly Doubled Between 2018 and 2022
abstract: Black students were the most frequent reported victims, followed by L.G.B.T.Q. and Jewish students, according to F.B.I. statistics.
lead_paragraph: The number of reported hate crimes in schools and colleges nearly doubled between 2018 and 2022, according to data released Monday by the F.B.I.

headline: Defense Secretary Returns to Pentagon a Month After Surgery Complications
abstract: Lloyd J. Austin III was widely criticized for failing to immediately disclose his illness and hospitalization to President Biden and other officials.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III returned to the Pentagon on Monday for the first time in more than a month, the Defense Department said, after his surgery for prostate cancer and hospitalization for related medical complications.

headline: Georgia Senators Press Biden for Tougher Tariffs on Chinese Solar Panels
abstract: The issue goes to the core of one of President Biden’s arguments for re-election: that his economic policies are working.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan quartet of senators, led by two Democrats from the critical swing state of Georgia, are asking President Biden to toughen up tariffs on Chinese solar panels or face a glutted market just as the president’s clean-energy tax credits hit the market.

headline: French Farmers Block Roads Around Paris, Escalating Protests
abstract: Farmers around France sought to put pressure on the government over a wide range of grievances concerning the future of their industry.
lead_paragraph: Farmers around France sought to put pressure on the government over a wide range of grievances concerning the future of their industry.

headline: How to Wash Your Hair
abstract: A guide to building an effective, adaptable routine for every hair type.
lead_paragraph: Don’t I know how to do this already? you might be asking. But while washing your hair might seem straightforward, a truly effective cleanse requires some thought and expertise. Just like the skin on our faces, each person’s scalp, and the hair that grows out of it, is different. Using the wrong products for your hair type can lead to oily roots, flaky skin and lackluster strands. What’s more, our hair’s needs can shift daily, so the best routine is one that’s both personalized and flexible. Here’s how to tailor your approach to achieve clean, healthy tresses.

headline: U.N. to Study Reports of Sexual Violence in Israel During Oct. 7 Attack
abstract: A team from the United Nations has arrived in Israel to examine multiple reports of sexual violence during the Hamas-led attack.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations team has arrived in Israel to examine reports of sexual violence during the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7 even as Hamas and some critics of Israel continue to reject evidence that such assaults occurred.

headline: N. Scott Momaday, Pulitzer-Winning Native American Novelist, Dies at 89
abstract: The success of his novel “House Made of Dawn,” the first work by a Native American to win a Pulitzer, inspired a wave of Native literature.
lead_paragraph: N. Scott Momaday, whose portrayal of a disaffected World War II veteran’s journey to spiritual renewal in his novel “House Made of Dawn” won a Pulitzer Prize, the first for a Native American author, heralding a more prominent place in contemporary literature for Native writers, died on Wednesday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 89.

headline: Have Your Drinking Habits Changed in Recent Years?
abstract: The Times wants to hear from you.
lead_paragraph: Dry January is trickling to a close, marking the end of a month when many people rethink their relationship with drinking.

headline: As Trump Awaits Fraud Penalty, a Monitor’s Report Could Raise His Risk
abstract: A monitor drew attention to “deficiencies” in the Trump Organization’s financial reporting ahead of a verdict in a case brought by New York State that seeks $370 million.
lead_paragraph: As a New York judge weighs Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud case, new accusations of deficiencies in his company’s financial reporting could provide the judge with ammunition for a forceful ruling against the former president and his family business.

headline: After a Slow Start, Sundance Finishes With Plenty of Sales
abstract: The festival, seen as a barometer for the overall health of the film industry, featured several movies and documentaries snatched up by studios and streaming services.
lead_paragraph: Talk of the demise of the Sundance Film Festival as an incubator for audience-friendly independent films appears to have been greatly exaggerated.

headline: The Promises and Problems of Buying Local
abstract: There’s no right answer to whether buying local is better. It’s a matter, instead, of trade-offs.
lead_paragraph: You can crisscross North Dakota from Fargo to Bismarck to Minot and never see a Walgreens, Rite-Aid or Walmart pharmacy. With narrow exceptions, a 1963 state law prohibits drugstores that aren’t majority-owned by a pharmacist. (CVS Health, whose predecessor company was already in the state in 1963, is grandfathered in.)

headline: When the Governor Shotguns a Beer (or Maybe a Spiked Iced Tea)
abstract: The moment with Gov. Wes Moore of Maryland on Sunday garnered the approval of sports fans, but it didn’t ultimately help the Baltimore Ravens.
lead_paragraph: It is an adage in politics that voters want to elect politicians they can see themselves sharing a beer with.

headline: In Court, N.R.A. Questions Its Longtime Chief About His Luxury Spending
abstract: Wayne LaPierre was grilled by lawyers from a legal team he hired in testimony meant to show that the gun group has mended its ways.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Wayne LaPierre faced a second day of grilling on the witness stand about his lavish spending as the longtime chief of the National Rifle Association.

headline: The Accusations Against the Atlanta Prosecutor Fani Willis: What We Know
abstract: Donald Trump’s lawyers want Ms. Willis disqualified from the Georgia election case over accusations that she had a romantic relationship with a subordinate. A judge will decide what happens next.
lead_paragraph: The election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump and 14 of his allies in Georgia has been buffeted by allegations that the main prosecutor, Fani T. Willis, engaged in a romantic relationship with a lawyer she hired to help with the case.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Weighs a Response to the Drone Strike
abstract: Plus, Evergrande’s liquidation and Biden’s election strategy.
lead_paragraph: President Biden must decide how far he is willing to go after a drone strike killed three U.S. soldiers at a base in Jordan on Sunday. He vowed to respond to the attack, which he blamed on militant groups backed by Iran, but retaliation could risk a wider war.

headline: The World’s Biggest Jeweler Now Only Sources Recycled Metals
abstract: Is that as good as it sounds?
lead_paragraph: Pandora, known for its affordable sterling-silver charm bracelets, is the world’s largest jewelry company by volume: The Danish chain sells more than 100 million pieces annually. This week, it announced that it is now sourcing only 100-percent-recycled silver and gold for its collections.

headline: Former Contractor Who Leaked Trump’s Tax Returns Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison
abstract: Prosecutors accused Charles Littlejohn, 38, of stealing the tax documents of thousands of the country’s wealthiest people and said his actions “appear to be unparalleled in the I.R.S.’s history.”
lead_paragraph: A former Internal Revenue Service contractor accused of leaking the tax documents of Donald J. Trump and other wealthy Americans was sentenced on Monday to five years in prison.

headline: Skip the Flowers for a Sweethearts Cake From Nick Morgenstern
abstract: Sip coffee and listen to Bach’s “Coffee Cantata,” watch a chocolate maker documentary with an accompanying tasting and more food news.
lead_paragraph: A dozen roses would be challenged to compete with the delectable Sweethearts Cake from Nick Morgenstern, the ice cream wizard. A raspberry-dusted slather of gossamer whipped cream covers a half-cylinder of Madagascar vanilla ice cream, set on raspberry sponge cake for a snowy, edible Quonset hut. Hearts of tart red fruit jam show up in each slice to punctuate the delicate sweetness. It serves four, but just two might make short work of it. Though this confection needs no embellishment, a few spoonfuls alongside raspberry coulis, a new intense sauce from Francine’s Outrageous Kitchen, puts it on a pedestal.

headline: Vera Klement, Painter Who Saw Both Beauty and Evil, Dies at 93
abstract: A Holocaust survivor, she once said that she sought in her art to “recognize the nightmare but confirm rather than deny human life.”
lead_paragraph: In late 2009, as she was about to turn 80, Vera Klement was spattering and brushing red paint onto a 6-by-7-foot canvas on the floor of her loft in Chicago where she lived and worked. It depicted a faceless man, his arms pressed tightly to his chest, surrounded by a field of red. To the right, separated by white space, was a black rectangle.

headline: Heavy Rain and Cold Worsen Conditions for Palestinians in Gaza
abstract: Days of torrential rains have exacerbated the dire humanitarian crisis in Gaza, where tens of thousands of people are displaced.
lead_paragraph: Days of torrential rains have exacerbated the dire humanitarian crisis in Gaza, where tens of thousands of people are displaced.

headline: U.S. Charges Iranian Man and Two Canadians in Plot to Kill Refugees
abstract: Naji Sharifi Zindashti is accused of being the kingpin of a network that targeted defectors and hiring the two Canadians, including a member of the Hells Angels.
lead_paragraph: An Iranian man accused of being the kingpin of a network that targets dissidents has been charged with hiring two Canadians, including a member of the Hells Angels, to kill two Iranian refugees living in Maryland, according to indictments unsealed on Monday.

headline: They’ll Take the Travis Kelce — Hairdo, That Is
abstract: Not since Jennifer Aniston has a haircut become so popular. Barbers, in America and abroad, are being inundated with requests for “the Travis Kelce.”
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Dugas, who cuts hair at Obsidian Barbers in New Brunswick, Canada, has received a very specific request from clients in the past few weeks: They want the same style as Travis Kelce.

headline: ‘The Greatest Night in Pop’ Review: They Were the World
abstract: This documentary shows the highlights of the recording session for the charity song “We Are the World,” which assembled a who’s who of pop celebrities.
lead_paragraph: In late 1984 the singer and activist Harry Belafonte was both impressed and perturbed by “Do They Know It’s Christmas?,” a British charity single featuring a cast of pop stars. The proceeds from the project went to Ethiopian famine relief. Belafonte complained to the music manager Ken Kragen, “We have white folks saving Black folks and we don’t have Black folks saving Black folks.”

headline: U.N. Agency for Palestinians Imperiled by Terrorism Charges
abstract: Donors have pulled funds for the main aid agency in Gaza after allegations that some employees took part in the Oct. 7 attack, but it is not clear who would fill the vacuum if it ran out of money.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the largest United Nations agency in Gaza warned on Monday that it may soon run out of money as new allegations emerged about Hamas’s influence on the organization.

headline: Court Clears Way for Italy to Send Some Asylum Seekers to Albania
abstract: The arrangement, widely criticized by human rights groups, is part of the Italian government’s efforts to send the message that many undocumented migrants will not be allowed directly into the country.
lead_paragraph: An Albanian court on Monday gave the green light to an agreement allowing Italy to send migrants who are rescued in the Mediterranean by Italian ships to detention centers in Albania while their asylum claims are considered.

headline: Party Like ‘Saltburn’ — Bathwater Optional
abstract: Devoted fans gathered for a bash inspired by the film.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night at 3 Dollar Bill, a queer club in the East Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, partygoers danced and sang along to early 2000s hits by Fergie, Justin Timberlake and, of course, Sophie Ellis-Bextor whose “Murder on the Dancefloor” is currently having a renaissance.

headline: A Drone Mix-Up Was Cited in the Deaths of 3 U.S. Troops
abstract: Also, China’s troubled property giant will be dismantled. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: U.S. air defenses at a remote military outpost in Jordan failed to stop a deadly drone attack yesterday because it arrived at the same time that an American drone was returning to base, American officials said.

headline: Defense Department Identifies 3 Soldiers Killed at Base in Jordan
abstract: Officials said the dead were three Army Reserve soldiers from Georgia, part of an engineering company trained for deployment at short notice.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense on Monday identified three Army Reserve soldiers who were killed at a U.S. base in Jordan on Sunday in what the Biden administration said was a drone attack from an Iran-backed militia. The department said at least 34 other service members were wounded in the attack.

headline: Why Democrats Are Using Personal Abortion Stories
abstract: Plus: A Taylor Swift endorsement is Biden’s wildest dream.
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Austin Dennard, an OB-GYN in Dallas, learned that her 11-week-old fetus had a fatal medical condition in July 2022, she immediately understood the medical implications.

headline: Williamsburg. What Happened?
abstract: A four-decade timeline of total transformation in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A four-decade timeline of total transformation in Brooklyn.

headline: MAGA Is Based on Fear, Not Grounded in Reality
abstract: And the fear needn’t reflect reality.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, Kristi Noem, the Republican governor of South Dakota — a MAGA hard-liner sometimes mentioned as a potential running mate for Donald Trump — warned that President Biden is “remaking” America, turning us into Europe. My first thought was: So he’s going to raise our life expectancy by five or six years? In context, however, it was clear that Noem believes, or expects her audience to believe, that Europe is a scene of havoc wrought by hordes of immigrants.

headline: Officials Propose to Hamas a Six-Week War Pause and a Hostage-Prisoner Swap
abstract: The United States, Israel, Egypt and Qatar sketched out a bare-bones framework in Paris. Qatari officials are awaiting word from Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Representatives from four nations have agreed to have Qatar present a nascent framework to Hamas that proposes a six-week pause in the war in Gaza for Hamas to exchange some hostages for Palestinian prisoners held by Israel, officials say.

headline: Norfolk Southern Agrees to Try Out Federal Safety Reporting Program
abstract: The company, which operated the train that derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, is the first major freight railroad to join a federal program that allows workers to report safety issues.
lead_paragraph: Norfolk Southern, the operator of the freight train carrying toxic chemicals that derailed in East Palestine, Ohio, nearly a year ago, has agreed to participate in a federal program that allows employees to report safety issues confidentially, the company and federal officials announced on Monday.

headline: Colombia, a Usually Wet Nation, Reels Amid Widespread Wildfires
abstract: Firefighters, many of them volunteers, have been confronting dozens of blazes amid high temperatures this month. The conditions have been linked to climate change.
lead_paragraph: Helicopters hauling buckets of water fly toward the mountains where fires burn, a thick haze periodically covers the sky, and residents have been ordered to wear masks and limit driving because of the poor air quality.

headline: Jimy Williams, A.L. Manager of the Year in Boston in ’99, Dies at 80
abstract: He led the Red Sox into the playoffs twice, had managing stints in Toronto and Houston, and won more than 900 games as a dugout skipper.
lead_paragraph: Jimy Williams, the 1999 American League Manager of the Year for Boston who won 910 games over a dozen seasons that included stints with Toronto and Houston, died on Friday in Tarpon Springs, Fla. He was 80.

headline: Canada Delays Plan to Offer Medically Assisted Death to the Mentally Ill
abstract: A parliamentary panel concluded that there are not enough doctors, particularly psychiatrists, in the country to properly assess patients.
lead_paragraph: Canada is postponing a plan to offer people suffering from mental illnesses the option of a medically assisted death, two cabinet ministers said on Monday.

headline: Northern Ireland’s D.U.P. Signals End to Political Deadlock After 2 Years
abstract: The Democratic Unionist Party said it had agreed a deal to return to power-sharing after negotiating with the British government.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Unionist Party, the main Protestant party in Northern Ireland and one of its biggest political forces, said on Tuesday that it was ready to return to power sharing after a boycott of almost two years had paralyzed decision-making in the region.

headline: Arkansas Authorities Capture Second Escaped Inmate
abstract: Jatonia Bryant, 23, had been held at a jail in Pine Bluff, Ark., on a capital murder charge before he and another inmate fled last week, the authorities said. The other escapee was caught Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Arkansas on Monday captured a capital murder suspect who had escaped from a local jail with another inmate, ending a weeklong manhunt.

headline: Washed Out
abstract: Freddie Cheng assembles a body of experts.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: 5 Men Arrested in Mojave Desert Killings That Remained a Mystery for Days
abstract: Six victims were found in a remote area of San Bernardino County about 90 miles northeast of Los Angeles. The authorities believe the shooting deaths stemmed from a dispute over illegal marijuana.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Southern California announced on Monday that they had arrested five men in connection with the six people found fatally shot at a remote crossroads in the Mojave Desert last week, a grisly scene that investigators believe stemmed from a dispute over marijuana.

headline: Man Who Shot Bride and Bishop at Wedding Gets 50 Years to Life in Prison
abstract: Dale Holloway, 41, was sentenced Monday on several charges, including attempted murder, for opening fire at a New Hampshire church in 2019 in what the authorities called a revenge shooting.
lead_paragraph: A gunman who opened fire in a New Hampshire church during a wedding, wounding the bride and bishop, was sentenced Monday to a minimum of 50 years to life in prison.

headline: Neuralink Implanted a Device in a Patient’s Brain, Elon Musk Says
abstract: The billionaire said his company’s first product, called Telepathy, would let a person control a phone or computer “just by thinking.”
lead_paragraph: Neuralink, a company working to develop computer interfaces that can be implanted in human brains, placed its first device in a patient on Sunday, said its founder, Elon Musk.

headline: Quote of the Day: More Than Ever, Teenagers See a Bleak Future
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “The data is pretty stark: Our kids are not all right.”

headline: China’s Real Estate Crisis ‘Has Not Touched Bottom’
abstract: The forced liquidation of China Evergrande epitomizes the sector’s struggles: Nationwide, sales are down and millions of homes have been paid for but not delivered.
lead_paragraph: The unwavering belief of Chinese home buyers that real estate was a can’t-lose investment propelled the country’s property sector to become the backbone of its economy.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Biden weighs a response to Iran.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is faced with a decision on how far he is willing to go after a drone strike killed three U.S. soldiers at a base in Jordan on Sunday. He vowed to respond to the attack, which he blamed on militant groups backed by Iran, but retaliation could risk a wider war.

headline: If It Isn’t Perfect, Is It Still K-Pop?
abstract: Musical acts like Balming Tiger are challenging the idea that K-pop is nothing but polished, perfectly synchronized boy bands and girl groups.
lead_paragraph: What comes to mind when you hear the word “K-pop”? Is it the global boy band phenomenon BTS, wearing studded jackets and dancing in perfect sync? Or the girl group Blackpink, performing at Coachella in trendy fashions and perfectly curled hair?

headline: Word of the Day: oneiric
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word oneiric has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 2 in the book review “Daniel Clowes Dreams of the Apocalypse” by Junot Díaz:

headline: Aid Group Calls Halts in Funding for UNRWA ‘Reckless’
abstract: The U.S. and some other donor countries said they would suspend funding for the agency after Israel charged that a dozen of its workers had played a role in the Oct. 7 attack or its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: Aid groups working in Gaza expressed dismay at the decision by some donor nations to suspend funding to the main U.N. agency operating in the territory, calling the move “reckless” at a moment when the humanitarian crisis there is rapidly getting worse.

headline: Stephen Colbert Is Hoping for a Taylor Swift Super Bowl
abstract: With the Kansas City Chiefs in the game, Colbert can’t wait to see “the biggest star in the N.F.L.” (if she can get there from Japan in time).
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: New Subway Fare Gates and Platform Barriers Fail to Impress New Yorkers
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is testing ways to address passenger safety and fare evasion. It’s not clear the pilots will be effective.
lead_paragraph: Transit officials have struggled for years with two of the subway system’s most vexing problems: the dozens of people struck by trains every year and the millions of dollars lost to fare beaters. In the latest efforts to find solutions, they are testing new fare gates to stop turnstile jumpers and metal platform barriers to keep riders safe.

headline: Mayor Adams Loses Showdown Over 2 Criminal Justice Bills
abstract: The New York City Council overrode the mayor’s veto of two bills that would expand documentation of police stops and end solitary confinement.
lead_paragraph: Police officers will be required to record the race, age and gender of most people they stop and solitary confinement will be banned in New York City jails after the City Council overrode Mayor Eric Adams’s veto of two criminal justice bills on Tuesday.

headline: In Peru, a Mission to Save the Stingless Bee
abstract: Native to the tropics, these pollinators are taking a lead role in one of the latest efforts to conserve the Amazon rainforest.
lead_paragraph: As a child, Heriberto Vela, an Indigenous resident of Loreto, Peru, watched his father pull nests of wild stingless bees from trees in the Amazon forest. Together, the two then extracted honey from the nests to help cure colds and other ailments.

headline: Taylor Swift and the N.F.L.
abstract: Are TV broadcasts focusing on the pop star too much?
lead_paragraph: Please note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our writing prompts and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on nytimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only part of the site that explicitly invites the voices of young people.

headline: Imran Khan Sentenced to 10 Years Ahead of Pakistan’s Elections
abstract: The verdict is widely seen as part of a military-led campaign to sideline Mr. Khan’s political party.
lead_paragraph: Former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Tuesday, the latest twist in what is widely seen as a campaign by the military to sideline one of its leading critics.

headline: Letter to San Zaw Htway
abstract: After the 2021 military coup in Myanmar, loved ones of the deceased artist and political prisoner San Zaw Htway wrote him letters as an act of remembrance and hope.
lead_paragraph: After the 2021 military coup in Myanmar, loved ones of the deceased artist and political prisoner San Zaw Htway wrote him letters as an act of remembrance and hope.

headline: Our Friend Is Gone, but He Lives Through Our Resistance in Myanmar
abstract: After the 2021 military coup in Myanmar, loved ones of the deceased artist and political prisoner San Zaw Htway wrote him letters as an act of remembrance and hope.
lead_paragraph: San Zaw Htway was an artist, activist, political prisoner and dear friend.

headline: A Return to the Fatherland in Search of a Missing Father
abstract: In Leo Vardiashvili’s first novel, “Hard by a Great Forest,” a young man begins a fraught quest in the country he once fled.
lead_paragraph: “Hard by a Great Forest,” by Leo Vardiashvili, is a novel-as-postcard from a dissolute Georgia. Our narrator, the self-abnegating and guilt-ridden Saba, fled the former Soviet republic with his father and brother amid civil war, and arrived in 1990s London at the age of 8. Nearly two decades later, his father, Irakli, flies alone to Tbilisi to reconcile his past and goes missing. “I left a trail I can’t erase,” reads Irakli’s final message to his sons. “Do not follow it.” Naturally, Saba follows.

headline: An America Where Guns Do the Talking
abstract: Two new books consider how the country’s obsession with firearms has become an existential threat.
lead_paragraph: Last year, a friend from Brunei visited me in the United States. She is American but was raised in Sudan and has lived in Cambodia and Scotland, among other places. We were talking about the rise in anxiety among teenagers in America when another friend texted me; her daughter had just arrived home from school, where she’d spent the afternoon in lockdown. “Of course your kids have anxiety,” my Brunei friend said. “They’re being raised in a war zone.”

headline: The Curmudgeon of Rivington Street
abstract: As his apartment on the Lower East Side crumbled, a former Club Kid resented the moneyed millennials who filled his building. Then he let them in on a secret that transformed their lives.
lead_paragraph: The drag queens who once paraded through the hallways are long gone.

headline: Joel Embiid Wants the African Diaspora to Flourish Onscreen
abstract: “I’ve always been passionate about storytelling,” said the N.B.A. star, whose production studio will create a documentary about Memphis Depay’s success on the Dutch soccer team.
lead_paragraph: Joel Embiid knew as early as his rookie season in the National Basketball Association that he eventually wanted to enter the media industry.

headline: The Most Powerful Person in Publishing Doesn’t Like to Talk About Himself
abstract: Nihar Malaviya, Penguin Random House’s C.E.O., is a behind-the-scenes operator with a significant task: leading the company after a period of messy, and expensive, turbulence.
lead_paragraph: As chief executive of Penguin Random House, Nihar Malaviya runs a global company and the largest book publisher in the United States — a powerful cultural force that helps drive public debate and shape the country’s entertainment and literary worlds.

headline: Is Lip Balm Making My Chapped Lips Worse?
abstract: It can be a helpful barrier between your lips and the cold wind, but not all products are created equal.
lead_paragraph: Q: My lips are always dry, and I’m applying lip balm on repeat. Could this be exacerbating the problem?

headline: 394 Hot Dog Ice Sculptures Later, He Quit His Day Job
abstract: The artist who goes by Sunday Nobody has found millions of viewers with his elaborate, absurdist projects. They are not, he insists, “a waste of a human life.”
lead_paragraph: One day this summer, a man in Seattle gathered ingredients to make hot dogs: sausages, buns, a 50-pound block of aluminum.

headline: The Women of ‘Feud: Capote vs. the Swans’ Are Birds of a Feather
abstract: Famous women play the famous women in Ryan Murphy’s new period drama. In a group interview, they discuss the series and the burdens of public life.
lead_paragraph: The first season of Ryan Murphy’s “Feud” aired in 2017. A juicy survey of the bitter rivalry between Bette Davis and Joan Crawford, the co-stars of “What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?,” the show earned 18 Emmy nominations, winning two. A second season, based on Prince Charles and Princess Diana’s troubled marriage, was developed then scrapped, mostly because Murphy felt that he could never outdo “The Crown.” Another iteration, centered on William F. Buckley and Gore Vidal, also fell apart. Murphy and his producers toyed with a half dozen other ideas, though never for very long.

headline: Is True Crime As a Form of Entertainment Ethical?
abstract: A writer and activist says the genre can be harmful to victims and their families. What do you think?
lead_paragraph: True crime entertainment seems to be everywhere these days. Are you a fan? Do you listen to podcasts, read books, or watch documentaries, TV shows and movies that tell the stories of real-life victims and perpetrators?

headline: Do Housing Developers Need a (Tax) Break?
abstract: The 421a program expired in 2022. Developers and many officials say it was crucial in getting rental apartments built, but replacing it is politically challenging.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about a tax break that expired in 2022 — and why the fight over replacing it has implications for New York City’s future. We’ll also get details on why the City Council is expected to override Mayor Eric Adams’s veto of two bills today.

headline: Watch Me Lose My Job on TikTok
abstract: Some tech workers are filming their layoffs and sharing them on social media. They say it’s part catharsis, part transparency.
lead_paragraph: “I am about to get laid off,” Folashade Ade-Banjo spoke to the camera while positioning her phone, “and you are about to see it.”

headline: What Your Laundry Says About Your Life
abstract: What you’ve gone through and how you wear it, one wash cycle at a time.
lead_paragraph: My father has placed me in the basket and layered laundry neatly on top of me, then topped everything with a crocheted blanket. Time stamp: epitome of the ’70s. I’m ... 5? He has employed a classic parental trick, his version called Rock, inspired by Frank Zappa’s “Help, I’m a Rock,” which I also recommend. The game was: Pretend you’re a rock. You’re quiet. You’re still. I remember the weight of the laundry, the solemnity of my task and the laughter just beneath it. Something about the princess and the pea: being the pea.

headline: Linda Ronstadt’s Tucson
abstract: The Rock & Roll Hall of Famer known for hits like “Blue Bayou” and “Long Long Time” recommends spots she adores in the city where she was born and raised.
lead_paragraph: In the course of becoming a Rock & Roll Hall of Famer, a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award winner and the subject of a forthcoming biopic set to star Selena Gomez, Linda Ronstadt has packed theaters around the globe. But her favorite sits on a one-way side street in Tucson, Ariz.

headline: What Can Americans Agree on? Wolves.
abstract: In expanding pockets of the West, citizens across the political spectrum are finding common ground as they adjust to living beside wolves.
lead_paragraph: For generations, America waged a war against the wolf; now with the animals repopulating the Mountain West, the wolf war has taken on a new shape: pitting neighbors against neighbors as they fight over how to manage wolves.

headline: Trump Has Devoured the Republican Establishment
abstract: No matter which way you slice it, he is the engine of the party.
lead_paragraph: It was almost 15 months ago that The New York Post published a full-page cover photo of Ron DeSantis with the headline “DeFUTURE.” His 19-point victory in the Florida governor’s race was one of the few bright spots of the 2022 elections for a weary Republican elite, which was desperately looking to move on from Donald Trump after his handpicked candidates cost the party key Senate seats.

headline: Why Cut Rates in an Economy This Strong? A Big Question Confronts the Fed.
abstract: The central bank is widely expected to lower interest rates this year. But with growth and consumer spending chugging along, explaining it may take some work.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is widely expected to leave interest rates unchanged at the conclusion of its meeting on Wednesday, but investors will be watching closely for any hint at when and how much it might lower those rates this year.

headline: How Do You Make a Weed Empire? Sell It Like Streetwear.
abstract: Berner, the San Francisco rapper, has built a legal-weed empire out of his black-market past — and blurred the lines between the two.
lead_paragraph: The closest thing to a bat signal for stoners is the blue lettering of the Cookies logo. When a new storefront comes to a strip mall or a downtown shopping district, fans flock to grand-opening parties, drawn by a love of the brand — one based on more than its reputation for selling extremely potent weed. Until recently, the company was largely a West Coast phenomenon, but as marijuana legalization spread east, so did Cookies. A little over a year after recreational sales became legal in New Jersey, the chain opened a new location in a bland outdoor mall in Harrison, its aesthetic landing somewhere in the startup-meets-streetwear zone between Apple and Kith. I walked over to a large circular table laden with dozens of jars, each containing a different strain. There were longtime Cookies stalwarts like Gary Payton, a collaboration with the N.B.A. legend, and new variants with names like Mexican Flan and Dirty Muffler.

headline: Truck Makers Team Up to Push for Electric Vehicle Chargers
abstract: Daimler, Navistar and Volvo have been criticized for not selling many electric heavy trucks, but the companies say the country first needs many more chargers.
lead_paragraph: There are more than four million electric vehicles on American roads, but fewer than 1,000 of them are heavy-duty trucks. On Tuesday, the three largest truck makers announced a push to remedy that deficit by calling on governments and utilities to help them build many more places to charge big rigs.

headline: Focused Cuts and Fewer Layers: Tech Layoffs Enter a New Phase
abstract: Amazon, Google, Microsoft and other tech companies have been on a layoff spree this month, with the latest cuts differing from last year’s mass reductions.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Mark Zuckerberg declared 2023 to be a “year of efficiency.” His company, Meta, soon laid off a third of its employees. Amazon, Google and Microsoft also cut tens of thousands of workers.

headline: What Biden Can Do After Another Failed Border Deal
abstract: Without the chaos to exploit, the Republican advantage on this issue will fall.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan immigration deal to restrict border crossings took a hit last week when Donald Trump pushed Congress to reject it. It’s the latest in a series of episodes over the last decade where one party blows up a deal just as the other gives in. President Biden wants to break this cycle, but to get the politics right, he must get the policy right first.

headline: U.S. Will Pay to Add Solar Panels to Hospitals, Schools After Disasters
abstract: The federal government plans to reimburse state and local governments that rebuild damaged public buildings to be more energy resilient.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Emergency Management Agency will begin paying to install solar panels on schools, hospitals and other public buildings that are rebuilt after disasters, making them more resilient against future disasters while reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: I’m Not a Fan of TikTok, but We Can’t Blame It for Everything
abstract: Instead of scapegoating social media, start regulating it.
lead_paragraph: Gen Z and younger millennials are taking to apps like TikTok to express their anger about everything from the conflict in the Middle East to the cost of living. Some politicians are not happy. In this audio essay, the Opinion columnist Zeynep Tufekci argues that lawmakers should stop blaming social media platforms for corrupting people’s minds and instead concentrate on oversight and demand transparency from them.

headline: Biden Super PAC Plans a Historic $250 Million Ad Blitz
abstract: The flood of TV and digital spots in battleground states is set to be the largest single purchase of political advertising by a super PAC in U.S. history, according to the group, Future Forward.
lead_paragraph: The main Democratic super PAC supporting President Biden’s re-election bid, Future Forward, is beginning this week to reserve $250 million in advertising across the most important battleground states, a blitz that it says is the largest single purchase of political advertising by a super PAC in the nation’s history.

headline: First Bird Flu Deaths Reported in Antarctic Penguins
abstract: Dead gentoo penguins tested positive for the virus, and at least one suspected case has been reported in king penguins.
lead_paragraph: A highly lethal form of bird flu has been detected in Antarctic penguins for the first time. The virus, which is known as H5N1, was confirmed in two gentoo penguins that were found dead on Sea Lion Island in the Falkland Islands, a British territory.

headline: House Panel Approves Impeachment Charges Against Mayorkas
abstract: In a party-line vote, Republicans on the Homeland Security Committee recommended that the House impeach the homeland security secretary over his handling of the border.
lead_paragraph: The House Homeland Security Committee approved two articles of impeachment early Wednesday against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, over his handling of the southwestern border, as Republicans raced forward with a partisan indictment of President Biden’s immigration policies.

headline: More Money for Parents? Both Parties Just Might Make It Happen.
abstract: If an expansion of the child tax credit passed, here’s what would change and who would benefit.
lead_paragraph: At a time when congressional Democrats and Republicans seem unable to agree on almost anything, they may soon pass an expanded child tax credit, which gives money to parents.

headline: 6 Great Space Images in January
abstract: A rocket launching from the ocean, an asteroid hits Earth's atmosphere and more out of this world visual highlights from the past month.
lead_paragraph: A rocket launching from the ocean, an asteroid hits Earth's atmosphere and more out of this world visual highlights from the past month.

headline: If It Walks Like an Insurrection and Talks Like an Insurrection …
abstract: Trump has no rightful place in the leadership of the American Republic.
lead_paragraph: While we await oral argument in Trump v. Anderson — the U.S. Supreme Court case that will evaluate the Colorado Supreme Court’s decision to exclude the former president from the state’s Republican primary ballot — it’s worth revisiting the arguments leveled against the Colorado court’s decision and, by extension, its interpretation of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.

headline: The War the World Can’t See
abstract: From outside Gaza, the scale of death and destruction is impossible to grasp, shrouded by communications blackouts, restrictions barring international reporters and extreme challenges facing local journalists.
lead_paragraph: To many people outside Gaza, the war flashes by as a doomscroll of headlines and casualty tolls and photos of screaming children, the bloody shreds of somebody else’s anguish.

headline: She Gave Birth Two Weeks Ago. Now She’s in a Beauty Pageant.
abstract: Hannah Neeleman, a Utah homemaker with a huge social media following, goes to Las Vegas, newborn in tow, to compete for Mrs. World.
lead_paragraph: “I am still bleeding a little,” Hannah Neeleman said.

headline: Eurozone Economy Flatlines, Raising Concerns About Falling Behind
