abstract: The anemic pace of growth in Europe, dragged down by a weak German economy, is widening the gap with the United States.
lead_paragraph: The eurozone economy stagnated late last year as a lingering energy crisis sparked a loss of competitiveness in some European industries, and consumers reined in spending to grapple with high living costs, Europe’s statistics agency reported Tuesday.

headline: Trump’s Voters vs. Haley’s Donors
abstract: A class war is playing out inside the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Republican Party, a class war is playing out between the pro-Trump base, which is ready for the nomination fight to be over, and the anti-Trump donor class, which thinks it’s just getting started.

headline: U.S. Weighs Retaliation After Strike in Jordan, and Farmers Lay ‘Siege’ to Paris
abstract: Plus, the Biden campaign wants Taylor Swift.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Russian Skaters Stripped of Olympic Gold, Setting Up New Fight for Medals
abstract: A decision to address the disqualification of Kamila Valieva gave the United States the gold in the Beijing 2022 team event, but it kept Canada off the podium.
lead_paragraph: International skating’s governing body on Tuesday sought to put an end to a two-year-old controversy by revising the disputed results of a marquee figure skating competition at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics. But in stripping Russia of its victory in the team event, awarding the gold medal to the United States and denying Canada the bronze it had been expecting, the sport may have only set the stage for yet another protracted legal fight.

headline: Amazon Filmed ‘Expats’ in Hong Kong, but People There Can’t Watch It
abstract: The first two episodes of the show, which was filmed during the city’s pandemic restrictions, were released last week but were not available there.
lead_paragraph: At the height of Hong Kong’s Covid restrictions, the government gave Nicole Kidman and several others a rare exemption from the weeks of hotel quarantine required for travelers so that they could film a series about the malaise of privileged expatriates.

headline: G.M. Profits Hurt by Electric Car Business and Strike
abstract: The automaker has placed a bet on electric vehicles, but it has struggled to produce and sell the vehicles in large numbers.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Tuesday that its profit in the final three months of 2023 was depressed by the cost of a 40-day strike at some of its U.S. plants and an accounting charge related to electric vehicles.

headline: Experimental Drug Cuts Off Pain at the Source, Company Says
abstract: Vertex Pharmaceuticals said its medicine could address moderate to severe acute pain, and might be able to avoid the risk of addiction.
lead_paragraph: Vertex Pharmaceuticals of Boston announced Tuesday that it had developed an experimental drug that relieves moderate to severe pain, blocking pain signals before they can get to the brain. It works only on peripheral nerves — those outside the brain and the spinal cord — making it unlike opioids. Vertex says its new drug is expected to avoid opioids’ potential to lead to addiction.

headline: Hong Kong Pushes New Security Law to Root Out ‘Seeds of Unrest’
abstract: Warning of threats posed by spies, the city’s leader expressed confidence that the new law would enjoy public support. “They will love it,” he said.
lead_paragraph: The Hong Kong government will enact a long-shelved security law to curb foreign influence and expand the definition of offenses like stealing state secrets and treason, officials announced on Tuesday, in a move expected to further silence dissent in the once-freewheeling Chinese territory.

headline: What Iran Really Wants
abstract: The nation is at the center of the current turmoil in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Iran has emerged as the chief architect in multiple conflicts strafing the Middle East, from the Mediterranean to the Persian Gulf.

headline: Israeli Forces Kill a Hamas Commander Inside a West Bank Hospital, Military Says
abstract: Surveillance video released by the Palestinian Authority shows several gunmen in apparent civilian clothing brandishing weapons in the hospital.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces stormed a Palestinian hospital in the occupied West Bank early Tuesday morning, killing three militants, including a commander in Hamas, according to the Israeli military and Palestinian officials.

headline: Megan Thee Stallion and Nicki Minaj: Who’s Mad at Whom?
abstract: The two rappers ratcheted up hostilities with a pair of blustery, acid-dipped singles, each aiming to hit the other where it hurts.
lead_paragraph: In terms of social media oxygen consumed, not even Taylor Swift’s making it into the Super Bowl could compete with the weekend’s real main event: the very public drawing of battle lines between two titans of contemporary hip-hop.

headline: North Atlantic Right Whale Found Dead Near Martha’s Vineyard
abstract: The whale washed ashore with a rope wrapped around it. About 360 of the critically endangered species remain.
lead_paragraph: A female North Atlantic right whale was found dead on Sunday with a rope wrapped around it off the coast of Martha’s Vineyard, Mass., a rare event that had scientists worrying about the future of the critically endangered species with about 360 remaining animals.

headline: Global Economy Is Heading Toward ‘Soft Landing,’ I.M.F. Says
abstract: The International Monetary Fund upgraded its growth forecasts and offered a more optimistic outlook for the world economy.
lead_paragraph: The global economy has been battered by a pandemic, record levels of inflation, protracted wars and skyrocketing interest rates over the past four years, raising fears of a painful worldwide downturn. But fresh forecasts published on Tuesday suggest that the world has managed to defy the odds, averting the threat of a so-called hard landing.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Oscar Nominations, Football, Primaries
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Tax Break Scandal Leads to $5 Million Fine for N.J. Energy Company
abstract: The penalty allows Holtec International to avoid criminal charges after an investigation into tax breaks linked closely to George Norcross III, a powerful Democrat.
lead_paragraph: A business tied to George Norcross III, a high-profile New Jersey Democrat, has agreed to pay a $5 million penalty after a criminal investigation into hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks that the energy company, Holtec International, was awarded.

headline: Technology Companies Are Cutting Jobs and Wall Street Likes It
abstract: The sector is laying off workers after a hiring boom during the pandemic and their share prices are soaring.
lead_paragraph: Tech giants are set to report quarterly earnings, starting on Tuesday with Alphabet and Microsoft. Wall Street is expecting good news, including more progress on artificial intelligence.

headline: Saudi Aramco Abruptly Drops Plans to Expand Oil Production
abstract: The pullback, at the behest of the Saudi government and made with little comment, probably reflects a more subdued outlook for demand of Saudi Arabia’s oil.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Aramco said Tuesday that it would call off plans to expand its oil output, a remarkable turnaround by one of the world’s leading petroleum producers.

headline: Ukraine’s Latest Challenge: Festering Tension Among Top Leaders
abstract: Rampant speculation that President Volodymyr Zelensky will fire his top military commander has consumed Ukraine’s capital at a precarious moment in the war.
lead_paragraph: As Ukraine fights against a fierce Russian offensive and its leaders wait to see whether their Western allies will approve more than $100 billion in much-needed assistance, the government in Kyiv is dealing with a festering distraction: tumult in its top ranks centered on the fate of the top military commander.

headline: French Government Vows Rapid Aid for Farmers but Blockades Persist
abstract: Protesters blocking roads in and out of Paris, who say farms are squeezed by low prices and excessive regulation, seemed unmoved by promises from Prime Minister Gabriel Attal.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Gabriel Attal promised more aid for French agriculture on Tuesday and vowed to shield it from “unfair competition” in an attempt to appease protesting farmers, but many appeared unmoved by his efforts as they blocked major roads around Paris for a second day.

headline: Minute-Long Soap Operas Are Here. Is America Ready?
abstract: Popularized in China during the pandemic, ReelShort and other apps are hoping to bring minute-by-minute melodramas to the United States.
lead_paragraph: When Albee Zhang received an offer to produce cheesy short-form features made for phones last spring, she was skeptical, and so, she declined.

headline: Love Letters to California
abstract: Readers share what they love about their part of the state.
lead_paragraph: On a recent short drive from my home in San Francisco, I ended up in Petaluma, where I had as close to a perfect day as possible.

headline: New York Asks Realty Company to Investigate Sexual Assault Allegations
abstract: The state comptroller wants eXp Realty to look into allegations that female real estate agents were drugged and assaulted during company events.
lead_paragraph: The New York state comptroller has asked the real estate brokerage eXp Realty to open an independent investigation into sexual harassment and assault allegations exposed in a New York Times article last month.

headline: Arms Dealer Linked to Myanmar Junta Acquitted in Thai Money Laundering Case
abstract: U Tun Min Latt was placed under sanctions last year by the United States for supplying drones and aircraft parts to the military regime in Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: A wealthy Myanmar arms broker with close ties to the leader of Myanmar’s brutal military regime was acquitted on Tuesday by a Bangkok court on charges of drug trafficking and money laundering, raising fears that he will be free to resume his activities aiding the junta.

headline: Taylor Swift, Travis Kelce and a MAGA Meltdown
abstract: The fulminations surrounding the world’s biggest pop icon — and girlfriend of Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce — reached the stratosphere after Kansas City made it to the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: For football fans eager to see a new team in the Super Bowl, the conference championship games on Sunday that sent the Kansas City Chiefs and San Francisco 49ers back to the main event of American sports culture were sorely disappointing.

headline: ‘Passport’ Review: A Master of Comedy in a Migrant Camp
abstract: The new show by Alexis Michalik, a star of commercial theater, wades into political battles in France, where immigration restrictions have been at the forefront of the government’s agenda.
lead_paragraph: Badly injured from a fight, a man wakes up in the Calais Jungle, a ramshackle camp for migrants in northern France. His memory is gone, and all he has on him is an Eritrean passport with the name “Issa.”

headline: A Monkey Is on the Run in the Scottish Highlands
abstract: “You would think we were chasing an international fugitive,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: Was it a longing for freedom, for friends or for snacks that pushed the monkey to make his daring getaway?

headline: Britain’s Foreign Secretary Signals Willingness to Recognize Palestinian State Sooner
abstract: David Cameron, the foreign secretary, said that his country and other allies should show Palestinians “irreversible progress” toward an independent state.
lead_paragraph: David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary, has signaled that Britain is willing to move up conversations about formally recognizing a Palestinian state, saying that his country and other allies should show Palestinians “irreversible progress” toward that long-sought goal.

headline: Apocalyptic Scenes as Workers Sift Through Rubble in Turkey
abstract: When I arrived in southern Turkey on Tuesday, residents had joined the search for bodies as rescue workers continued to sift through endless mountains of debris.
lead_paragraph: This was featured on the home screen.

headline: Monkey Eats From Bird Feeder After Escaping Scottish Wildlife Park
abstract: A Japanese macaque was spotted in a man’s backyard after it escaped from Highland Wildlife Park in Scotland.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese macaque was spotted in a man’s backyard after it escaped from Highland Wildlife Park in Scotland.

headline: Attacking, and Defending, D.E.I. in America
abstract: Responses to a front-page article and a guest essay about diversity, equity and inclusion. Also: The death penalty; saving rivers; Donald Trump and celebrity.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Syphilis Is Soaring in the U.S.
abstract: Cases have risen by 80 percent since 2018, the C.D.C. reported. But chlamydia remains far more common.
lead_paragraph: Syphilis, once nearly eliminated in the United States, continues to resurge, reaching the highest rate of new infections recorded since 1950, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Tuesday.

headline: Breakfast for Dinner!
abstract: Green shakshuka, sweet potato hash, miso-butter mushrooms with silky eggs: Welcome to Five Weeknight Breakfasts.
lead_paragraph: Egg lovers, rejoice: This week we’re talking breakfast for dinner, a beloved genre of cooking and a subject that several of you requested when I asked if you were interested last week. (Sample reader email in my inbox: “Brunch, brinner!! All breakfast edition YES!”)

headline: Haley Says U.S. Should ‘Go After’ Iranian Military Over Deadly Drone Strike
abstract: “This is surgical,” she said after a drone strike by an Iranian-backed militia killed three American service members. “You take one or two of them out.”
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley suggested on Tuesday morning that the United States should “go after” Iranian military leaders in response to the drone attack by an Iran-backed militia that killed three American service members.

headline: At 80, the Modest Queen of Contemporary Music Keeps Exploring
abstract: The pianist Ursula Oppens will celebrate her birthday at Merkin Concert Hall with a program drawn from the large catalog of works written for her.
lead_paragraph: On a cold afternoon in early January, the pianist Ursula Oppens was making an album at Brooklyn College.

headline: Jury Finds Sotheby’s Did Not Help in Any Fraud of Russian Oligarch
abstract: Dmitry Rybolovlev had accused the auction house of aiding a Swiss art dealer who he says cheated him out of tens of millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: A jury in a civil trial in New York decided in favor of Sotheby’s on Tuesday, rejecting a Russian oligarch’s claim that the auction house had helped a Swiss dealer who he said defrauded him out of tens of millions of dollars in high-end art sales.

headline: How Does Alcohol Affect the Gut Microbiome?
abstract: Scientists are just beginning to explore the relationship between drinking and the good and bad bacteria in your gut.
lead_paragraph: A frothy beer or a glass of wine can enhance a meal and settle the mind. But what does alcohol do to the trillions of microbes living in your gut?

headline: Jaap van Zweden, New York Phil Maestro, Takes Podium in Seoul
abstract: The conductor officially began his tenure as the Seoul Philharmonic Orchestra’s new music director, months before he is to step down in New York.
lead_paragraph: In New York, Jaap van Zweden, the New York Philharmonic’s music director, is preparing to say goodbye: Farewell concerts under the banner “Celebrate Jaap!” are planned over the next few months before his brief, pandemic-interrupted tenure ends this summer.

headline: Hope Wanes Amid the Wreckage Where 600 Apartments Once Stood
abstract: No building remains intact at 600 Konut, an apartment complex in Antakya, Turkey, near the epicenter of the earthquake. Many residents were killed in the collapse.
lead_paragraph: This was featured on the home screen.

headline: UPS to Cut 12,000 Jobs as Wages Rise and Package Volumes Fall
abstract: After what the company called a “difficult and disappointing” 2023, UPS said the cuts would save $1 billion this year.
lead_paragraph: United Parcel Service plans to cut about 12,000 jobs this year as the company tries to slash costs in the face of falling package volumes and higher wages linked to a union contract it signed in the summer.

headline: How the Border Crisis Shattered Biden’s Immigration Hopes
abstract: An examination of President Biden’s record reveals how he failed to overcome a surge in new arrivals and political obstacles in both parties.
lead_paragraph: On President Biden’s first day in office, he paused nearly all deportations. He vowed to end the harsh practices of the Trump administration, show compassion toward those wishing to come to the United States and secure the southern border.

headline: Video Shows Gunmen Storming West Bank Hospital
abstract: The Palestinian Authority Health Ministry released surveillance video that shows several armed Israeli forces dressed in civilian clothes inside Ibn Sina Specialized Hospital in Jenin.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian Authority Health Ministry released surveillance video that shows several armed Israeli forces dressed in civilian clothes inside Ibn Sina Specialized Hospital in Jenin.

headline: Khaled Nezzar, General at Center of Algeria’s Bloodshed, Dies at 86
abstract: In the 1990s, he oversaw troops that committed a host of atrocities against equally brutal Islamist rebels in what became known as the Black Decade.
lead_paragraph: Khaled Nezzar, a wily, outspoken Algerian general and former defense minister who played a central role in the bloodshed that marked his troubled country’s passage out of the 20th century, died on Dec. 29 in Algiers. He was 86.

headline: Is It Safe to Travel to the Bahamas? Here’s What You Need to Know.
abstract: A string of gang-related murders in the local community prompted the U.S. embassy in the island nation to issue a security alert.
lead_paragraph: Drawn by clear turquoise waters and miles of white-sand beaches, around seven million travelers visit the Bahamas each year, but a new warning about increased violence on the island nation has raised alarm over the safety of visiting there.

headline: Video Shows Gunmen Storming West Bank Hospital
abstract: The Palestinian Authority Health Ministry released surveillance video that shows armed members of Israeli forces dressed in civilian clothes inside Ibn Sina Specialized Hospital in Jenin.
lead_paragraph: The Palestinian Authority Health Ministry released surveillance video that shows armed members of Israeli forces dressed in civilian clothes inside Ibn Sina Specialized Hospital in Jenin.

headline: Study Tracking Women’s Music Credits Has a Surprise: Good News
abstract: The Annenberg Inclusion Initiative’s latest report finds that women’s involvement in the biggest hits of 2023 was greatly improved over previous years.
lead_paragraph: Each year since 2018, the University of Southern California’s Annenberg Inclusion Initiative has tracked the number of women credited on the music industry’s biggest hits, and the numbers have usually been dismal — year after year, female artists, songwriters and producers have been crowded out by men, sometimes by extraordinary margins.

headline: Lizards, Monkeys and Bears, Oh My! Try the Animal Movement Workout.
abstract: Crawling around like a crab or gorilla has become a bona fide exercise fad. It looks a little silly, but it’s also a serious workout.
lead_paragraph: Lately, my workouts have looked a bit odd: I’ve been slithering like a lizard, crawling like a bear and scuttling like a crab. It’s called quadrupedal movement training (or animal movement), and it’s taken over TikTok (the related hashtag, #primalmovement, has 2.4 billion views).

headline: Boeing Faces Tricky Balance Between Safety and Financial Performance
abstract: The company is under pressure to show regulators and customers that it takes safety seriously and to reassure investors about its financial outlook.
lead_paragraph: Less than four weeks after a hole blew open on a Boeing 737 Max 9 jet during a flight, company executives face a thorny question: Should they emphasize safety or financial performance?

headline: Trump Stays on Ballot in Illinois, State Board Rules
abstract: The state elections board said that it did not have the authority to decide whether Donald Trump had engaged in insurrection.
lead_paragraph: The Illinois State Board of Elections rejected a complaint on Tuesday that accused former President Donald J. Trump of insurrection by trying to remain in office after losing the 2020 election, and that sought to disqualify him from the state’s primary ballot.

headline: Josephine Baker, Still Moving
abstract: She entertained Europe between the wars and still inspires artists and activists now, as a new exhibition in Berlin shows.
lead_paragraph: There was no shortage of epithets for Josephine Baker, the St. Louis-born polymath who took Paris by storm when she arrived there in 1925, aged 19, to headline “La Revue Nègre,” a show of all-Black performers at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées.

headline: Citi Is Sued by New York State Over Account Transfer Fraud
abstract: New York’s attorney general said the bank failed to protect its customers from hackers who, in some cases, stole their life savings and college funds.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s attorney general sued Citi on Tuesday, accusing it of failing to stop scammers from stealing an unspecified amount of money from customer accounts, and saying the bank should reimburse fraud victims for any losses.

headline: Justice Department Investigating Cori Bush’s Handling of Campaign Funds
abstract: Investigators have raised questions about the Missouri Democrat’s hiring of her husband to provide her with security. A congressional ethics inquiry dismissed charges that the arrangement was inappropriate.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is conducting an investigation into whether Representative Cori Bush mishandled campaign funds, including when she hired her romantic partner — who is now her husband — to provide her with security services.

headline: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
abstract: Economic exploitation, climate change, entrenched corruption: These acclaimed films find fascination in catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

headline: War in Ukraine Has Weakened Putin, C.I.A. Director Writes
abstract: William J. Burns says Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has created recruiting opportunities for the spy agency and ushered in a new era.
lead_paragraph: The war in Ukraine has “quietly corroded” the power of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, the C.I.A. director, William J. Burns, wrote in an essay published on Tuesday.

headline: The Secret of Thomas Mann’s Translator
abstract: A new novel about Thomas Mann’s longstanding American translator portrays a woman ahead of her time and, despite her shortcomings, important to leading Mann to a Nobel Prize.
lead_paragraph: Before she could sign on to translate the entirety of Thomas Mann, the giant of German letters, into English, Helen Tracy Lowe-Porter had to translate herself.

headline: Patagonia’s Profits Are Funding Conservation — and Politics
abstract: $71 million of the clothing company’s earnings have been used since September 2022 to fund wildlife restoration, dam removal and Democratic groups.
lead_paragraph: A little more than $3 million to block a proposed mine in Alaska. Another $3 million to conserve land in Chile and Argentina. And $1 million to help elect Democrats around the country, including $200,000 to a super PAC this month.

headline: A Lead Scare Strikes Stanley Tumblers, but You Don’t Need to Worry
abstract: There is some lead in the sealing material used in the cup, the company says. But experts say it’s inaccessible to people drinking from one, and caution that at-home lead tests are unreliable.
lead_paragraph: You might have heard of the Stanley tumbler, the hip, trendy water bottle that has people camping outside stores or getting into fights to get their hands on one.

headline: Trump Is Turning Court Appearances Into Campaign Stops
abstract: The New York Times’ Jonathan Swan analyzes Donald J. Trump’s campaign strategy in the court room.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’ Jonathan Swan analyzes Donald J. Trump’s campaign strategy in the court room.

headline: ‘A Long Time Coming’: Northern Ireland Deal Receives Broad Welcome
abstract: An agreement by the Democratic Unionist Party to return to power-sharing with Sinn Fein after a two year boycott was greeted by widespread relief.
lead_paragraph: Britain, Ireland and the United States on Tuesday welcomed a deal to end almost two years of political deadlock in Northern Ireland that will, for the first time, hand the territory’s top leadership role to Sinn Fein, a party that mainly represents Roman Catholic voters committed to a united Ireland.

headline: Zuma’s Enduring Appeal Threatens His Old Allies’ Hold on South Africa
abstract: Six years after he was forced from office, former President Jacob Zuma, who still has a loyal following, is campaigning for opponents of the party he once led, the African National Congress.
lead_paragraph: When the African National Congress suspended former President Jacob Zuma this week, a top party official portrayed him as a traitor to the ongoing struggle for Black prosperity in South Africa and a symbol of corruption that the organization is looking to move past.

headline: Was 1968 the Grammys’ Best Year Ever?
abstract: Before the 2024 awards on Sunday, revisit a ceremony where the Recording Academy got it right, honoring the Beatles, Bobbie Gentry, Aretha Franklin and more.
lead_paragraph: The 66th annual Grammy Awards take place on Sunday, and this year’s lineup of performers is pretty exceptional. I mean, Joni Mitchell is performing! For the first time ever at the Grammys! I could really just stop there, but Billy Joel, Billie Eilish, SZA, U2, Olivia Rodrigo, Burna Boy, Luke Combs, Dua Lipa, Travis Scott and more are scheduled to grace the stage. Will Joel and Eilish take this opportunity to start a supergroup called the Billies? Will SZA and U2 start an all-caps collaborative side project called SUZA2? Will Travis Scott meet Joni Mitchell, and if so, what will they talk about? The possibilities of this year’s ceremony are endless, and a little weird.

headline: A Mind-Bending 7-Hour Epic About Hitler Gets a Rare Screening
abstract: Hans-Jürgen Syberberg’s surreal film collage was a cause celebre when it reached the United States in 1980. It’s a fascinating contrast with current Holocaust dramas.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, the hottest ticket in New York is a seven-hour-plus movie about Adolf Hitler.

headline: Here’s How the Next Two Atmospheric Rivers Will Affect California
abstract: A storm hitting California through Thursday will set the stage for another week of unsettled weather across the state.
lead_paragraph: Forecasters have warned California residents that unsettled weather through Thursday is likely to bring heavy rains, strong winds and mountain snow as another atmospheric river moves down along the West Coast. Another storm will threaten the region early next week.

headline: Trump’s PACs Spent Roughly $50 Million on Legal Expenses in 2023
abstract: The former president is facing four criminal indictments and potential trials that could drive his legal bills even higher as he seeks to lock up the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump piled up legal expenses in 2023 as he was indicted four times, spending approximately $50 million in donor money on legal bills and investigation-related expenses last year, according to two people briefed on the figure.

headline: Virginia Moves to End Legacy Admissions at Its Public Universities
abstract: The state legislature overwhelmingly passed a bill that ends preferences for children of alumni. The governor appears poised to sign it.
lead_paragraph: Virginia is on track to ban legacy preferences at its public universities, which give a boost to children of alumni who apply for admission.

headline: Israeli Military Confirms It Has Begun Flooding Hamas Tunnels
abstract: It is the first time the military has publicly acknowledged using the tactic, which the U.N. has warned could damage Gaza’s drinking water.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said Tuesday that it had begun pumping water into the vast network of tunnels beneath Gaza, which Hamas has used to launch attacks, store weapons and imprison Israeli hostages.

headline: Law Enforcement Braces for Flood of Child Sex Abuse Images Generated by A.I.
abstract: Artificial intelligence technology has drastically simplified the creation of images of children being exploited or abused, whether real or fake.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials are bracing for an explosion of material generated by artificial intelligence that realistically depicts children being sexually exploited, deepening the challenge of identifying victims and combating such abuse.

headline: Chita Rivera, Electrifying Star of Broadway and Beyond, Is Dead at 91
abstract: Appearing in scores of stage productions, she dazzled audiences for nearly six decades, most memorably starring as Anita in “West Side Story” and Velma Kelly in “Chicago.”
lead_paragraph: Chita Rivera, the fire-and-ice dancer, singer and actress who leapt to stardom in the original Broadway production of “West Side Story” and dazzled audiences for nearly seven decades as a Puerto Rican lodestar of the American musical theater, died on Tuesday in New York. She was 91.

headline: Abolish the U.N.’s Palestinian Refugee Agency
abstract: UNRWA’s problem goes much deeper than charges that it is infested with terrorists.
lead_paragraph: United Nations agencies and officials are no strangers to scandal and infamy.

headline: German Authorities Seize $2 Billion Worth of Bitcoin
abstract: The police described the transfer of funds as the “most extensive seizure of Bitcoins by law enforcement in the Federal Republic of Germany.”
lead_paragraph: A German programmer who is accused of running an illegal movie streaming site more than a decade ago transferred $2.17 billion worth of Bitcoin to the authorities to repay at least some of the money he had made illegally, the police said on Tuesday. The transfer required the man to use his unique Bitcoin credentials to hand over the funds.

headline: Colleges Won’t Get FAFSA Data Until March, Delaying Aid Offers
abstract: The wait will make it difficult for many schools to finalize financial aid packages, despite already offering admissions to high school seniors.
lead_paragraph: It may be another few months before millions of students and families know how much they’ll have to pay for college this fall.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘He’s a Minimalist; I’m a Hoarder’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: For our 12th anniversary, I gave my boyfriend an empty box, his most-wanted anti-gift. He’s a minimalist; I’m a hoarder. That difference has been the source of our most epic and ongoing arguments. Whenever I ask what I should buy him, he tells me to clear out my belongings from his closet. This January, I finally did. Rather than painstakingly analyzing each photo, tangled piece of jewelry or DVD in my box marked “mementos,” I set a timer for 30 minutes and discarded ruthlessly. It was difficult, but his grin was worth it. — Rachel Kramer Bussel

headline: Using A.I., Hollywood Agency and Tech Start-Up Aim to Protect Artists
abstract: WME said the partnership would help its clients get fake images of themselves removed or receive compensation for use of their likenesses.
lead_paragraph: The talent agency WME announced a partnership with the technology firm Vermillio on Tuesday that it hopes will protect its clients from having their likenesses misused through artificial intelligence technology.

headline: What’s the Matter With Europe?
abstract: Long term, not much. But policy is too tight now.
lead_paragraph: In my most recent column I had a bit of fun with Kristi Noem, the governor of South Dakota, who has ominously warned that President Biden will turn us into Europe. I joked that this would mean adding five or six years to our life expectancy. When I shared Noem’s remarks on social media, some of my correspondents asked whether this meant that we’re about to get good train service and better food.

headline: Chita Rivera, Finding Her Voice
abstract: Her dancing sometimes overshadowed her thrillingly dramatic way with a song: husky yet clarion, unaffected but full of comment and character.
lead_paragraph: Yes, the legs. Yes, the line. Yes, the look.

headline: An Explorer Believes He Found Amelia Earhart’s Plane. Experts Aren’t Convinced.
abstract: A robotics company captured a sonar image that its chief executive believes shows Earhart’s long-lost plane at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean. Archaeologists say it’s too early to know.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the greatest enduring mysteries in aviation history: the disappearance of Amelia Earhart after she took off from Lae, New Guinea, in a Lockheed 10-E Electra on July 2, 1937.

headline: N.C.A.A. Inquiry Takes On Growing Role of Booster Groups
abstract: The University of Tennessee’s football program is under investigation for recruiting violations involving a donor collective, signaling an effort to rein in the role of outside money in college sports.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. is investigating the University of Tennessee’s football program for recruiting violations involving a group of outside donors, signaling an escalation of efforts to rein in the growing influence of money flooding into college sports, according to documents and people familiar with the case.

headline: On Nantucket, a Legal Maneuver to Protect Historic Homes From Gutting
abstract: A steady erosion of history has been underway on the island for years, with ultrawealthy newcomers remaking the interiors of antique structures.
lead_paragraph: On an island where the average home sale topped $4 million last year, Ginger Andrews’s scallop shanty is a golden ticket.

headline: The Patty Melt Is Tired of Hearing About Your Favorite Burger
abstract: The undersung cousin of an American classic is a superior sandwich, our critic argues.
lead_paragraph: We patty-melt people will always be outnumbered by the hamburger people, and we know it.

headline: Oregon Leaders Declare Drug Emergency in Portland
abstract: Oregon’s governor, Tina Kotek, hopes to counter homelessness, crime and widespread public use of fentanyl that she says threatens the state’s largest city.
lead_paragraph: Oregon leaders on Tuesday declared a 90-day state of emergency in central Portland as part of a broad effort to tackle the effects of fentanyl on the streets of the state’s largest city.

headline: The Ballet Roots of a Broadway Star
abstract: Chita Rivera saw herself as a dancer, and that’s fitting: Her early ballet training was her secret weapon — and it never left her body.
lead_paragraph: Chita Rivera grew up to be a Broadway queen, but you can’t leave out that she was a ballet kid. Her training began after a botched jump at her family home in Washington, D.C. Rivera — still Dolores Conchita Figueroa del Rivero at the time — landed on the coffee table. It shattered.

headline: Tiny Political Party Shuns Amnesty Measure, in Setback for Spanish Leader
abstract: A hard-line Catalan separatist party argued that the legislative shield against prosecution for alleged crimes linked to a failed bid for independence is weak and has to be broader.
lead_paragraph: The fragile coalition of Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain revealed deep and potentially paralyzing cracks on Tuesday when a tiny, hard-line Catalan separatist party he has allied with rejected a critical amnesty measure as unsatisfactory.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Imran Khan Gets 10 Years
abstract: Also, a possible Israel-Hamas deal and a security proposal in Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: Imran Khan, Pakistan’s former prime minister, was sentenced to 10 years in prison yesterday. The verdict is widely seen as part of a military campaign to sideline him and his party, and comes about a week before the country’s first national election since Khan was ousted in April 2022.

headline: Red Sorghum Brings Vintage Chinese Glamour to Long Island City
abstract: Third Kingdom focuses on mushrooms in the East Village, Quique Crudo brings Cosme Aguilar’s small plates to the West Village and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: The 1930s romanticized movie-set look of China, with fringed hanging lanterns, vermilion accents, wicker and greenery, has come to Long Island City. The elaborate new restaurant from Vincent Lin and his business partner, Mandy Zhang, who also own Blue Willow in Midtown Manhattan and Ye’s Apothecary in Chinatown, and their executive chef, Bruce Li, showcase Sichuan and Hunan cooking here. The menu is peppered with Sichuan wontons, Xiang Xi fried rice, Chairman’s braised pork, Chongqing braised beef, peppercorn fish stew and a number of Mala dry pot dishes starring ingredients like pork belly, tripe, Spam, potatoes and mushrooms. Traditional Chinese American standbys like kung pao chicken and lo mein are also served. The drinks list is heavy on the baiju, a spirit made from sorghum and often raised in glasses for celebrations; the list of cocktails mixed with the spirit is extensive, devised by Robert Burns, the mixologist for the partners’ three restaurants. The owners selected a Long Island City location for the diversity of the neighborhood.

headline: Microsoft Reports 33% Rise in Profit
abstract: Revenue was up 18% in the latest quarter, the tech giant said, as investors look for signs that it’s beginning to profit from artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Microsoft topped Apple as the most valuable public company. Last week, it surpassed $3 trillion in market valuation. Next week, Satya Nadella will hit his 10th anniversary as the company’s chief executive.

headline: States Where the Death Penalty Has Stalled Look to Alabama
abstract: A bill in Ohio, which hasn’t executed anyone since 2018, would allow the state to adopt a method first used in Alabama last week.
lead_paragraph: Days after Alabama became the first state to put an inmate to death using nitrogen gas, officials elsewhere have started considering the new method of execution.

headline: When We Do, and Don’t, Need a New Phrase to Describe Reality
abstract: We get by fine with one word for “blue.”
lead_paragraph: In my last newsletter, I argued that it is unsuitably awkward for the word “plagiarism” to be applied both to the stealing of others’ ideas and the copying, perhaps accidentally, of boilerplate text without citing its source. To the extent that most would consider the former an egregious transgression and the latter more of a lazy misstep, English would benefit from using a different term for it.

headline: Alphabet’s Search Revenue Disappoints in Fourth Quarter
abstract: Google’s parent company reported that sales climbed 13 percent to $86.3 billion while profit jumped 52 percent.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Google’s parent company, on Tuesday reported search revenue and a profit margin for its latest quarter that fell short of Wall Street’s expectations, in a sign that growth in its flagship business and recent layoffs, intended to cut costs, were not enough to offset its growing investment in artificial intelligence.

headline: French Lawmakers Vote to Enshrine Abortion Rights in Constitution
abstract: Most of France’s political parties broadly support the right to abortion. But the proposal still has to undergo a long and complex legislative process before it comes to fruition.
lead_paragraph: French lawmakers on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a bill to enshrine abortion rights in France’s Constitution, the first step in a complex legislative process that began in direct response to the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: A Tote Bag for $120?
abstract: Emily Mariko, best known for her viral salmon bowl, draws criticism for peddling a pricey canvas bag.
lead_paragraph: Picture a tote bag. A really big tote bag, cut extra wide to fit your entire farmer’s market haul, with wide straps to evenly distribute weight while you lug your satsuma mandarins and eggs and the kale you’ll forget about and leave to rot in the bottom drawer of your refrigerator. It’s 100 percent cotton, made in the United States and comes in a ballet pink or a lovely faded olive color.

headline: Elon Musk’s Tesla Pay Package Is Voided by Judge
abstract: Shareholders had sued, arguing that Mr. Musk’s compensation — which helped make him the world’s richest person — was excessive.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, suffered a stunning rebuke Tuesday when a Delaware judge voided the pay package that helped make him a billionaire many times over and the world’s wealthiest human being.

headline: Chita Rivera: A Life in Photos
abstract: A performer who never retired is remembered for her electric Broadway performances and daring cabaret work.
lead_paragraph: The dancer Chita Rivera, who “dazzled audiences for nearly seven decades as a Puerto Rican lodestar of the American musical theater,” has died at 91. Her influence can be seen in many Broadway productions over the years, including “West Side Story” (1957), “Bye Bye Birdie” (1960), “Chicago” (1975) and “Kiss of the Spider Woman” (1993).

headline: Prosecutor on Trump Georgia Case Avoids Testifying in Divorce Proceeding
abstract: The prosecutor, Nathan Wade, might have been forced to address allegations of a romantic relationship with his boss, Fani T. Willis, at a divorce hearing this week.
lead_paragraph: The special prosecutor leading the election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump will not have to testify this week about an alleged romantic relationship with his boss, Fani T. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, after reaching a temporary agreement in his divorce case on Tuesday.

headline: Republicans Push to Impeach Biden’s Homeland Security Chief
abstract: Also, Chita Rivera, the electrifying Broadway star, died at 91. Here's the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-led House panel on homeland security is set to advance articles of impeachment today, seeking to oust Alejandro Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, for his handling of immigration at the southern U.S. border.

headline: Letha Dawson Scanzoni, Pioneer of Evangelical Feminism, Dies at 88
abstract: In books like “All We’re Meant to Be” and “Is the Homosexual My Neighbor?” she used the Bible to challenge beliefs that women were inferior to men and that homosexuality was a sin.
lead_paragraph: Letha Dawson Scanzoni, an evangelical author who argued, gently but persuasively, that the Bible considered women equal to men, inspiring a wave of Christian feminism and, perhaps inevitably, a backlash against it, died on Jan. 9 in Charlotte, N.C. She was 88.

headline: Elmo Asked an Innocuous Question
abstract: Elmo was not expecting it to open a yawning chasm of despair.
lead_paragraph: On Monday the X account for Elmo, the fuzzy red monster from “Sesame Street,” posed a softball question to its 457,000 followers: “Elmo is just checking in! How is everybody doing?”

headline: Israel Raids West Bank Hospital as Clashes Erupt With Hamas in Northern Gaza
abstract: The raid, by a small team wearing medical garb, killed a Hamas commander. It came as Israel confirmed it was trying to flush militants out of tunnels with seawater and had renewed fighting in northern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: One of the Israeli soldiers wore medical scrubs, another a white coat and surgical mask. Their team swept into the West Bank hospital brandishing rifles, took up positions by the waiting-room chairs, then entered a patient’s room and killed a Hamas commander.

headline: Memphis Releases New Footage From Night of Tyre Nichols’s Fatal Beating
abstract: The additional 21 hours of recordings offer a fuller picture of what happened after the traffic stop, but they do not show what led to it.
lead_paragraph: The city of Memphis released on Tuesday hours of audio, surveillance and police body-camera footage that offered a fuller picture of the night police officers fatally beat Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black FedEx worker, during a traffic stop last January.

headline: Brooklyn Jewish Newspaper’s Ex-Top Editor Pleads Guilty to Jan. 6 Charge
abstract: Elliot Resnick, a longtime journalist at The Jewish Press, admitted that he impeded officers’ efforts to keep a mob from storming the U.S. Capitol.
lead_paragraph: A onetime top editor of an Orthodox Jewish newspaper in Brooklyn pleaded guilty on Tuesday to obstructing police officers’ efforts to hold off the mob that stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Biden Says U.S. Response to Deadly Drone Strike in Jordan Has Been Decided
abstract: The president vowed to retaliate after the attack, which killed three American soldiers on Sunday. On Tuesday, he confirmed a decision without providing details.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said on Tuesday that he had decided on a U.S. response to the drone attack on a remote outpost in Jordan on Sunday that killed three American soldiers and injured more than 40 others, leaving unstated what that decision was.

headline: Pieces of Jackie Robinson Statue Are Found Burning in Kansas Park
abstract: The life-size bronze tribute to the legendary baseball player who broke the color barrier was stolen from a different park last week. What was left of it “is beyond repair,” officials said.
lead_paragraph: Parts of a life-size bronze statue that celebrated the legacy of the legendary baseball player and civil rights figure Jackie Robinson were found dismantled and burned early Tuesday after it had been stolen from a Kansas park last week, the authorities said.

headline: Ohio Man Who Threw Molotov Cocktails at a Church Gets 18 Years in Prison
abstract: Aimenn D. Penny, 20, was angry because the Community Church of Chesterland had planned to host two drag shows, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio man who prosecutors said had tried to burn down a church in anger by throwing Molotov cocktails at it last year because it planned to host two drag shows was sentenced on Monday to 18 years in prison, federal authorities said.

headline: This Ancient Fish Gave the Whole Ocean the Stiff Lower Lip
abstract: What paleontologists long believed were long spines on the aptly named Alienacanthus turn out to be an extended lower jaw.
lead_paragraph: Some 375 million years ago, armored fishes ruled a watery world. Known as placoderms, these primitive jawed vertebrates came in all shapes and sizes, from small bottom-dwellers to giant filter-feeders. Some, like the wrecking-ball-shaped Dunkleosteus, were among the ocean’s earliest apex predators.

headline: Parrots Use Their Beaks to Swing Like Monkeys
abstract: A study offers the latest evidence of the problem-solving prowess of the clever birds.
lead_paragraph: Rosy-faced lovebirds are charismatic, petite parrots. They also aren’t afraid to use their heads — literally — to get around an awkward situation.

headline: Major Layoffs at Fair Fight, Voting Rights Group Founded by Stacey Abrams
abstract: The cuts would decimate a high-profile liberal group that was once a fund-raising powerhouse for Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Fair Fight, the liberal voting rights group founded by Stacey Abrams, is laying off most of its staff and scaling back its efforts in response to mounting debts incurred by court battles.

headline: Track the Latest Atmospheric Rivers to Hit California and the Pacific Northwest
abstract: Use these maps to follow the storm’s forecast and impact.
lead_paragraph: Use these maps to follow the storm’s forecast and impact.

headline: What Is Going on at Machu Picchu?
abstract: Protesters blocked access to the Incan site in Peru over a new ticketing system. Tourists have been evacuated, but there could be more unrest. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of tourists were stranded near Machu Picchu, Peru’s most-visited site, over the weekend after demonstrators blocked railway and bus routes to the site and shut down local shops and restaurants in Aguas Calientes, the gateway to Machu Picchu, in the country’s Cuzco region. Some visitors posted videos on social media pleading for help. The police evacuated about 700 tourists on Saturday. Many left without seeing the site.

headline: Frozen U.S. Spending for U.N. in Gaza Is Minimal, State Dept. Says
abstract: Just $300,000 is on hold after Israeli claims that UNRWA employees joined the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks, U.S. officials say.
lead_paragraph: The State Department downplayed the significance on Tuesday of its decision to pause funding for the main U.N. aid agency in Gaza, explaining that it had already provided virtually all the money allocated by Congress for that purpose and that the Biden administration hoped the matter could be resolved quickly.

headline: Adams vs. Adams: New York’s Top Democrats Clash on City’s Path
abstract: Adrienne Adams, the speaker of the City Council, has become one of Mayor Eric Adams’s most powerful critics as he struggles with crises and low approval ratings.
lead_paragraph: As Mayor Eric Adams battles low poll ratings, a federal investigation and potential challengers to his re-election in New York City, a Democratic ally has emerged as an unexpected adversary: Adrienne Adams, the City Council speaker.

headline: Jean Carnahan, 90, First Woman to Represent Missouri in U.S. Senate, Dies
abstract: Ms. Carnahan was appointed to the seat after her husband was posthumously elected to it just weeks after he was killed in a plane crash in 2000.
lead_paragraph: Jean Carnahan, who in 2001 became the first woman to represent Missouri in the U.S. Senate after being appointed to fill her husband’s seat following his posthumous election, died on Tuesday in St. Louis County, Mo. She was 90.

headline: Taking Off
abstract: Nathan Hale makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Corrections: Jan. 31, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about a lack of support for Nikki Haley in her home state of South Carolina misstated when Ms. Haley resigned as governor of South Carolina to serve in Donald J. Trump’s administration. It was seven years ago, not eight.

headline: Why Tourists Have Been Stranded Near Machu Picchu
abstract: Demonstrators protesting a new ticketing system blocked access to Peru’s most-visited site and threw rocks at police officers, who fired tear gas into the crowd.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators protesting a new ticketing system blocked access to Peru’s most-visited site and threw rocks at police officers, who fired tear gas into the crowd.

headline: Corrections: Jan. 30, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about a United Nations investigation of claims that employees participated in the Oct. 7 attack misstated the number of people working for UNRWA. The agency has 13,000 employees in Gaza alone, not across the world.

headline: Melinda Wilson, 77,Who Helped Brian Wilson Through Mental Illness, Dies
abstract: Ms. Wilson’s relationship with her husband, a co-founder of the Beach Boys, was portrayed in the 2014 film “Love & Mercy.”
lead_paragraph: Melinda Wilson, who rescued her future husband, the Beach Boys co-founder Brian Wilson, from psychological ruin when they were dating in the 1980s, died on Tuesday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 77.

headline: Quote of the Day: Monkey Is Living ‘His Best Life’ on the Run in the Scottish Highlands
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 31, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You would think we were chasing an international fugitive instead of an innocent monkey.”

headline: China’s Censorship Dragnet Targets Critics of the Economy
abstract: As Beijing struggles with a slumping stock market and a collapsing real estate sector, commentary and even financial analysis it deems negative are blocked.
lead_paragraph: China’s top intelligence agency issued an ominous warning last month about an emerging threat to the country’s national security: Chinese people who criticize the economy.

headline: The Farmers’ Protests Have Become a Wildfire. He Was the Spark.
abstract: Jérôme Bayle had enough of the hardships of French farming, so he blocked a highway with friends. Hundreds of other farmers have followed suit.
lead_paragraph: Jérôme Bayle had spent seven nights on a major French highway, leading a group of aggrieved farmers in protest, when the prime minister arrived, dressed in his Parisian blue suit and tie, to thank them for “making France proud” and announced he would meet their demands.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Israel raided a West Bank hospital.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers raided the Ibn Sina Specialized Hospital in the northern West Bank city of Jenin, killing a Hamas commander. The raid took place as Israel confirmed that it had begun pumping seawater into the vast Hamas tunnel network beneath Gaza to flush out militants and had renewed fighting in northern Gaza.

headline: Germany Has Finally Woken Up
abstract: Any complacency about the threat of the far right has been shattered.
lead_paragraph: The ground was icy as my partner, my son and I made our way to the center of Berlin two Sundays ago. Still, as we joined about 100,000 others who had gathered there to protest right-wing extremism, it felt cozy — both in a literal and in a metaphorical sense. The mass of human bodies created a microclimate that made it bearable to be outside in the frosty Berlin dark for a couple of hours. And it was also warming to see this many people turn out to defend our democracy.

headline: Word of the Day: auteur
abstract: This word has appeared in 71 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word auteur has appeared in 71 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 2 in “Beyoncé the Auteur Takes Center Stage in ‘Renaissance’” by Salamishah Tillet:

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Breaks Down MAGA’s Super Bowl Conspiracy Theories
abstract: Is the N.F.L. rigged? Is Taylor Swift a psy-op? Kimmel says that “this nonsense is now everywhere your angry grandpa goes.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Your Energy Playlist
abstract: What would you put on a playlist designed to get you moving?
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of this month, the Well section asked Ahmir K. Thompson, also known as Questlove, to curate a playlist for their Six-Day Energy Challenge.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: N.J. Transit Wants a Big Fare Increase. Riders Want Better Service.
abstract: Gov. Philip D. Murphy said that major improvements to the transit system on his watch justified the proposed 15 percent fare hike, but customers disagreed.
lead_paragraph: Unlike many of his fellow New Jerseyans, Ian Whelan seems too polite to broadcast his gripes about the state’s much-maligned commuter railroad. But a new plan to raise train fares by 15 percent set him off.

headline: In His Second Sentencing in Two Days, Imran Khan Gets 14 Years
abstract: The sentences, just over a week before Pakistan’s national election, come as the former prime minister’s party has been battered by a crackdown.
lead_paragraph: Just a day after he was sentenced to a decade in prison, former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan on Wednesday was ordered jailed for 14 years in a separate case, dealing him another heavy blow in his bitter feud with the country’s powerful military.

headline: Thai Court Rules Progressive Party’s Reform Push Violated Constitution
abstract: Critics call the verdict against the popular Move Forward Party, which hoped to scale back a royal defamation law, another blatant attempt to block the people’s will.
lead_paragraph: The most popular political party in Thailand won its following last year, and the ire of the conservative establishment, by campaigning to end military rule and to weaken the draconian law that prohibits criticism of the country’s monarchy.

headline: Students Are Making a ‘Surprising’ Rebound From Pandemic Closures. But Some May Never Catch Up.
abstract: The first detailed nationwide data on schools’ recovery shows that achievement gaps have widened, with the poorest students the furthest behind.
lead_paragraph: The first detailed nationwide data on schools’ recovery shows that achievement gaps have widened, with the poorest students the furthest behind.

headline: No Pain, No Gain? Your Body Would Like a Word.
abstract: Experts say it’s crucial to listen to your body to avoid injury. But what does that really mean, and how can you put it into practice?
lead_paragraph: As a sprint relay track cyclist on the U.S. Olympic Team, Joshua Hartman spends much of his training time lifting weights to build power and speed. In 2023, while trying to deadlift a load near the limit of his ability, he noticed that his form was off, and the weight wasn’t moving as quickly as he wanted.

headline: A Pre-I.P.O. Gift to Company Executives: ‘11th-Hour Options Discounting’
abstract: A new research paper finds that companies price stock options at steep discounts just before going public and take steps to obscure them.
lead_paragraph: Public companies must abide by strict rules when granting stock options to their top executives, including pricing them where the company’s shares are trading on the day they are granted and disclosing them swiftly.

headline: Is High School a Good Time to Train for a Career?
abstract: If a full-time job with a good salary were yours at graduation, would you start preparing for it now?
lead_paragraph: What career or careers interest you? Do you know what path will take you to your dream job? Will it require training, experience, a college degree or perhaps additional degrees, internships and so on?

headline: Can San Francisco Solve Its Drug Crisis? Five Things to Consider.
abstract: A comparison with Portugal’s approach to decriminalization shows why many liberal cities have struggled to match its success.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco is in the middle of a drug crisis. Overdose deaths reached a record high last year, topping 800. Public drug use is widespread in some neighborhoods.

headline: Everybody Is Talking About A.I. What the Heck Is It, Anyway?
abstract: A guide to the best books about artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Much of the current discourse about artificial intelligence sucks. A.I. is one of those subjects that seem to appear out of nowhere, blotting out everything else — like the sun rising over the desert — and a mixture of ludicrous hype and vacuous panic has rushed in to shade the blinding dazzle. A.I. is going to transform every industry, or it’s going to end the world, or both, and you need to know which now. Meanwhile, accurate answers to basic questions — What even is it? How does it work? Where did it come from? Where is it going? — tend to be tucked away in dry technical language that borders on the incomprehensible.

headline: ‘Destination Dupes’ and Other Ways to Save Money in 2024
abstract: Frugal strategies — like traveling where the dollar is strong and sampling unsung destinations — help make the most of your budget.
lead_paragraph: While others focus on New Year’s resolutions, my family and I come up with a dream list of where we want to go. Places we missed the previous year (Thailand and the Cook Islands) often get rolled over, but we always add new places (this year, South Korea) that can — with careful planning — be done affordably.

headline: The Essential Alice Munro
abstract: The only prerequisite for reading the Nobel laureate, a master of short stories, is: having lived. Here’s where to start.
lead_paragraph: Before I’d read Alice Munro — when my knowledge of her amounted to an oafish word cloud (“older woman,” “Canadian,” “short stories”) — I imagined that the experience of reading her books, if I ever bothered to, would be like listening to classical music on fancy headphones in a college library: civilized, subtle, probably sleep-inducing.

headline: Silicon Valley Battles States Over New Online Safety Laws for Children
abstract: Lawsuits filed by NetChoice, which represents companies including TikTok and Meta, have stalled protection efforts in three states.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, Ohio enacted a social media statute that would require Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok and YouTube to get a parent’s consent before permitting children under age 16 to use their platforms.

headline: Unlikely Allies Want to Bar a Brazilian Beef Giant From U.S. Stock Markets
abstract: Environmentalists and American meat producers alike are asking regulators to keep JBS, the world’s biggest meatpacker, off the New York Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: A giant Brazilian meatpacking company is facing persistent opposition to its plans for a listing on the New York Stock Exchange because of concerns about corruption settlements, accusations of Amazon deforestation and its growing market share in the United States.

headline: Don’t Let Your Winter Walk End Up on a Blooper Reel
abstract: How to stroll with confidence in icy weather.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the wintry morning when I stepped out of the carpool van, hit an icy patch and went skidding on my backside toward the doors of my middle school as my classmates looked on. Or the day I stood on my front porch waving goodbye to a friend and watched in terror as she slid all the way down my frozen front steps.

headline: There’s Always Been Trouble in ‘The Groves of Academe’
abstract: How a 1950s novel explains the crisis in higher education.
lead_paragraph: American higher education is in crisis. What else is new?

headline: We Were Wrong About What Happened to America in 2020
abstract: The answer, only now coming into view, explains why that awful year still has us in its grip.
lead_paragraph: Covid numbers recently climbed again. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention once again reported monthly death tolls in the thousands. Mask mandates are back in New York City’s public medical facilities and nursing homes. The presidential race has kicked into gear and, just as in 2020, the stakes seem existential. It all makes me feel like I’m revisiting a past I never actually left.

headline: A Chocolate Fondue to Remember
abstract: This midcentury classic has a way of stirring up the past.
lead_paragraph: The summer after college, I worked briefly as a shoe model. By briefly, I mean that I was fired after one day. I had sublet a basement room somewhere in the hundreds on the West Side of Manhattan, and my belongings, mostly books, remained unpacked, in duct-taped boxes stacked around the bed. I had to crawl over them when I wanted to lie down, which was most of the time. I slept 14, 15 hours at a shot.

headline: The Queer Kids Are All Right. And Now They’re Making Me Better.
abstract: How watching gay coming-of-age stories has helped repair a heart still stuck in the past — and still scarred by a less welcoming world.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a list of every openly queer person I knew when I was 15:

headline: Who Will Have the Biggest Grammy Night?
abstract: Taylor Swift and SZA could make history at the 66th annual awards on Sunday night, where young women dominate the nominations, and revered older artists will take the stage.
lead_paragraph: The 66th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday are poised to be a celebration of a dominant year for women in pop music, with female stars like SZA, Taylor Swift, Olivia Rodrigo and Billie Eilish facing off in the major categories.

headline: Rescuing the Holocaust From Distortion and Cliché
abstract: A new book by the historian Dan Stone seeks to amend — and expand — our understanding of the genocide.
lead_paragraph: “The Holocaust teaches us nothing”: It’s a surprising declaration to encounter in the early pages of “The Holocaust: An Unfinished History,” not least because its author, Dan Stone, also happens to be the director of the Holocaust Research Institute at the University of London. But Stone is doing what a conscientious historian does, countering platitudes with demystification.

headline: When a Cure Comes Too Late
abstract: Future generations will see breakthroughs that cure many kinds of diseases. But where does that leave current patients?
lead_paragraph: Tyler Parish thinks of himself as “the last dinosaur.”

headline: $950,000 Homes in Indiana, Pennsylvania and Washington
abstract: A Tudor Revival house in Indianapolis, a Colonial Revival home in Lancaster and an updated Craftsman bungalow in Walla Walla.
lead_paragraph: This home is in the Meridian-Kessler neighborhood, less than a mile from a number of popular bars and restaurants, including a jazz club, a pub housed in a 1933 building and a barbecue spot with a beer garden. It is also close to Butler University, a private school with around 4,500 undergraduate students.

headline: The World Needs Love. Hallmark Is Cashing in.
abstract: When more people are watching the Hallmark Channel than CNN, you know we’ve reached a new level of interpersonal isolation.
lead_paragraph: In this lull between perhaps the most successful slate of the Hallmark Channel’s Countdown to Christmas films ever and the Jane Austen-drenched debut of Hallmark’s Loveuary 2024, it’s time to admit that Hallmark movies are actually just Hollywood movies — and specifically rom-coms. Straight couples dance, in well-lit venues, to the music of real instruments. Wrenching decisions are suffered through. Misunderstandings abound. Soulful kisses are for denouements. Happy endings feel required by law. Call it vapid if you will, but the culture of the Hallmark universe has been around since the 16th century, when a shrew apparently needed to be tamed.

headline: Why Bedrooms Aren’t Just for Sleeping Anymore
abstract: Maybe you’re working from home more often — or you need a place to retreat from the world. Here’s how to make your bedroom do double (or triple) duty.
lead_paragraph: Making the most of whatever space you have is just good sense — whether you’ve recently bought your dream home or, like many people, are staying put until the housing market calms down.

headline: A New Gig in the Science World
abstract: Jennifer Raab, the former president of Hunter College, is now heading the New York Stem Cell Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll meet the new president and chief executive of a foundation that backs stem cell research. We’ll also get details on a $5 million fine in a New Jersey tax break scandal.

headline: Recruited to Play Sports, and Win a Culture War
abstract: Many New College athletes had no idea they were part of Ron DeSantis’s attack on “woke ideology.” Then the semester began.
lead_paragraph: They came to be somewhere sunny and warm. Some came because their parents lived nearby; others came from far away — from abroad — because it was a way to study in the United States. Madison Garcia, a softball player who previously attended Lincoln University, a historically Black college in Missouri, came because she was lonely and cold in the Midwest. The school recruiting Garcia and the others, New College of Florida, offered all freshmen free laptops, which was a nice perk. But the main reason most of the athletes showed up for the very first season of varsity sports at New College was that someone there was offering them the chance to keep doing what they loved. “I would do anything to be on that field,” said Nahuel Garcia, a freshman soccer player from Miami. “I’ll be water boy. I’ll be ball boy. It’s like, I need soccer in my life.”

headline: Chita Rivera Lived to Entertain. Here Are 9 Memorable Performances.
abstract: A quadruple threat, Rivera could make a lasting impression in minutes, whether onstage or onscreen. These videos illustrate why.
lead_paragraph: Chita Rivera, who died on Tuesday at the age of 91, was known for her extraordinary artistry. Yet, it is hard to comprehend the full scope of her talent because, like so many Broadway performers of her generation, much of her best work was not captured on-screen. Her Anita in the landmark 1957 Broadway production of “West Side Story”? Rita Moreno took it on in the Hollywood adaptation. Rose in the hit “Bye Bye Birdie,” from 1960? That role went to Janet Leigh in the movie. Only in 1969 did Rivera make her feature-film debut, in “Sweet Charity,” almost two decades after her Broadway debut. Thankfully, we have variety shows, TV specials and unofficial fan videos to help us patch together a compelling video portrait. Her life force bursts through in every second.

headline: The Federal Reserve Meets Wednesday. Here’s What to Watch.
abstract: Officials are likely to keep interest rates unchanged at the conclusion of their January meeting. Here’s a look at what might come next.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials will conclude their two-day meeting on Wednesday, and they are widely expected to keep interest rates steady at a two-decade high when they release their policy decision at 2 p.m.

headline: ‘We Are Not Very Far From an Explosion’
abstract: As the war grinds on in Gaza, settler attacks are rising — and Palestinian anger is growing.
lead_paragraph: One recent morning in Huwara, a Palestinian man maneuvered a front-end loader back and forth, clearing rocks and rubble that Israel Defense Forces soldiers had piled into a roadblock. Four young soldiers looked on, fingers tensed on triggers, as the machine’s claws heaved shattered masonry from clutching mud. A crowd of approving Palestinian onlookers gathered.

headline: My Sister’s Murder Isn’t for Your Entertainment
abstract: True crime commodified my sister’s death. Then lawmakers weaponized it.
lead_paragraph: In 1993, Polly Klaas was kidnapped and murdered at the age of 12. Following her death, Polly’s tragic story became a plotline in true crime podcasts, TV shows and books. In this audio essay, Polly’s sister Annie Nichol argues that the popularization of true crime not only re-traumatized victims’ families but also helped create demand for “tough on crime” legislation. “Our legal system actually became more reactionary and more fixated on punishment and fundamentally less just,” she says.

headline: Taylor Swift, Donald Trump and the Right’s Abnormality Problem
abstract: Girl meets boy and falls in love. Conservatives are furious.
lead_paragraph: There was a brief period in the later part of the Covid-19 pandemic, between the moment when Glenn Youngkin swept into the Virginia governorship and the full political return of Donald Trump, when I became convinced that American liberalism was headed for a truly epochal defeat in 2024.

headline: Can Biden Take a Page Out of Trump’s Playbook?
abstract: The prize in the struggle over the border is the 2024 presidency and all the power that goes with it.
lead_paragraph: In a bid to weaken Donald Trump’s domination of the immigration crisis going into the 2024 election, President Biden has reversed his position and adopted a high-risk strategy.

headline: Why So Many People Can’t Get That Galliano Show Out of Their Heads
abstract: In celebrating John Galliano’s “return to his roots,” have we somehow missed the point?
lead_paragraph: There is a certain irony to the fact that of all the shows that took place during couture last week, the one designed to be the most off-line — the one conceived as an in-person experience rather than as a simple catwalk — is the one that ended up going the most viral.

headline: A Beloved ’90s TV Show Finally Comes to Streaming
abstract: Our TV critic on the joy and melancholy of “Northern Exposure.”
lead_paragraph: “Northern Exposure” premiered on CBS in 1990. Over the next six years, it drew millions of viewers, won a raft of Emmys and adorned the cover of multiple issues of TV Guide. But despite its success decades ago, “Northern Exposure” wasn’t widely available on streaming platforms until recently. Our TV critic Margaret Lyons considers how being out of circulation affected the show’s legacy, and the joys of rediscovering this classic series.

headline: Nikki Haley Goes After Trump and Biden in ‘Grumpy Old Men’ Campaign
abstract: Ms. Haley has recently shifted her strategy, casting Donald Trump, 77, and President Biden, 81, as part of the same bygone era of politician.
lead_paragraph: Two curmudgeonly old rivals, reclusive spendthrifts, are marching toward a showdown that a lot of people really wish wasn’t happening. If that is the plot of a slapstick comedy, it’s also the latest knock from Nikki Haley on former President Donald J. Trump and President Biden as she fights for oxygen ahead of the Republican primary in South Carolina on Feb. 24.

headline: An Israeli Charity for Palestinians Grapples With Oct. 7 Attacks
abstract: Before the war, Road to Recovery helped bring sick Gazans to Israeli hospitals. Several of its volunteers died in the Hamas attacks, and donations to the group have slowed.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every week for a decade, Iri Kassel picked up sick Palestinian children at Israel’s Erez border crossing with Gaza and drove them with their guardians to Israeli hospitals for treatment.

headline: They Took Their Horses to the Swiss Alps for Snow Polo. They Got Slush Instead.
abstract: In St. Moritz, a ski resort town that revolves around winter tourism, high temperatures made full matches impossible and raised concerns about the future.
lead_paragraph: The horses were all set. The players were ready. As were the spectators, many of whom had arrived at the idyllic winter wonderland of St. Moritz, Switzerland, with soft fur coats and stylish moon boots. Everything was in place for the Snow Polo World Cup.

headline: A Stunningly Well-Preserved 600-Year-Old Gauntlet Is Found in Switzerland
abstract: The iron glove was found near a castle in Switzerland and saved from the effects of planned demolition. Who exactly wore it remains a mystery.
lead_paragraph: A medieval knight returns to a Swiss castle after a victorious battle. With a hearty whoop he tosses aside his prized gauntlets at the blacksmith shop. As he rushes off to a celebratory feast, they sit out of sight in a dark corner. Not too long after, a fire breaks out, the shop is destroyed and the gauntlets are lost for more than 600 years.

headline: An Impeachment Push, and a Militia’s Surprise Move
abstract: Plus, broadcasting layoffs on TikTok.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Meta Rejected Efforts to Improve Children’s Safety, Documents Show
abstract: Lawmakers released internal emails detailing the company’s failed efforts to add staff to focus on the online safety of minors, hours before a hearing on the topic.
lead_paragraph: Hours before Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, was set to testify on Wednesday about child safety online, lawmakers released internal documents showing how his company had rejected calls to bulk up on resources to combat the problem.

headline: Is the Future of Medicine Hidden in Ancient DNA?
abstract: Genetic fragments from thousands of years ago are providing insights into illnesses such as multiple sclerosis and diabetes.
lead_paragraph: In a major advance in science, DNA from Bronze Age skeletons is providing clues to modern medical mysteries.

headline: San Francisco’s “Pro-Drug Culture”
abstract: The city’s addiction crisis has worsened quickly — and culture is a big factor.
lead_paragraph: For some San Franciscans, a drug crisis is just part of city living. They see people shooting up in front of their homes and businesses. They often find someone dozing on a sidewalk, high. Sometimes, they check for a pulse. “That’s how I found my first dead body,” said Adam Mesnick, owner of a local deli.

headline: Do Panic: Dario Argento’s Cinema
abstract: The Italian horror director is the subject of a new documentary and a film retrospective. But his artistry can be summed up in his feature directing debut, “The Bird With the Crystal Plumage.”
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment in “Dario Argento Panico,” a new documentary about the Italian horror movie maestro Dario Argento, that made me wonder if I’ve misunderstood why his assertively macabre and stylishly grotesque films so deeply give me the willies. It comes late in the film in Argento’s own words — word, actually — as he talks about what makes his scary movies scary.

headline: News Outlet Blames Photoshop for Making Australian Lawmaker’s Photo More Revealing
abstract: 9News apologized for the edited photo of the member of state Parliament, Georgie Purcell, which it said was a result of “automation by Photoshop.”
lead_paragraph: A lawmaker in the Australian state of Victoria sat down to watch the nightly news on Monday, expecting to see herself featured as a prominent opponent of duck hunting.

headline: Good Marriages Are Good. Bad Marriages Are, Well, Bad.
abstract: On luxury beliefs and why marriage isn’t a cure-all.
lead_paragraph: There’s an idea that’s been floating around for a few years that when it comes to marriage, wealthy elites hold luxury beliefs.

headline: What Elon Musk Could Lose After His Big Pay Deal Is Blocked
abstract: A Delaware court ruling on his $50 billion compensation plan at Tesla raises questions about corporate governance and more.
